Due to its scope and nature, sustainable development is a matter which is very
interdisciplinary, and draws from knowledge and inputs from the social sciences
and environmental sciences on the one hand, but also from physical sciences and
arts on the other. As such, there is a perceived need to foster integrative approaches,
whereby the combination of inputs from various ﬁelds may contribute to a better
understanding of what sustainability is, and means to people. But despite the need
for and the relevance of integrative approaches towards sustainable development,
there is a paucity of literature which address matters related to sustainability in an
integrated way.
Notes on the quality assurance and peer review of this publication
Prior to publication, the works published in this book are initially assessed and
reviewed by an in-house editor. If suitable for publication, manuscripts are sent for
further review, which includes a combined effort by the editorial board and appointed
subject experts, who provide independent peer-review. The feedback obtained in this
way was communicated to authors, and with manuscripts checked upon return before
ﬁnally accepted. The peer-reviewed nature of the books in the “World Sustainability
Series” means that contributions to them have, over many years, been ofﬁcially
accepted for tenure and promotion purposes.

Preface
Sustainable development encompasses a range of complex issues including poverty,
inequality, climate change, environmental degradation, peace, and justice. A compre-
hensive research agenda helps in understanding these interconnections and in devel-
oping holistic solutions. This is because research provides the necessary evidence
to inform policy decisions. Reliable data and rigorous analysis help policymakers
create effective, efﬁcient, and equitable sustainability policies that are more likely to
succeed.
The creation of an agenda for sustainable development research involves estab-
lishing a set of priorities and a roadmap that can guide scholarly and practical efforts
towards sustainability goals.
It may encourage collaboration across disciplines to address complex sustain-
ability issues that span social, economic, and environmental domains. It may also
support the development of robust methodologies for conducting research, including
quantitative, qualitative, and mixed methods approaches. But despite the importance
of and the need for an agenda for sustainable development research, many efforts
are isolated and thematically disconnected. Also, it is difﬁcult to ﬁnd information on
how sustainability research is being undertaken, and on the wide range of methods
being used.
Against this backdrop and in order to facilitate a broad discussion on the contribu-
tion of sustainable development research, the book An Agenda for Sustainable Devel-
opment Research has been prepared, gathering inputs from universities and research
organisations working on matters related to sustainable development research in a
variety of contexts. It also provides a platform for the dissemination of informa-
tion on the latest initiatives, paving the way for technology transfer and networking.
Furthermore, the book intends to provide a fertile basis upon which universities,
research centres and practitioners, may cooperate more closely in this key area.
Lastbutnotleast,afurtheraimofthebookistopresentmethodologicalapproaches
and experiences deriving from case studies and projects, which aim to show how
sustainability research may be implemented across a range of disciplines.
v
vi
Preface
This book is structured in two parts.
Part One—Sustainable Development from theory to practice
Part Two—Research and Educational Opportunities
Part One—Sustainable Development from Theory to Practice: this section delves into
the theoretical and practical application of sustainable development principles. Chap-
ters within this part examine various aspects of sustainable development, exploring
concepts such as circular economy, energy sustainability and climate action. Through
case studies and theoretical frameworks, these chapters highlight the importance of
integrating sustainability into decision-making processes and fostering sustainable
practices across different sectors and regions.
Part Two—Research and Educational Opportunities: in this section, chapters
explore the diverse opportunities for research, teaching and outreach in the ﬁeld of
sustainable development. Through collaborative partnerships and interdisciplinary
approaches, this part reinforces the role of research and learning opportunities in
different areas and in all educational levels.
We thank all authors for sharing their knowledge and their experience by means
of their chapters, and those colleagues who have contributed to it by assisting with
the reviews. Thanks to its scope and interdisciplinarity, this book makes an excellent
reading for everyone interested in sustainability research.

Sustainable Development from Theory
to Practice
Empowering Citizens for Energy
Communities in the European Union
Alba Medina-Bousoño and Javier Sierra
Abstract In the face of the pressing global environmental and social challenges,
it’s imperative to chart pathways towards sustainable development. The European
Union faces signiﬁcant environmental challenges, and energy community solutions
have emerged as a promising avenue to address these problems and foster sustainable
energy transition. Acknowledging the need of addressing global concerns locally,
the transition to decentralized energy systems emerges as a critical step forward.
However, ensuring a prosperous and fair energy transition relies not solely on tech-
nological progress but also on fostering participatory decision-making processes.
This study explores the concept of energy communities as mechanisms for promoting
citizenengagementinsustainabilitypolicybyexaminingtheirlegalandpolicyframe-
works, different models, motivations, and barriers to citizen participation. A compre-
hensive review of the existing literature has also identiﬁed the positive impacts of
energy communities. In addition, the crucial factors that enable citizen empower-
ment are explored, including interaction patterns, incentives for participation, and
potential hurdles. The conclusions shed light on the importance of fostering citizen
participation in sustainable energy transitions as models that shape effective policy
actions to enhance energy transitions and promote more sustainable societies.
Keywords Energy · Transition · Citizen · Community · Engagement ·
Participation · Sustainability · Europe
1
Introduction
Amidst today’s urgent global environmental and social crisis, it’s crucial to
explore pathways towards sustainable development. As regards energy transitions,
these strategies should empower individuals and communities, prioritizing sustain-
able energy initiatives. As decentralized production technologies advance, energy
communities have become a topic of increased interest (Otamendi-Irizar et al. 2022).
A. Medina-Bousoño · J. Sierra (B)
University of Salamanca, Salamanca, Spain
e-mail: jsierra@usal.es
© The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024
W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_1
3
4
A. Medina-Bousoño and J. Sierra
Yet, achieving a successful and equitable energy transition hinges not only on tech-
nological advancements but also on inclusive decision-making processes (Abada
et al. 2020). This necessitates a blend of rigorous analysis, expertise in engineering
and spatial planning, and insights from social sciences. Recognizing the necessity to
tackle global issues at the local level, the shift towards decentralized energy systems,
stands as a pivotal step forward for enhancing local strategies for sustainability
(Hoicka et al. 2021).
The goal of energy transitions is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate
climate change. Furthermore, they are designed to end the dependence on imported
fossil fuels that creates a high vulnerability in a country’s energy supply. Transi-
tioning to local energy sources can increase energy autonomy. Energy communities
have emerged as an alternative to centralized energy management structures, and
are perceived as a promising area to enhance economic, social, and environmental
sustainability in the European Union (EU) (2023). The concept is diverse and is
frequently adapted to local contexts and dynamics. Therefore, there seems to be a
gap in the literature as regards how these structures are deﬁned in different settings,
and how these initiatives can contribute to promote more sustainable societies at the
local level.
Energy communities support a more democratic and participatory energy system,
rather than relying solely on large, centrally managed energy networks. The promo-
tion of citizen engagement in energy decision-making can increase public accep-
tance of renewable energy sources, making it possible to foster the incorporation of
renewable sources into the energy system. Finally, research on energy communities
promotes efﬁciency and creativity by investigating new business models, tools for
managing energy, and governance strategies. In short, the transition to local energy
sources has the potential be a strategic, and necessary, way to build a sustainable and
resilient future.
This chapter provides a comprehensive overview of the literature on empowering
citizens for energy communities, speciﬁcally focusing on energy communities in the
EU. The study examines the concept of energy communities in the EU and their role
in fostering citizen participation in sustainable energy initiatives. The results present
a wide variety of different models of interaction, as well as their frequent ineffective-
ness in terms of communicating between different parts of local and national govern-
ments, providing useful information to better understand the problems inherent in
interactions between the different actors in the energy transition.
The chapter is structured as follows. After describing the research background,
the methodology used in the study is presented, followed by an analysis of the results
and, ﬁnally, the primary conclusions.
Empowering Citizens for Energy Communities in the European Union
5
2
Background
Climate change poses a signiﬁcant challenge due to its potential economic, social,
and environmental impact. For that reason, the EU has intensiﬁed efforts in recent
years to accelerate the transition to a low-carbon, sustainable economy, reinforcing
its ﬁrm commitment to climate change mitigation and adaptation. In this context,
the European Green Deal has established the target of reducing emissions by 55%
by 2023 and achieving climate neutrality (European Commission 2019). Consonant
with this, the EU Climate Law commits the Union to implement the 2050 target
within EU legislation, and the Fit for 55 package of proposals orients legislation
towards the 2030 greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reduction targets and the 2050
vision (European Commission 2020).
Global energy consumption continues to be highly dependent on fossil fuels.
Althoughgasconsumption—consideredacleanertransitionalenergy—hasincreased
in recent years, the European economy is overly dependent on Russia for natural gas.
Therefore, the energy crisis, fueled by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, has thrown
commercial energy markets into unprecedented turmoil, with households coming
under increasing pressure from exorbitant primary commodity prices. In response,
the European Union swiftly launched the REPowerEU plan, which implemented
ﬁscal and energy measures in all the EU countries to soften the adverse effects of the
situation on their economies (European Commission 2022).
Recently, there has been a growing recognition that traditional models of repre-
sentative democracy are not sufﬁcient to address the complex and diverse challenges
facing modern societies (Dacombe and Parvin 2021). As a result, new forms of demo-
cratic participation and engagement have emerged to increase citizen involvement in
decision-making processes. The aim of these democratic innovations is to empower
citizens and give them a greater say in the decisions that affect their lives, while
also promoting transparency, accountability, and public trust in government (OECD
2020). The EU supports a bottom-up approach in which citizens have a real role in
democracy and advocates for an energy transition that takes their needs into account.
A sustainable low-carbon future will not be possible without the involvement of the
citizens who produce and consume energy locally. Therefore, citizen engagement in
the process of achieving climate neutrality and energy transition is key. Over the past
few years, there has been a growing interest among researchers and policy makers
in understanding the role of this engagement and participation by citizens in energy
transitions. Particularly in Europe, this increased attention has been reﬂected by the
creation of more than 10,000 initiatives and over 22,000 projects between 2000 and
2020 focusing on energy transition (Schwanitz et al. 2023).
6
A. Medina-Bousoño and J. Sierra
3
Methodology
Following the latest developments in bibliographic research, a systematic literature
review was conducted to provide a precise analysis of the role of citizen participation
and engagement in energy transition (Donthu et al. 2021; Sweileh 2020). The current
study is based on Scopus, an online database that contains over 25,000 journals from
all ﬁelds of study. Scopus is widely used in bibliometric studies because it provides
an accurate and comprehensive overview of the world’s research output in different
ﬁelds including the social sciences.
The search string “TITLE-ABS-KEY (energy AND transition AND citizen AND
(participation OR engagement))” was used to identify articles relevant to the study
published on or before March 27 2023. Since the approach used in this study is based
on the implementation process of citizen-centered projects, the emphasis was placed
on identifying the leading stakeholders, different types of project models, motivation
for developing these initiatives and main obstacles and barriers encountered.
The search string identiﬁed 270 publications, the majority research articles (72%),
followed by book chapters (10%), and conference papers (9%). Although the ﬁrst
article identiﬁed in the search was from 1975, the publications showed a pronounced
annual increase beginning in 2016 (n = 251). 2022 was the year with the most
publications (n = 68), demonstrating the growing recognition of the importance of
this subject (Fig. 1).
Theleadingjournals interms of number of articles writtenintheﬁeldarepresented
in Table 1. Energy Research and Social Science published a total of 28 articles. This
is closely followed by Energies, with 24 articles, and Sustainability, with 18 articles.
These journals are renowned for their focus on research and analysis in the ﬁeld of
Fig. 1 Publications per year. Source Scopus

energy, offering a wide range of knowledge and perspectives for readers interested
in this area.
Several criteria were then used to check the 270 publications and select the key
articles that were reviewed in detail. Of the 270 papers, only 152 were open access.
Giventhatthesigniﬁcanceofthisstudyisbasedontheroleofcitizensasactiveagents,
the decision to focus on open access only was made to ensure that only publications
which are available for anyone to read, were used. Also, all the selected articles were
originally written in English. In addition to this, the selection was then restricted
to published scientiﬁc articles. Furthermore, only works written from countries in
the European Union were chosen, and they had to contain the word “local” in their
title, abstract, or keywords, ensuring that the study focused on the local level in
the European Union. Using these criteria, 37 articles were selected. This process is
reﬂected in Fig. 2.
4
Results
4.1
Types of Actors
Regarding the stakeholders, there are three main actors involved in energy transi-
tion: governmental actors (municipality and/or other levels of government); private
actors; and civil society. In this context, citizen participation can help stimulate
niche innovation and experimentation, challenge the dominant regime, and create
new opportunities for more sustainable energy systems (Boeri et al. 2017). Citizens
are, in this case, the main leading actors in these types of initiatives. Most of the
literature deﬁnes these leading actors as energy citizens, meaning that the public is
conceived as an active stakeholder in energy transition, and are actively involved in
8
A. Medina-Bousoño and J. Sierra
Fig. 2 Process for selection
of publications
participation (Beauchampet and Walsh 2021). However, this activity can take many
forms, from homeowners choosing renewable energy solutions or households using
electric vehicles, to participating in, for instance, climate change demonstrations.
Considering this, different subtypes of citizens have also been identiﬁed in the
literature. The captive consumer is distanced from the sources of renewable energy
generation and consumes green energy passively; the energy producer owns and oper-
ates their own green energy generation technologies (Kloppenburg et al. 2019); the
prosumer consumes energy, produces energy and may provide ﬂexibility (Ryszawska
et al. 2021; Leal Filho et al. 2024); and the citipreneur ﬁlls an in-between position,
possessing the pioneering skills that enable local entrepreneurs to forge technology-
enabled, co-creative strategies to address societal issues and thus generate public
value (Tomor 2019).
In energy transition research, both democratic energy and community energy
have emerged as the central axes from which different forms of citizen initia-
tives develop. Energy communities are groups of people or organizations that work
together to produce, distribute, and consume energy in a more sustainable, equitable
and community-centered way than traditional energy systems. They collaborate in
the creation of initiatives, whether formal or informal, aiming to reduce their depen-
dence on fossil fuels and promoting renewable energy sources (Schmid et al. 2020).
Empowering Citizens for Energy Communities in the European Union
9
Energy democracy, on the other hand, is a broader concept that encompasses not only
energy production and consumption, but also the governance and decision-making
processes that shape energy policies and systems. Energy democracy stresses the
importance of democratic participation, community control and social justice in the
design and management of energy systems. It advocates the decentralization of power
in the energy sector and the empowerment of communities to shape their own energy
futures. In short, energy communities focus on energy production and consumption,
while energy democracy focuses on the broader political and social dimensions of
energy systems. However, the two concepts are closely related and often overlap in
practice (Szulecki 2018).
These two concepts have produced different forms of initiatives. Local renewable
energy cooperatives (LRECs) mobilize the public by serving as a link between the
government and individuals who are not involved in the energy industry. The main
objective is to implement renewable energy while engaging in cooperative energy
use (Wagemans et al. 2019). Energy cooperatives, also known as renewable energy
cooperatives (Wagemans et al. 2019; Schmid et al. 2020; Ahlemeyer et al. 2022),
are recognized and encouraged in several of the EU directives that promote the
transition to a more sustainable and democratic energy system. One such example
being Directive 2019/944 on Common Rules for the Internal Market in Electricity.
Although the two concepts (energy cooperatives and energy communities) overlap
in many respects and are often used interchangeably, there are some differences that
could lead to energy community being more widely used. Speciﬁcally, an energy
cooperative is a legal entity owned and controlled by its members who use it. Its
main objective is to provide energy services to its members, such as renewable energy
production and distribution, demand-side management, and energy efﬁciency, and
is regulated and governed by speciﬁc laws and rules. On the other hand, an energy
community is a group of individuals, organizations or companies that come together
to develop, produce, and consume energy in a joint and sustainable manner (Schmid
et al. 2020). Energy communities can include both cooperatives and other types of
organizations and aim to improve the energy sustainability of a given community or
territory. They can be regulated by speciﬁc laws and standards but can also be more
informal and ﬂexible initiatives. Therefore, the key difference between the two is
that energy cooperatives are legal entities, while energy communities can be more
informal and do not necessarily have a deﬁned legal structure. In addition, while
energy cooperatives focus primarily on providing energy services to their members,
energy communities have a broader focus that includes collaboration with other local
actors and the promotion of broader energy sustainability goals in the community
or territory in which they operate. The combination of the engaged stakeholders and
the form of initiatives is illustrated in Fig. 3.
The lack of a single deﬁnition for the initiatives can easily lead to confusion,
as well as proposals for more concepts (Hartmann and Palm 2023). At the same
time, however, there is no real single deﬁnition for energy communities, as this term
has different meanings and approaches depending on the context and the speciﬁc
objectives of each initiative. In fact, a diversity of deﬁnitions and approaches can be
10
A. Medina-Bousoño and J. Sierra
Fig. 3 Actors and initiatives. Source Authors
beneﬁcial with regard to fostering innovation and creativity in designing sustainable
energy solutions that are adapted to the needs of different communities and contexts.
4.2
Models of Interaction
As with the concepts, a wide variety of types of interaction models between different
actors have been identiﬁed in the literature. The three-levels-model, a framework
used to describe the local energy transition process, provides a structured approach
to analyzing the distribution of power and decision-making in energy transitions.
The local or micro context plays an important role in the regional energy transition
process. Factors such as geography, geology, meteorology, and demographics can
inﬂuence the production and use of renewable energy sources in different ways. The
economic regional (meso) structure can also impact the choice of renewable energy
sources, considering the different approaches required depending on the population
density. Finally, the macro level involves national and supranational policies that
provide a framework for local initiatives. In this context, a successful transition
depends on the ability of the stakeholders to enhance community empowerment
(Drewello 2022).
Thequadruplehelixisaframeworkthatunderlinestheimportanceofcollaboration
and co-creation between four stakeholders: government, industry, academia, and civil
society. According to Nijkamp et al. (2023), innovation and sustainable development
canonlybeachievedthroughtheparticipationofallfourstakeholders,whomustwork
together to identify and solve complex societal problems. However, the quadruple
helix does not reﬂect the difﬁculties of involving citizens in the process. Against
this background, the diabolo model of citizen participation was developed to include
local energy brokers, who act as the nexus between citizens and government bodies
(Nijkamp et al. 2023). The concept of co-production refers to the active involvement
of different actors, including citizens, in the design and delivery of public services.
Co-production is essential to achieve a more participatory and democratic process,
where citizens actively participate in the design and implementation of services. In
the energy sector it can have several beneﬁts, provided there is real collaboration
between the initiatives and the government, requiring careful planning, adequate
Empowering Citizens for Energy Communities in the European Union
11
resources, and a supportive institutional and policy framework (Soares da Silva and
Horlings 2020).
The strategic niche management (SNM) framework helps to explain the develop-
ment and diffusion of new technologies in complex social environments. Its central
idea is that new technologies are developed and nurtured within so-called niche envi-
ronments that provide the necessary conditions for innovation to occur. These niches
are typically small, protected spaces where innovators can experiment with new ideas
and approaches without being constrained by the dominant technological regime or
social norms (Koirala et al. 2018). Local action groups (LAGs) are groupings of
public and private actors, including local authorities, business organizations, NGOs,
and citizens, working together to promote sustainable development in local areas.
LAGs in general have great potential to become drivers of the change needed for
energy transition, if they are fostered by the local framework conditions in which
they operate (Kola-Bezka 2023). Community-based adaptation (CBA) is a bottom-
up approach that places local communities at the center of adaptation planning and
implementation. This model recognizes the important role that communities can play
inadaptingtotheimpactsofclimatechange.Theobjectivehereistoincreasethelong-
term resilience of local communities by enabling them to identify and implement
their own adaptation strategies. CBA involves community mobilization and participa-
tion, vulnerability and risk assessment, identiﬁcation and prioritization of adaptation
options, and the implementation of adaptation measures (Boeri et al. 2017). Finally,
the dialogue, access, risk management and transparency (DART) model is a partici-
patory approach for the development and implementation of sustainable energy plans
in local communities that emphasizes the importance of involving all stakeholders
in the energy transition process. In this model, ‘dialogue’ focuses on creating a plat-
form for open and inclusive discussions between stakeholders to ensure inclusion
with effective communication; ‘access’ increases the positive effects of participation
in their communication; ‘risk management’ underlines the importance of evaluating
the possible beneﬁts and risks of the development of initiatives; and the object of
‘transparency’ is to develop a good legal foundation in order to ensure that all actors
are of equal value, and that no one actor receives favorable treatment (Ryszawska
et al. 2021).
All these models of interaction have several common factors that make them
valid for energy communities. They are all based on collaboration and participation,
involvingeverymemberofthecommunityindecision-makingandprojectimplemen-
tation processes, thus increasing the commitment and motivation of the participants.
In addition, these models help citizens feel more empowered and engaged in the
energy community, which increases the likelihood of the long-term success of the
implemented projects.
As each energy community has its own speciﬁc characteristics and needs, making
a single model unsuitable for all communities, the existence of multiple different
models of stakeholder interaction in energy community development can be bene-
ﬁcial, and for several reasons. First, having access to a variety of models allows
communities to select the strategy that best satisﬁes their requirements and goals.
This can then stimulate innovation and creativity in the way that energy community
12
A. Medina-Bousoño and J. Sierra
development is approached. However, the availability of multiple options can also
have a negative side, potentially resulting in a lack of clarity and confusion about the
roles and responsibilities of each actor, as shown in Table 2. In the end, this may stunt
the growth of the projects. While the array of different models may make it easier to
understand and study socio-technical dynamics, the analysis that they provide is not
complete.
As seen in the table, all the models have advantages and disadvantages. The
three-levels-model helps to understand the barriers and opportunities faced by these
initiatives at different levels, but can be too simplistic, failing to consider the complex
interactions between the different levels and actors and potentially underestimating
the inﬂuence of the context and macroeconomic factors on the implementation of
community energy initiatives (Drewello 2022). While the quadruple helix model
encourages cooperation and teamwork between many actors and innovation and
creativity, it can be challenging to implement if the different actors ﬁnd it difﬁcult
to collaborate and potential disparities in the authority and inﬂuence of the various

Empowering Citizens for Energy Communities in the European Union
13
individuals might prevent some of them from contributing completely to the process
(Soares da Silva and Horlings 2020). The diabolo model makes it possible to identify
the factors that inﬂuence success, highlighting the signiﬁcance of user practices and
the institutional context in driving the adoption of novel community energy tech-
nology. It also underscores the importance of solution co-creation and co-design
among many stakeholders, including citizens, government, and industry. However,
it does not provide a clear framework for assessing the impact of community energy
efforts in terms of social and environmental consequences. Additionally, the theoret-
ical framework assumes that users are passive agents who embrace new technologies
based on their own preferences, rather than considering the role of power dynamics
and social structures in driving adoption processes (Soares da Silva and Horlings
2020). The SNM model emphasizes the importance of creating protected spaces for
experimentation and innovation, and one of its strengths is that it stresses the impor-
tance of communication between the different actors. However, it does not include
a clear framework to evaluate the impact of innovation on social and environmental
outcomes. Furthermore, as it proposes that innovations develop from niches before
spreading to broader contexts, it ignores the effect of social and cultural norms on
the diffusion process. Finally, it does not address the issue of equity and the potential
for innovations to exacerbate existing inequalities (Koirala et al. 2018). The LAG
model offers a framework to involve a wide range of local stakeholders, helping to
build broad support for community energy projects and, thus, increase the likelihood
of their success. However, it can be difﬁcult to maintain the required momentum and
commitment over time, as when LAGs are set up with initial funding and support from
external sources, but the ﬁnancing comes to an end. In addition, LAGs at times ﬁnd
it onerous to balance competing interests and priorities among different stakeholder
groups (Kola-Bezka 2023). The community-based approach, in turn, emphasizes
building strong communities by developing their resilience and ability to adapt to the
different challenges that may arise. By involving the entire community, the model
can build trust and foster social cohesion, while indirectly improving health and
wellbeing and increasing economic and employment opportunities, thereby creating
greater social capital. However, the model can be difﬁcult to scale up and replicate
in different contexts and regions; the success of community energy projects is highly
dependent on cultural and social factors as well as the political environment of the
community itself, which can create barriers, especially when seeking funding (Boeri
et al. 2017). Finally, while the DART model builds trust and understanding between
different stakeholder groups, promoting learning and capacity-building among the
participants and encouraging inclusion in community energy projects, its implemen-
tation requires signiﬁcant time and resources, and its effectiveness can be vulnerable
to power imbalances between stakeholders (Ryszawska et al. 2021).
14
A. Medina-Bousoño and J. Sierra
4.3
Motives and Incentives
While most of the literature argues that protecting the environment from climate
change and a sense of belonging to the community are the key drivers of decision-
making (Soeiro and Ferreira Dias 2020), some authors have also identiﬁed monetary
incentives as one of the main reasons that community members participate in citizen-
led energy transitions. Thus, a mix of ﬁnancial and non-ﬁnancial incentives usually
inﬂuence citizens (Ryszawska et al. 2021). However, these factors do not apply to
all population types. Indeed, in many cases, the population is often idealized as a
homogenous community, when the reality is quite the contrary.
The most consequential behavioral changes in this respect tend to occur among the
older population. Individuals with higher purchasing power are often more reluctant
to change their minds because they have more resources to maintain their current
lifestyle, leading them to focus on short-term gains and oblivious to the long-term
beneﬁts of community energy initiatives. But at the same time the elderly may have a
greater sense of community and social responsibility, as they have had more time to
develop and build relationships where they live, making them more willing to work
together towards a common goal and more concerned about the long-term impact of
their actions on the environment and future generations (Radtke et al. 2022).
In addition to generational and ﬁnancial inﬂuences, motives, and incentives to
participate in energy communities often vary from country to country due to their
unique cultural, political, economic, and social factors. In particular, a country’s
energy policy can be a key factor inﬂuencing participation in energy communities
(de Waal and Stremke 2014; Hager 2015). Financial policies also play a crucial role.
For instance, high energy tariffs can motivate people to search for cheaper alternatives
like energy communities. Finally, there is a signiﬁcant difference between countries
where the community culture is more developed, and the sense of citizenship and
belonging is more deeply rooted than those that lack these characteristics.
As a last example of incentives, bottom-up energy transition narratives play a
part in assessing how global challenges have been translated into local realities and,
above all, into success stories. In line with this, creating a narrative enhances the
value of being part of a community striving for change and increases the acceptance
of renewable energy through ﬁnancial participation and an emotional attachment to
the project (David and Schönborn 2018).
4.4
Barriers
The list of barriers to and challenges faced by energy communities that can hinder
their implementation and development is varied in nature. Narratives about energy
transition, for example, can become contentious and polarizing, because they are
intertwined with the complex social, political, and economic issues in each country,
creatingcontroversiesovereconomiccostsandbeneﬁts(DavidandSchönborn2018).
Empowering Citizens for Energy Communities in the European Union
15
Additionally, starting and operating an energy community may require signiﬁcant
upfront capital investment. A lack of access to ﬁnance can limit the ability of
energycommunitiestoinvestininfrastructureandothernecessaryresources.Without
possible funding from the public sector, in many situations these energy communi-
ties remain an idea, with no possibility of being enacted (Kloppenburg et al. 2019).
Geopolitical factors can also pose challenges. For example, concerns about national
security and balance of power can be raised by shifting to renewable energy sources,
as some countries currently dependent on fossil fuels become less important in the
global energy market (Drewello 2022).
Also, energy communities require technical expertise to design, install and operate
their infrastructure. Accordingly, a lack of technical expertise or necessary resources
can limit the ability of energy communities to develop. Moreover, many citizens
are not aware of the beneﬁts of energy communities or do not understand how they
work, making it complicated for the communities to attract new members or gain
support from policymakers (Nouri et al. 2022). Energy communities are also often
subject to complex and sometimes conﬂicting regulations at the national and local
levels, which can limit their ability to operate or access ﬁnancial incentives and other
support. By the same token, energy communities can disrupt the established energy
market, which can lead to resistance from existing energy suppliers, who may see
them as competition and try to block their development. Consequently, municipalities
must be provided with the necessary knowledge and expertise to initiate communi-
ties, while institutional and legal frameworks often slow innovation projects down
(Beauchampet and Walsh 2021).
Another major problem is the lack of transparency in government decision-
making, which can lead to citizens and the different actors involved in the processes
of these initiatives to feel excluded from the process around energy communities
(Lennon et al. 2019). Often, a large communication barrier between stakeholders
makes the development of these projects impossible (Nouri et al. 2022). Suprana-
tional policies for an idealized community frequently do not take local realities into
consideration and have a limited view or lack of understanding of the local realities
in different countries and regions. In addition, they may develop in a restricted time
frame and with limited resources, hindering the ability to research and understand
local realities in depth. Finally, the affected communities are often not involved in the
policy formulation process. This can lead to policies that do not reﬂect the needs and
concerns of communities and may be inadequate or ineffective in practice (Radtke
et al. 2022).
However, the most important barrier to these initiatives appears at the local level.
While the energy transition may be clear at the supranational or national level, it may
not always be obvious at the sub-national, regional and local levels (Dam and van der
Windt 2022). However, it is crucial to consider these scales because energy transition
is ultimately a bottom-up process that depends on the participation and engagement
of communities and stakeholders at the local level. At sub-national, regional and local
scales, the energy transition can take various forms, depending on the local context,
resources and priorities. By taking this into account, the transition can be tailored to
meet the speciﬁc needs and challenges of different communities and stakeholders.
16
A. Medina-Bousoño and J. Sierra
This can help ensure that the transition is equitable, inclusive, and sustainable, and
that it addresses the speciﬁc energy challenges and opportunities faced by different
regions and communities. State governments also need to ensure that there is good
communication between supranational, national, and municipal levels.
5
Conclusion
In the current urgent global environmental and social crisis, it’s essential to develop
strategies towards sustainable development. In advocating for the shift towards a
society reliant on renewable energy sources, such as a low-carbon society, there is
a growing emphasis on the importance of energy communities. In this regard, this
chapter has explored the importance of energy communities as one of the instruments
that can contribute to improving economic, social, and environmental sustainability
from the perspective of energy production with renewable sources. It is also one of
the areas where participatory methods in public decision making are gaining more
prominence in recent years as mechanisms for enhancing citizen engagement in
sustainability policy.
Energy transitions should empower both individuals and communities, empha-
sizing sustainable energy endeavors. With the progression of decentralized produc-
tion technologies, there has been a growing interest in energy communities. However,
achieving a successful and fair energy transition doesn’t solely rely on technological
advancements. In this regard, it is essential to improve decision-making processes to
make them more inclusive and participatory. This requires a fusion of thorough anal-
ysis, expertise in engineering and spatial planning, and insights from social sciences.
Acknowledging the need to address global challenges at the local level, the transi-
tion to decentralized energy systems represents a crucial advancement towards more
sustainable and resilient societies.
Against this background, citizens are key stakeholders as they are directly affected
by energy policies and infrastructures. The creation of energy communities can be
seen as a form of citizen empowerment and as a response to a democratic deﬁcit. In
somecases,citizensmayfeelthattheyhavenosayinenergy-relateddecision-making,
and these participatory approaches can be useful to regain control and involvement in
this area. It also creates peoples’ empowerment, as it involves the direct participation
of local communities. Hence, their perspectives and needs can be better incorpo-
rated into the transition plan, which can lead to greater community acceptance and
support. In addition, when citizens are informed and engaged, they can help increase
awareness and momentum for renewable energy projects, which can lead to more
widespread adoption and support. Overall, this can contribute to greater sustainability
and resilience.
The way in which energy communities are created and managed may determine
whether they are an effective and fair form of citizen empowerment or simply a
temporary stopgap to a broader problem of democratic deﬁcit. The development of
community-owned renewable energy projects contributes to more distributed energy
Empowering Citizens for Energy Communities in the European Union
17
generation and less reliance on centralized power plants, leading directly to greater
energy security and independence, as well as other local economic beneﬁts. The
perception of local governments and the possible communications relevant actors
can determine the degree of success of the local energy transition process.
This study is affected by some limitations. Using Scopus as the only biblio-
graphic database may have excluded some useful documents. In addition, since only
articles in English were selected, some particularities from local contexts may not be
reﬂected. The same applies to the fact that we included research articles only. Taking
this into consideration, future research may beneﬁt from exploring a wider range of
documents in different languages. In addition to this, it would be very interesting
to examine the legal and regulatory frameworks of energy communities in non-EU
countries, to draw distinctions between different contexts and identify possible key
points for enhancing the development of energy communities.
In the face of current and future energy crises, energy communities as citizens’
initiatives are a powerful tool. The private sector is also very relevant in the energy
transition, and many companies recognize the opportunities and beneﬁts that can
arise from energy communities, even though they can also be seen as a competitor.
Ultimately, it becomes crucial to develop an appropriate regulatory framework. To
accomplish this, dialogue between the private sector, energy communities, and the
public sector is essential to overcome resistance and move towards a more sustainable
and democratic energy system.

Edible Weeds in Agricultural Landscapes
as a Research Emphasis for Sustainability
Bruno Borsari and Malcolm F. Vidrine
Abstract Weeds have been attributed negative connotations since an expansion of
monocultures gained increasing worldwide support. For the last forty years however,
agroecology has been emerging as a respectable paradigm for sustainable agriculture,
which exposes the ﬂaws of industrial farming and its implications for resource deple-
tion and environmental degradation. Within an agroecological framework, weeds
have become more appreciated for spurring agrobiodiversity and providing a variety
of ecological services, including culinary uses. Therefore, there is a compelling need
to re-consider management practices that were initially conceived to eradicate weeds
from agroecosystems. This chapter aimed at highlighting ecological approaches in
controlling and/or even enhancing weeds populations in agricultural landscapes for
nutrition purposes. Through a systematic review of the literature we described present
knowledges available for managing edible weeds in agroecosystems in the U.S., with
a focus on uses and ecological services these provide. Our study suggests that weeds
may contribute effectively to human nutrition and to environmental health. In addi-
tion, we present ideas that may inspire more growers to redesign and manage farms
through agroecological principles and approaches that are conservative of native
plant communities. Many of these plants that are becoming marketable as vegetables
are appreciated also for diversifying human diets as well as ecosystems. Although the
idea of consuming wild plants is not new, an emerging interest in edible weeds looks
promising as a research agenda for an enhancement of sustainability in agriculture,
with its beneﬁts extending from agroecosystems to food systems and public health.
Keywords Agroecosystems · Edible weeds · Food · Rewilding · Sustainability ·
Weed management
B. Borsari (B)
Department of Biology, Winona State University, Winona, MN, USA
e-mail: bborsari@winona.edu
M. F. Vidrine
Division of Arts & Sciences, Louisiana State University-Eunice, Eunice, LA, USA
e-mail: mvidrine@lsue.edu

W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_2
