B. Borsari and M. F. Vidrine
1
Introduction
Although the ecological and economic effects of weeds have impacted crop yields
since the dawn of agriculture, many of these unwanted plants were collected and
routinely consumed by our farming ancestors (Pfeiffer 1970; Rapoport et al. 1995;
Turner et al. 2011). Similarly, early Cajuns (Louisiana French Acadians) harvested
crawﬁsh (Procambarus clarkii) and ate them—these, too, were once considered
‘weeds’ among invertebrate animals, and now, they are a delicacy that generates more
than $423 million every year (Smith 2020). In many locations of the U.S. Gulf region,
they are the only crop providing real income, whereas the others (rice and soybeans)
require subsidies and insurance as a result of routine failings. Nonetheless, weeds
remain notorious for harming crops through competition of resources and/or inter-
ferences with their growth via allelopathy (Putnam et al. 1983; Batish et al. 2006). In
many competitive interactions with cultivated plants, weeds are capable of securing
critical resources, like space, water, nutrients, and sunlight, at the detriment of agri-
cultural crops, depending on a variety of conditions related to speciﬁc environments
(Gliessman 2015). However, competition for soil moisture should not be a problem
for agronomic species growing on healthy soils that receive abundant precipitation.
For example, weeds like purslane (Portulaca spp.) seldom compete with cultivated
plants for sunlight, because its leaves grow parallel to the ground surface. In addi-
tion, Lampkin (1999) explained that when desired crops develop deep root systems,
shallow-rooted weeds absorb water and nutrients at depths near the surface of a soil
proﬁle, thus, competing gently for these resources. Yet, most crops struggle against
weeds for all these resources, making the control of their populations and distribu-
tion a major agricultural chore. For these reasons, weed management has focused on
minimizing the presence of non-crops in cultivated ﬁelds, in spite of the use of many
wild species as spices, seasonal foods, or medicine.
Rather than being cultivated, edible weeds can also be collected from remnant
areas of wilderness, within agroecosystems or in their immediate vicinity (Turner
et al. 2011). According to Yakovleva (2020), typical sites on farms, where weeds
may thrive, are disturbed areas, the edges of cultivated ﬁelds, paths along farm
implements routes, and/or in the vicinity of composting sites and built infrastructures
(barns, greenhouses and other buildings). Weeds can thrive in these spaces, spurring
agroecosystems’ biodiversity, while contributing to the health of landscapes through
a variety of ecological services, beneﬁtting farms and wildlife habitats (Altieri 1995;
Jackson and Jackson 2002). For example, weeds protect soils from erosion (Weil and
Brady 2017) and/or serve as pollen and nectar sources for insects and more biota
(Pickett and Bugg 1998). Also, many weed species are consumed by herbivores
including people thus, contributing with nutrients towards a diversiﬁcation of human
and livestock nutrition that beneﬁt the health and well-being of all heterotrophs.
Even omnivores like the already mentioned crawﬁsh, consume much of the weeds
growing in their ponds. Also, nymphs of the Green Darner dragonﬂy (Anax junius)—
an insect predator, inhabit crawﬁsh habitats all winter season, feeding on the newly
emerging crustaceans. However, as winter transitions into spring, the young crawﬁsh
Edible Weeds in Agricultural Landscapes as a Research Emphasis …
23
begins consuming the dragonﬂy nymphs (Huner 1994). These intersecting cycles are
key to thriving environments and economies and depend from an effective function-
ality of carbon cycling. Eliminating the dragonﬂies may appear necessary manage-
ment but in actuality, it hampers the cycle of the crawﬁsh. Weeds participate in anal-
ogous cycles thus, attempting to eradicate these from crops could become dangerous
to the ecology of agroecosystems!
Current models for growing agronomic crops employ mainly genetically engi-
neered (GE) cultivars and the use of powerful, yet toxic, endocrine disrup-
tors (glyphosate, atrazine, neonicotinoids, organophosphates, and more). These
molecules are also detrimental to weed development in a cropping system, both
because they serve not only as herbicides but also as insecticides thus, killing plants,
insectsnecessarytopollinatetheplants,birdsandﬁshfeedingontheweeds.However,
social acceptance of GE cultivars could change, and when large segments of the popu-
lation learn that food production relies on endocrine disruptors, this may result in
potential ‘food fear,’ hampering existing food chains. For example, the impacts of
insecticides on juvenile crawﬁsh (when noted and denounced by farmers and the
public), changed the entire chemical application scheme in rice ﬁelds intercropped
with these crustaceans, in south Louisiana (Stout et al. 2011).
This work summarizes current knowledges (western and indigenous) about
managing edible weeds in agroecosystems, with a focus on their uses and ecological
services these provide as a viable research agenda for sustainable development. In
addition, we present ideas that may inspire more growers to redesign and manage
farms through agroecological principles and approaches that are conservative of
native plant communities. Within this framework, edible weeds could offer dietary
opportunities for human and livestock species that from the One-Health-theory
perspective (Xie et al. 2017), may extend their beneﬁts to agriculture, with potential
to establish new, thriving economies, while boosting agrobiodiversity. Wilson (2016)
suggested farming only half of all lands, to leave the remaining half to be rewilded.
Similarly, the U.N. clarion calls for rewilding 30% of lands by 2030, suggesting the
global need to rethink agriculture and native plant resources!
Furthermore, agricultural soils are recurring themes central to our discussion
(Lymbery 2022), suggesting ideas that weed species can add signiﬁcantly to the
health of ecosystems and organismal communities of which human beings are part.
According to Edgeworth (2023) landscapes manipulated by humans, are more than a
parchment of symbols, remains, tracks and residues of their activities that determine
inevitable changes to land, no matter whether these are human-caused or non-human
forces yet, they are inseparably associated with what happens to the entire Earth
system.
24
B. Borsari and M. F. Vidrine
2
Methodology
This study consisted in a detailed and critical review of the literature about salient
aspectsofweedmanagementintheU.S.,withaspeciﬁcfocusabouttheirfeasibilityto
be employed more noticeably, as novel foods. Our research effort aimed at shedding
a new light on weed species especially, for expanding their uses in human nutri-
tion but also to substantiate their ecological values and services to ecosystems and
agroecosystems (Gliessman et al. 2023). The convergence of these themes aimed
at identifying possible research venues that could even make weeds attractive for
achieving sustainability in the agricultural sciences. From a broader perspective,
Patten (2004) pointed out that, literature reviews can be of interest for detecting what
has been written about speciﬁc topics, while assisting researchers to determine the
degree of knowledge gained in certain research sectors, and whether any trends exist
among these.
3
The Ambiguous Nature of Weeds: Friends or Foes?
According to an old linguistic dichotomy, non-crop plants classiﬁed as ‘weeds’ can
be bad, or good, depending on how, or under what occurrences they are assessed.
Tompkins and Bird (1989, p. 163) explained that: “The old English word ‘weod’,
since become ‘weed’ had a double meaning as it was spoken in the Kingdom to
about 1100. Its pejorative overtone, when it referred to plants tending to overgrow
or choke out more desirable ones cultivated for food, was applied to their being
entirely worthless but to their being without value when growing in certain locations.
Weed could also mean herb-derived from the Latin herba-or any plant that does not
develop persistent woody tissue but like grasses dies back at the end of each growing
season. To add to the confusion, the term herb also applied more restrictedly to a
class of plants having savory, aromatic, or medicinal value”. Most agroecologists
would agree that weeds are plants whose properties and value yet remain to be
discovered, thus, an understanding of weed ecology becomes necessary to appreciate
the multifaceted roles that these plants play in every agrarian landscape (Gliessman
et al. 2023; Altieri 1995). After all, non-crop plants collected from the wild have
been used for millennia for a variety of uses beyond food (Fritz 2019) and it appears
that in a pre-industrialized world, weeds co-existed more harmoniously with humans.
Therefore, noxious characterizations of weeds are not only due to farming expansions
achieved through technological breakthroughs of 20th century agriculture, but also
through an infusion of Christian ideology that became established in America with
the arrival of European conquistadors and pilgrims, since the discovery of the ‘New
World’ (Borsari and DeGrazia 2015).
Edible Weeds in Agricultural Landscapes as a Research Emphasis …
25
3.1
Edible Weeds of the Prairie Biome
The grasslands of North America possess a unique assortment of plant commu-
nities, which are supported by thriving, living counterparts within the soil food-
web of prairies. The plants were used in several human-based economies and in a
host of ecosystem economies that created soil and clean water in a hydrologically-
balanced system, ultimately supporting diverse downstream terrestrial and aquatic
plant, fungal and animal communities in marshes, rivers and oceans (Vidrine 2010).
In the North American continent, these prairies stretched from what are now the
southern, central provinces of Canada to the Gulf of Mexico and from the Rockies
to the Appalachian Mountains. This interwoven network of ecosystems is part of the
prairie biome and shares distinctive climatic conditions, that have been conducive
in evolving unique communities dominated by herbaceous plants, rather than trees
(Smith and Smith 2014). Rain precipitation ranges between 25 and 100 cm/year, and
this limiting factor has been regulating the ecology of North American grasslands
from tallgrass prairie in the east to a drier mixed-grass prairie that begins in the U.S.
Midwest, to a short-grass prairie, nestled further west, on the east side of the Rocky
Mountains (Borsari and Vidrine 2023).
According to Duke (1992), Indigenous Americans used more than 1,000 plant
species as food, which accounts for about the 6% of 18,956 species of the ﬂowering
plants in this continent. Also, Allen and his collaborators (2005) accurately reported
the abundance of edible, wild plants of the southern U.S. coastal prairie region.
Regretfully, these North American prairies have been replaced by pasture, crop land
(364 million hectares), and cityscapes (Borsari and Kunnas 2020), that include 16
million hectares of lawns (Tallamy 2020). Historically, these plant communities were
highly diverse and supported large populations of herbivores and their predators; they
also nourished, sheltered, clothed and healed the numerous indigenous communities
who inhabited the prairie biome (Fritz 2019). We argue that indigenous knowledge of
non-crop plants uses contributed to the health and aided the successful establishment
of European colonists in North America (Vidrine et al. 2001).
All prairies host weeds with many symbiotic relationships, while protecting their
soil. A study by Hirsch and colleagues (2013) indicated that a conversion of 10–
20% of cropland into prairie buffer strips in Iowa re-established iconic perennial
species of native prairies without increasing densities of weeds in adjacent culti-
vated ﬁelds. To reiterate the worth of wild plants (Cocannauer 1980) explained that,
milkweeds (Asclepias spp.), goldenrods (Solidago, spp.), ironweeds (Vernonia, spp.),
thistles (Cirsium, spp.) and more, sustain the prairie grasses in an obligatory relation-
ship. Additionally, many other prairie species, like sow thistle (Sonchus oleraceus),
lamb’s quarter (Chenopodium album), smooth-leaf pigweed (Amaranthus hybridus),
stingingnettles(Urticaspp.),dandelion(Taraxacumofﬁcinale),wildlettuce(Lactuca
virosa), are edible, and they must have played important roles for the sustenance of
indigenous peoples and early, European prairie-settlers.
26
B. Borsari and M. F. Vidrine
3.2
Edible Weeds in Indigenous Cultures
In pre-agriculture times, humans’ food choices must have relied heavily on wild
plants. This traditional, ecological knowledge (TEK) of wild, edible plants was trans-
ferred through generations among indigenous cultures, as wild food plants continue
to be a source of cultural identity, both reﬂecting an important body of environmental
understanding, survival, and sustainable living (Turner et al. 2011). This habit is often
embedded within animist worldviews, where nature is conceived as a spiritual entity,
nurturing all living beings. The conceptualization of nature by indigenous people
highlights a unique predisposition of trust for it, that tends to harmonize human
interactions with their physical habitat and other living beings, transforming the
relationship with nature into a co-evolutionary one, between individuals and land-
scape (Aswani et al. 2018). Consequently, an ecological agriculture depends upon
interactions with all forms of life because we, humans, relate intimately with all the
places in which we reside (Provenza et al. 2013).
Tompkins and Bird (1989) reported that in the Kalahari Desert of south Africa,
the Kung bushmen relied on 85 wild plant species, never once setting eyes on the
less than a dozen plants that now make up a 75% of the human diet around the
world. For this reason, traditional home gardens and indigenous farms in countries,
where agriculture is a subsistence activity, continue to champion biodiversity conser-
vation, while, fulﬁlling the nutrition needs of indigenous communities (Orsini et al.
2013). A case study from Perú suggested that edible weeds are increasingly managed
in deforested areas both in-situ and ex-situ, demonstrating farmers’ adaptability at
securing food under circumstances of extreme disturbances, in this tropical region
of the Amazon (Cruz-Garcia 2017). More examples of weed use and consumption
come from studies conducted in China (Zhang et al. 2015) and the Philippines (Tan
Chua-Barcelo 2014). An additional report from Brazil (Sanchez-Bel et al. 2015)
substantiated the relevance that edible weeds continue having in the human diet as
food.
4
Researching Management Tactics for Promoting Edible
Weeds
The management of weeds in agriculture, whether edible or not, has traditionally
focused on physical methods (e.g.: hoeing, pulling, cultivating or ﬂaming), whereas
the spraying of herbicides is getting traction with an increasing agricultural indus-
trialization. Common knowledge infers weeds are pioneer species thriving on land-
scapes whose soils are frequently disturbed, like agricultural soils (Magdoff and Van
Es 2009). From this perspective they are cover crops, making their presence toler-
able and even cherished by agriculturists, when their densities can be maintained at
levels that do not affect the performance of cultivated crops (Lampkin 1999). Yet,
abstaining from herbicides use, as in organic agriculture, makes these farms more
Edible Weeds in Agricultural Landscapes as a Research Emphasis …
27
susceptible to weed establishment. For example, a study in long-term crop rotations
from Nebraska showed that weed seedbank and above-ground weed populations were
higher in organic-grown crops, indicating a need for more intense management in
long-term organic rotations that include annual crop species; however, results showed
also that including a perennial forage crop in organic rotations reduces broadleaf
weed seedbank populations (Wortman et al. 2010). With an emerging interest in
weeds as foods, substantial changes are sought in managing wild plants on farms.
Nonetheless, weeds continue to be monitored attentively, and through agroecology,
several practices are available to reduce their populations, without having to rely on
herbicides (Gliessman et al. 2023).
4.1
Weeds Ecological Control Strategies and Farm Design
Polyculture systems like orchards, vineyards and/or agroforestry systems (alley crop-
ping, silvopasture, riparian buffer zones), are more tolerant for the coexistence of
agronomic crops with weeds than for monocultures (Stanek et al. 2019). An ecolog-
ical management of weeds in these and similar systems, including permaculture,
demands strategies that employ holistic approaches. According to Ferguson and
Lovell (2017), frequent ﬁeld observations, long-term planning and adaptations to
the characteristics of local soils, topography and other environmental conditions,
constitute typical strategies for an ecological control of unwanted plants. Unavoid-
ably, farms and gardens require a design for growing spaces and crop rows with
distancing among plants for minimal cultivation to reduce soil loss and disturbance.
Although more labor intensive, the intercropping “coltura promiscua” of northeastern
Italy exempliﬁes a traditional ﬁeld design, which accommodates multiple herbaceous
species, including fruit trees and grapevines (Ferrario 2021). This design approach
remains a tangible demonstration of a multifunctionally-productive landscape, that
to this day continues to fulﬁl human needs, while boosting biodiversity and ecolog-
ical services. Thus, weeding may become even an obsolete practice when farmers
understand that the interactions among all the parts of an agroecosystem are multi-
faceted (Fukuoka 1985). However, a few speciﬁc principles for weed control should
always be considered, and these refer to knowing the weed species that are present,
because these vary in their growth patterns, phenology, and interactions with culti-
vated crops. Therefore, an accurate identiﬁcation at every stage of weed development
is critical for an effective management, planning and implementation in and around
agroecosystems (Altieri 1995). More valuable traits of weed species relevant for
their identiﬁcation and control include: time of emergence, conditions that trigger
seeds germination, growth rate and height, allelopathic potential, time to ﬂowering,
seed setting, and methods of seed dispersal (Carlberg 2014). These assist farmers in
realizing at what stage of their biological cycle can weeds become most vulnerable
or palatable for herbivores (Lampkin 1999; Magdoff and Van Es 2009), including
humans.
28
B. Borsari and M. F. Vidrine
Limiting the niches for weed growth is also very important because weeds are
adapted to prosper in disturbed environments, which are typical conditions in farms
and/or gardens. Therefore, reducing soil cultivation, while keeping it protected with
cover crops or mulches are viable ecological practices to control weeds, where these
are unwanted. Also, maximizing heterogeneity in time and space can boost diversity
and enhance agroecosystems health, while permitting adaptive management of all
plants, including non-crop species (Jackson and Jackson 2002).
Understanding weeds’ reproduction and dispersal patterns is important too,
because annual weeds are r-strategists that germinate rapidly, yielding copious
numbers of seeds that remain viable in the soil, for years. Literally, every seed can
produce thousands of new plants, thus, determining exponential population growths
(Gliessman et al. 2023). The key to controlling weeds lies in constraining their repro-
ductive capabilities, while developing strategies aimed at reducing their seed bank
(Wilson 1988), which makes essential the biological knowledge of every species.
4.2
Research About Managing the Growth of Edible Weeds
Most of the weeds that are economically important are not invasive and need special
culture just as agronomic crops. Among these, notable, species in the Poaceae (grass
family), are Eastern gamagrass (Tripsacum dactyloides) and kernza (Thinopyrum
intermedium), that together with some perennial sunﬂowers (Asteraceae), have been
studiedatTheLandInstituteaspromisingfoodsources(SouleandPiper 1991).These
perennial plants re-emerge to the soil surface from apical meristems located on the
tips of their massive root system, at the onset of a new growing season, yielding food
in abundance without the need for agrichemical applications or tillage, all-the-while
demonstrating a sustainable potential for shifting agriculture from the cultivation of
annual to perennial species (Fig. 1).
Propagating edible weeds differs from the approaches that are employed for the
production of cultivated crops, because wild species grow in any disturbed site.
According to Pfeiffer (1970, p. 18): “weeds are weeds only from our human, egotis-
tical point of view, because they grow where we do not want them. In nature however,
they play an important and interesting role. They resist conditions that cultivated
plants cannot resist, such as drought, acidity, lack of humus, mineral deﬁciencies.
They are witnesses of man’s failure to master the soil, and they grow abundantly
where man has ‘missed the train’—they only indicate our errors and nature’s correc-
tions”. They are known to provide great biodiversity resources, including bird, ﬁsh,
and insect food, while hosting numerous insects in vital food chains. In fact, the loss
of weeds ultimately could mean the loss of agriculture, since they build soil humus,
while regulating its hydrology. Thus, conceptualizing weeds as indicators of soil
conditions could be used to spur their growth further, especially when these become
marketable as foods. Marginal lands, depleted soils and similar environmental condi-
tions, are feasible sites for an establishment of edible weeds, because they are adapt-
able to thrive during the early phase of secondary succession (Vidrine 2010). Farmers
Edible Weeds in Agricultural Landscapes as a Research Emphasis …
29
Fig. 1 Massive root system
of Mamou plant (Erythrina
herbacea), perennial plant
from remnant prairies of
southwestern Louisiana,
USA
interested in growing wild plants as food should observe what emerges from the seed
bankofmarginalsitesoftheirfarmsandsupportthegrowthofoneoralimitednumber
of weed species, while culling the remainder. This should enable growers to enhance
their knowledge about wild plants, including speciﬁc conditions needed by each one
to optimize its development.
Making predictions about weeds’ growth patterns in different farms or from one
growingseasontothenextremainschallengingyet,athoroughknowledgeofagrarian
landscapes is necessary to reconnect farms with ecosystems (Jackson and Jackson
2002). Growers’ conservation skills are essential for producing edible weeds, as
the farms become part of a new, agriculture paradigm that encourages landscape
rewilding (Monbiot 2022). Understanding what composition of species to expect on
tilled soils is a more predictable undertaking than learning weed phenology, as there
may be speciﬁc patterns about seed germination and dispersal within the soil seed
bank (Bhowmik 1997).
An identiﬁcation of weed species at their seedling stages is valuable for planning
the growing spaces for both cultivated plants and edible weeds. When seedling iden-
tiﬁcation is challenging, however, marking and letting patches of unknown seedlings
grow will facilitate their identiﬁcation. Enticing seeds to grow into edible plants in
tilled, annual crop production ﬁelds or in other spaces, where succession is reset to
habitats suitable for ruderal species, is always intertwined with weeding chores. After
all, weeding remains a keystone agricultural task, and adding edible weeds in agroe-
cosystems could add more work for farmers (Lampkin 1999). Yet, when growers
gain knowledge about edible weeds, they begin to welcome the yearly return of
certain species from one season to the next. At this point, selective weeding becomes
30
B. Borsari and M. F. Vidrine
necessary, and although this could reduce weeding efﬁciency as Yakovleva (2020)
explained, in return there will be extra crops available at harvest time.
In our opinion, the concurrent growth of edible weeds and cultivated crops is
feasible, if farmers relinquish the idea of maintaining manicured ﬁelds and shift away
from unrealistic designs and management utopias predicated by industrial agricul-
ture. Additional challenges beyond the ﬁelds’ esthetics could be: competing issues
among plants, transmission of pathogens, or insects transfer from weeds to cultivated
crops, or allelopathy (Batish et al. 2006; Gliessman et al. 2023). Therefore, seeking
balance while increasing agrobiodiversity, which boosts resilience and reduces these
and similar stressors, remains an important management component for handling
weeds (Altieri 1995; Borsari 2022).
The thought of letting weeds mature to a harvestable stage may evoke frightening
circumstances of increased hand-weeding chores. Thus, Assirelli and team (2022)
successfully employed a speciﬁc machine to control weed growth in a high-density
olive orchard in central Italy, suggesting that keeping pathways between rows mowed
is necessary to ensure the healthy growth of young trees, while reducing topsoil and
moisture losses that otherwise would occur when soils are kept free of vegetation.
Farms that grow perennial crops will rely on mowing and living mulched pathways,
while supplementing the maintenance of hard-to-reach spots with hand mowing
tools, or ad-hoc designed, small engine cultivators (Borsari et al. 2004). Also, ﬁeld
margins and hedgerows can support the growth of edible weeds in abundance as well
as natural habitats within and/or around farms (DeVore 2018). Managing these habi-
tats on a farm requires a committed relationship with the land, since management
decisions may have reverberating impacts on the entire local ecosystem. On agricul-
tural lands, where habitats are already fragmented, management decisions pertaining
to peripheral or marginal lands are signiﬁcant because these are often in riparian,
buffer zones, and protecting these will also protect water, soil, wildlife (Jackson and
Jackson 2002), and people.
Aside from variances in spatial conditions, the temporal divide among culti-
vated and wild crops offers additional possibilities for managing edible weeds.
For example, in a typical rotation of fast-growing crops, like radishes followed
by lettuce and kale, wilds plants can also be rotated in similar fashions (Lampkin
1999). Annual edible weeds peak in early spring or in early summer. Therefore,
farmers who welcome certain wild plants as food know when to expect them, hence,
growers should leave gaps in their rotation plans for one or more seasonal ﬂuxes of
wild edible weeds among their agronomic crops (Yakovleva 2020). Edible perennial
weeds that thrive on the edges of agricultural lands are common species that repro-
duceasexually,suchas:stingingnettle(Urticadioica),commonmilkweed(Asclepias
syriaca), sumac (Sumac spp.), and daylily (Lilium spp.). The harvesting and selective
weeding of these species occurs from the perimeter toward the center ﬁeld, because
this approach reduces excessive development. Additionally, this strategy minimizes
disturbance that, for some perennial species instead, stimulates growth. Harvesting
time is often a race against the summer temperatures and humidity to maintain the
produces’ quality, and thus, proﬁts from harvesting weeds for market should always
be weighed against produce losses.
Edible Weeds in Agricultural Landscapes as a Research Emphasis …
31
Few, well known edible weed seeds like saltwort (Salsola soda), shiso (Perilla
frutescens), candy-leaf (Stevia rebaudiana) and more, are marketed as herbs and can
be purchased from seed catalogs (Johnny’s Selected Seeds 2023; Seed Savers 2023).
Some of these commercial seeds are saved from wild populations, whereas others
are the outcome of domesticating efforts that augment wild plants’ desirable traits.
For example, cultivated dandelions tend to be less bitter than their feral counterparts,
and cultivated purslane grows more upright. Iconic species that growers ﬁrst got to
know in the wild and then transplanted to more convenient locations were stinging
nettles (Urtica spp.). These plants prefer wetter soils but tolerate a wide-range of
conditions and are easily propagated via stem cuttings, or through the splitting of
their wide, rhizomatous roots (Pfeiffer 1970). The cultivation of edible weeds can
be advantageous in minimizing health risks that their consumption may determine
because of an accumulation of pollutants and also in reducing risks for foodborne
diseases, due to limited predispositions to microbial contamination that wild plants
possess, when compared with agricultural crops (Baldi et al. 2022).
4.3
Research on Rewilding—A New Way to Look
at Agriculture and Ecological Economics
The term ‘weed’ has an entirely different context in the new science of rewilding—a
visionary concept, which is extensible to agroeconomic systems was developed and
proposed in several books by Wilson (2003, 2013, 2016). In rewilding, a ‘weed’ is
an exotic or non-native species, with ‘native’ plants being varyingly described as
‘precolonial’ or ‘naturalized early in colonial times.’ Debate, however, continues,
and we do not intend to resolve this in this chapter. Rather, we want to make readers
aware that current thinking about agriculture and food systems, as they both integrate
with water and petroleum resource usages, have grown to include an entirely new
ﬁeld, since Aldo Leopold’s groundbreaking role in the 1930s in habitat restoration,
by re-growing prairie on wasted agricultural lands, in an effort to depict a new
‘land ethic’ that integrates agriculture into natural habitats. Here our contention is
to recommend research on ‘native plants ordinarily considered weeds’ as not only
food and ﬁber for human and animal consumption but also as integral to stable, if
not sustainable, ecosystems that would support long-term agriculture; both currently
accepted crops and also new crops, especially new ‘native’ crops. The integration
of biodiversity in ﬁelds and around ﬁelds redoubles the potential for E. O. Wilson’s
vision of ‘half-Earth,’ as rewilded and integrated with humans and nature, becomes
a viable hypothesis. At present, we see this clearly documented by the recent work
of restorationists from England (Tree and Burrell 2023). The continued focus of
agriculture on the crops in vogue today is too susceptible to climatic and natural
changes occurring today, and thus, they cannot be the only options in changing the
face of agriculture to an extent that will be necessary to provide sustainable systems.
32
B. Borsari and M. F. Vidrine
5
Conclusion and Recommendations
Edible weeds in the human diet are expanding a new frontier for a development
of sustainable food systems. This emerging trend is cherished as a complemen-
tary strategy to efforts in sustainability, as present approaches to food production,
consumption and distribution by industrial agriculture remain unsustainable. Gordon
and team (2022) articulated a set of persuasive themes that should aid in shifting agri-
culture from consumptive to restorative, emphasizing landscape transformations that
veer farm design and management towards regaining complexity, biodiversity and
resilience. Within this framework, an integration of wild plants as food becomes ideal
for achieving the needed rehabilitation of landscapes and for realizing the improve-
ments that edible weeds can offer to human and planetary health. Therefore, farmers
should become proud to bring wild plants to market, despite chances of unavoid-
able criticism by some of their peers and consumers. The fact that customers may
scorn growers, when they see plants they identify as weeds for sale, could make
some farmers feel uncomfortable because this judgment could damage their profes-
sional image. In a recent report about unconventional plant-foods, Bellows and team
(2023) shed light on the amount of antioxidant phytochemicals in these foods and
their potential to increase dietary diversity and quality. From this study emerged the
need for micro- and macro-nutrients research on a larger spectrum of “wild foods”
together with needs for community nutrition education.
At the same time, the conﬁnes between weeds and agricultural crops, and/or
farming versus foraging is well marked and strongly maintained in U.S. afﬂuent
society. This has to do with the fact that edible weeds are considered famine
food and the only option for survival during hard times of crisis (Hjeltnes 2018).
According to Bexultanova and her collaborators (2022), interests in edible weeds
were spurred in the former USSR during World War II. Non-military circumstances,
such as environmental disasters leading to a food system collapse, constitute another
set of reasons that legitimize interests in edible, wild plants (Vorstenbosch et al.
2017). Nonetheless, we think that there is no obvious boundary between the contexts
presented here because wild and cultivated food crops befall along a broad range.
Consumers who engage on one side of this spectrum might feel more uncomfortable
to consider edible weeds as food, whereas others may regard wild plants with respect
and gratitude. However, most people maintain deeply rooted apprehensions about
consuming novel foods, and weeds although edible are no exception. This should not
be surprising though, because such hostility is embedded in western, afﬂuent culture,
including its language (Tompkins and Bird 1989). Therefore, promoting positive
experiences about weeds as foods is necessary, and this could occur through similar
marketing strategies as those that have been employed in persuading consumers to
eat insects-derived foods (Borsari 2023). Thus, various strategies justify needs for
future research about edible weeds that when added to overall recommendations
could more speciﬁcally focus on:
• Strengthening relationships between growers and consumers. This can be
achieved through surveys and marketing studies to assess consumers’ behavior.
Edible Weeds in Agricultural Landscapes as a Research Emphasis …
33
• Cooking demonstrations with edible weeds, including opportunities for degusta-
tion sampling at farmers’ markets, grocery stores, food cooperatives, and other
public sites, or events can be viable approaches in nutrition education and outreach
in support of edible weeds.
• Sharing of recipes and publications about using edible weeds as foods and
beverages.
• Subsidizingland‘rewilding’efforts,whichincludegrowingweedsforfood,ﬁbers,
as well as for clean air, drinkable water and healthy soils.
• Restoring vernacular knowledge of Indigenous uses of edible weeds through
informal education programs, but also through an establishment of eco-centric
education in schools, for every level of instruction.
• Leveling with the human population that food security is tenuously linked
to several ensuing conditions resulting from climate chaos, biodiversity loss,
hydrology changes, and more—the system is failing as critical tipping points
are being traversed.
This penultimate recommendation is substantiated by archeological evidence from
ancient agricultural centers in Europe and western Asia, suggesting that weeds’
evolutionary processes and selection by Neolithic farmers led to the domestication of
plants and their transformation into agronomic crops (Zohary et al. 2012). In essence,
all food crops have been domesticated from their wild ancestors exemplifying how
weeds became central to economies. Weeds, from other continents, like rice and
soybean, are examples of domesticated plants that have become ubiquitous; yet, their
production costs (social, economic, environmental) remain mostly unsustainable.
This gap requires agriculture to rely on government subsidies and crop insurance
for their continued survival. Thus, weeds remain a keystone farming theme, which
advocates for changes in agriculture and attitude in most peoples’ relationships with
food and co-existences with nature, in order to appreciate the beneﬁts that weeds can
bring to farming for conserving pollinators, beneﬁcial insects (Altieri and Whitcomb
1979), and ecosystems. Therefore, education remains pivotal to make all consumers
comprehend that wild plants have always been part of the human diet. This knowledge
may not affect consumers’ acceptance or rejection of non-crop plants, however,
increasing awareness continues to stand as a necessary task to be undertaken in
efforts to veer agriculture towards sustainability.
The latter recommendation has been treated in part in previous chapters of ours
(Borsari and Vidrine 2022, 2023). Preparation for adapting to climate change requires
open-minded education across a variety of disciplines, including agriculture, ecology,
humanities, and certainly, history. Most importantly, this public awareness about
edible weeds needs to be inclusive of Indigenous knowledges and wisdom (Bellows
et al. 2023), while expanding education efforts about an ethic, supportive of wild
foods ecologies.
In sum, edible weeds can become desirable for swerving peoples’ dietary habits a
step closer toward new gastronomic boundaries, located outside established norms,
but not as far as generally thought. We have options of achieving sustainability
34
B. Borsari and M. F. Vidrine
through edible weeds. Yet, these will be realized through land trusts and a mobiliza-
tion of citizens’ organizations that will make these changes occur. An approach,
which is inclusive of non-crop plants in agriculture possesses tangible beneﬁts
for both human and planetary health. It showcases possibilities and prospects for
achieving sustainability at the food system level, and beyond. We close with the
notion that ‘native’ plants or ‘native weeds,’ as they may be referred to by general
agriculturalists, couple potential research interests in growing weeds for food and
ﬁber with growing weeds to sustain natural habitats, which embrace agricultural
systems as we know them today and potentially extend their lifetimes.

Transitioning to a Sustainable Smart
Agriculture Using Deep Machine
Learning Techniques: The Case
of a Greek Project
Aristea Kounani, Alkiviadis Tsimpiris, and Dimitrios Varsamis
Abstract In these times of global crisis, agriculture has been confronted with many
challenges that must be met in order to serve a rapidly expanding global population
and contribute to the sustainability of the planet. Hence, Sustainable Smart Agri-
culture could provide better and faster solutions to the challenges that need to be
addressed. The concept of smart agriculture refers to the use of modern informa-
tion and communication technologies in agricultural production. The purpose of
this chapter is to demonstrate how to transition to a smart, sustainable agriculture
by using deep machine learning techniques. Additionally this chapter discusses a
research effort and an initiative developed by International Hellenic University, a
Greek university located in a rural area. A web service based on deep machine
learning has been developed by the research team to monitor crops and promote
agricultural sustainability. Using drone images of various crops at different develop-
mental stages, models were trained to diagnose and treat affected plants as quickly
as possible. Plant health is improved while avoiding the use of pesticides and fertil-
izers that cause numerous environmental issues, such as eutrophication and water
pollution, as well as posing a health threat to humans. The web-based application
enables Greek farmers to upload a picture of their crops and receive a prediction for
decision-making. Consequently, agricultural yields are expected to increase, while
transitioning to sustainable smart agriculture is expected to be promoted.
Keywords Sustainable smart agriculture · Deep machine learning · Plant disease
detection · Convolutional neural networks

1
Introduction
In recent years, the increase in per capita consumption of products has been one
of the main drivers of unpredictable environmental challenges, as a consequence of
the continuous increase in the needs for agricultural products of an ever-growing
global population (Berbel and Posadillo 2018). Thus, the agricultural sector needs
to increase global agricultural production by about 50% to meet the demands of a
world population expected to reach 10 billion by 2050 (FAO 2017). Nevertheless,
the production of increasingly nutritious and safe food not only does require more
arable land and inputs, such as water and energy, but also results in the depletion
of natural resources (Berkum and Dengerink 2019). Besides that, food production
is adversely affected by plant pests and diseases, which compromise the quality of
crops and negatively affect their productivity.
In many cases, plant pests and diseases have become a global threat to some crops,
making them a major concern for the agricultural sector (Arsenovic et al. 2019).
Chemical control can be a temporary solution, but may not be beneﬁcial in the long
run. Agrochemicals can have adverse effects on the crop, while at the same time they
can pose a health risk to farmers and rural residents alike (Panchal et al. 2021). Thus,
plant pathologists recommend continuous monitoring of the crop, as well as quick
and accurate diagnosis as a management and control measure, in order to minimize
production losses and maintain the viability of the crop (Abade et al. 2021). Conse-
quently, agriculture faces an increased challenge in identifying the symptoms of pests
and diseases that affect crops (Mohanty et al. 2016; Abade et al. 2021). In order to
counter these threats, agriculture must reduce pesticide and insecticide use (Toda and
Okura 2019), as well as promote sustainability in the sector. The Smart Sustainable
Agriculture is an initiative that could provide solutions to these challenges. By using
modern technologies, it is possible to increase the quantity of production as well as
the quality, while at the same time minimizing environmental impact and maximizing
the use of resources (Tao et al. 2021). The concept of smart sustainable agriculture
refers to the utilization of technology to improve the sustainability of the agricultural
industry, including the Internet of Things, big data analytics, smart supply chains,
sensors, robotics, artiﬁcial intelligence, and block chain (Jararweh et al. 2023).
Recent years have seen the development of a variety of diagnostic methods aimed
at preventing large losses in agricultural production. A standard approach to the
detection of infestations and the identiﬁcation of crop pests and diseases has tradi-
tionally relied on human intervention through visual inspection (Toda and Okura
2019), which is usually conducted after extensive damage has been done to the
crop (Bhatia et al. 2019). In today’ s technology-driven world, this method is often
combined or replaced by other techniques, such as machine learning (ML), deep
machine learning (DML), convolutional neural networks (CNN) etc., which are very
effective ways to detect plant pests and diseases. A number of image-based diag-
nostic methods have been introduced into practice as a result of the advancements in
technology and signiﬁcant cost reductions in digital imaging (West et al. 2003).
Transitioning to a Sustainable Smart Agriculture Using Deep Machine …
41
The goal of this chapter is to demonstrate how to transition to a smart, sustain-
able agriculture model. The case study describes a project that the Department
of Computer, Informatics, and Telecommunications Engineering of International
Hellenic University has developed in Serres, a rural area of Greece. Through this
project, the research team developed a new application and service for monitoring
and improving crops using DML. Drone images of different plants at different devel-
opmental stages were collected in order to train models in diagnosing affected plants
as effectively as possible, resulting in improved plant health. In this way, pesti-
cides and insecticides are reduced in agriculture, thus enhancing sustainability. In
this regard, the proposed system will prove useful to farmers as it enables them
to diagnose crop infestations in real time and support their decision to make more
rational use of pesticides as and when it is really necessary, and thus stop unneces-
sary spraying in cases where infestations are at very low levels or are not going to
cause signiﬁcant losses in the crop yield. Meanwhile, the system provides scientiﬁc
community, government agencies, and businesses with information on the spread of
crop pests and diseases at a regional level. Moreover, this research project contributes
to the advancement of sustainability research by maximizing the accuracy of correct
diagnosis, using automated methods for identifying plant pests and diseases, which
reduce input costs and increase crop yields.
2
Literature Review
2.1
Smart Sustainable Agriculture
Agricultural production and food systems have been disproportionately vulnerable
to a number of environmental challenges over the past few decades. The effects of
climate change events, the increased cost of energy, the shortage of arable land and
restricted water resources, as well as the continuing outﬂow of farmers, increase
the risk to global and national food security (Fu et al. 2021; O’Shaughnessy et al.
2021). Multiple governments have established national policies to address these
multifaceted challenges to ensure long-term sustainability and resilience of the agri-
cultural sector. Through the implementation of smart systems, this concept seeks
to provide solutions based on data from agricultural production. Additionally, to
ensure national security and protect natural resources, sustainable agriculture must
be promoted. The key objective is to emphasize on productivity enhancing tech-
nologies, such as mechanization and digitized farming, as critical to promoting agri-
cultural and climate-smart technologies and preventing environmental degradation
(Rasul 2021; Sanders et al. 2022; Lee and Kim 2022). Automatic irrigating systems
for each plot of land according to its particular characteristics and the weather fore-
cast, drones that monitor hundreds of acres to assess the growth and health of crops,
smart sensors that help detect pest and disease infestations in time. These are just
42
A. Kounani et al.
some of the advantages of smart agriculture, which can help eliminate hunger and
ensure a sustainable future (Kamilaris and Prenafeta-Boldu 2018).
As a result of utilizing a sustainable agriculture approach, farmers ensure the food
they produce for future generations without compromising the quality of the food
they are producing for the current generation (Dhanaraju et al. 2022). Combining
modern technology with eco-friendly practices, smart farming can improve agricul-
ture, increasing the quantity as well as quality of nutrition of food produced (O’Grady
and O’Hare 2017; Ramdinthara and Bala 2020).
Several advanced technologies have already been used in various agriculture prac-
tices in the past, including tillage, seedling, fertilization, weed detection, irrigation,
spraying pesticides, harvesting etc. Smart agriculture is an important step in global
agriculture history (Fawzy and El-Ramady 2022). There has been a dramatic change
in agriculture due to new technological developments that have changed the tradi-
tional way of farming and transformed conventional methods into a technique known
as the Internet of Things (Ramdinthara and Bala 2020). Through the combination of
satellite imagery and information from ground sensors, these systems enable farmers
to make informed decisions about how, when, and where to allocate resources. A fact
thatcontributestoachievingbettereconomicandecologicalresults(BachandMauser
2018). With the advent of this technology, agriculture has undergone a signiﬁcant
transformation that has the potential to lead to more accurate and efﬁcient farming.
Undoubtedly, proper automation of the cultivation process helps optimize crop
yield and ensure perpetual productivity and sustainability. There is a strong link
between increased productivity and economic growth. Thus, the application of smart
agriculture techniques in the agricultural sector can strengthen the development of
the economy in many countries (Elnemr 2019).
2.2
Application of Convolutional Neural Networks
in Sustainable Agriculture
Today, agriculture is in the early days of another revolution, centered on data and
connectivity. Artiﬁcial intelligence, analytics, connected sensors and other technolo-
gies could further increase yields, improve efﬁciency of water and other inputs, and
promote sustainability and resilience in crops and livestock. These are just some
of the beneﬁts of smart agriculture, which can help eradicate hunger and ensure a
sustainable future (Kamilaris and Prenafeta-Boldu 2018).
The use of CNNs for processing aerial photographs of vegetation can be success-
fully applied to various precision agriculture applications (Mate et al. 2016),
including:
• Weed extraction from ﬁelds using data obtained from robots with greater than
90% accuracy, as well as ﬂower detection to estimate ﬂowering intensity to
predict yields with a detection accuracy of 67–94% (depending on the plants
photographed) (Dias et al. 2018),
Transitioning to a Sustainable Smart Agriculture Using Deep Machine …
43
• Estimating yields from newly developing fruits, using multi-level perceptrons and
CNNs (Bargoti and Underwood 2017),
• IdentiﬁcationofvegetationfromGaofen-2remotesensingimages,whichprovides
accuracy of 89–90% (Zhang et al. 2018),
• Selection of agricultural land characteristics,
• Pests and diseases detection with high accuracy rates (96%) (Lin et al. 2019;
Ganchenko and Doudkin 2019).
In recent years, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), as a machine learning
approach, represent a ﬂexible approach to assimilate large amounts of heterogeneous
data and support reliable predictions of uncertain or complex phenomena (Good-
fellow et al. 2016). Thus, they show excellent results in the classiﬁcation of many
images, which allows researchers to improve the accuracy of classiﬁcations of plant
pests and diseases (Brahimi et al. 2018). Thus, systems that detect and identify plant
pests and diseases using CNN architectures have been proposed and are continuously
being proposed. In these systems, affected plant parts, e.g. leaf, can be captured in
order to detect and identify pests and diseases. The systems also have the ability to
generate heat maps, which provide information about the spread of disease in an area
as well as facilitate data analysis (Bhatia et al. 2019).
Convolutional Neural Networks are trained using images of healthy plants and
infected plants as inputs. The color or pattern information of the images triggers the
neuronsintheCNN.Sinceimagesofinfectedplantscontainfeaturesthatdifferentiate
them from those of healthy plants, it is possible to distinguish these features based on
patterns, colors, infection status, plant location, etc. Thus, when an image is imported,
these features are examined to determine whether the plant is healthy or affected by
a pest or a disease (Udawant and Srinath 2019).
2.3
State of the Art
In the last decade, several studies have been conducted using deep machine learning
techniques to automate the diagnosis of plant pests and diseases with high accu-
racy and validity (Arivazhagan and VinethLigi 2018). A few of them are mentioned
below indicatively. Therefore, Sladojevic et al. (2016) applied CNNs for the classi-
ﬁcation of plant diseases by collecting a dataset from publicly available images on
the Internet. Brahimi et al. (2017) classiﬁed tomato diseases using CNNs, based on
leaf images from PlantVillage’s public dataset. Lu et al. (2017) investigated the use
of CNNs to classify rice diseases. Arivazhagan and VinethLigi (2018) proposed an
automated method for identifying mango leaf diseases. Ale et al. (2019) introduced
a transfer learning technique based on densely connected convolutional networks
(DenseNet) to detect plant diseases. Arsenovic et al. (2019) developed a new dataset
containing real-life leaf images at different angles and in various weather conditions.
Richey et al. (2020) developed a mobile application-based technique for the detec-
tion and classiﬁcation of diseases in maize crops. Chohan et al. (2020) proposed
44
A. Kounani et al.
a model based on CNNs, using DL capabilities, for automatic detection of plant
diseases. Bedi and Gole (2021) proposed a new hybrid model for the automatic
detection of plant diseases that infect the leaves of peach plants using the Convo-
lutional Autoencoder-CAE network. Nagaraj et al. (2023) used the Plant Village
Dataset and the MobileNetV2 architecture to develop a CNN-based framework for
detecting pest-borne diseases on tomato leaves. Mahadevan et al. (2024) provided an
introduction to Rice Plant leaf blight diagnosis and symptoms, using conventional
methods to test real-time images. Rai and Pahuja’s (2024) research explored a real-
time, effective method for segmenting and detecting NLB diseases in maize crops
using a deep learning-based Attention U-Net model. Saraswat et al. (2024) exam-
ined optimistic solutions to detect fungus and bacteria in plants to improve their
health and freshness, using CNN, DL, artiﬁcial neural networks, ML, clustering and
deterministic probability-based data fusion.
Undoubtedly recent years have seen extensive research to identify and classify
plant pests and diseases (i.e., multiple diseases and pests that affect one plant, or a
single pest or disease that affects a number of plants) using advanced techniques like
CNNs which requires little or no pre-processing of the images.
3
The Case of the Greek Project
During the years 2022 and 2023, a group of academics and researchers from the
Department of Computer, Informatics, and Telecommunications Engineering of
International Hellenic University in Serres, a rural region of Northern Greece, initi-
ated a project. Among the key objectives of this project was the development of new
applications and services based on DML to monitor and improve crops cultivation
and yields. To promote sustainable practices in agriculture, the project intends to
reduce unnecessary spraying interventions and only use pesticides and insecticides
when necessary. Further, the project is intended to provide, implement, and utilize
smart agriculture techniques and solutions. The concept of Smart Agriculture refers
to the application of modern Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) in
the agricultural sector, thus it has the potential to provide solutions to the challenges
facing farmers today.
3.1
Short Description
In particular, this project developed innovative DML applications and models for
crop path estimation with image data. An online application has been developed
that allow the farmer to upload a photo taken by ones mobile phone and receive
as a response from the trained DL model the corresponding prediction towards the
growth and health of the crop for decision-making. For the proposed application,
the design of the appropriate algorithm and the development of relevant software
Transitioning to a Sustainable Smart Agriculture Using Deep Machine …
45
were required for the automatic estimation of the course of the crops from their
digital image. In addition, an asynchronous training platform was developed for
remote training of farmers on new technologies for sustainable crops, rational use of
pesticides-fertilizers and maintenance of machinery, sprayers, etc. In order to train
models to diagnose and treat affected plants as quickly as possible, drone images
of different crops were collected at different plant growth stages, as well as in ﬁeld
pictures taken by an agronomist, resulting in improved plant health while minimizing
the use of pesticides and fertilizers. As a result, through an online application, Greek
farmers can upload a photo of their crop and receive a prediction for decision-making
from the trained deep learning model. Thus, agricultural yields will increase on the
one hand, and the transition to sustainable smart agriculture will be promoted on the
other hand.
3.2
Project Implementation Methodology—Description
of Work Units
The part of the application dealing with the visual recognition of crop condition
utilized Deep Learning models such as GoogleNet and Resnet, along with a CNN
(Convolutional Neural Network) model. In the context of this project, these models
were trained and adapted to the environment and conditions of the problems it was
tasked with solving. A two-phase development process was followed when devel-
oping the software. Initially, a CNN model was developed using mathematical devel-
opment tools (proediting), and in the second phase, a web application was developed
to integrate these tools and provide access to them to registered users.
A schematic view of the implementation stages of the entire project is shown in
Fig. 1, while a more detailed description is provided in the following section.

1st Stage: Record requirements analysis
In order to ensure that the project is implemented correctly, initial mapping and
analysis of the project’s overall requirements, primarily involving the development
and operation of the systems under development, the needs of the end users, as well
as the framework for simulated testing of the results were conducted. Furthermore,
the acquisition of photographic material for the development and evolution of DML
algorithms and models were examined in light of issues and problems related to
real content acquisition. It was also investigated whether material can be used as
a “testbed” for the reliability control of algorithms for DML models designed ML
(Fig. 2).
2nd Stage: Architecture, technology framework and system management
The task involved designing and deﬁning a technological work framework that served
as the basis for software development, developing deep learning models, algorithms
for processing and categorization, asynchronous training systems, and integrating
and integrating all of these components. Figure 3 depicts the architecture of how a
typical CNN is structured as a sequence of stages (Liu et al. 2019).
In addition, software control tools (white box and black box techniques) were
deﬁned. Finally, the architecture for collecting, storing, processing, and presenting
the data were developed.
Fig. 2 Work organizing plan
Fig. 3 CNN’s structure (Based on Liu et al. 2019)
Transitioning to a Sustainable Smart Agriculture Using Deep Machine …
47
3rd Stage: selection, initial training and adaptation of algorithms to implement DL
models
As part of the crop image classiﬁcation component of the application, DML tech-
niques were used with CNN models. These models were applied to the categorization
of images, from a vast database of images, which could be classiﬁed into thousands
of categories and relate to various types of content. An evaluation of CNN models
parameterized in the problem environment, such as Google Net and ResNet, was
carried out. Meanwhile, a new CNN model with a shallower depth than previously
known models was developed by the project team and parameterized so that its
performance is comparable to or even better than the well-known pre-trained models.
The appropriate conﬁguration and assignment of roles was carried out to the selected
users after a software asynchronous training platform (e.g. Moodle, Open eclass) was
selected and installed on a server. The responsible party also developed modules with
educational and informational material pertaining to the rational use of pesticides
and fertilizers as well as the correct use of spraying equipment.
4th Stage: Generating additional training data and retraining and optimizing deep
learning algorithms
In order to achieve consistently high accuracy of the CNN model regardless of
lighting conditions, viewing angle and distance, a larger and heterogeneous training
dataset consisting of thousands of images was created to train the system. To capture
the images of the crops, a drone was used that was directed to certain heights in
order to capture the images from different angles and distances. Images were also
taken of the same crops with both smart mobile device cameras and a still camera.
Each image was properly characterized by an agronomist for the growth stage and
category of the crop as well as the identiﬁcation and identiﬁcation of the enemies and
diseases that have attacked the cultivated plants. Using the extended learning data,
the algorithms that the previous stages arrived at were retrained and optimized. The
end result was the trained algorithms and deep learning model used to complete a
uniﬁed web application and lead to the complete project solution. The installation of
an open software asynchronous education platform and enrichment with appropriate
content was also carried out.
5th Stage: Integrating DML models into a web application and adding automation
features-Web application development and integration of the deep machine learning
model as well as its operation as a web service
It involved developing a web application (Fig. 4) that communicates with a DML
model that has been developed, parameterized, and trained on thousands of crops of
photographs. According to the rights that have been assigned to the user, the web
application identiﬁes him and allows him to access the appropriate features.
The communication of the web application with the asynchronous training plat-
form was conducted by integrating automatic communication capabilities with users
and agronomists with the web application. A deep machine learning model and
related software were designed and developed, and the results were disseminated
48
A. Kounani et al.
Fig. 4 The web application of the project
to the scientiﬁc community through publications. It is important to convey the key
messages and outcomes of the project during and after its completion, as well as
to highlight its positive impacts. The results were disseminated, communicated, and
publicized primarily through the website and social media presence, as well as third
party websites.
3.3
Results
Among the outcomes of the project was the development of applications and models
for crop path estimation based on deep machine learning algorithms. An online
application was developed that allows farmers to upload photos of their crops and
receive a response from the trained DL model with the corresponding prediction for
decision making. As a result, they are able to make an informed decision regarding
the methods to be employed in order to deal with any threats to their crops. This
prevents unnecessary spraying interventions and the use of pesticides and insecticides
is restricted to when necessary, in order to promote sustainable agricultural practices.
Figure 5 illustrates how the web service identiﬁes an infested or a healthy plant
and determines the nature of the infestation. Moreover, Figs. 6, 7 and 8 illustrate the
step-by-step process of using the application by farmers. This application required
the design of an appropriate algorithm and the development of relevant software for
the automatic assessment of the progress of crops based on the digital images of the
crops.

Meanwhile, the outcome of the project was the creation of an asynchronous

sprayer maintenance. In order to determine the best solution, results are compared.
By automating crop progress information, a number of advantages will be provided
to the farmer and business, including faster and more efﬁcient operation throughout
the entire crop process, as well as continuous training and information via an
asynchronous platform education platform.
A few highlights of the project’s beneﬁts and outcomes are listed below:
• The application automatically updates the crop status upon taking a photo.
• There is a user proﬁle and a crop proﬁle for each crop
• There is a record of the history of each crop available to the agronomist for a more
informed opinion. In addition, photos taken by a drone or from a mobile device
can reduce the transition period from one crop to another.
• Using the system will minimize the possibility of a wrong diagnosis by the
agronomist due to the system’s training, and it will provide a ﬁrst estimate to
the agronomist. This will increase the company’s clientele.
• Providing timely information on disease management to farmers
• The use of pesticides and insecticides is restricted to when necessary, thereby
promoting sustainable agriculture.

4
Conclusions
In order to increase food production, sustainable agriculture must be implemented to
protect natural ecosystems, while maintaining nutritional value and safety. Detecting
the various natural phenomena occurring in these environments is an effective means
of achieving this goal. Agricultural ecosystems can be understood using remote
sensing, big data analysis, cloud computing and Internet of Things.
In the past few years, machine vision, digital image processing and image analysis
have strongly advanced to be and a signiﬁcant part of artiﬁcial intelligence and the
interface between human and machine-based theory and applied technology. These
technologies have been widely applied in industry and medicine, and efforts are being
made to apply them to the agricultural sector as well. Thus, DML has signiﬁcantly
improved the identiﬁcation and diagnosis of various plant pests and diseases.
An examination of the transition to smart sustainable agriculture utilizing
DML techniques is presented in this chapter. The case study of an initiative developed
by the International Hellenic University, a Greek university located in a rural area,
was also discussed. Developed by a research team of the Department of Computer,
Informatics, and Telecommunications Engineering, this project aims to develop new
applications and services that rely heavily on deep machine learning, for the purpose
of promoting sustainable agricultural practices. Several models have been developed
to diagnose and treat a variety of crops during various developmental stages in a
timely manner, and drone images have been collected at various stages to improve
plant health and reduce pesticide and fertilizer usage, thereby improving plant health.
As a result, crop yields can be increased in a more sustainable manner. By uploading
a photo of their crop, Greek farmers receive a decision-making insight via a web
service. So, this project proved to be an excellent technique that can facilitate farmers
to quickly and easily identify their crop infestations in real time in the ﬁeld.
Modern technologies and smart agriculture techniques are being applied in
the agricultural sector to increase harvests and minimize losses, which directly
contributes to sustainability. Providing an environment-friendly option for agricul-
ture, the reduction of agrochemical inputs is beneﬁcial for the environment, while at
the same time increase the income of farmers due to the harvest of a larger, healthier
and safer crop. Furthermore, a reduced use of agrochemicals protects both farmers’
health and that of rural residents as well.
In the next step, the web service should be evaluated by the farmers in order to
identify the difﬁculties and make the appropriate impovements.

Sustainable Infrastructure and Climate
Change: Natural Disaster Risk Insurance
Solutions for Belt and Road Countries
Jintao Yang, Kirill Savrassov, and Nikolai Gorbatchev
Abstract There is a strong relationship between climate change and natural catas-
trophes. Climate change pertains to enduring alterations in temperature, rainfall,
and additional atmospheric conditions, which arise from human actions, predom-
inantly the combustion of fossil fuels. Natural catastrophes encompass extensive
natural disasters such as hurricanes, ﬂoods, and droughts, which result in extensive
destruction on a massive scale. Chapter’s objectives include analysis of infrastruc-
ture sustainability of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) countries located on transport
corridor China—EU. BRI aiming at the creation of infrastructure for international
trade between African, European and Asian countries, according to the World Bank,
will increase the volume of trade by 30%, the volume of foreign investment by
70%, can help the upliftment of 7.6 million individuals from severe poverty and
improve the conditions for 32 million individuals in moderate poverty. Applica-
tion the insurance-linked securities (ILS) mechanisms can assist in rapid access to
ﬁnances for local communities in case of natural catastrophes. This is important as
over 62% of the region’s transport infrastructure is at risk from natural disasters,
referring to report “Climate Change and Earthquake Impacts in the Asia–Paciﬁc
Region Energy and Transport Infrastructure Assessment” (Asian Development Bank
2022. Climate Change and Earthquake Exposure in Asia and The Paciﬁc Assess-
ment of Energy and Transport Infrastructure. Accessed 5 June 2023 from 10.22617/
TCS178839-2). Employed methodology included studying the statistical data and
analysis of querying the insurance professionals on insurance-based approach to the
implementation of SDGs and natural disaster protections of developing countries.
As a result, insurance coverage for natural catastrophes is an important issue for

these countries linked to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): climate change,

Keywords Sustainable infrastructure · Climate change · Natural disaster risk
