1
Introduction
The global community has made a concerted effort to incorporate sustainability into
activities across all sectors since the introduction of the Sustainable Development
Goals (SDGs) (UN 2015). The goals seek to address global challenges like poverty,
inequality, degradation of the environment, and climate change, alongside promoting
peace and justice (Leal Filho et al. 2023). The initial idea of SDGs was targeted at
the three aspects of sustainability: environmental, economic, and social spheres.
Investing in infrastructure plays an essential role in the achievement of sustainable
development. Making incorrect decisions could lead to neglecting the requirements
of groups and nations. SDGs principles are aimed at efforts towards the creation of
an inclusive, sustainable, and resilient future for populations and the planet.
The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) was launched in 2013 (McBride et al. 2023).
Thus, it had to follow the SDGs approach in public development. The BRI holds
substantial promise in aiding nations in their pursuit of sustainable development. This
aims to promote enduring environmentally friendly and sustainable progress to all
concerned nations, in alignment with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.
The creation of infrastructure for international trade with Asian countries,
according to the World Bank, will increase the volume of trade by 30%, the volume
of foreign investment by 70%, and alleviate extreme poverty for 7.6 million indi-
viduals while raising 32 million individuals from moderate poverty (Asian Devel-
opment Bank 2022). The project requires signiﬁcant investments in the creation
of infrastructure. According to the Organization for Economic Co-operation and
Development (OECD 2018) and the American Enterprise Institute (AEI 2023),
from December 2013 to December 2022, China’s involvement in the BRI, which
encompasses construction agreements funded by Chinese ﬁnancial institutions, and
investments, reached a total value of approximately 881 billion US dollars.
The research on climate change and earthquake impacts in the Asia–Paciﬁc region
energy and transport infrastructure assessment indicates that more than 62% of the
region’s transport infrastructure is at risk from natural disasters (Asian Development
Bank 2022). At the same time, energy infrastructure facilities are subject to the
risks of earthquakes (72.4%), cyclones (22.4%) and sea level rise (8.3%). It can be
stated that there is an increase in risks for governments and the population associated
with global natural and climate change. The damage caused by them over the past 30
years has increased by more than ﬁve times. According to experts, direct and indirect
damage from major disasters is 4–5% of the gross national product (Lane 2022).
Sustainable Infrastructure and Climate Change: Natural Disaster Risk …
57
In addition to the risks of natural disasters, many of the BRI countries are devel-
oping countries. Natural disasters occurring in low-income countries lead to a signif-
icant surge in social inequality. The recovery of such countries after natural disasters
takes longer, which leads to a decline in the living standards of the population for a
long period.
This issue is topical to most countries. According to the current UN SDGs progress
report, as of the end of 2022, the number of countries with local governments imple-
menting disaster risk reduction strategies had risen to 102, which is a signiﬁcant
increase compared to the 51 countries reported in 2015 (UN 2023).
As the amount of natural catastrophes increase due to climate change, the current
agenda for sustainable development research is closely related with rapid elimination
of their consequences.
This paper discusses one of the promising solutions for ﬁnancing the elimination
of possible consequences of natural catastrophes, namely insurance-linked securities
(ILS).ILSareﬁnancialderivativesthatprovideinvestmentattractivenessofinsurance
risks, allowing institutional investors to directly participate in the reinsurance of
peak risks in exchange for an acceptable level of proﬁtability. They are designed to
transfer risks from the insurance industry to the much larger capital markets, allowing
insurers or government agencies to shift some of their catastrophic risks to investors,
providing the latter with a unique diversiﬁcation of investment portfolios, since these
instruments are not subject to macroeconomic cycles and in no way associated with
ﬂuctuations in the stock, currency and other markets.
2
Methodology
The authors studied statistical data available from different sources related to the
economic sustainability of countries of the EU-China transport corridor directly or
indirectly related to SDGs:
SDG 9—Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure encompasses the development
of critical infrastructure, including disaster-resilient infrastructure, which is a key
component in the prevention and management of catastrophes.
SDG 11—Sustainable Cities and Communities, which focuses on building resilient
and sustainable cities and communities, enhancing the preparation for and response
to catastrophes.
SDG 13—Climate Action, as it addresses the need for countries to mitigate carbon
emissions and adapt to the consequences of climate change, such as the heightened
occurrence and intensity of extreme weather.
The statistical data analysis included such indicators as:
– distribution of BRI countries by income level required for understanding the
ﬁnancial stability of local communities in case of natural catastrophes;
58
J. Yang et al.
– non-life insurance penetration rates for China-EU transport corridor countries for
2018–2022 to identify the availability of ﬁnances to the local communities in case
of disaster occurrence;
– estimation of the volume of reserve state funds intended to combat the conse-
quences of natural disasters and other emergency situations, which are important
for ﬁnancial sustainability at the state level.
In addition, the present research is based on the results of a questionnaire among
alumni of the CPD-certiﬁed course “The Fundamentals of ILS” (ILS n.d.). The
methodology for this research involved administering a questionnaire to 121 insur-
ance professionals to gather their opinions and knowledge about the UN SDGs and
catastrophes. The survey included questions related to the perception of current risks
facing the infrastructure, current insurance and risk management practices, under-
standing of the ILS approach, and the willingness and ability of respondents to partic-
ipate in providing coverage for infrastructure risks. The questionnaire also assessed
therespondents’understandingofhowthisapproachcancontributetomeetingSDGs.
The ﬁrst step in the process was to design the questionnaire, which consisted of
a mix of closed-ended and open-ended questions. The closed-ended questions were
aimed at collecting quantitative data and included multiple choice questions and
Likert scale questions where respondents could rate their level of agreement with a
statement on a scale of 1–5. The open-ended questions were aimed at collecting
qualitative data and allowed respondents to provide more detailed and nuanced
answers.
After the survey responses were collected, the data were analyzed utilizing
descriptive statistical methods. Descriptive statistics were applied for summarizing
the data and providing an overview of the respondents’ opinions. The results were
generalized for understanding the relationship between knowledge about the SDGs
and attitudes towards catastrophe bonds.
Finally, the results of the survey were compiled into a report that summarized
the ﬁndings and provided insights into the current state of knowledge and attitudes
among insurance professionals towards the SDGs and catastrophe bonds.
3
Belt and Road Initiative
By building and maintaining the infrastructure, communities can improve access to
basic human needs while also supporting economic growth. Furthermore, sustainable
infrastructure development can contribute to reduced carbon emissions, increased
energy efﬁciency, and improved natural resource management.
Infrastructure projects have a signiﬁcant impact on the promotion of sustainable
development. Infrastructure refers to the basic physical and organizational structures
and facilities that are essential to the functioning of society, such as roads, bridges,
water systems, schools, hospitals, and power grids. An adequate and well-functioning
infrastructure is essential for economic growth and development as it ensures the
Sustainable Infrastructure and Climate Change: Natural Disaster Risk …
59
efﬁcient production, distribution and exchange of goods and services. It also supports
social development by providing better employment, access to quality education, and
improved healthcare.
Moreover, investments in infrastructure create new jobs and stimulate economic
activity, which leads to further development.
In addition, by providing access to basic services, infrastructure can improve
living standards and help reduce poverty. Infrastructure holds a critical position in a
country’s development, underpinning economic and social progress and supporting
the well-being and prosperity of communities.
Oneofthelargestinfrastructureprojectsofthe21stcenturyistheBRI,launchedby
the Chinese government in 2013. It is aimed at connecting countries in Asia, Europe,
Africa and Oceania with networks of roads, railways, ports and other transport infras-
tructure facilities in order to develop trade, investment and economic cooperation
between the participating countries.
The initiative is based on two main components: the Silk Road Economic Belt,
with the objective of linking China to Europe via Central and West Asia, and the
Maritime Silk Road, aiming to establish connections between China, Southeast Asia,
Africa, and Europe.
The BRI is seen as an investment and development opportunity for participating
countries. To this end, China allocates signiﬁcant investment to ﬁnance infrastructure
projects. This initiative has been supported by many countries, especially in Asia and
Africa, as a way to foster their economic growth and connectivity with the rest of
the world.
At the time of this writing, the memorandum on participation in the BRI has been
signed by 147 states (Fanhai International School of Finance n.d.), of which:
– 43 countries are in sub-Saharan Africa;
– 35 BRI countries are located in Europe and Central Asia (including 18 EU
countries that are part of the BRI);
– 25 countries are in East Asia and the Paciﬁc region;
– 20 BRI countries are located in Latin America and the Caribbean;
– 18 BRI countries in the Middle East and North Africa;
– 6 countries are in Southeast Asia.
The level of national income in the BRI countries is shown in Table 1. A signiﬁcant
part of the countries participating in the initiative belongs to countries with lower
middle income. This leads to instability and inequality of access to resources in the
development of the project infrastructure.
Critics of the initiative raise a number of concerns (Lo 2021; Enderwick 2021),
including concerns about the project’s debt sustainability and transparency, China’s
growing global inﬂuence, and the environmental impact and potential cultural bias
of some infrastructure projects.
Despite this, the BRI is playing an important role today in promoting interna-
tional trade, investment and economic cooperation (Belt and Road Portal n.d.). For
sustainable China-EU transport links, the geographically key states of the BRI are

Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Mongolia, Russia, Turkey and Uzbek-

natural disasters, we can mention that they are developing countries that have to
implement the local disaster reduction risk strategies (UN 2023). Some of examples
from policies of Georgia and Kazakhstan are provided by Großmann et al. (2023).
However, this paper adds examples from more BRI countries.
4
Infrastructure Sustainability for BRI Transit Countries
The main problems hindering the formation of a comprehensive system for protecting
infrastructure from the consequences of natural disasters for the China-EU transit
countries are the extremely low coverage of insurance and a large share of state
ownership of transport infrastructure facilities.
Despite the high risks of catastrophes in the BRI countries, the level of insurance
coverage (insurance penetration) is extremely low. The insurance coverage parameter
serves as a measure of the growth of the insurance industry within a nation. It is
determined by dividing the total insurance premiums by the gross domestic product
(GDP) for a speciﬁc year (Enz 2000).
The following formula is used to calculate the level of insurance penetration:
IPR =

GDP Gross Domestic Product, represents the total value of all products and services
produced within a speciﬁc nation during a speciﬁed timeframe.
Results for BRI countries are listed in Table 2.
For most countries, the level of insurance coverage is proportional to the level of
wealth growth. However, in the countries under consideration, the structure of GDP

leads to a negative correlation between insurance coverage and the share of natural
resource rent.
This effect is observed in countries with economies heavily dependent on natural
resources (for example, Russia or Kazakhstan). The negative correlation between
insurance coverage and the share of natural resource rent in GDP can be explained
by the following factors:
1. Economic dependence on natural resources: in countries where a signiﬁcant
part of GDP comes from the extraction of natural resources, the economy can
be highly concentrated in a particular industry or sector, which can lead to an
uneven distribution of wealth and economic activity. In such cases, insurance
coverage may be perceived as less important or necessary, since natural resource
wealth can be used to cover potential losses or risks.
2. Public safety nets and subsidies: In countries with signiﬁcant resource rents,
the government may provide safety nets or subsidies to individuals or busi-
nesses, which reduces the perceived need for insurance coverage. For example,
the government may provide subsidies for fuel, utilities, or other essential goods
and services in times of natural disasters. This results in a reduced demand for
insurance coverage, as individuals and legal entities rely on government support
in the event of adverse events.
3. Risk perception and cultural factors. Risk perception and cultural variables may
also contribute to the insurance coverage level. In some countries with high
resource rents, there is a belief that the risks associated with property, liability or
other non-death events are small or that they can be mitigated through traditional
or informal budgetary mechanisms rather than with the help of insurance.
62
J. Yang et al.
It is crucial to acknowledge that the presence of correlation does not necessarily
indicate causality, and that there may be other variables that affect insurance coverage
in countries with high resource rents. In addition, the relationship between GDP
structure and insurance coverage can be complex and vary by country, economic
context, and other factors. Further research and analysis will be needed to better
understand the relationship between GDP structure, resource rents and insurance
coverage across regions and countries. Also, an important obstacle to the organization
of an effective system for protecting infrastructure from natural disasters is local
protectionism in reinsurance (Global Reconstruction Foundation 2023). This practice
leads to the concentration of risks within the country, while limiting the choice, and
is observed to one degree or another in Belarus, China, Mongolia, Uzbekistan, and
Russia.
Addressing the pressing and extensive issues encountered by developing nations
in the event of a signiﬁcant natural disaster, it becomes imperative to prioritize
employing inventive approaches for ﬁnancing the aftermath of such disastrous risks.
For emergency disaster ﬁnance, these innovations include national disaster funds,
regional pooling schemes using parametric insurance, conditional credit lines,
catastrophe bonds, and other insurance derivatives market solutions.
Discussing the issues of infrastructure sustainability of this countries, it is neces-
sary to mention that the key challenges faced by sustainable infrastructure designs is
the low risk-adjusted returns they tend to generate. This is primarily due to the fact
that investments in sustainability are often not adequately compensated by revenue
streams or public incentives (International Institute for Sustainable Development
2018). However, it is crucial to create a supportive environment that encourages
investment in sustainable infrastructure. This can be done through the introduction
of appropriate ﬁnancial mechanisms, such as subsidies, tax incentives, and grants,
targeting sustainable projects.
5
Sustainability of Available Funds for Natural Disasters
A high proportion of state ownership of infrastructure may discourage the clas-
sical disaster insurance model, as there is a high risk that insurance companies and
government agencies will be forced to interact as parties with common interests.
When the state owns most of the major infrastructure, like roads, bridges, and
power plants, among others, natural disasters can result in considerable damage
to both state property and its population. In this situation, insurance companies
may face a number of difﬁculties in determining the actual number of losses and
indemniﬁcation.
Therefore, in some cases, government agencies may choose to create their own
reserve fund or use alternative methods of ﬁnancing, such as government loans, to
protect their property and population in the event of natural disasters.
Sustainable Infrastructure and Climate Change: Natural Disaster Risk …
63
Some of these countries have reserve public funds designed to deal with natural
disasters and other emergencies. An estimate of the volumes of these funds is given
in Table 3.
China has set up several reserve funds to fund disaster relief and disaster recovery
efforts. The National Disaster Reduction and Relief Fund is administered by the
Ministry of Finance and is used to provide emergency relief and support to disaster-
affected areas. As of 2021, the fund has accumulated more than 190 billion yuan
(approximately $29 billion) in reserves, according to ofﬁcial ﬁgures. The Natural
Disaster Insurance Fund is administered by the China Insurance Regulatory Commis-
sion and is used to compensate for losses caused by natural disasters. The Fund is
mainly ﬁnanced by insurance premiums paid by individuals and legal entities. As of
2021, the fund has accumulated over 50 billion yuan (approximately $7.7 billion) in
reserves.
The World Bank (PreventionWeb n.d.) recommends to the countries of Central
Asia the creation of a regional disaster risk insurance pool, which would contribute
to the rapid growth of demand for separate coverage of catastrophe risks in each of
the countries of the region through the introduction of compulsory insurance of the
entire housing stock in cities. In addition to enabling local homeowners to purchase
affordable and reliable insurance coverage, a regional insurance pool mechanism
would also reduce the ﬁnancial exposure of local insurers and governments to catas-
trophe risk. Given the higher level of development of the Kazakhstan insurance
market compared to other countries in the region, apparently Almaty could be the
most suitable place for placing such a regional insurance fund.
In world practice, there are four commonly used approaches for ﬁnancing the
mitigation of the effects caused by natural disasters (Table 4).

Description
National disaster funds
Internal budget rule. Authorities have the option to utilize ﬁscal means
to take advantage of reserve funds. The government’s allocated budget
determines the expenditure for the reserve fund. Another approach is
for governments to secure loans to ﬁnance emergency funds, whereby
the expenses include the present value of the principal amount and the
interest payments on the borrowed funds. Additionally, governments
may assume the responsibility of covering the administrative or legal
expenses linked to the establishment of a reserve fund
Conditional credit lines
Pre-negotiated “deferred” credit lines with international ﬁnancial
institutions, such as World Bank, International Bank for
Reconstruction and Development, Islamic Development Bank etc. The
cost of a conditional loan consists of two elements: the present value
of the loan’s principal and interest payments for any portion that has
been utilized, typically offered at lower interest rates by multilateral
development banks compared to what the country paid in the private
market, along with the costs linked to the transaction
Sovereign parametric
insurance products
Numerous regional insurance pools have been established by
governments and development partners with the aim of providing
developing nations with sovereign parametric insurance. The cost is
the insurance premium on the policy paid by the government. The level
of the premium is primarily determined by expected losses (taking into
account the selected policy options). Other factors, including
reinsurance and operating costs, also affect the level of premiums
Catastrophe bonds
(CAT bonds)
Transferring disaster risk to private capital markets. The cost of a
catastrophe bond consists of two elements: the present value of the
annual coupon payments that need to be made by the issuer throughout
the duration of the catastrophe bond, along with the expenses and fees
related to the transaction in terms of legality and administration
Source prepared by authors
A successful example of natural disaster resilience is the Bosphorus catastrophe
bonds issued by the Turkish Catastrophe Insurance Pool (TCIP), which is a state-
owned insurance company in Turkey. The bonds are intended to transfer the risk of
natural disasters, such as earthquakes and ﬂoods in the Istanbul region, from TCIP
to investors in the capital markets.
Bosphorus Catastrophe bonds were ﬁrst issued in 2013 and were the ﬁrst catas-
trophe bonds issued by a Turkish entity. The bonds were issued in several tranches
with different maturities and coverages. The triggers were speciﬁc natural disasters:
earthquakes or ﬂoods, which correspond to predetermined criteria.

6
Surveying Insurance Professionals on SDGs and Natural
Catastrophe Protection
In order to conﬁrm the hypothesis of correlations between the ILS approach for the
protection of critical infrastructure of the China-EU transport route and SDGs, a
survey was introduced to 121 insurance market professionals.
Research Objective: The aim of this research is to investigate the feasibility of
introducing an ILS approach for protecting the critical infrastructure of China-EU
transport routes. Additionally, the research will examine how this approach can
contribute to SDGs and increase the resiliency of infrastructure against natural
disasters and human-caused disruptions.
Data Collection: Data was collected using a questionnaire addressed to alumni
of the CPD-certiﬁed course “The Fundamentals of ILS”. As a selection method, the
random sampling method was used. The locations of the respondents are indicated
in Fig. 1.
It is notable that participants from Europe (30%) and Asia (27%) had the
highest representation among the regions surveyed. Professionals from various
regions, including Africa and Australia/Oceania, participated in the research, thereby
providing a more diverse and global perspective.
Professional segmentation of survey participants is available in Table 5.
These results indicate that (re-)insurers constituted the largest proportion of partic-
ipants at 35%, indicating a strong interest within the industry in the relationship
between SDGs and ILS. It is also notable that Sovereign Pools, Academia, Asset
Managers, and Brokers all had notable representation among the respondents, with
each making up more than 10% of the participants. The diverse range of professionals
who participated in the survey is very encouraging, as it suggests that there is a broad
interest in understanding the connections between SDGs and ILS.

It is encouraging to see that the majority (80%) of the respondents considered
SDGs to be “very important” and “highly important”, indicating a strong recognition
among insurance professionals of the signiﬁcance of creating sustainable solutions
thatenableenvironmentalandsocialprogress.Furthermore,afurther20%considered
SDGs “important”, highlighting the interest that insurers have in aligning with global
sustainable development goals. It is vital for the ﬁnancial industry to realize that
SDGs not only align with their corporate social responsibility targets but also present
enormous business opportunities for insurance and ﬁnancial companies.
On the question “In your opinion, which SDGs are most relevant to the insurance
industry and ILS?” the responders graded them in the following way:
1. Goal 17: Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the Global
Partnership for Sustainable Development.
2. Goal 13: Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts.
3. Goal 11: Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and
sustainable.
4. Goal 7: Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for
all.

sustainable agriculture.

7
Conclusions
This research was based on two main approaches:
– studying the statistical data related to critical infrastructure in BRI coun-
tries located on transport route China—EU (China, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan,
Mongolia, Türkiye, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Belarus)
– results of querying the insurance professionals on insurance-based approach to the
implementation of SDGs and natural disaster protections of developing countries.
The Chinese government’s BRI includes the construction of various transport
infrastructure projects such as roads, railways, ports and pipelines to facilitate trade
and economic integration between participating countries. The Belt and Road coun-
tries that are part of the China-EU land transport corridor are at high risk of natural
disasters. This leads to the uncertainty associated with possible physical damage to
the infrastructure being built, potential disruption of supply chains, as well as impacts
on local communities due to the risk of damage to the local economy, disruption of
the social fabric, labor availability, etc.
The main lessons from the paper are:
1. There are peculiarities of investment in infrastructure facilities by the Chinese
government. In the vast majority of cases, the money is allocated under the
guarantees of the governments of the countries where the investments are made.
In the event of natural disasters, the risks are borne by local governments.
2. Sustainable infrastructure and climate change are two crucial aspects that need
to be addressed simultaneously. The implementation of ILS for BRI countries
is to mitigate the effects of climate change and reduce the damage caused by
Sustainable Infrastructure and Climate Change: Natural Disaster Risk …
69
natural disasters. The development of infrastructure and the implementation of
inclusive and accessible insurance mechanisms can help ensure sustainable and
resilient growth in these countries.
3. One of the few options for obtaining additional ﬁnancing to deal with major
natural disasters is World Bank conditional loans. To obtain them, a number
of conditions must be met (compliance with certain ﬁnancial management and
sustainability standards, a minimum damage threshold set by the World Bank).
In addition, the country must agree to the terms of the loan proposed by the World
Bank, such as interest rate, loan term, repayment schedule and other conditions.
That is, the loan leads to an increase in public debt to the World Bank for a state
affected by a natural disaster, which can make the macroeconomic position of
the state that suffered from natural disasters unsustainable.
4. Effective collaboration and partnership between governments, private sector
stakeholders,andinternationalorganizationscanleadtopractical,innovative,and
sustainable solutions in infrastructure and policy planning. These solutions can
help countries adapt to the changing climate and ensure sustainable development
for future generations.
5. ILS, as they are based on the capital market and can offer competitive conditions
on the cost of capital. Also, these instruments provide an opportunity for insurers
and reinsurers to diversify risk by raising capital from various sources, which
can reduce risk-related capital investments and improve the ﬁnancial stability of
companies. ILS allow for fast payouts in the event of an insurance trigger as they
are based on pre-determined activation and payout criteria, which can facilitate
a faster response to natural disasters and help manage ﬁnancial challenges.
The results of this paper also indicate that insurance professionals have deep
understanding of relations between natural catastrophes preventions and protection
and SDGs.
ILS professionals that participated in the research, suggested the following actions
for BRI countries that are directly addressing the following SDGs (SDG-1, SDG-3,
SDG-5, SDG-7, SDG-8, SDG-9, SDG-13, SDG-14, SDG-15, SDG-16):
1. Developing ILS that speciﬁcally target investments in green and sustainable
infrastructure projects, such as renewable energy or sustainable transport.
2. Developing ILS that cover risks associated with climate change, such as extreme
weather events, sea-level rise, or agricultural losses, to help reduce vulnerability
and build resilience.
3. Developing ILS that support sustainable development goals in developing coun-
tries, such as ﬁnancing for health and education, small and medium-sized
enterprises, or microﬁnance.
4. Developing ILS that promote biodiversity conservation and ecosystem services,
such as supporting reforestation or coastal protection projects.
5. Developing ILS that address social and governance issues, such as supporting
projects that promote gender equality, human rights, or transparency and
accountability.
70
J. Yang et al.
Outlining the future research prospects, our team plans to link it with the
assessment of the possibility of implementing the “System of global indicators for
achieving sustainable development goals and achieving the goals of the 2030 Agenda
for Sustainable Development” (UN 2017) to insurance protection against natural
disasters using the ILS mechanisms.

Ecotourism: The Concept
and the Practice of Sustainability Within
Tourism
Cláudia Toriz Ramos and Allison Margaret Byrne
Abstract Sustainability is a challenge for tourism since it often implies travel-
ling and high levels of consumption. As a concept, sustainable tourism envisions a
major change: making tourism compatible with environmental sustainability without
hindering both the economic and the social beneﬁts it brings. It is therefore about
introducing a third arm of positive impacts, which are environmental impacts.
Tourism thus becomes an interesting focal point in a sustainability research agenda,
due to the opportunity it creates for testing the possibilities of convergence between
the economic, the social and the environmental pillars of sustainability. Ecotourism
is a particular type of tourism and, given its speciﬁcities, a privileged ﬁeld for
testing sustainability, whether ‘strong’ or ‘weak’. The chapter has two main foci: the
genesis and conceptual contours of ecotourism within sustainable tourism and policy-
oriented practices, standardisation and benchmarking in sustainability. Additionally,
a selection of cases in ecotourism are presented in brief, in order to characterise
ecotourism as a ﬁeld for the sustainability research agenda.
Keywords Ecotourism · Sustainable tourism · Nature tourism · Conservation ·
Ecological standards

C. T. Ramos and A. M. Byrne
1
Introduction
Sustainability is a major challenge for tourism, since it often implies travelling and
elevated levels of consumption. Tourism is therefore an interesting focal point in a
sustainability research agenda (Leal Filho et al. 2018; McCool and Bosak 2019),
because of the opportunity it creates for testing the possibilities of balancing the
economic, the social and the environmental pillars of sustainability (Purvis et al.
2019). Tourism impacts all three levels: as economic activity; as a generator of
jobs, wealth and well-being; and as a consumer-driven activity, normally associated
with high levels of consumption, and thus a depletor of natural resources. Whether
coupling tourism with sustainability is possible at all and, if so, whether from a
‘strong’ sustainability perspective (i.e., one that does not compromise the environ-
mental pillar to beneﬁt the other two), or solely from a rather ‘weak sustainability’
standpoint, as put forward in the debate that emerged in environmental economics,
years ago (cf. Ayres et al. 2001), are the paramount questions for a sustainability
research agenda on tourism.
Ecotourism, as further discussed below, is a speciﬁc type of tourism and an inter-
esting ﬁeld for testing the conditions of this balance. Its conservation approach, its
insertion within local communities, and its small scale, all contribute to providing
an economic activity guided by environmental concerns but also bearing substantial
positive social impacts. However, such an approach is hardly compatible with the
scale of present- day tourism, and thus may remain very limited in scope (Fennell
2020; TIES 2019).
For tourism, standardisation and benchmarking have also become assessment
techniques of sustainability performance, both at the level of policy analysis and
for businesses. Available tools, as further illustrated in the text, provide for statis-
tics and comparison. These instruments can also serve a research agenda on the
sustainability of tourism by providing standardised and comparative data (GSTC
2022b). Furthermore, tourism, and ecotourism in particular, encompasses different
types of stakeholders: from tourism operators to the many agents of the local commu-
nities, and the tourists themselves, who are the clients, but who can also perform as
self-aware ecotourists. The interaction between all these stakeholders substantially
contributes to the outcome of the ‘industry’, in terms of its sustainability goals, and
thus constitutes yet another ﬁeld of research.
This chapter aims to frame the discussion on sustainable tourism as a focal point
in a sustainability research agenda and, within this, undertakes the speciﬁc objective
of analysing ecotourism, namely its standardisation, in order to hypothesise whether
it can showcase a strong sustainability approach to tourism; if so, then the model
might be replicated for other types of tourist activities.
After this initial section, the chapter is divided in four main parts. The next section
analyses the genesis and conceptual contours of ecotourism, as a type of sustainable
tourism. The third part considers policy-oriented practices, standards and bench-
marking in sustainable tourism, and provides examples from organisations at the
global level, but with a special focus on the European Union (EU) regional level.
Ecotourism: The Concept and the Practice of Sustainability Within Tourism
75
The EU is a global leader in environmental policies, but it is also a regional organisa-
tion that brings together countries for whom tourism represents an important socio-
economic factor. EU efforts, therefore, to foster sustainable tourism, balancing strin-
gent environmental protection policies with industry interests, make it an interesting
focus of study. The fourth section covers case studies in ecotourism. These exem-
plify how the sustainability approach is being applied in the niche of ecotourism. The
chapter ends with some concluding remarks, leading to a proposal on how ecotourism
and sustainable tourism can contribute to the sustainability research agenda.
2
Ecotourism: Conceptualisation
Ecotourism occupies a speciﬁc niche within tourism, and one that is prone to create
enhanced conditions for sustainable practices. Ecotourism is normally considered as
‘nature-based’ tourism.
As early as 2002, the Québec Declaration on Ecotourism (UNWTO 2002) stated
that a number of speciﬁc principles distinguish ecotourism from the broader perspec-
tive of sustainable tourism: namely the conservation and interpretation of natural
and cultural heritage, the involvement of local or indigenous communities and the
tendencytobringtogethereitherindependenttravellersororganisedbutsmallgroups.
Many deﬁnitions have meanwhile been offered but not all of them have delim-
ited the exact same object. Fennell (2020), after comparing the most relevant of
these, highlights the core ideas they all address: (i) their nature-based foundation;
(ii) sustainability and conservation; (iii) the human dimension as local participation
and beneﬁts; (iv) learning and education; and (v) the ethical imperative. He therefore
deﬁnes ecotourism as:
Travel with a primary interest in the natural history of a destination. It is a non-invasive
and participatory form of nature-based tourism that is built around learning, sustain-
ability (conservation and local participation beneﬁts) and ethical planning, development
and management (Fennell 2020: 14).
In turn, The International Ecotourism Society deﬁnes ecotourism as: “responsible
travel to natural areas that conserves the environment, sustains the well-being of the
local people, andinvolves interpretationandeducation”(TIES 2019: n/p). TheGlobal
Ecotourism Network (GEN 2022) provides a very similar deﬁnition.
TIES emphasises that Ecotourism is about bringing together conservation,
communities, and sustainable travel, and identiﬁes the following ecotourism princi-
ples:
•
Minimize physical, social, behavioural, and psychological impacts.
•
Build environmental and cultural awareness and respect.
•
Provide positive experiences for both visitors and hosts.
•
Provide direct ﬁnancial beneﬁts for conservation.
•
Generate ﬁnancial beneﬁts for both local people and private industry.
76
C. T. Ramos and A. M. Byrne
•
Deliver memorable interpretative experiences to visitors that help raise sensitivity to host
countries’ political, environmental, and social climates.
•
Design, construct and operate low-impact facilities.
•
Recognize the rights and spiritual beliefs of the Indigenous People in your community
and work in partnership with them to create empowerment (TIES 2019: n/p)
All the perspectives outlined provide information on the object—natural areas
and, in some deﬁnitions, also cultural heritage; on the travelling and accommodation
infrastructures—which should be low-impact; on the type of activities—non intru-
sive, prone to conservation and interpretation; on the tourism operators—expected to
be deeply rooted in the local community and generating positive ﬁnancial and other
outcomes for the latter; on the tourists themselves—small scale and with a speciﬁc
interest in nature and local life; on ethics—which are the ethics of conservation and
education for natural and cultural heritage.
The formula thus achieved is very demanding and sets serious limits to the tourist
activity, even beyond what conventional deﬁnitions on sustainable tourism might
require. The United Nations World Tourism Organisation (UNWTO n.d.) deﬁnes
sustainable tourism as “Tourism that takes full account of its current and future
economic, social and environmental impacts, addressing the needs of visitors, the
industry, the environment and host communities”, i.e., using a rather general formula
on sustainability.
However, even within ecotourism, there may be variation in terms of the scope of
sustainability attained. Fennell differentiates ‘soft’ and ‘hard’ ecotourism, meaning
that softer versions require “mechanised transport, easy accessibility and a high level
of services” (Fennell 2020: 21), which of course have an increased environmental
impact.
Transport remains very much an unsolved issue when it comes to ﬁtting tourism
into the boundaries of sustainability (Gale and Hill 2016). Travelling inevitably
carries an environmental footprint, hence the only thing to do is to lower its negative
impacts (Hunter 2016). Walking, or travelling by bike, especially for medium to
long distances is simply not feasible. Means of transport relying on green mobility
(from electric cars to travelling by train) are increasingly available but there is still
a long way to go in order to couple efﬁciency with price and availability. Locally,
however, ecotourism may indeed welcome traditional non pollutant means of trans-
port. Accessibility may nevertheless be compromised, which further increases the
niche characteristic of this sector of activity.
With reference to the object, it is also worth drawing a clear line between
ecotourism and coterminous concepts such as nature-based tourism, wildlife tourism,
or cultural tourism (Fennell 2020; Gale and Hill 2016; Jackson 2022). Many forms
of nature-based tourism (i.e., tourism relying on the natural characteristics of the
destination, such as seaside spots or mountains) do not comply with the deﬁnitions
of ecotourism and are indeed quite close to mass tourism, as in the case of cruises
or exploration safaris. Adventure tourism is yet another close concept but does not
entirely overlap with ecotourism (Amici et al. 2022). Furthermore, greenwashing or
Ecotourism: The Concept and the Practice of Sustainability Within Tourism
77
environmental opportunism may emerge in the promotional language of some opera-
tors,andthusblurthelinebetweenwhatisandwhatisnotecotourism.Inturn,cultural
and heritage tourism are also broader than ecotourism, which seems to address
culture, but only as an interpretive framework of nature and the local communities’
interactions with it. Besides, cultural and heritage tourism are often connected with
mass tourism (Koščak and O’Rourke 2023). Some of the literature draws a connec-
tion between ecotourism and indigenous or aboriginal tourism (Lemelin and Blangy
2009). The principles of minimal impact, awareness and respect aim at providing
conditions for learning without disturbing the host communities, whether human or
natural ecosystems. The rewilding movement (Hall 2019; Rewilding Europe 2023),
for instance, does introduce a contradiction with this principle.
The ecotourist is also of a different ‘species’ compared with the ordinary tourist.
Fennell (2020) states that ecotourists differ from other types of tourists in their
motivations, expectations and behaviours. They are close to naturalists and prone to
nature observation, ranging from botany to geology or zoology. The hard-liners tend
to be rather independent, or possibly specialised, as in the case of scientiﬁc groups.
Nonetheless, there is also the casual ecotourist, who may have been introduced to
it by means of organised tours, and who is possibly expecting a certain amount
of service. Weaver (2005), distinguishes between ‘hard’ and ‘soft’ ecotourists and
Beall and Boley (2022) propose a scale development exercise, in order to differentiate
ecotourists from non-ecotourists.
For the tourism operators, remaining within ecotourism standards is also a major
challenge, not least in terms of the ﬁnancial viability of the projects (Neger 2022).
From the infrastructures, to consumables, they are expected to respect the orig-
inal balance with nature, while providing a good service for tourists and delivering
ﬁnancial beneﬁts for themselves and the local community. Agrotourism, for instance,
provides good opportunities to improve the income of small farmers or rural commu-
nities, while allowing the tourist to participate in community routines (harvesting for
example). Yet again, the concept does not fully overlap with ecotourism (Little and
Blau 2020). One possible way of dealing with deﬁnitional problems is standardi-
sation and certiﬁcation, as further addressed below, which provide both rules and
incentives for entrepreneurs and public (Jackson 2022).
To sum up: the deﬁnition of ecotourism adopted for the purposes of this text
is in line with the vision provided by TIES (2019) and by Fennell (2020), i.e.,
discarding similar, but broader and looser deﬁnitions of ecotourism and cotermi-
nous concepts. The focus on natural areas (with cultural heritage as a subsidiary
factor only, the emphasis on sustainable travel and accommodation, the importance
of positive but sustainable returns to the local community, the observation and conser-
vation focus and the principle of learning without disturbing, coupled with the ethical
responsibility of the tourists themselves deﬁne the core issues covered by a coherent
ecotourism concept.
78
C. T. Ramos and A. M. Byrne
3
Policy-Oriented Practices, Standardisation
and Benchmarking in Sustainable Tourism
Ecotourism is not speciﬁcally mentioned in the sustainable development goals
(SDG), nor in their related targets and indicators. Only tourism in general is
mentioned (UNGA 2017). As for many other human activities, it is commonly
accepted that tourism bears a relation with several of the goals, or even with all
of them, as stated in the Tourism4SDGS Platform: Tourism has the potential to
contribute, directly or indirectly to all of the goals (Tourism4SDGS n.d.; UNWTO
n.d.). However, that connection is more obvious for some goals than for others; in a
number of cases, the SDG agenda speciﬁcally mentions tourism, as shown in Fig. 1.
Tourism has an evident link with SDG 8, “Decent work and economic growth”,
since it is an economic activity. Moreover, it generates substantial income for both
developed and developing countries and is also a sector that includes many small
and medium size companies, thereby being deeply rooted in the local life of the host
communities. The focus on promoting “sustainable tourism that creates jobs and
promotes local culture and products” clearly aims to reinforce that local dimension
and also aligns with the niche within which ecotourism stands. The indicators deﬁned
for this target also highlight the economic (GDP and jobs) importance of tourism.
The same occurs with SDG 12, “Sustainable consumption and production”, which
mentions as a target the development of “tools to monitor sustainable development
impacts for sustainable tourism”. The target is therefore assessed on the basis of
the quantitative measurement of “strategies, policies and implemented action plans”
submitted to sustainability monitoring and evaluation tools. Lastly, SDG 14, with
reference to “the sustainable use of oceans and marine resources”, also includes
sustainable tourism, within the strategies to develop “small island developing States
and least developed countries” (UNGA 2017).

Ecotourism: The Concept and the Practice of Sustainability Within Tourism
79
The general conclusion therefore is that the SDG agenda considers tourism as
having the potential to incorporate sustainability standards of an economic, social
and environmental nature. In order to operationalise this, UNWTO (2023) is working
on the preparation of statistical tools for Measuring the Sustainability of Tourism
(MST). Criteria for identifying sustainable tourism have also been deﬁned by the
Global Sustainable Tourism Council (2022a). The deﬁnition emerged from the 2007
joint initiative to adopt universal sustainable tourism principles by the Rainforest
Alliance, the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), the United Nations
Foundation (UN Foundation), and the United Nations World Tourism Organization
(UNWTO). It is now an independent organisation which establishes global standards
for sustainable travel and tourism, known as the GSTC Criteria (for industry and for
destination). The GTS destination Criteria in the 2019 version already identiﬁed
performance indicators with the relevant SDGs (GSTC 2019).
If we look at the European Union (EU) example, and search for tourism as policy
area, the activity is also more immediately visible in the economic sector than in
the environmental sector. As an economic activity, tourism falls under the actions
to support, coordinate or supplement the actions of the Member States (articles 6
and 195, TFEU), i.e., leaving substantial autonomy to EU Member States. Tourism
is quite important in Europe: for its volume, but also as a tool for the development
of Member States lagging behind EU averages. However, from the environmental
angle, the EU is ambitious and runs a common (and therefore binding) policy, and
one, moreover, that sets the sustainability bar quite high (Jordan and Gravey 2021).
The legal framework is deﬁned under articles 11 and 191–193 of the TFEU, which
provide the EU with broad competences.
Recently, the EU approved its “European Climate Law” (Regulation (EU) 2021/
1119) as a follow-up of the Commission’s “European Green Deal” plan of 2019,
and which sets a target of climate neutrality by 2050, and an intermediate target of
a 55% reduction of gas emissions by 2030. These ambitious goals inevitably impact
tourism and that is why, coupled with the strategic importance of the sector for the
Europeans, the EU has focused on providing guidance for a sustainable transition to
happen also within tourism activities. For the purpose, the Commission has set up
a roadmap which includes, inter alia: measures for smart and sustainable mobility;
eco-labelling for tourist destinations; an Eco-Management and Audit Scheme; energy
efﬁciency; sustainable use of natural resources; the circularity of tourism services
(e.g. use of local ingredients; reduction of food waste); protection of biodiversity;
environmental education for operators and for tourists; and a EU Tourism Dashboard
for measuring the ecological footprint of a given destination (European Commission
2022). Below is a brief analysis of some of these tools.
The Eco-Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) dates back to 1993 (Council
Regulation (EEC) Nº 1836/1993) and originally aimed at creating a community
eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS) based on the voluntary participation
of organisations. In the 2009 update (Regulation (EC) Nº 1221/2009), Article 46
also established the necessity to develop Sectoral Reference Documents (SRD),
which the European Commission did for tourism, in 2016 (Commission Decision

(n.d.)
(EU) 2016/611 of 15 April 2016). The SRDs are expected to include Best Envi-
ronmental Management Practices (BEMPs), Environmental Performance Indicators
and, if applicable, Benchmarks of Excellence and rating systems identifying perfor-
mance levels and best performers. Hence, the 2016 document, after identifying key
environmental pressures impending over tourism related activities, deﬁnes seven
areas of BEMPs (Fig. 2).
The impact of this audit scheme upon tourism and tourism related activities
is difﬁcult to access in quantitative terms, given the complexity of tourism as an
industrial ecosystem which encompasses many sectors of economic activity (Euro-
pean Commission, DG Internal Market 2022: 2). Even so, in 2020, the European
Commission (European Commission, DG Environment 2020: 3) highlighted that
EMAS registered 177 entries in the sector of accommodation activities, 71 in the
food service activities, and 77 in the arts, entertainment and recreation sector (results
from 2018). It further pointed out that nearly 95% of those were actually small and
medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). While these numbers are not high in terms of the
dimension of the sector in the EU, they nevertheless bear witness to an emergent
awareness on environmental auditing and potential beneﬁts.
Ecolabelling may be one such advantage. Labelling supports both the consumers
and the professionals in the sector, as it deﬁnes sine qua non criteria for certiﬁcation
and can provide a catalogue of certiﬁed destinations. The involvement of both ends of
the process is crucial and, indeed, consumers’ attitudes and choices make a difference
when it comes to sustainability. In the EU, legislation was passed (Commission
Decision 2023) deﬁning the criteria for the ‘EU Ecolabel tourist accommodation’.
This EU Ecolabel is in accordance with ISO Ecolabelling standards, as set out in
ISO 14024: 2018 Type I. Environmental labels and declarations (ISO 2023).
Another interesting EU tool for the tourist industry, for consumers, and also
for policy makers is the ‘Tourist Dashboard’, as developed since 2021 (European
Commissionn.d.).Initiallyaproofofconceptitisnowopentothepublicandprovides
Ecotourism: The Concept and the Practice of Sustainability Within Tourism
81
relevant information on European destinations (at country and, where possible, also at
regional and sub-regional levels) according to several indicators distributed by three
pillars (or policy areas): environmental impacts, digitalisation, and socio-economic
vulnerability. Environmental impacts are measured according to the following indi-
cators: air travel emission intensity; tourism GHG intensity; tourism energy intensity;
share of trips by train; excellent bathing water; dependence on distant origins.
4
Ecotourism: A Special Niche?
According to the deﬁnition of ecotourism presented above, efforts for standardis-
ation and benchmarking can make a difference in actually deﬁning and delimiting
ecotourist initiatives, and at the same time making them known to the public.
General information on ecotourism states that it is fast growing and is therefore an
expanding area in the tourism business (Jackson 2022). Despite the opportunities it
may provide, the fact is not necessarily good news for the sub-sector, especially for its
‘small scale’ characteristic, but also because of the difﬁculties in reaching consensus
on what is and what is not ecotourism. More often than not, it seems there is a grey
area between sustainable tourism and ecotourism, which may result in a ‘distorted’
use of the label ‘ecotourism’. These problems obviously impact on the efforts to
standardise and certify ecotourism. Moreover, the assessment of its effectiveness in
the promotion of sustainable development is at least debatable (Wondirad 2019).
Hence, for a systematic research agenda, a good research question will address the
deﬁnition of the criteria to be taken into account, in order to identify and assess
ecotourism practices and outcomes. The broader natural, human and institutional
contexts are also relevant. Examples of ongoing cases are brieﬂy analysed below.
The ﬁrst case is an EU case, the InterregMED Programme—DestiMED Plus
Project (DestiMED PLUS 2023). This is a project within the Interreg Euro-MED
Programme, which is an EU cooperation structure across Mediterranean borders.
The DestiMED Plus aims at developing ecotourism in Mediterranean protected areas
by bringing together nine Mediterranean regions that want to promote ecotourism
in their protected areas. The project builds on the previous experience and results of
the Mediterranean Experience of Ecotourism (MEET 2023) and DestiMED project
(DestiMED 2019).
The Mediterranean is a highly signiﬁcant geographical space for this debate, since
it is also a favourite destination for mass tourism, which is a challenge for Protected
Areas (PAs), and therefore one where conﬂicting interests between the conservation
and tourism sectors may emerge. Hence, the plan aims at bringing together conserva-
tion and tourism policies, resorting to the tools previously developed for MEET, and
further developing a methodology for measuring and monitoring impacts of tourism.
The MEET network was created in 2018 as a follow up to a project initiated in 2013
by a group of conservation and tourism organisations aiming at bridging the gap
between tourism and conservation in the Mediterranean area (MEET 2023). Under
the DestiMed project they developed a manual for that purpose (MEET 2019). At
82
C. T. Ramos and A. M. Byrne
present, MEET and DestiMED Plus provide an Ecotourism Standard and an online
Ecological Footprint Calculator, both included in the online indicator monitoring
platform (MEET n.d.). The Ecological Footprint Calculator measures and analyses
the ecological footprint of an ecotourism itinerary, in line with the criteria established
by the Global Footprint Network (GFN 2023; Mancini et al. 2018, 2022). The Indi-
cator Monitoring Platform provides tourism destinations in protected areas with a
self-assessment tool, aligned with the criteria of the MEET Standard, which is being
updated in the framework of the DestiMED Plus project (a draft version is available
online).
In 2022, a DestiMED Plus report highlighted some very important conclusions on
the ecological footprint measured over the course of the project in the nine Mediter-
ranean protected areas. First, it shows that the footprint of ecotourism is lower than
that of mass tourism (if medium and long-distance travelling are not considered).
Besides, in some cases, the ecological footprint of the tourists at the destination
was even lower than that of local residents. Travelling remains the key issue for
lowering the ecological footprint of tourism and, consequently, proximity tourism
is recommendable (DestiMED Plus 2022). For the EU, these projects are also very
important as tools for testing the viability of alternative forms of tourism bearing a
much smaller impact upon natural resources.
The second example is a non-European example. It is ECO Certiﬁcation by
Ecotourism Australia, which appears to be a realistic effort to create a scale leading
from very basic requirements of ecotourism to more ‘advanced’ versions (Ecotourism
Australia 2023a).
It was launched in 1996 and is now a certiﬁcation programme recognised by the
Global Sustainable Tourism Council (2022b). What this programme provides is the
certiﬁcation of tourism products with a primary focus on nature. For the consumer,
it means that the certiﬁed products carry a strong commitment to sustainability and a
guarantee of genuine nature-based tourism experiences. As explained in the instruc-
tions for candidates (Ecotourism Australia 2023b), ECO certiﬁcation “is product-
speciﬁc”, which means that applicants “can apply for Certiﬁcation even if not all of
[their] products are nature-based”. This is also a step-by-step certiﬁcation procedure.
There are three levels: “nature tourism”, “ecotourism”, and “advanced ecotourism”.
Beyond these, but also with a connection to the fundamentals of ecotourism, the same
organisation also runs the “Respecting Our Culture (ROC)” certiﬁcation programme,
with reference to Indigenous communities and their cultural heritage. Requirements
therefore go from simpler versions to more complex ones, thus creating a scale
associated with certiﬁcation (p. 14) as explained in Fig. 3.
For preparingCertiﬁcation, candidates must consider eight sections, eachof which
considers a dense list of indicators. The sections are: “Business management and
operational planning; Responsible marketing; Customer satisfaction; Environmental
management; Interpretation and education; Contribution to conservation; Working
with local communities; and Cultural respect and sensitivity” (Ecotourism Australia
(2023b: 19).
The next example comes from a developing country. Kenya, which has long
attractedtouristsforthe‘natural’experiencesitoffers,buthardlywithinsustainability

Australia (2023b)
and conservation patterns, has meanwhile embraced sustainability and ecotourism
standards. Ecotourism Kenya (EK) was created in 1996 and was the ﬁrst ecotourism
society in Africa. It uses as leitmotiv the expression “linking tourism, conservation
and communities” to which end it has established initiatives in different focus areas,
and works in order to produce that outcome. Among its activities, there is the promo-
tion of standards and best practices in tourism. The Eco-rating Certiﬁcation Scheme
was launched in 2002 and is recognised by the Global Sustainable Tourism Council
(GSTC 2022b). It addresses tourism accommodation facilities from the environ-
mental, economic and socio-cultural perspectives, on the basis of set criteria. The
certiﬁcation system provides three graded levels—bronze, silver and gold ecorated—
according to whether tourism facilities have shown awareness, progress or excellence
“in responsible resource use, environmental conservation and socio-economic invest-
ment” (EK 2023a). The organisation also has a strong focus on ‘community devel-
opment’, which is one of the deﬁnitional tenets of ecotourism. As stated in their
website (EK 2023b), the programme aims:
84
C. T. Ramos and A. M. Byrne
1.
To integrate host communities and community-based tourism (CBT) into mainstream
tourism in Kenya;
2.
To build capacity for local people to more effectively engage with tourism issues;
3.
To explore improvement ideas and opportunities for tourism involvements within and
beyond the destinations where the host communities exist.
It is also worth mentioning that Ecotourism Kenya is backing a tour operators
certiﬁcation scheme, therefore entering the difﬁcult issue of travel, from the sustain-
ability point of view. This is also a step-by-step process, tour operators being able to
ﬁrst certify their companies as ‘engaged’ in sustainability; then as ‘partners’, when
complying with increased requirements; and ﬁnally, as ‘certiﬁed’, meaning they
have achieved an internationally recognised pattern of sustainability (EK 2023a).
The assessment of the outcome of this move towards sustainability in African devel-
oping countries has normally produced twofold results, showing progress but also
shortcomings (JoE 2015). The impacts of ecotourism on developing economies thus
deserve further and ongoing research.
The fourth and last example is Costa Rica. This central American country is often
presented as a good case study in sustainability and ecotourism projects, for the
abundance of classiﬁed natural parks (29), wildlife refuges (19), biological reserves
(8), and consequently remarkable biological diversity and geological landscapes
(Amici et al. 2022; Costa Rica Tourism Board 2023).
These natural conditions provide good opportunities for ecotourism, with a strong
emphasis on sustainability, conservation and responsible tourism, as documented by
the National System of Conservation Areas (SINAC-Sistema Nacional de Áreas de
Conservación). SINAC is a governmental agency, under the Ministry of Environ-
ment. Altogether, a quarter of the national territory of Costa Rica is by law under
some category of protection (SINAC n.d.). This also accounts for the substantial
importance of nature tourism in Costa Rica’s GDP, although the pandemic led to a
decline, which is now to be overcome (Oxford Analytica 2022). However, priori-
tising the importance of tourism in the national economy may raise issues as to the
sustainability of the activity from a ‘purely’ ecotourist perspective (Sanchez 2018).
Indeed, the use of the word ‘ecotourism’ seems less established in Costa Rica than
the adherence to the broader concept of sustainability and to sustainability certiﬁ-
cation. The interest and involvement of Costa Rican national governmental entities
with tourism is obvious, and so is their networking with the UNWTO (2017). This
again highlights the importance for the research agenda of governance in sustainable
tourism and ecotourism.
5
Final Considerations
The reasons for including sustainable tourism and ecotourism in an agenda for
sustainable development research would appear to be undeniable.
Ecotourism: The Concept and the Practice of Sustainability Within Tourism
85
Tourism is a complex economic cluster, encompassing several different sectors of
activity. It is important as an economic activity and pivotal in development processes.
It is also an activity where SMEs abound, which brings it closer to the community,
and to participation mechanisms and education and learning skills.
Furthermore, it enjoys a special relationship with the clients, i.e., the tourists. The
tourist is also responsible for ethical tourism and can choose, learn, and participate in
localprocesses.Hencetheactivityisbidirectional,andsustainabilitycanbeimproved
also from that point of view.
Ecotourism represents a very speciﬁc challenge for sustainable tourism. Its
grounding in nature-related tourism, in preservation and conservation, in observa-
tion and learning, in communitarian life and minimal impacts, make it a test case
for ‘hard’ sustainability in tourism. If achieved, ecotourism will have proved its rele-
vance, along with the relevance of tourism for conservation, and will set a benchmark
for sustainable tourism in general. However, none of this has been fully proven to
date. A tension can be identiﬁed between mass- and eco-tourism: concurrent spots,
maximisation of proﬁts, high seasons, even democratisation of the access to culture
and nature. Economic viability, along with medium and long-distance sustainable
transport appear to be the strongest environmental and economic weaknesses of
ecotourism. A step by step (product by product) approach may be more realistic,
allowing some space for ‘soft’ ecotourism, which in turn may help build bridges
with sustainable tourism in general.
The introduction of rigorous concepts, standards and benchmarking is a precious
tool for businesses, but also for science and research, as it enables categorisation,
comparison and ranking. However, at this level, we are still far from full congruence
and are facing a whole universe of diverse standardising tools with little integration
between them, despite the efforts of some organisations in the ﬁeld (e.g., UNWTO,
ISO or the EU) as summarised in this chapter.
The necessity for increased international sustainable tourism governance thus
becomes evident. Nevertheless, and despite the shortcomings, extant work on stan-
dardisation and measurement tools for sustainable tourism and for ecotourism
provide already available and promising research material with which to monitor
sustainability pathways. It is also a task for the research community to compare,
integrate, solidify and consolidate both the deﬁnitions and the research instruments
on sustainable tourism and ecotourism. A vast theoretical and empirical ﬁeld is
therefore opening up before us with every passing day.
Hence, the following agenda for future research, the importance of which the
chapter has aimed to outline, is suggested:
– conceptual research on the standardisation and the integration of extant standards
regarding ‘sustainable tourism’ and ‘ecotourism’, in order to foster conceptual
accuracy and enable comparative research;
– empirical and comparative research on both the advantages and the limitations of
ecotourism in the promotion of sustainable tourism;
– contextual and comparative studies, namely on the natural, human and develop-
ment backgrounds of the cases considered;
86
C. T. Ramos and A. M. Byrne
– a focus on the multilevel structure of governance underlying sustainable tourism
and ecotourism: the role of local, regional, national and international govern-
mental organisations; the speciﬁc role of non-governmental organisations and
local communities;
– a focus on the responsible traveller, on a culture of conservation, learning and
sustainability practices.
The potential for a strong sustainability outcome of ecotourism, one that serves
the broad objective of sustainability in tourism, thus very much remains an open
question, which can only be answered by solid theoretical and empirical research.

Rewilding the Cajun Prairie: Efforts
in Land Rehabilitation Ensure
a Sustainable Future in Southwestern
Louisiana and Beyond
M. F. Vidrine, B. Borsari, M. Pastorek, and C. M. Allen
Abstract Before European settlement, the prairie ecosystem (Cajun Prairie) of
southwestern Louisiana covered an estimated area of more than one million hectares.
The landscape of this region, Acadiana, was converted into farmland, oil infrastruc-
ture, and urbanscape. Estimated areas are destroyed (99.9%); the remaining 1,500
hectares (0.1%) persist in degraded states. We elaborate upon knock-on negative
regional impacts. Restoring the ecological integrity of prairies with native plants is
proposed in this work, as a viable approach to sustainable development and a research
agenda, which is urgently needed to ensure a sustainable future. Our evaluation study
considered a selection of case studies to present achievements and challenges at rewil-
ding in this region at various times and scales. Our report includes 1,349.3 hectares
of prairie under restoration. The data were triangulated with qualitative data derived
from a systematic literature review and quantitative data from estimates of hectares
that were reclaimed into prairie during the last forty years. This assessment enabled
us to quantify the values of these efforts for Acadiana. Implications for adoptions and/
or adaptations to rewilding in other regions of the world are presented in a distinc-
tive holistic model, which appears in the conclusion section of this manuscript. We
envision multiple beneﬁts in rewilding land on a larger scale to achieve the United
Nations Sustainable Development Goal# 15 (life on land). Using methods resem-
bling those of the American Prairie project, we propose a Cajun Prairie project at the
southern end of the massive prairie ecosystem of the central United States, a region
that has lost its ‘relative ecological integrity.’
