1
Introduction
Human encroachment on most ecosystems leaves clear evidence of people’s impacts
on wilderness, that since prehistoric times has been shaping the traits of landscapes
on Earth. Many argue that we must reckon with the fact that coexistence with other
species is a necessary condition for the long-term prosperity of ecosystems thus,
‘rewilding’ has surged as an approach for returning the landscapes we have modiﬁed
into wild lands (Foley et al. 2005; Dirzo and Raven 2003; Perino et al. 2019; Freese
2023). The Cajun Prairie exempliﬁes the human alteration of an ecosystem whose
plant community once hosted about 1000 native plant species. It extends from Lake
Charles, LA east to Lafayette, LA along the coastal plain and is part of the coastal
prairie of the Gulf of Mexico (Fig. 1). This region is known as Acadiana, a name
celebrated for its early colonists in the 1700s, the French Acadians (Vidrine et al.
2001a, b). We are extending the effort of the American Prairie by moving into a distant
but connected habitat–one that has lost its ‘relative ecological integrity’ (REI) and
no longer provides many of the ecological resources that it once did (Smith 2001).
While the American Prairie provides a wonderful model, most of the prairie region
of America has already lost its REI and requires a model where restoration precedes
implementationoftheAmericanPrairiemodel–amuch‘heavierlift,’asFreese(2023)
deﬁnes.
The Cajun Prairie ecosystem was essentially a tallgrass prairie dissected by 3
rivers and their riparian forests (Allain et al. 2000). Its primary river is the Mermentau
River, which feeds a large freshwater marsh and saline marsh at its massive delta.
Louisiana has the most extensive surface elevation table-marker horizon strategy,
with a network of stations which is used to quantify the processes affecting wetland
elevation change in the region, because of its rapid rates of wetland loss and sea-level
rise (Osland et al. 2017).
Rich soils in the prairie have literally been eroded by plowing and irrigation,
farming practices that have led to the pollution of rivers via siltation and channel-
ization of the same (Leonard 2017). Consequently, this area is considered the most
biologically-degraded region in Louisiana, yet the most feasible for rewilding—
a process in prairie ecosystems restoration, that apparently is most rapid, when
compared to forests and other systems (Vidrine 2010). With an estimated 99.9% of
the original one-million hectares currently plowed or mowed routinely and otherwise
lost, rewilding is immediately necessary, while native plant propagules remain extant.
This land rehabilitation effort centers around rewilding the prairies and surrounding
environs.
The impacts of the degradation of the land are obvious with nearly every hectare
either routinely mowed or plowed! Consider the following points:
Rewilding the Cajun Prairie: Efforts in Land Rehabilitation Ensure …
93
Fig. 1 The Cajun Prairie (Acadiana) region in southwestern Louisiana. Map prepared by Steven
Dale Nevitt (The Cajun Prairie Habitat Preservation Society)
1. The Cajun Prairie is the most endangered habitat in Louisiana, and prairie is the
most endangered terrestrial habitat in the world. It is essentially extirpated as an
ecological unit, with its biodiversity in ramshackle. In 2020, Brian Sean Early
estimated 1,356 Ha. of the original one million Ha. remained, with circa 81
Ha., along railroad rights of-way and 1,234 Ha. of rangeland, including marsh
fringing remnants—much of this hectarage in some state of degradation, too
(Reﬂections December 2020-The Cajun Prairie and Native Grasses—YouTube
see minute 30). This is a mere 0.1% of the original prairie; 99.9% has been
routinely plowed, mowed or destroyed by other human activities.
2. The bayous (rivers) in the prairie region are dark and muddy. Massive soil losses
from cultivation practices accumulate in our bayous and waterways in the form
of silt. Drainage problems result, and engineers then channel or modify streams
to expedite drainage. Much of the riparian forests were harvested and invaded
by aggressive exotic species, e.g., Chinese Tallow trees (Triadica sebifera).
Remaining forested areas often are pine plantations—farms that don’t function
ecologically, as our typical ecosystems.
3. Every suburban and rural home has a yard, or rather a few thousand square
meters, or more of mowed area. These are deserts for wildlife and we will not
even elaborate here on all of the chemicals being used on lawns.
94
M. F. Vidrine et al.
4. Early workers who studied dragonﬂies (George Bick) and butterﬂies (Edward
Lambremont) noted at the onset of their works back in the 1950s that Acadiana
was an ecological desert, and their time was best spent in any other region of
Louisiana.
5. Local cattle ranching is directly related to mosquito population levels, where
cattle density is directly proportional to mosquito population size in rice-
cultivation areas of the Cajun Prairie (McLaughlin and Vidrine 1987). This
is directly related to the development of parish-wide mosquito-abatement
districts and intensive spraying, which has extirpated local insect diversity and
abundance.
6. Over the years, numerous naturalists who studied birds, ﬁsh, insects,
plants,
etc.,
considered
the
region
to
have
decreasing
populations;
however, large numbers of migrating birds ﬂew through the region.
Globally, wildlife losses estimates since 1970 are nearly 70% in abun-
dance (https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/oct/13/almost-70-of-
animal-populations-wiped-out-since-1970-report-reveals-aoe).
7. Large areas in Acadiana (especially Acadia and Jeff Davis Parishes) are
decimated by non-renewable oil extraction developments.
8. Acadiana has a mix of crawﬁsh, rice, soybean, and sugarcane farms, which use
massive amounts of water, fertilizer, biocides, and more agrichemical products.
Plowing and land-levelling are ever-present. The marshes are drained, and every
bayou has been dredged, straightened and/or remodeled for rapid drainage, or
to facilitate boat trafﬁc. Many waterways are man-made canals and lakes.
9. Most homes and commercial properties have a security light. These are now
considered to be a prime trap for beneﬁcial insects. This companioned with
wholesale mosquito spraying create an inhospitable place for invertebrate life
across the agricultural and suburban areas.
10. Acadiana’s farm and urban regions contribute to the size and extent of the dead
zone in the Gulf of Mexico and ﬁsh kills in the rivers and marshes in Gulf
coastal region. Recent NOAA press releases paint a distinct picture of the 1,640
Km2 of dead zone off the Louisiana coast (Fig. 2), where the largest hypoxic
region is immediately south and west of the outﬂow of the Mermentau River
basin ﬂowing west in a Gulf current.
In contrast, the positive impacts of rewilding in this region are potentially breath-
taking.Immediateimpactsonboththeglobalclimatecrisisandtheglobalbiodiversity
crisis will be felt and grow exponentially. Generating prairie soils rapidly sequesters
carbon and builds biodiversity deep into the soils, as prairie plants create a rhizo-
sphere that reaches as many as 4.6 m. in depth. According to Vidrine (2010), prairie
is the fastest and easiest of the ecosystems to reconstruct, if native plant ecotypes
are available. Farmers and ﬁshermen in Acadiana are facing a near-term economic
collapse that can be partially evaded if farmers and lawn-owners rewild parts of their
ﬁelds as an ‘investment’ in the local, long-term regional economy. In general, re-
invigorating soils, clearing rivers, changing hydrology, increasing biodiversity have
numerous positive impacts.
Rewilding the Cajun Prairie: Efforts in Land Rehabilitation Ensure …
95
Fig. 2 Hypoxic zones (dead zones) of the northern Gulf of Mexico (map prepared by NOAA, LSU
and LUMCON in 2021)
Enric Sala’s The Nature of Nature (2020) and Isabella Tree’s Wilding (2018)
compel readers with the impacts of rewilding ocean and farm habitats by providing
many examples of knock-on impacts of rewilding efforts. These authors concede
that even small efforts can affect a much larger neighboring region and potentially
have nearly global impacts, especially if migrating species use the rewilded habitat.
The point here is that a hectare of restored prairie can affect the surrounding several
hectares, provide a refuge for insects/life and connecting many isolated habitats into
ecological corridors that become effective in boosting biodiversity and restoring
services (Ricklefs and Releya 2014; Vidrine et al. 1995; Vidrine and Vidrine 2018).
National Parks were intended to protect the biodiversity of North America as
well as its natural beauty, in addition to providing an inroad for people to ﬁll some
innate desire to be in nature (Butcher 1985). These ideas were great, timely, and
accomplished many facets of their initial designs, but we (scientists included) under-
estimated the biodiversity of this country by an order(s) of magnitude, i.e., there
are tens to hundreds of times more species than we initially estimated, and they
are much more locally distributed than we imagined. Sadly, the bulk of the biodi-
versity remains imperiled. Doug Tallamy’s vision (2020)—a Homegrown National
Park—companioned with Ed Wilson’s concept (2016)—(half-Earth) are ambitious
and focus our immediate concerns—half of the planet has to become rewilded not
only for the conservation of biodiversity but also for the survival of humankind.
At the same time, biodiversity turns out to be much more complex than we
could imagine. Not only are there many more species than we thought, but they
also coevolved more intimately with their immediate neighboring species than we
have appreciated. With modern DNA sequencing and more detailed study of habi-
tats, restoration of wild places is gaining steam. Plant propagules and even animal
ecotypes used in restorations need to be in synchronism with local species, weather,
96
M. F. Vidrine et al.
soils, water, or any combination of these, via trophic rewilding. This is an ecolog-
ical restoration approach that focuses on restoring the functional roles of animals in
ecosystems, as these species can sequester huge amounts of atmospheric carbon,
pulling it out of the atmosphere into the soil thus, making wildlife populations
maintain healthy ecosystems (Schmitz et al. 2023).
Collateral impacts of restoration affect hydrology and soils—the two keystone
pillars of human survival and civilization. Both food and water security are impacted
by hydrology (water cycles) and soils (carbon cycles). Our Cajun Prairie had at least
a 1.0 m rhizosphere as a topsoil base above the clay pan at the onset of agriculture
about 150 years ago—it is now mere centimeters above the clay pan in some areas
and continually blowing away or running off into our bayous—once clear and sandy-
bottomed rich with ﬁsh and massive beds of freshwater mussels, literally cobbling
the bottoms of lakes, swamps and bayous (Vidrine 2010). Rainwater soaked into the
prairie soils and followed the 2.5–3.5 m. deep roots of our native plants recharging
the shallow aquifer system, which ran in the clay pan to the nearby ponds and
bayous and bubbled up in springs and seeps along these. The loss of this ‘run-on’
(percolation) hydrology has also resulted in ‘run-off’ hydrology, causing local ﬂoods
and sedimentation of lakes and bayous to an extent that mussel beds and ﬁsh resources
are imperiled.
We suggest that government agencies consider subsidizing and insuring farmers’
efforts at rewilding portions of their properties in order to improve crop production
that should appear with improved soils and hydrology. No-till and cover crops incor-
porated with rewilding appear to improve soils and crops (Tree 2019; Brown 2018).
The potential is obvious for our region (Fig. 3; Vidrine 2010).
After nearly 5 decades of inventorying species and monitoring the demise of their
habitats, it is time to begin measuring and celebrating the creation of new habitats and
the rehabilitation of degraded ones. Climate change (https://www.noaa.gov/educat
ion/resource-collections/data/climate) and biodiversity loss are changing faster and
faster in negative ways, but a positive revision is needed. It is time to closely monitor
and revel every positive change, while energizing any human endeavor directed at
restoring biodiversity and climate.
As a ﬁnal note, sea levels rise and local subsidence pose signiﬁcant, additional
risks to the Acadiana region. The U.S. Geological Service’s predictions are dire,
with much of the land area south of Interstate 10 becoming open water, marsh, or
deltaic—all conditions that are not suitable for agriculture. A predicted 12 cm. rise
in sea level per decade over the next 100 years is emblematic—these changes are
occurring faster than when initially predicted in 2008 (Fig. 4).
Restoring prairies as part of an emergency rewilding effort is necessary not only
to assist Acadiana with ecological and economic development, but also to reduce the
global impacts of climate change as predicted by meteorological models (LaHaye-
Fontenot 2023). Signiﬁcant reduction in the applications of pesticides and restoration
of historical hydrology by rewilding could create impacts that improve ecological
services (Vidrine 2010).
We are taking stock of the remaining patches of prairie and prairie habitats under
construction in Acadiana. As the hectares accrete, effects should become apparent,
Rewilding the Cajun Prairie: Efforts in Land Rehabilitation Ensure …
97
Fig. 3 Acadiana contains a variety of farms that are plowed annually for rice and soybean produc-
tion. Selected areas are used as pasture for livestock. More recently, many ﬁelds have been modiﬁed
for aquaculture of crayﬁsh. Aerial photo taken near Welsh, LA, in the center of the Cajun Prairie
ecosystem by M. Vidrine (1982)
although some of those effects may take years to be appreciated. An understanding of
the status of these habitats is urgently necessary to assess the potential for sustainable
development in the region.
2
Methodology
This study aimed at a strategy of collecting a combination of qualitative and quanti-
tative data. The qualitative data derived from a systematic literature review of recent
studies about rewilding theory and methods with a focus on reconstructing natural
habitats from agricultural lands. An analysis of selected case studies from south-
western Louisiana contributed to the collection of qualitative and quantitative data
(restored Ha.). Additional quantitative data derived from calculations of hectarage
whose conversion has happened already within a timeframe of almost forty years
(1986–2023) in this bioregion. Thus, the qualitative data from the literature review
and case study analysis (2 sets), were triangulated with the quantitative data to realize
the rewilding efforts accomplished in Acadiana.
This methodology has been effective in understanding challenges but also oppor-
tunities about restoring agrarian landscapes, despite the diversity of environmental
98
M. F. Vidrine et al.
Fig. 4 Ofﬁcial map prepared by USGS showing low-lying areas in red. These areas are subsiding
and susceptible to sea level rise. Many other maps are available that clearly show impending losses
due to the combined impacts of subsidence and sea level rise. Louisiana is proposing a 50-billion-
dollar Master Plan to avert some of these potential losses. It is evident that the Cajun Prairie
ecosystem is immediately north of this area, and bayous will be impacted upstream into the prairie
region
and ecological traits, that distinguish ecosystems and ecotones. Our study strived to
look for relationships between the two qualitative methods used for their data collec-
tion because in Popham’s experience (1993), these have the potential to enhance the
trustworthiness of assessment studies, especially when these are triangulated with the
quantitative data yielded by the case studies and estimate calculations of additional
lands undergoing rewilding in southwestern Louisiana.
3
Results
We present here a synopsis (in chronological order), of distinctive case studies from
southwestern Louisiana that demonstrate achievements in restoring the Cajun Prairie.
Rewilding the Cajun Prairie: Efforts in Land Rehabilitation Ensure …
99
3.1
Case Studies Analysis
1. TheCajunPrairieRestorationProjectinEunice—this,theoriginalprairierestora-
tion, was established in 1988 and created by the Cajun Prairie Habitat Preserva-
tion Society, LSU Eunice, and the community of Eunice (Fig. 5). Four hectares of
former railroad right-of-way were seeded and plugged with native Cajun Prairie
plant ecotypes (seeds and plugs). Prairies are in a good state of restoration with
a good mix of hillside and wetland prairie plant species.
2. The Duralde Prairie—this prairie restoration, established in 1994, created by the
Lacassine National Wildlife Refuge and currently managed by the Cajun Prairie
Habitat Preservation Society and the Refuge. Some 135 hectares were seeded
with seed from Oklahoma and Texas (non-ecotypes), but 12 hectares were over-
seeded and plugged with native Cajun Prairie plant ecotypes. Prairies are in a
good state of restoration with a good mix of hillside and wetland prairie plant
species however, large areas are monocultures of Little bluestem (Schizachyrium
scoparium) probably originating from the original seeding.
3. The Cajun Prairie Gardens—this prairie restoration, established in 1996 by Gail
andMalcolmVidrine,isafamilyresearchandlandscapingproject(Fig.6).Nearly
0.8 hectare was seeded and plugged with native Cajun Prairie plant ecotypes.
Fig. 5 The Cajun Prairie Restoration Project in Eunice, LA, serves as a refuge for ecotypes of
hundreds of plant species. The site is enhanced by a parking area and a concrete trail. Aerial view
by Marc Pastorek (taken in 2016)
100
M. F. Vidrine et al.
Prairies are in a good state of restoration with a good mix of hillside and wetland
prairie plant species, but primarily wetland species.
4. Fuselier farms—these prairie restorations, established in 2003 and since by
Vernon and Justin Fuselier, are currently used in a mob-grazing (rotational
grazing) cattle operation. Approximately 26 hectares were seeded with native
Cajun Prairie plant ecotypes. Prairies are in a good state of restoration with a
good mix of hillside and wetland prairie plant species, but primarily hillside
species.
5. Bruce and Gladys Guillory Family farm—these prairie restorations, established
in 2020 and since by the Guillory family, contain 162 hectares as part of a
wetland mitigation bank and additional acreages as part of a C-GRIP program
and personal prairie gardens. These were seeded and plugged with native Cajun
Prairie plant ecotypes. These prairies are too young to readily assess.
Early work on the ﬁrst and third of these projects has been outlined in several
books and articles (Vidrine 2010, 2018; Vidrine and Vidrine 2018; Vidrine et al.
1995, 2001a, b, 2003). Many new projects are too recently initiated to assess.
Fig. 6 The Cajun Prairie Gardens. Circles of predominant grasses containing smaller circles of
other grasses and forbs clearly evidence the high diversity and complex structure of this 26-year-
old project just outside Eunice, LA, USA. The large trees are Live oaks, while the prairie restoration
is cut by mowed trails into demonstration gardens in a rural, commercial lot. Aerial photo by Marc
Pastorek (taken in 2016)
Rewilding the Cajun Prairie: Efforts in Land Rehabilitation Ensure …
101
Prairie restoration provides the easiest opportunity to rewild Acadiana. These case
studies are tangible examples of rewilding efforts, both farmland and lawn, both
for grazing, wetland mitigation, research, and enjoyment/landscape beautiﬁcation.
Collectively, these sites provide refuge for native plant species and numerous wildlife
species. Extant, complex associations between native plants, insects, birds, ﬁsh, and
mussels, renegotiate food pyramids and energy cycles. The plants also provide seed
for further development of prairies in other locations of this unique bioregion.
3.2
Rewilding Farmland
PhilipLymbery(2022)providedaclarioncallforfarmerstounderstandthatindustrial
agriculture is the major driver of the climate change phenomenon and to act to restore
ecosystem health and most importantly, soil health. Conservation farming practices
effectively restore the fertility of the soils and reduce needs for non-renewable, fossil
fuel-based, synthetic fertilizers (Lal 2015; Borsari 2023; Gliessman et al. 2023).
Soil is a complex ecosystem, with unique local fungal/bacterial/animal genetics that
interact with native plants (Weil and Brady 2017; Borsari 2020). Rewilding lawns
and farmlands is the only way to secure native soils and extend future harvests,
despite the alarming narrative of industrial agriculture business groups urging an
intensiﬁcation of production to satisfy the needs of a growing human population
(Borsari and Kunnas 2020; Borsari 2021). With a goal of rewilding 50% of the
land/soil in Acadiana, farmers and landowners will need to commit to new farming
methods, where agriculture will have to be re-designed to ﬁt more harmoniously
within the ecosystems in which this is taking place.
Isabella Tree (2019) and Gabe Brown (2018) eloquently described that rewilding
and regenerative farming provide for healthier soil and may integrate into complex
farms with a mix of rewilding and regenerative farming in a sustainable system.
However, it is too early to be optimistic in thinking that the industrial model for
modern farming will evolve into one that sanctions their ideas because a fossil fuels
economy continues to support agribusiness (Borsari 2023). In Acadiana, farming is
failing both to maintain farmers’ livelihoods and to protect nearby biodiversity. While
we see beneﬁts to regenerative farming, inspired by agroecological principles and
practices (Altieri and Nicholls 2020), many ecologists see immediate beneﬁt from
rewilding across the board, where conserving local biodiversity is primary among
our concerns (Perino et al. 2019).
George Monbiot (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ny9qvGPx5ds) proposes
new ways to ‘farm’ and ensure food security, while, at the same time, rewilding and
conserving water, soil, habitats and the great remaining biodiversity of the planet.
His book, Regenesis (2022), provided a blueprint for rethinking global food secu-
rity. A recent article highlighted salient points about rewilding, which included: an
increasing recognition of the value of ecosystem restoration at a time of fast environ-
mental change; understanding the beneﬁts and beneﬁciaries in supporting ﬁnancially,
restoration projects; exploring the theoretical framework about the relevance of large
102
M. F. Vidrine et al.
plants and animal species for driving rewilding processes such as ecosystem total
biomass, resource ﬂows and fertility; and for showcasing successful initiatives on
how rewilding nature in the developing world is reversing the impact of invasive
species (Egoh et al. 2021).
The Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem
Services (IPBES https://www.ipbes.net/) has reported most accurately the loss of
biodiversity across space and time. This novel decline of living species is the conse-
quence of habitat loss, which justiﬁes the need for a restoration with emphasis on
rewilding landscapes. Preservation of existing habitats and restoration of agricul-
tural farmlands increase ‘wilderness’ as in areas where wildlife biodiversity can be
secured. We might survive climate change, however, we are unlikely to survive the
loss of biodiversity to the Sixth Great Extinction! While climate change and biodiver-
sity losses are linked, they are separate phenomena; ranking these as to importance is
clear for biologists, but it appears difﬁcult for public and private audiences to grasp.
Agriculture and aquaculture, as we know it, must change.
Obviously, changes in food resources and diets are immediately impacted. An
implementation of rewilding should expeditiously transition the human diet from
meat, milk, and dairy foods, toward a diverse microbial (Monbiot 2022), plant
(Musicus et al. 2022), and entomophagy-based diet (van Huis 2023).
3.3
The Signiﬁcance of Rewilding in Research, Education
and Extension
Ecologists argue that we humans have been operating as a massive geologic force
(Crutzen 2016) and a biodiversity strainer for millennia, facilitating an establish-
ment of only certain species, thus, modifying ecosystems to serve mainly human
needs (Young and Duchicela 2022). Tallamy (2020) added that people’s habits like
mowing the lawn, or even building nests, feeders and waterers in home backyards,
boost certain species populations, yet, in most cases thriving opportunities become
exclusive for some species, but not for others.
Moral arguments about biodiversity’s ecological worth remain important issues
that could become relevant for generating consensus among conservation practi-
tioners when an eco-centric education for sustainable development is employed since
the earliest age of future leaders (Borsari and Kunnas 2022). For example, Berry and
her colleagues (2018) discovered that among various stakeholder groups, there was
a broad diversity of views about biodiversity, suggesting that species valuation does
not justify always a destruction of nature; yet, differences among the groups, corre-
lated with their support for either an eco-centric, or an anthropocentric worldview.
Therefore, it is imperative to boost education in sustainability with an emphasis on
ecosystem conservation, rehabilitation and sustainable management, while engaging
Rewilding the Cajun Prairie: Efforts in Land Rehabilitation Ensure …
103
all segments of society in understanding the need to rewild landscapes. This aware-
ness can be achieved through outreach efforts similar to those provided by the exten-
sionpersonnelofthecollegeofagricultureintheU.S.forfarmers,gardeners,ranchers
and/or homeowners. Borsari and Vidrine (2023) envision curriculum modules and
hands-on activities that could become transformative for educating all learners in
sustainability. Shifting the emphasis of study programs (from pre-k to college-level),
towards ecocentrism appears to be the necessary reform in education, which is neces-
sary to develop a culture for stewardship and sustainability (Borsari and Mora 2020),
while reconnecting people with nature thus, restoring human wellbeing and planetary
health (Borsari and Vidrine 2022).
Our goal is to ultimately create a prairie reserve (10,000 hectares) through rewil-
ding of areas currently used for crops cultivation and rangeland. We hope that
homeowners join in this process and create prairie habitats in their yards, thus,
connecting habitat dots by corridors allowing us to live within the habitat matrix,
while keeping in mind ‘island biogeography’, understanding that every piece of
habitat is interconnected (MacArthur and Wilson 2001).
3.4
Quantitative Data: Hectares that Have Been Restored/
Rewilded
Since 1988, Cajun Prairie restoration has provided an opportunity to preserve plant
genetics (local ecotypes)—a resource for further restoration. Setting goals and moni-
toring progress in attaining goals is useful and informative. Attempts to develop
native plant gardens by the Louisiana Native Plant Society by setting goals and
monitoring progress and rewarding gardeners has proved to work well in Acadiana
(Marc Pastorek, pers. comm. 2023). The sites and hectarage of rewilding projects
are reported (Table 1).
Our best estimates include 1,349.3 hectares of prairie under construction. These
will create habitat for wildlife, affect hydrology, and beneﬁt human health. But at
this point, one of their most important functions is to serve as a ‘Noah’s Ark’ of local
Cajun Prairie plant and animal genetics (ecotypes) and provide the native populations
needed to properly recreate this habitat to maximize the number of species and
ecological roles/associations of species in the habitat.

by 2030, 20,234 hectares (50,000 acres) by 2050, and 404,700 hectares (one million

acres) by 2100. These are rough goals, and we are suggesting that they be accelerated,
just as the loss of biodiversity and climate change are accelerating.
Farming and ranching as they are currently performed are decidedly unsustain-
able and purport future economic and ecological devastation—evidence is already
accumulating that the living fabric of our nature is collapsing.
Unfortunately, landowners, farmers, and landowners who farm represent 3 distinct
groups, both economically and emotionally as to this enterprise. Most are waiting
for government subsidies/intervention, which by the way has come in the form of
subsidies for the development of solar farms, and/or commercial interventions from
large oil companies or other businesses (a practice commonly seen in the coastal
marshes, e. g., Rockefeller Refuge, where oil companies have subsidized numerous
efforts to rehabilitate and protect coastal habitats). Both of these will require time,
maybe years, and intervention is unlikely until agriculture is obviously failing; thus,
it is necessary for the landowners to work with other groups and invest their land
in rewilding. Rewilding apparently creates new opportunities both for wildlife and
employment for humans. The Acadiana community and the global community is
involved.
Sustainable Development Goal 15 (SDG-15) is one of the 17 Sustainable Devel-
opment Goals established by the United Nations in 2015. The ofﬁcial wording is:
“Protect, restore and promote sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, sustainably
manage forests, combat desertiﬁcation, and halt and reverse land degradation and
halt biodiversity loss.” The Goal has 12 targets to be achieved by 2030 (Sustainable
Development Goal 15—Wikipedia). We focus on the following targets in our efforts
to restore Cajun Prairie:
Target 15.1: Conserve and restore terrestrial and freshwater ecosystems,
Target 15.3: End desertiﬁcation and restore degraded land,
Target 15.5: Protect biodiversity and natural habitats,
Target 15.6: Protect access to genetic resources and fair sharing of the beneﬁts,
Target 15.8: Prevent invasive alien species on land and in water ecosystems,
Target 15.9: Integrate ecosystem and biodiversity in governmental planning,
Target 15.a: Increase ﬁnancial resources to conserve and sustainably use ecosystem and
biodiversity.
Our efforts also touch on many of the Goals and could signiﬁcantly impact
outcomes (SDG 1. No poverty|Sustainable Development Goals|Food and Agriculture
Organization of the United Nations (fao.org)). Due to page constraints, these need
to be discussed elsewhere.

5
Conclusion and Recommendations
Our study is supportive of rewilding Acadiana’s Cajun Prairie because this out-of-
the-box ecosystem management approach can ensure a sustainable future in south-
western Louisiana and into currently affected marshes, north of the Gulf of Mexico.
In addition to this, our effort has potential to become a model for rehabilitation of
the most ecologically devastated region in Louisiana. Our ﬁeld experience in this
bioregion indicates that readjusting this natural ecosystem in a relatively short time
fashion through rewilding, with prairie restoration is technically and economically
feasible. Because of the dominance of grasslands among terrestrial ecosystems and
their common fate in having been converted into farmland, we propose a theoretical
model, which could serve well rewilding purposes in more bioregions around the
world (Fig. 7).
Rewilding is a process, which requires ﬁrst an ecologically-educated society to
understand that we humans are components of a complex ecosphere and NOT in
control of it. This kind of education, or simply awareness, are necessary elements
to amplify values of stewardship and conservation thus, aiding in removing feel-
ings, or attitudes of indifference for living systems (Borsari and Mora 2020). Strate-
gies and techniques for rewilding are adaptable and thus may vary however, the
autochthonous germplasm of native organisms (especially plants), remains pivotal
to restore biodiversity (Perino et al. 2019), the health and resilience of rehabili-
tated ecosystems. Thus, the rewilding process described in our model yields restored
landscapes. These will spur a restoration of ecological services, species richness and
diversity a step further, making the system self-sustaining, or requiring only minimal
management. For these reasons an achievement of the rewilding objectives (and in
line with several targets to achieve SDG 15), will lead inevitably and over time,
Fig. 7 Holistic rewilding
model for rewilding
ecosystems
Rewilding the Cajun Prairie: Efforts in Land Rehabilitation Ensure …
107
to a new beginning of the rewilding process. The latter should require less human
intervention and adjustments, as time passes.
As environmental policies and actions of government agencies, corporations and
nongovernmentalorganizationscontinuetofailineffortstoreducetheilleffectsofthe
global climate change emergency, we think that, more robust research agendas about
rewilding landscapes should become more supported, worldwide. At the same time,
the joining voices from individuals, indigenous peoples and grassroots activists, may
expand further rewilding opportunities by challenging neoliberal market economies
(Dauvergne and Clapp 2023). In other words, an ecological recovery of landscapes
cannot occur in a vacuum because humanity is an integral component of these.
There is a need for reorganizing a political and social life that give the much-needed
emphasis to achieving the biological integrity of ecosystems and social justice,
concurrently.Thus,acommunityeffortbylandowners,farmersandthegeneralpublic
can make a difference. While one individual’s contribution is generally small, there
are large landowners that are making decisions to make large contributions (LaHaye-
Fontenot 2023). Collectively, both small and large efforts are needed to make signiﬁ-
cant changes leading to sustainability for the current lifestyle (Egoh et al. 2021). This
bottom-up, new environmentalism trend is what Dauvergne and Clapp (2023) called
‘biojustice’, or environmentalism from below and how this surging movement grows
in the coming years, will become decisive for present society to stem the escalating
global environmental crisis.
UsingmethodsresemblingthoseoftheAmericanPrairieproject(Freese2023),we
propose a Cajun Prairie project at the southern end of the massive prairie ecosystem
of the central United States. However, Freese (2023, p. 88) clearly acknowledges
the ‘relative ecological integrity’ of their region and recognizes the ‘heavy lifting of
habitat restoration that wildlife recovery requires’ in other regions. Acadiana is one
such region that has lost this ‘relative ecological integrity’ and requires a ‘heavy lift’.
The Acadiana community should recognize the perils of their decimated habitat, their
withering agriculture, their intense landscaping, and immediately seize the opportu-
nity to make signiﬁcant changes. The Cajun Prairie is their native habitat! This is the
easiest to restore to ecological integrity—both local scientists and prairie gardeners
have protected much of the unique genetics of the region in the last 50 years and half
a dozen techniques of restoration have received considerable study and implementa-
tion. Despite signiﬁcant anthropogenic impacts and environmental insults caused by
various economic activities in the bioregion under study, the native wildlife is largely
still present (Allain et al. 2000). On this positive note, we trust that the biological
community will be restored according to the timeframe presented here to its near-
original state, as Acadiana makes progress toward achieving the U.N. sustainability
goals for 2030, if and only if, our human community acts now!

Strategies for the Sustainability of Cane
Agroindustry and Development of Green
Agribusiness for Well-Being
Noé Aguilar-Rivera
Abstract Sugarcane is one of the main crops in the world as a source of food and
energy. It is located as agroindustry in more than 130 countries worldwide. The main
product obtained from its processing is sucrose, as granulated sugar of different qual-
ities, which has a story that began from the spices route as a luxury article until today
with marginal integration of agroindustry into the Agriculture 4.0 and Industry 4.0
with the production of bioethanol and energy by cogeneration. As a comprehensive
production process, all the stages of growing, management, harvesting, and trans-
portation of cane stalks with unit operations in sugar mills, trapiches (artisanal sugar
mills), distilleries, and bioreﬁneries, without sustainable practices, impact ecosys-
tems, the well-being of growers and human health; besides generate greenhouse
gases, consume high amounts of energy fossil and agrochemicals. Concerning the
byproducts (molasses, ﬁlter mud, vinases, ashes, bagasse, and trash), are minimally
processed or conﬁned in landﬁlls or the environment as waste. Although there are
a large number of technological proposals and sustainable development research
for their conversion to bioproducts, this agribusiness maintains, in most regions, the
cane-sugar mono-production which is highly unsustainable. The purpose of this work
was to analyze the challenges, constraints, public policy options, and the application
of transdisciplinary frameworks for incorporation in sugarcane agribusiness for the
sustainable production of raw material, valorization of byproducts, development of
new value chains, and generate well-being for stakeholders based on the objectives
of sustainable development.

1
Introduction
Sugarcane (Saccharum ofﬁcinarum) is a subtropical and tropical C4 plant that carries
outphotosynthesisandtheconversionofCO2 sunlightandwaterintosimple(sucrose,
glucose, fructose, etc.) and complex (holocellulose) carbohydrates more efﬁciently.
Cane for sucrose or energy cane is also considered a carbon sink comparable to
forests (Singels et al. 2021). The agricultural fruit of this plant is the stalk, in which
sucrose accumulates during the phenological cycle, and as a raw material, it is of
great importance to produce sugars and thick-walled ﬁbers of Liberian type used for
decades in the production of cellulose for paper and cardboard products. It is the
raw material of the traditional sugar industry as an economic activity of high social
impact due to its production, the employment it creates in the cane ﬁelds and because
sugar (sucrose) of numerous qualities, types, forms, and commercial presentations
is a fundamental product of high consumption, basic in the economy and the culture
and diet of many countries that has been impacted in recent years by numerous
complex factors that threaten its viability as an economic activity and for survival
of the population that depends on it. The sugarcane is sold mainly to sugar mills
considering only the quantity of stalks (tons) and not their quality (sucrose and ﬁber
in %) and the industrialists extract sucrose of low commercial quality and concerning
the by-products generated, only molasses is sold in regional or international markets.
As a result, this model is unsustainable.
However, sugarcane production and processing can signiﬁcantly help the achieve-
ment of the sustainability objectives of the 2030 Agenda (climate change, food secu-
rity, and eco-efﬁciency) and The Paris Agreement because most goals are related to
the crop ﬁelds and agroindustrial facilities. As a result, sugarcane is an important
crop that impacts environmental and socioeconomic sustainability, which generates
employment, income, and wellness (Yang et al. 2022). Concerning the foregoing, this
work proposes the sugarcane agroindustry must carry out the goal of analyzing the
current situation, challenges, constraints, public policy options, and the application
of transdisciplinary frameworks to transform the value chain and generate well-
being for all stakeholders within the objectives of the 2030 agenda for sustainable
development.
This review is structured highlighting key issues to explain (1) the expansion of
this crop through most of the tropical and subtropical regions of the world to produce
white gold as a spice in the sugar islands and with the centuries and technological
development, since the industrial revolution, as a staple food for the entire world
population. (2) The characteristics and advantages of the sugarcane plant for the
formation of a worldwide agroindustry (3) The technological, socioeconomic, and
environmental challenges of sucrose production, competition with other sweeteners,
and the use of harvesting and processing byproducts to create new value chains
called productive diversiﬁcation and (4) the incorporation of new frameworks such as
circular economy, life cycle analysis, agroecology, Agriculture 4.0, and Industry 4.0
to revalorize and convert this age-old agroindustry under the premise of sustainable
development.
Strategies for the Sustainability of Cane Agroindustry and Development …
113
2
Methodology
The research issues related to the sustainability of sugarcane agroindustry and
bioreﬁneries are numerous, complex, and highly interrelated. This proliferation of
knowledge is being generated among different disciplines (agronomy, engineering,
economics, environmental sciences, chemistry, biotechnology, and others), regions,
populations, ethnic groups, beliefs, worldviews, etc., in addition to the fact that
agribusinesses derived from sugarcane are constrained by regional public policies,
sugar geopolitics, technological developments, socioeconomic and environmental
impacts, changing consumer preferences and the business perspective of stake-
holders. For this reason, it is necessary to apply a trans-disciplinary approach with
the adoption of several methodological frameworks to develop solid conclusions for
the sustainability of any agribusiness derived from sugarcane.
Thisworkwascarriedoutinsugarcane-producingregionsofMexico,animportant
sugar-producing country, using a mixed approach. The quantitative stage was based
ontheconstructionofastate-of-the-artaccordingtotheProtocolandReportingresult
withSearch, Appraisal, Synthesis, andAnalysis framework, anddevelop (PSALSAR)
framework using the well-known scientiﬁc databases Scopus, science direct WoS,
and google scholar and keywords (Mengist et al. 2020). Besides the qualitative stage
was structured around open-ended interviews face-to-face or by e-mail to sugarcane
agroindustrystakeholders,mainlyacademicsandresearchers,consideringthecurrent
state, challenges, possible alternatives for management or technological solutions to
achieve changes in the medium term, and the prospective of a sustainable future for
the sugarcane agroindustry (Osborne and Grant-Smith 2021; Dahlin 2021).
3
Sugar, Nature, and Society
Sugarcane is one of the oldest commercially exploited plants in the world. It is one
of the main lucrative cash crops and source of energy in the form of disaccharides
(sucrose) widely available in different degrees of purity, commercial presentations,
and qualities, and economically accessible to the population of high marginalization
and poverty. Its botanical origin is in New Guinea, and from this place, according to
the numerous commercial routes, it was taken to the Asian and European continents
during centuries the process of obtaining sugar (from the Arabic “sukkar” and the
Hispanic Arabic as-súkkar) was improved and techniﬁed to obtain different types
and qualities with the invention of the trapiche (artisanal sugar factory) which is
currently used in several countries of America and Asia for the production of non-
centrifuged sugar that has numerous regional names such as panela, chanchaca,
piloncillo, jaggery, gur, etc. (Daniels and Daniels 1993).
Afterward, during the period of European exploration and conquest in America,
the search for gold and silver was the main driving force; however, the richness of
its natural resources promoted the transfer of sugar cane from the Canary Islands
114
N. Aguilar-Rivera
during Christopher Columbus’ second voyage, which was later planted in the lands
now occupied by the Dominican Republic.
Sugar was considered a highly sophisticated, luxurious, and inaccessible commer-
cial product mainly produced in the Mediterranean with artisanal technology as the
Trapiche (Galloway 1977). According to Higman (2000) the discovery of America
and the establishment of plantations in the Caribbean in the so-called Sugar Islands
and the colonies of New Spain, Colombia, Peru, Brazil, and others started the
world sugar cycle in which Spanish, French, English, Portuguese, and Netherlands
conquerors participated. Subsequently, the cultivation and processing of sugarcane
spread to numerous regions of the world. Besides, with the Industrial Revolution and
the use of sugar beet, the large-scale process extended its consumption by reducing its
sale price. In this way, sugarcane cultivation and the production of sucrose, rum, and
ethanol were commercial products that deﬁned regions, cultures, trade routes, and
nationalisms. Today, sugar cane or beet sucrose is the most widely used sweetener
in the world, and since the 16th century, it has been a highly valued and sought-after
product for adding sweetness to food products and for having a stable and growing
market niche (de Matos et al. 2020).
About 80% of global sugar cane production is converted into cane sugar, while
the rest is for the production of biofuel. Sucrose is composed of fructose and glucose
in an equal ratio. As a raw material is currently used in the food, pharmaceutical,
chemical, and biotechnology industries, among others. However, since the 1970s
sucrose has been in strong competition with high-intensity sweeteners obtained by
chemical and biotechnological routes such as high fructose corn syrup (HFCS) used
mainly in the manufacture of beverages and food, the intense scientiﬁc debate about
the potential dangers of excessive consumption towards the development of public
health problems such as obesity, diabetes, hypertension, mental disorders, etc. (de
Matos et al. 2020; Castro-Muñoz et al. 2022; Li et al. 2022; Crucho and Barros 2023).
Based on the conclusions of Ogura et al. (2022), it has been demonstrated that
the agricultural sugarcane management practices for sugar production have impacted
in an often irreversible way numerous environments and ecosystems, in addition to
generating contaminants in the soil, air, water, and impacting the health of growers
and populations with practices such as harvesting with burning, non-techniﬁed use of
agrochemicals and the low level of use of byproducts such as harvest residues (trash),
ﬁlter mud, ashes and vinasse, despite the existence in scientiﬁc databases of numerous
researchstudiesthatdemonstratethetechnical,economicandenvironmentalviability
of bioproducts derived from sugarcane and best management practices in crop ﬁelds
considered key challenges to achieve sustainability.
Notwithstanding, the cultural, technological, economic, low social capital forma-
tion and public policy failures are the factors that have conditioned the evolution of
the sugarcane agroindustry, considering only sucrose as a basic and strategic product,
necessary for national economies and popular consumption, making its survival and
non-competitive crop, unlike in other regions where it has been the major devel-
opment factor, as in the case of the establishment of agroecological practices and
sugarcane bioreﬁneries and Industry 4.0 (Zaiets et al. 2023).
Strategies for the Sustainability of Cane Agroindustry and Development …
115
Nevertheless, this millenary crop faces the challenge of evolving its marginal
value chain so that stakeholders (growers, entrepreneurs, and consumers) together
with decision-makers redirect actions for its sustainability due to complex factors that
although they cannot be generalized, some occur in most of the sugarcane producing
countries:
– Currently sugarcane stalks are the feedstock of sucrose production for the food
industry and in some cases for the combined production of sugars, biofuels
(ethanol and bioelectricity), and other bioproducts with biotechnologies.
– Heterogeneity, aging of the production plants in crop ﬁelds, few ﬁnancial and
technical capacities, as well as marketing capacities in certain markets where
public policies and stakeholder decisions have not been entirely effective.
– Breeding is a novel technology only employed at an increase in sucrose/ha.
– Bagasse is used inefﬁciently and trash is burned in crop ﬁelds in most of the
producing regions.
– Very few countries have focused on bioenergy prioritizing technological options
to increase yields in sugarcane and sugar production.
– Byproducts such as molasses are still sold as raw materials or exported without
any added value.
– Sugarcane production is still small-scale smallholder production of less than 3 ha
in developing countries such as Mexico.
– Degradation of sugarcane-cultivated soils is characterized by erosion, the impact
of harvesting with burning and extraction, volatilization, and leaching of nutrients.
– No fertilization according to crop and soil requirements due to numerous
economic, social, and cultural factors and low technology transfer.
– Quality (certiﬁed) seed is not produced due to the linkage with specialized sugar-
cane research centers that do not exist in several countries and the generation of
new varieties is a time-consuming and costly process.
– There is an efﬁcient composition of varieties and cycles (low plant level and
extensive ratoon).
– High incidence of pests, diseases, and weeds increased each cycle due to the
impact of climate change.
– Low sugarcane seedling renewal rates, high level of variety mixtures, and
depopulation of sugarcane ﬁelds.
– Extensive sugarcane production under rainfed conditions, highly impacted by
climate change.
– Unproductive system of traditional harvesting, without considering the soil
and climatic conditions of each region (a single fertilization formula generally
combined with ﬁlter mud and ashes or with vinasse irrigation).
– Sugarcane is cultivated in areas of higher vulnerability and risks due to the low
use of tools as agroecological zoning.
In general, there is great environmental deterioration due to unsustainable produc-
tion practices, which generates current and potential economic losses for the
sector.
116
N. Aguilar-Rivera
Besides,accordingtoRuthsetal.(2023),theruralworkingconditionsinsugarcane
crop ﬁelds are exposed to thermal, chemical, biological, physiological, mechanical,
and emotional risks and health problems such as respiratory, circulatory, renal, and
musculoskeletal diseases, genotoxic agents, and work-related accidents.
4
Sugarcane Cultivation, Processing, and Sustainability
Of all crops, sugarcane is the plant that converts solar energy into chemical energy
in complex biochemical processes during photosynthesis, in which water, oxygen,
carbohydrates, cellulose, sucrose, and other elements are generated (Takaragawa and
Matsuda 2023). However, only a percentage greater than 20% of the dry matter accu-
mulated during the vegetative period is attributed to commercial value; the remaining
is made up of the residues resulting from sugar production, such as leaves and straws,
bagasse, molasses, ﬁlter, vinasse, and ashes.
The expansion of sugarcane cultivation without sustainable management practices
and cleaner production in industrial facilities were the result of population growth, the
wide application of sucrose as a raw material in the food industry in the development
of new and attractive products for the growing labor force with less time for food
preparation, the wide adaptation of the crop to different regions due to the resilience
characteristics of the sugarcane plant to various environmental limiting factors and
constraints and regional public policies that focused on the cultivation and processing
of sugarcane as a factor of regional development (Singh et al. 2024; Cardoso et al.
2018, 2019).
For ﬁve centuries, sugarcane has been a major cash crop for social welfare in
tropical regions; however, throughout this period, sugarcane production has experi-
enced boom and bust periods due to various geopolitical events such as the oil price
crisis, world wars, the environmental crisis, consumerism and others of various kinds.
According to FAOSTAT (2023), sugarcane is currently grown in more than 130 trop-
ical countries, most of which are developing countries with high levels of poverty,
where sugarcane is perceived as a strategic survival crop that guarantees income,
some social beneﬁts such as access to health services, retirement, life insurance,
etc., since this crop is characterized by its wide adaptation to tropical climates. It is
characterized by its wide adaptation to soil diversity, climate, topography, fertility,
and agronomic management; high green matter production capacity (more than 100
t/ha per year) and dry matter per unit area due to its photosynthetic capacity and its
phenotypic characteristics, including its large leaf area, which helps it to efﬁciently
capture solar energy to transform it into biomass. This represents an opportunity for
the cane sector to continue supporting the global decarbonization effort and become
a welfare factor for the population as a sustainable agroindustry o bioreﬁnery.
The biggest producers of sugar from cane in the world are Brazil, India, China,
Thailand, Pakistan, Mexico, Colombia, Guatemala, and Australia. However, produc-
tion depends on various agroecological and crop management, institutional, and
political factors which are reﬂected in the productivity of the crop. In other words,
Strategies for the Sustainability of Cane Agroindustry and Development …
117
sugarcane is a potential high-yield crop but requires extensive husbandry, contin-
uous investment, and maintenance of capital assets to maximize yields. Brazil is the
world’s largest sugar consumer (123 kg per capita) and plays a critical role in the
global market as both a producer and consumer (Voora et al. 2023) besides producing
40% of the world’s sugar cane.
On the other hand, worldwide sugarcane is grown at all technological levels and
scales of production, from small family farms with limited resources and inputs to
large-scale plantation agriculture, mechanization, techniﬁed irrigation, intensive use
of agrochemicals and precision farming tools and Agriculture 4.0 to supply non-
centrifuged artisanal sugar mills, sugar mills, distilleries and bioreﬁneries (Sanches
et al. 2023) (Table 1 and Fig. 1).

Fig. 1 Value chain of the conventional sugar industry
Since the Industrial Revolution and the consolidation of the capitalist system, the
conception of the nature-society relationship has been based on the consideration of
sugarcane as an external resource that can be exploited for economic purposes.
However, its main target product, sucrose, or table sugar, is a commodity of
great demand and instability derived from geopolitical, public health, environmental,
socioeconomic, and climate change events that directly affect commercialization
within regional preferential agreements and the world market.
These cyclical behaviors evidence periods of shortages followed by growing sugar
surpluses, which inﬂuence international prices that depend mainly on what happens
in the main sugar-producing, consuming, importing, and exporting countries (Fig. 2).
This approach is based on the premise of weak sustainability where technology
and manufactured capital can supply the ecosystem services of natural capital. This
contributes to the argument that reproducible capital is substitutable so that the
economy would not collapse when natural resources decline in productivity based on
resource economics, quantiﬁes the capital investment needed to balance the reduction
of non-renewable resources with the expansion of the harvested area. Such invest-
ment is made to ensure that the standard of living does not decline as society develops
into the indeﬁnite future.
One of the most controversial aspects of this model of sugarcane production is
harvesting. In conventional management, the crop ﬁeld is burned to cut cane by
hand; stem collection is carried out using forklifts and transportation to the industrial
facilities it is through old, highly polluting trucks. In the case of mechanized green

harvesting, specialized machinery is used to cut and lift the cane, sending it to a
vehicle that accompanies it, collecting the cane in small pieces, which are then
transported to the sugar mill (Stem et al. 2024).
Green harvesting of sugarcane represents a viable and sustainable alternative to
the traditional harvesting method used in most sugarcane-producing countries and
can be carried out on land with the required topography (Solomon et al. 2019).
Concerning the unsustainable management practices derived from the controversy
in public health, the environmental impact of the so-called sugarcane agroindustry,
agricultural management practices, and industrial processing, the high generation
of byproducts with a reduced sustainable use, the failed public policies towards the
creation of competitive environments among many other factors of political, envi-
ronmental, technological and socioeconomic context, have led stakeholders, mainly
from academia and research, since the 1950s to seek options to increase the value of
sugarcane as a raw material and processing byproducts in the so-called diversiﬁcation
and reconversion of the sugar industry.
Ni et al. (2022) concluded initial research focused on the chemical and/or biotech-
nological modiﬁcation of sucrose as a molecule of high purity, low cost, and
high conversion capacity through sucrochemicals. This technological initiative was
widely disseminated due to the increasing international instability and price volatility
of sucrose, however, few sucrochemical technological developments were able to
compete with similar products obtained from other sources such as petroleum.
However, it has been demonstrated and driven by the effects of climate change and
the instability of the international price of fossil fuels that cane industries have enor-
mous potential to contribute to the sustainable transition to greener energy, either via
the generation of electricity by cogeneration or the production of biofuels (briquettes,
120
N. Aguilar-Rivera
pellets, ethanol, biogas, biohydrogen, and biomethane) to add value and reduce
emissions. Renewable energy production can be a successful diversiﬁcation option
when supported by public policy, the synergy between entrepreneurs, researchers,
and academics, and the creation of infrastructures to facilitate independent power
production.
Moreover, the search for increased efﬁciency in sugarcane production, extracted
sucrose, and productive diversiﬁcation with emphasis on green energy has led to the
use of different techniques, methodologies, and multi-, inter- and trans-disciplinary
tools, to maximize the use of resources, energy, increasing the quality of processes
and products, as well as reducing the impact on the environment and increasing
proﬁts (Grandis et al. 2023).
Notwithstanding, the current sugarcane agroindustry must face great challenges in
terms of productivity, productive diversiﬁcation, sustainability, competitiveness, and
welfare for the population. Conventional technological management options based
on agrochemicals, water, fossil fuels, and high energy consumption to obtain prod-
ucts of low competitiveness to enter the international market will not be successful,
especially those based on natural resources, and cheap and low-skilled labor.
In this respect, Guerra et al. (2020) commented that competitiveness for the sugar-
cane agroindustry should not only consider high productivity of goods (sugarcane
and sucrose), export capacity and diversiﬁcation of the supply of products from the
sugar mill, distillery, bioreﬁnery (industrialization of byproducts) or in the agricul-
tural ﬁeld with agroecological management practices, it also refers to aspects related
to environmental, social and economic sustainability criteria, its capacity to generate
increasing standards of sustainability, living and welfare of the population located in
the producing geographic regions.
Consequently, the competitiveness of the new sugarcane agribusinesses and bio-
reﬁneries will be achieved in addition to cost leadership/differentiation of products
obtained with state-of-the-art technology, speciﬁc and differentiated inputs, circular
economy and sustainable production of inputs, market knowledge, change of orien-
tation of the productive activity (diversiﬁcation and reconversion) and the technolog-
ical innovation process. This implies a transformation in the research model of the
research, development, innovation, and technology transfer (R + D + I + TT), from
the demand side and the impacts of the industry, ﬁeld, and markets on the quality of
life in the region, i.e., the sustainability of the new agribusinesses based on sugarcane
involves People, Planet and Proﬁtability (Aguilar-Rivera 2022).
The sustainable development approach will allow the concept of nature to be
replaced by the environment in sugarcane production, by proposing a new paradigm,
which is used worldwide, and on which indicators are built and progress can be
measured, as in the case of the BONSUCRO guide (https://bonsucro.com/produc
tion-standard/).
Nevertheless, in most sugarcane-producing countries, agroecological practices,
improvements in processing facilities and infrastructure, treatment and/or diversiﬁed
use of crop residues and processing byproducts, in general, are considered complex
and costly activities due to the low level of R + D + I + TT being carried out, and both
public institutions and private companies have not carried out this work effectively,
Strategies for the Sustainability of Cane Agroindustry and Development …
121
either due to lack of vision, legislation without prospective vision, political will,
diverse interests or lack of economic means. Consequently, it contributes to the
deterioration of the environment in large areas of the sugarcane-producing regions
(Lee et al. 2023).
Thereby, modern sugarcane agribusiness and bioreﬁneries refer to a combina-
tion of diverse technologies and disciplines, institutions, activities, and companies
that develop and deliver material inputs to the agricultural sector, produce primary
goods and, subsequently, have the technological capacity and human capital to
handle, process, transport, market and distribute food and other products such as
new raw materials, ﬁbers, livestock foods, biofuels, bioenergy, and others to various
consumers to generate the greatest sustainability (Reena et al. 2022).
Nonetheless, although diversiﬁcation and bioreﬁneries are fundamentally devel-
opment strategies of the traditional sugar sector; the diversiﬁcation projects in the
sugar and ethanol industry have not been completely successful, due in part to the
fact that technical and economic analyses for each case depend on the geographical
location of projects and predominant economic activities in the regions. In addition,
diversiﬁcation projects have been isolated or limited because they have been devel-
oped due to the economic need to increase income but mainly to reduce production
costs due to environmental impact payments by the waste disposal according to the
environmental laws of each country, such as burning bagasse on boilers to generate
steam and electricity, sell to pulp and paper factories, molasses as livestock feed
raw material, production of fermentation goods or export according to international
prices (Iwuozor et al. 2022; Karp et al. 2022).
As a consequence, the complexity of factors to be analyzed, mainly environ-
mental, social, economic, and political, in the project of a “multipurpose, multipro-
ductive and sustainable sugarcane agroindustry” has not been a reality in most of the
sugarcane-producing countries; and at the present time sugarcane growers are facing
the challenge of productivity reduction in spite of numerous advances in the areas
of agroecology, nutrition and plant protection, instability of the value of sugar, as
a unique product for commercialization in national and international markets. This
complexity requires prioritizing actions to evaluate alternatives for the industrializa-
tion of sugarcane and byproducts to create marketable, proﬁtable, and sustainable
productions, in addition to a change in traditional approaches, betting on innovation,
transformation and the creation of new production chains considering the quality of
the raw material, the composition of the byproducts and not the survival of the crop
and traditional agroindustries (Ungureanu et al. 2022).
Based on the existence of a robust research capital throughout the sugarcane
value chain, it is possible to raise the complex hypothesis: Is it possible to design
a strategy to promote, revalue, consolidate a regional identity and productive inte-
gration, reconvert, diversify, and/or transform the conventional sugarcane agroin-
dustry through the analysis of environmental management and the nature-society
relationship of economic, technological, social, political, cultural and environmental
elements involved in it to generate welfare?
Considering the above, incorporating productive diversiﬁcation in the conven-
tional sugar industry, as a strategy for the development and generation of well-being,
122
N. Aguilar-Rivera
Fig. 3 Constraints for diversiﬁcation projects
is a complex task since it depends on the analysis of numerous factors (Fig. 3).
However,itshouldbeacommonobjectivebetweenstakeholdersanddecision-makers
to generate high proﬁt and welfare for the participants in the value chain (Gonçalves
et al. 2021).
5
Challenges for Increasing Sustainability
in the Valorization of Sugarcane as a Raw Material
in the Circular Economy
Jaroenkietkajorn et al. (2024), Sequeira and Tortato (2023) and Katakojwala et al.
(2019) concluded that the valorization of byproducts to be converted into options
for sustainable development and the well-being of the population, it is necessary to
enhance competencies that allow stakeholders to make technical and administrative
decisions in the short and medium term to increase the productivity of sugarcane
ﬁelds, conventional agroindustry and develop bioreﬁneries within a framework of
sustainable development and circularity in the context of the world economy. This
approach must respond to the challenges of the current sugar industry:
– What is the sustainable future of the sugarcane industry?
– How much can we get from sugarcane and byproducts with novel technologies?
– What will be the competitiveness of the cane products against commercial
products?
– What characteristics should be incorporated in the cane ﬁelds of the future?
– How to move to sustainable sugarcane production?
– How to maximize the use of sugarcane biomass for alternative products?
– How many end products can we get from sugarcane?
Strategies for the Sustainability of Cane Agroindustry and Development …
123
– How to turn the new sugarcane agroindustry or sugarcane bioreﬁnery into a
welfare cluster?
The actions that enable the transition from conventional systems based on the green
revolution and industrialization with fossil-based inputs to sustainable sugarcane
agriculture and eco-industrialization are as follows:
– Territorial Management Approach and intensive use of precision agriculture
(Geographic Information Systems [GIS], Global Positioning System [GPS], and
Remote Sensing [RS]), to restructure the architecture of sugarcane crop ﬁelds to
optimize resources, develop the potential of current cultivars and minimizing the
use of high-cost environmental inputs such as water, energy, and agrochemicals
(Som-Ard et al. 2021).
– Agroecological management of current and future crops to develop the productive
potential of the sugarcane plant to its maximum biomass production potential
(Agroecological approach).
– Nutrition is based on the synergy of the state-of-the-art of chemical fertilizers,
liquid and solid organic manures, biofertilizers, and green manures (Nature-based
solutions).
– Development of new varieties considering extreme climatic conditions (biotic and
abiotic stress) to have enough new varieties to replace current old varieties.
– The use of technological tools such as in vitro cultivation to generate elite,
vigorous, and highly resilient sugarcane plants to improve growth and devel-
opment under unfavorable conditions activates defense mechanisms and favors
the use of other nutrients utilization.
– Techniﬁed irrigation systems using solar energy and water from high-tech
treatment plants.
– Agroecological practices such as intercropping with sugar cane, rotation, regen-
erative agriculture, and permaculture.
– Valorization of ecosystem services, generating new market chains integrating the
environmental dimension in public policies, and establishing clear mechanisms
for their implementation in the territory.
– Tools for modeling, prevention, and management of phytosanitary impacts, i.e., to
establish Epidemiological Surveillance platforms to determine the phytosanitary
status of sugarcane, through spatial and temporal surveys at the regional level, to
issue timely alerts and thus take appropriate measures to prevent infestations.
– Climatology will make it possible to carry out predictive models of climatic events
for the producing region, issuing monthly bulletins for decision-making, and thus
strengthen the epidemiological surveillance process in the behavior of sugarcane
pests and diseases.
– Increase mechanization and harvesting with commercial models with adequate
conditions for this purpose and develop equipment according to the topography
of each region, with advantages in terms of time and labor reduction.
– Signiﬁcantly reduce harvesting by burning because of lower greenhouse gas
(GHG) emissions, improved soil structure, lower water requirements, and savings
in herbicide application in the initial growth stage of the crop. Besides green
124
N. Aguilar-Rivera
harvesting provides the transformation process with higher quality stems and
biology deterioration is extended, unlike the burned cane.
– Establish regional strategies for rural uses of trash (energy, pellets, briquettes,
biochar, substrate for edible mushrooms, and in sugarcane cultivation as mulch for
pest management and soil moisture retention and decomposition as biofertilizer.
– Use trash and byproducts from sugarcane processing and other agroindustries
in synergy in animal feed production, especially for ruminants, through various
technologies such as the production of ﬂours, silage, and supplementary blocks
to improve the quality and availability of nutrients, especially in times of drought.
– In the industrial facilities for processing sugarcane stalks, improve the oper-
ating capacity for production, use of resources, inputs, and lost time, etc. in
strategic planning that allows the achievement of optimal conditions that beneﬁt
the results of the sugarcane agroindustry and identify opportunities for continuous
improvement.
– Increase wastewater treatment plants from efﬂuents of cane processing for the
intelligent use of pollutants and treated water
– The

of

bioproducts will allow a substantial reduction of production costs, inputs, energy,
and water, and increase of sugarcane competitiveness.
– Industry 4.0-based process integration is an indispensable condition to optimize
the comprehensive cane processing process, which is considered a development
objective not only for the minimization of productive costs or the maximization
of different ﬁnancial indicators but also for the improvement of environmental

with the same equipment. Efﬁciency: produce more bioproducts with the same
raw material. Reduction of losses and emissions-contamination. Energy: produce
more with the same energy. Water: produce more with the same or lesser water.
Chemical products: produce more with fewer chemical products, less pollution.

energy, and the growers and entrepreneurs share the proﬁtability of diversiﬁed
production, the payment for cane stems quality and trash where the deal includes
participation to growers of the sale of byproducts and bioproducts.
6
Ecotourism of Agribusiness of Sugarcane
For decades and until centuries the cultivation of cane has been a source of income
for many residents with a high level of poverty in regions that were characterized by
being pioneers in the agricultural development of sugarcane, speciﬁcally in the instal-
lation of the productive systems represented by cane plantation, sugar haciendas,
trapiche, sugar mill, and products, and byproducts. However, with the reduction of
income due to the low proﬁtability of the monoculture derived from the reduction
of soil capacity to support the cane plant to its maximum potential, climatic factors,
pollution by non-technical use of agrochemicals, etc. It is necessary to evaluate
regional alternatives to generate income and well-being for Growers and the popu-
lation. Therefore, the activation of an ecotourism route in the sugarcane landscape,
as an alternative for diversiﬁcation to the traditional cultivation and processing of
cane, would signiﬁcantly contribute to reducing part of the effects of the crisis in
cane regions and would help reduce emigration, poverty and improve the quality of
life of the population located in the areas where sugarcane is cultivated.
Furthermore, ecotourism, as an option of rural transformation, is one of the most
important vehicles for cultural exchange, its conservation should provide respon-
sible and well-managed opportunities to the members of the host community, as
well as provide visitors with the experimentation and immediate understanding of
culture, traditions, religions, beliefs, and environmental heritage of the region. Both
approaches are important to spatially displaying the socio-territorial impact of the
sugar agroindustrial complex in a region to understand the successive crises that
occurred, rescue their assets, and thus be able to raise some alternatives, including
tourism development linked to the sugarcane route (Fig. 4).
Fig. 4 Elements for the sugarcane ecotourism (Sugar hacienda and landscape sugarcane crop ﬁeld
in Córdoba Veracruz México)
126
N. Aguilar-Rivera
For instance, it is indispensable for a possible ecotourism route of the cane in a
region to carry out an inventory of tourist resources, services, and infrastructure such
as geographical situation, type of heritage (cultural and/or natural), accessibility,
characteristics, type and quality of available tourism services, current and potential
infrastructure such as sugar and derivatives museum, art, visit crop ﬁelds, artisanal
production of sugar, rum, spirits, etc. (Martín et al. 2021).
7
Conclusions
In this work, as part of the main objective, the challenges, constraints, public policy
options,andtheapplicationoftransdisciplinaryframeworkswereanalyzedtoachieve
a sustainable sugar cane value chain considering its enormous complexity in each
producing region thereby it is necessary to highlight some conclusions.
Sugar is a physical good (commodity), derived from sugarcane, a plant with high
climate resilience where its vegetative growth with various strategies and techniques
for crop management is carried out in a ﬁeld and an as monoculture and agribusiness
have a deep impact on social and political issues around the world. Sugar or sucrose
is the main ingredient of basic and processed products. Its price ﬂuctuates due to
the relationship between the abundance or shortage of production and its demand,
which is closely related to the production of cane stalks that depend on complex
factors difﬁcult to control, such as weather. The above results in uncertainty and
price volatility for consumers and producers.
The relevance of sugarcane as an agribusiness is partly due to very important
capital investments, as well as the direct dependence of millions of people, who
develop various inherent and complementary activities such as planting, cultivation,
harvest, transport, industrialization, marketing, through industrial facilities called
trapiche,sugarmill,distillery,andbioreﬁnerythatprocesssugarcaneandbyproducts.
Concerning the current characteristics of its consumption as a basic food, there
is a need to generate opportunities to diversify and develop new high-proﬁtability
agribusiness based on cane stems, crop ﬁelds, industrial facilities, and byproducts to
integrate a single vision of all stakeholders towards the same direction, a common
goal of achieving productivity, sustainability, and competitiveness.
This productive sector should be oriented toward the improvement of the value
chain since there is the production of raw material (cane stalks and trash), trans-
port, conversion, manufacturing, and generation of primary goods (sucrose, non-non-
centrifugated sugar, ethanol, electricity, and others), byproducts (bagasse, molasses,
vinasse, ﬁlter mud, combustion ashes, wastewater) that are still marginally used
despite being abundant, technologically suitable for high value-added bioproducts
and ﬁnally to meet regional development goals.
Throughout this novel value chain, stakeholders must optimize production factors,
supplies, goods produced, and conversion of byproducts according to the principles
of the circular economy and use tools and frames such as Life Cycle Assessment
(LCAS), Life Cycle Inventory (LCI) Life Cycle Impacts Assessment (LCIA), Life
Strategies for the Sustainability of Cane Agroindustry and Development …
127
Cycle Costing (LCC), Life Cycle Engineering (LCE), Social Life-Cycle Assessment
(S-LCA), ISO and Bonsucro Certiﬁcations, Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR),
Agriculture 4.0 and Industry 4.0 to fully develop the potential of sugarcane and as a
result of the foregoing, collateral agribusiness contribute signiﬁcantly to sustainable
development and well-being of the producing regions.
