Greening Main Street USA: Adapting
Sustainability Indicators to Rural Areas
A’dayr Shewmaker, Anne E. Egelston, and Karl Aho
Abstract Given the recent rises in climate change, inﬂation rates, and social strife,
sustainable development is increasingly important. Accordingly, sustainability indi-
cators should be adapted for use across a variety of local levels, not just in the urban
counties containing metropolitan hotspots where they are currently most commonly
employed. As sustainable development indicators reﬂect the relationship of both
communal and individual sustainability and resiliency, this project will highlight
areas of concern that could further advance sustainable development in rural areas
in developed countries.
Keywords Sustainable indicators · Rural sustainable development · Resiliency ·
Ecoregions
1
Introduction
Within American society, the idea of “Main Street” with its tidy buildings, quaint
houses, and pristine tree-lined roadways remains a critical component of American
identity. Main Street designated communities celebrate their distinctive local culture,
public history, and economic development. Receiving the Main Street designation
or other similar recognition serves as a mark of distinction that could serve to bolster
community pride, increase real estate values, and encourage economic development
(Birch 2002; van Leuven 2022).
Main Street USA has come to symbolize both the populous urban areas that
have preserved some of their historic buildings and picturesque countryside as well
as the quaint small towns that eagerly await tourists coming to get away from it
all. Yet the lived experience of many residents of rural America may conﬂict with
the idyllic picture the Main Street designation implies. With the mass migration of
people entering the American city, rural areas have suffered a signiﬁcant decline.
A. Shewmaker · A. E. Egelston (B) · K. Aho
Tarleton State University, Stephenville, TX, USA
e-mail: egelston@tarleton.edu
© The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024
W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_8
131
132
A. Shewmaker et al.
Today roughly 20% of Americans live in rural communities (United States Census
Bureau 2017).
The decline in rural resources combined with the lack of government support
has made rural communities vulnerable to further population decline and economic
instability. Rural communities are less likely to adopt sustainability than their urban
counterparts due to a lack of ﬁnancial ability and institutional capacities (Haider
et al. 2017). These communities are further hampered because they do not receive
the same level of developmental resources from government funding (Ajilore and
Willingham 2019). Additionally, the absence of many facets of an urban society
may also impact the resiliency of communities, a concept that should be closely
intertwined with sustainability.
Rural American communities may be vulnerable to a wider variety of negative
externalities than people relocating from rural communities to urban areas. Like
many urban areas, global environmental problems such as climate change, ozone
depletion, and biodiversity loss also impact rural populations. Additionally, local and
regional environmental degradation such as a reduction in the water table impacts
people, especially that portion of the population that choose to live more remotely
on property far removed from a population center.
This facet of the American experience may emphasize people as part of the land as
explainedbyLeopold(1949).Throughthispioneeringwork,Leopoldpointedoutthat
those who loved the land were more likely to act to preserve it. Thus, for Leopold, one
focalpointofpeople’srelationshipwithnaturefocusedontheirintroductiontonature,
primarily through characteristically rural activities like hunting, ﬁshing, farming, and
ranching. Nature tourism also constitutes an entry point into a relationship with land.
Signiﬁcant regional differences exist within the United States that contribute
to nature tourism. The American insistence on creating the National Park Service
embedded nature tourism as part of the American experience. Much like the Main
Street Program, hosting national parks, or their state counterparts, also increases the
prestige of a community as interest in understanding differences between the regions
grows.
As part of their national responsibilities in protecting the environment, the Envi-
ronmental Protection Agency (EPA) publishes research about the status of the coun-
tryside, including information about the various regions. EPA currently utilizes a
tiered approach to describing ecoregions within North America, including the conti-
nental United States. Level 1 ecoregions focus on the highest levels of commonalities
to discern large-scale patterns. Level 2 and Level 3 ecoregions each improve clarity
by focusing on successfully smaller differences. With 84 so-called Level 3 ecore-
gions recognized by EPA (2013) for the continental United States, the American
landscape contains great diversity that merits consideration. While rural lifestyles
may share similarities, generic or vague indicators may not be able to capture the
distinctive nature of the relationships with the land given the amount of variation
within the country.
The sheer variety of ecoregions within the United States could constitute a signif-
icant barrier to a full understanding of the relationships necessary to implement
sustainability in a rural setting. Rural communities and ecoregions have rarely been
Greening Main Street USA: Adapting Sustainability Indicators to Rural …
133
a priority for academic researchers as urban areas receive signiﬁcantly more scrutiny
(Opp and Saunders 2013). This, however, may be changing as recent innovations in
big data allow for larger scales of study. For example, the recently published Climate
Vulnerability Index uses data at the Census block level to predict the areas that may
be most vulnerable to climate change in the future (Lewis et al. 2023).
Adding rural areas of study to the existing literature increases our ability to
successfully implement sustainable development. This project establishes a ratio-
nale for creating sustainability indicators for rural communities that encompass
ecoregions in addition to political boundaries, as a necessary condition to under-
standing the relationship between people and the environment along with increasing
our understanding of the overall health and well-being of rural America.
The chapter continues in the next section by reviewing critical elements within
the scope of the project, namely rural communities, ecoregions, sustainability, and
resiliency. The chapter continues by highlighting current scholarship that may be
used to derive theoretical insights about these elements to create a new theoretical
model for future testing. This section also includes the development of hypotheses
that could be tested in future research. This chapter concludes by reviewing the
potential limitations of the model and hypotheses.
1.1
Deﬁning Ecoregions, Sustainability, and Resiliency
As this work closely examines the intersection of ecoregions, sustainability, and
resiliency, deﬁning these terms and describing the basis of their interactions may
be prudent. Sustainable communities affect the social, economic, and environmental
well-being of the persons, ﬂora, and fauna that comprise them. These communities
or ecological regions, also called ecoregions, are areas exhibiting similarities in the
ecosystem (Omernik and Bailey 1997) that fuse together ecological and geograph-
ical conceptualizations to create a socio-ecological system (Loveland and Merchant
2004). Ecoregions are important to the sustainability discussion because sustain-
ability occurs within, and depends upon, an ecoregion. Human well-being cannot be
separated from the well-being of the land, in its broadest sense. By emphasizing the
role that ecoregions play in determining environmental quality, it may be possible to
ensure a more sustainable and resilient society (Walker et al. 2004).
Ecoregions contain both biological diversity and social diversity. These two facets
interact along at least two dimensions. First, the contours of the ecoregion may dictate
human behavior as people base their lifestyle on their geography, including natural
resource availability and climate. Natural resource availability not only impacts
whether humans can comfortably dwell in the area, but it also contributes to the
economy through natural resource extraction. Second, social processes may have
the ability to transform the ecoregion as socio-ecological drivers interact to form
complex relationships at a systems level (Londe et al. 2022).
Sustainability, introduced in the late 1970s, seeks to alter the dominant global
economic paradigm and its growth imperative by incorporating human dimensions
134
A. Shewmaker et al.
and environmental resource limitations directly into the global economy. While
the earliest uses of sustainability occurred most directly in relationship to natural
resource conservation, the World Commission on Environment and Development
broadened its conceptualization (Egelston 2013, 2022; Mebratu 1998). Thus, sustain-
able development acquired its now familiar deﬁnition of “a development that meets
the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to
meet their own needs” (World Commission on Environment and Development 1987).
Sustainable development contains three policy dimensions or “pillars” responsible
for equally carrying the weight of achieving sustainable development: environment,
economy, and society. The three pillars of sustainability reinforce each other to
provide equilibrium between these three elements.
Since Our Common Future’s release in 1987, sustainability has remained an
elusive concept, in that it consistently means different things to different groups
(White 2013). While states agreed to discuss sustainability at the Earth Summit in
1992, adopting Agenda 21 proved to be contentious and difﬁcult (Egelston 2013,
2022). Within Agenda 21, states emphasized eliminating poverty as a major goal
along with managing individual consumption, shifting energy production from fossil
fuels to renewable resources, and limiting natural resource extraction. States also
highlighted the need for ensuring clean water, sewage, and solid waste treatment for
all global residents. However, the United States vociferously objected to provisions
that requested limiting future consumption and swiftly ignored the document, turning
into a “laggard” in the words of Lafferty and Meadowcroft (2000).
Selman (1998) called the emergence of Local Agenda 21 as one of the “unexpected
outcomes” of the Earth Summit that spurred action in many cities. As a result, urban
areas mobilized to support sustainability. This response added a layer of governance
to the sustainability discourse and cities gained political saliency that coexists, albeit
unequally, with national policies. It is unsurprising, then, that cities quickly emerged
as a focal area for sustainability as these governments looked to limit their negative
impact on the environment and provide positive examples of implementing projects
in support of sustainable development.
Efforts within the formal diplomatic systems to further implement sustainability
culminated in the 2000 Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) that galvanized
action through a framework of accountability for national governments from 2000
to 2015 (Fukuda-Parr 2004). While developing countries, the target audience for
the MDGs, widely failed to meet many of these goals, the creation process behind
the MDGs proved beneﬁcial and garnered global attention. States’ interest grew
over this ﬁfteen-year period, culminating with the World Summit on Sustainable
Development, held in New York City, September 25–27th 2015. States authored
Transforming Our World: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development which
continued to support the three pillars of sustainability (UN General Assembly 2015).
The SDGs emphasized goals and targets that apply to sustainable development.
Organizations at all levels of society may develop indicators, as they are an indis-
pensable tool to properly analyze and measure sustainable development (Lehtonen
et al. 2016). The pursuit of sustainability measurement has occurred on two different
Greening Main Street USA: Adapting Sustainability Indicators to Rural …
135
tracks, one led by states through the United Nations, and another by the so-called non-
state actors, many of which have focused on cities, away from formal arenas of inter-
national diplomacy. Thus, the debate over the creation and selection of sustainability
indicators evolved through self-selection for organizations, research initiatives, and
UN-led initiatives.
Many research projects developing indicators for rural context do so in the context
of speciﬁc development projects. Some sustainability studies focused on rural areas
emphasized the need for development that enables data collection, extending that
concept from smart cities to smart rural villages (Maja et al. 2020). Other studies
used speciﬁc goals, like a “safe, healthy, convenient and comfortable rural living
environment,” to guide their selection of indicators (Li et al. 2021). A third sort of
study used a restricted set of indicators, e.g. focusing on socio-economic indicators
rather than social indicators as such (Zhao et al. 2021). Each of these approaches
adds to sustainability research and can guide sustainable policymaking. However,
the fact that rural areas are studied less frequently mean that many such areas lack
the insights that might be gleaned from such studies, or are limited by not having a
more complete set of indicators.
Urban areas beneﬁtted from multiple research projects that created indicators.
Projects range in scale from those involving single cities (Holden 2006), multiple
cities (Opp and Saunders 2013; Steiniger et al. 2020), or cities and their surrounding
areas (Mascarenhas et al. 2010). Methodologies for these various categories vary as
Opp and Saunders (2013) created a methodology speciﬁcally for ranking cities while
Steiniger et al. (2020) designed a methodology to allow a comparison yet avoid a
ranking.
The focus on cities within sustainability also led to concerns about resilience as
SDG 11’s mission is to “make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient
and sustainable” (United Nations General Assembly 2015). This phrasing, along with
the linkage between climate change adaptation and resiliency, led to discussion and
debate of the nature of the relationship between sustainability and resiliency. Like
sustainability, resiliency is an elusive concept. Holling (1973) described resilience
as the magnitude of disruption that could occur before the system reorganized.
While sustainability focuses on how to responsibly manage resources to not
disrupt the needs of future generations, resiliency focuses on the response of a system,
to consistent stress and drastic shocks including natural disasters and climate changes
as well as human-induced catastrophes (Marchese et al. 2018). Resiliency has also
been conceptualized as identical or exceptionally similar to sustainability (Adger
2003, Edwards 2009; Farrell and Twinning-Ward 2005; Marchese et al. 2018), as
persistence (Fiksel et al. 2014), as recovery from a shock (Walker 2020; Walker et al.
2002; Walker et al. 2004; Walker and Salt 2006), and as an adaptative capacity with a
particular emphasis on linkages to climate change adaptation (Redman 2014). With
these deﬁnitions in place, the next section begins to develop a theoretical model that
relates sustainability indicators to resiliency.
136
A. Shewmaker et al.
2
Literature Review
While state governments may have a vested interest in assuring that resiliency
occurs within their boundaries, other actors have signiﬁcant input in measuring this
social phenomenon (Roostaie et al. 2019). The shared concern from both political
and academic entities in sustainability indicators through both formal negotiating
processes and informal systems suggests that implementing sustainability fall under
the heading of global governance with its reliance on non-state actors, academic
resources, and weak institutional arrangements (Biermann et al. 2017; Kanie and
Biermann 2017). Governance, particularly global governance, may be used to indi-
cate instances where political goals such as sustainability and resiliency may be
deemed worthwhile by states, but that the political power of the state may be notably
absent in dictating measures to meet these goals (Eskelinen 2021).
Managing global society to achieve sustainable development requires self-
directing tools given the decentralization of state power (Biermann et al. 2017).
Utilizing frameworks with indicators thus serves as one means to coordinate these
independent movements as the existence of these frameworks has the potential to
improve the communication of sustainable development to internal and external audi-
ences (Kanie and Biermann 2017; Lehtonen et al. 2016; Lyytimäki et al. 2013). Thus,
the incorporation of additional levels of government could be seen as a necessary
expansion to complete the shift to a sustainable development paradigm that also
emphasizes resiliency.
A rapid proliferation of indicator frameworks has emerged and continues to
expand. Lehtonen et al. (2016) noted that no universal framework for sustainability
currently exists that applies to all circumstances in all locales. Consequently, sustain-
ability frameworks exist at multiple levels of government including the local, the
regional, the national, and the supranational (c.f. Lehtonen et al. 2016; Michalina
et al. 2021; Moreno Pires et al. 2014).
Indicator selection remains a difﬁcult and contested process within sustainability
frameworks. Not only does the selection process reﬂect the application of political
power structures and inﬂuence over outcomes, but the process also reﬂects norma-
tive elements of what constitutes well-being for both individuals and communi-
ties (Rametsteiner et al. 2011). These political and normative processes also impact
studies of sustainability and resiliency.
Moreno Pires et al. (2014) noted that common indicators for sustainability frame-
works may not be viable as solutions vary according to cultural, political, and insti-
tutional contexts. Ecological diversity also impacts sustainability solutions. Sustain-
ability in the Mojave Desert, by necessity, will appear signiﬁcantly different from
sustainability on the American Gulf Coast.
For the researcher, creating an indicator framework also could introduce bias
due to these inherent relationships. Academic scholarship separates the indicator
selection process into a “bottom-up” approach that requires the formation of a group
consisting of local experts who select the indicators for their area (Lützkendorf
and Balouktsi 2017) Conversely, other scholars advocate the “top-down” approach
Greening Main Street USA: Adapting Sustainability Indicators to Rural …
137
where the researcher selects the indicators based on their expert knowledge (Hajer
et al. 2015). Atanada (2018) introduced a methodology that combined these two
approaches. In the case, where a single researcher seeks to perform these steps,
heightened potential for bias occurs.
Sustainability frameworks tend to be created by similar processes that include
selecting or creating indicators, selecting variables, applying the indicator to the
target, and evaluating the information provided (Steiniger et al. 2020). With the
proliferation of case studies, the indicator search process itself becomes increasingly
difﬁcult. As each study adds to the academic literature, the amount of knowledge,
time, and effort necessary to complete a study disproportionately increases. No easy
solution to the laborious process of sorting through indicators exists in part because
some indicators may be able to transcend boundaries, while other indicators will not.
That is not tosaythat commonalities betweensustainabilityindicators donot exist,
regardless of the process of their creation. For example, there should not be much
variability in an indicator seeking to measure unemployment to determine the amount
of poverty within a country, regardless of the level of analysis of the sustainability
framework. However, ecosystems while universal, are also uniquely constituted, and
some portion of the sustainability indicators may need to be highly localized. For
example, there is a difference between an indicator that seeks to measure biodiversity
(a commonly included indicator) as opposed to an indicator that seeks to measure the
health and well-being of a so-called keystone species as an indicator of ecosystem
health (Dale et al. 2018).
Miola and Schlitz (2019) conﬁrm that there is a tradeoff between the need
for generic indicators that allow comparability and the desire to have detailed
data for local decision-making processes. While it is understandable that certain
commonalities between areas would allow for some standardization, the diversity of
sustainability solutions remains an important, if elusive, concept.
Past attempts to reconcile sustainability and resiliency into an integrative frame-
work focused on resiliency in light of a socio-economic system. Marchese et al.
(2018) suggested three possible relationships between sustainability and resiliency.
First, resiliency serves as a subset of sustainability. Second, sustainability serves
as a subset of resiliency. Third, sustainability and resiliency serve as two indepen-
dent constructs. Lew et al. (2016) supported the third framework and distinguished
sustainability and resiliency as differing discourses that approach similar questions
and policy choices with differing outlooks, normative frameworks, and assumptions
that ultimately result in different outcomes.
The relationship between resiliency and sustainability then can be categorized
into a positive relationship, a negative relationship, or an uncorrelated relationship
(Marchese et al. 2018). Recognizing that much of the research to date occurred at the
system level, we propose instead using indicators to investigate the sub-system levels
to ask the question of why resiliency and sustainability may be positively, negatively,
or not correlated. Folke et al. (2010) also recognize the need to examine resiliency
at a sub-system level. They distinguish resiliency at the system level (generalized
resiliency) versus resiliency at the sub-system level (specialized resiliency). There
is, however, no linkage provided between sustainability and specialized resiliency.
138
A. Shewmaker et al.
Introducing the sub-system level allows for consideration of resiliency from
differing points within the system. For example, some scholars consider resiliency
from the perspective of an individual psychological standpoint as a positive adap-
tive response to adversity (Chaskin 2008; Luther et al. 2000). Other scholars view
resiliency as promoting recovery from traumatic life events (Masten et al. 1990), such
as rebuilding communities after a hurricane. Finally, there is the idea that resiliency
is a result of everyday human activities, or “ordinary magic,” rather than extraor-
dinary interventions (Masten 2001). These speciﬁc social perspectives contribute
to our understanding of the relationship between resilience and sustainability by
illuminating phenomena that a system-level approach would not.
Consider, for example, a teacher who brings food to their classroom because
they know their students are food-insecure. The teacher’s action is not extraordinary.
They observed student hunger and found a solution that reduced hunger, thereby
improving education outcomes psychologically (because students have the energy
to learn) and socially (because of the beneﬁcial effects of eating together). A system-
level analysis would not recognize this teacher as contributing to the community’s
resilience because this method relies on outcomes rather than observation. Nor would
such an approach recognize community institutions like food pantries or groups
offering free meals to hungry college students. These sorts of hidden interventions
may be especially important in rural communities, particularly those without the
economies of scale that (Haider et al. 2017) describe. Such communities may lack
mechanisms for data collection and analysis. Attending to the social sub-system thus
provides insights into resilience that a system-level analysis would not. Moreover,
these insights may prove especially salient for maintaining Main Street, particularly
in rural contexts.
Shifting perspectives to the sub-system level may also allow a closer analysis
of the sustainability and resiliency relationship and the indicators used to measure
them in the context of particular communities. Returning to the deﬁnitions of both
resiliency and sustainability, four possible types of relationships emerge. The ﬁrst is
that indicators may be both sustainable and resilient. The second is that indicators
may be sustainable, but not resilient. The third is that indicators may be resilient, but
not sustainable. The fourth is that indicators may be neither sustainable nor resilient.
Understanding the four types of relationship between sustainability and resiliency
may help illustrate where the negative trade-offs occur. Awareness of these trade-
offs may help decision-makers negotiate pathways to the future that provide a better
balance not only between these trade-offs but also between these two concepts. The
underlying theoretical framework suggests that sustainability and resiliency could
work together to transform our society. Alternatively, an unsustainable system that
is highly resilient may frustrate attempts to establish a new system.
Greening Main Street USA: Adapting Sustainability Indicators to Rural …
139
3
Methods
The methods applied within this research combine the use of a meta-analysis in an
attempt to investigate the relationship between sustainability and resiliency. This
research incorporates part of Glass’ (1976) deﬁnition where an analysis occurs of “a
large collection of analysis results from individual studies for the purpose of inte-
gratingtheﬁndings”.ThisresearchalsoincorporatedCooper’s(1982)suggestionthat
rigorous methods must be used in the “process of collecting and coding studies”. The
conceptualization and creation of this research process can be broken down into the
same ﬁve stages that Cooper (1982) utilized: “problem formulation, data collection,
evaluation of data points, data analysis and interpretation, and the presentation of
results.” The meta-analysis for this research began by examining the Web of Science
database. First, a search conducted on the Web of Science database for “sustain-
ability indicators” resulted in 3,075 article results. Furthermore, this research only
searched the database Web of Science for “sustainability indicators”, limiting this
research to only containing Web of Science available articles. The assessment of
the Web of Science database implemented two notes made by Seuring and Müller
(2008) and used (1) only peer-reviewed scientiﬁc journals in English and (2) did not
use publications from known predatory journals. Applying these two steps narrowed
the scope of the study to 659 articles.
Individual indicators from each article formed the initial indicator dataset. Consol-
idation of duplicate indicators that stated the same thing such as “voter participation”
across multiple articles, or if the indicators measured the same thing, just worded
differently, such as “percent change in the forest area” and “rate of forest deple-
tion” occurred. Additionally, “vague” indicators appeared consistently throughout
the previous literature as articles discussed indicators as a broad category such as
“education” instead of focusing on a more detailed issue within the category such as
“number of students entering the primary education last year, according to gender”
(Jeníček 2013). Deciphering which indicators to incorporate led to the creation
of a 393 indicator meta-sustainability index, creating a comprehensive account of
sustainable development.
4
Results
Continued research investigating the interconnectedness of resiliency and sustain-
ability will require signiﬁcant intellectual curiosity. A variety of indicators already
exist that have been developed either under the guise of sustainability indicators or
resiliency indicators. The more problematic process will be consolidating the two
differing literatures given the historical disagreement of normative values, primary
ﬁelds of study, and diversity of geographic areas that could be studied. Equally
important, the likelihood that sustainability frameworks and resiliency frameworks
utilize the same indicators is, in our opinion, high. That does not necessarily mean
140
A. Shewmaker et al.
that sustainability and resiliency are, or should be, the same concept. Instead, it is
much more likely that resiliency, the “ordinary magic” of the individual working or
organizing at the sub-system level, may not be measurable. It does not mean that the
phenomena do not exist. Therefore, we recommend a research agenda that acts to
identify, consolidate, and classify the nature and type of each indicator.
A preliminary analysis attempted this analysis for communities located in rural
Texas (Shewmaker 2023). Texas serves as an interesting example when attempting to
assess sustainability utilizing ecoregions within the United States in that it provides
the second largest land mass, the second largest population, and the largest number
of Level 3 ecoregions within the continental United States at twelve. Texas would
not necessarily rank highly in the public recognition of sustainability initiatives, yet
these projects and initiatives do occur regularly.
5
Conclusions
While this work did not construct new theoretical insights per se, two generative
conclusions emerged from this project. The ﬁrst is that sustainability indicators
dominate resiliency indicators at the system and the sub-system level. This ﬁnding
may have two reasons: research predominantly focuses on sustainability indicators.
Resilience indicators, those that deal with a shock to the system or recovery from a
disaster,maybehardertoconceptualizeandmeasure.Thisisperhapsnotassurprising
as it ﬁrst appears. Recalling that one of Marchese et al. (2018)’s frameworks involved
the supposition that sustainability and resiliency are effectively the same concept,
it may not be so surprising that the indicators reﬂect this conceptual conundrum.
Additionally, the nature of resiliency, especially at the sub-system level, as ordinary
magic reﬂected by individuals may defy easy measurement by an indicator system.
This may be especially relevant when dealing with areas where there may be fewer
people and more livestock and feral animals.
A second signiﬁcant conclusion of this project is that the current body of literature
dealing with sustainability and resiliency indicators is highly duplicative, vague, and
generic. Even relatively similar concepts such as improving water quality may be
expressed in differing formats. For example, water quality appeared in multiple arti-
clesaseitherthepopulationwithaccesstodrainageandwastewatertreatmentsystems
or as independent indicators that speciﬁed the pollutant in the water. Isolating indica-
tors generated to be compatible across geographical locations that were nevertheless
unique to any singular ecosystem was nearly impossible.
The problem is not a lack of indicators, the problem is an overabundance thereof.
Michelina et al. (2021) pointed out that the number of indicator choices may be in
the hundreds for urban indices. In the absence of the constraint limiting the indi-
cator selection process to cities, Shewmaker’s (2023) research demonstrated that
this number may be dramatically understated with an initial indicator selection
process that numbered in the thousands and continues to rise. The impact of this
Greening Main Street USA: Adapting Sustainability Indicators to Rural …
141
overwhelming number of possibilities for indicators on researchers may be signiﬁ-
cant. Referring to Steiniger et al.’s four step methodology, step 1 involves indicator
selection (2013) that either comes from previous efforts or injects new indicators
into an already crowded ﬁeld. As the number of works increases, this task becomes
increasingly difﬁcult given the sheer volume of indicators to review.
We are not suggesting an end to research studying local and regional areas, espe-
cially ones that focus on environmental boundaries as well as political boundaries.
There are too few studies, especially in rural regions in both the developing South and
the developed North, for our comfort. We merely note that the absence of consis-
tency in the literature more dramatically impacts scholars who experience more
resource constraints in the areas of time and money. We also express our concern that
recirculating generic or vague indicators focused on urban communities may yield
diminishing returns. In the end, it may not matter much if one person calculated the
penetration of renewable energy by measuring the amount of government buildings
with solar panels while another person calculated the same target by measuring the
number of buildings in the city with solar installations.
We point out that people around the globe are concerned about the same things—
unemployment and poverty, housing, water quality, access to water, and the source
of energy. These things tend to dominate sustainability frameworks. Recapitulating
(Opp and Saunders’ 2013) comment that the social pillar within sustainability has
been understudied, we suspect this would no longer be the case. Research has rushed
to ﬁll this gap in the years since the comment was ﬁrst made.
We note the absence of indicators that apply to unique items; while many studies
mentioned biodiversity, few indicators could capture details about the local ecore-
gion. For example, generic indicators exist that seek to measure the environmental
quality of any of the Texas ecoregions. One that applied to multiple ecoregions
included measuring the density of the trees. We are unconvinced that this indicator
sufﬁciently measures sustainability or resiliency. The Main Street America designa-
tion requires that cities have a unique quality about them, our indicators should reﬂect
this diversity as well. Tolstoy famously contended that all happy families are alike,
but sustainable and resilient communities succeed differently from one another.

The Impact of Monetary Policy
on Climate Change: A Systematic
Literature Review and Future Research
Recommendations
Nadeen Omar and Dina Yousri
Abstract Central banks’ efforts in combating climate change are now a rising topic
of discussion. Until recently, environmental concerns were not the focus of central
banks’ policies. As of writing this chapter, some central banks have already taken
action to address climate change. However, this topic is highly debated as it is seen
as a threat to central banks’ policy effectiveness: it puts the policies under political
pressure and risks their independence. To provide a comprehensive overview of the
existing research on the subject, we conducted a systematic literature review of 20
empirical studies. Despite its importance, the impact of monetary policy on climate
change has been understudied. This chapter summarizes the current debate and calls
for action to central banks to be involved in the climate change issue. Moreover,
the review seeks to inform policymakers about the potential impact of their policies
on climate change, offering a foundation for their decision-making. Therefore, this
review aims to not only summarize the existing empirical studies but also to suggest
directions for future research.
Keywords Central bank mandates · Central bank · Climate change · Mission
creep · Monetary policy · Systematic literature review
1
Introduction
Sustainable development, as it was ﬁrst deﬁned, is the concept of meeting present
needs without compromising future generations (Burton 1987). Promoting inclusive
and sustainable growth is a crucial element of the 2030 Agenda and its Sustain-
able Development Goals (SDGs). Governments are prioritizing sustainable economic
growth to integrate economic, social, and environmental dimensions of development,
N. Omar (B) · D. Yousri
German University in Cairo, New Cairo, Egypt
e-mail: Nadeen.emadeldin@guc.edu.eg
D. Yousri
e-mail: Dina.elsayed@guc.edu.eg
© The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024
W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_9
145
146
N. Omar and D. Yousri
especially in the face of economic crises like the Great Financial Crisis and the Covid-
19 pandemic (Pérez-Moreno et al. 2022). However, the debate surrounding the inclu-
sion of climate mandates within the operational mandate of central banks remains
controversial. The reason being the persistent questions regarding the effective-
ness and costs associated with implementing monetary policy measures to advance
environmental sustainability (Shobande 2022).
The main aim of ﬁscal and monetary policies is to stabilize economies. According
to growth literature, we can hypothesize a potential spillover from policies on the
environment. Therefore, it is an empirical question to investigate the impact of such
policies on the environment (Faria 1998). In the literature on environmental pollution,
a set of determinants are acknowledged, usually include: remittance inﬂows, aggre-
gate domestic demand consumption, and national income (Gassebner et al. 2011).
Considering that almost all acknowledged determinants affect economic growth and
subsequently the environment, it makes monetary policy a potential determinant. A
new strand of empirical literature empirically investigated monetary policy as one
of the determinants of climate change (Qingquan et al. 2020). However, the link
between monetary policy and the environment is under-studied (Aghabalayev and
Ahmad 2023).
Concurrently, as climate change issues have been on the rise, there is a call for
action to central banks to use their toolkit to mitigate the environmental crisis.
However, incorporating such environmental issues is argued to put their policies
under political pressure and risk their independence and policy effectiveness. The
framework developed in Qingquan et al. (2020) is the basis for most of the studies
in this review; it shows that contractionary monetary policy has a negative effect
on Carbon Dioxide (CO2) emissions due to its tightening effects on investment and
consumption while the opposite holds for expansionary monetary policy (Chishti
et al. 2021; Pradeep 2022; Zeraibi et al. 2022). To plan for the changing role of
central banks, we must learn how the standing mandates are affecting the climate
change issue.
1.1
Monetary Policy and Climate Change: Why Should
Central Banks Be Involved?
Greenhouse gas emissions dramatically increased since the 1960s, with 81% of
these emissions attributed to rising levels of CO2 gas emissions, making it the
most commonly used measure when econometrically modeling climate change. The
expected consequences of this phenomenon are wide-ranging and include the melting
of polar ice caps, rising sea levels, deterioration in environmental quality, damage
to agricultural crop production, and a range of other natural disasters in addition to
an increase in temperature, losses in human lives, and spread of diseases (Taha et al.
2022). As a result, the current strand of environmental research aim to determine
The Impact of Monetary Policy on Climate Change: A Systematic …
147
the contributing factors to CO2 emissions to help policy makers target the correct
variables to mitigate it (Chishti et al. 2021; Liguo et al. 2022; Nguyen et al. 2022).
The increasing environmental damage due to climate change is believed to even-
tually put the effectiveness of monetary policy at risk if global warming surpasses
a certain level; this is related to the instability it may cause to macro-ﬁnance and
sovereign risk. Hence, there is a call to action for Central banks to account for this
risk and to get involved in sustainability issues and mitigate climate change. This will
require an evolution in the role, governance, and mandate of central banks (Dikau
and Volz 2021).
Climate change threatens ﬁnancial stability through market risks, reduced ﬁrm
proﬁtability, loan default, and asset price deﬂation. After the ﬁnancial crisis, central
banks, such as the European Central Bank (ECB), used unconventional monetary
policy measures to rescue economies, such as unlimited provision of liquidity to
banks with ﬁxed interest rates, long-term reﬁnancing operations, extension of assets
accepted as collateral, liquidity swaps, and asset and bond purchases (Hilmi et al.
2022). This raised the question of how central banks can allocate their resources
and direct their policies in a way that balances economic growth and environmental
stability (Ullah et al. 2021).
Recent research explores the inﬂuence monetary policy has on CO2 emissions
(Chishti et al. 2021). As monetary policy targets price stability and growth, it is
expected that monetary policy potentially impacts CO2 emissions. This transmis-
sion is hypothesized to occur through energy consumption, innovation, aggregate
demand consumption, ﬁnancial development, and income level (Nguyen et al. 2022);
when contractionary monetary policy is employed, central banks increase interest
rates, making borrowing more expensive. This, in turn, reduces in aggregate demand,
production, and fossil fuel consumption, and ultimately, lowers CO2 emission levels.
The opposite is true for an expansionary monetary policy (Jiang et al. 2021).
Hence, expansionary policies are hypothesized to be associated with higher levels
of emissions. However, central banks’ policies cannot substitute climate policies,
as this intervention can cause ﬁnancial disruptions making it an unsuitable tool to
combat climate change (Shobande 2022). Nevertheless, there is a push towards the
idea that central banks should consider the environment and climate-related ﬁnancial
risks (Nguyen et al. 2022). The main recommendation is to adopt green monetary
policy that encourages green ﬁnance (Mahmood et al. 2022).
1.2
Are Central Banks Taking Action?
Since 2019, a number of central banks have begun to recognize the issue and explic-
itly acknowledge it in their public communication. The ﬁrst San Francisco Federal
Reserve convention marked the ﬁrst-ever Economics of Climate Change conference
in November 2019 (Pradeep 2022). In 2021, the ECB introduced a plan towards
mitigating climate risks and is strongly committed to considering climate change in
monetary policy (European Central Bank 2021).
148
N. Omar and D. Yousri
Dikau and Volz (2021) provide a report of the central bank mandates and highlight
thecentralbanksthathaveexplicitlyadjustedtheirmandatetoaddressclimatechange
and green policies, the implicit ones, and the ones of no mention at all. Out of
their analysis of 135 central banks’ mandates, 12% adopted the idea explicitly in
their mandates (that is, to promote sustainable growth), and 40% support national
policy objectives without interfering with their primary objective (that is mostly price
stability). Those 2 categories totaled to 70 central banks. One central bank with no
explicit mention of sustainability in their mandate is the Bank of England, yet they
are taking action to combat climate change. This is regarded as over-stepping their
mandate, too political, and referred to as “mission creep”. Dikau and Volz (2021)
continue to highlight that the central banks with sustainable growth in their objectives
did not intend to include climate change, however, with the rising sustainability issues
it falls under their mandates.
To plan for the changing role of central banks, we have to learn how the standing
mandates are affecting the Climate Change issue. This review is an attempt at a
comprehensive summary of all empirical studies done on the impact of monetary
policy on climate change. Despite its importance, this topic is understudied, thus, we
aim to draw some future research recommendations. Additionally, inform policy-
makers of the potential impact of their policies on climate change and help provide
a base to support their decisions to include this issue in their mandates.
2
Methodology
To provide a research summary that serves as a steppingstone for future studies and
policy makers, a qualitative research design has been adopted (Palmatier et al. 2018).
The review was conducted in accordance with Tranﬁeld et al. (2003), Palmatier
et al. (2018), and Snyder (2019). With this review, we have two aims: ﬁrst, to
encourage future research building upon earlier studies on this topic. Second, we
aim to showcase the diversity and critically evaluate the methods and results of our
sample.
For this purpose, we chose a systematic review, as it is regarded to be the most
efﬁcient and high-quality method to evaluate the existing literature in a given ﬁeld
(Tranﬁeld et al. 2003). Systematic reviews are considered the “gold standard” as they
follow a detailed and transparent procedure, with explicit inclusion and exclusion
criteria and documented steps that aim to minimize bias and encourage replicating
the procedure (Palmatier et al. 2018; Snyder 2019). Table 1 lists the answer to each
step from Snyder (2019).
The ﬁltering process is shown in Fig. 1: ﬁrst, the research question was formulated,
followed by retrieving articles from the Scopus Database which is categorized as
one of the largest citation index platforms. Next, we removed any duplicates and
irrelevant articles. While there were no duplicates, we scanned the titles and abstracts
and excluded 98 articles that were either irrelevant or theoretical. After this stage,
we were left with 20 articles. Following that, the articles were ﬁltered through a

as they were either theoretical papers or testing a different relationship, such as
CO2 and inﬂation. During the full-text reading, four in-text citations of articles were
found that were not originally retrieved from the Scopus database (two articles from
Aghabalayev and Ahmed 2023 and two articles from Pradeep 2022). Therefore, the
ﬁnal total of included articles in our review is 20 empirical studies.
3
Results
Out of the extensive reading of the included empirical studies, the extracted data
is provided in Annex 1. The ﬁrst study from our sample was published in 2019.
Over the subsequent years, the topic has garnered more attention, with the highest
number of studies being conducted by 2022. It is important to note that the sample
of studies was collected at the beginning of 2023, hence the low number of studies
for 2023. However, we anticipate that the number of studies will be higher than that

N. Omar and D. Yousri
Fig. 1 Search and screening
results
of 2022, given the increasing trend and the growing attention received by the topic.
The remainder of this section discusses the conceptual foundation and descriptive
account of data, methods, and results of the sample of publications.
3.1
Conceptual Foundation
Two concepts underlie most models of this relationship, namely the Environmental
Kuznets curve hypothesis (EKC) and the Cobb–Douglas production function. EKC
hypothesis is used to explain the relationship between income and pollution. Kuznet
hypothesized that as income increases; pollution goes up to a certain threshold,
beyond which it decreases as income continues to increase (Chishti et al. 2021;
Pradeep 2022; Zeraibi et al. 2022). Furthermore, as higher economic activity is
linked to higher CO2 emissions, CO2 emissions can be integrated into the Cobb–
Douglas model, along with monetary policy, as shown by Qingquan et al. (2020).
Noureen et al. (2022) include real cash balance into the Cobb–Douglas production
The Impact of Monetary Policy on Climate Change: A Systematic …
151
function, and the expected effect on production is positive, as ﬁrms have better access
to capital, leading to increased production.
Most of the reviewed empirical studies are built on the framework by Qingquan
et al. (2020). The framework shows the spillover of contractionary and expansionary
monetary policy. In the case of an expansionary monetary policy; reduced interest
rates lead to higher consumption, borrowing power, aggregate demand, and produc-
tion. This increased production may result in producers using cheaper fossil fuels
or non-clean energy, leading to higher CO2 emissions. Conversely, contractionary
monetary policy, with declining income, money supply, and aggregate demand, leads
to reduced production and fossil fuel consumption, resulting in lower CO2 levels.
(Mahmood et al. 2022; Nguyen et al. 2022; Noureen et al. 2022; Zeraibi et al. 2022;
Aghabalayev and Ahmad 2023).
From the literature, the relationship suggested is that contractionary monetary
policy is a climate change mitigator. However, other literature frames it as a disruptor
of technological innovation. So, if we consider technological innovation to improve
climate-relatedissues,thentheeffectofcontractionarymonetarypolicyisneutralized
or partially offset. A suggested remedy is “greening” monetary policy by setting
lower interest rates for investors in green projects to encourage further technological
innovations and transition to clean resources (Zeraibi et al. 2022).
On the other hand, expansionary monetary policy is hypothesized to reduce capital
costs, making clean investments more proﬁtable when calculating the net value of
the project. However, there is an opposing argument that a low interest rate means
less costly production, which reduces the incentive to transform into clean production
since the high carbon emission penalty may go unnoticed. This is particularly relevant
as lower interest rate (expansionary policy) positively impacts investment levels, as
well as, energy consumption, innovation, and economic activity (Zhang et al. 2023).
Three channels are suggested for the spillover that the real interest rate could have
on CO2 emissions. First, through the effect on the cost of ﬁnance, as a lower interest
rate lowers the cost of ﬁnance, this is likely to lead to higher investment, production,
and energy consumption, resulting in higher CO2 emissions. Second, through foreign
direct investment (FDI) and trade, as a lower interest rate leads to higher real income,
this will result in higher energy consumption and, therefore, higher CO2 emissions.
Third, as a lower interest rate means a lower cost of lending, more consumer loans
will lead to higher consumption of automobiles and electric machines, which is likely
to contribute to CO2 emissions (Isiksal et al. 2019; Aghabalayev and Ahmad 2023).
We should acknowledge the other side of the debate that is not in support of
involving central banks in mitigating climate change; it is believed it will affect
the effectiveness of monetary policy. This side of the argument is concerned about
“carbon bubbles” and ﬁnancial instability that may occur due to this intervention.
Shobande (2022) identiﬁes ﬁve ways through which this could occur: uncertainty
due to slowed down productivity, the risk of physical damage leading to a surge in
asset pricing, ﬁnancial turmoil due to mortgage borrowers’ default, and using the
monetary policy transmission channels (credit and interest rate channels) to promote
sustainable ﬁnance.
152
N. Omar and D. Yousri
3.2
Descriptive Account
3.2.1
Data
In modeling climate change in empirical studies (Table 2), Carbon Dioxide (CO2)
emissions is the most used measure (Zeraibi et al. 2022), although other measures
such as Methane and Nitrous emissions are also used (as in Noureen et al. 2022). In
our sample, all studies used CO2 emissions as the main indicator of climate change
and only use other measures to test the robustness of their statistical results.
Monetary policy is measured by either real interest rates (Isiksal et al. 2019;
Muhaﬁdin 2020; Qingquan et al. 2020; Chishti et al. 2021; Hilmi et al. 2022; Huang
et al. 2022; Jiang et al. 2021; Nguyen et al. 2022; Noureen et al. 2022; Shobande

Some articles also consider discount rates (Mughal et al. 2021; Ullah et al.

and measures of credit (Shobande 2022). One study by Hilmi et al. (2022) exam-
ines the impact of unconventional monetary policy (using green-labeled bonds and
asset purchase program) on CO2 emissions. Additionally, Alola (2019) focuses on
monetary policy uncertainty.
In the tested contexts, the majority of studies focus on Asian countries (Muhaﬁdin
2020; Qingquan et al. 2020; Pradeep 2022; Ullah et al. 2021; Zeraibi et al. 2022;
Zhang et al. 2023) and developing economies (Isiksal et al. 2019; Chishti et al. 2021;
Mughal et al. 2021; Mahmood et al. 2022; Nguyen et al. 2022; Noureen et al. 2022;
Shobande 2022).
Three studies examine the US context (Alola 2019; Xin et al. 2022; Liguo et al.
2022), two articles analyze a panel of EU countries (Hilmi et al. 2022; Huang et al.
2022), one study explores the G7 economies (Aghabalayev and Ahmad 2023), and
one article focuses on Australia (Jiang et al. 2021).
3.2.2
Methods
Regarding the methods (Table 3) the most commonly employed are Fully-modiﬁed
OLS (FM-OLS) (Chishti et al. 2021; Jiang et al. 2021; Nguyen et al. 2022; Mahmood
et al. 2022; Zeraibi et al. 2022; Xin et al. 2022; Liguo et al. 2022; Zhang et al. 2023),
Dynamic OLS (D-OLS) (Chishti et al. 2021; Jiang et al. 2021; Nguyen et al. 2022;
Mahmood et al. 2022; Zeraibi et al. 2022; Xin et al. 2022; Liguo et al. 2022), and
Autoregressive Distributed Lag model (ARDL) or Pooled mean group for panel
(Alola 2019; Isiksal et al. 2019; Muhaﬁdin 2020; Chishti et al. 2021; Pradeep 2022;
Mahmood et al. 2022; Zeraibi et al. 2022).
The assumption of asymmetry was only tested in two articles using the NARDL
methodology (Ullah et al. 2021; Mughal et al. 2021). Although the VAR methodology
is widely used for analyzing monetary policy, its usage is scarce in the sample.
Moreover, no threshold models were employed. However, the articles that build on
the EKC hypothesis included a squared variable to account for the threshold factor
(Chishti et al. 2021; Pradeep 2022; Zeraibi et al. 2022). Additionally, some studies
examined Granger causality and found a signiﬁcant causal relationship in most of
the studies (Muhaﬁdin 2020; Chishti et al. 2021; Shobande 2022; Huang et al. 2022;
Liguo et al. 2022; Zeraibi et al. 2022).
3.2.3
Findings
Most of the studies concluded that a lower interest rate (expansionary monetary
policy) is associated with a higher level of CO2 emissions, while the opposite is true
for a higher interest rate (contractionary monetary policy). These studies are: Isiksal

Articles

• Aghabalayev and Ahmad (2023)
VECM
• Isiksal et al. (2019)
• Zeraibi et al. (2022)
et al. (2019) found that the real interest rate has a negative effect on CO2 emis-
sions in Turkey. Supporting these results, Qingquan et al. (2020) found a long-term
cointegration between monetary policy and CO2 emissions in a selected sample of
Asian economies. The coefﬁcients supported the idea that an expansionary mone-
tary policy increases CO2 emissions, while a contractionary monetary policy reduces
CO2 emissions in the long run.
Also, Chishti et al. (2021) tested the impact of monetary policy on CO2 emis-
sions in the BRICS economies and found that expansionary monetary policy esca-
lates CO2 emissions, whereas contractionary policy has the opposite effect. Nguyen
et al. (2022) tested the impact of contractionary and expansionary monetary poli-
cies on CO2 emissions for a sample of 14 emerging economies. The results showed
that expansionary monetary policy escalates CO2 emissions, whereas contractionary
policy has the opposite effect. The quantile regression showed that the effects appear
in the middle and large quantiles of CO2 levels.
Xin et al. (2022), in the context of the US, found that expansionary monetary
policy (proxied by the real interest rate) has a positive impact on CO2 emissions.
In addition, they found a one-way causality from expansionary monetary policy to
CO2 emissions. Aghabalayev and Ahmad (2023), in the context of G7 states, found
that expansionary monetary policy increases CO2 emissions, whereas contractionary
monetary policy decreases CO2 emissions.
Noureen et al. (2022), for a selected sample of developing countries, showed that
expansionary monetary policy worsens environmental quality (increases emissions)
whereas contractionary monetary policy improves it (reduces emissions). Huang
et al. (2022), for a sample of EU countries, concluded that expansionary monetary
policy increases CO2 emissions, whereas contractionary monetary policy showed
the opposite impact.
Liguo et al. (2022), in the context of the US, found that expansionary monetary
policy (proxied by the real interest rate) has a positive impact on CO2 emissions.
Jiang et al. (2021), in the context of Australia, found a signiﬁcant long-term positive
relationship between expansionary monetary policy and CO2 emissions.
On the other hand, three studies found that expansionary monetary policy (lower
interest rate) is associated with a lower level of CO2 emissions, while the oppo-
site is true for contractionary monetary policy (higher interest rate). These studies
are Pradeep (2022) showed that interest rate has a signiﬁcant positive impact on
per-capita emissions in the long and short run. Muhaﬁdin (2020), in the context
of Indonesia, showed a positive signiﬁcant relationship between the interest rate
156
N. Omar and D. Yousri
and CO2 emissions. Zeraibi et al. (2022), in the context of China, concluded that
expansionary monetary policy lowered CO2 emissions in the long and short run.
Two studies yielded mixed results: Mahmood et al. (2022), in the context of the
GCC economies, found a negative long-term impact and a positive short-term impact
between money supply and CBC (Consumption-Based CO2) and TBC (Territory-
Based CO2). Zhang et al. (2023), for a panel of 9 Asian economies, found cointe-
gration between the variables and that expansionary monetary policy increases the
level of clean energy investment, but the relationship between CO2 emissions and
clean energy investments differed when testing for developing countries; while it is
positive for the full sample, it turns negative when testing for developing countries
only.
Some articles took different approaches (assuming asymmetry, including mone-
tary policy uncertainty, and unconventional monetary policy). Alola (2019), in the
context of the United States, found a positive cointegrating relationship between CO2
emissions and monetary policy uncertainty. The results showed that the relationship
was positive in the short and long run. Hilmi et al. (2022) examined the impact
of quantitative easing on CO2 emissions in a panel of 13 European countries. The
results revealed a positive relationship between green-labeled bonds (GLB) and CO2
emissions, while other measures were found to be insigniﬁcant.
Ullah et al. (2021), in Pakistan, found an asymmetric impact in the long run,
where contractionary policies worsened environmental quality (increase CO2 emis-
sions) while expansionary policies had no signiﬁcant effect. Mughal et al. (2021)
concluded that expansionary monetary policy had a positive impact on CO2 emis-
sions, while contractionary monetary policy had the opposite effect in a sample of
ASEAN countries.
Several studies investigated the Granger Causality between monetary policy
and CO2 emissions and reached various conclusions on the direction of causality.
Shobande (2022) conducted research on a panel of 6 East African countries and iden-
tiﬁed a unidirectional causality from the credit channel to CO2 emissions. They also
observed a bidirectional impact between the interest rate channel and CO2 emis-
sions. Moreover, they concluded that the trade, agriculture, and energy consump-
tion channels were the main mechanisms through which monetary policy impacted
CO2 emissions. Huang et al. (2022) studied a sample of EU countries and found
evidence of a one-way causality from expansionary monetary policy to CO2 emis-
sions. Liguo et al. (2022) focused on the US and discovered a unidirectional causality
from expansionary monetary policy to CO2 emissions.
Muhaﬁdin (2020), in the Indonesian context, found a bidirectional causal rela-
tionship between interest rates and CO2 emissions. Zeraibi et al. (2022) investigated
China and found evidence of a bidirectional causal relationship between M2 supply
and CO2 emissions in the long run. However, in the short run, there was evidence of
unidirectional causality from money supply to CO2 emissions. Finally, Chishti et al.
(2021) studied the BRICS economies and concluded that there is a unidirectional
causality from contractionary and expansionary monetary policy to CO2 emissions.
The Impact of Monetary Policy on Climate Change: A Systematic …
157
4
Discussion
A general impression is that the articles yield similar conclusions, but there is a
lack of policy implications to effectively utilize these ﬁndings. For example, if CO2
levels are lowered due to a contractionary monetary policy (CMP), then what steps
should be taken to address this? Implementing contractionary measures may not be
an appropriate solution to reducing CO2 emissions, at least not alone. Additionally,
it is worth examining whether the volatility associated with expansionary monetary
policies contributes to its positive association with carbon emissions. In other words,
we should explore the question if uncertainty plays a role in ﬁrms’ inclination to
use dirty or non-clean technologies for production. This question can be extended to
explore if the risk associated with unconventional expansionary measures inﬂuence
the choice of production methods?
The choice of contexts in the literature was well elaborated, with a focus on Asian
economies that are known to have the highest share of CO2 emissions. We further
recommend conducting a comparison between high and low-emission economies as
wellasacomparisonbetweenpanelsofdevelopedvs.developingeconomies.Further,
we would recommend more research to be done on the impact of unconventional
monetarypolicymeasuresonclimatechangeandutilizingawidervarietyofmeasures
for said variables. While the literature agrees that the effect of monetary policy
on CO2 emissions is indirect, there is no clear consensus on the mediator factors.
Understanding the link between these two variables is integral to provide valuable
policy implications.
A ﬁnal note: it is important to consider the conceptual aspects of this argument,
(i.e. central bank independence). Before recommending the use of monetary policy
to address the climate issue, these considerations should be acknowledged and thor-
oughly examined. The participation of all institutions and organizations in mitigating
climate change is vital, but given that central banks are the moderator of the monetary
system of any economy, it is particularly crucial to closely scrutinize the role of the
central bank. Therefore, any additional responsibilities assigned to the central bank
should be carefully considered and researched.
For future research, we suggest the following research gaps to build upon the
previous research on this topic:
1. Investigatethemediatingfactorsthatinﬂuencetherelationshipbetweenmonetary
policies and CO2 emissions, such as output and clean energy investment, as well
as income inequality.
2. Examine the impact of central bank announcements on corporate actions to
reduce CO2 emissions and actual levels of CO2 emissions.
3. Explore the potential policy measures that can effectively utilize the ﬁndings of
the relationship between monetary policies and CO2 emissions.
4. Analyze the role of volatility associated with expansionary monetary policies in
ﬁrms’ inclination to use dirty or non-clean technologies for production.
158
N. Omar and D. Yousri
5. Conduct further studies comparing high and low-emission economies, as well as
panels of developed versus developing economies, to enhance the understanding
of the topic.
6. Investigate the impact of unconventional monetary policy measures on climate
change and consider utilizing a wider variety of measures for monetary policy
and climate change variables.
7. Work towards a framework to be used in the relationship between monetary
policy and CO2 emissions.
8. Employ more studies with high frequency data given the nature of the interest
rate volatility.
9. Explore the spillover effects of monetary policy for large economies such as the
United States on the level of emissions in other economies.
5
Conclusion
This extensive review of the literature yielded to some insights, most importantly, it
showcased the scarcity of research on this topic. One limitation of this review is that
focused mainly on the direct relationship between monetary policies and CO2 emis-
sions. However, it is important to consider other factors that may mediate this rela-
tionship, such as clean energy investment (as discussed in Zhang et al. 2023). Another
key aspect to explore is the inﬂuence of a central bank announcement that calls for
action to mitigate climate change. Some questions to explore may include: Does this
announcement have an impact on corporate actions to reduce CO2 emissions? And,
does it have any effect on the actual levels of CO2 emissions?
Concurrent with the environmental threat, income disparity is widening across
nation. A series of empirical research started to investigate the potential link between
income inequality and climate change (Bai et al. 2020; Wang et al. 2023). The
importance of this discussion is ever increasing as both are SDGs set to be reached
by 2030, making it an urgent matter to explore. Given the strand of literature linking
income inequality and monetary policy (Omar and Richter, 2021), it is potentially
a next step to investigate the nexus between income inequality, climate change and
monetary policy.
To conclude, we endeavored to fulﬁll the points outlined in Palmatier et al. (2018)
and Snyder (2019) to the best of our abilities. To ensure depth and rigor, we remained
unbiased and provided full disclosure of our procedure. Our commitment to repli-
cability is evident in the documentation we provided of the entire process and the
decisions made at each step. Additionally, we placed importance on the usability of
this synthesis by offering implications and cohesive conclusions. After examining
20 empirical studies, we highly encourage further reviews as the research on this
topic gets richer, to contribute to the global move toward a sustainable future.

The Role of Islamic Values on Sustainable
Lifestyles: Does Living Area Matter?
Mohamad Saifudin Mohamad Saleh, Ali Mehellou, and Bahiyah Omar
Abstract Relevant research has highlighted the signiﬁcance of religious values in
promoting sustainable lifestyles. Living areas, which are frequently distinguished
by technological, social, and economic variances, potentially inﬂuence people’s
lifestyles. This study aimed to examine the impact of living areas on the correla-
tion between the (i) ﬁve Islamic values (preserving religion, life, intellect, progeny,
and wealth) drawn from (Maqasid) Shariah goals and (ii) sustainable lifestyles. As a
Muslim-majority country with a large disparity between urban and rural conditions,
Malaysia was chosen as the study location. Survey data were collected from 682
Malaysian citizens and subsequently analysed via Partial Least Squares-Structural
Equation Modelling (PLS-SEM). Resultantly, the moderating effect of living area
was unsupported. The correlations between the ﬁve Shariah goals and sustainable
lifestyles proved unaffected by people’s urban or rural living areas. In this vein,
sustainable lifestyles were signiﬁcantly inﬂuenced by the Islamic values practised in
communities, regardless of their living area. The interview outcomes also rendered
social media exposure and the universal understanding of sustainable lifestyles and
Maqasid Shariah made the living area as not signiﬁcant to inﬂuence people’s under-
standing of both elements. This research could facilitate national policymakers to
increase public awareness of sustainable lifestyles in the Islamic framework without
needing to distinguish between rural and urban communities.
Keywords Sustainable lifestyles · Religion · Values · Survey · Sustainable
development
1

to Singapore, Thailand, and Indonesia. The country is committed to attaining the
2030 Agenda, such as (i) developing green technology to strike a balance between

(Isa et al. 2021). Unsurprisingly, Malaysia is known for its sustainable development
efforts to mitigate poverty, elevate people’s quality of life, offer high-quality educa-
tion, and improve environmental quality since the 1970s (Beton Kalmaz and Awosusi
2022). Malaysia ranked 60 out of 166 countries worldwide under the SDG global
rank (Sachs et al. 2020) and has achieved SDG1 (no poverty), 95% of SDG 7 (afford-
able and clean energy), and 94% of SDG 11 (sustainable cities and communities)
(Sachs et al. 2020).
Despite efforts to catalyse and attain sustainable development, Malaysia remains
susceptible to environmental degradation. For example, the country is in the prelimi-
nary stages of renewable energy (Rahman et al. 2022), which renders it vulnerable to
climate change and adverse environmental effects (Patwary et al. 2022). The incon-
gruency between rural and urban settings, speciﬁcally in terms of facilities, technolo-
gies and social economic issues (poverty), is another national conundrum. Poverty in
rural areas has garnered much attention from the Malaysian government via policy
implementation (Tedong et al. 2022). Rural settlements in Malaysia encompass a
population of under 10,000, with most of the residents employed in the agricul-
tural sector as their primary source of income (Hanapiah et al. 2022). Based on the
Economic Planning Unit of Malaysia, relevant government bodies strive to accelerate
regional- and state-level developments and bridge the rural–urban development gap
for higher inclusion (Economic Planning Unit 2021).
As a country with a Muslim-majority (63.5%) population known (Department
of Statistics Malaysia 2022), Malaysia has often been selected as the study context
to examine Maqasid Shariah and its association with environmental and sustain-
ability issues. The Maqasid Shariah (the objectives of Islamic law) underscores the
well-being of humanity (Al-Nahari et al. 2022). Five key goals, such as preserving
religion, life, intellect, progeny, and wealth constitute Maqasid Shariah. Notably, the
ultimate goal of well-being is attained by considering the ﬁve aforementioned goals,
which could motivate and guide human beings to behave appropriately and live a
better life (Al-Nahari et al. 2022). Nurul Aida (2015) examined the integration of
sustainability notions with current urban sustainability practices in Malaysia from an
Islamic perspective, while (Md Dali et al. 2016) used the Maqasid Shariah framework
to explore the liveability planning for Malaysian cities. Likewise, Dali et al. (2018)
aimed to structure an evaluation model by identifying and ranking Maqasid Shariah
indicators and sub-indicators based on liveability and quality of life in Malaysian
cities. Yaakub and Abdullah (2020) investigated and discussed a port’s strategies to
be environmentally sustainable following the Maqasid Shariah tenets.
Notwithstanding, research on Maqasid Shariah with regards to sustainable
lifestyles in Malaysia remains scarce. The essentiality of such studies stems from the
role of human behaviour in sustainable development and environmental degradation.
Previous works such as Hiratsuka et al. (2018), Jackson and Smith (2018) under-
scored unsustainable human behaviours as the key determinants of environmental
degradation, climate change, health deterioration, and economic issues. Western
academia has conducted summits and performed research and projects on sustainable
The Role of Islamic Values on Sustainable Lifestyles: Does Living Area …
165
lifestyles, such as The SPREAD Sustainable Lifestyles 2050, to support Europeans’
adoption of sustainable lifestyles (Backhaus et al. 2012).
The current work differed from other studies following its examination of sustain-
able lifestyles from an Islamic perspective and values. This study aimed to determine
whether the (urban versus rural) living areas affect people’s internalisation of the
Maqasid Shariah-sustainable lifestyle relationship.
2
Maqasid Shariah as a Framework for Sustainable
Lifestyles in Malaysia
The Maqasid Shariah framework (see Fig. 1) is extensively utilised in economy,
ﬁnance, accounting, and banking-related domains (Tubarad et al. 2022). Saifud-
deen et al. (2014) aimed to establish a complementary model of bioethics following
Maqasid Shariah to address bioethical concerns, while (Md Dali et al. 2016)
employed this framework for urban liveability planning. Perceivably, such a frame-
work would render cities more liveable in the future. Shompa and Mohadis’s
(2022) proposed a conceptual integrated persuasive behavioural changed framework
following Maqasid Shariah aiming to promote green practices in municipal solid
waste disposal among Malaysians.
The aforementioned framework has garnered much attention from Muslim
scholars and practitioners in different domains, speciﬁcally those in Malaysia (Azis
et al. 2020). Parallel to Azis et al. (2020), approximately 80% of the listed companies
in Malaysia are Shariah-compliant. Regardless, the integration of Maqasid Shariah
with environmental and sustainability research and practices remains inadequate,
particularly in corporate studies (Nizam and Larbani 2016).
Fig. 1 The elements of Maqasid Shariah framework
166
M. S. Mohamad Saleh et al.
3
Urbanisation and Sustainable Lifestyles in Malaysia
Although the urbanisation rate in Malaysia reached 77.2% in 2020 based on the last
census statistics (Economic Planning Unit 2021), the local population’s urbanisation
process and unsustainable lifestyles instigate environmental, social, or economic
issues involving air pollution, water pollution, noise and congestion, and waste
disposal (Md Dali et al. 2016; Murad and Pereira 2019). These challenges led the
Federal Town and Country Planning Department (FTCPD) to develop the Malaysian
Urban Rural Indicators Network (MURNInet) to ascertain the sustainability level
(Dali et al. 2017).
The Economic Planning Unit recently highlighted the gap between urban and
rural areas in Malaysia as one of the issues underlying the development processes
of infrastructure, telecommunications, transportation, and quality of life (Economic
Planning Unit 2021). As such, many local studies (Denan et al. 2015; Pathman et al.
2018; Rani et al. 2019; Sulaiman et al. 2018; Thompson 2020; Vethanayagam James
and How 2017) have examined the effect of (urban or rural) living areas on people’s
knowledge, values, feelings, attitudes, lifestyles, practices, and behaviours.
Numerous studies and reports on the environment and sustainability have consid-
ered the distinct characteristics between urban and rural settings and inhabitants
based on social, environmental, and economic factors, such as perceptions of envi-
ronmental change or development. As reported by Rasoolimanesh et al. (2017), urban
areas and their residents were the intended beneﬁciaries of most urban facilities, such
as roads, infrastructure, public transportation, and services. Hiratsuka et al. (2018)
also claimed that the public transportation network is more developed in urban areas
than their rural counterparts. Such disparity can affect people’s use of public trans-
portation. Additionally, environmental and health issues could impact their choices
andpreferences.YangandHuang(2018)underscoredthevariancebetweenurbanand
rural areas and the reﬂection of residency status on individual behaviour. Likewise,
the level of awareness related to climate change differed among rural and urban
residents (Nash et al. 2019). Nevertheless, the urban–rural differences depend on
the research nature, objectives, context, and method. Jeinie et al. (2021) revealed no
difference in nutrition knowledge between urban and rural secondary school students
in Malaysia. Contrarily, Shah et al. (2020) identiﬁed differences in the level of stress
and eating behaviour of Malaysian secondary school adolescents living in rural and
urban areas. The aforementioned discussions led to the development of the study
hypotheses and theoretical framework (Fig. 2).
4
Hypotheses
H1: There is a signiﬁcant difference in the effect of preserving religion on sustainable
lifestyles among individuals living in rural and urban areas in Malaysia.
