H2: There is a signiﬁcant difference in the effect of preserving life on sustainable
lifestyles among individuals living in rural and urban areas in Malaysia.
H3: There is a signiﬁcant difference in the effect of preserving intellect on sustainable
lifestyles among individuals living in rural and urban areas in Malaysia.
H4: There is a signiﬁcant difference in the effect of preserving progeny on sustainable
lifestyles among individuals living in rural and urban areas in Malaysia.
H5: There is a signiﬁcant difference in the effect of preserving wealth on sustainable
lifestyles among individuals living in rural and urban areas in Malaysia.
5
Methodology
This study used a mixed method approach involving survey data (see Annex 1) to
test the study hypotheses and in-depth interview to derive some meaningful insights
from the ﬁndings. This sequential mixed method design would help to explore the
quantitative data in great detail.
In the ﬁrst phase, a survey was performed on six Malaysian states involving
Malaysian citizens from rural (30%) and urban (about 70%) areas. Following the
urbanisation stratum in Malaysia, two states were selected to represent each stratum.
For example, (i) Selangor and Penang, (ii) Johor and Terengganu, and (iii) Sarawak
and Kelantan represented high, medium, and low urbanisation rates, respectively.
Approximately 78% of the respondents have lived in their places for over ﬁve years.
Questionnaire items involving the dependent and independent variables were adapted
168
M. S. Mohamad Saleh et al.
from past literature (Ahamad and Arifﬁn 2018; Yusof et al. 2019). The survey items
were expert-reviewed, translated into the Malay language, and back-translated to
conﬁrm the accuracy of meaning pre-distribution. Subsequently, the questionnaire
was pilot-tested with 50 respondents. As the respondents could easily comprehend
the survey items, the test outcomes denoted high levels of reliability and validity. A
total of 682 valid questionnaires were collected between October 2021 and July 2022
during the actual survey. The collected data was later analysed using PLS-SEM.
Following Table 1, 55.4% of the respondents were women, while the remaining
44.6% were men. In terms of marital status, 56.0% of the respondents were single,
whereas 43.4% of them were married. With regards to age, 49% of the respondents
were from 21 to 30 years old. Religion-wise, 72.4% of the respondents were Muslims,
with 69.8% of them being Malay. Most of the respondents (59%) were college or
university graduates. In line with income, 28.6%, of the respondents earned below
RM2,000 annually.
In the second phase, an n-depth interview sessions were conducted with selected
respondents post-survey and outcome analysis to derive more information on the
reason underlying insigniﬁcant living areas on the Maqasid Shariah-sustainable
lifestyle relationship. Fundamentally, six interviewees from each group of the three
sub-groups (key Islamic ﬁgures, environmentalists, and survey respondents) (18
respondents) were interviewed until attaining data saturation. Six of the 18 respon-
dents were female, while the remaining 12 were male. The interviewees’ age ranged
between 25 and 56 years old. Furthermore, the interviewees hailed from ethnically
and religiously diverse backgrounds: Malay Muslims (N = 14), Hindus (N = 3),
and Chinese Christians (N = 1). Most of the interviewees (N = 7) held a Bachelor’s
degree in multiple disciplines, such as communication, human development, Islamic
studies, production, and animal health. Several other occupations (mufti and deputy
mufti, director, president, and ofﬁcer) were represented among the interviewees.
Notably, the interviewees were assigned identiﬁcation codes (ID 1, ID 2, and so on)
to protect their privacy. The interview ﬁndings were thematically analysed and coded
via the MAXQDA programme. Moreover, Braun and Clarke’s (2006) thematic anal-
ysis framework served as a guideline to initiate the codes and themes and analyse
the interview outcomes. Notably, the Human Research Ethics Committee of USM
(USM/JEPeM/21040327) approved the ethical aspect of this study, including the
survey and interview.
6
Survey Results
Using PLS-SEM, this study employed a three-stage approach involving the (i) assess-
ment of measurement models, (ii) assessment of structural models, and (iii) multi-
group analysis (MGA) to assess both (urban and rural) models and compare the
estimated path coefﬁcient outcomes via PLS-SEM.

7
Assessment of Measurement Model
As presented in Table 2, the measurement model assessment results conﬁrmed the
models’ validity and reliability in urban and rural areas. Both the composite reliability
(CR) and average variance extracted (AVE) denoted acceptable values. Additionally,
CR demonstrated a higher level of reliability (0.8–0.9) for both models. The high
AVE for both models (0.50) implied that the construct explains 50% of the items’
variance (Hair et al. 2019). Furthermore, most of the outer loadings exceeded 0.7
(Avkiran and Ringle 2018).
In addition, the Heterotrait-Monotrait ratio (HTMT) and Fornell-Larcker criterion
for both models’ discriminant validity proved that the model constructs were distinct
from one another (see Tables 3 and 4). No value exceeded the threshold value of
0.90 for HTMT. Meanwhile, the Fornell-Larcker criterion was fulﬁlled, with all
the diagonal values of each construct higher than their corresponding correlation
coefﬁcients (Hair et al. 2019). Overall, discriminant validity was established.

Assessment of the Structural Model and Hypothesis
Testing
Upon establishing the outer or measurement models, the inner structural model was
later accessed According to Avkiran and Ringle (2018), the structural model aims to
ﬁnd evidence that supports the theoretical model (the theorised exogenous construct-
endogenous construct relationships).
Hair et al. (2019) proposed examining collinearity before testing the structural
relationships to avoid bias in the regression results. Based on Table 5, the Variance

Inﬂation Factor (VIF) values of all constructs were under 3 (Avkiran and Ringle

9
Multigroup Analysis (MGA)
MGA was employed to assess whether living areas matter by treating vicinity
(urban and rural areas) as the moderator. According to Henseler et al. (2016), the
measurement invariance must be established prior to assessing the structural model
and performing MGA. The measurement invariance or equivalence afﬁrms that the
measurement models specify measures of the same attribute under different condi-
tions (Cheah et al. 2020; Henseler et al. 2016). As such, the measurement invariance
ofthecompositemodels(MICOM)procedureservedtoevaluatemeasurementinvari-
ance (Avkiran and Ringle 2018) in this study. This three-step procedure entails (i)
conﬁgural invariance assessment (Step 1); (ii) compositional invariance assessment
(Step 2); (iii) equal means and variances assessment (Step 3) (Cheah et al. 2020).
In this vein, MGA is viable if Steps 1 and 2 are established (partial measurement
invariance) (Cheah et al. 2020). Based on Table 6, both steps 1 and 2 except 3 were
established in this study, with the partial measurement invariance conﬁrmed, but not
the full measurment invariance, where the mean for the construct PR was not equal
(see Table 6). Therefore, in this case, the data of different groups cannot be pooled
(Henseler et al. 2016). Meaning that, the statistical power cannot be increased and
the result of the model of this study cannot be generalized (Henseler et al. 2016).
Table 7 demonstrates the structural model assessment and MGA outcomes for
rural and urban inhabitants in Malaysia. Two non-parametric tests (MGA and permu-
tation) were used to compare path coefﬁcients between both groups. Resultantly,
non-signiﬁcant differences were identiﬁed between all the path coefﬁcients and
relationships across both models.
Although the difference of path coefﬁcients between the two models could not be
established (see Table 7), this study found that the total variance explained by the ﬁve
Islamic values for rural area was slightly higher (R2: 0.318, 32% variance explained)
than the urban area (R2: 0.289, 29% of variance explained).The results suggest that
the effect of Islamic values on sustainable lifestyle was greater for those living in
rural area than urban area. Nevertheless, the difference is marginal and insigniﬁcant.

10
Interview Results
Two themes on why (rural and urban) living setting does not signiﬁcantly inﬂuence
people’s understanding of Maqasid Shariah and sustainable lifestyles were derived
from the in-depth interviews.
11
Same Exposure from Social Media
Most of the interviewees deemed urban or rural areas insigniﬁcant due to people’s
ability to easily access information from social media. In other words, no infor-
mation gap exists between rural and urban communities in Malaysia. Some of the
interviewees explained as follows:
In Malaysia, I think, because information can now be found at your ﬁngertips, a lot of
information is spread on social media and everyone can access it. The second, going back
to the problem, these Malaysians often associate every problem, must refer to religion. So,
it doesn’t matter whether he is in the urban or rural area, for example we see in this city the
issue may be a social issue. This social issue happens because of not following religion. If
we go outside the city, we also face the same issues, such as cleanliness. (ID 4).
There is no difference… This Maqasid Shariah effect on sustainable lifestyles has no
difference for people living in the city and also in the countryside. Maybe for me… what
I think is that… the world at your ﬁngertips. I mean, if we look at it now, village or rural
society is the same as today’s city society. Even if we look at the case of dumping babies, it’s
the same level… the countryside is the same, the city is the same. No difference. In the past,
we might have said that this city… it’s worse socially, the social life in this city is worse, but
176
M. S. Mohamad Saleh et al.
now it is not. Now… not now. Why? Because now the world is at your ﬁngertips. All people
can do whatever they want. (ID 14).
12
Universal Understanding
Intriguingly, the effect of Maqasid Shariah (religion value) on sustainable lifestyles
is universally understood by both rural and urban inhabitants. Thus, the living setting
proved insigniﬁcant. Two interviewees shared as follows:
I think back to, because in terms of understanding religion… it has no difference between the
village and the city. The understanding of religion no longer depends on the city or village.
(ID 18).
In my opinion, there is no signiﬁcant difference between those who live in the city and
the countryside in question understand the Maqasid Shariah towards a sustainable lifestyle
due to their understanding and attitude in understanding Islamic law. (ID 15).
13
Discussion
This study aimed to uncover whether the effect of Islamic values on sustainable
lifestyle would be different for Malaysians who live in urban and rural areas. The
results show that living areas does not matter. The effects were almost the same across
the two groups. Following the moderation results, the R2 value of the rural model
was slightly higher than that of the urban model. All ﬁve Maqasid Shariah predictors
denoted a slightly larger effect on sustainable lifestyles in rural than urban areas.
Although the study’s MGA and permutation result (p-value) revealed no signiﬁcant
difference between Malaysian urban and rural inhabitants, the effect of Islamic values
on sustainable lifestyle was greater for rural area than urban area. Such output calls
for a closer attention. One possible reason is that people in rural area may have higher
level of religiosity than urban people. Because of their strong belief of the Maqasid
Shariah, Malaysians who live in rural areas tend to adopt sustainable lifestyle—
which values are interwoven with the teachings of Islam—better than those who live
in urban areas. This assumption, however, requires further validation. It is important
to note that the ﬁve proposed hypotheses were unsupported when the results were
compared according to living areas.
The results of this study were consistent with some comparative studies
which evaluated differences between rural and urban areas in Malaysia context.
Vethanayagam James and How (2017), for example, found no signiﬁcant differ-
ence in the level of attitude between urban and rural residents in the Klang Valley,
Malaysia. Likewise, Jeinie et al. (2021) reported no difference in nutritional knowl-
edge among urban and rural students in East Malaysia. Similarly, the effect was
almost equivalent between Malaysians who live in rural and urban areas; suggesting
no signiﬁcant moderating effect of living area in this study.
The Role of Islamic Values on Sustainable Lifestyles: Does Living Area …
177
Based on the qualitative interview results, most of the interviewees corresponded
to the quantitative survey outcomes. Rural or urban living areas did not signiﬁcantly
impact the Maqasid Shariah-sustainable lifestyle relationship. Observably, rural and
urban inhabitants were exposed to social media and the issues underlying Maqasid
Shariah and sustainable lifestyles, which they deemed to be relatively common.
The Malaysian government, speciﬁcally the Department of Islamic Development
Malaysia (JAKIM), should impart Maqasid Shariah values and their connection to
sustainable lifestyles without differentiating the campaigns and education or training
strategies between the rural and urban areas.
14
Conclusion
The novelty of this study lies in its implementation of MST to address sustain-
able lifestyle issues in Malaysia and the impact of urban or rural living areas as a
moderator between the ﬁve Shariah goals and sustainable lifestyles. Additionally,
this study expanded the current body of literature on sustainable lifestyle issues. The
empirical outcomes derived from this study could beneﬁt local academicians with
a sound understanding of Maqasid Shariah and its implications for environmental
and sustainability issues, particularly those entailing sustainable lifestyles. Further-
more, the Malaysian government could develop key strategies and plans that suitably
educate the Muslim-dominant population on sustainable lifestyles within the Islamic
framework.
This research compared two test results (MGA and permutation) based on the
p-value to report the corresponding outcomes between urban and rural groups. This
comparison may have limited the study. Thus, further research could consider results
from the other SmartPLS-oriented tests (bootstrapping results) to demonstrate the
signiﬁcant difference between path coefﬁcients among both groups.
Although the ﬁndings of previous research related to the inﬂuence of living area
such as urban and rural settings on individuals’ perceptions have demonstrated posi-
tive effects, this study found different results. The negative result of this study may
be attributed to the urbanization rate in Malaysia, where less areas are considered
rural. Additionally, the inﬂuence of living area could be affected by other control-
ling variables such as religion, gender, income, or level of education, among others.
Testing the living area, i.e., urban, and rural as a categorical moderator might yield
different statistical results. Considering the absence of testing control variables in this
study as a limitation, future studies could examine the inﬂuence of control variables
on both independent variables (i.e., Maqasid Shariah) and the dependent variable
(i.e., sustainable lifestyles). Moreover, as this study was conﬁned to the Malaysian
context, future research could explore other Muslim-majority countries (such as
Brunei, Indonesia, or the Middle East) for comparative purposes.

Where’s Wally? The Search for Social
Sustainability in the Maritime Industry
and Recommendations for Future
Research
Michael Ekow Manuel and Alina Prylipko
Abstract Transport systems play a vital role in the pursuit of sustainable develop-
ment. Approximately 80% of the global merchandise trade is facilitated by shipping,
which is considered the foremost environmentally and economically efﬁcient mode
of transport per unit of cargo. Despite these advantages, shipping is responsible for
nearly 3% of greenhouse gas emissions, making it imperative to research operational,
technological, and market-based solutions for decarbonization. Unfortunately, these
endeavors frequently fail to integrate social aspects. This missing piece fundamen-
tally distorts the understanding of sustainability and risks introducing even more
shipping-related externalities. Drawing from the ﬁndings of a systematic review
of maritime literature between years 2015 to 2023, complemented by a thematic
synthesis, this paper interrogates academic research in the realm of social sustain-
ability within maritime transport. The study aims to offer insights for future research
on sustainable maritime transport and speciﬁcally its social dimension. The paper
urges academics to establish theoretical foundations for their studies that consider
contextual and sectoral variations and thereby to substantiate their choices. In addi-
tion, this paper suggests focusing future research endeavors on empirical data gath-
ering and deploying innovative research methods in the collection of such data.
Finally, this study identiﬁes speciﬁc social sustainability themes that could be further
elaborated and highlights the importance of considering procedural aspects of social
sustainability in policy formation and implementation.
Keywords Social sustainability · Maritime industry · Shipping · Research
M. E. Manuel · A. Prylipko (B)

M. E. Manuel

World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_11

184
M. E. Manuel and A. Prylipko
1
Introduction
The social dimension of sustainable development has proven to be particularly
challenging to research, especially in its operationalization, predominantly due to
ontological and epistemological debates surrounding the concept. Social sustain-
ability is value-laden (Spangenberg 2011) and continuously evolving (Colantonio
2009) across time and contexts (Boström 2012). As a result, the concept is strongly
inﬂuenced by the particular theoretical, methodological, normative, contextual, and
measurement approaches that one adopts (McGuinn 2020). Additionally, social
sustainability could be examined from various standpoints such as analytical, norma-
tive, substantive, and practical perspectives (Saunders et al. 2020). Despite academic
efforts to explain the multifaceted nature of social sustainability (Boström 2012;
Colantonio 2009; de Fine Licht and Folland 2019; Littig and Griessler 2005;
McGuinn 2020; Murphy 2012; Spangenberg 2011), the integration of this concept
intospeciﬁccontextsremainsproblematic(LealFilhoetal.2022).Theuniquecontext
of the maritime transportation system is no exception (Karakasnaki et al. 2023).
This is a challenge, given that transportation networks are critical in supporting
the achievement of sustainable development goals. Optimal sustainable transport
systems can facilitate economic growth, mitigate negative environmental impacts and
preserve natural resources, enhance access to essential goods and services, reduce
energy consumption, ensure resilience and effective disaster response, and enable
progress towards other sustainability goals (United Nations 2021).
Among all the modes of transportation, the maritime industry1 is particularly
signiﬁcant as it handles approximately 80% of global merchandised trade (UNCTAD
2023). By providing this essential transportation service, the maritime industry
contributes to addressing some of humanity’s most pressing sustainability chal-
lenges, including food and energy security and fostering prosperity of communi-
ties through trade facilitation (IMO n.d.). Nevertheless, like any other business,
shipping companies remain viable only when they generate revenue for their share-
holders. This primary economic focus and business-to-business nature of the industry
presents signiﬁcant challenges in accommodating competing environmental and
social interests (Parviainen et al. 2018).
Economies of scale allow shipping to be regarded as the most economically
and environmentally efﬁcient mode of transport per unit of cargo (Stopford 2009).
However, the industry’s reliance on an ageing ﬂeet that primarily runs on fossil fuels
(UNCTAD 2023) coupled with high volumes of goods transported over the years
have contributed to its substantial environmental impact. As an example, shipping
is currently responsible for nearly 3% of greenhouse gas emissions, representing
a 20% increase in emissions over the last decade (UNCTAD 2023). The growing
1 The maritime industry—also often referred to as international merchant shipping or shipping—
relates to the use of ships for international transportation of cargo and people and related activities
including legal, insurance, classiﬁcation, ﬁnance, education and other services (Hildebrand and
Schröder-Hinrichs 2014; Karagiannis et al. 2022).
Where’s Wally? The Search for Social Sustainability in the Maritime …
185
global attention to environmental sustainability and climate change in particular, is
putting the industry under considerable pressure to expedite its decarbonization.
As important as it is that the maritime industry continues to develop technical,
operational and market-based solutions to address pressing environmental challenges
“while sustaining economic growth” (UNCTAD 2023), it is becoming increasingly
critical to recognize the importance of social sustainability and to evaluate how these
aspects are considered in tandem with the economic and environmental dimensions
(Arslan et al. 2023). It has been highlighted that neglecting social sustainability
results not only in a lack of attention to critical social aspects, but it also funda-
mentally distorts the understanding of society-nature relationships and sustainable
development at large (Boström 2012). Similarly, Leal Filho et al. (2022, p. 2617)
stresses the importance of “the systems perspective in which social sustainability
impacts not only in terms of the social dimension but being also able to bring posi-
tive externalities to the other dimensions of sustainability, such as the economic and
environmental dimensions”. Therefore, for the maritime industry to progress towards
sustainability in its full paradigmatic scope, it should adopt a strategic and preven-
tive approach that integrates social considerations alongside its economic focus and
ongoing environmental efforts.
In a social context, shipping impacts the broader public in terms of its envi-
ronmental performance and the satisfaction of economic needs and rights (Kronfeld-
Goharani2018).Leastdevelopedcountries,smallislanddevelopingstatesandcertain
coastal communities are often dependent on the industry and are therefore the most
vulnerable during disruptions and transitions in shipping (UNCTAD 2023). The
sectoralsolargelyreliesonaninternationallaborforce,whichoftenmeansoperations
in a multicultural working environment. Although the industry employs nearly 1.9
millionseafarersandadditionalshorepersonnel,itstillstruggleswithrecruitmentand
retention and has to deal with a forecast shortage of suitably qualiﬁed seafarers and
other shore-based personnel (Drewry Maritime Research 2022; Nightingale 2023).
The industry also has signiﬁcant security, health and safety concerns, including chal-
lenges to physiological and mental health (Hayes-Mejia and Stafström2023), adverse
work/restarrangementsandfatigue(BaumlerandManuel2023;RajapakseandEmad
2023) and decreasing happiness overall (The Mission to Seafarers 2023). Further-
more, it is often characterized by higher salience of ﬁnancial stakeholders (Parvi-
ainen et al. 2018) and trade associations as compared to civil society organizations
(Baumler et al. 2021) and wider social partners (European Commission 2020).
However, social considerations are increasingly gaining attention in maritime
research. Reviewing the maritime literature between 1993 and 2017, Shin et al.
(2018) provide directions for sustainability research in shipping. Regarding social
sustainability, the authors recommend that future studies should dedicate equal atten-
tion to social aspects as given to the economic and environmental aspects of sustain-
able shipping and explore topics such as the “effectiveness of community plan-
ning, labor laws and regulations, and strategic policy-making”. Zhou et al. (2023)
also discuss a broader research agenda for sustainable shipping and highlight the
need to further investigate the link between the environmental and social pillars.
Their paper outlines risks related to social sustainability and offers suggestions
186
M. E. Manuel and A. Prylipko
for researching speciﬁc issues, including gender equality, the shortage of qualiﬁed
seafarers, seafarers’ wellbeing, and their physiological and psychological health.
Nevertheless, given the recent growing interest in social aspects in maritime research
(Arslan et al. 2023; Fasoulis 2023; Karakasnaki et al. 2023), it would be beneﬁcial to
review academic literature dedicated to social sustainability speciﬁcally and analyze
gaps in the relevant areas of research in detail.
This paper speciﬁcally focuses on social sustainability in the maritime industry
rather than the broader sustainable development discourse in shipping and is aimed
at offering detailed recommendations for future research, extending beyond research
questions to provide suggestions for theoretical foundations, data collection methods,
speciﬁcs of social sustainability discourse for various stakeholder groups, and related
thematic explorations.
2
Method
This section presents the systematic literature review methodology employed in the
study, covering the process of academic literature selection and screening. Addi-
tionally, it lists publications chosen for the full-text review and subsequent thematic
synthesis.
A systematic literature review methodology (Alexander 2020; Petticrew and
Roberts 2006; The Campbell Collaboration 2020) is employed. The work is also
informed by highly regarded procedures for quality appraisal and evidence synthesis
for qualitative studies developed by Dixon-Woods and colleagues (Dixon-Woods
et al. 2004, 2006, 2007). For the synthesis of ﬁndings this study uses thematic
synthesis (Barnett-Page and Thomas 2009), which was completed in three stages:
selective coding, generation of descriptive themes and generating analytical themes
as recommended by Bryman (2016).
Structure of Publications
To collect academic publications, this study used SCOPUS, EBSCO, and Google
Scholar and complemented the literature search with a snowballing technique (refer-
ring to “the search of the reference lists of initially identiﬁed research items [in this
case literature] for further potentially relevant items” (Hiebl 2021)). The search was
limited to studies published between 2015 (when the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable
Development was adopted) and September 2023. However, a number of seminal pre-
2015 publications discovered through the snowballing approach was also included.
Keywords used for the search included ‘maritime’, ‘shipping’, ‘marine’ or ‘ocean’
and ‘social and sustainab*’, ‘corporate and responsibility’, ‘green’, and ‘human
resourc*’. All publications underwent a three-level screening process (title, abstract
and full text) to exclude papers that solely addressed economic and environmental
Where’s Wally? The Search for Social Sustainability in the Maritime …
187
pillars of sustainable development without references to social sustainability. Addi-
tionally, publications limited to speciﬁc contexts, such as those dedicated to a partic-
ular country or a case study, were excluded, due to the possibility of low external
validity.
After reviewing 6,889 titles matching the search criteria, 555 papers were selected
for the abstract review. In this stage, a further 389 papers were eliminated, resulting in
166 studies selected for full-text screening. Surprisingly, after reviewing the full texts,
only 22 publications were deemed suitable for thematic analysis as the rest of the
articles did not address social aspects in the text. An additional 32 publications were
added to the review using the snowballing techniques, resulting in 54 publications
selected for the ﬁnal analysis (Table 1).
3
Results
The selected publications are distributed across a wide range of academic journals,
extending beyond the maritime ﬁeld to transport and broader journals, and include
10 book chapters.
Theoretical Foundations and Methodological Choices
Corporate social responsibility and stakeholder theories were the most popular refer-
ence theories, appearing in 10 and 6 papers, respectively. Other theories applied
included resource-based theory (3 papers), resource dependence theory (2 papers),
governance theory, objectiﬁcation, organizational theory, poststructuralist discourse
theory, service-dominant logic, grounded theory, slack resource theory, and relational
view. Slightly more than half of the papers, 28 publications, did not have explicit
references to any theoretical foundation used for the study. Among the remaining
studies that included references to underpinning theories, not all substantiated their
choice or discussed the implications and limitations of the theories selected on the
research outcomes. This fact posed a signiﬁcant challenge to analyzing the literature
and assessing the relevance and impact of the theoretical foundations.
To illustrate the signiﬁcance of theoretical choices, consider exploring the limi-
tations of the most commonly used theory in this context—corporate social respon-
sibility. Corporate social responsibility and more recently corporate sustainability
are used as managerial techniques to incorporate social aspects into business oper-
ations (Fasoulis and Kurt 2019b). Publications that employ this theory approach
social sustainability from an organizational perspective, focusing on the micro-
and meso- levels of individual persons and ﬁrms. Consequently, depending on the
speciﬁc research objectives/questions, corporate social responsibility might not be
the most suitable theoretical foundation, particularly when the study investigates
social sustainability on a macro scale (Vejvar 2019). Furthermore, empirical evidence
suggests that the corporate shipping sector often prioritizes economic and environ-
mental considerations over social (Kunnaala et al. 2013). Considering that corporate
initiatives are voluntary actions, adopting a corporate perspective to the research has

Sustainable shipping: a critical review for a

the tendency to limit the breadth and depth of understanding social sustainability in
the maritime industry at a macro level. Additionally, if the methodology relies on
self-reported data, such as is common for corporate social responsibility or sustain-
ability reporting, this could introduce signiﬁcant limitations of reliability and validity.
Given these considerations, the choice of a theoretical foundation for a study should
be justiﬁed with respect to research objectives, contextual and sectoral considerations
and account for the associated limitations in the outcomes of the research.
The methods employed in selected studies were largely traditional, with most
papers providing literature reviews (34 papers), primarily narrative. Only 4 studies
utilized systematic reviews. For data collection, studies frequently used surveys/
questionnaires (14 papers) and content analysis (3 papers). Given the signiﬁcant
methodological difﬁculties in measuring social sustainability (Karakasnaki et al.
2023), future research could explore methodological suggestions provided within
the broader social research literature such as those explored by Fahy and Rau (2013)
and Franklin and Blyton (2011). While the choice of research methods and tools
would largely depend on the speciﬁc research goals and related data gaps, researchers
should consider empirical data collection with alternative methods such as in-depth
interviews, focus groups, expert surveys, longitudinal studies, social experiments,
participatory action research and network analysis.
Research Directions and Thematic Synthesis
The analysis of the selected maritime literature identiﬁed a range of research direc-
tions relating to social sustainability broadly. Some aspects of social sustainability
are discussed in the broader context of sustainable maritime development (Bena-
mara et al. 2019; Vejvar 2019; Wang et al. 2020; Wu et al. 2020). Notably, the
192
M. E. Manuel and A. Prylipko
largest number of publications exploring social aspects belong to the corporate social
responsibility discourse (for example, Fasoulis 2023; Fasoulis and Kurt 2019a; Kara-
giannis et al. 2022; Kunnaala et al. 2013; Lund-Thomsen et al. 2016; Sampson 2016;
Sampson and Ellis 2016). This trend could be attributed the business nature of the
shipping industry and the inherent alignment of corporate social responsibility with
social connotations. Furthermore, the corporate perspectives on social aspects in the
World Maritime University’s edited publication ‘Corporate Social Responsibility in
the Maritime Industry’ (Froholdt 2018; Grewal 2018; Manuel 2018) increased the
number of search results in this area. This publication also accounted for the relatively
high number of book chapters (10) reviewed.
The research literature also dedicates attention to port sustainability and social
aspects in port operations (Ashraﬁet al. 2020; Dooms 2019; Sislian et al. 2016;
Stein and Acciaro 2020). This focus may be due to a larger proportion of business-
to-customer relationships in this sector and the attention from local communities
(Karakasnakietal.2023).Acommondiscussionthreadinthisliteraturearea/streamis
the impact of sustainable practices on stakeholder relationships and opportunities for
improvements in port performance. Studies have also explored the relation between
sustainability and the business performance of maritime transportation ﬁrms and
shipping companies (Yuen et al. 2019a, b) and the role of stakeholders in this
process (Osobajo et al. 2021; Parviainen et al. 2018; Yuen et al. 2020). Addition-
ally, the maritime literature discusses approaches to measuring social sustainability
(Andersson et al. 2017; Bonilla-Priego et al. 2014).
Some publications offer a more focused inquiry dedicated to speciﬁc shipping
sectors, including the cruise industry (Bonilla-Priego et al. 2014; Hillier et al. 2017;
Jonesetal.2019)andoffshoreplatforms(Koundourietal.2017).Socialsustainability
aspects align well with a human resources perspective (Ovais 2019; Pantouvakis
and Vlachos 2020; Progoulaki and Roe 2011; Progoulaki and Theotokas 2016).
Additionally, social sustainability is alluded to from the perspective of various social
issues, such as retention of seafarers (Cahoon et al. 2014), seafarers’ welfare (Graham
2009), safety and risk management (Manuel 2018), and safety culture (Pyć 2020).
Recent literature has begun to focus more on social aspects pertaining to seafarers
(Arslanetal.2023;Fasoulis2023;Karakasnakietal.2023).Thisemphasiscouldhave
been prompted by the COVID-19 pandemic, which highlighted the essential role of
seafarers in the shipping industry. However, it is important to stress that this emphasis
tends to overlook other onboard and shore-based maritime professionals, including
port employees, governmental ofﬁcials, surveyors, and educators. In fact, while the
indispensable role of stakeholder engagement in social sustainability is a common
thread observed across publications, there is no comprehensive consideration of what
social sustainability means to a broader range of stakeholders such as maritime ﬁrms,
governmental agencies, local communities, customers, and suppliers. The descriptive
and analytical synthesis of social sustainability themes conﬁrmed the conclusion
presented by Zhou et al. (2023) regarding the imbalance in the discussion of various
aspects of social sustainability with employees’ health and safety being the most
frequently mentioned in literature (Fig. 1).

2015 and 20232
Interestingly, the reviewed publications did not differentiate between the social
sustainability goals to be achieved and the procedural mechanisms for identifying and
implementing these goals effectively as suggested by Boström et al. (2015). Based
on Boström et al.’s insightful analysis, it is incontrovertible that the achievement and
strengthening of the substantive goals of social sustainability require the effective and
equitable involvement of the relevant social stakeholders, which should be embedded
procedurally in the governance model.
Furthermore, it was sometimes unclear whether publications were addressing the
role of the shipping industry in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals more
broadly or focusing on the sustainability of the shipping industry itself. In future
research, these two perspectives could be distinguished more clearly.
Finally, the overall observation from analyzing the literature is that the under-
standing and description of social sustainability in the shipping industry remains
fragmented. The maritime literature does not provide a clear deﬁnition of the concept.
This is not very surprising as the discussion about deﬁning social sustainability in the
wider context is fraught with confusion (de Fine Licht and Folland 2019). Similarly,
despite some attempts to conceptualize “maritime social sustainability” (Karakas-
naki et al. 2023), a comprehensive conceptualization model for the maritime context
of social sustainability as such (encompassing micro, meso and macro levels) is
yet to be attained. In the discussions about social sustainability, the publications
reviewed made little reference to the broader body of social science research, despite
the existence of seminal work in this area (Boström 2012; Colantonio 2009; de Fine
2 Social sustainability themes are mentioned in this table according to the frequency of references
in the academic literature selected for the review.
194
M. E. Manuel and A. Prylipko
Licht and Folland 2019; Littig and Griessler 2005; McGuinn 2020; Murphy 2012;
Spangenberg 2011). These works indicate possibilities for further research within
this sector drawn from a more holistic and well-rounded understanding of social
sustainability and thereby the progression towards crafting a deﬁnition that allows
for broad-based empirical data collection and analysis in the maritime industry.
4
Recommendations for Future Research
Building on the existing maritime literature, the following recommendations offer
a roadmap for future research endeavors in the ﬁeld of social sustainability in the
shipping industry.
Recommendation 1. Academic research and initiatives focused on the technical,
operational, environmental and market-based dimensions of sustainable maritime
development should incorporate social sustainability as an intrinsic component of any
sustainability framework. To achieve this integration, interdisciplinary collaboration
is crucial, involving researchers with a foundation in social sciences.
Recommendation 2. Researchers should be meticulous in both selecting and justi-
fying the theoretical foundations they apply in their work. It is essential to provide a
clear rationale for the selection of the theory while acknowledging its limitations and
potential implications on the research outcomes. These considerations are crucial not
only for improving academic rigor but also for advancing a more profound under-
standing of the multifaceted construct of social sustainability within the maritime
industry.
Recommendation 3. In their research designs, researchers should explore innovative
methods for empirical data collection beyond the traditional approaches. This has
the potential to signiﬁcantly contribute to theoretical advancements and to foster an
improved understanding of social sustainability from diverse perspectives.
Recommendation 4. It is important to continue the ongoing efforts to conceptualize
social sustainability within the maritime industry. In future research, it is recom-
mended that researchers distinguish between the micro-level perspective of indi-
viduals (e.g., seafarers), the meso-level of corporate entities (e.g., shipping compa-
nies) and the macro-level societal perspective (e.g., international/national gover-
nance in States and in organizations such as the International Maritime Organiza-
tion). This means clearly delineating social aspects relevant to various stakeholders,
including society at large, local communities, maritime ﬁrms, regulators, the range of
employees, customers, and suppliers. In turn, this will allow for the expansion of the
scope of social sustainability research beyond seafarers to include a broader spectrum
of maritime employees and other relevant stakeholders. Additionally, researchers
should endeavor to provide a comprehensive deﬁnition of social sustainability for
the maritime industry that allows for operationalizing of the construct across all the
relevant levels to allow for reliable and valid empirical data collection and analysis.
Where’s Wally? The Search for Social Sustainability in the Maritime …
195
Recommendation 5. Subsequent studies should explore and analyze extant social
issues in the maritime industry within a framework that interrogates both substantive
social sustainability goals and the procedural mechanisms for achieving them, as
recommended by Boström et al. (2015). A heightened focus on the procedural aspects
of social sustainability has the potential to expedite the achievement of the substantive
goals of social sustainability.
Recommendation 6. It is recommended that the broad conceptualizations and
deﬁnitions alluded to in Recommendation 4 should be contextualized to speciﬁc
research settings across the diverse operational parts of the maritime industry. This
focused/targeted approach offers better opportunities to ﬁll social sustainability with
substance and develop mechanisms for measuring social sustainability.
Recommendation 7. To further advance the progress of social sustainability research
within the maritime industry, it is recommended that institutional support be provided
and opportunities created for research into this subject. This will help the maritime
community address the issue of sustainable development holistically and alleviate
the current imbalance that favors its economic or environmental dimensions.
5
Conclusion
This study aimed to interrogate academic research in the realm of social sustainability
within the maritime transport with the purpose of offering insights for future research
in this area. Based on the outcomes of the systematic review of maritime literature
between years 2015 and 2023, the paper concludes that the pursuit of sustainable
development seems to compel maritime researchers to align their inquiries with
the global sustainability discourse. In maritime literature, however, it appears that
academic publications rarely adopt a holistic approach to sustainability, one that inte-
grates social considerations into research discussions focused on technical, opera-
tional, environmental, and market-based sustainable solutions. Furthermore, research
dedicated speciﬁcally to social sustainability in the maritime industry remains limited
and fragmented.
The persistent challenge in incorporating social sustainability can be attributed
to the inherent epistemological and ontological complexities of this construct. This
challenge is further compounded by the technical nature of maritime affairs that
seems to reduce the emphasis on social considerations. Additionally, the business-
oriented nature of the industry contributes further to the prioritization of ﬁnancial
considerations over social ones.
To facilitate progress in this research ﬁeld and enable the shipping industry to
advance towards genuinely sustainable solutions, institutionalized efforts can support
interdisciplinary research conducted by diverse research teams, with an additional
focus on social sustainability. Future research efforts could bring together the pieces
of the social sustainability puzzle into a comprehensive analytical conceptualization
196
M. E. Manuel and A. Prylipko
model based on a sound deﬁnition that can be applied across various shipping sectors,
jurisdictions, and stakeholder groups.
This systematic literature review often felt like searching for elements of social
sustainability in a seek-and-ﬁnd book, similar to searching for “Wally” in Martin
Handford’s humorous puzzle book series (Handford 2007). Searching for Wally is a
challengingtaskasthelandscapesinwhichWallyis“lost”,bustlewithactivityandthe
character himself often blends into the vibrant setting. Similarly, searching for social
sustainability across a range of research topics posed a challenge of unifying various/
diverse perspectives. Furthermore, social sustainability is related to a vibrant setting
of discourses on the human element, human resources, safety and security, diversity,
stakeholder salience and engagement, maritime governance at different levels, and
sustainable development. It encompasses a broad range of speciﬁc social considera-
tions making it exceptionally challenging to identify coherent and concise positions.
Additionally,thefactthatenvironmentalandeconomicfactorsalsocarrysocialimpli-
cations creates more complications. These intricacies and interconnections make the
pursuit of social sustainability a challenging endeavor, with elements that are multi-
faceted, elusive, and overlapping. However, it is a challenge that must be faced head-
on and prioritized given the importance of sustainable development. Wally must be
found!
The work informing this paper uncovered some vital pieces of the social sustain-
ability puzzle, but the quest does not conclude here. With the proposed recommen-
dations, future research can offer a more comprehensive understanding of social
sustainability within the maritime context.

Incorporating Existential Risks
into Sustainable Development Research
Bertrand G. Guillaume
Abstract In this chapter, I investigate dimensions of current sustainable develop-
ment research in the face of existential risks, i.e. potential global threats to humanity
that could lead to human extinction or civilizational collapse. My methodology
includesliteraturereviews,historicalresearchandhermeneuticsofideas.Iﬁrstsketch
the history of sustainable development and describe the evolution of sustainability
research and science. I then question the interplay between sustainable development
research and the imperative of actually safeguarding no less than human survival.
After exploring of existing connections based on two different frameworks, I turn
to the history and recent development of existential risks research and suggest a
more coupled agenda for upcoming research. Based on scholarship, I ﬁnally suggest
two basic options for safeguarding the future and discuss them in terms of strategic
prospects or pathways.
Keywords Sustainable development · Existential risks · Research · Future ·
Planetary
1
Introduction: Sustainable Development
and the Evolution of Sustainability Research
During the twentieth century, the grand narratives of progress, growth, and develop-
ment forged within Western culture up through modernity, were reconsidered. Espe-
cially after World War II, both the failure of the global economy to fairly distribute
wealth worldwide and the looming environmental crisis made it obvious that a new
paradigm was required (Du Pisani 2006).
The elaboration of the idea of sustainable development (SD) was ﬁrst focused
on the rational use and conservation of natural resources (UNESCO 1970) in line
B. G. Guillaume (B)
Université de Technologie de Troyes (UTT), Troyes, France
e-mail: bertrand.guillaume@utt.fr
European University of Technology (EUT+), Dublin, Ireland
© The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024
W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_12
201
202
B. G. Guillaume
with earlier concerns in human history regarding the depletion of energy reserves
such as wood and coal. In 1972 the report to the Club of Rome entitled The Limits
to Growth alerted that our planet had a ﬁnite supply of resources and that popu-
lation and economic growth could excess what the natural systems may support.
Should the socioeconomic trends remain steady, the most likely outcome would be
a catastrophic decline in world population and industrial production over the course
of the 21th century (Meadows et al. 1972). The modeling has been criticized on both
methodological and epistemological grounds (Guillaume 2023). Also, such a dire
forecast may have dramatized the question of environmental constraints at the time
(Mebratu 1998). However, the phenomenon of “overshoot and collapse” exhibited
by the model was an unsustainable prospect indeed! The ﬁrst in a series of decennial
international meetings on the global ecological crisis, a UN conference on the human
environment held in Stockholm started promoting the idea of SD institutionally in
the very same year (UN 1972).
By the end of the 1980s, the new SD paradigm gained popularity and provided us
with a deﬁnition. After the term was used in the World Conservation Strategy (1980)
of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, the UN World Commission
on Environment and Development issued the “Brundtland report” (1987). Entitled
Our Common Future, the document deﬁned SD as “development that meets the needs
of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their
own needs” and emphasized two associated key imbalances, namely the inequity of
the allocation of wealth worldwide and the global pressure on the environment and
the biosphere because of the features of the existing sociotechnological complex.
(WCED 1987).
So, after an “embryonic period” (before 1972) and a “molding period” (1972–
1987) for the theory of SD (Shi et al. 2019), the time came for a third “developing
period” (1987–present), paving the road for sustainability science (NRC 1999; Kates
et al. 2001). This new dynamic ﬁeld of research and innovation aimed at promoting
what the National Research Council has labeled a “transition toward sustainabil-
ity”, namely fostering our capacity to reduce poverty and meet the needs of human
population together with sustaining the life support systems of the biosphere (Clark
2007).
From a primary focus on gaining better knowledge into the complex interactions
between human and environmental systems, sustainability science has expanded to
practical inquiries into the resolution of urgent human problems (Hajian and Kashani
2021) through the establishment of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) with
the ratiﬁcation of the 2030 Agenda for SD framework (UN 2015). With a range of
scientiﬁc approaches, numerous studies have been published regarding the 17 SDGs
built upon the accomplishments of the former 8 Millennium Goals (2000). Research
has been mainly involved with the need for a shared understanding of the SDGs and
their practical operationalization (Sachs et al. 2019), or with different assessments of
the interplay between them, including synergies and possible conﬂicts (Scharlemann
et al. 2020).
Incorporating Existential Risks into Sustainable Development Research
203
2
The Interplay Between Sustainable Development (SD)
and Existential Risks (ER) Research
In this context, recent scholarship has exempliﬁed the importance to make explicit
again in SD research the imperative of actually safeguarding no less than human
survival. Should SD be conceived of as a social output aiming at achieving
human development within ecological limits through the co-production of innova-
tive knowledge and active practices (Norström et al. 2020), the complex interactions
among the 17 SDGs can for instance be investigated through a simple 3-categories
matrix approach in order to help promote sound and consistent policies for both
technological and institutional change (Bojie et al. 2019).
One category includes SDG-1 (no poverty), SDG-3 (good health and well-being),
SDG-4 (quality education), SDG-5 (gender equality), SDG-8 (decent work and
economic growth), SDG-10 (reduced inequalities), and SDG-16 (peace and justice).
Called “expected objectives”, it focuses on normative goals related to “the good
life”. Centered on the distribution of goods and services and the internalization
of sustainability-oriented norms within society, achieving this set of goals should
arguably rely on cultural change and institutional innovation in the ﬁrst place, thereby
calling for research across the social, political and behavioral sciences (Davis et al.
2018).
Another category includes SDG-2 (zero hunger), SDG-6 (clean water and sanita-
tion), SDG-7 (affordable and clean energy), SDG-14 (life below water), and SDG-15
(life on land). Labeled “essential needs”, it deals precisely with the necessity for SD
to satisfy basic requirements for human societies while safeguarding the functioning
of the life-support systems of the Earth in the Anthropocene (Griggs et al. 2013).
This set of goals refers to the very conditions of human survival in the long run,
which basically depends on food, water and energy resources, and the stable state of
the planetary machinery including the provision of terrestrial and oceanic ecosystem
services. This depends to a large extent on advances based on science and engineering
in resource use efﬁciency, net waste reduction and lower material and energy ﬂows
at all scales, and calls for innovations likely to satisfy basic needs while reducing the
pressure on the planet (Davis et al. 2018).
The last category includes SDG-9 (industry, innovation and infrastructures), SDG-
11 (sustainable cities and communities), SDG-12 (responsible consumption and
production), SDG-13 (climate action), and SDG-17 (partnerships for the goals).
Entitled “governance”, it encompasses the management and regulation of economic
or geopolitical competitions, as well as the establishment and enforcement of fair
systems and practices which can ensure the compatibility of the former two sets of
goals (at worst), or even maximize the ﬁrst under the constraints of the second one (at
best). This entails accountable management systems and new equity norms in envi-
ronmental politics when it comes to climate action in the industrial and agricultural
sectors, the resilience of infrastructures and communities, and mutually beneﬁcial
relationships between developed and developing countries (Okereke 2008).
204
B. G. Guillaume
Another exampleof suchascholarshipis thetwoconcentricrings of the“doughnut
economics” (Raworth 2017), which also articulates a set of normative welfare targets
(“social foundation”) with a set of strict ecological constraints (“ecological ceiling”).
Speciﬁcally, the latter follows directly the planetary boundaries framework, which
provides a science-based inquiry into the risk that the Earth system could be destabi-
lized at the planetary scale, thus jeopardizing our future, several limits being already
transgressed, pushing the planet outside the Holocenic “safe operating space for
humanity” (Rockström et al. 2009; Steffen et al. 2015; Richardson et al. 2023).
Still, it has been argued that the possibility, or the likelihood, of the extinction of
humankind in the decades or centuries to come is the “elephant in the (living) room”
in the literature on SD and the Anthropocene, such a prospect being mentioned on rare
occasions eventually, and being probably under-estimated anyway (Stewart 2023).
Therefore, SD research should integrate further in its development existential risks
(ER) research in order to safeguard the future, going back to the core of inquiries into
the history and the future of people on Earth, which have suggested that humanity is
now facing an alternative: sustainability or collapse (Costanza et al. 2006, 2007).
Surveying ER research in Western culture reveals the long intellectual history
of thinking about human extinction. Apocalyptic thought has a staggeringly proliﬁc
record in past centuries, from cosmogonies and religions in Antiquity, eschatological
imagination and the end of time in the Middle Ages, through Enlightenment and
modernity, scientiﬁc discoveries of the nineteenth century (e.g. the second law of
thermodynamics, new evolutionary theory and geological history of the Earth), up to
the nuclear era and the build-out of SD in the twentieth century, and current anxieties
about the Anthropocene, climate change, global outbreaks, or advanced artiﬁcial
intelligence (Torres 2023).
However, genuine ER research has only really blossomed during the last two
decades or so. It refers to the study of global catastrophic risks which could result
either in the irreversible destruction of our civilization (impacting both current and
future generations) or, even more radically, the terminal and permanent extinction of
humankind without any recovery. Existential risks can be formally deﬁned as “risks
that threaten the premature extinction of Earth-originating intelligent life or the
permanent and drastic destruction of its potential for desirable future development”
(Bostrom 2013) or risks that threaten “the destruction of humanity’s long-term
potential” (Ord 2020).
Such threats encompass events, processes, or phenomena likely to hinder the
(sustainable) development of humanity but also its long-term survival on a global
scale. Back to 2003, the ways ER could threaten the future of humankind in the course
of the twenty-ﬁrst century were investigated. They include environmental disasters
for sure (e.g. extreme global warming, ecological collapse, toxic waste accumula-
tion and pollution, as well as super-volcanoes, massive earthquakes or tsunamis, and
large asteroids), but also acts of terrorism or war-induced consequences (e.g. atomic
bombs and nuclear winter, chemical or biological weapons, genetically engineered
organisms released on purpose) and scientiﬁc errors or technological mayhem (e.g.
Incorporating Existential Risks into Sustainable Development Research
205
computers or machines taking over„ accidents with nano- or bio-technologies, unin-
tended consequence of DNA alteration, experiments in fundamental physics gone
wrong), all things that could wipe out mankind (Rees 2003).
Progressively, research centers on ER have been established worldwide, e.g. the
FutureofHumanityInstituteatOxfordUniversity(UK),theGlobalCatastrophicRisk
Institute (US), the Centre for the Study of Existential Risk at Cambridge University
(UK), the Global Challenges Foundation (SE), the Global Survivability Institute at
Kyoto University (JP), the Future of Life Institute (US). Additionally, university
courses and academic workshops have been given on ER at the University of Copen-
hagen (DE), the University of Gothenburg (SE), the University of Warwick (UK),
and Harvard University (US), among others (Currie and ÓhÉigeartaigh 2018).
Together with the characterization of such global catastrophic risks, inquiries into
both mitigation options and ethical thinking have been discussed in international
scholarship. Among the core concepts of ER research are longtermism and “further-
loss”. Longtermism is based on the idea that we should care much more for future
people, because their lives do count and have moral relevance, also their numbers
could be huge (the largest part of human beings who will ever live have probably
not been born yet), and we have the power to affect their existence and to harm
them in the long run (MacAskill 2022). The “further-loss” idea is based on the view
that avoiding the end of humankind should be our critical moral priority, the non-
existence of future generations being the greatest loss. The argument is that a global
catastrophe completely wiping out the human species would not only destroy our
present, but also annihilate our future, making the destruction of humanity “by far
the greatest of all conceivable crimes” according to classical utilitarianism. (Parﬁt
1986; Torres 2023).
While its ethical stance provides strong support for longtermism and “further-
loss” approaches to the future, it is doubtful that certain aspects of SD research
can actually safeguard human life and civilization in the long run. Should inquiries
into ER be taken seriously, some dimensions of current SD research and strategic
options for the future should be investigated further (and to some extent criticized)
in order to design a more coupled agenda for upcoming SD-ER research in the face
of catastrophic risks likely to threaten the future existence of humankind and its
long-term potential.
3
Two Basic Options for Safeguarding Planetary Futures,
and Their Strategic Prospects
In order to sketch items to be considered in designing such an integrated research
agenda, a recent study is of special interest. Blending the planetary boundaries frame-
work and ecological/material “footprint” indicators for various consumption-based
resource ﬂows, it assesses SD at the national level for a series of countries worldwide.
It is shown that meeting the basic human needs of their citizens today, extended to all
206
B. G. Guillaume
people on Earth universally on a per capita basis, can actually be achieved within the
biophysical limits of critical planetary processes (e.g. biogeochemical cycles) and
sustainable use of natural resources (e.g. water, energy, raw materials) in either of
two ways. Restrict the spectrum of the normative needs to be satisﬁed, or increase by
a factor of 2–6 the efﬁciency of the physical and institutional “provisioning systems”
(technology/infrastructures, markets/governments), which connect the use of natural
resources to welfare (O‘Neill et al. 2018).
Consider the ﬁrst option. Such a move would of course promote the view that more
is not always better, and imply acknowledging the social and ecological damages
of over-consumption in rich countries, together with developing new principles,
behaviors, and norms of “sufﬁciency” for our time (Princen 2005). It would also
fuel the debates about at last shifting away from GDP-oriented policies towards new
metrics of progress, “steady-states” economies or “degrowth” approaches (Costanza
etal.2014;Kerschner2010).However,withthisstrategyalone,only“physicalneeds”
would be met in average (namely, according to authors, nutrition, sanitation, access
to electricity, no extreme poverty) without any other higher targets achieved (i.e.
high life satisfaction, healthy life expectancy, secondary education, social support,
democratic quality, income equality), and just for a population of seven billions
(O‘Neill et al. 2018) ! Additionally, a second study establishes that countries are
already exceeding ecological limits much faster than they are meeting the basic needs
of people (Fanning et al. 2022), pushing them to further lower standards according
to this logic.
If standards of living can for sure be lowered to some extent in many rich countries
without signiﬁcantly changing their welfare levels, it is doubtful that a generalized
“degrowth”optionisasoundstrategyforthefutureof9.0–12.5billionpeopleby2100
according to current trends in global population size (UN 2022). First, it is disputable
that the outcome could then be labeled SD at all, depending on the actual quality
of life achievable eventually. Second, while it would clearly decrease the likelihood
of some ER (e.g. for environmental disasters: extreme global warming, toxic waste
accumulation and pollution, ecological collapse), it would also probably leave us
defenseless in the face of other ER (e.g. super-volcanoes, massive earthquakes or
tsunamis, asteroids).
However, it has been claimed that we could undergo a complete collapse should
such a radical rearrangement not be accomplished soon enough. All we have to
do, it is argued, is to halve the scale of our operations and reconsider afresh the
idea of progress we inherited towards “not a (simple) diminution [but] a veritable
transformation: the quest for progress liberated from the quest for power.” (Stewart
2023). Explicitly referring to the idea of “neganthropology” in contemporary philos-
ophy (Stiegler 2017), it is in fact an old anthropological distinction, which becomes
apparentagain,between“cold”and“hot”humansocieties,thoselikeclocksandthose
like steam-engines. In the ﬁrst case, so-called “primitive” societies tend to persevere
in their being while they are surrounded by the external ﬂow of events. Therefore,
they appear static and an-historical. In the second case, so-called “civilized” societies
internalize historical change and make it a driver of their development. Therefore,
they appear dynamic and evolving in time (Levi-Strauss 1966, 1967).
Incorporating Existential Risks into Sustainable Development Research
207
Again, this is perfectly sound in the context of SD research, especially in the
framework of a strong precautionary approach (Guillaume, 2012), and even regarding
some ER (especially the ones which are directly related to potential dire effects of
modern technology), but it would leave us helpless in the face of other ER (just to
mention a few: global outbreaks, hostile attacks, asteroid collisions).
Now consider the second option exempliﬁed in the study (O‘Neill et al. 2018),
namelyimprovingthe“provisioningsystems”asastrategytoachievegoodlifewithin
ecological limits worldwide. Physical improvements would involve approaches well-
known in SD research and practices: decoupling in energy and material consump-
tion through e.g. waste reduction, industrial ecology and circular economy schemes
(McDowall et al. 2017), deploying innovations such as passive energy systems across
economic sectors (Cullen et al. 2011), or achieving carbon–neutral economies by
reducing greenhouse gas emissions and strengthening natural carbon sinks (Walsh
et al. 2017). Social improvements would be necessary in order to limit direct and indi-
rect “rebound effects” on consumption, which are usually observed as the efﬁciency
of systems increases (Freeman 2018), and to improve social support and income
equality (non-intensive in resource use but inﬂuencing positively welfare), as well
as self-reported life satisfaction (intensive in resource use but also achievable by
non-material factors), as stressed by colleagues (O‘Neill et al. 2018).
Here the features of such a strategic option for SD seems mostly congruent with a
watchful and responsible oversight of ER, just as e.g. developing knowledge, educa-
tion, and transparency (or even well-argued targeted speciﬁc post-growth policies!).
This means that any sound future agenda for SD research to include ER research
could be based on the lineaments of “provisioning systems” rearranged in this way
to allow all people to live a good life with the critical limits of resource use.
At least two important difﬁculties remain, however. First, the kind of pathway
needed is incredibly ambitious, for meeting universal basic human development on
the planet in compliance with the SDGs without transgressing unsafe ecological
limits would mean achieving an unprecedented ×2–×6 net gain in efﬁciency, say in
tribute a factor 4 in average (Weizsäcker et al. 1998). Second, just as among SDGs,
conﬂicts can exist between SD and ER research, or even within ER research alone,
calling for complicated trade-offs. For instance, boosting cleaner energy systems
and industrial production or sustainable manufacturing through advanced artiﬁcial
intelligence or nanobots may ultimately represent a global catastrophic risk, should
we proceed then? Improving food security and agriculture through sophisticated
DNA technologies may be dangerous eventually… Perhaps in a near future, lunar or
martian settlements and space travel conceived of as redundancies for human life in
the solar system will require great destructive energies like fusion reactors. And so
on.
For these reasons, more dual and articulated SD-ER research is needed and should
be encouraged, together with making more efﬁcient use of natural resources and envi-
ronmental systems to reduce extreme poverty (Cernev and Fenner 2020). Similarly,
SD research has been applied to design and implement policies for the conserva-
tion of nature and planetary life-support systems, and should be extended to other
prospects likely to threaten human survival beyond climate change (Awang 2021).
208
B. G. Guillaume
4
Conclusion: Towards More Congruence Between
Sustainability Research and Existential Risks
The idea of “sustainable development” (SD) emerged in the late twentieth century
as a new paradigm associated with two fundamental imbalances i.e. the inequity
of the worldwide allocation of wealth and the global pressure on the environment
and the biosphere. In the last decades, SD research has dealt with the resolution of
corresponding urgent human problems within the framework of the UN Sustainable
Development Goals (SDGs) and with inquiries into the complex interactions between
human and critical environmental systems through time, both in the past and towards
the future, suggesting that humanity is facing an alternative in the Anthropocene:
sustainability or collapse.
Considering also so-called “existential risks” (ER) i.e. events, processes, or
phenomena likely to irremediably jeopardize the long-term survival of humanity
on a global scale, this chapter argues that SD research should integrate further in its
development ER research, beyond climate change and ecosystem collapse, in order
to safeguard the future. The agendas for SD and ER research can be more or less
congruent, or more or less conﬂicting, depending on the strategies considered. As
suggested in this chapter, we could for instance experience both sustainability and
collapse!
While physical and social improvements of “provisioning systems” seem in ﬁrst
analysis a sound strategy (together with the development of knowledge, education,
and transparency and arguably targeted post-growth policies) to both achieve good
life within ecological limits worldwide and allow for a watchful and responsible
oversight of existential risks, SD research and ER research should obviously be better
articulated worldwide, their interlinkages carefully investigated, and the associated
trade-offs further analyzed on a systematic basis. From the point of view of integrated
SD-ER research, using natural resources and environmental systems more efﬁciently
to reduce poverty and ensure human development in the long run is indeed necessary,
but not sufﬁcient, for as a species we are prone to other catastrophic global risks
beyond climate change and biodiversity loss in our co-evolution with the planet, life
and the Universe.

Circular Economy Adoption
in Construction: A Pathway
to Sustainable Development and UN SDG
11 Achievement
Rayra Brandão and Livia Verissimo
Abstract This article explores how the adoption of circular economy principles in
the construction industry can contribute to the achievement of the UN Sustainable
Development Goal 11, which aims to make cities and communities more inclusive,
safe, resilient and sustainable. Adopting a circular economy approach to construction
can reduce waste, reuse materials and promote healthier and more sustainable built
environments. The article highlights key factors driving the adoption of the circular
economy in the construction industry, including environmental concerns, resource
scarcity, cost savings and regulatory pressure. However, there are several barriers
that can impede the adoption and implementation of circular economy in construc-
tion, such as lack of awareness and understanding of circular economy principles
and difﬁculty in tracking materials and products throughout their lifecycle. Over-
coming these challenges requires greater awareness, investment in new technologies
and favorable regulatory frameworks. It is concluded that the adoption of circular
economy principles can signiﬁcantly contribute to building a more sustainable and
equitable future.
Keywords Circular economy · Civil construction · United Nations · Sustainable
Development Goals
1
Introduction
Strengthening the connection between this chapter and the book’s theme of Sustain-
able Research, we delve into the burgeoning concept of the circular economy, which
has garnered widespread attention in recent years, especially in diverse industries.
