214
R. Brandão and L. Verissimo
Among these, the construction sector stands out as a major global player, yet it also
bears a hefty responsibility for signiﬁcant waste generation. Therefore, integrating
circular economy principles into construction practices emerges as a pivotal strategy
for mitigating the industry’s environmental impact and fostering sustainability (Ruiz,
et al. 2020).
Indeed, the construction industry’s footprint on the environment is profound. A
report from the United Nations Environment Programme underscores this, revealing
that the sector contributes to 40% of global waste generation and 11% of green-
house gas emissions worldwide. Moreover, its voracious appetite for resources sees
it devouring 36% of global energy and 40% of raw materials (Brandão et al. 2020).
Central to the challenge lies the issue of construction waste, encompassing
materials like concrete, wood, metal, and plastics. The production processes
involved in handling these materials also yield signiﬁcant greenhouse gas emissions,
exacerbating environmental concerns (Poon et al. 2001).
Enter the circular economy—a beacon of hope for reducing construction waste
(Ruiz et al. 2020). This paradigm shift entails the reuse, repair, refurbishment, and
recycling of materials, aiming to minimize waste and maximize resource efﬁciency.
Embracing principles like waste elimination, product longevity, and ecosystem
regeneration, the circular economy offers a holistic approach to sustainable construc-
tion (Huovila et al. 2019).
The adoption of circular economy principles in construction is not merely a trend
but a necessity driven by a conﬂuence of factors. Environmental imperatives, resource
scarcity, economic viability, and regulatory pressures converge to compel the industry
towards sustainability. With mounting concerns over waste generation and emissions,
stakeholders are increasingly pushing for sustainable practices (Arora et al. 2020).
The construction industry heavily relies on natural resources such as wood,
minerals, and metals, extracted from the Earth’s crust. These resources are ﬁnite,
and their extraction can have negative environmental and social impacts, including
deforestation, air and water pollution, and displacement of local communities. There-
fore, the industry has a signiﬁcant impact on the achievement of the United Nations
Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG 11: Sustainable Cities
and Communities. The adoption of circular economy principles in the construction
industry can contribute to the attainment of SDG 11 by promoting more sustainable
and inclusive built environments (Ghaffar, Burman, and Braimah 2020).
This article discusses the potential of the circular economy in the construction
industry, with a speciﬁc focus on the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal
(SDG) 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities. The paper provides literature-based
insights into the circular economy in the construction industry and prompts an inves-
tigation into the broader environmental implications and impacts when considered
in the context of the UN SDGs Agenda 17. The argument is made for prioritizing
not only localized collaborative thinking and approaches but also adopting a united
international approach, given globalization, global economic indices, and sustainable
development goals that involve partnerships and the cross-pollination of knowledge,
expertise, and experience.
Circular Economy Adoption in Construction: A Pathway to Sustainable …
215
The burgeoning concept of the circular economy presents a promising pathway
towards sustainability, especially within the construction industry, which stands as
one of the largest contributors to global waste production and resource consump-
tion. This chapter explores the transformative potential of the circular economy in
addressing the environmental challenges inherent in construction practices, thereby
aligning closely with the overarching theme of Sustainable Research.
2
Sustainable Research Role in the Circular Economy
Within the Construction Industry
Sustainable research plays a pivotal role in advancing the Circular Economy within
the construction industry, aligning with the overarching objectives of the United
Nations’ 11th Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) focused on Sustainable Cities
and Communities. One avenue of sustainable research involves the exploration
and development of innovative materials that adhere to circular principles. This
could include the creation of eco-friendly, recycled, or upcycled materials, thereby
contributing to SDG 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production) by reducing
resource depletion and waste in construction projects (Sala 2019).
At its core, sustainability in construction entails the responsible management of
resources, minimization of environmental impact, and promotion of social equity
and economic prosperity. Traditional linear models of construction, characterized
by “take-make-dispose” practices, have led to rampant resource depletion, waste
generation, and ecological degradation. In contrast, the circular economy paradigm
offers a transformative approach, emphasizing the principles of reduce, reuse,
recycle, and regenerate. By fostering a closed-loop system where materials and
resources are continuously circulated within the economy, the circular economy
aims to decouple economic growth from resource consumption and environmental
degradation (Lobato et al. 2024).
Furthermore, sustainable research can delve into life-cycle assessments, providing
a comprehensive analysis of the environmental impact associated with construc-
tion projects. By scrutinizing the entire life cycle—from material extraction to
disposal—researchers can contribute to both SDG 12 and SDG 13 (Climate Action)
by promoting sustainable practices and mitigating the carbon footprints associated
with construction activities (Backes and Traverso 2022).
Circular design principles form another crucial aspect of sustainable research in
the construction industry. Researchers can focus on developing design concepts that
prioritize circularity, emphasizing structures that are easily disassembled and mate-
rials that can be seamlessly reintegrated into the circular economy. Such initiatives
align with SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure) and SDG 11, working
towards the establishment of sustainable cities and communities (Baldassarre et al.
2020).
216
R. Brandão and L. Verissimo
Efforts to reduce construction waste can be a focal point of sustainable research,
exploring strategies that minimize waste generation through efﬁcient construction
methods and responsible material usage. This directly contributes to SDG 12 by
addressing the sustainable consumption and production practices advocated by the
United Nations (Calvo et al. 2014).
Integrating smart technologies into construction processes is another avenue for
sustainable research. The use of sensors, IoT devices, and data analytics can optimize
resource management, providing real-time insights into resource consumption and
efﬁciency. This aligns with both SDG 9, focusing on industry and infrastructure
innovation, and SDG 12, emphasizing responsible consumption and production (Lim
et al. 2021).
In the realm of sustainable construction, research can extend its reach to policy
recommendations that encourage and enforce circular practices. By developing
frameworks that align regulatory environments with circular economy principles,
researchers contribute to SDG 17 (Partnerships for the Goals) by fostering collab-
orations between governments, industries, and communities to achieve sustainable
outcomes (Júnior et al. 2023).
The establishment of green certiﬁcation systems and standards for circular
constructionpracticesisanotherareawheresustainableresearchcanmakesubstantial
contributions. By setting industry benchmarks and promoting adherence to sustain-
able principles, these efforts align with SDG 12, endorsing responsible consumption
and production (Doan et al. 2019).
Renewable energy integration within construction projects stands as a notable
avenue for sustainable research. By exploring ways to incorporate renewable energy
sources, such as solar or wind power, researchers can contribute to SDG 7 (Afford-
able and Clean Energy), ensuring the overall sustainability of construction projects.
Conservation efforts can extend beyond construction materials to encompass biodi-
versity preservation in and around construction sites. Sustainable research can
explore landscaping practices that support local ecosystems, contributing to SDG 15
(Life on Land) by promoting biodiversity conservation (Pietrosemoli and Monroy
2013).
Finally, social impact assessments can be a valuable component of sustainable
research. Investigating the effects of circular construction practices on local commu-
nities, including factors such as job creation, community well-being, and social
equity, aligns with SDG 8 (Decent Work and Economic Growth) and SDG 11,
ensuring that the social dimensions of sustainability are thoroughly considered (Silva
et al. 2021).
In summary, by addressing these diverse avenues of sustainable research, the
construction industry can effectively contribute to the realization of the United
Nations’ 11 Sustainable Development Goals, fostering a more circular and sustain-
able approach to construction practices.

3
Circular Economy
Circular economy is a system of production and consumption that prioritizes the
use of resources in a closed loop, minimizing waste and maximizing efﬁciency. It is
an alternative to the traditional linear economy, which follows a take-make-dispose
approach, where resources are extracted, used once, and then discarded. In contrast,
the circular economy aims to keep resources in use for as long as possible, whether
through reuse, repair, or recycling (Huovila et al. 2019).
The circular economy has become increasingly popular in recent years due
to concerns about resource depletion, waste generation, and climate change. By
adopting the principles of the circular economy, businesses and industries can reduce
their environmental impact, conserve resources, and cut costs. The circular economy
can also create new economic opportunities and generate new revenue streams by
reusing and recycling materials (Brandão et al. 2020).
The circular economy is built on various key principles; Eliminate Waste and
Pollution, This entails designing products and processes that minimize waste gener-
ation and pollution throughout their lifecycles. Strategies include eco-design, cleaner
production technologies, and closed-loop manufacturing. Keep Products and Mate-
rials in Use, This involves extending the lifespan of products through repair,
reuse, remanufacturing, and recycling. Examples include product-service systems,
extended producer responsibility, and deposit-refund schemes. Regenerate Natural
Systems: This principle emphasizes protecting and restoring natural resources,
such as forests, water, and air. This includes practices like sustainable agriculture,
renewable energy generation, and biodiversity conservation (Polzer et al. 2016).
These principles require a systemic shift in how we produce and consume
goods and services and involve collaboration between businesses, governments, and
consumers (Silva et al. 2021).
The transition to a circular economy presents a myriad of beneﬁts across envi-
ronmental, economic, and social dimensions. From an environmental standpoint,
embracing a circular economy model leads to a signiﬁcant reduction in greenhouse
gas emissions. Moreover, this transition plays a crucial role in curbing resource
depletion, as it minimizes pollution and waste. The approach also contributes to the
conservation of biodiversity and enhances air and water quality (Silva et al. 2021).
On the economic front, the circular economy fosters increased resource efﬁ-
ciency and productivity. This shift in economic paradigms also sparks the creation
of new jobs and businesses, cultivating a dynamic and sustainable employment
landscape. Additionally, the circular economy mitigates reliance on imported
resources, promoting self-sufﬁciency and contributing to overall economic growth
and development (Huovila et al. 2019).
From a social perspective, the advantages are equally compelling. The circular
economy positively impacts public health and well-being by mitigating the adverse
effects of environmental degradation. Moreover, it ensures increased access to
resources, fostering a more equitable distribution of beneﬁts. As a result, the circular
218
R. Brandão and L. Verissimo
economy contributes to the reduction of social inequality and the development of
more resilient communities (Nadazdi et al. 2022).
In essence, the circular economy represents a new way of thinking about resource
management and sustainability. It offers a vision of a more efﬁcient and regenerative
economy where resources are valued and used intelligently, and waste is minimized.
Implementing the circular economy necessitates a comprehensive strategy
involving diverse stakeholders. Governments can play a pivotal role in this tran-
sition by establishing policy and regulatory frameworks that incentivize circular
practices. This includes implementing eco-taxes, extended producer responsibility
regulations, and public procurement policies that favor circular products and services
(Iyer-Raniga et al. 2023).
At the corporate level, companies must embrace circular business models, such as
product-as-a-service, leasing, and pay-per-use. Shifting the focus from product sales
to resource utilization and value retention is essential for fostering sustainability.
Technological advancements are critical in developing efﬁcient and cost-effective
solutions for resource recovery, remanufacturing, and recycling. Consumer behavior
plays a pivotal role, and empowering individuals to make informed choices is crucial.
Encouraging sustainable consumption patterns, such as selecting durable products,
participating in reuse and repair initiatives, and supporting businesses committed to
circular practices (Veleva and Bodkin 2018). Furthermore, effective collaboration
between governments, businesses, research institutions, and civil society organiza-
tions is essential for creating an environment conducive to the circular economy.
This collaborative effort, as highlighted by (Abadi et al. 2023), promotes shared
responsibility and a holistic approach.
Despite the signiﬁcant potential of the circular economy, there are challenges
that must be addressed for successful implementation. Existing economic and regu-
latory frameworks often favor the linear economy, creating systemic barriers that
hinder circular businesses. Additionally, technological gaps persist, requiring further
advancements to enhance the efﬁciency and cost-effectiveness of circular technolo-
gies. Overcoming challenges related to consumer awareness and behavior is crucial,
as lack of awareness and resistance to behavioral change can impede the transition to
circular consumption patterns. Access to ﬁnance for circular businesses and infras-
tructure development poses another signiﬁcant barrier that must be addressed for the
circular economy to ﬂourish (Abdul-Hamid et al. 2020).
4
The Construction Industry
The civil construction industry is a broad sector that encompasses a range of activi-
ties involved in the design, planning, construction, and maintenance of buildings and
infrastructure. It is a critical sector that contributes to economic growth and devel-
opment, providing employment opportunities and creating the built environment in
which we live and work (Brandão et al. 2020).
Circular Economy Adoption in Construction: A Pathway to Sustainable …
219
The construction industry is diverse, ranging from small residential renovations
to large infrastructure projects, and involves a variety of professions, including archi-
tects, engineers, contractors, and specialized professionals. The industry is a signif-
icant contributor to the economy, with a global market size of over $11 trillion in
2019 (Aslam, Huang, and Cui 2020).
Despite its importance, the construction industry faces signiﬁcant challenges,
including rising costs, labor shortages, and environmental concerns. The industry
is also a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and resource depletion,
underscoring the need for more sustainable practices (Chinda 2017).
To address these challenges, the construction industry is increasingly adopting
new technologies such as Building Information Modeling (BIM) and automation to
enhance efﬁciency and reduce costs. The industry is also exploring more sustainable
and circular approaches to construction, such as the use of renewable materials and
the adoption of circular economy principles (Ghaffar, Burman, and Braimah 2020).
5
Construction Waste
Construction waste refers to the by-products generated during the construction, reno-
vation, demolition, and dismantling of buildings and infrastructure. The amount of
construction waste generated is signiﬁcant, representing up to 40% of the total waste
generated in many countries (De Lima 2021).
Constructionwasteincludesavarietyofmaterials,includingconcrete,wood,steel,
brick, insulation, among others. These waste materials can be hazardous, containing
substances such as asbestos, lead, and mercury, which can have negative impacts
on health and the environment if not handled and disposed of properly (Poon et al.
2001).
Improper handling and disposal of construction waste can also contribute to envi-
ronmental issues such as soil and water pollution, as well as greenhouse gas emis-
sions. In contrast, proper management and disposal of construction waste can help
reduce the negative environmental impacts of the construction industry and conserve
resources (Brandão, Edwards, et al. 2021a, b).
To address the issue of construction waste, many countries and organizations
have implemented waste management strategies such as reduction, reuse, and recy-
cling. This includes the adoption of circular economy principles, which aim to keep
materials and products in use for as long as possible, minimizing waste generation
(Gálvez-Martos et al. 2018).
Overall, the management of construction waste is a crucial aspect of sustain-
able construction, as it can help mitigate the negative environmental impacts of the
construction industry and contribute to resource conservation.
220
R. Brandão and L. Verissimo
6
United Nations Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 11:
Sustainable Cities and Communities
TheSDG11aimstomakecitiesandhumansettlementsmoreinclusive,safe,resilient,
and sustainable. The civil construction industry plays a crucial role in achieving this
goal as it is responsible for the construction and maintenance of the infrastructure
and housing that form the foundation of urban and rural communities.
The adoption of circular economy principles in the civil construction industry can
contribute to the attainment of SDG 11 through:
1. Reduction of Waste and Promotion of Resource Efﬁciency:
The civil construction industry generates a signiﬁcant amount of waste, much of
which can be avoided through the application of circular economy principles. By
reusing materials and designing for disassembly, the industry can reduce the amount
of waste generated and promote more efﬁcient use of resources. For example, the
use of recycled concrete can reduce the carbon footprint of construction projects and
improve air quality in surrounding areas. By reusing materials and reducing waste,
the civil construction industry can also decrease the demand for virgin materials and
the associated environmental impacts, such as deforestation, soil degradation, and
water pollution (Noll et al. 2019).
2. Promotion of More Sustainable and Healthy Built Environments:
The use of recycled and reclaimed materials, as well as the application of lean
construction principles, can lead to more sustainable and healthy built environments.
For instance, the use of recycled wood can decrease the demand for virgin timber and
the associated environmental impacts, such as deforestation and habitat destruction.
Similarly, the use of recycled steel can reduce the energy needed to produce new steel
and the associated greenhouse gas emissions. The application of lean construction
principles, such as just-in-time material delivery and waste reduction, can also lead
to more efﬁcient and sustainable construction practices. By reducing the amount
by reducing the time and resources required to complete a construction project, the
industry can decrease its environmental impact and enhance efﬁciency (Huovila et al.
2019).
3. Adoption of Circular Economy Principles in the Civil Construction Industry:
The adoption of circular economy principles in the civil construction industry
can create new economic opportunities, such as the development of recycling tech-
nologies and waste management, and promote more equitable access to housing and
affordable infrastructure. By fostering more sustainable and inclusive built environ-
ments, the industry can contribute to the achievement of SDG 11, which aims to
make cities and human settlements more inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable.
For example, the use of recycled materials in affordable housing projects can reduce
construction costs and increase access to affordable housing. Similarly, the applica-
tion of circular economy principles in infrastructure projects can enhance access to
Circular Economy Adoption in Construction: A Pathway to Sustainable …
221
basic services such as water and sanitation, promoting more equitable development
(Ruiz et al. 2020).
7
Methods
The exploratory study embarked on a literature research within databases of scien-
tiﬁc references to elucidate insights pertinent to the chosen topic (Creswell 2012).
The research mechanism was set up with the following search strings in the in
article’s title, abstract and keywords ((“reverse logistics” OR “circular economy”)
AND (“construction industry” OR “AEC industry” OR “building industry” OR “con-
struction sector” OR “construction and demolition waste” OR “construction waste”)
AND (“construction and demolition waste,” OR “construction waste”)).
A search was performed across three internationally recognized scientiﬁc
databases,Scopus,ScienceDirectandWebofScience.Thesedatabaseswereselected
based on their extensive coverage of multidisciplinary scholarly literature, providing
a robust foundation for comprehensive exploration.
The execution of the search strategy across the identiﬁed databases was conducted
with precision, aiming to retrieve a diverse range of articles, publications, and
academicpapersrelevanttotheresearchtopic.Eachsearchresultunderwentthorough
scrutiny, beginning with the review of titles and abstracts to assess their alignment
with the research objectives. The culmination of the exploratory study involved a
comprehensive analysis and interpretation of the synthesized data, aiming to derive
meaningful insights and implications (Creswell 2018).
8
Drivers of the Circular Economy in the Civil
Construction Industry
The drivers of the circular economy in the construction industry are multifaceted and
encompass a variety of economic, environmental, and social factors (Brandão et al.
2020).
One of the main drivers is the need to reduce the environmental impact of the
construction industry. Construction signiﬁcantly contributes to greenhouse gas emis-
sionsandresourcescarcity,andthereisagrowingawarenessoftheneedtoadoptmore
sustainablepractices. Byembracingcircular economyprinciples suchas wastereduc-
tion, material reuse, and recycling, the construction industry can diminish its envi-
ronmental footprint and contribute to a more sustainable future (Kucukvar, Egilmez,
and Tatari 2014).
Another driver is the economic beneﬁts of the circular economy. By adopting
circular economy principles, the construction industry can cut costs, increase efﬁ-
ciency, and create new revenue streams. For instance, through the reuse and recycling
222
R. Brandão and L. Verissimo
of materials, companies can save on raw material costs and disposal fees. Addition-
ally, the circular economy can generate new business opportunities, such as the
development of innovative recycling technologies and waste management solutions.
Embracing a circular economy approach can help reduce costs by minimizing waste
production and the need for new materials, especially beneﬁcial in the long term as
resources become scarcer and more expensive (Hoo, Hashim, and Ho 2020).
Finally, the social beneﬁts of the circular economy also drive its adoption. By
embracing circular economy principles, the construction industry can create more
sustainable and healthy built environments, promoting the well-being of occupants
and communities. This approach can also foster more equitable and inclusive oppor-
tunities, such as the development of affordable housing and the creation of jobs in
sustainable construction (Brandão, Edwards, et al. 2021a, b).
Resource scarcity is another driver of the circular economy in the construction
industry. Construction heavily relies on ﬁnite resources like raw materials and energy.
As these resources become scarcer, it becomes increasingly important for the industry
to adopt a circular economy approach to resource management (Hoo et al. 2020).
Emerging technologies are facilitating the transition to a circular construction
industry. From digital twins and building information modeling (BIM) to artiﬁcial
intelligence and advanced materials, these technologies are enabling design for disas-
sembly, optimizing material use, and improving waste management (Oraee et al.
2017). Consumers are increasingly demanding sustainable products and services,
including those related to construction. This growing demand creates a market for
circular construction solutions that offer environmental beneﬁts alongside economic
value (Bickel et al. 2020).
Collaboration and partnerships: Successful implementation of CE in the civil
construction industry requires collaboration between stakeholders across the entire
supply chain. This includes designers, contractors, manufacturers, waste manage-
ment companies, policymakers, and researchers. Initiatives like the Global Alliance
for Circular Economy in Construction are fostering cross-sector collaboration and
knowledge exchange to accelerate the transition to a circular construction economy
(Brandão et al. 2020).
Lastly, regulatory pressure is also a driving force behind the circular economy
in the construction industry. Governments and regulatory bodies are increasingly
pushing for more sustainable practices in the construction industry, including the
adoption of circular economy principles (Brandão et al. 2020).
Overall, the drivers of the circular economy in the construction industry are
complex and multifaceted, encompassing economic, environmental, and social
factors. By recognizing these drivers and working to adopt circular economy
principles, the construction industry can contribute to a more sustainable future.
Circular Economy Adoption in Construction: A Pathway to Sustainable …
223
9
Challenges of Circular Economy in the Construction
Industry
Despite the potential beneﬁts of the circular economy in the construction industry,
there are several challenges that can hinder its adoption and implementation. One of
the main challenges is the lack of awareness and understanding of circular economy
principles among industry stakeholders. This can lead to a lack of knowledge on how
to implement circular practices and a preference for traditional linear approaches in
construction. Additionally, resistance to change may arise due to a lack of incentive
to alter established practices and invest in new technologies (Brandão et al. 2020).
Another signiﬁcant barrier is the difﬁculty in tracking and tracing materials and
products throughout their lifecycle. This is crucial for the circular economy, but
the complexity of construction supply chains can make it challenging to implement
circular practices effectively. This includes issues related to the quality and safety
of recycled materials and the difﬁculty of implementing circular practices across
various types and scales of projects (Brandão, Edwards, et al. 2021a, b).
Furthermore, the initial costs of implementing circular practices can be a signif-
icant barrier for many construction companies. This involves investments in new
technologies and the retraining of the workforce, which can be a substantial ﬁnancial
burden for smaller companies (Werning and Spinler 2020).
Finally, regulatory barriers, such as local or national regulations that do not
encourage or prioritize the adoption of circular practices in construction, can also
pose a challenge (Ghisellini et al. 2018).
Overall, the challenges to the adoption of the circular economy in the construc-
tion industry are complex and varied, requiring industry stakeholders to work
collaboratively to address these issues and create a more sustainable future.
10
The Way Forward
Overcoming the challenges associated with the Circular Economy in the construc-
tion industry demands a multifaceted and concerted effort. The ﬁrst critical step
involves the establishment and implementation of standardized testing protocols
tailored speciﬁcally to recycled and repurposed construction materials. These proto-
cols must address the inherent variability in source materials, diverse processing
methods, and potential contaminants. Through such standardization, the industry can
ensure a consistent and high-quality supply of materials, thereby mitigating concerns
related to structural integrity and safety in the construction process (Martins et al.
2022).
Technological advancements play a pivotal role in surmounting these chal-
lenges. Investing in research and development initiatives focused on non-destructive
testing methods and real-time monitoring technologies can signiﬁcantly enhance the
industry’s capability to monitor and guarantee the quality of construction materials
224
R. Brandão and L. Verissimo
throughout the entirety of a project’s lifecycle. Such innovations not only contribute
to more effective quality assurance but also enable a more dynamic and responsive
approach to managing materials in circular construction practices (Sobotka and Czaja
2015).
In the Project Design stage, several Circular Economy practices have been
employed within the construction industry to promote sustainability and resource
efﬁciency. Firstly, there’s a focus on the design and implementation of modular
buildings, which streamline construction processes and facilitate easier disassembly
and reassembly, thereby reducing waste and promoting material reuse. Additionally,
there’s an emphasis on designing buildings with adaptability in mind, allowing for
future modiﬁcations and repurposing to accommodate changing needs and func-
tions. Furthermore, strategies for designing buildings for disassembly are integrated,
ensuring that materials can be efﬁciently recovered and reused at the end of a
building’s lifecycle (Benachio et al. 2020).
Moreover, companies are adopting tools such as scales to assess the level
of Circular Economy practices implemented within their operations, promoting
accountability and continuous improvement. Additionally, simulations within
Building Information Modeling (BIM) software are utilized to analyze the reuse
potential of materials across various design scenarios, enabling informed decision-
making early in the project lifecycle. Life-cycle analysis techniques are employed to
evaluate the environmental beneﬁts of reusing different types of materials, guiding
design choices towards more sustainable outcomes. Furthermore, material stock data
isleveragedtofacilitatethereuseofmaterialsinnewconstructionprojects,promoting
resource conservation and reducing the demand for virgin materials (Hossain et al.
2020).
At the End of Life stage within the construction industry’s life cycle, various
Circular Economy practices are employed to enhance sustainability and resource
efﬁciency. Firstly, there’s an emphasis on analyzing the potential for reusing or recy-
cling existing materials, evaluating their feasibility compared to using new materials.
This process involves careful management of demolition waste, ensuring that mate-
rials are properly sorted and processed for reuse or recycling, thereby minimizing
landﬁll disposal and reducing environmental impact (Guerra et al. 2021).
Furthermore, circularity tools are utilized to assess existing buildings and provide
optimal solutions for refurbishment. These tools enable comprehensive evaluations
of building components and systems, identifying opportunities for repair, renova-
tion, and material reuse to extend the lifespan of structures and minimize resource
consumption. Additionally, the deconstruction of building structures and parts is
conducted systematically, with a focus on salvaging materials for reuse or recy-
cling. By dismantling buildings in a methodical manner, valuable materials can be
recovered and repurposed, contributing to a more circular and sustainable construc-
tion industry. Overall, these Circular Economy practices at the End of Life stage
underscore the industry’s commitment to sustainable practices and the responsible
management of resources throughout the building lifecycle (Charef et al. 2021).
Collaboration emerges as a cornerstone in overcoming the hurdles associated with
circularity in construction. Establishing a collaborative framework among industry
Circular Economy Adoption in Construction: A Pathway to Sustainable …
225
stakeholders, including manufacturers, suppliers, regulatory bodies, and construction
professionals, is imperative. Such collaboration fosters knowledge sharing, promotes
the adoption of best practices, and facilitates the development of industry-wide
standards. By collectively addressing challenges and aligning efforts, stakeholders
can instill conﬁdence in the quality of circular construction materials, laying the
groundwork for widespread adoption of circular practices (Brandao et al. 2023).
A fundamental shift in design thinking within the construction industry is crucial
for embracing circularity. Advocacy for modular and adaptable design principles,
where structures are conceived with disassembly and material recovery in mind, is
paramount. Architects and engineers must prioritize not only the functionality and
aesthetics of a structure but also the ease with which its components can be disman-
tled, repurposed, or recycled. This paradigm shift ensures that circular principles are
embedded in the very design and architecture of buildings, fostering sustainability
from the ground up (Melo et al. 2021).
Education and training programs play a pivotal role in equipping professionals in
the construction industry with the knowledge and skills required for navigating the
complexities of circular construction materials. Architects, engineers, and construc-
tion workers need to be well-versed in understanding how different materials behave
in recycled forms and be adept at addressing potential challenges associated with
their use. Comprehensive education programs contribute to building a workforce
that is not only skilled in traditional construction practices but is also proﬁcient in
the intricacies of circular construction (Opoku and Guthrie 2018).
Transparent communication is another linchpin in overcoming challenges associ-
ated with circularity in construction. There is a need to educate clients, investors, and
end-users about the beneﬁts and challenges of using recycled materials. Clearly artic-
ulating the quality assurance processes in place, the environmental impact of circular
practices, and the long-term beneﬁts of embracing the circular economy in construc-
tion is essential. Transparent communication fosters trust and understanding, crucial
components for wider acceptance and support for circular construction practices
(Wolff et al. 2020).
Innovation in material science is a critical avenue for addressing the material
complexity and quality assurance barrier. Research and development initiatives
focused on material science can lead to the creation of new materials or enhancements
to existing ones speciﬁcally tailored for circular construction. Developing recycled
materials with consistent quality and performance becomes instrumental in allaying
concerns regarding variability and safety in construction projects (Melo et al. 2021).
Moreover, advocating for regulatory support and incentives becomes integral
to facilitating the adoption of circular practices in construction. Governments can
play a pivotal role by incentivizing the use of recycled materials through policies,
tax breaks, or grants. Aligning regulations with circular economy goals not only
provides a supportive framework but also addresses ﬁnancial barriers, encouraging
the construction industry to embrace sustainable practices (Iyer-Raniga et al. 2023).
Enhanced integration within the construction supply chain is another key strategy
for overcoming challenges. Encouraging seamless collaboration among suppliers,
manufacturers, contractors, and waste management entities ensures that materials
226
R. Brandão and L. Verissimo
are sourced, used, and recycled in a coordinated manner. This integrated approach
reduces inefﬁciencies, promotes circularity, and fosters a more sustainable and
resilient construction ecosystem (Nunes et al. 2023).
Furthermore, integrating life-cycle assessments into construction projects
becomes imperative. This involves evaluating the environmental impact of materials
and processes throughout the entire life cycle of a building, from material extraction
to end-of-life disposal. By considering the broader ecological footprint, construction
professionals can make more informed decisions that prioritize sustainability and
circularity (Backes and Traverso 2022).
Public awareness campaigns serve as a vital component in the broader strategy of
overcoming challenges in the circular economy within the construction industry.
Educating the general population about the importance of circular practices in
construction not only builds public support but also creates a demand for sustain-
able construction methods and materials. This, in turn, inﬂuences industry practices,
encouragesfurtherinnovation,andestablishesasocietalfoundationforthesuccessful
implementation of circular principles in construction (Abdul-Hamid et al. 2020).
In conclusion, overcoming the challenges associated with the Circular Economy
intheconstructionindustrynecessitates acomprehensiveandcollaborativeapproach.
From standardized testing protocols and technological advancements to collaborative
stakeholder engagement and public awareness campaigns, each facet plays a crucial
role in paving the way for a more sustainable and circular construction industry.
11
Conclusions
The principles of the circular economy have the potential to transform the construc-
tion industry by reducing waste, reusing materials, and promoting more sustainable
and healthy built environments. The adoption of these principles can contribute to
achieving UN Sustainable Development Goal 11 (SDG 11), fostering more sustain-
able and inclusive cities and communities. However, there are various barriers to
the adoption of the circular economy in the construction industry, highlighting the
need for increased education and awareness, investment in new technologies, and
supportive regulatory frameworks.
The pursuit of sustainability within the construction industry is intricately linked
with the broader agenda of sustainable development, as encapsulated in the United
Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and
Communities emphasizes the need for inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable urban
environments. By embracing circular economy principles, the construction industry
can contribute to achieving SDG 11s objectives by creating more sustainable and
livable cities. From green building design and energy-efﬁcient infrastructure to
affordable housing and inclusive urban planning, sustainable construction practices
play a pivotal role in shaping the cities of the future.
By embracing a circular economy approach, the construction industry can
decrease waste production, conserve resources, and lessen its environmental impact.
Circular Economy Adoption in Construction: A Pathway to Sustainable …
227
Several factors are driving the adoption of the circular economy in the construction
industry, including environmental concerns, resource scarcity, cost savings, and regu-
latory pressure. Overall, the circular economy presents signiﬁcant opportunities for
the construction industry to become more sustainable and reduce its environmental
footprint.
Future research in this ﬁeld may focus on several key areas to further advance the
adoption of circular economy principles in the construction industry and effectively
achieve the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). There is a need
for research addressing awareness and education regarding circular economy princi-
ples within the construction industry. This entails developing training and educational
programs targeting engineers, architects, builders, and other industry professionals,
elucidating the environmental and economic beneﬁts of embracing circular practices.
Additionally, technological advancements are required to enhance the traceability
and monitoring of materials throughout their lifecycle. This may entail the develop-
ment of blockchain-based tracking systems or other innovative technologies enabling
transparent and precise insights into the origin, usage, and ultimate disposition of
construction materials. Another pivotal point is the necessity to investigate and
develop circular business models speciﬁc to the construction sector. This involves
crafting ﬁnancial and economic incentives that promote the reuse, recycling, and
remanufacturing of construction materials, as well as fostering partnerships among
enterprises, governments, and civil society organizations to drive innovation and
collaboration.
Lastly, it is imperative to continue advocating for favorable policies and regula-
tions that incentivize and support the adoption of circular economy principles in the
construction industry. This may entail the development of international guidelines
and standards, as well as ﬁscal incentives and subsidies for companies embracing
circular practices. Ultimately, future research should concentrate on developing
holistic and integrated solutions addressing the multifaceted challenges of circular
economy adoption in construction, thereby fostering more inclusive, safe, resilient,
and sustainable cities and communities.

The Use of Blockchain in Public
Administration: A Transformative Tool
for a More Sustainable Future
María Cendán Castillo and Isabel Novo Corti
Abstract The application of Blockchain technology in public administration is
emerging as a topic of growing interest in the global context. The fundamental role of
administration, focused on resource management and decision-making with social
impact, places it in a strategic position to make the world more sustainable. At the
same time, Blockchain technology is seen as an innovative tool, due to its ability
to create immutable digital records, generating increasing interest for its potential
to enhance sustainability and reduce environmental impact in the management of
public resources. The objective of this sustainability-focused research is to conduct
an in-depth analysis of the main advantages and challenges of applying Blockchain
technologies in public administration as well as its potential impact on sustainability.
To achieve this, a review of key documents and case studies related to the subject will
be conducted. The results suggest new areas of study within sustainability research,
focusing on the development of scalable solutions, longitudinal studies on environ-
mental impact, and cross-disciplinary collaboration. Focusing sustainability research
on these areas will enable Blockchain to become a truly transformative tool for a
more sustainable future.
Keywords Blockchain technology · Public administration · Sustainability ·
Efﬁcient governance · Transparency
M. C. Castillo (B) · I. N. Corti
Economic Development and Social Sustainability (EDASS), Faculty of Economics and Business,
University of A Coruña. Elviña Campus, 15008 A Coruña, Spain

I. N. Corti

M. C. Castillo and I. N. Corti
1
Introduction: Blockchain as a Lever for Sustainability
in the Digital Strategy of the Public Sector
Digital transformation has emerged as a priority both at European and global levels
for governments with a particular focus on improving public services, protecting
citizens’ well-being and strengthening the relationship between society and govern-
ment in terms of sustainability, quality, and transparency (European Commission
2021). Within the framework of public administration (PA), the digital strategies
focuses on the need of creating a digital ecosystem (Schmidt and Krimmer 2022)
focusing on improving the efﬁciency of public services, strengthening citizen partic-
ipation, and fostering a transition to a public sector more adapted to the digital age
in pursuit of a progressively sustainable system (Lindgren et al. 2019; Catalini and
Gans 2020). With the growing awareness of climate change and the urgent need for
more social inclusion practices, PA is increasingly looking towards innovative tech-
nologies to address sustainable challenges (Elisa et al. 2023; Tavares et al. 2020). One
such technology that has caught the attention of public administrators is Blockchain
(Schletz et al. 2020). Blockchain technology (BC) has the potential to revolutionize
PA by enhancing transparency, accountability, and efﬁciency in sustainability efforts
(Jayawardhana and Colombage 2020; Aysan et al. 2021). It considered as a catalyzing
tool for a digital strategy aligned with the sustainable development goals proposed
by the Agenda 2030. Its intrinsic features, such as immutability, traceability, or
decentralization, enable the construction of new approaches in the ﬁeld of inno-
vation towards a more robust sustainability (Changwony et al. 2015; Aburumman
et al. 2020). BC can enhance governance systems within cities or smart cities by
offering more sustainable services and decentralizing trust. This can prevent manip-
ulation by central authorities, promote transparency, and ensure trust-free transac-
tions (Rana et al. 2019; Aysan et al. 2021). Research into its principal advantages
and challenges is an ongoing necessity within sustainability research that enables a
deeper exploration of the applicability of BC across various domains. Drawing from
a comprehensive review of the literature, the primary advantages and challenges
of applying BC in pursuit of a more sustainable PA are delineated. As we shall
observe, its attributes enable information tracing, heightening interaction security,
and fostering sustainability in decision-making, particularly within the framework
of public policies.
The Use of Blockchain in Public Administration: A Transformative …
233
2
The Role of Blockchain Technology in a New Sustainable
Public Governance
2.1
Main Characteristics of Blockchain Technology
In 2008, under the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto, the white paper introducing the
concept of Bitcoin, a decentralized payment method, was published (Nakamoto
2008). Although he does not mention the word “Blockchain”, Nakamoto introduces
the idea of interlocking blocks of data, which gives rise to the term and establishes
it as a key tool in the digital realm (Mattila 2016). BC, deﬁned as an electronic
database system, aims to record and distribute transactional data through the use
of cryptography to ensure security and direct consensus among participants (Sun
Yin et al. 2019), strengthening data protection, and reinforcing protection in the
exchange of digital data (Sansone et al. 2023). Also known as Distributed Ledger
Technology, BC is applied to facilitate the exchange of digital data between peers
without intermediaries, establishing a decentralized trust system (Ølnes et al. 2017).
Once a transaction is embedded and veriﬁed on the BC, it cannot be deleted, which
ensures an immutable record of transactions (Yfantis et al. 2021). The BC peer-to-
peer (P2P) network allows transactions with digital assets between different actors in
the system, called miners. These miners solve mathematical problems by “Proof of
Work” (PoW) to verify the transparency of the transaction and create a hash value that
connects the blocks in the chain. They are usually compensated in return in cryp-
tocurrencies (Tschorsch and Scheuermann 2016). Although efﬁcient, this process
consumes high levels of energy, which has led to the proposal of Proof of Stake
(PoS) as a more sustainable alternative.
The potential of BC to enhance sustainability is a topic of growing interest (Son-
Turan 2019). Although BC technology has found applications in various ﬁelds,
such as security, integrity, and sustainability (Sansone et al. 2023) its presumed
immutability, authenticity, and decentralized nature offer new opportunities to
enhance trust and transparency in different sectors (Secinaro et al. 2021). While
its application in the public sector is still relatively unexplored, it is seen as a driver
for transformative change, particularly in terms of networking services, data secu-
rity, and operational efﬁciency (Sousa 2023; Cagigas et al 2021). However, despite
its innovative potential, BC is still in an experimental phase (Allen et al. 2020) and
its impact should not be overestimated (Aysan et al. 2021). Ignorance of this tech-
nology generates mistrust in its applicability, and a thorough analysis of its impact in
a holistic context is suggested before assessing its beneﬁts (Bai et al. 2020; Catalini
and Gans 2020).
234
M. C. Castillo and I. N. Corti
2.2
The Application of Blockchain in Public Administration
The emergence of BC, initially linked to Bitcoin, has spawned an innovative
ecosystem that transcends the ﬁnancial sphere (Tapscott and Tapscott 2016) and
extends to diverse sectors such as agriculture and education (Swan 2015). In the ﬁeld
of PA, the implementation of BC technology stands as a tool aimed at improving
management efﬁciency, promoting increased trust, reducing corruption, and safe-
guarding transparency in processes. This adoption of BC is positioned as a crucial
lever of change for the so- called “New Public Governance”. This innovative manage-
ment approach in the PA, oriented towards a more decentralised perspective, boosts
aspects such as transparency, citizen participation, service quality and innovation
(Brinkmann 2021). In the context of BC, governance is understood as the processes
of directing, controlling, and coordinating stakeholders in a BC project (Pelt et al.
2021). As we will see, different forms of governance include the management of the
BC and its use in decision making through smart contracts and automated algorithms
(De Filippi and Loveluck 2016). A tool whose use enables the creation of digital iden-
tities (Abdul Bujang et al. 2020) facilitating interaction with public records (Maza
2019). In addition, it is effectively applied in real estate registration (Akhmetbek and
Špaček 2021), land registry (Shahaab et al. 2023) as well as in the improvement of
judicial, ﬁscal, commercial and basic service processes (Lu et al. 2020). Technology
also plays an essential role in the efﬁcient allocation of resources (Zhu 2022) among
other uses.
The application of BC in PA has triggered new lines of research focused on
assessing the characteristics necessary for its proper functioning in the public
sphere (Cagigas et al. 2022). Its essential characteristics such as traceability,
immutability, and decentralisation, as we will see, offer opportunities to transform
public management, improving transparency and efﬁciency.
3
The Impact of Blockchain on Sustainability
Concerns associated with the implementation of BC in institutions address not only
high costs or development risk, but also technical and ethical concerns, especially
in sustainability (Bai and Sarkis 2017). Although it is still in early development and
requires empirical testing to demonstrate its future scalability (Aldieri et al. 2021) BC
is presented as a lever to achieve the SDGs, especially those with an environmental
focus (Parmentola et al. 2022). A detailed exploration of the essential qualities of BC
technology opens the door to a new perspective on public management, boosting the
transparency and efﬁciency of processes. In particular, a comprehensive literature
review has been carried out in order to delineate the advantages and challenges of
this technology in the framework of PA. This review covers various academic sources
and specialised studies, with the aim of providing a comprehensive overview of the
various ways in which BC has been implemented in administrative environments. A
The Use of Blockchain in Public Administration: A Transformative …
235
structured summary of key ﬁndings is then developed, highlighting speciﬁc use cases,
identiﬁed beneﬁts and potential associated challenges. This compilation is presented
as a valuable tool for understanding and analysing the diversity of BC applications
in PA, providing a solid basis for future research and strategic decisions.
3.1
Blockchain´s Positive Impact on Sustainability in Public
Administration
In today’s digital era, the PA is facing an increasing need to adopt innovative technolo-
gies that improve efﬁciency, transparency, and security in data and process manage-
ment. The main advantages reported in the current literature regarding the application
of BC in PA are the following (Fig. 1):
Starting with traceability, as the ﬁrst outstanding advantage of the use of BC
in PA, it is revealed as a fundamental pillar to strengthen transparency and trust
in government management (Shava and Mhlanga 2023). Each transaction recorded
on the BC is meticulously veriﬁed and publicly accessible to all nodes, allowing
for detailed tracking of items from their point of origin to their ﬁnal destination
(Zhu 2022). This process not only safeguards the integrity of information along the
Advantages
Traceability

automation

Fig. 1 Main advantages of BC application in PA
236
M. C. Castillo and I. N. Corti
entire journey, but also encourages greater citizen participation (Engin and Treleaven
2019) by providing citizens with the ability to clearly visualise and understand the
ﬂow of government transactions (Brinkmann 2021). The public BC is fully acces-
sible and any node could trace any transaction, presenting a high potential for data
auditability (Cagigas et al. 2022; Elisa et al. 2023; Iftekhar et al. 2021). This trans-
parency contributes to increasing the legitimacy of PA and institutional control,
creating an environment for more effective accountability, and strengthening trust in
governmental institutions (Akhmetbek and Špaček 2021). Blockchain’s traceability
capability not only enhances efﬁciency in resource management and waste preven-
tion but also contributes to product and service traceability, crucial for ensuring
sustainability in government supply chains, such as food procurement or material
management.
The impossibility of modifying the data incorporated in the chain is reﬂected in
the advantage of immutability, and translates into a solid guarantee of integrity and
authenticity (Viano et al. 2022). In the BC platform, although it is true that once
a transaction has been carried out, it is impossible to reverse it, posing a potential
barrier to adapting the use of BCs to real changes in transactions (Sharma et al. 2023).
However, this feature becomes an advantage by providing an additional level of secu-
rity, as it eliminates the possibility of malicious alterations or fraud (Shahaab et al.
2023). Historical information remains intact, supporting the integrity of transactions
and building conﬁdence in the reliability of the system. The immutability of data
in BC ensures the integrity and transparency of governmental records, essential for
regulatory compliance and accountability in implementing sustainability measures.
Traceability and immutability closely linked to governance. The possible lack of
clear leadership in the PA (Sharma et al. 2023) can be addressed through the imple-
mentation of more transparent and participatory governance structures, which foster
effective collaboration and coordination of all stakeholders (Bodó and Janssen 2022;
Zhu 2022). To this end, BC enables the establishment of a shared and secure plat-
form for data sharing, collaboration, and innovation, thus enhancing interoperability
and efﬁciency in government management (Brinkmann 2021). The introduction of
BC also provides the opportunity to address the competing interests of each party,
avoiding potential trade-offs associated with the implementation of emerging tech-
nologies (Bodó and Janssen 2022) through consensus-building and agreements that
beneﬁt all actors involved (Elisa et al. 2023). Furthermore, it can be a valuable tool
for increasing transparency and combating corruption in PA, promoting more ethical
and accountable governance (Engin and Treleaven 2019). While it is true, potential
anti-corruption use will depend on the strength of policies, infrastructure, laws, and
socio-economic factors (Adam and Fazekas 2021).
The fourth advantage we will explore is decentralisation representing a paradigm
shift in the way government data is managed, from creating a self-sovereign iden-
tity (Schulz et al. 2020). The complexity associated with inserting unauthorised
changes to the BC, due to the distribution of information across different nodes,
provides an additional layer of security and immutability of data (Bachynskyy and
Radeiko 2019). This decentralised nature not only makes it difﬁcult to manipulate
information, but also eliminates the need for intermediaries (Kuo and Shyu 2021)
The Use of Blockchain in Public Administration: A Transformative …
237
establishing an environment of institutional trust and reliability. In turn, it encourages
cooperative socio-economic interactions (Viano et al. 2022) reducing intermediate
costs (Brinkmann 2021; Elisa et al. 2023; Iftekhar et al. 2021; Glavantis 2020).
While it is true that challenges and obstacles may arise in relation to the involve-
ment of multiple nodes. The absence of a single administrator creates risks both
for the functioning of the system and for the determination of legal issues such as
the deﬁnition of jurisdiction for the resolution of disputes related to the use of BCs
(Bachynskyy and Radeiko 2019). In turn, the slower the nodes will be to validate
and agree on transactions, the greater the number of participants, including an added
difﬁculty in relation to possible negative attitudes of miners such as possible selﬁsh
behaviour (Akhmetbek and Špaček 2021). However, despite these potential difﬁcul-
ties, decentralisation is presented as an advantage as it is understood that resistance
to corruption, fraud and manipulation is strengthened by requiring the unanimous
consensus of the nodes for the incorporation of changes in the BC. The inherent
decentralisation and transparency of BC can enhance public governance by fostering
more active citizen participation in decision-making and oversight of sustainability
policies.
In turn, the implementation of cryptography not only makes information manip-
ulation more difﬁcult, but also ensures the integrity and security of data through
timestamps and cryptographic signatures on each transaction (Shahaab et al. 2023).
This feature brings multiple beneﬁts for the PA. Firstly, there is a noticeable increase
in the security of government servers, providing an additional barrier against possible
cyber-attacks (Bachynskyy and Radeiko 2019) although ensuring security is no easy
task (Maza 2019). In addition, the use of cryptography contributes to increased
privacy protection, as each transaction has a digital identiﬁcation that ensures the
conﬁdentiality of personal data (Schulz et al. 2020). Veriﬁcation of information
ownership and resistance to malicious behaviour, such as spam, are strengthened,
promoting higher data integrity and data quality (Cirillo et al. 2022). At the same
time, BC uses hash functions, Merkle trees and digital signatures to strengthen secu-
rity, which means that, overall, less than one third of nodes are successfully attacked
(Zhang et al. 2022). Blockchain’s cryptographic security strengthens trust in govern-
mental processes and data, crucial for the effective implementation of sustainability
and transparency policies in resource management.
Sixth, the automation of processes that BC enables, especially through smart
contracts, represents a signiﬁcant advance in the efﬁciency and agility of processes
in PA (Fiorentino and Bartolucci 2021). Based on smart contracts, BC can establish
automatic processing mechanisms through procedures, as well as establish govern-
mental data sharing mechanisms with clear responsibilities and control (Zhang et al.
2022). The ability to automate government processes not only reduces the need for
intermediaries, but also minimises possible errors and optimises various interactions
with the administration (Zhu 2022). This provides easier and faster access to informa-
tion, allowing transactions to be executed immediately and services to be available
24/7 (Vrabie 2023). The standardisation and streamlining of interactions with the
PA also results in a de-bureaucratisation of it (Bachynskyy and Radeiko 2019) a
reduction in operational costs and a signiﬁcant decrease in human error (Cagigas
238
M. C. Castillo and I. N. Corti
et al. 2022). Process automation through smart contracts not only improves oper-
ational efﬁciency but also can reduce resource consumption and associated costs,
thus promoting ﬁnancial and environmental sustainability in administrative activi-
ties. Improved process efﬁciency by reducing redundant constructions and applying
the principle of “submit only once” (Brinkmann 2021) contributes to the social value
and well-being of citizens by simplifying procedures and channeling information
more efﬁciently.
Finally, the integration of BC technology in the PA, from an innovation perspec-
tive, opens up a wide range of beneﬁts beyond operational efﬁciency. The introduc-
tion of BC creates an enabling environment for the development and maintenance of
innovative technologies. It facilitates a more efﬁcient dialogue between the PA, busi-
nesses and citizens, promoting collaboration and interoperability between different
governmental departments (Rukanova et al. 2023). In addition, it provides concrete
support for climate action and the mobilisation of green ﬁnance by improving moni-
toring and providing data for reporting (Schulz et al. 2020). It also stimulates social
and economic innovation by making use of this technology in the framework of Big
Data and predictive analytics for public policy development (Engin and Treleaven
2019). An example of this can be found in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic.
It is observed that this technology accelerates the achievement of the SDGs related
to health (SDG 3) and the reduction of inequalities (SDG 10) (Calandra et al. 2023).
The traceability provided by BC creates a health ecosystem that integrates clinical,
organisational, and managerial outcomes, reducing fraud and improving governance
(Cerchione et al. 2023).
Finally, different authors claim that the use of BC can also accelerate economic
development (Metechko and Sorokin 2023) and foster the search for new service
delivery models in the framework of innovative solutions, although their implemen-
tation is still in its infancy (Grover et al. 2019).
3.2
Evaluating Sustainability Challenges of Blockchain
in Public Administration
Although BC has attracted attention as an innovative tool with the potential to
transform PA, its implementation also poses challenges that need to be carefully
considered. Blockchain technology has the potential to transform PA by stream-
lining processes, increasing transparency, and reducing costs (Aburumman et al.
2020; Dziundziuk 2022). However, its implementation is hindered by several limi-
tations. These include security and privacy concerns, the need for changes in admin-
istrative processes, and the lack of effective governance models (Aburumman et al.
2020; Dziundziuk 2022). Furthermore, the lack of understanding of the technology’s
beneﬁts and the legal and regulatory environment also pose signiﬁcant barriers
(Dziundziuk 2022). The main challenges reported in the literature are the following
(Fig. 2):

Fig. 2 Main challenges of BC application in PA
The implementation of large-scale BC requires signiﬁcant investment in infras-
tructure and training (Shahaab et al. 2023). This additional resource demand may be
prohibitive for some organisations or government entities seeking to adopt this tech-
nology on a large scale. In turn, the immaturity of BC technology also contributes
to the difﬁculty in scalability (Brinkmann 2021). This disadvantage can hinder
the widespread adoption of sustainable practices and technologies within govern-
mental operations, limiting the potential impact on resource management and envi-
ronmental conservation efforts. As this technology evolves and grows, the lack of
clear standards and mature solutions (Sharma et al. 2023) may limit its ability to efﬁ-
ciently handle large numbers of simultaneous transactions. This could lead to delays,
network congestion and affect the speed and efﬁciency of the system in high-demand
situations.
Numerous authors highlight the vulnerability of the technology to security
threats as one of the main challenges of BC. The loss of private keys on the BC plat-
form represents a threat with permanent consequences on the access to the ownership
of the corresponding blocks (Akhmetbek and Špaček 2021). In turn, in the context
of private BC, which require permissions and have a smaller number of nodes, they
may also be more vulnerable from a security point of view with the understanding
that trust in the chain increases when the number of nodes increases (Maza 2019).
The limited number of nodes may increase the risk of malicious attacks, as there
240
M. C. Castillo and I. N. Corti
are fewer checkpoints and validation points compared to larger, decentralised BCs.
Privacy leaks represent another vulnerability in BC security. Although the BC is
designed to be transparent and secure, improper exposure of sensitive information
can compromise the privacy of users and transactions (Brinkmann 2021). Moreover,
the possibility of collaborating with entities without international legitimacy adds an
additional layer of risk. The lack of clear regulations and international standards may
allow unauthorised actors to participate (Rukanova et al. 2023) which could compro-
mise the integrity and security of the platform (Maza 2019). Finally, the security of
information in BC transactions also depends on the constant updating of software
products (Metechko and Sorokin 2023). The need to keep systems up-to-date to
address potential vulnerabilities and security threats highlights the importance of
continuous security management.
A third disadvantage of the application of BC in PA centers on data manage-
ment. The presence of inaccurate or untruthful original data represents a potential
threat to the efﬁciency of the BC. Inaccuracy in the initial data can compromise
the validity and accuracy of the transactions recorded in the chain (Maza 2019).
The impossibility of verifying the validity of the will of the parties to the trans-
action adds complexity to data management in the BC (Shahaab et al. 2023). The
potential for corruptibility in data management within BC systems raises concerns
about the integrity and accuracy of government records, undermining transparency
and accountability in sustainability initiatives (Sousa 2023). The lack of effective
mechanisms to ensure the authenticity of transactions can undermine trust in the
platform (Bachynskyy and Radeiko 2019). On a second point, the lack of adequate
incentives for companies to voluntarily share their data may limit the availability of
valuable information on the BC (Shahaab et al. 2023). On a ﬁnal point in the data
management framework, the anonymity status of users on the BC, while it may be
beneﬁcial in terms of privacy, makes it difﬁcult to know their identity (Metechko and
Sorokin 2023). The challenge of aligning the identity management scheme with the
Public Key Infrastructure and Qualiﬁed Digital Certiﬁcates issued by Qualiﬁed Trust
Service Providers highlights the need for effective coordination between different
systems and standards (Turkanovic and Podgorelec 2020).
The structure of BC is complex, which can lead to difﬁcult initial adoption of BC.
Funding for widespread adoption is an initial obstacle. Lack of sufﬁcient ﬁnancial
resources may limit the government’s ability to effectively implement and scale up
BC projects (Shava and Mhlanga 2023). In this context, weak government internal
control systems may hinder the effective adoption of BC (Shava and Mhlanga 2023).
It is therefore essential to strengthen government intermediaries to ensure robust
and efﬁcient implementation. At the same time, the high costs of setting up the
BC system also represent a signiﬁcant challenge. It is necessary to have available
hardware and trusted IT infrastructures, e.g. with the guarantee that a backup key
EK (Goldsmith et al. 2022). The need for technical experts to set up and maintain
the necessary technology infrastructure can generate additional costs (Viano et al.
2022). Limited previous experience with BC implementations in PA, which are often
in pilot or proof-of-concept stages, may limit the availability of good practices and
lessons learned (Brinkmann 2021). High barriers to initial adoption, combined with
The Use of Blockchain in Public Administration: A Transformative …
241
resistance to change by interest groups, may impede the implementation of innovative
and sustainable solutions in PA, slowing progress towards achieving environmental
sustainability goals.
In relation to this we encounter a potential barrier in relation to accessibility
Internet connectivity is highlighted as a fundamental requirement for the effective
implementation of BC (Adam and Fazekas 2021). At the same time, the availability
of power supplies is another challenge, especially in regions with limited infras-
tructure. It further exacerbates inequalities in access to sustainable governance prac-
tices, potentially marginalizing certain groups from participating in decision-making
processes related to environmental conservation and resource management. Linked
to this, the need for broadband is related to the speed and efﬁciency of transactions,
making the lack of communications infrastructure an obstacle to the effective imple-
mentation of BC (Shava and Mhlanga 2023). The digital divide highlights the impor-
tance of addressing inequality in access to technology (Viano et al. 2022). Addressing
this challenge involves investments in the development of robust and reliable commu-
nication infrastructures and implementing inclusive policies and technology training
programs (Schulz et al. 2020).
Undoubtedly, the application of BC technology has a human component with the
possibility of having behaviours of resistance to change that must be taken into
account for a correct application. Lack of knowledge about BC and its applications
in PA can generate reluctance and mistrust among community members (Rukanova
et al. 2023). In particular, the lack of training in BC among public ofﬁcials and citizens
(Adam and Fazekas 2021). In turn, concerns about job cuts, the tendency to cling
to traditional continuous processes, or the perception of excessive visibility of their
work management due to traceability of BC, are examples of resistances (Cagigas
et al. 2022). However, it can be proactively addressed by reorienting and training
employees to adapt to new roles and responsibilities generated by technology.
A next disadvantage focuses on the regulatory framework. The implementation
of BC in the PA clashes with the current legislative structure, so an assessment
of its modiﬁcation is needed to adapt to new technological realities. For example,
the incompatibility of BC with the “right to be forgotten”, due to its immutable
nature, raises concerns about privacy and data security (Maza 2019). The ease of
tracing vulnerable data without the consent of the data subject highlights the need
to address these critical issues in relation to the management of personal and sensi-
tive data. On a second point, although the wallet does not present data protection
concerns by storing only the necessary data, the BC may generate conﬂicts with
data protection laws by not attributing direct responsibility to any data subject over
them (Viano et al. 2022). In this area, smart contracts present difﬁculties, such as
the expression of content using provisions that require human judgement, the depen-
dence on external sources of information and the difﬁculty in amending them once
they have been encoded (Maza 2019). The lack of regulatory regulation surrounding
BC leaves room for security threats and vulnerabilities, posing risks to the conﬁden-
tiality and integrity of sensitive governmental data, thereby undermining efforts to
ensure sustainable and responsible governance practices. These challenges highlight
242
M. C. Castillo and I. N. Corti
the need to develop regulations that address speciﬁc aspects of smart contracts and
provide a clear framework for their implementation.
Finally, the intersection between sustainability and innovation in the context of
the BC chain provides opportunities, but also signiﬁcant challenges. The associated
high energy costs, especially in public BC, raise signiﬁcant environmental concerns.
Inaddition,theyhighlightlimitedinnovativecapabilitiesforattractingcompaniesand
stakeholders to government to lead the delivery of public services through BC. The
Jevons Paradox, which suggests that improvements in efﬁciency and technology can
result in an overall increase in consumption, adds an additional layer of complexity
(Vrabie 2023). The system’s ease of use and speed of response can generate higher
demand, offsetting the savings from increased efﬁciency and creating a cycle of
increased consumption. The environmental impact of BC, particularly its energy-
intensive mining processes, raises concerns about its sustainability credentials and
its compatibility with broader environmental conservation objectives.
Despite these challenges, the successful development of blockchain-based
systems can lead to signiﬁcant cost savings and increased trust in public institutions
(Dziundziuk 2022). The identiﬁed disadvantages of BC in PA present signiﬁcant
challenges to achieving sustainability goals, necessitating careful consideration and
mitigation strategies to ensure BC can effectively support sustainable governance
practices and environmental conservation efforts.
4
Conclusions
In the course of this comprehensive literature review, the impact in sustainability
of BC on PA has been explored in depth, assessing in detail its pre-eminent advan-
tages and challenges. First of all, the inherent traceability provided by blockchain
technology enhances efﬁciency in resource management and product/service tracing,
essential for governance practices that prioritize long-term sustainability. Addition-
ally, the security guaranteed by cryptographic measures within BC instills trust in
processes overseen by authorities, a critical component for implementing policies
focused on transparency and enduring viability. Cybersecurity, in constant evolution,
persists as a critical research domain, focusing on the identiﬁcation of vulnerabilities
and the development of strategies aimed at safeguarding data integrity in the dynamic
BC environment. Furthermore, the automation of procedures through smart contracts
enhances operational efﬁciency and promotes economic and ecological resilience.
The reliable nature of data ensures integrity and transparency in government docu-
ments, crucial for regulatory compliance and responsible sustainability efforts. The
decentralized nature and transparency facilitated by BC foster citizen engagement
in decision-making processes, thus advancing governance with a sustainable focus.
On the ethical and social level, assessing the impact of BC on PA, considering facets
such as privacy, equitable access and ethics in the use of technology, is a key area of
research.
The Use of Blockchain in Public Administration: A Transformative …
243
Inconclusion,thesigniﬁcanceofintegratingsustainabilityresearchintotheeduca-
tion and training of government ofﬁcials in BC is underscored as a critical element to
bridge the knowledge gap and enable effective utilization of this technology within
PA. However, several substantial challenges have been identiﬁed that require focused
attention to optimize the effectiveness of BC implementation in government settings.
Future research on blockchain technology’s impact on sustainability in PA should
prioritize critical areas such as scalability, regulatory frameworks, environmental
impact, and standards for governmental use.
Investigating scalable solutions tailored for government operations can address
limitations and promote sustainable practices. Understanding regulatory needs is
crucial for ensuring security and data integrity. Longitudinal studies on environ-
mental impact are essential for informing mitigation strategies while maintaining
blockchain’s sustainability. Establishing standards for governmental BC use is vital
for safeguarding data security and promoting interoperability. Moreover, enhancing
accessibility and inclusiveness in decision-making activities can further support
sustainability efforts.
Cross-disciplinary collaborations among scholars, policymakers, and stake-
holders are indispensable for advancing understanding and implementing sustainable
governance practices in response to sustainable challenges.
