The Mediating Effect of Perceived
Persuasiveness on the Relationship
Between Gamiﬁed Reward in Ant Forest
and User’s Sustainable Behaviour
in China
Miao Huang, Mohamad Saifudin Mohamad Saleh, Izzal Asnira Zolkepli,
and Lei Wang
Abstract Gamiﬁcation is frequently used as a standard design module in creating
mobile applications. Gamiﬁed rewards are the one of the most effective in gamiﬁ-
cation elements in inﬂuencing users’ sustainable behaviour. Ant Forest, a Chinese
sustainable mobile application, encourages users to develop sustainable behaviours
in exchange for virtual and real rewards. Consequently, this study investigates the
perceived persuasiveness mediating effect in the relationship between gamiﬁed
reward in Ant Forest and users’ sustainable behaviour in China. This study ﬁlls
the gap by focusing on the inﬂuence of gamiﬁed reward and perceived persuasive-
ness on users’ sustainable behaviour with the Stimuli-Organism-Response Theory.
This study applied a survey technique with 621 samples of Ant Forest users across
China with stratiﬁed proportional sampling. The ﬁndings show that the gamiﬁed
reward in Ant Forest positively and strongly inﬂuences the perceived persuasiveness
on user. Simultaneously, perceived persuasiveness is a complementary partial medi-
ating effect on the relationship between gamiﬁed reward and sustainable behaviour.
These ﬁndings reasonably explain the mechanism of gamiﬁed reward and perceived
persuasiveness. It also demonstrates the importance of increasing gamiﬁed rewards to
improvetheperceivedpersuasiveness of mobileapplications andpromotesustainable
behaviours of users.
Keywords Gamiﬁcation · Reward · Perceived persuasiveness · Sustainable
behaviour · Ant forest · Stimuli-organism-response theory
M. Huang · M. S. Mohamad Saleh (B) · I. A. Zolkepli
School of Communication, Universiti Sains Malaysia, George Town, Malaysia
e-mail: saifudinsaleh@usm.my
M. Huang · L. Wang
School of Animation and Digital Arts, Communication University of China, Beijing, Nanjing,

248
M. Huang et al.
1
Sustainability Issues Caused by Vegetation Degradation
Climatechangeandthedynamicresponseofvegetationcausedbyitaretheecosystem
functions that affect the sustainable development of human beings (Afuye et al.
2021). Climate, water, and vegetation, as important factors affecting soil, are being
seriously threatened by soil degradation caused by population increase, improvement
of living standards and scarcity of natural resources (Lal 2020). Global sustainable
development faces the problem of land degradation, especially in desert areas (Zhang
et al. 2021a, b). Data show that more than 75% of land is being degraded, and it is
expected to rise to 90% by 2050, affecting billions of people (Zhang et al. 2021a, b).
As a core element of the land, soil is responsible for more than a quarter of all
greenhouse gas emissions in agricultural and forestry applications and is also under
enormous pressure from rising temperatures, prolonged droughts, and ﬂooding (Leal
Filho et al. 2023). China’s industrial and agricultural output has increased substan-
tially over the past century, but at the expense of ecosystem beneﬁts, resulting in
problems such as ﬂooding, water pollution, climate imbalance, and decline in biolog-
ical species (Zheng et al. 2019). For example, the typical loess area in northern China
has severe and large-scale landslides due to rapid urban expansion and vegetation
reduction, making it an area with frequent geological disasters in China (Juang et al.
2019).
According to 2019 data, China’s carbon dioxide emissions accounted for 28% of
global emissions, making it the world’s largest carbon dioxide emitter (Friedlingstein
et al. 2020). Over the past decade, the continuous ups and downs in carbon emis-
sions indicate that long-term emission reduction remains a major challenge for the
Chinese government (Shan et al. 2020). In this context, the Chinese government is
actively investing in ecological restoration, deepening people’s cognition of nature,
and promoting the harmonious development of man and nature through classiﬁcation,
coordination, and integration.
The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) provide an impor-
tant framework for China to reverse land degradation, which restores land observ-
able indicators through sustainable land management and restoration of land cover
(Sims et al. 2019). Among the monitoring indicators set for this purpose, vegetation
productivity is considered a mature indicator, which requires not only attention to the
physiological processes of plants, but also careful analysis of the factors considered
to inﬂuence it (Prince 2019).
2
Ant Forest Restore Vegetation Through Fintech
Technological, ﬁnancial companies (Fintech) manage many users with high efﬁ-
ciency and low cost through cloud services, artiﬁcial intelligence, and big data tech-
nologies, improve resource utilization efﬁciency, and reduce carbon emissions and
environmental pollution (Mi and Coffman 2019). Ant Forest is a green gamiﬁcation
The Mediating Effect of Perceived Persuasiveness on the Relationship …
249
module launched by Alipay, one of China’s largest digital payment platforms (Wang
et al. 2022a, b). Furthermore, Alipay is an outstanding representative of Fintech in
China (Zhang et al. 2021a, b). Ant Forest allows users to participate in green actions
by promoting users’ intrinsic motivation (social interaction, enjoyment, achieve-
ment, mutual assistance) and extrinsic motivation (reward, competition, cooperation)
(Wang et al. 2022a, b).
Ant Forest creates a carbon account for each user and encourages users to convert
low-carbon behaviours (such as walking, paying online, using public transportation
and using shared bicycles) into virtual gamiﬁed rewards (Ashfaq et al. 2021). When
the virtual rewards in the user’s carbon account reach a certain value, Ant Forest will
redeemarealplantfortheuserandplantitinthedesertedareasthatneedtoberestored
to green (Ashfaq et al. 2021). As of the end of May 2020, Ant Forest has gathered 550
million users who are keen to practice pro-environmental behaviours and has planted
more than 200 million plants in desert areas, which has made a positive contribution
to China’s low-carbon goals (Zhang et al. 2022). Ant Forest has cultivated many
online green users through digital technology (Chen et al. 2020). These users are
satisﬁed through the entertainment function of Ant Forest, which makes their social
motivation positively correlated with environmental awareness (Chen et al. 2020).
Therefore, analyzing Ant Forest users’ feelings and attitudes towards game functions
is extremely important for gaining insight into users’ motivations for sustainable
behaviours (Ashfaq et al. 2021).
3
The Role of Gamiﬁcation in Ant Forest
Using gamiﬁcation to stimulate users to promote their behaviour has become a new
research ﬁeld, which is extremely important for increasing potential users for the
platform and motivating their willingness to protect the environment (Xiong et al.
2022). Gamiﬁcation refers to using game elements in non-game contexts to achieve
individual or group goals. It can also be called a “serious game”, and has devel-
oped a practical, systematic theory (Krath et al. 2021). Ant Forest combines people’s
sustainablelifestylewithreal-worldafforestationthroughavirtualgamiﬁcationexpe-
rience, which motivates the public to participate in sustainable behaviour (Mi et al.
2021). The gamiﬁcation elements of Ant Forest can be divided into four categories:
rewards, feedback, task design and social interaction (Wang and Yao 2020). Among
them, reward elements represented by virtual medals and ofﬁcial certiﬁcates are
most recognised by users (Wang and Yao 2020). Gamiﬁcation incentives are used to
provide feedback on the participation of Ant Forest users so that they can accurately
record the results of behavioural efforts (Yang & Cai, 2019).
The success of Ant Forest is due to the rapid development of China’s social
economy and mobile Internet technology (Chen and Cai 2019). Its gamiﬁcation
and participatory communication practice integrates mobile media technology and
public power, resulting in a good user experience and effective persuasive effect
(Chen and Cai 2019). Ant Forest integrates gamiﬁcation functions to build a new
250
M. Huang et al.
persuasive system (Sun and Xing 2022). Its advantage lies in the combination of
game elements and persuasive functions, which makes the gamiﬁcation persuasive
system more interesting and immersive than traditional ones (Sun and Xing 2022).
The persuasive system of Ant Forest has the attributes of both gamiﬁcation and social
media (Yang et al. 2018). Task support, perceived credibility, and perceived social
support affect perceived persuasiveness, sense of accomplishment, and perceived
entertainment, ultimately affecting users’ continuous usage intentions (Yang et al.
2018).
4
Application of the Stimuli-Organism-Response Theory
in Gamiﬁcation Research
In order to study how the gamiﬁcation reward elements in Ant Forest affect the
sustainable behaviour of users, this study plans to use The Stimuli-Organism-
Response Theory to research this process. The Stimuli-Organism-Response Theory,
often referred to simply as the S-O-R Theory, is often used to study how people’s
motivation and behaviour are affected by external stimuli (Goi et al. 2014; Vieira
2013).TheS-O-RTheorywasproposedbyMehrabianandRussell(1974)andusually
included three variables: (1) Stimulus (S) for the predictor variable, (2) Organism (O)
for the intervening variable, and (3) Response (R) for the outcome variable (Vieira
2013).
In order to correspond to the theoretical framework of the S-O-R Theory, this
study sets the gamiﬁed reward as the predictor variable (Stimulus) (Tak and Gupta
2021). Research by Tak and Gupta (2021) shows that adding reward elements to
applications can stimulate users to respond and excite them. The perceived persua-
siveness is the intervening variable (Organism) (Gao et al. 2021). In this study, the
perceived persuasiveness can be understood as the approximate effect of the human
individual sensing the effectiveness of external interventions (Thomas et al. 2019).
Theperceivedpersuasivenesscanalsobefurtherinterpretedastheeffectofthehuman
individual feeling the interactive system and changing their behaviour (Oyibo and
Morita 2022). The sustainable behaviour is the outcome variable (Response) (Pili-
grimienė et al. 2020). Sustainable behaviour is the user’s response to external stimuli
and self-identity (Lavuri et al. 2023). The research on sustainable behaviour as the
response is a common application context of the S-O-R Theory (Busalim et al. 2022).
Therefore, after substituting the variables into the theoretical framework of the
S-O-R Theory, this study determined the theoretical framework (Fig. 1).
The study by Orji et al. (2019) selected ten persuasion strategies, including
rewards, and proved that rewards provide persuasiveness by increasing users’ satis-
faction (especially men) with signiﬁcant effects. This view is also supported by
Cemiloglu et al. (2023), who also pointed out that users have the highest sensitivity
to in-game rewards among all persuasive design techniques. Therefore, this study
hypothesised as follows:
The Mediating Effect of Perceived Persuasiveness on the Relationship …
251
Fig. 1 Theoretical framework of this study
H1. The gamiﬁed reward positively inﬂuences the perceived persuasiveness on
user in Ant Forest.
Persuasive systems can evoke users’ behavioural changes to achieve desired objec-
tives, such as increasing user loyalty, health awareness, or sustainable behaviour
(Shevchuk and Oinas-Kukkonen 2019). Applying persuasive technology to e-
learning management systems can encourage positive learning behaviours and thus
change students’ study habits (Ahmad et al. 2022). Therefore, this study hypothesised
as follows:
H2. The perceived persuasiveness on Ant Forest user positively inﬂuences the
user’s sustainable behaviour.
Gamiﬁed rewards based on badges and trophies can strengthen users’ acquisition of
sustainability knowledge and ultimately affect their behavioural values (Whittaker
et al. 2021). Gamiﬁed rewards can provide users with social and economic incentives,
and Ant Forest promotes users’ pro-environmental behaviour through dual incentives
(Xiong et al. 2022). Therefore, this study hypothesised as follows:
H3. The gamiﬁed reward positively inﬂuences the user’s sustainable behaviour
through Ant Forest.
Gamiﬁed persuasive systems are very effective in motivating user behavioural
change, and these systems are often designed to use rewards and punishments to
achieve the desired effects (Orji et al. 2023). Gamiﬁcation can trigger a state of deep
interaction between users and the information system, making users feel the persua-
siveness of the gamiﬁcation persuasive system, resulting in behavioural changes
(Shevchuk et al. 2019). Therefore, this study hypothesised as follows:
H4. The perceived persuasiveness on Ant Forest user mediates the relationship
between the gamiﬁed reward and the user’s sustainable behaviour.
252
M. Huang et al.
5
Research Design
This study used the research method of quantitative survey with Wenjuanxing, the
largest online questionnaire platform in China, to make an online questionnaire to
collect survey data (Zhang et al. 2020). After the online questionnaire was designed,
it was distributed and collected in the online community of Ant Forest users through
two common instant messaging applications in China, QQ and WeChat (Zhang et al.
2020).AntForesthasmorethan500millionusersacrossChina(Wangetal.2022a,b),
so this study applied a sampling formula (n = z2σ2/e2) suitable for a large population
(Leavy 2022). By calculating the formula, this study’s minimum number of samples
was determined to be 505 to ensure a 95% signiﬁcance level and 15% acceptable
error (Leavy 2022).
As of 2019, Ant Forest has more than 500 million users in China (Mi et al. 2021),
which has led researchers to choose stratiﬁed proportional sampling to alleviate the
difﬁculties caused by the large sampling population (Sekaran and Bougie 2016). In
order to deal with the sampling problem of China’s large population and cities, this
study used the development status of Chinese cities as the stratiﬁcation basis for
sampling (Guan et al. 2019). According to Government Data (2022), the six cities of
Shanghai, Wuhan, Harbin, Lanzhou, Shuozhou, and Beihai were randomly selected
according to three different sizes (extra-large, large, and small and medium-sized)
(State Council 2014). According to the norms of stratiﬁed proportional sampling,
the researchers allocated the number of samples according to the population ratio of
each city (Sekaran and Bougie 2016).
According to the theoretical framework of this study, the researchers developed
three constructs from previous studies corresponding to the three variables. Among
them, the construct for gamiﬁed reward includes 6 items developed by Zhang et al.
(2021a, b), the construct for perceived persuasiveness includes 5 items developed by
Busch et al. (2016), and the construct for sustainable behaviour includes 5 items
developed from the research of Shaﬁei and Maleksaeidi (2020) (see Appendix
1). Considering research ethics, participants will be informed about the research
overview and their rights before answering the questionnaire (Brown et al. 2022).
Participants voluntarily provide personal information, which will be treated conﬁden-
tially to protect participants’ privacy (Paulin et al. 2022). The questionnaire adopts
the ﬁve-level Likert-type scale evaluation standard (1 = Strongly Disagree, 2 =
Disagree, 3 = Neutral, 4 = Agree, 5 = Strongly Agree) (Phakiti 2020).
A total of 621 valid responses were obtained in this online questionnaire, and the
characteristics of respondents are shown in Table 1. According to the requirements of
stratiﬁed proportional sampling, the researchers controlled the proportion of respon-
dents from each city. According to the statistical results, the main users of Ant Forest
are young and middle-aged people (18–49 years old), accounting for 76.7%. Among
them, the sex ratio of men and women is roughly equal (M: F = 1.06:1), which is
also in line with the gender status of the Chinese population (Su et al. 2022).

6
Research Results
Smart-PLS software (V4.0) was used to analyze survey data for measurement and
evaluation. First, the assessment results of the measurement model were obtained
through the PLS-SEM algorithm. The results show that the outer loading of all items
254
M. Huang et al.
is higher than 0.7, representing a high degree of credibility (Nasution et al. 2020).
The values of Cronbach’s Alpha and Composite Reliability (CR) of each variable are
higher than 0.7, while the values of Average Variance Extracted (AVE) are higher
than 0.5, which means that the results of the questionnaire in this study have good
consistency and reliability (Hair et al. 2019).
Two common methods, the Heterotrait-Monotrait Ratio (HTMT) Criterion and the
Fornell & Larcker criterion, were used to evaluate the discriminant effectiveness in
this study (Afthanorhan et al. 2021). All the values in the HTMT Criterion are lower
than 0.9 (Sarstedt et al. 2021). At the same time, the square root of each variable’s
AVE in the Fornell-Larcker Criterion is greater than the correlations with other latent
variables (Hair et al. 2021). The analysis results meeting the above double standards
represent that this study has qualiﬁed discriminant validity (Sarstedt et al. 2021; Hair
et al. 2021).
The calculation function of bootstrapping resampling in the Smart-PLS software
was applied to detect hypotheses in the research study framework. The data is calcu-
lated to obtain the path coefﬁcient from the structural model (Table 2). In the data
validation of the direct effect hypothesis, the H1 on the effect of gamiﬁed reward
on perceived persuasiveness is positive and signiﬁcant (β = 0.710, p = 0.000). The
impact of perceived persuasiveness veriﬁed by H2 on sustainable behaviour is posi-
tive and signiﬁcant (β = 0.217, p = 0.000). H3, used to verify the impact of gamiﬁed
reward on sustainable behaviour, is also positive and signiﬁcant (β = 0.369, p =
0.000). In addition, the indirect effect of perceived persuasiveness as the mediator on
the relationship between gamiﬁed reward and sustainable behaviour is positive and
signiﬁcant (β = 0.154, p = 0.000), meaning that all the hypotheses of this research
have been proved to be true.
Sincetheparametersinthepathcoefﬁcientstestcanonlyrepresentthesigniﬁcance
of the effect and cannot indicate the size of the effect, this study additionally tested
the results of f 2 to judge the effect size (Hair et al. 2019). According to the standard
proposed by Cohen (2013), the effect size of H1 can be judged as large, which means
that gamiﬁed reward greatly inﬂuences perceived persuasiveness. The effect size of
H2 and H3 can be judged as small, which means that perceived persuasiveness and
gamiﬁed reward have little impact on sustainable (Table 2). The inﬂuence of the
mediating effect in H4 will be discussed separately below.
At the same time, Fig. 2 shows that the graphical structural model of this study
includes the R2 of the two dependent variables. The R2 values of perceived persua-
siveness and sustainable behaviour were lower than 0.9, maintaining a suitable ﬁt
(Hair et al. 2019). According to the standard provided by Hair et al. (2019), the
R2 (0.504) of perceived persuasiveness was judged as moderate, indicating that this
study included 50.4% of the factors affecting perceived persuasiveness. Correspond-
ingly, the R2 (0.297) of sustainable behaviour is judged as weak, which means this
study only includes 29.7% of the factors that affect sustainable behaviour (Hair et al.
2019).
In order to further determine the mediating effect of perceived persuasiveness
according to the research objectives, this study calculated according to the VAF
(Variance Accounted For), Value standard proposed by Hair Jr et al. (2017). In this

7
Discussion
First, it can be concluded that the three characteristics of Ant Forest users are high
education level, long service life and high participation through the analysis of the
characteristics of the participant’s personal information. These results are mutually
veriﬁed with the conclusions drawn by other related studies of Ant Forest, and it can
be inferred that users of Ant Forest have strong cognitive ability and enthusiasm for
participation (Ashfaq et al. 2022; Wang et al. 2022a, b; Zhang et al. 2022, 2020; Mi
et al. 2021).
Second, the gamiﬁed reward provided by Ant Forest has greatly promoted its
persuasiveness on users, which also achieved the ﬁrst research objective of this
study. In addition, gamiﬁed rewards have also proven to be a very effective stimu-
lating element that meets the criteria of the S-O-R Theory (Shankar 2022). Most Ant
Forest users are motivated by gamiﬁed rewards to continue using Ant Forest (Wang
et al. 2022a, b). This study also obtained approximate data (75% continuous usage
rate, 70% complete reward acquisition), which shows that gamiﬁed reward plays an
important role in Ant Forest. Game-based rewards play a positive role in persuasive
games, especially as physical rewards are more effective than virtual rewards (van
Dooren et al. 2019). Ant Forest also arouses environmental awareness by allowing
users to plant a real tree (Ashfaq et al. 2021). At the same time, the gamiﬁed reward
has also been proven to directly impact sustainable behaviour in Ant Forest, which
shows its importance in Ant Forest to promoting users’ sustainable behaviour. So,
the third research objective of this study has been achieved. Wang and Yao (2020)
detected that virtual rewards are the most effective gamiﬁcation elements in Ant
Forest to please users and promote their pro-environmental behaviour through the
Kano Model dedicated to game design testing. In addition, the effect of gamiﬁed
rewards is further expanded by the green advertising effect of Ant Forest so that it
can better inﬂuence the sustainable behaviour of users (Huang et al. 2023).
Third, perceived persuasiveness is an important variable because it has a signif-
icant positive impact on the sustainable behaviour of Ant Forest users. The second
research objective of this study has been achieved. The researchers pointed out that
perceived persuasiveness is the ability of human–computer interaction systems to
affect changes in user behaviour (Oyibo and Morita 2022). Therefore, this study
applies perceived persuasiveness as the Organism in the S-O-R Theory, representing
the interactive system’s effect that users can perceive as living organisms. After that,
the user’s sustainable behaviour change is used as the Response in the S-O-R Theory
to complete the entire impact process. The perceived persuasiveness of the persuasive
system can arouse user loyalty and improve user health awareness and sustainable
behaviour (Shevchuk and Oinas-Kukkonen 2019). Ant Forest integrates the above
The Mediating Effect of Perceived Persuasiveness on the Relationship …
257
elements as a reliable persuasive system to further promote the transformation of
users to a green lifestyle (Yang et al. 2018).
Fourth, the mediation effect of perceived persuasiveness has been conﬁrmed. It
can positively mediate the effect of gamiﬁed reward on sustainable behaviour, but
this effect is relatively small and partial (Hair Jr et al. 2017). Regarding the value
of the sustainable behaviour variable R2 (0.297), the inﬂuence of the variable in
this study only accounts for 29.7%, which shows that there are still other factors
at play. Persuasive systems can persuade people to make behavioural changes by
changing their perceptions, and gamiﬁcation can achieve this goal by enhancing the
persuasiveness of the system more playfully and emotionally (Wenker 2022). When
the user recognises the practicability of the system, perceived persuasiveness can
play a good intermediary role in inﬂuencing the user’s usage behaviour (Oyibo and
Vassileva 2020). In similar cases, researchers have also proved that perceived persua-
siveness can mediate the inﬂuence of internal and external factors of webcast content
on viewer behaviour (Gao et al. 2021). From a practical viewpoint, the reciprocity
and liking that gamiﬁed rewards bring users is the most effective promotion for the
inﬂuence of persuasive principles on individual behaviour (Ciocarlan et al. 2019).
8
Conclusion
This study applied the S-O-R Theory to verify the process of gamiﬁed reward
affecting users’ sustainable behaviour in Ant Forest and, at the same time, concluded
the partial mediating effect of perceived persuasiveness in this process. In addi-
tion, this study concluded that gamiﬁed rewards can play an active role as an effec-
tive Stimulus in the S-O-R Theory, which will positively affect future gamiﬁcation
research.
This study veriﬁes the impact of Ant Forest as a persuasive system on public
sustainable behaviour. Ant Forest has created a good brand image for its parent
company, gaining public recognition and enhancing its persuasiveness. A large
institution’s sustainable brand image and philosophy will promote positive public
attitudes towards the institution (Saleh et al. 2021). Therefore, this study suggests
that Ant Forest enhances its perceived persuasiveness with richer gamiﬁed rewards.
Mobile application developers can consider better integrating gamiﬁed reward into
the development company’s image promotion strategy to enhance the persuasive-
ness that the public can perceive, and use this comprehensive effect to promote the
public’s sustainable behaviour.
This study only tested the effect of gamiﬁed rewards in Ant Forest, but the gami-
ﬁcation elements of Ant Forest are not limited to rewards. In addition, the research
results of partial mediation of perceived persuasiveness and the lower R2 value indi-
cate that more elements affect users’ sustainable behaviour in the Ant Forest, which
will be a feasible research direction in the future.

The Importance of Being Returned
from Bottled Water to Tap Water
in Turkey in Terms of Sustainable
Development
Canan Karakaş Ulusoy
Abstract In Turkey after 2000s, prefering policies of aimed at boundary span-
ning of urban areas and increasing of urban population, correspondingly, passing
to supplying urban drinking water requirements from central water treatment plants
have caused to arise important problems in terms of sustainability. In spite of puri-
fying process in accordance with domestic water standards especially in the metropo-
liten cities like Ankara and Istanbul, tap water has become not to drink. So, spring
water being necessary to be strategically protected has commenced to be consumed
as a bottled water for drinking water purposes, instead of concentration on why tap
water cannot drink. Today being explicitly experienced effects of climate change any
more, it is important that tap water can become to drink again in regards to sustain-
able development. Consequently, it is necessary to study topics in terms of economic,
social, environmental, management and sustainability that whether new urban and
urban water infrastructure systems planning policies should be preferred to ensure
that the tap water quality of urban water infrastructure systems will become drinkable
standard or policies aimed at bottled water, where plastic pollution is increasing day
by day and causing serious health problems and environmental pollution, should be
preferred. Therefore, the primary purpose of this article is to evaluate how the return
of bottled water to tap water for drinking purposes can be achieved in Turkey. The
secondary purpose of the article is to reveal the importance of achieving the potability
of tap water in terms of sustainable development. In this context, a theoretical analysis
based on literature review and professional knowledge and experience is preferred
as the method in writing the article. In this connection, in the introduction section
is summarized the reasons and solutions for not drinking tap water, and revealed its
relationship with sustainable development. In the second part, methods to solve tap
water quality problems are tried to be presented as a holistic view. In the third part,
domestic water supply systems; in the fourth part, the relationship between sustain-
able development and urban tap water is discussed. It is defend that sustainable urban
water service can be only achieved through sustainable urbanization. Finally, in the

conclusion section; it has been concluded that planning the distribution of drinking
water is as important as the production of drinking water, for this, the current urban
planning approach and the existing centralized conventional water infrastructure
systems must be changed, and sustainable urban water service can be achieved by
planning a multi-centered, ﬂexible, multi-source, multi-disciplinary integrated urban
water infrastructure system based on protecting intergenerational equality, resistant
to climate change, a nature-based, nature-respecting, water-sensitive urban planning
approach.
Keywords Tap water · Bottled water · Plastic pollution · Health · Urban area ·
Sustainable development
1
Introduction
In Turkey, metropolitan municipalities and water and sewerage administrations afﬁl-
iated to this directorate are responsible for urban planning and meeting urban water
needs in metropolitan cities, and municipalities are responsible for cities without
metropolitan administration. The drinking and domestic water needs of cities are
met by central conventional urban water infrastructure systems that have been used
for more than two centuries. These systems are designed to overcome needs such as
water supply security, public health protection and ﬂood protection, emerging from
the holistic planning and design of water systems in ever-expanding urban areas to
meet changing needs in terms of public health and environmental concerns (Harald
2005; Nottarp-Heim et al. 2015).
In centralized conventional water infrastructure systems, water is transported
through the network. The water network includes water supply and distribution
systems. The task of water supply systems is to transmit raw water (taken from
dams, wells and springs) to the central drinking water treatment facility, where it is
puriﬁed through different physical, chemical and biological processes to ensure the
required quality standards. Puriﬁed water is stored in tanks used as intermediate units
to regulate daily water demand. Afterwards, it is offered for consumption through the
pipes and pump system in the water distribution systems (Der 2015). Drinking water
distribution systems are pressurized pipe networks that transmit puriﬁed drinking
water from the central treatment plant to the water meters in consumers’ buildings.
These networks consists of pipes, pumps, valves, water tanks and other hydraulic
equipment. Generally, pipes of different diameters, qualities (metal, plastic, steel,
cement) and lengths (from tens of meters to several hundred kilometers) used in the
network are buried underground (Liu et al. 2017a, b). Drinking water distribution
systems are ﬁnally connected to domestic water supply systems.
Domestic water supply systems (water installation) include the distribution
network parts connecting a house or building to the main water pipe and the pipes
within the building. They have long retention times, higher temperatures, and close
one-to-one contact with water (NRC 2006; Nguyen et al. 2012; Wang et al. 2013; Liu
The Importance of Being Returned from Bottled Water to Tap Water …
267
et al. 2017a). Distribution networks are the last barriers that protect drinking water
from pollutants during distribution. Therefore, it is directly related to the quality of
water offered for consumption (Liu et al. 2017a). However, in practice, although
puriﬁcation technologies have improved a lot and raw water is puriﬁed to drinking
water quality, it is possible that high quality puriﬁed water offered for consumption
is again contaminated in the distribution network and building installations and is
reduced to undrinkable quality. Water quality degradation can occur during trans-
portation in both distribution pipes and home or building pipes (Liu et al. 2017b).
Especially in metropolitan cities such as Ankara and Istanbul, water quality deteri-
orates again and the water ﬂowing from fountains becomes undrinkable, depending
on the distance of the houses to the treatment facility, the aging of the network
pipes, the pipe material used, the planning logic of home and building water supply
systems, the technical characteristics and aging of the materials used. For this reason,
domestic water users prefer to use domestic package puriﬁcation systems or bottled
water instead of tap water.
Bottledwateristhoughttobehealthierandmorehygienicthantapwater.However,
many studies have proven that bottled water is more unhealthy than tap water. For
example; water samples in single-use (PET) bottles of six different brands produced
and sold locally were examined, and the presence of microplastics was detected in all
analyzed samples. As a result of the analysis, a total of 207 microplastics were found
in 36 samples (Yozukmaz 2022). Another study stated that plastic bottle waters may
contain high levels of endocrine disruptors and microplastics (Villanuva et al. 2021;
Gambino et al. 2022). It is seen that microplastics not only harm human health, but
also cause serious environmental pollution (Rhodes 2018; Baran 2020; Guo et al.
2021; Luqman et al. 2021). In addition, when considering the road routes and annual
trip numbers of the vehicles used to convey water from strategically protected spring
water to bottling facilities, from there to distribute bottled water to markets or bottle
distribution ofﬁces in all cities and then to residences and workplaces; the use of fossil
fuels, contrary to greenhouse gas emissions reduction policies, and the resulting air
pollution and energy consumption is not a sustainable policy in terms of drinking
water supply and quality. So, determining the reasons for the deterioration of the
quality of water in the network and ﬁnding solutions to ensure the return of bottled
water to mains water, the effectiveness and efﬁciency of drinking water infrastructure
systems are extremely important and necessary in terms of drinking water quality,
safety, public health and sustainable development.
Since sustainable development is the total result of economic, social and environ-
mental sustainability achieved in each sector separately, it is extremely important for
the total sustainable development that urban water service, in particular, is econom-
ically, socially and environmentally sustainable. For this reason, many studies have
been carried out and continue to be carried out to ensure that water ﬂows continuously
and in potable quality from fountains and to provide urban drinking water service
in a sustainable manner (Brown and Farelly 2009; Brown et al. 2009; Makropoulos
et al. 2012; Marques and Leeuwen 2012; BrattebØ et al. 2013; Alegre and Covas
2015; Ingemarsson et al. 2022; Bilalova et al. 2023).
268
C. Karakaş Ulusoy
2
Methods for Troubleshooting Tap Water Quality
Problems
Tap water quality in urban water infrastructure systems, depending on the raw
water quality, treatment processes, disinfectant substances, pipe material used in
the distribution network, pipe aging and loss-leakage, in-pipe hydraulic water pres-
sure changes, in-pipe water temperature, and the time the water stays in the network,
developing bioﬁlm, free sediment and encrusting substances remixed into water and
in relation to the characteristics of domestic water supply systems can be deteriorated.
Because; in drinking water supply, not only production but also distribution is
very important. The quality of tap water can be as good as the conditions of the pipe
through which it ﬂows (Liu et al. 2017a). Drinking water distribution networks can
act as biological and physicochemical reactors that change and reduce water quality
during water transmission (Fish et al. 2017). Of course, risks and uncertainties are
inevitable factors in drinking water supply and sanitation (Savic 2005). However,
drinking water distribution systems are critical for maintaining the quality of urban
life (Zan et al. 2014). Therefore, risks must be minimized and high-quality puriﬁed
water must be ﬂowed from fountains. The ﬁrst step is to protect raw water quality.
Second, reclamation of puriﬁed water; third, distribution network cleaning; fourth,
monitoring; the ﬁfth is maintenance-repair and renovation, and the last is the planning
and quality of domestic water systems.
The Protection of Raw Water Quality: The protection and sustainability of raw
water quality is directly related to sustainable urban planning policies. However,
today, urbanization that is not compatible with the natural texture, that is; urbaniza-
tion, which is carried out without paying attention to settlement site selection, seis-
micity, drinking and utility water, surface and ground water, drainage, morphology,
ground properties, wind condition, land slope, landforms, building stones, raw mate-
rial resources and similar features, affects the loss of urban identity and urban
heritage, and even causes the history of the city to be lost (Kazancı et al. 2018).
Ankara, the capital of Turkey, is a very good example of this situation. Ankara
is a city that has lost its rivers, waterways, lakes, vineyards and gardens (Kazancı
et al. 2018). Many large and small rivers had been covered and their waters had
been connected to the sewage system, and river basins had been zoned for housing.
If Ankara was not built like this, but was planned in a water-sensitive manner,
preserving the river basins and lake areas, and preserving its natural structure, where
urban forests, green areas and agricultural areas continue to exist along intercon-
nected waterways; Would there be problems such as drought, water problems, air
pollution, which are predicted to become much more severe in the future, or to what
extent? Would Ankara’s urban value increase? Would Ankara be a more resilient and
livable city in terms of public health and water resources? Considering the answers
to questions such as these is extremely important in terms of determining the main
parameters that should be taken into consideration when planning new settlements
by drawing lessons from the past.
The Importance of Being Returned from Bottled Water to Tap Water …
269
Fig. 1 Schematic representation of protecting and improving the quality of underground and
surface raw water resources
Although urbanization in harmony with nature is the newest urbanization model
offered today for adaptation to climate change, it was actually the lifestyle of people
in historical periods. Considering the concept of sustainability, returning to this
lifestyle will ensure the continuity of societies. For this reason, it is now accepted that
protecting and improving the quality of underground and surface raw water resources
to be used for drinking water purposes is only possible by urban planning and land
use in a way that respects nature and is sensitive to water within the scope of the
ecosystem approach (Fig. 1).
For this reason, it is of great importance that water basins are not opened to
construction. For example; water conveyed by gravity from the Catskill and Delaware
Water Basin, where New York’s drinking water needs are met, is offered for consump-
tion only after disinfection, without puriﬁcation. It is of strategic importance not to
deteriorate raw water quality. For this reason, the water basin is protected. In this
context; in order to prevent the lands in the basin from being opened to development
and to protect the green area and forest area ecosystem, it has been decided by the
State Environmental Protection Directorate to purchase and expropriate all lands in
the water basin until 2025. At least 20.20 acres of land are purchased every year
(NYC 2010).
Besides; In order to ﬂow potable water from fountains, to minimize risks and
uncertainties, and to obtain the best results; all stages of urban drinking water
systems, from source to fountain, must be planned in a multi-dimensional and
multi-disciplinary manner.
Urban water systems (water supply, wastewater and rainwater) must be designed
and implemented together with other public investments, with an integrated plan-
ning approach, at the top of urban planning processes (Alegre and Covas 2015).
270
C. Karakaş Ulusoy
Figure 2 shows integrated water resources planning schematically. For this, ﬁrst of
all, strategic, tactical and business planning levels and their relationships with each
other, the methodology deﬁned at these planning levels, the tools and techniques used
should be carefully considered (Souza and Silva 2014; Alegre and Covas 2015). This
type of planning approach is the most important issue in protecting underground and
surface water resources, and therefore raw water quality. Accordingly, by obtaining
potable water with simple puriﬁcation process techniques, the elimination of the need
to use chemicals used in puriﬁcation processes will prevent the formation, accumu-
lation and mixing of substances originating from chemicals used in puriﬁcation in
the distribution network.
Improvement of Treated Water: Sustainable sanitation systems and the use
of compatible technology require decision-making by examining complex multiple
criteria (Spuhler et al. 2020). Properly improvement treated water can help prevent
uneven changes during distribution. For this reason, critical parameters in puriﬁcation
are; The distribution network should be determined according to the presence or
absence of old pipes downstream and the characteristics of pipe shells, free sediments
and bioﬁlm matrix. Because; The process of improvement treated water requires
serious examination and research (Liu et al. 2017a).
The Cleaning of Distribution Network: Since the quality of distributed drinking
water can only be as good as the conditions of the distribution network, one of the
recommended control strategies is to clean the pipe network before the quality of
Fig. 2 Integrated water resources planning
The Importance of Being Returned from Bottled Water to Tap Water …
271
water available for consumption changes. Three methods are used: cleaning with
water,airandcleaningball.Themethodcommonlyusedfordistributionpipecleaning
is known as one-way water washing. In this method; High velocity water (1.5 m/s)
is used to move sediments in the water and is discharged from the ﬁre hydrant. The
problem of the method is that water is wasted and it may not be effective in removing
adherent contaminants (tubers, crusts, bioﬁlm), especially when there are difﬁculties
in maintaining the required speed (Liu et al. 2017a).
Air cleaning is similar to spraying water. However; except for irregular ﬂow,
introducing air to create high velocity in the water column costs at least twice as
much as washing. Another alternative technique is to clean the inside of the pipe
with a cleaning ball (a lead-shaped object) by pushing or pulling along the pipelines
using water pressure. Hard balls have higher cleaning efﬁciency than soft balls.
Recently, cleaning with ice balls has been developed and accepted (Liu et al. 2017a).
In terms of application, considering the complexity and cost of each model, water and
air cleaning options are much more convenient compared to replacing the cleaning
ball and pipes.
Monitoring: Often, it is difﬁcult to monitor the release of pollutants in the distri-
bution network. Since the release is not periodic, the uncertainties regarding whether
and when the release will occur are often not perceived. In order to overcome this
problem,e.g.real-timewaterqualityparameterscanbemonitoredwithonlineparticle
counting and online cell counting using ﬂow cytometry. Samples taken at multiple
points in the distribution system can provide background data before water quality
changes. By comparing the data obtained from samples taken at the same points
during and after the quality change in the water offered for consumption with the
background data, very valuable information about the quality change occurring in
the distribution network can be obtained. However, online detection is limited. For
example, online tools for heavy metals and pathogens (such as As, Pb) are not yet
available. In addition, the release states of pollutants may be very low compared to
background and transition period measurements (Liu et al. 2017a). Therefore, this
issue needs to be investigated in more detail.
Maintenance—Repair, Replacement: Frequent bursts of old pipes and high
water losses require urgent renovations. The largest portion of the operation and
maintenance budget of water distribution systems consists of burst pipe repairs. The
earlier a burst is identiﬁed and repaired, the lower the cost of operation, mainte-
nance, water loss, and the risk of external contaminants entering the system (Capelo
et al. 2021). Intelligent management of the system requires the achievement of high
efﬁciency (Candelleri et al. 2014). This is just; the most appropriate and efﬁcient
technique can be made possible by correct design which is one of the most difﬁ-
cult tasks and instant monitoring of the drinking water network (Creacoa and Fran-
chinia 2014). In the light of today’s information, instant monitoring of water loss and
network water quality can be done the new internet of things technology as well as
using different acoustic techniques, SCADA and GIS systems (Radhakrishnan and
Wu 2020; Shahanas and Sivakumar 2016). It is predicted that this technology will
become widespread in the near future.
272
C. Karakaş Ulusoy
3
Domestic Water Supply Systems
Domestic water supply systems (home plumbing) are deﬁned as the drinking water
infrastructure between the water meter and the fountain connected to the drinking
water distribution network. It is the last phase of the water conveyed to ﬂow drinking
water from fountains. At this stage, water quality may change depending on water
temperature, residence time in the pipe and pipe materials while passing through
domestic water supply systems, just like in distribution systems (Moerman et al.
2014).
Temperature is an important parameter for water quality. For example; According
to the Drinking Water Law in the Netherlands, the temperature of drinking water
should not exceed the 25 °C threshold, both in the distribution network and in foun-
tains, which are the end-use point in homes. Therefore, Moerman et al. (2014) devel-
oped a temperature model for domestic water supply systems on behalf of the Dutch
Plumbers Organization in order to calculate the required pipe insulation for drinking
water pipes in pipe shafts in order to prevent the temperature from rising above
25 °C. Since the water temperature in the drinking water distribution system is equal
to the soil temperature at the pipe depth, it is assumed that the temperature in the
domestic water supply system is equal to the soil temperature around the drinking
water distribution system. When the model results are evaluated; In the Netherlands,
25 °C is the legal threshold; It has been determined that in the summer season or if
the hot water pipes of regional or ﬂoor heating are laid close to the drinking water
pipes, they may be exceeded due to the long residence time in the drinking water pipe
(Moerman et al. 2014). In this case, it is extremely important to ensure full insulation
in places where hot water pipes are close to drinking water pipes in order to prevent
the quality of the water ﬂowing from the fountain from deteriorating.
4
The Relationship Between Sustainable Development
and Urban Tap Water
Sustainable development is the simultaneous achievement of economic, social
and environmental developments (Miller et al. 2014). Therefore, the continuity of
local, regional, national and international studies that are multi-dimensional, multi-
disciplinary and dynamic enough to produce solutions to the problems of the age
is important in every sector. The common connotation of the words sustainability
and development already necessitates multi-sectorality, inter-sectorality and holistic
approach. Whether or not the sustainability of almost all sectors is linked to the
phenomenon of urbanization. Therefore, sustainable urban development is a target
policy for developed and developing countries.
Sustainable cities in the twenty-ﬁrst century should be cities where there is polit-
ical participation, socially equitable, economically vibrant and ecological renewal is
a priority (Uslu 2009).
The Importance of Being Returned from Bottled Water to Tap Water …
273
Flowing healthy, drinkable quality water from fountains is one of the most impor-
tant issues of sustainable development in terms of protecting human and natural
health and is directly related to sustainable urbanization. Climate change, all kinds
of wastes and chemical pollution caused by poor mining operations, plastic pollu-
tion, and urban and land use planning choices that are incompatible with nature
directly affect raw water quality. Drinking water quality and public health are also
affected by this situation. As a result, the costs of obtaining quality drinking water
and health expenses are increasing day by day. Therefore, it is extremely important
for sustainable development to establish the rules of transition to a circular economy
by choosing policies that reduce waste and pollution.
In cities where fresh water resources will decrease due to climate change in the
future and the urban population will increase, strategy and management changes
must be made in order to switch to resilient urban water management. Resilient
urban water management is based on the logic of meeting the water needs of today
and future generations in a healthy and sustainable way. Therefore, on the basis
of urban planning compatible with climate change; it is necessary to achieve the
transition from existing centralized conventional water infrastructure systems and
central wastewater treatment facilities to urban water infrastructure with discrete,
diversiﬁed water resources. For this reason, the planning approach of the existing
urban, water and wastewater infrastructure systems and housing technology must
change: Each local government must ﬁrst know the natural characteristics of its own
region very well. Zoning planning should be done in harmony with nature, respectful
of nature, sensitive to water, with a multi-sectoral and multi-stakeholder approach.
City, water, wastewater and stormwater infrastructure facilities should be planned
simultaneously and together.
Alternative water sources reduce dependence on a single source and the risk of
water scarcity (Smith et al. 2012). In this context, urban planning for the reuse and
storage of wastewater, ﬂood or rainwater, building, road and pavement construc-
tion, building water network systems, building roof design, the researchs of new
technologies to beneﬁt from wastewater, rainwater and seawater have accelerated. In
addition, efforts to reduce greenhouse gases and increase forest areas and green areas
to combat drought have triggered the idea that the world should be built and greened
in accordance with its natural geography, and designs compatible with nature have
begun to be preferred.
The use of energy at every stage of urban drinking and potable water supply (trans-
mission, storage, network, puriﬁcation, disinfection, domestic use) and wastewater
treatment, diversifying energy sources and using renewable energy sources (solar,
wind, geothermal, thermal energy storage techniques, etc.), development of new
water and energy efﬁcient integrated models are important efforts in resilient urban
water management.
274
C. Karakaş Ulusoy
5
Conclusions
In this study, how to ensure the drinkability of tap water is examined as the primary
objective and its relationship with sustainable development as the secondary objec-
tive.Primarily,Itisextremelyimportanttoreducetheuseofbottledwaterfordrinking
purposes within the framework of reducing plastic pollution and chemical pollution,
reusing waste and protecting natural resources. In order to avoid using bottled water,
the drinkability rate of tap water should be increased. it is seen that planning the
distribution of water is as important as its production in providing potable water
from fountains in urban drinking water service provision. However, it is known that
in practice, in expanding cities, the drinking water needs of the whole city are gener-
ally met from the central conventional drinking water treatment facility with pipes
of different diameters, lengths, materials and ages. This ﬁnding is important as it
shows that the distribution network design was made without considering its impact
on water quality. Should the aim be to be able to run water from fountains or to drink
water ﬂowing from fountains? If the choice is to drink water ﬂowing from fountains,
the urban planning approach must be completely changed, as well as the existing
centralized conventional water infrastructure planning approach.
Providing the physical, chemical and biological conditions for potable water to
ﬂow from fountains can be possible with multi-dimensional, multi-disciplinary, inte-
grated planning and studies based on scientiﬁc foundations, from the source to the
fountain. In this context, it is important to be able to predict current and future risks
and take the necessary precautions quickly. For this, a detailed analysis of the envi-
ronmental, economic, political and managerial dimensions of the transition from
existing single-centered conventional systems to ﬂexible, multi-centered, diverse,
small and changeable systems should be undertaken as soon as possible.
Secondarily, in efforts to adapt to climate change and sustainable development; It
is considered that providing urban water service in a sustainable way is only possible
with multi-centered, ﬂexible, multi-source, multi-disciplinary integrated urban water
infrastructure system planning, based on a nature-based, nature-respecting, water-
sensitive urban planning approach that protects intergenerational equality, is resistant
to climate change.

Demonstrating Energy Transitions
in Micro Industries: Sustainability
of Energy Justice
Mini Govindan, Rashmi Murali, Abhinish Boora, and Amit Kumar Thakur
Abstract Micro-enterprises in India engage a signiﬁcant proportion of formal and
informal employment, including marginalized communities. Initiating and fostering
clean energy transitions in this sector throws open a plethora of challenges and
opportunities. Faced with barriers of low productivity, poor wages, and inaccessi-
bility to credit and inadequate energy inputs, clean energy transition, which receives
the support of the national government, philanthropies and other private players,
offers transformative growth to the enterprises, while ensuring energy justice and
inclusivity. However, despite a growing interest to adopt renewable energy tech-
nologies, such as solar, the inherent vulnerability of these communities renders
these enterprises risk-averse, and there is a sense of trepidation and apprehension.
The fear of incurring debt and the possibility of credit risks loom large. With the
objective to address these challenges, an on-going initiative- Sustainable Energy
in Micro-enterprises for Income and Livelihood Enhancement (SMILE)- adopts a
practical pathway based on the demonstration effect, wherein relatively larger and
more stable micro-enterprises, which exhibit greater propensity to undertake trans-
formative endeavours, were chosen as pioneers for change. By empowering these
enterprises with renewable energy technologies and showcasing the tangible beneﬁts
that ensue, the success of the demonstration projects showcased to the marginalised
communities, the positive impact on productivity, reliability, and cost savings. The
initial reservations were gradually replaced with newfound conviction and eagerness
to embrace sustainable energy solutions, leading to a spillover effect on neighbouring
microenterprises. This paper explores the interplay of demonstration and spillover
effects as a powerful tool for ensuring the sustainability of energy justice.
M. Govindan · R. Murali (B)
The Energy and Resources Institute (TERI), New Delhi, India

Keywords Energy transition · Micro-enterprises · Demonstration · Spillover
1
Introduction
Developing economies like India are driven by Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises
(MSMEs) whose contribution to formal and informal employment generation and
stimulating local economies in rural and peri-urban areas has been immense. India’s
vibrant MSME landscape has been a strong contributor to macroeconomic indica-
tors like Gross Domestic Product (GDP), wherein MSMEs held a share of around
29% in 2021–22. Further the sector’s contribution to manufacturing and exports, at
36 and 43% (2021–22) respectively, serves to strengthen India’s position as a glob-
ally competent economy (Press Information Bureau 2023). Another relatively less
highlighted facet of MSMEs is their role in preserving several traditional arts and
indigenous crafts, practiced by cottage industries and artisans, whose livelihoods
depend on it. Appropriately titled as ‘Engines of Growth,’ the MSME sector has
received a strong push from policy makers in the form of supportive schemes for
ﬁnancial, technological, marketing assistance.
In spite of the immense potential and prospects presented by the sector, chal-
lenges still persist when it comes to infrastructure gaps, accessing credit, availing
government assistance, and sustaining their businesses in the face of market and
supply chain ﬂuctuations. The micro-enterprise sector within MSMEs, accounting
for around 99% of all MSMEs, is particularly vulnerable to challenges, especially
those of infrastructure including energy inputs. Reliability and quality of electricity
supply are critical parameters for seamless production activities in the enterprises,
and gaps in electricity supply cause disruptions in production, leading to added costs
of back-up supply, additional labour costs and compromised product quality. Afford-
ability of electricity also becomes an impediment when micro-enterprises attempt
to mechanise and expand their production processes. Overall, energy becomes a
deciding factor for the viability and sustainability of micro-enterprises.
Inthisscenario,MSMEscouldgreatlybeneﬁtfromatransitiontocleanenergythat
addresses the issues with affordability and reliability of supply. The government’s
focus on expanding India’s renewable energy capacities to 500 GW by 2030 opens
up immense opportunities for MSMEs to beneﬁt from the transition to enhance their
business operations, as well as opens doors for the creation of new businesses in
the energy supply chain. By achieving energy transitions in the MSME sector, the
country could conﬁdently progress towards an environmentally sustainable economy.
To ensure that the transition is ‘just’, its beneﬁts should be accessible to all sections
of the society, including the marginalised. However, energy justice is a complex
process, intrinsically linked to factors that go beyond energy access, but take into
account social, economic, cultural and behavioural facets and the accompanying
barriers. Moving in this direction would require support and mentoring that goes
beyond policy mandated physical assistance, to an ecosystem of supportive inputs
that build an equitable and resilient environment for business growth. Stakeholders
Demonstrating Energy Transitions in Micro Industries: Sustainability …
279
including the private sector, non-governmental agencies and philanthropies carry the
motivation and the resources that could transform the landscape of MSMEs. They
can foster innovation, strengthen the supply chain, and provide handholding and
capacities to struggling MSMEs to adopt sustainable business practices through the
just transition pathway.
Acceptance of new technologies for business requires time and an assurance
of minimal risks. Demonstrating innovative approaches and customised techno-
commercial models designed to meet the requirements of micro-enterprises would
go a long way in developing conﬁdence in adopting a new technology. An attempt in
this direction was made by an on-going philanthropy-supported programme- Sustain-
able Energy in Micro-enterprises for Income and Livelihood Enhancement (SMILE).
Implemented by The Energy and Resources Institute (TERI) supported by the IKEA
Foundation, SMILE aims to facilitate the deployment of energy efﬁcient renew-
able energy technologies to empower productive utilization in micro-enterprises in
India. With a comprehensive but pragmatic approach, interventions under SMILE
include technical assistance, devising ﬁnancial instruments, supporting market link-
ages, forging new partnerships, and up-skilling entrepreneurs. Numerous micro-
enterprise clusters were identiﬁed for pilot demonstrations, primarily concentrated
in Uttar Pradesh, one of the top contributing states to the MSME sector in India.
Notably, Uttar Pradesh is one of the most economically challenged and technolog-
ically marginalized regions in India, which has been on a path of economic growth
and technology adoption in recent times. The clusters in Uttar Pradesh where the
SMILE programme was implemented include the Brassware cluster in Moradabad,
Silk-weaving clusters in Varanasi, and the Moonj rope-making clusters in Amethi and
Sultanpur districts. This paper explores the interplay of demonstration and spillover
effects as a powerful tool for ensuring the sustainability of energy justice, in the
context of the Moonj cluster.
2
SMILE Programme Background
The Moonj rope making cluster derives its name from the ﬁbre obtained from a
perennial species of wild grass called Saccharum Munja, locally known as ‘Sarpat
Ghas,’ which is found in the low lands along the banks of the Gomti River. Making
ropes and handicrafts from Moonj ﬁbres is a traditional art practiced by the ﬁshing
communities in the districts Amethi, Sultanpur, Prayagraj and Ambedkar Nagar.
The SMILE programme identiﬁed this cluster to be unique in artistry and least
developed in terms of technological interventions. Since most of the production work
is done manually even today, the cluster offered immense scope for mechanisation
and electriﬁcation through a clean energy source.
Of late, the popularity of Moonj products has been on the rise with the promotion
of sustainable lifestyles and organic products. A few urban craft and home décor
designers have promoted modern designs with the traditional weaving methods,
giving the products a contemporary appeal. Moreover, Moonj is endorsed by the
