government’s One District One Product (ODOP) scheme that promotes a unique
product from each district of the states of India through marketing support.
Primary research in the cluster revealed that rope making was a home-based
activity involving family members, where tasks were divided among the men and
women. While harvesting the grass, beating, extracting the ﬁbres was done by the
men, women took up rope twisting and weaving to create baskets and other household
items. Interestingly, only the rope was sold in the markets, whereas other products
were given as gifts during weddings. Weaving baskets was done by women at their
convenience in their free time, and it had not been commercialised. Mechanising the
production activities using clean energy could gradually help with commercialising
the cluster and make it a key contributor to the household income, which presently
was dependent on agriculture and small-scale ﬁshing, followed by casual labour
work, sometimes in other cities.
Based on a baseline technical and socio-economic survey under the SMILE
programme, an off-grid solar photovoltaic model was designed for the cluster that
could support the operation of rope twisting machines. The machines were intended
to alleviate the drudgery involved in manual rope-twisting and increase the pace and
volume of rope production. The technical model comprised a 670 Watt-peak solar
panel that would charge two batteries of 150 Ampere-hour, which in turn would run a
rope-twisting machine of 0.5 Horsepower (Table 1). The system could operate for 5 h
of peak sunlight, which also coincided with the usual working hours for households
in the villages. The modularity of the system provided the ﬂexibility to increase the
solar capacity as well as add more machines as the volume of production increased.
The combined solar and rope-twisting machine system cost around INR 175,000
(USD 2101),1 of which the community was expected to pay 50%, that is INR 87,500
(USD 1051), and the rest was supported by the SMILE programme. Understanding
the socio-economic challenges faced by the community, extensive community mobil-
isation activities and awareness drives were conducted under the programme. Locally
stationed ﬁeld staff held regular interactions with various stakeholders in the villages-
both men and women- to familiarise them with SMILE and the prospective beneﬁts
towards livelihood augmentation. Since, the objective of the SMILE programme was
to give voice to the marginalised sections of society and make them key actors in
the energy transition landscape; the mobilisation activities primarily prioritised the
involvement of socio- economically poorer households in the clusters. To exhibit
1 1 INR = 0.012 USD.
Demonstrating Energy Transitions in Micro Industries: Sustainability …
281
the working of the technology, pilot models were demonstrated in several villages.
The community was invited to try their hand at running the machines, and verify
the quality of the rope produced. They were also made aware of options for ﬁnan-
cial assistance, considering their economic challenges. Support for market linkages
was also offered to the community members, as many of them had not thought of
selling Moonj products other than ropes. In the course of the project, TERI also
partnered with two local non-governmental organizations- Omkar Seva Sansthan in
Amethi and Moonj Craft in Sultanpur districts. These NGOs primarily work with
local women to support them in enhancing their livelihoods, in addition to working in
various welfare domains of health, education, youth affairs, legal and human rights,
and housing among others.
It is however documented that many technologies that could spur considerable
increase in welfare, economy and environment are often adopted at low rates even
when donors, researchers and civil society have invested their effort in them heavily
(Parks et al. 2016). Hence, this article aims to address some questions that are of
particular importance to policy makers and donors and project implementers- (a) Can
demonstration effect act as a potential driver in challenging existing regimes in rural
societies for promoting low carbon technologies for productive use?, and (b) What
are the factors and conditions that drive demonstration effect of such technologies?
3
Utilising the Demonstration Effect to Move the Needle
on Rural Energy Transition
The research landscape surrounding rural energy transitions in micro-industries is
multifaceted, encompassing a variety of crucial aspects of social dynamics and
community energy models in the context of the demonstration effect. Coined in 1949
by the noted American economist J. S. Duesenberry in the paper Income, Saving and
the Theory of Consumer Behaviour, the demonstration effect was propounded as a
phenomenon concerning a Relative Income Hypothesis (Duesenberry 1949), which
described the tendency of lower income households to imitate and compete with their
higher income counterparts in the community, in terms of consumption behaviours
(Dwivedi 2015). This pattern could be seen as disruptive to lower income entities
(households, societies, countries), where imitative consumption trumps savings and
as a result impedes capital formation in certain cases, and thus the demonstration
effect could be discouraged (Adhikari 2022). However, alternate applications of the
demonstration effect that actuates positive adoption of socio-economically beneﬁcial
instruments is highly desirable and the subject of the present paper.
Energy transitions in India over the past decades have occurred over a lab-to-
ﬁeld approach, often mandated by policy, where new renewable energy designs have
been tested and customised through pilot demonstrations in real world conditions.
In addition to improving the technical parameters of these models and developing
new technologies for climate action, demonstrating amongst the community has
282
M. Govindan et al.
been instrumental in generating curiosity and anticipation for alternative affordable
energy solutions. Testing various technological models are essential for anticipating
and mitigating technical, market and institutional uncertainties and challenges that
emerge from new technology deployment, thus evolving a broader socio-technical
system (Hendry et al. 2010; Hellsmark et al. 2016). However, there are examples
of where demonstrations without technology ‘readiness’ may not have achieved the
desired outcomes, despite supportive incentives for its adoption (Frankel 1986). Thus
the important aspect of assessing technical and economic feasibility of technologies
through demonstration models must not be overlooked, as the learning gathered
could determine the prospect of future commercialisation and scale-up (Degiorgis
et al. 2007; Gocht et al. 1988; Nguyen et al. 1996).
While literature demarcates demonstration models or plants into those for estab-
lishing technical viability and others that promote ‘exemplars’ for adoption (Karl-
ström and Sandén 2004; Magill and Rogers 1981), the present study of technology
demonstration in the Moonj cluster is an amalgamation of both approaches, where
technical feasibility is established in concurrence with socio-economic beneﬁts,
contributing to relatively quicker adoption and future scale-up.
However, demonstrating and then upscaling sustainable energy programmes
requires a supportive ecosystem anchored on factors like government support,
industry-academia collaboration, market forces and investments. Demonstrations
also form the basis of transformative upscaling where demonstrated break out tech-
nologiesscaleupfromnichemarketstoregularmarkets(Bossinketal.2023).Further,
a deeper understanding of the role of ‘actor networks’ in demonstration projects is
also advocated by studies (Frishammar et al. 2015).
Finally, one of the most signiﬁcant opportunities presented by demonstration
projects in sustainable energy is that of capturing learning and insights on technical,
marketing organisational and policy aspects of energy transitions and future research
(Bossink 2017).
4
Methodology
A case study approach was adopted, which included various data gathering tools to
collect both primary and secondary data. It has been noted that case study approach is
helpful in theory development, generation of new evidence and hypothesis testing and
also provides a detailed consideration of the contextual factors for a research study
which are different from statistical analysis (George and Bennet 2004). (Gerring
2006)arguesthatanalysingatypicalcaseisusefulinordertoextensivelycomprehend
and explain a particular phenomenon. However, ﬁndings from a case study cannot
be generalised and hence it should be noted that case studies can provide depth and
thickness of understanding, despite sacriﬁcing the generalisability (Sartori 1991).
Fieldwork was conducted between February and November 2023 in the selected
Moonj micro-enterprise clusters, in Sultanpur district of Uttar Pradesh, India, along-
side a desk review of relevant studies, reports and publications. To examine the
Demonstrating Energy Transitions in Micro Industries: Sustainability …
283
phenomenon of demonstration effect, the following types of micro-clusters were
considered:
• Large enterprises who have willingly taken up the technology to be demonstrated
as pilot project
• Small enterprises and individual artisans/households who were initially reluctant,
but after seeing the success of pilot demonstration have adopted the technology.
Both these enterprises have a few things in common—they are situated in rural
areas, they have erratic power supply but still pay high electricity rates and have
not been part of any renewable energy projects in the past either by the government
or the private sector including civil society organisations and philanthropies. The
larger enterprises however, had an edge over the small enterprises in their volume of
production and access to markets, ﬁnance and resources. The smaller enterprises and
the households involved in making Moonj products were composed of low income
households and limited access to ﬁnance and resources.
In order to understand and analyse the factors that led to the adoption of the tech-
nology primarily by the large enterprises, even though the program was prioritised
for marginalized and low income households, in-depth key stakeholder interviews,
site visits, walk-throughs and community observations were carried out during the
ﬁeldwork. Efforts were made to understand the causal mechanism of the demonstra-
tion effect on the smaller enterprise. In this study, as we describe and analyse the
nature of demonstration effect, we also paid attention to the characteristics, patterns
and challenges that are associated with it.
The interviewees were selected through a combination of purposive and snow-
balling methods. In total, 30 in-depth interviews were conducted with the following
types of respondents—households engaged in Moonj work, the head and ofﬁce
bearers of the NGOs working in the clusters (Moonj Craft and Omkar Seva Sansthan),
women working in the clusters, technology providers, village leaders and subject
experts. The interviews were transcribed, and the data gathered were categorised
into themes and sub-themes for content analysis.
Although, guided by relevant literature and ﬁndings from the ﬁeld, this paper
is meant to be exploratory and open to generating new ideas and explanations on
the inﬂuence of demonstration effect in addressing the challenges or lessons for
future policy or project interventions on renewable energy adoption in other rural
communities.
5
Demonstration Effect as a Potential Driver
in Challenging Existing Regimes
The communities engaged in Moonj rope making in Amethi and Sultanpur districts
rank low on several developmental indicators, with around 30% of the population
of Amethi and 22% of the population of Sultanpur being multidimensionally poor
284
M. Govindan et al.
(Government of Uttar Pradesh 2023). Limited education, especially among women
and the youth, has severely constrained their livelihoods. Agriculture continues to be
the mainstay of the economy, supported in some regions by small-scale inland ﬁshing.
Other local jobs include tiny businesses like petty shops. Seasonal migration of men
to cities is common, where casual labour or odd jobs in small private ﬁrms become
an additional income source, alongside agriculture in the villages. Women in the
community largely remain occupied with household responsibilities and agriculture.
The Moonj grass is abundantly available in the villages, growing wild along river
banks, which is seasonally harvested by men, and processed further by women.
Traditionally, Moonj grass was used to insulate roofs of houses or to create boundary
walls. As other uses of the grass evolved, women predominantly undertook manual
rope twisting, which was a laborious and time-consuming process. Weaving other
household products such as baskets, mats, containers, and bags, among others, are
done by women in their leisure time along with household chores. Reportedly, around
150,000 people are engaged in working with materials made of Moonj in Sultanpur
district (National Skill Development Council 2021).The meagre income earned from
making and selling Moonj ropes in the local markets hardly meets the needs of the
household, and is not regarded as a formal income source. This background enabled
the cluster to be chosen for interventions under SMILE, as the programme aimed
to beneﬁt the poorest of the poor and marginalised sections of the society, facing
socio-cultural, economic and gender-based disparities, through technology imple-
mentation and other supportive measures. The programme also envisaged creating
pathways for the community to improve their visibility in the markets and promote
their products beyond local bazars, by creating awareness, conducting trainings and
utilising exhibitions, fairs and online sales platforms.
It is well noted that supporting renewable energy demonstration projects to spread
information and create awareness in remote areas, training microﬁnance leaders and
decentralising the implementation of such projects may foster renewable energy
adoption (Kochtcheeva 2016). Such actions would also help build a better equipped
sustainable renewable industry, generate proﬁts and create jobs, alongside increasing
efﬁciency in ﬁnancing (Mohiuddin 2006; MacLeod et al. 2015). Hence, extensive
awareness drives were conducted which generated signiﬁcant curiosity for solar
technology amongst the community. The prospect of mechanising the process of rope
twisting found favour with the women who appreciated the potential time savings.
The possibility of increased productivity and more volume of production brought
with it the hope of a better livelihood, which was attractive to the community.
Due to the relatively high upfront costs of most technologies, having access
to ﬁnance is considered to be an important prerequisite for their adoption
(Brunnschweiler 2010; Huenteler and Schmidt 2014). Hence, the SMILE programme
offered to support up to ﬁfty per cent of the system costs and the rest was to be
contributed by the community. However, owing to their poor economic situation,
affording the systems became challenging. Paying the cost upfront or even in instal-
ments was difﬁcult for them given their low disposable incomes. In addition, the
community showed apprehensions regarding the functioning of the solar system,
which was, in a way, alien to them, as they had not seen any applications of solar
Demonstrating Energy Transitions in Micro Industries: Sustainability …
285
in their villages. According to some studies, in many rural populations, a lack of
awareness of solar products is a major obstacle in developing the solar energy market
(Rebane and Barham 2011; Halder 2016). In a study conducted by Urpelainen and
Yoon (2015), it was found that rural households in Uttar Pradesh, were unaware
of even solar home systems (Urpelainen and Yoon 2015). This led to less demand
for solar products, especially in energy-poor rural areas. Moonj harvesting being a
seasonal activity, the community was concerned with the utility of the system in the
lean season, since the system was not designed to power their household appliances
due to cost constraints. Another aspect highlighted was that despite their interest
in using machines to ease the manual labour of rope-twisting, the women had not
operated any machines before. The shift from a leisurely activity to running a formal
commercial enterprise was overwhelming for the rural women, who had no previous
experience of such work.
Various efforts were made in this cluster to enable affordability for the poten-
tial beneﬁciaries. However, their aversion to taking ﬁnancial risks proved to be a
hindrance. It is a natural tendency to be averse of risks and prefer outcomes with low
uncertainty over those with high uncertainty. In the current context, certain factors
have led to this risk aversion among the community, such as their inherent vulnera-
bility, poor ﬁnancial condition, present economic status, market situation, and lack of
awareness and skills regarding the technology. For instance, linkages with rural banks
were proposed to the artisans for availing loans to afford the system cost. This was
however, met with resistance, as the fear of incurring debt which they may not be able
to repay given their small scale of operation loomed large. The possibility of ﬁnancial
instability made them hesitant to undertake potentially transformative but uncertain
and unheard-of endeavours. Given that the other costs involved in the production
are minimal, investing in a new technology through loans did not seem proﬁtable
to the community. On the ﬂip side, even banks considered these unorganised micro-
enterprises to be high risk in terms of payment defaults and credibility and hesitated
to provide them business loans, unless mandated by a government scheme. Studies
have noted that bankers cited lack of awareness and uncertain techno-commercial
viability of proposals relating to solar-powered livelihood appliances as key concerns
(Jha et al. 2019).
The other option presented to the community was to avail subsidies or ﬁnancial
assistance under government schemes such as Mudra Loans,2 designed to support
technology infusion in the MSME sector including solar installations. This too was
notattractivetothecommunityaslackofawarenessofschemes,immensepaperwork,
and long waiting times gave the impression of a cumbersome and laborious process.
They were of the belief that the time spent on availing scheme beneﬁts may take away
from their livelihood as they lose days of productive work. Further, the presence of
severalGovernmentschemesonsolartechnologyliketherecentSuryaGharscheme,3
2 The Pradhan Mantri Mudra Yojana (PMMY) is a Central Government scheme to extend affordable
credit to micro and small enterprises.
3 PM Surya Ghar Muft Bijlee Yojana provides free electricity of up to 300 units per month to
households that opt for solar rooftop systems.
286
M. Govindan et al.
distort the value of initiatives like SMILE by sending asymmetric information into
the community and inﬂuencing their decision making, as they expected to receive
free of cost or highly subsidised systems.
The SMILE programme was designed with the understanding that the accep-
tance of any new technology takes time, and always comes with a cost. The path
towards large scale adoption of a potentially transformative technology would require
customisation of the technology to suit the enterprise needs, demonstration of the
beneﬁts, and ﬁnancial investment. With the barriers and apprehensions presented in
the Moonj cluster, the SMILE programme modiﬁed its approach to a more inno-
vative yet practical pathway. Instead of promoting the intervention amongst the
smallest individual entrepreneurs in the community as planned earlier, larger and
relatively more stable micro-enterprises or groups of entrepreneurs were identiﬁed
for piloting the interventions. These enterprises exhibited a greater propensity to
undertake transformative endeavours, given their ﬁnancial strength, experience of
running businesses and a better understanding of the prospects to improve the gap
in their business methods. Energy was seen by them as a crucial input to improve
productivity, and solar was seen to provide affordable, reliable and long-term energy
security for their enterprise operations. The maturity and modularity offered by solar
technology added to its value in terms of contributing to expanding the business in
the future. By empowering these enterprises with renewable energy technologies and
showcasing the tangible beneﬁts that ensue, these larger enterprises could potentially
turn out to be compelling examples for their marginalized counterparts.
The SMILE programme, with a renewed strategy identiﬁed larger players in the
Moonj cluster who had a good standing amongst the community and had taken
measures to commercialise Moonj products with the support of existing government
schemes. Two such civil society organisations- Omkar Seva Sansthan and Moonj
Craft- worked closely with local women to engage them in livelihood augmenta-
tion activities. While Omkar Seva Sansthan was a small NGO that newly ventured
into the Moonj business, Moonj Craft was a larger established player in the market,
which operated on the cooperative model where groups of women contributed their
skills to developing Moonj products. Women were trained by the NGOs in crafting
good quality, diverse Moonj articles like bags, containers, furniture, home décor, etc.,
ready to be sold to consumers. Government support for these organisations came in
the form of infrastructure support, like a small building that served as a training
centre cum work space (at Moonj Craft Sultanpur), access to training programmes,
and representation in government-promoted fairs. In addition, these organisations
received orders for products from various government agencies. In a bid to commer-
cialise their operations further, and promote women-led livelihood activities, efforts
were made to market these products in exhibitions in large cities, and make use
of online marketing platforms. These efforts have helped women realise the worth
of their craftsmanship, improved their conﬁdence, and helped them command fair
remuneration for their labour.
When the SMILE programme was introduced in the larger cooperative (Moonj
Craft), the interventions received a positive response from the women who were keen
tolearntheworkingsofthenewmachinesandtechnology.Theyunderstoodtheutility
Demonstrating Energy Transitions in Micro Industries: Sustainability …
287
of the machines in easing their task, and appreciated solar as an energy source as
opposed to conventional electricity. The group model eased the affordability. The
SMILE team conducted demonstrations of the systems to familiarise the women
with the operations, and also trained them on the management of the solar systems
installed. The overall success of the initiative in the cooperatives helped spread the
word on the beneﬁts of mechanising the rope twisting activity and an affordable and
reliable energy source in the form of solar.
In this situation, the demonstration effect came into play which led to gener-
ating awareness and interest in this new technology, which also had a transformative
potential. A ripple effect was created in the community which took inspiration from
a large organisation like Moonj Craft and saw the prospects of commercialising their
craft supported by solar technology provisioned under SMILE. The newly generated
demand for solar rope-twisting machines came largely from the smaller NGO Omkar
Seva Sansthan, individual households and women who were not directly part of the
cooperative group (Fig. 1). These were also the artisans who held apprehensions on
the technology and its perceived risks, but observing the successful demonstration
of the systems, their trepidations paved the way for curiosity and an aspiration for
better quality of life. They recognised the livelihood opportunity in selling ropes in
the local market and other products like baskets to the cooperatives for a negotiated
price. Despite being marginalised and having a poor economic situation, the demon-
stration effect created from the success of the interventions for the larger players,
instilled a sense of conﬁdence in the community and smaller players to push their
boundaries and take up entrepreneurship.
Fig. 1 Inﬂuence of demonstration effect on technology adoption
288
M. Govindan et al.
6
Factors Inﬂuencing Demonstration Effect
The SMILE programme laid strategic emphasis on inspiring micro-enterprises
through exemplars, and set in motion a virtuous cycle, where a ‘Spillover Effect’
could be observed. Energized by the successes of the pioneering enterprises, neigh-
bouring marginalised microenterprises were emboldened to adopt renewable energy
interventions, creating a momentum that permeated throughout the micro-enterprise
cluster. The positive spillovers of the demonstration were both spatial and social in
nature. Spatial spillover effect was seen in similar geographies that were keen to
implement similar projects (Wang et al. 2023). As Omkar Seva Sansthan and Moonj
Craft connected women’s groups from several villages in the districts of Amethi and
Sultanpur, the positive word-of-mouth in their respective villages generated demand
for solar systems in geographically similar set-ups through a sense of relatability. A
social spillover effect was seen in the hints of changes in the way the community
viewed technology as a tool for economic development as well as for the participation
and upliftment of marginalised sections, including women (Fang et al. 2023). Whilst
it is understood that social changes take time and are inﬂuenced by several factors,
the potential of sustainable transition technologies in initiating social changes cannot
be ignored.
Upon critical examination, the cycle of demonstration and spillover effects in the
current context are guided by some glaring factors. Primarily, direct evidence of the
technical performance of the system was available for the community to witness.
Exposure visits were conducted for micro-entrepreneurs to the installation sites to
viewtheactualworkingofthesystems.Manydoubtsorapprehensionsweregenerally
quickly dispelled through the visits and interactions with system installers. The next
most important factor was the ﬁnancial viability of the technology. The support
from the SMILE programme and the relatively low costs of individual small solar
rope twisting machines helped nudge interested micro-entrepreneurs to make the
small investment for sustained future returns and enhanced livelihood opportunities.
Additional support from SMILE in the form of training programmes, reliable after-
sales services, guarantee and warranty on equipment and presence of SMILE ﬁeld
coordinators at the project sites expedited the technology adoption.
Another crucial factor was the strong presence and reputation of the organisations
Omkar Seva Sansthan and Moonj Craft in the villages. The peer groups developed
through these organisations were a platform for women to collectively work towards
improving their livelihood, while sharing their problems and joys with fellow women
from the villages. The barriers faced by individual women in taking up entrepreneur-
ship in addition to their household responsibilities got eased with the encouragement
and inspiration from other women who were engaged with these organisations. What
helped further was the prospect for additional family income which found favour
among the men of the household, who then did not hold the women back from
participating. Further instruments of support provided by these organisations such
as assistance for administrative paperwork, school admissions for children, hygienic
work spaces, pick-up and drop facilities from the villages, and the option of working
Demonstrating Energy Transitions in Micro Industries: Sustainability …
289
from home greatly beneﬁtted women and the organisations in maintaining women’s
long-term engagement in the group activities. Hence, women were able to overcome
their socially deﬁned barriers and marginalisation to break their own comfort zones
and contribute ﬁnancially for the welfare of their families.
Over the past two decades, it is widely acknowledged that the inclusion of
techno—economic and environmental appropriateness is critical in the provision
of environmental friendly technology for rural contexts (Pin et al. 2021). In the study
villages, it was revealed that the main factor considered for adoption of solar powered
Moonj rope making technology by both Moonj Craft and Omkar Seva Sansthan and
the individual households hoping to get this technology, is the technical efﬁciency
and economic performance followed by social beneﬁts. The common arguments by
environmental scholars (Talaei et al. 2014) which refers to the roll-out of low carbon
technologiestomaintaintheprogressivedevelopmentofenergy-hungrysectorswhile
also controlling, reducing, and/or preventing anthropogenic greenhouse gas emis-
sions, does not seem to be the main criteria for adoption of the low carbon technology
in the study area.
The head of Omkar Seva Sansthan clearly mentioned that there is a need to
alleviateeconomicconstraintsrelevanttosavings,credit,andotherliquidityissuesfor
stimulating such technology adoption practices in rural enterprises. This means the
renewable energy projects are mainly driven by local concerns and not by any national
policy on environment. Moreover, the choice and scale of projects reﬂects local
opportunities such as affordability, proﬁtability and creation of local employment.
Hence, only the least expensive energy solution that can also satisfy carbon emission
reduction requirements may be at best acceptable to the local community. As noted
by Talaei et al. (2014), technologies claiming to be climate-friendly should ﬁrst be
friendly and acceptable to the surrounding environment.
Director of Moonj Craft which has started commercialising their products opined
that eventually they would like to build the brand as a ‘pro environmental NGO’
and want to present their products and activities having environmental or ‘green
dimension.’
During ﬁeld interactions, he conﬁdently stated that “having a pro environmental
tag will help us in generating more business through better opportunities in exhibi-
tions and fairs. Lifestyle conscious customers are always looking for clean and green
brands.”
In a rural context, the provision of environment-friendly technologies shall
initially go through local barriers typically inherited from the lack of resources.
However, as noticed in the study region and as advocated by certain scholars such as
(Gupt et al. 2003), NGOs play a major role in helping articulating socio-ethical capital
in enhancing knowledge, values, and institutions to foster technological innovations
at the grassroots level. Therefore, in the long run if this pro-environment identity of
the NGO will drive better socio- economic gains, it will deﬁnitely initiate a powerful
Demonstration Effect within the micro-enterprise clusters.
290
M. Govindan et al.
7
Conclusion
The demonstration of low carbon technology in Moonj cluster played a pivotal role
in bridging the gap between concept development and implementation. It provided
a tangible representation of the innovation, highlighting its potential and real-world
value, while giving feedback to reﬁne the technology and guide further development.
This clearly indicated that the success of pilot projects in the larger micro-enterprises
such as the Moonj Craft, accomplished through SHGs, had an unambiguously posi-
tive effect on the smaller micro-enterprises managed by the marginalised communi-
ties and even motivated individual households to install systems. The pilot projects
established itself an effective and continuous source of information dissemination
mechanism which in turn improved the understanding of the technology effects and
its characteristics and lowered the cognitive bias towards such technologies by the
smaller micro enterprises and reduced their uncertainty in revenue expectations and
inﬂuenced their adoption decisions. In this process of diffusion of ideas, the smaller
players imitated the actions of the larger NGO Moonj Craft and its successful SHG
network, who commanded respect and appeared successful. However, these diffusion
mechanisms may operate along behavioural logic such as human capital, personal
preferences,entrepreneurialexperiences,valueperceptions,riskperceptions,govern-
ment schemes, technology training and policy subsidies among others. Moreover,
these factors play out in different time frames, while some effects may be felt imme-
diately, broader shifts in public opinion and societal impression of the beneﬁts of
these technologies may occur over a period of time and become a deciding factor
whether to adopt it and how much to adopt.
Nevertheless, the strategic utilization of the ‘Demonstration Effect’ and ‘Spillover
Effect’ not only expedites the pace of sustainable energy adoption but also enhances
its comprehensiveness within micro-enterprise clusters. By building on the successes
of relatively larger and stable micro-enterprises, the SMILE initiative was able to
achieve its objectives and targets much faster and more comprehensively. Though
it was planned initially to target mostly the micro-enterprises within marginalized
communities, its mid-course correction of demonstrating the pilot in large micro
enterprises has empowered the small players to overcome challenges and take proac-
tive steps to adopt new technologies. This proactive and adaptive approach will not
only push further India’s progress towards its ambitious renewable energy goals but
also provides an opportunity for micro-enterprises from marginalized communities
to participate actively in the country’s transition to sustainable energy. As it is, the
concept of demonstration projects could potentially contribute to the formulation of
public policy by virtually gaining the approval of the community for replication at
scale (Dawson 1977). As the SMILE program advances towards its ultimate goal
of fostering a ‘Just Transition’ for all micro-enterprises, transcending economic and
social boundaries, it serves as a beacon of hope for inclusive growth and sustainable
development. Through such well-targeted initiatives, the SMILE program stands as
a testament to the transformative power of collaboration, innovation, and inclusivity
in India’s journey towards a greener and more sustainable future.

Priority Issues for Future Cities:
Opportunities and Challenges
for Sustainable Development Research
Jerry Kolo
Abstract Since the 1992 Rio Summit when the world endorsed Brundtlant Commis-
sion’s sustainable development as the framework for development policy and agenda
around the world, development scholars, practitioners and policy makers have
focused more on the economy pillar and, with the recent threats of climate change,
the natural environment pillar of the Brundtland sustainability framework. Receiving
inadequate attention is the social equity pillar. Meanwhile, cities are facing serious
political, economic, environmental and social challenges resulting from pervasive
inequity and injustices. The complex myriad of issues in the face of limited political,
ﬁnancial, environmental and other resources would require cities to prioritize their
challenges. What would the priority issues be for future cities? What opportunities
and challenges would the priorities pose for sustainability research? These ques-
tions were answered through an online global snowball survey, and the results were
analyzed qualitatively using the nominal group technique with a research group of
ﬁfteen millennials. The chapter concluded by delineating the nexus and implications
of future city challenges and sustainability research.
Keywords Future cities · Sustainability pillars · Sustainability pentagon ·
Sustainability research
1
Introduction
At the ﬁrst earth summit on environment and development that was held in Rio
de Janeiro in Brazil in 1992, the world leaders in attendance acknowledged the
precarious relationship between the natural environment and economic growth and
development. As a result, the leaders endorsed sustainable development (SD) as the
conceptual framework to guide and drive development policy, programs and agenda
around the world. The concept of SD was articulated and deﬁned in the report by the
J. Kolo (B)
College of Architecture, Art & Design, Master of Urban Planning Program, American University
of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates
e-mail: jkolo@aus.edu
© The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024
W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_18
293
294
J. Kolo
1983 UN-established Brundtland Commission as “development that meets the needs
of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their
own needs” (WCED 1987, p. 43) This deﬁnition is widely used in policy, governance,
corporate, and advocacy circles, the conceptual debate and criticisms by SD scholars
notwithstanding.
The Brundtland Report anchored SD on three pillars, namely, economy, envi-
ronment and equity (3-Es). Variants of this Brundtland 3-E framework have been
proposed by scholars, in efforts to facilitate both understanding and implementation,
feasibility or application of SD. Three examples of such variants are the sustain-
ability triple-bottom-line (TBL) by Elkington (1994; 2004); the sustainability prism
by Godschalk (2004) and Berke et al. (2006); and, the sustainability pentagon by
Kolo (2015). Generally, the point of departure of each of these variants is Brundt-
land’s framework. More speciﬁcally, Elkington (ibid) substituted Brundtland’s 3-E
pillars with his TBL pillars, which are people, proﬁt and planet. He argued from a
business standpoint that businesses could pursue their primary proﬁt-making motive
while simultaneously caring about the people or communities they serve, and the
environment that enables the production of goods and services. Godschalk (2004)
and Berke et al. (2006) added a fourth pillar, which is livability, to the Brundtland’s
3-E framework, resulting in the label ‘prism.’ As urban planners, they examined the
axes that connect livability to the economy, environment and equity pillars, noting
that ‘intractable’ value conﬂicts arise or occur on each axis. They stated emphatically
that “although the sustainability concept has considerable promise and local plan-
ning programs have forged ahead in experimenting and applying their own variants,
management of conﬂicts arising from the separate thrusts of environment, economy,
and equity has been less than tractable” (Berke et al. 2006, p. 37).
In proposing a 5-E sustainability framework dubbed sustainability pentagon, Kolo
(2015) added two Es to Brundtland’s 3-Es, namely engagement and enlightenment.
The framework resulted from his extensive ﬁeld work in community outreach and
empowerment in low- and moderate-income communities in South Florida, USA.
One of the key insights and lessons from the ﬁeld work is that the three Brundt-
land pillars are feasible only if communities are directly, actively and meaningfully
engaged in planning, implementing, evaluating and scaling up on sustainability initia-
tives. A dividend of such engagement is enlightenment, where the transmission of
knowledge, skills, information and insights among community stakeholders results in
clear and substantive understanding of all sustainability policies, programs, projects
and issues. The ﬁve pillars of the SD pentagon were used as the analytical framework
for the results of the survey conducted for this chapter.
Since Rio 1992 and the plethora of conventions signed by the world leaders
to implement SD locally, nationally and globally, an array of policies, programs,
projects, agreements and collaborations has emerged and continues to emerge on SD
implementation. Examples of notable initiatives include Kyoto Protocol, which is a
1990 agreement made under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate
Change (UNFCCC), urging the industrialized countries to reduce their collective
emissions of greenhouse gases by 5.2% compared to the year 1990. This is the
origin of all that is attributed to the Conference of Parties (COP) to date in terms of
Priority Issues for Future Cities: Opportunities and Challenges …
295
climate change mitigation and adaptation initiatives. Another example is the United
Nations (UN) Agenda 21, which is a comprehensive plan of global, national, and
local environmental protection actions, dubbed ‘Local Agenda 21’ or ‘LA21’ plans,
by agencies of the UN system, governments, and grassroots communities. Another
example is the UN Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), which resulted from
a declaration by world leaders at the UN Millennium Summit in 2000. The leaders
adopted eight goals to be achieved by 2015. The goals covered the issues of poverty,
hunger, education, equality, health, the environment and global partnership for devel-
opment. Building on and superseding the MDGs is another example, which consists
of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), designed to be achieved by year
2030. Besides these global examples, there are various other sub-global examples
around the world, aimed at implementing the spirit and intent of SD. There is, for
example, the eco-municipality program, formulated by Swedish oncologist Karl-
Henrik Robert in a model he called The Natural Step (TNS) (James and Lahti 2004).
Various urban design models and environmental audit systems are also currently
used, most of them voluntarily by cities, to promote or achieve sustainability. These
range from design models, such as 15-minute cities, walkable cities, slow cities, smart
cities, inclusive cities, etc., to environmental impact audit systems, also known as
green building rating systems (Li et al. 2017), such as Building Research Establish-
ment Environmental Assessment Methodology (BREEAM), which originated in the
UK in 1990; Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) in the USA in
1998; Haute Qualité Environmentale (HQE) in France in 1996; Global Sustainability
Assessment System (GSAS) in Qatar in 2009; Green Star in Australia in 2002 and
used in New Zealand and South Africa; Comprehensive Assessment System for Built
Environment Efﬁciency (CASBEE) in Japan in 2004; DGNB in Germany in 2008;
Estidama (Pearl) in the United Arab Emirates in 2010; Green Pyramid in Egypt in
2009; Green Globes in Canada in 2000; Green Mark in Singapore in 2009; BEAM
Plus in Hong Kong in 1996; etc.
Efforts and initiatives around the world to facilitate the implementation of SD have
received mixed reviews, but mostly on the negative side, with some analysts even
advocating new models or a paradigm shift (Clark and Kavanagh 2019). However,
evidence is irrefutable that SD implementation continues to be hampered by various
political, economic, psychosocial and environmental challenges. While most of the
challenges are attributable to human decisions, some are caused by force majeure,
which are forces beyond human control but directly impactful on humans. In spite of
the mixed reviews of SD implementation and the incremental, controversial and even
contradictory overlay of initiatives, the UN is currently strategizing, negotiating and
charting the next phase of SD programming, which will be 2030–2045. The next SD
programming phase provided the context for the aim of this chapter, and the questions
addressed about priority issues for future cities and the SD research implications of
the priorities.
296
J. Kolo
2
SD Implementation Challenges
In spite of the mixed reviews of the effectiveness of SD implementation around
the world to date, this chapter noted that a viewpoint, observation or verdict that
reverberates in most circles of assessment is that progress in implementing and
achieving SD worldwide lags distantly behind the most modest of expectations, and
that the world is faced with a herculean task in quickening or shrinking this pace.
Various reasons have been adduced in the academic and professional literature
for the mixed review of SD implementation and achievement to date. For example,
in a review of the literature on SD implementation challenges, Kolo et al. (2022)
clustered various reasons, with annotations, under ﬁve categories, viz, political or
governance; economic; psychosocial; natural environment; and built environment.
Under each of these clusters, speciﬁc reasons have been identiﬁed or adduced by
scholars and experts. For example, alluding broadly to the relationship between the
environment and development, Marsh and Grossa (1996) identiﬁed four dilemmas
that the world faces in harmonizing this relationship. The dilemmas are population
explosion, consumerism, technological exploit, and discord about the meaning of
SD.
3
SD and Future Cities: Research Questions, Aim
and Methods
Reﬂecting on, and examining the challenges of SD implementation in cities today,
three questions were posed and addressed in this chapter. One, what growth, devel-
opment and quality of life issues would the respondents to the survey conducted in
the research for this chapter deem to be priorities for future cities to address? Two,
under which of the ﬁve SD pentagon pillars will the research think tank that analyzed
the survey results cluster the priorities for future cities? Three, what would be impli-
cations of the priorities for future cities for SD research? The focus on future cities
is proactive or forward-thinking, given the rapid rate of urbanization worldwide, and
the complex issues that will confound cities. The challenges and characteristics of
future cities are subjects of robust research and policy debates and reﬂection, in the
quest to facilitate proactive measures by cities to govern and manage the affairs of
citizens responsibly and cost-effectively. In the same ‘futuristic’ sense, millennials
were directly engaged in this research, for their chronological ages and generational
perspectives, in assigning priority importance to the issues that future cities will face.
Ultimately, the key aim of this chapter is to delineate how SD research can facilitate
the governance of future cities sustainably.
Methodologically, three techniques were used for the research for this chapter.
One, in order to capture the priorities for future cities, an online questionnaire survey
was conducted over a two-week period, using the snowball survey technique. 111
valid responses were received from 16 countries worldwide. Two, in order to assign
Priority Issues for Future Cities: Opportunities and Challenges …
297
priorities to the results of the survey, ﬁfteen millennials in a graduate urban planning
program were involved in an intensive three-hour think tank that used the Nominal
Group Technique—NGT (Van De Ven and Delbecq 1974) to assign priorities to
the issues identiﬁed through the survey, and to cluster the issues according to the
ﬁve pillars of the SD pentagon. Three, the desktop method was used to review the
literature on SD pillars, and for insights into how scholarly research can facilitate
SD implementation.
The ratings and clustering of issues in the NGT process were done through guide-
lines negotiated and agreed upon by the participants in the process. For both rating
and clustering, a participant proposed a high, medium or low rating for an issue,
and a cluster for the same issue. A brief discussion of the proposal was followed
by a simple majority vote by all the participants to approve or reject the rating or
cluster. An issue was assigned to a pillar if addressing it would enhance the pillar
highly, moderately or lowly, or if ignoring it would harm, undermine the pillar highly,
moderately or lowly. Most important for policy and planning purposes is the high
rating, which suggests or implies issues that need continued or accelerated attention,
resources and intervention by government and other pertinent stakeholders. Real-
izing that an issue could apply to more than one cluster, the participants agreed to
select the top three of the ﬁve clusters that an issue could apply or be assigned to.
4
Survey Results, Analysis and Discussion
The results of the online survey are shown in Table 1. The results show that a total
of 25 priority issues for future cities were identiﬁed by the survey respondents. The
Table shows the ratings of the issues by participants in the NGT process as high,
medium or low in priority. The issues were ranked, based on the percentage weight
of high priority assigned to each issue. The Table also shows that the highest ranked
issue is environmental or climate change management, while the lowest is advanced
air mobility. Each issue was assigned to any top three of the ﬁve SD pillars of the
pentagon framework that the NGT participants deemed most pertinent for policy
and planning focus and action in future cities. The frequencies of the clusters were
compiled and, as Table 1 shows, the equity pillar, with a frequency of 22, would
require priority attention in future cities for the issues assigned to the pillar. Following
the equity pillar are, successively, the economy pillar with a frequency of 18; the
engagement pillar with a frequency of 13; the environment pillar with a frequency of
12; and, the enlightenment pillar with a frequency of 10. It is important to state that
the NGT participants acknowledged the complementarity and mutual reinforcement
of the pillars and the cluster of issues under each pillar. This points fundamentally
and crucially to the need to integrate policies, programs and plans across scales,
speciﬁcally vertically between and among levels of governments and the relevant
stakeholders, and horizontally between and among agencies of governments and all
the relevant stakeholders.

Reﬂecting on the results of the survey presented in Table 1 and the outcomes of the
NGT exercise, two speciﬁc observations stand out for discussion in this chapter. One
is that the 25 issues identiﬁed by the survey respondents are examples of the issues
that cities are currently wrestling with. More importantly, they are issues that cities
will contend with on a more intensiﬁed scale in the future, due largely to political
and ideological conﬂicts; budgetary constraints; environmental challenges; social
exigencies and conﬂicts; rising public expectations and agitation; and, various other
factors.
The issues identiﬁed by the survey respondents are not inconsistent with the issues
and challenges that are widely discussed in the literature for current and future cities,
in their quest to be more resilient, prosperous, livable and sustainable (Borja and
Castells 1997; Planete Energies 2024; Futureagenda 2017). Worth highlighting here
are the ﬁndings of an extensive empirical study of the challenges of future cities
by Futureagenda (2017), the world’s leading open foresight program. In 2015 and
300
J. Kolo
2016, several ‘future of cities’ workshops were run in key locations worldwide,
complemented by over 100 other events that provided multiple insights on the future
of cities. The program concluded that:
Although some points were speciﬁc to individual locations, a number of issues were uniﬁed
across all our discussions. We found three common challenges, three shared future ambitions
and three emerging concerns. The three common challenges are managing migration, coun-
tering inequality and scaling sustainability. The three shared ambitions are healthy cities,
accessible cities and intelligent cities. The three emerging concerns are safe cities, resilient
cities and collaborative competition.
It is noteworthy that the ﬁndings of the program across the three clusters of issues
bear close semblance to the ﬁndings of the survey conducted for this chapter.
A second observation on the outcomes of the survey and NGT exercise for this
chapter is that the outcomes of the exercise are very consistent with what seems
to be a universal concern among SD scholars and professionals, that the equity
pillar of SD is not accorded equal or due attention, compared to the economy and
environment pillars (Stronati 2024; Sivaraman 2020; Monnapula-Mapesela 2014;
Murphy 2014; Cuthill 2009; Berke et al. 2006; Stymne and Jackson 2000;). This
is in spite of the widespread, mounting and disturbing evidence that the cluster
of issues under the pillar are destabilizing age-old traditions, systems and norms in
societies worldwide (Oxfam 2024; UNDESA 2023; Sivaraman 2020). From extreme
political and ideological divisions at the governance level to social and cultural intol-
erance at the grassroots level, the virtues of the world’s common humanity are being
eroded and decimated ﬂagrantly by inequitable, unjust, exclusionary, discriminatory,
prejudiced and hateful policies, programs and behaviors by formal institutions and
ill-intentioned groups and individuals. The spread, severity and impacts of social
inequity and injustice across the world are well documented in both the empirical
and scholarly literature.
The results of the survey and the NGT process presented earlier, and the two key
observations discussed brieﬂy above, have signiﬁcant implications for public policy,
entrepreneurship, advocacy, research and grassroots initiatives across the world. In
line with the aim of this chapter, the focus in the chapter is on the implications of
the priority issues for future cities for academic SD research. The implications are
presented in the following section.
5
Priorities Issues for Future Cites and the Role of SD
Research
In conjecturing or delineating the implications of the priorities for future cities for
scholarly SD research, this chapter projects research from the broadest lenses in
terms of the various intentions, activities, phases, outcomes, and applications that
research design may imply or entail. In essence, the chapter deems research to go
beyond the traditional or normative notion of data collection and analysis, to various
Priority Issues for Future Cities: Opportunities and Challenges …
301
other dimensions that make research a valuable component of the broad and intricate
process of understanding and improving phenomena, that is, linking knowledge to
action,orproblem-solving.Inthissense,Table2identiﬁeswhatthischapterconsiders
to be some opportunities and challenges of the priorities for future cities for SD
research. The Table uses the broad view of research implied above to compile ten
tasks or roles of SD research in enabling future cities to address their priority issues.
The roles reﬂect the inextricable relationship between and among the SD pillars,
hence, the essence and overall goal of the roles are to facilitate each and all the pillars
of SD. The roles are suggestive and by no means exhaustive. Some opportunities and
challenges associated with each role or task are listed.
6
Conclusion
This chapter presented 25 issues that 111 anonymous respondents to an empirical
survey identiﬁed for future cities to prioritize, in order to serve their citizens effec-
tively and be livable and sustainable. The issues were rated and clustered by a think
tank of millennial scholars, based on the ﬁve pillars of the SD pentagon framework,
viz, environment, economy, equity, engagement and enlightenment. The pillars were
ranked according to the cluster of issues assigned to them by the think tank. The
ranking showed the equity pillar as the cluster with the highest frequency of issues
that future cities should prioritize, in order for them to be livable and sustainable. The
equity pillar was followed successively by the economy, engagement, environment
and enlightenment pillars. This ranking in no way denies the complementary and
inseparable relationship between and among the ﬁve SD pillars. Therefore, policies,
plans, programs and projects ought to be integrated both vertically and horizontally,
in order to implement SD cost-effectively.
The chapter emphasized that, in the face of decision-making or choices about
thriving and surviving, historical evidence and experiences show that societies have
always prioritized the economy and politics over the environment and equity. Pitched
against each other for prioritization, the order of priority is always the economy,
followed by politics then the environment and, lastly, social equity. Pertinently,
scholars such as Thin (2002) described equity as the elusive pillar of SD. In this
sense, prioritizing rather than integrating all the SD pillars into policies, programs
and projects is more detrimental than beneﬁcial for society or the public. The prior-
itization implied in this chapter is to alert governments and societal stakeholders to
scale up on equity, so it aligns with the economy and environment pillars, thereby
enabling future cities to avoid the destabilizing impacts of inequity and injustice.
Finally, the chapter took a broad and multi-dimensional view of research and, in
line with the aim of the chapter, delineated some implications of the priorities for
future cities for SD research. The view of research represents the multiple roles that
research can and should play in enabling future cities to address their priority issues
effectively. Some of the opportunities and challenges associated with each research
role were identiﬁed as actionable guides for SD researchers, scholars and other

An Agenda for Sustainable Development:
The Role of Strategic Impact Assessment
in Promoting Namibia’s Transition
to a Green Economy
Philip Mensah, Eric Yankson, and Derrick Frimpong Buabeng
Abstract Strategic impact assessment (SIA), also known as strategic environmental
assessment (SEA), is a systematic approach to decision-making that considers
the dimensions of a green economy transformation for sustainable development.
Although, Namibia has made signiﬁcant strides to attain the United Nations Sustain-
able Development Goals (UN-SDGs) 5, 13 and 15 i.e. gender equality, climate action
and life on land respectively, the country seems to be struggling to meet the other
aspects of the SDG targets. The chapter reviews relevant documents and analyzes
results to identify the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats of the current
impact assessment methodologies, in the context of the UN-SDGs. Followed by a
qualitative research approach, utilizing a case study design and purposive sampling
technique. The target population comprised personnel from the National Environ-
mental Affairs, Development Planning Commission, and Lands and Resettlement
Authority in Namibia, key exploration of stakeholders in SEA administration. Data
collection involved conducting in-depth interviews with six ofﬁcers, two from each
institution, using semi-structured interview guide. The ﬁndings show that Namibia
undertook a voluntary SEA between 2008 and 2013, although it is not yet a legal
mandate. It is evident that the drivers of SEA legislation have the potential to a
green economy transformation for sustainable development with 64.3% SDG index
score and 89.7% spillover score in Namibia. The level of this SDG achievement
indicates the country’s commitment to SIA in land use and spatial planning poli-
cies, plans and programs for sustainable development. The research also identiﬁes
potential improvements and recommendations for a more robust impact assessment

1
Introduction: “An Agenda for Sustainable Development”
In the twenty-ﬁrst century, sustainable development has emerged as a paramount
global concern that encompasses three pillars: economic growth, environmental
justice and social equity i.e. prosperity, planet and people respectively (UN-SDGs
2021). This multifaceted challenge has prompted nations worldwide to reevaluate
their development models and prioritize sustainable practices through research.
Namibia, a country located in the southwestern corner of Africa, is no exception
to this global imperative. The nation’s developmental ambitions are inextricably
linked to the urgent need for an economically viable, environmentally sustainable
andsociallyequitablefuture.Thischapterthuscontributestothediscourseonsustain-
able development research by focusing on the role of SIA as a crucial instrument for
fostering environmental consciousness and economic resilience. This is particularly
evident in Namibia, where the transition to a green economy stands as a paramount
objective for ensuring long-term sustainability and prosperity. According to Sachs
et al. (2023), the adoption and acceptance of the UN-SDGs of Agenda 2030 aimed to
achieve the slogan “leave no one behind” (LNOB) by accomplishing 17 goals aligned
with the three sustainable pillars (see Fig. 1). Nevertheless, inefﬁcient growth in a
single nation can undermine even the most well-intentioned initiatives for sustainable
development in other regions, ultimately leading to an unsustainable planet.
The SDGs, which are a universal call to action to end poverty, protect the planet
and ensure that all people enjoy peace and prosperity, are the goals that the United
Nations(UN)isworkingoninNamibia(UN2023b).AccordingtotheUnitedNations
Development Programme (UNDP), these goals are interconnected, and addressing
themrequireseffectivepartnerships,buildingontheexperienceandresourcingstrate-
gies of partnerships (UNDP 2023). Namibia has made signiﬁcant strides in reducing
poverty and improving access to education, and the country has also taken bold
steps including the adoption of renewable energy sources to address climate change
(Nangolo 2023). However, there are still challenges that impede progress, such as
high levels of inequality and limited access to decent housing (UN-SDGs 2021; Sachs
et al. 2023). The country faces unsustainable development challenges, and addressing
An Agenda for Sustainable Development: The Role of Strategic Impact …
309
Fig. 1 The 17 UN SDGs. Source Modiﬁed from UN SDG Knowledge Platform (2023)
these issues requires a comprehensive research approach that considers the inter-
connectedness of the three SDG pillars: people, prosperity, and planet (UN-SDGs
2021).
Sustainable development is universally relevant, but its level varies by location,
direction, and evolution (see Fig. 2). Thus, countries are positioned differently on the
sustainability continuum, with developed economies prioritizing goals like reducing
greenhouse emissions while developing economies focus on issues like food provi-
sion and poverty eradication (UN-SDGs 2021). The COVID-19 pandemic has under-
scored the dynamic nature of sustainable development, where economic recovery
may sometimes come at the expense of the environment (Jensen et al. 2021). Namibia
possesses a unique opportunity to build a sustainable future through research because
it is characterized by a delicate ecological balance and a unique blend of natural
beauty and extraordinary natural resources including pristine landscapes, diverse
wildlife, and renewable energy potential (UN-SDGs 2021). Its landscapes span from
the arid deserts of Namib to the lush green banks of the Okavango River, teeming
with diverse ﬂora and fauna that best represent the chosen case study in sub-Saharan
Africa.
However, like many other nations, Namibia faces critical challenges in terms of
economic development, environmental conservation and social inclusion. Thus, its
journey towards sustainable development is a testament to the dynamics or nuances
inherent in such a transformation (UN-SDGs 2021). In other words, Namibia’s
commitment to enhancing the livelihoods of its citizens, particularly in informal
settlements within urban areas, underscores the need for inclusive and equitable
310
P. Mensah et al.
Fig. 2 The universal, dynamic, location-dependent and evolutionary nature of sustainable devel-
opment. Source Modiﬁed from Ibeh and Walmsley (2021)
development strategies. Cities are central to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Devel-
opment, and making cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and
sustainable is a key aspect of SDG 11 (UN-SDGs 2021). Moreover, existing liter-
ature, while insightful, often lacks a comprehensive analysis of the nexus between
sustainable development and the green economy in many parts of the Global South,
leaving a signiﬁcant gap in our understanding of this pressing concern. In this chapter,
we delve into the multifaceted issue of sustainable development and its impacts on
the environment, exploring its ramiﬁcations for one of the most promising and rele-
vant paradigms of our time i.e. the role of SIA on a green economy transforma-
tion for sustainable development agenda. Although the green economy is a subset
of achieving the universal sustainable development goals known as the agenda
for sustainability (UN-SDGs 2021), it represents a crucial aspect of the broader
sustainability agenda.
Therefore, the primary objective of this chapter is to unpack the relationships
between sustainable development and the green economy, highlighting the role of
SEA in promoting sustainable economic development. To achieve this objective, the
research addresses the following questions: What is the current state of Namibia’s
green economy transition and its challenges? What tools and frameworks are used
for SIA in Namibia, and how effective are they? What international case studies
offer models for SIA in Namibia? What recommendations support SIA integra-
tion for sustainable development and the green economy transition in Namibia? By
exploring these questions, the chapter utilizes documentary review and exploration
of stakeholders via interviews, speciﬁcally six ofﬁcers from three pubic ministries
i.e. two staff members in each SEA administration. The ultimate goal is to deepen
An Agenda for Sustainable Development: The Role of Strategic Impact …
311
our understanding of the complex interplay between sustainable development and a
green economy transformation, guiding us toward a more sustainable and responsible
approach to land use and spatial planning PPPs.
In the pages that follow, we unpack the concepts, challenges, opportunities, and
potential solutions to safeguarding our green economy for generations to come i.e. the
global call for sustainable development using SEA as the methodological framework.
In the context of Namibia, data for the paper was collected through secondary litera-
ture, institutional instruments, reports, and in-depth interviews with selected govern-
ment agencies purposely to comprehend how SEA is inﬂuencing land use and spatial
planning PPPs. Its analysis also draws on the challenges and prospects for transition
which could serve as the roadmap for a green economy and sustainable development
elsewhere other than Namibia. Therefore, the sections that follow provide insights
into how strategic assessments can be leveraged to support sustainable land use and
spatial planning PPPs in Namibia.
2
Strategic Environmental Assessment Framework
The concept of SIA is a powerful tool for incorporating ecological issues into PPPs
that guide nations worldwide to a green economy (Fischer and González 2021).
This approach helps to ensure that development projects consider the environ-
mental consequences of their actions and promote sustainable practices (Broman and
Robèrt 2017). By integrating sustainable development into PPPs, countries can work
together to address environmental challenges and promote a more sustainable future
(UNDP 2023). SIA offers a structured method for decision-making that considers the
economic, environmental and social impacts of a project or policy. It involves iden-
tifying potential impacts, assessing their signiﬁcance and implementing measures to
mitigate or address these impacts (Fischer and González 2021). This process helps
to ensure that development projects are designed and executed in a manner that
promotes sustainable development, meets the needs of present generations without
compromising the ability of posterity to satisfy their own needs, and contributes to
the achievement of the UN SDGs (Sachs et al. 2023).
In the United States for instance, the national environmental policy act (NEPA)
was signed into law on January 1, 1970. This legislation mandates that before making
decisions, government agencies evaluate how their proposed actions may affect the
environment (George et al. 2020). The practice of evaluating the environmental
impact of projects has evolved since the introduction of the NEPA. The SEA emerged
as an extension of environmental impact assessment (EIA) which has been effective
in enhancing development project outcomes for over four decades now (Fischer and
González 2021). However, the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Devel-
opment (OECD), noted that the application of EIA in developing countries has faced
challenges, as it tends to restrict strategic options and increase risks of environmental
degradation and unsustainable outcomes (OECD 2012). Many developing countries
have historically overlooked ecological issues in their development paths. As a result,
312
P. Mensah et al.
SEA is now recognized and promoted as an assessment tool that is applied to strategic
decision-making (Islam and Zhang 2018).
The European Union (EU) directive for SEA stipulated that 80% of EU member
states should incorporate SEA into national legislation by 2004, and many inter-
national development organizations have subsequently encouraged the practice of
SEA worldwide. SEA is now conducted formally in more than 60 countries, and
legislation is being formulated in various developing countries to integrate SEA into
their policy-making and planning processes (OECD 2012). The need for sustainable
or green economies is emphasized, with SEA playing a role in evaluating envi-
ronmental aspects of socio-economic development towards ensuring sound environ-
mental management. It is noted that a green economy involves changes in production
and consumption patterns, emphasizing efﬁcient use of natural resources, preserva-
tion of environmental quality, and addressing social inequities (Cooper et al. 2020).
In response to the global push for green economy development, various initiatives
and institutional frameworks have emerged within international and national polit-
ical economies as the core principles of sustainable development i.e. SIA framework
(Wanner 2015).
In Africa, a green economy aims to achieve inclusive economic growth through
sustainable infrastructure investments, efﬁcient resource utilization, food security
enhancement, and resilience building against natural disasters through SIA legisla-
tion (African Development Bank 2018; Fischer and González 2021). African coun-
tries including Rwanda, Ethiopia, Kenya, and South Africa are actively pursuing
green growth strategies to address resource efﬁciency, ecological concerns and social
equity (Cooper et al. 2020). The United Nations Economic Commission for Africa
(UNECA), stated that Rwanda and Ethiopia in particular are committed to compre-
hensive green growth strategies, and they are among the fastest-growing economies
in Africa (UNECA 2023). Namibia is also committed to building a sustainable future
aligned with various initiatives and institutional frameworks. This paper thus delves
into understanding the pivotal role of SIA in promoting Namibia’s transition to a
green economy for sustainable development.
Globally, it is increasingly becoming evident that the philosophy for SIA legis-
lation on a green economy promotes long-term sustainable development. Namibia,
a nation endowed with a wealth of natural resources, holds enormous potential to
pioneer this transition within the African context. Thus, the nexus between the drivers
of SIA and the green economy has signiﬁcant implications for sustainable develop-
ment in the country (see Fig. 3). This paper presents a review of SIA legislation in
Namibia within the context of the UN SDGs. This serves as an assessment of the
obstacles in the way of accomplishing the SDGs and an examination of the poten-
tial beneﬁt that might result from using best practice SIA as a tool to help Namibia
achieve the SDGs (see Table 1).
Table 1 presents a summary of how Namibia is fairing concerning the 17 SDGs,
adopted from the 2023 UN SDGs report. According to Sachs et al. (2023), out
of the 17 goals, Namibia is only on course to maintain or meet Goals 5, 13 and
15 i.e. gender equality, climate action and life on land respectively. Despite some
improvements, Namibia is behind other countries in most other aspects of the SDGs.

Contrary to the UN slogan of LNOB, Namibia seems to be struggling to meet various
SDG targets due to militating factors. These include data issues, conﬂict, governance
issues and weak institutions, ﬁnance, climate change, demographics and migration
(Ibeh and Walmsley 2021). According to the 2023 UN-SDGs report, Namibia ranks
109 out of 166 nations with a 64.3% SDG index score and 89.7% spillover score
which shows a good positive correlation between the development of SIA legislation
and green economy transformation for sustainable development (Sachs et al. 2023).
This implies that in order to integrate the SDGs with the SIA process, the three-
dimensional pillars—which deﬁne goals, design procedures, create deadlines, and
formulate and carry out choices to reach targets for the proactive creation of attainable
sustainable outcomes—are necessary. This means making certain that plans, policies,
and programs are in line with the SDGs’ ambition for transformative change. As a
result, activities to meet targets for socio-economic goals, environmental betterment
and restoration are in line with the targeted results of SIA.
