Existing institutional reports, legislative instruments and literature reviewed do
not explicitly address the presence of SIA or SEA frameworks within Namibia’s
existing PPPs for green economy transformation and sustainable development in
land use and spatial planning. This reality notwithstanding, it is evident that Namibia
is actively engaged in initiatives that are aligned with the principles of SEA. These
include the following: legal basis for SEA; terms of reference (ToR); choice of
consultants; screening and scoping; participation and public consultation; presenta-
tion of SEA; alternatives and cumulative effects; synergies and antagonisms; period,
timing and duration for conducting an SEA; the strategic perspective; the inﬂuence of
SEA; contentious issues; mitigation, monitoring and sustainability issues; and costs
(Hipondoka et al. 2016; Ibeh and Walmsley 2021). These principles of SEA underpin
the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats discussed in the next section, its
role in a green economy transformation and sustainable development agenda.
3
Trends in Green Economy for Sustainable Development
Namibia is transitioning towards a green economy, with various policies and initia-
tivesimplementedbythegovernmenttopromotesustainabledevelopmentandreduce
environmental risks (Lubinda 2015). Key aspects of this transition include policies
and initiatives, renewable energy adoption, waste management, and sustainable agri-
culture. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), the Namibian
government has identiﬁed green jobs as a strategic pillar for job creation in the
revised Namibian employment policy, launched in October 2013 (ILO 2014a). The
World Economic Forum (WEF), afﬁrmed that the policy aims to create increased and
decent employment opportunities in the green economy. Namibia is exploring the
potential of renewable energy sources such as hydrogen, to grow its economy and
reduce its emissions by 91% (WEF 2021). The country is also working on improving
the renewable energy value chain in the Southern African region (Lubinda 2015).
The government is focusing on improving waste management practices, intending
to reduce environmental pollution and promote sustainable development (Lubinda
2015). Sustainable agriculture is another aspect of the green economy in Namibia,
with the potential for further growth in the future (Lubinda 2015). However, during
the transition process, Namibia faces various challenges and barriers such as the need
for a behavior change and increased responsibility in using natural resources sustain-
ably (Lubinda 2015). Additionally, the country needs to address structural chal-
lenges and constraints to achieve sustainable growth and diversiﬁcation opportunities
(Growth Lab 2023).
316
P. Mensah et al.
3.1
Strategies and Policies for Sustainable Development
Namibia has made signiﬁcant progress towards sustainable development, with
various policies and strategies implemented to promote economic, environmental and
social sustainability (UN-SDGs 2021). Key strategies and policies needed to promote
sustainable development in Namibia include national development plans, sustain-
able development goals, partnerships, and international best practices (see Table 2).
The ﬁfth National Development Plan (NDP5) focuses on economic progression,
social transformation, environmental sustainability, and good governance, which are
comprehensively integrated into the SDG pillars of people, prosperity, planet, peace,
and partnership (UN-SDGs 2021). Namibia has committed to achieving the SDGs,
which are a universal call to action to end poverty, protect the planet, and ensure that
all people enjoy peace and prosperity (Nangolo 2023). The country has prioritized the
SDG targets for 2030 and is working towards their implementation (Nangolo 2023).
Effective partnerships are however needed to address systemic and other develop-
ment challenges in the nation (UN 2023a). Thus, the UN Partnership Framework for
Namibia is an example of a strategic approach for UN cooperation to support sustain-
able development in the country (UN 2023a). Namibia can learn from international
best practices and experiences to promote sustainable development. These include
promoting sustainable practices in public procurement, strengthening scientiﬁc and
technological capacity, and enhancing capacity-building support to developing coun-
tries (UNDP 2023). However, the feasibility and effectiveness of these strategies
in the Namibian context depend on various factors such as the country’s political,
economic, and social conditions. Additionally, challenges such as limited access to
development assistance, informal settlements, and dissatisfaction with government
efforts to promote sustainable agriculture and combat climate change need to be
addressed (UN-SDGs 2021; Nangolo 2023).
3.2
Impact of Strategies on Namibia’s Economy,
Environment and Society
The transition to a green economy in Namibia has the potential to bring about signif-
icant economic beneﬁts and opportunities. The green economy is deﬁned as an
economy that results in improved human well-being and social equity, while signiﬁ-
cantly reducing environmental risks (Lubinda 2015). Examples of the green economy
in Namibia include sustainable agriculture, the trade of non-timber forestry prod-
ucts, ﬁsheries, waste management, renewable energy and sustainable tourism. Future
expansion is possible for these industries, which are also rather eco-friendly (Lubinda
2015). One of the key economic beneﬁts of the transition to a green economy is the
potential for job creation and income generation in green sectors. Namibia’s updated
employment policy speciﬁcally “the green jobs” as a strategic pillar for job develop-
ment, and the need for a broad variety of skills in the context of the green economy

both domestically and internationally is rising (ILO 2014b). A green jobs assess-
ment, which will be used to prioritize and inform Namibia’s development goals and
policy interventions toward better job creation in the transition to a green economy,
will give empirical information on the country’s potential for creating green employ-
ment (ILO 2014a). In addition to job creation, the transition to a green economy can
also lead to ﬁnancial investments that are required to support the growth of green
sectors. For example, the Government of Namibia is focusing on the potential of
green energy to grow its economy and has pledged to reduce its carbon emissions
by 91% over a certain period i.e. the next ﬁve years (WEF 2021). This will require
signiﬁcant ﬁnancial investments in renewable energy infrastructure and other green
technologies. However, these investments are expected to yield a positive return on
investment in the form of reduced environmental risks, improved human well-being,
and sustainable economic growth.
The transition to a green economy, including the promotion of renewable energy
and sustainable practices, also has the potential to signiﬁcantly reduce greenhouse
gas emissions and other pollutants in Namibia. This is particularly important given
the country’s vulnerability to the impact of climate change, as evidenced by excep-
tional ﬂooding and the negative impact on sustainable development (Herunga 2023).
According to the World Wildlife Fund (WWF), the transition to a green economy
can have a positive impact on biodiversity conservation and land-use practices in
Namibia. For example, sustainable agriculture and land management practices can
help preserve natural habitats and protect biodiversity, while also promoting sustain-
able economic development (WWF 2023). The transition to a green economy can
also contribute to the mitigation of climate change and the adaptation to its effects
in Namibia. For example, the government is ﬁnalizing a national strategy on adap-
tation and mitigation to climate change, which will help guide the country’s efforts
to address the impacts of climate change and promote sustainable development
(Herunga 2023).
Besides economic and environmental impacts, the green economy can contribute
to improvements in public health, access to clean water, and sanitation. For example,
Namibia has made progress in providing access to safe drinking water in both rural
and urban areas, with an average access rate of 98% (UN-SDGs 2021). The transition
to a green economy can further improve access to clean water and sanitation for all
citizens. The green economy in Namibia is expected to be inclusive and equitable,
addressing poverty and inequality. The transition to a green economy can create
opportunities for a wide range of skills within the context of sustainable development,
beneﬁting current and future generations (Lubinda 2015). Thus, the green economy
calls for a behavior change and increased responsibility in using natural resources
sustainably (Lubinda 2015). This transformation can lead to a more sustainable and
equitable society, where all citizens are aware of the importance of preserving the
environment and natural resources for sustainable development.
An Agenda for Sustainable Development: The Role of Strategic Impact …
319
3.3
Role of Strategic Impact Assessment in Guiding
Sustainable Development
The role of SIA in guiding sustainable development is crucial, as it helps to eval-
uate the environmental consequences of proposed policies, plans, and programs. This
ensures they are fully addressed and appropriately managed at the earliest appropriate
stage of decision-making, alongside economic and social considerations (UNDP
2013). However, the review of current impact assessment methodologies provides
a systematic and transparent approach to evaluating the environmental impacts of
proposed PPPs. It also helps decision-makers incorporate environmental and other
sustainability objectives in the formulation of these PPPs. Moreover, it facilitates the
gathering and analysis of information necessary for sound decision-making including
inputs from relevant stakeholders (UNDP 2013). Despite the numerous strengths of
SIA, its weaknesses emanate from limited resources and capacity, especially in devel-
oping countries when conducting comprehensive impact assessments. There is also
lack of stakeholder engagement and participation in the impact assessment process as
well as insufﬁcient integration of social and economic aspects in the assessment (Del-
Campo et al. 2020). Impact assessment can be effective in guiding policy-making
and decision-making processes by providing a comprehensive understanding of the
potential environmental, social, and economic impacts of proposed PPPs. These
facilitate the evaluation of signiﬁcant environmental and health effects of strategic
options and proposed actions while setting conditions for environmentally sound
implementation of strategic decisions (UNDP 2013).
4
Syntheses and Observations
Namibia has undertaken voluntary SEAs between 2008 and 2013, although it is
not yet a legal mandate (Hipondoka et al. 2016). Additionally, National Planning
Commission (NPC), asserted that the country is ﬁnalizing a national strategy on
adaptation and mitigation to climate change, which may involve strategic impact
assessment (NPC 2023). Therefore, the theoretical value of the interplay between the
development of SIA legislation and the green economy transformation for sustainable
development in Namibia is compelling. SIA is an important element of Namibian
transition to a green economy which ensures the attainment of sustainable devel-
opment outcomes. For instance, the underpinned study through in-depth interviews
revealed the key principles for SIA initiatives (see Table 3).
A correlation was established by the majority of participants between national
land use policies and plans, and regional and local plans. Nevertheless, the majority
of respondents were unsure of the relationship between land use and spatial PPPs and
other sectoral PPPs, such as housing, waste management, forestry, and water supply.

5
Implications and Conclusion
The shift to a green economy has the ability to mitigate risks to the economy, society,
and environment while also enhancing all economic sectors in a sustainable manner.
Such a shift is pertinent for Namibia, a nation that is extremely sensitive to the
effects of climate change because it depends heavily on the natural environment for
its survival. The study’s ﬁndings demonstrate that Namibia’s SIA laws have a great
deal of promise for greening the country’s economy. Therefore, it is crucial that
policymakers implement plans that may both help address the dangers and vulner-
abilities and help capitalize on the possibilities and strengths. Thus, the potential
improvements or recommendations for a more robust impact assessment framework
in guiding sustainable development entail four main ways. First, it is important to
enhance stakeholder engagement and participation in the impact assessment process
to ensure a more inclusive and transparent approach (Del-Campo et al. 2020). Second,
the social and economic aspects should be integrated more effectively in the assess-
ment, recognizing the interdependence between environmental, social, and economic
factors (OECD 2012). Third, the capacity of governments and stakeholders should
be strengthened to conduct comprehensive impact assessments, especially in devel-
oping countries (Del-Campo et al. 2020). And ﬁnally, the use of strategic impact
assessment should be promoted as a tool for development PPPs, recognizing its
potential beneﬁts in promoting sustainable development (UNDP 2013). In conclu-
sion, SIA plays a crucial role in guiding sustainable development by evaluating the
environmental consequences of proposed PPPs. However, there are strengths and
weaknesses in current impact assessment methodologies, and improvements can be
madetoenhancetheeffectivenessofimpactassessmentinguidingpolicy-makingand
decision-making processes. By addressing these weaknesses and implementing the
recommended improvements, the impact assessment framework can become more
robust and effective in promoting sustainable development.

The Role of Urban Design in Achieving
the UN SDGs
Şebnem Hoşkara and Özge Selen Koç
Abstract The impact of growing inequality and poverty among nations on spatial
and social concerns has become critical, leading to environmental and humanitarian
crises like pollution, resource depletion, and unemployment, which hinder urban
development and sustainable growth. Addressing climate issues is urgent due to
their global repercussions, prompting a search for comprehensive solutions globally.
Various action plans and agendas, from Our Common Future to the 2030 Agenda, aim
to enhance quality of life through environmental awareness, development strategies,
technological innovation, and social structure change. Existing research provides a
framework to examine how the 2030 Agenda and Sustainable Development Goals
(SDGs) serve as tools for sustainable urban development. However, there is insuf-
ﬁcient data on how urban design dimensions and objectives interact with SDGs,
which is critical for urban sustainability. This research aims to propose a supple-
mentary methodological framework for analyzing, graphically representing, and
assessing the impact of urban design on SDGs. It demonstrates an integrated assess-
ment framework for addressing urban design’s multidimensionality in a structured
manner, revealing its role in achieving the SDGs. The methodology involves a litera-
ture review of relevant documents on sustainable development processes, goals, and
urban design dimensions and objectives to analyze and evaluate the impact of urban
design on SDGs using qualitative research methods. The collected data underwent
cross-concept analysis incorporating rankings and narratives. The discussion then
focuses on how SDGs are embedded in urban design through coding.
Keywords 2030 agenda · Sustainable development goals (SDGs) · Urban design ·
Urban design dimensions

1
Introduction
The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development stands as a comprehensive strategy
aimed at fostering prosperity while respecting the environment and its inhabitants.
This universal and inclusive agenda, centered on human rights, offers a transfor-
mative and integrated action plan for nations, United Nations organizations, and
various stakeholders. Aligned with the principles of sustainability, the 2030 Agenda
encompasses a set of goals designed to ensure the well-being of both people and the
planet. It presents new opportunities for the built environment to prioritize sustain-
ability and adapt to future challenges. Furthermore, the Agenda promotes global
peace, aims to eradicate poverty, and addresses inequalities within and between
countries. To achieve its objectives, the 2030 Agenda emphasizes coordinated and
comprehensive sustainable development across economic, social, and environmental
dimensions. It builds upon the achievements of the Millennium Development Goals
while endeavoring to address unﬁnished challenges.
Central to the Agenda are the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and
their associated targets, forming a shared action plan of unprecedented scope. These
goals,focusingonpeople,theplanet,prosperity,partnership,andpeace,seektocreate
conditions conducive to meeting basic human needs and fostering progress in areas
such as industry and innovation. Despite the collaborative spirit encouraged by the
SDGs, some disciplines, such as architecture, urban design, and urban planning, have
not always been fully recognized for their role in achieving sustainability objectives.
While often associated with SDG 11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities), these
disciplines play a crucial role in advancing all SDGs with a holistic perspective.
Accordingly, the primary aim of this research is to explore the role of urban
design in achieving the SDGs and their targets. Speciﬁcally, the paper will examine
how urban design can contribute to harmonizing three core elements of sustainable
development: economic growth, social inclusion, and environmental protection. In
the context of rapid technological and industrial advancements, urban design has
emerged as a critical tool for addressing ecological imbalances and preserving natural
resources. It entails the creation of successful places that prioritize consistency and
balance between urban planning and architectural disciplines, thereby enhancing the
quality of life. While existing research provides a framework for understanding the
relationship between the 2030 Agenda, SDGs, and urban development, there remains
a gap in understanding the interaction between urban design principles and SDG
targets. Addressing this gap is crucial for ensuring sustainable urban development
and shaping the future of cities.
The Role of Urban Design in Achieving the UN SDGs
329
2
Concept of Sustainability
Sustainability is a concept that encompasses social issues such as poverty and health
problems, as well as environmental challenges such as climate change and biodi-
versity loss. It is concerned with making decisions about these issues. Sustainable
development should be considered a crucial step in human progress. The concept of
sustainable development was introduced in the 1987 report “Our Common Future”
by the World Commission on Environment and Development. The United Nations
Conference on Environment and Development converted it into a comprehensive
theoretical system with “Agenda 21” in 1992, and it was recognized as a common
approach in most countries. The Brundtland Report stated that poverty, unsustainable
consumption, and production habits were inﬂuential in bringing sustainable devel-
opment to the agenda. To solve critical environmental and socioeconomic-based
problems, the report combined development and environmental issues, which called
for the creation of a concept of sustainable development to develop joint solution
proposals. The report deﬁnes sustainable development as “a development that meets
the needs of today without compromising the ability of future generations to meet
theirownneeds”(WCED1987:15–17).Accordingtothereport,povertyisexpanding
rapidly, technology and social progress are limiting people’s lives, and sustainable
development will provide an opportunity to meet everyone’s basic needs and fulﬁll
desires for a better life as a solution proposal. Although sustainable development is
deﬁned in many ways, it is considered a method aimed at promoting awareness of
society’s environmental, social, and economic concerns and addressing needs in this
direction. The outcomes of sustainable development are not always predictable in
a particular order. It is a processed product, and through experiential learning, this
process has formed a dynamic structure. For this purpose, it is a solution-producing
approach that chooses the best available way that beneﬁts everyone. The dynamic
structure of sustainable development includes adopting and implementing sustain-
able development principles in all areas for different organizations, policies, opera-
tions, and people. The requirement for equality between other groups, sectors, and
generations is at the core of the sustainable development approach.
Moreover, generational equality can also be assembled with a better expression.
While emphasizing the importance of intergenerational equality, people belonging to
different political, economic, social, and geographical contexts must have the same
rights. The scope of the concept of sustainable development has primarily been
focused on environmental issues and ecological concerns and gained increasing
prominence as a source of inspiration for many kinds of research over time, and
thus can be managed to answer the question of what the dimensions of sustainable
development are. It is recognized that growth through sustainable development must
be both an inclusive participatory and environmentally friendly process to reduce
poverty, establish shared prosperity for those living on earth, respond to human
needs, environmental sustainability, human rights, and partnerships, and continue to
meet the needs of future generations. As a result, the three key pillars of sustain-
able development were highlighted: economic growth, environmental management,
330
¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
and social inclusion. Although sustainable development encompasses all sectors of
development, considering the impact of urban design on the environment and social
behavior, it might be regarded as one of the essential tools for achieving sustainable
development. The most recent attempt in this direction is the Agenda 2030 mani-
festo, adopted in 2015. The central theme of Agenda 2030 is “no one is left behind,”
in line with this purpose, 17 Sustainable Development Goals and 169 Targets have
been set.
2.1
Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)
Unlike the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), the SDGs provide a more
speciﬁc and comprehensive perspective on such problems and respond to the human
and natural system needs from a broader point of view (Kumar et al. 2016). In
this regard, a comprehensive and integrative common understanding has emerged to
answer these concerns. Thus, the SDGs have provided the opportunity to create a
common language around ﬁve main themes (people, planet, prosperity, peace, and
partnerships) that all countries and communities can use. The SDGs also provide a
better connection and utilization of sustainable development’s economic, social, and
environmental dimensions and an opportunity to initiate systemic change toward
a more sustainable future. It has been predicted that the SDGs will substantially
impact policy, capital ﬂows, and development policies since their publication. The
aims of the agenda seem to be more comprehensive than those of earlier develop-
ment initiatives because they consider the international community, including corpo-
rations, non-governmental organizations, and research institutions, directly respon-
sible for achieving development. Thus, it has been observed that attaining these goals
builds the framework for new partnerships between the business, public, and research
sectors. After adopting the agenda, researchers have generally focused on exploring,
analyzing, and examining the SDGs and their interactions with other disciplines
and implementation experience. According to Sachs (2012), a solid problem-solving
network should be proposed to ensure sustainable development, including univer-
sities, companies, non-governmental organizations, governments, and, most impor-
tantly, the world’s younger generation. SDGs’ inclusive and integrative approaches
have been further developed. After the participation of different sectors and genera-
tions was mentioned, the involvement of different socioeconomic groups also became
increasingly important. Kumi et al. (2014) highlighted three main concerns in their
work and aimed to use them as a guideline for operational policies aligned with the
SDGs. First, when it comes to poor communities, the focus should be on the pro-
poverty rather than the traditional pro-growth. Then equality should be identiﬁed as a
serious concern, and lastly, the concerns and problems of these communities should
be responded to with appropriate actions taken in this direction. (Bai et al. 2016).
Jayasuriya’s study (2001) emphasized the evolving role of social workers in
promoting social equity and development. She argued that social workers must
broaden their scope to include responsibilities related to economic development,
The Role of Urban Design in Achieving the UN SDGs
331
human rights, and environmental sustainability. This perspective aligns with the
principles later outlined in the SDGs, which provide a comprehensive framework
for addressing socioeconomic disparities and ensuring equal access to opportunities
and resources.
The agenda of the SDGs has signiﬁcantly impacted social roles and equity,
particularly in the ﬁeld of social work. Recent studies highlight the importance
of expanding social workers’ responsibilities to encompass social and economic
development, human rights, and environmental sustainability. According to Jones
and Truell (2012), the SDGs provide a comprehensive framework that addresses
issues of socioeconomic division and promotes equal access and outcomes. This
expanded scope of social work is crucial for effectively tackling contemporary global
challenges and fostering a more equitable society.
Many studies have attempted to provide a comprehensive overview and integrated
approach to implementing the SDGs. Accordingly, many different partnerships are
required (Kroll et al. 2019), and Stafford-Smith et al. (2016) drew attention to the
linkage between three main areas: sectors, agencies, and countries. According to the
Future World of Science overview’s sustainability practice, the 17 SDGs should cover
seven categories to develop these links: ﬁnancial, technology, competence, political
integrity, partnerships, and the application of data, monitoring, and accountability in
the data ﬁeld.
On the other hand, Caiado et al. (2018) criticized the comprehensive review of
the existing literature and the role of individual urban areas in achieving the SDGs.
According to them, the differences in the needs and experiences of the urban space
caused difﬁculties in achieving the SDG goals. They also emphasized the role of
information technology in addressing SDGs’ targets, concentrating on aspects of
sustainability science and information management, as well as their applications and
linkages. As a result, the research recommended several methods to address some of
the challenges affecting the implementation of the 17 SDGs while focusing on the
gaps in the ﬁeld. In this perspective, by 2030, practically all issues will be addressed
through implementing goals (17 goals), targets (169 targets), and indicators. When
considering the 17 SDGs adopted by UN countries in 2015 (Fig. 1), it becomes
evident that most goals and targets are inextricably linked to urban design strate-
gies, with the 17 goals collectively aiming to “make cities and human settlements
inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable.“ These goals underscore the signiﬁcance of
sustainableurbandevelopment,disasterriskreduction,sustainabletransportsystems,
and inclusive urbanization. For instance, creating green spaces, improving public
transportation networks, and promoting participatory urban planning processes are
crucial measures that contribute to environmental sustainability and social equity
within urban settings. Consequently, urban design strategies are paramount in effec-
tively implementing the SDGs, as they demonstrate their crucial role in addressing
contemporary global challenges.

¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
Fig. 1 The 17 sustainable development goals (https://worldslargestlesson.globalgoals.org/)
3
Urban Design and Its Dimensions
Urban design has been recognized as a signiﬁcant ﬁeld within the city planning
and design professions since the 1960s. Urban design concepts and practices have
progressed into a specialized and effective profession that merges planning, archi-
tecture, and landscape architecture. The classiﬁcation of urban design is further
complex by its wide range of activities, ranging from minor neighborhood improve-
ments and design to large-scale development projects, community strategies, and
even regional networks. Urban design is an important concept that requires inter-
disciplinary collaboration and should promote physical and social integrity. Thus,
urban design is generally conducted by groups of people with various specializa-
tions and ideologies. As a response to increasing health, housing, transportation,
and other urban crises, modern urban design theory emerged in the late 1920s. The
Congress Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne, or CIAM, was founded in 1928
by Le Corbusier and other architects and planners to examine subjects and models
for contemporary, rational city development. Their criticisms were primarily philo-
sophic and strategic concerns on what a city should be based on theory and assump-
tion rather than understanding people’s interactions with their surroundings. Unfor-
tunately, largescale urban regeneration and theoretical models failed due to a lack
of human aspects and strict rules when new contemporary urbanism models were
applied. Considering the neglected part of these theoretical urban design models,
researchers such as Jane Jacobs, Edward Hall, and Lewis Mumford led to a discus-
sion on the impact of the physical environment on community life. Gordon Cullen in
his book Townscape (Cullen 1961) established that combining buildings, streets,
and open spaces is more signiﬁcant than single architectural monuments in shaping
our perception of urban values. Then, Kevin Lynch in his book The Image of the
The Role of Urban Design in Achieving the UN SDGs
333
City (Lynch 1960) and others introduced theories that allowed designers to concep-
tualize and visualize greater urban forms and landscape-scaled components. In light
of these 1960 and 1970s perspectives, research approaches and methodology estab-
lishedastrongbaseforurbandesigntheoryandpractice.However,themainchallenge
was that discipline was still considered expert-focused.
While urban design was inﬂuential in transforming a wide variety of public
realms into physical development, there needed to be a participatory decision-making
process to examine the implications of physical design solutions regarding shared
values and objectives. As a result, the role of urban design in the planning process
has increased in recent years, emphasizing the necessity for interdisciplinary struc-
tured action for the future of cities. The inﬂuence of social variables in urban design
should be examined to create human-oriented environments and improve existing
ones. Urban design is a ﬁeld of study that requires creating a strategy for a commu-
nity and mobilizing all skills and resources to bring that vision to life. The growth
of the urban population and the diversiﬁcation of individual needs over time, as
well as the fact that these changes will continue in the future, have demonstrated
the signiﬁcance of the time dimension in the urban design process (Elshater 2012).
The concern that cities will experience due to the high quality of life and living
standards that will emerge in the coming years strengthens the importance of urban
design (Yeang 2000). The signiﬁcance of urban design in investigating and solving
problems in cities is expanding in response to the continuing growth of cities, the
rapid increase in population, and the continuation of development. The difﬁculties of
the uncontrollability of cities caused by rapid urbanization are insufﬁcient to respond
to the methods used in urban design.
Cities are constantly changing due to expanding population and built environ-
ment daily, and by responding to these changes, they create a development pattern.
The discipline of urban design has emerged to maximize people’s living standards
and conditions. When the process of urban planning is examined, the main aim
of each pioneer is to raise living conditions and improve living environments. The
basic principle of urban design results from this relationship between people and
their meaningful environment. This section categorized urban design into six dimen-
sions according to Matthew Carmona’s classiﬁcation in his book Public Places—
Urban Spaces (Carmona and Wunderlich 2013; Carmona 2021). These dimensions
are components of a whole. For this research, the dimensions of urban design are
distributed in eight main sections—morphological dimension, perceptual dimen-
sion, social dimension, visual dimension, functional dimension, temporal dimension,
design governance, and place production—with brief explanations and then matched
with the SDGs.
334
¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
4
Methodological Approach
This research endeavored to provide a framework for examining how the SDGs
and the 2030 Agenda serve as instruments for sustainable urban development. The
study sought to categorize the SDGs’ dimensions and elements according to speciﬁc
criteria and to determine their relative signiﬁcance in the theory and practice of urban
design. In this context, the study was conducted in the following stages (Fig. 2):
In the initial stage of the study, theoretical and documentary research was
conducted through a literature review to understand and explore the concepts under
study: urban design and the SDGs. This review utilized the databases Google Scholar,
Web of Science, and JSTOR, with a majority of sources from Routledge. The
keywords “urban design”, “sustainable development goals”, “SDGs”, “urban plan-
ning”, and “sustainability” were applied to identify relevant literature. The search
was limited to 34 relevant books, book reviews, reports, and articles, along with
one primary source (Appendix 1). The selected articles were among the most cited
primary sources, and similar content articles were excluded from the evaluation. The
articles were generally categorized into two groups: theoretical approaches to urban
design and practical application areas.
In the second step of the process, the collected data on urban design and the 169
targets of SDGs were interconnected through a coding system created through a
comprehensive literature review. This involves identifying keywords for each SDG
using concepts (Appendix 2). Subsequently, the generated codes were utilized to
analyze the data through the MaxQDA qualitative data analysis software to determine
the relationship between the two concepts. The concept of urban design, through its
dimensions and elements, was incorporated into the analysis software in the form
of written text, and data were collected on whether the codes deﬁned for the SDGs
existed in these texts and, if so, how many times they were repeated.
Fig. 2 Research process stages
The Role of Urban Design in Achieving the UN SDGs
335
In the third step of the process, the assessment matrix (Table 1) categorized the
critical elements of urban design dimensions (in the ﬁrst two columns), aiming to
determine the consistency of each category with the 17 SDGs (the ﬁrst row). Whether
directly or indirectly, elements that could meet the SDGs were identiﬁed and color-
coded according to their social, economic, and environmental impacts. Red denoted
the social impact, blue signiﬁed the economic impact, and green represented the envi-
ronmental impact. Yellow was used to represent SDG 11 speciﬁcally, as it encom-
passed all the keywords of the targets and showed a similarity between 88 and 96%
in terms of application and theory. Different shades of red, blue, and green were
utilized to indicate the varying levels of relevance of the urban design elements to
the SDG targets. Light shades represented low relevance (7–37%), medium shades
indicated moderate relevance (37–63%), and dark shades signiﬁed high relevance
(63–100%).
In the section where evaluations of the results were prepared, separate matrices
were constructed to illustrate the relationship between each dimension and the SDGs
based on the data obtained from the analysis tool regarding code repetition. The
content of the code system for each dimension was developed by considering the
deﬁnitions of concepts in previous studies, as well as ﬁndings and examples of appli-
cations in urban areas. For instance, speciﬁc codes were created for each SDG to
Table 1 Complete criteria for evaluating the SDGs and urban design dimensions in the matrix
format
336
¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
determine the relationship between urban design dimensions and SDGs based on the
source Public Places, Urban Spaces: The Dimensions of Urban Design by Carmona
et al. (2003). SDG 1 was coded as A1 and included elements such as poverty, social
protection, inequality, and vulnerable groups. SDG 2 was coded as A2, focusing on
food security, agriculture, nutrition, sustainable farming, and resilient crop produc-
tion. Similarly, SDG 3 was coded as A3, encompassing health, well-being, disease
prevention, universal health coverage, and maternal and child health. These codes
facilitated the analysis by aligning urban design dimensions with relevant SDG
targets, providing a structured approach to assess their interconnections.
The codes representing the dimensions and ﬁndings from the literature review
were evaluated using the qualitative analysis tool MaxQDA. The relationship of
each dimension to the SDGs was rated from 1 (minimum) to 8 (maximum). The
codes were added to the code system via Excel, and the number of matches was
extracted. Thus, 1 represents the lowest relation level, while 8 represents the highest.
Studying each urban design dimension related to the SDGs made evaluating urban
design’s overall relationship to the SDGs possible. Accordingly, each dimension of
urban design has been explored and discussed in relation to the SDGs through the
developed ranking system and narratively, focusing on the social, economic, and
environmental dimensions of sustainable development. All this analysis has also
been presented visually in ﬁgures.
5
Relationship Between Urban Design Dimensions
and the SDGs
5.1
Morphological Dimension and the SDGs
To ensure the functionality, aesthetics, and continuity of urban areas, the morpho-
logical dimension focuses on the conﬁguration of land and streets within the city and
region, land utilization, and the physical characteristics and organization of build-
ings. In this context, fundamental urban design decisions, such as suitable housing,
parks, green spaces, educational centers, libraries, agricultural and commercial areas,
and infrastructure development in urban areas, become effective methods to achieve
SDGs. These goals encompass concerns ranging from urban form and characteristics,
urban and regional land uses, and street scale to the physical attributes of buildings.
The initial evaluation matrix, which assesses the morphological dimension, has
unveiled the following key ﬁndings: SDG11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities)
emerges as the most pertinent goal, trailed by SDG9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infras-
tructure), SDG7 (Affordable and Clean Energy), SDG6 (Clean Water and Sanitation),
SDG13 (Climate Action), and then SDG15 (Life on Land). SDG7 (Affordable and
Clean Energy), SDG6 (Clean Water and Sanitation), and SDG13 (Climate Action)
are highlighted based on concerns regarding energy efﬁciency and infrastructure.
Subsequently, SDG15 (Life on Land) is underscored for its focus on protecting and
The Role of Urban Design in Achieving the UN SDGs
337
Fig. 3 Correlation between the morphological dimension of urban design and the SDGs
restoring green spaces, followed by SDG10 (Reduced Inequality) due to concerns
about diminishing social disparities. The table shows other SDGs directly or indi-
rectly related (Fig. 3). As a result of the examination of the morphological dimension,
it was concluded that 62.5% (Score: 5) of the data in the relevant code system was
related to the SDGs.
Therefore, appropriate land use, environmentally friendly building structures,
sustainable infrastructure, green spaces, and community-oriented social arrange-
ments are essential for achieving the SDGs.
5.2
Perceptual Dimension and the SDGs
The perceptual dimension, encompassing elements such as the sense and under-
standing of the city and how people use it, is rooted in individual and community
experiences. It is related to the unique characteristics of the place, including its
cultural and historical heritage, natural environment, and human interaction. In this
context, urban concerns such as preserving the unique identities of cities, sustaining
cultural heritage, and clarifying the relationship between spaces should be recognized
as effective methods for achieving SDGs.
Intheperceptual dimensionandSDGrelationships addressedinthesecondassess-
ment matrix, SDG11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities) emerged as the most rele-
vant goal, followed by SDG16 (Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions) and SDG17
(Partnership for the Goals). This is due to decisions supporting the relationship
338
¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
Fig. 4 Relationship between the perceptual dimension of urban design and the SDGs
between governments, civil society organizations, and the private sector, with the
principle of transparent and equal services for all, thereby supporting the creation of
urban areas designed according to the needs of society. These goals are followed by
SDG3 (Good Health and Well-Being), SDG4 (Quality Education), SDG5 (Gender
Equality), and SDG10 (Reducing Inequality). These goals are driven by concerns
aboutsafeaccesstogreenspacesandessentialservices,increasedaccesstoeducation,
and establishing libraries and education centers to promote awareness and a sense
of belonging. Subsequently, SDG8 (Decent Work and Economic Growth) stands out
due to the impact of accessibility, employment, and economic growth. At the same
time, SDG14 (Life below Water) and SDG15 (Life on Land) are the most relevant
targets due to people’s sense of belonging to the local ecosystem and the natural
environment in their regions. The table indicates other SDGs that are partly directly
or indirectly related. Based on the examination of the dimension, it was concluded
that it is related to the SDGs at a rate of 50% (score: 4), according to the data in the
relevant code system (Fig. 4).
5.3
Social Dimension and the SDGs
The primary goal of addressing the social dimension is to design urban areas to
enhance community life, promote social interaction, and reduce social inequalities.
It promotes equal opportunities and access to resources for all segments of society
in the city and includes essential elements affecting community participation and
The Role of Urban Design in Achieving the UN SDGs
339
Fig. 5 Relationship between the social dimension of urban design and the SDGs
well-being. Concerns such as accessible and usable parks, streets, alleys, and urban
green spaces, the organization of transportation systems, and the development of
solidarity are also addressed. In this context, urban issues such as community partic-
ipation, equality of opportunity and resources, and well-being should be recognized
as effective means of achieving SDGs. SDG11 (Sustainable Cities and Communi-
ties) was identiﬁed as the most relevant goal due to the role of public space provi-
sion in community interaction. At the same time, SDG3 (Good Health and Well
Being), SDG4 (Quality Education), SDG5 (Gender Equality), and SDG10 (Reduced
Inequality) were highlighted due to concerns such as increasing access to accessible
green spaces, health, and education services, and other essential resources. Then,
with a focus on social inclusion, justice, security, civil society engagement, accessible
transportation, employment, andeconomicgrowthincentives, SDG7(Affordableand
Clean Energy), SDG8 (Decent Work and Economic Growth), SDG16 (Peace, Justice,
and Strong Institutions), and SDG17 (Partnership for the Goals) were pursued. The
third matrix table shows the other SDGs to which it is directly or indirectly related.
Based on the data in the code system, this dimension is highly relevant to the SDGs,
scoring 7 out of 8 (87.5%) (Fig. 5).
5.4
Visual Dimension and the SDGs
The visual dimension encompasses crucial elements that determine urban areas’
aesthetic quality, visual appeal, and environmental compatibility. It focuses on the
340
¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
physical layout, urban identities, character, structure, and the aesthetic relationship
between open and closed spaces. In this way, it enhances the order and durability
of urban spaces and encourages interaction with nature. By increasing the order
and durability of urban spaces, this approach also promotes interaction with nature,
effectively achieving SDGs. The design and improvement of the physical quality
of urban areas promote environmental sustainability by providing a healthy envi-
ronment and enhancing well-being. This is why SDG11 (Sustainable Cities and
Communities) is the most relevant target. This is followed by SDG 8 (Decent Work
and Economic Growth) and SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure). These
goals emphasize that improving the physical environment can enhance the attractive-
ness of urban spaces, increase the competitiveness of cities, and promote industrial
innovation. The incorporation of green spaces in urban areas has a positive impact on
the overall health of the population, promoting physical activity. This relates to SDG3
(Good Health and Well-Being). Additionally, incorporating hard and soft landscape
elements into design concerns can eliminate environmental pollution and improve
the natural environment, ecosystem, and water quality. This relates to SDG6 (Clean
Water and Sanitation), SDG14 (Life below Water), and SDG15 (Life on Land). The
fourth matrix table in the assessment illustrates the association with other SDGs that
are directly or indirectly relevant. Based on the code system data, 37.5% (Score: 3)
of this dimension relates to SDGs. (Fig. 6).

5.5
Functional Dimension and the SDGs
The ﬁfth matrix table explores the relationship between the SDGs and the func-
tional dimension, focusing on the effectiveness and utilization of urban areas. This
dimension includes services and urban systems created to meet people’s daily needs.
This dimension consists of ﬁve main components: public spaces, diversity, security,
vibrancy, and vitality, as well as the capital web. For this reason, the main objec-
tives include being accessible to everyone, not neglecting the needs of different
social, cultural, and ethnic groups, ensuring the dynamic structure of urban spaces,
and addressing design concerns that promote various social, cultural, artistic, and
economic activities. It also involves engaging various actors such as businesses,
institutions, local governments, and cultural and educational facilities. Due to these
concerns, it can be considered a key component in creating sustainable cities and
societies and is highly relevant to SDG11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities).
Furthermore, due to its diversity and inclusiveness, it can be argued that it has a strong
relationship with SDG10 (Reduced Inequality), SDG1, SDG16 (Peace, Justice, and
Strong Institutions), and SDG17 (Partnership for the Goals). In addition, design deci-
sions that aim to enhance the vibrancy of cities are related to SDG8 (Decent Work
and Economic Growth) and are a potential driver for the city’s economic growth.
The ﬁfth matrix table includes other indirectly related SDGs. According to the code
system, this dimension is related to the SDGs by 62.5% (Score: 5) (Fig. 7).
Fig. 7 Relationship between the functional dimension of urban design and the SDGs
342
¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
5.6
Temporal Dimension and the SDGs
The sixth table in the matrix shows the relationship between the SDGs and the
temporal dimension. This dimension concerns how urban design changes and evolves
with the inﬂuence of time, such as the city’s past, present, and future states, current
trends, and historical layers. The primary aspect of this dimension is its consideration
of a city’s changes, continuity, and stability over time while respecting its history
and considering future needs to enable sustainable development. Within the temporal
dimension, the time cycle, continuity, and stability are vital components for plan-
ning and managing the progression of systems. Integrating green spaces, health and
education services, infrastructure, and communication networks into urban design
can improve the timing and interaction of activities. Therefore, SDG3 (Good Health
and Well-Being), SDG4 (Quality Education), SDG8 (Decent Work and Economic
Growth), SDG9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure), and SDG13 (Climate
Action) are highly relevant SDGs. In addition, preserving a city’s historical and
cultural heritage is critical to maintaining its identity and continuity, directly related
to SDG11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities). Protecting underwater life, soils,
forests, and biodiversity is essential to ecosystem health and contributes to the contin-
uation of natural time cycles, consistent with SDG14 (Life below Water) and SDG15
(Life on Land). The matrix table indicates SDGs that are also indirectly related. This
dimension shows a high correlation with the SDGs, with a rate of 87.5 percent (score:
7), according to the data in the code system (Fig. 8).
Fig. 8 Relationship between the temporal dimension of urban design and the SDGs

5.7
Design Governance and the SDGs
TherelationshipbetweendesignmanagementandtheSDGsisexploredintheseventh
table of the evaluation matrix. This dimension deals with managing and monitoring
the decisions taken, which can be considered the next design stage. The main compo-
nents of this process are standards, responsibilities, regulations, and participatory
processes. Therefore, as a part of the design concern, design and planning process
policies have been recognized in regulations. The design of urban areas can be seen as
a nexus of regulations, urban planning, structural design, and environmental protec-
tion, and therefore has a high capacity to align with SDG11 (Sustainable Cities and
Communities) to promote sustainable development and enhance livability. Consid-
erations regarding accountability, cooperation, and partnership relate to SDG 17
(Partnership for the Goals). At the same time, aspects such as standards, inspections,
quality in infrastructure and industrial processes, and the increasing control and efﬁ-
ciency in consumption are linked to SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure)
and SDG12 (Responsible Consumption and Production), enhancing the capacity to
innovate and adapt to technological advances. Furthermore, participatory involve-
ment and resource management are moderately high-interaction targets of SDG10
(Reduced Inequality) and SDG13 (Climate Action). The matrix below illustrates the
relationship of this dimension with other SDGs. According to the data in the code
system, this dimension is partially highly correlated with the SDGs and has a rate of
75% (Score: 6) (Fig. 9).
Fig. 9 Relationship between the design management dimension of urban design and the SDGs

¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
5.8
Place Production and the SDGs
The following assessment matrix in Fig. 10 focused on the relationship between the
place production dimension and the SDGs. This dimension includes concerns about
how urban spaces are created and reconﬁgured, such as urban regeneration projects
and the remaking of public spaces. This dimension comprises four main elements:
place production, place identity, place management, and place value. The place
production dimension contributes to the empowerment of local cultural commu-
nities, the protection of cultural richness, and economic development. Therefore,
it has a strong relationship with the SDGs. Protecting local products and cultural
heritage and reﬂecting and strengthening local identity in the built environment
are directly related to SDG11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities) and SDG12
(Responsible Consumption and Production) as they promote sustainable production
and consumption, and the design and development of livable spaces. Following that,
SDG16 (Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions) is related to the inclusion of public
spaces where strong institutions and local government can be involved in the design
processes and the production of design in response to the needs and demands of
local communities. It is important to note that these factors are highly inﬂuential in
achieving the SDG. In addition, it plays a crucial role in reducing income inequality
while promoting economic growth by designing spaces for small businesses and
initiatives that support local economies and development. Therefore, it also strongly
relates to SDG8 (Decent Work and Economic Growth). The assessment matrix table
in Fig. 10 also provides information on the SDGs to which they are indirectly related.
Based on the data in the code system, the last dimension is also partially highly related
to the SDGs, with 62.5% (Score: 5).
6
Findings and Discussions
Urban design is one of the main contributors to social behavior, the global economy,
and environmental management. Until recently, urban design applications have been
mainly focused on four dimensions of sustainable development, which are environ-
mental, social, economic, and cultural issues. However, as urban design ideas have
progressed, it has been determined that these four elements are insufﬁcient in the
spatial formation process. They should be supplemented with participation, manage-
ment support, and organizations at different scales. The ﬁndings of this study utilized
a multi-step research technique to examine the 2030 Agenda’s aims and impact on
urban design strategies. This research contributes to the literature on implementing
the 2030 New Urban Agenda. Also, it aimed to identify how the urban design
objectives interact with the SDGs.
Urban design can help achieve the SDGs by beneﬁting communities, individuals,
the economy, and the environment. The analysis shows that potential beneﬁts include
improved public health, increased social equity, increased land values, a more vibrant
The Role of Urban Design in Achieving the UN SDGs
345
Fig. 10 Relationship between the place production dimension of urban design and the SDGs
local economy, reduced environmental impact—vehicle emissions—and more envi-
ronmentally friendly usage of non-renewable resources. For this reason, urban design
has a decisive role in creating sustainable cities and increasing social awareness.
In analyzing the relationship between the dimensions of urban design and the
SDGs using the code system, we consider the number of matched codes. This
matching supports the potential of urban design as a tool for achieving SDGs,
as it reveals the perception and development process of urban design over time.
Initially discussed as a supportive discipline at the interface of architecture and plan-
ning, the ever-evolving ideology of urban design updates itself by considering the
changing characteristics of today’s world, including shifting boundaries, collabora-
tion, speed of transfer, environmental concerns, and consumer behavior, where many
concerns are discussed beyond the scope of being an interface discipline. Although
the concept was initially introduced with six dimensions (morphological, percep-
tual, social, visual, functional, and time-based), which mainly focused on physical
organization, order, social interaction, and community production through design
methods and space production, the last two dimensions, design management, and
space production were developed as ﬂexible spatial organizations and arrangements
that can be adapted to urban crises and challenges, and as part of management
collaboration and control processes. (Carmona, 2023) The concept also considers
the uniqueness and aesthetics of the city, functionality, and the past, present, and
future layers, as well as providing a partial reﬂection of the dynamic structure of
cities. Due to its diverse and dynamic nature, urban design was found to respond
directly or indirectly to many SDGs. These relationships are presented in detail in
346
¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
Table 2 through code matching, with red denoting the social impact, blue signi-
fying the economic impact, and green representing the environmental impact, as has
already been mentioned in the methodology section. Yellow on the matrix represents
the total and direct relationship of SDG11 to all dimensions.
The data shows that SDG11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities) has a 100%
correlation with urban design, followed by SDG3 (Good Health and Well Being) with
77.7%, SDG16 (Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions) with 74%, SDG10 (Reduced
Inequality) with 72.2%, SDG8 (Decent Work and Economic Growth) with 70.3%,
and SDG9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure) with 70.3%. On the other hand,
SDG14 (Life below Water) has the lowest correlation with 12.9%, followed by SDG2

(Zero Hunger) with 25.9%, and SDG1 (No Poverty) with 31.4%. These results are
presented in Fig. 11.
Furthermore, upon analyzing the individual relationship between urban design
dimensions (Fig. 12), it becomes apparent that the social and temporal dimension
has the highest rate of concern, 87.5%, followed by design governance, 75%, and
place production and morphological dimensions, 62.5%. However, compared to the
other dimensions, the visual dimension showed a lower response rate of 37.5% in
both practical and theoretical performance.
7
Conclusion
As stated in the introduction, the existing body of research provides a foundation for
examining the role of the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs in guiding cities’ development
processes as tools for sustainability assessment. However, there remains a signiﬁcant
gap in understanding how urban design principles interact with the SDGs and their
targets, a crucial aspect for fostering sustainable urban development and shaping
the future of cities. Thus, this research endeavored to address the following inquiry
through an extensive literature review of urban design theories, particularly focusing
on dimensions of urban design deﬁned by Carmona and Wunderlich (2013): How
can urban design contribute to achieving SDGs?
348
¸S. Ho¸skara and Ö. S. Koç
Based on grounded theory, following the ﬁndings of this theoretical, documentary,
and qualitative research, it can be argued that to achieve SDGs, urban design theories
and practices must consider the effects of changing needs and social structures and
be shaped by the following factors:
1. A universal approach for more systematic knowledge development and applica-
tion,
2. Identiﬁcation of limits that cause a gap between urban expectations and actual
practice,
3. Providing strategic focal points to address this knowledge gap.
These three factors reveal that the differentiation between urban design practice
and theory should be reduced, and a more comprehensive and unifying understanding
introduced. Finally, the most pressing need is developing integrated strategies at
broader urban scales. Within any urban design scheme, the knowledge framework
should adopt a systems perspective, including the SDGs and their targets, leaving no
one and no place behind.
Keeping these main lessons of the paper in mind, one should remember that this
research focused on the relationship between urban design (and its dimensions) and
the SDGs within its limitations. However, focusing solely on urban design theories
may overlook valuable insights from other disciplines, such as architecture, plan-
ning, sociology, economics, and environmental science, which also play a role in
achieving SDGs through urban development. Besides, urban development is a multi-
faceted process inﬂuenced by various factors beyond urban design, such as gover-
nance structures, economic policies, and social dynamics. It may be argued that
the research may struggle to capture these interactions’ complexities adequately.
Therefore, based on the research ﬁndings presented in this paper, the authors suggest
further research to explore the relationship and contribution of diverse ﬁelds, such
as sociology, economics, environmental science, policy studies, etc., to SDGs. This
would make it possible to identify common themes, overlaps, and areas of diver-
gence across disciplines to develop a holistic understanding of how urban design
contributes to achieving SDGs. Besides, engaging experts from diverse disciplines
in the research process can enrich an understanding of how various disciplines
contribute to achieving SDGs through urban development. Their diverse perspec-
tives and expertise can offer valuable insights and ensure the new research addresses
multidimensional aspects of sustainable urban development and further supports
achieving SDGs.
