Fostering Sustainability Through
Research and Education? The
Transformative Role of Switzerland’s
Centre for Development
and Environment (CDE)
Christoph Bader, Sabin Bieri, Lilian Trechsel, and Anu Lannen
Abstract As environmental challenges and social inequalities continue to mount,
the current decade has acquired unprecedented importance. The urgency of
addressing unsustainable development and achieving the sustainable development
goals (SDG) is greater than ever. This chapter examines the contributions of Switzer-
land’s Centre for Development and Environment (CDE) towards realizing a sustain-
able world, highlighting selected research and educational projects from CDE’s
past and current initiatives. Emphasizing CDE’s commitment to actionable knowl-
edge, inclusiveness, and systems thinking—as expressed in its theory of change—the
chapter shows how transformative science is put to work. This includes producing
knowledge that not only contributes to global sustainability debates, but also beneﬁts
speciﬁc marginalized communities and ecosystems on the ground. Over the years,
CDE has learned that its sustainability contributions are most effective when rooted in
speciﬁc contexts and carried out with trusted local partners. Its recommendations for
a future research agenda include continuing reﬁnement of methodologies to support
transdisciplinarity and concerted expansion of efforts to decolonize academia.
Keywords Sustainable development · Transformation · Transdisciplinary
1
Introduction
In a world that confronts intensifying environmental challenges and persistent social
inequalities, the present decade has assumed unparalleled signiﬁcance. The urgency
of tackling unsustainable development and achieving the sustainable development
goals (SDGs) is greater than ever. Higher education institutions have a particular
responsibility to contribute to transformation pathways for global sustainability.
C. Bader (B) · S. Bieri · L. Trechsel · A. Lannen
Centre for Development and Environment (CDE), University of Bern, Mittelstrasse 43,
Bern 3012, Switzerland
e-mail: christoph.bader@unibe.ch
© The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024
W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_21
357
358
C. Bader et al.
Through their research and education activities, higher education institutions are
in a privileged, yet critical position to help bring about the sustainability transfor-
mations the world so desperately needs. In the following, we explore the transfor-
mative approach of Switzerland’s Centre for Development and Environment (CDE).
Begun as a research group in 1988, CDE set out on a journey to make meaningful
contributions to sustainable development by weaving together scientiﬁc rigour and
real-world engagement. The integration of sustainable development at the Univer-
sity of Bern was eventually afforded greater political anchoring by legislation passed
in 1996 (Gesetz über die Universität (UniG) 1996). Then, in 2009, CDE experi-
enced a renaissance when it was made an ofﬁcial research centre under the Univer-
sity of Bern’s banner. Its rising prominence was shaped by the leadership role it
assumed in the National Centre of Competence in Research (NCCR) North–South,
a sweeping international research programme focused on sustainable development,
originally launched in 2001. CDE’s emergence on a wider stage aligned perfectly
with the University of Bern’s strategic focus on “mastering global change” and its
commitment to furthering sustainable development. Today, CDE is a cross-faculty
research centre encompassing around 90 specialists from 25 disciplines working in
collaboration with numerous partners around the globe (www.cde.unibe.ch).
Now empowered as a university-wide entity, CDE oversees all University of Bern
research, teaching, knowledge exchange, and service capacities concerning sustain-
able development and environmental issues. Its original focus on natural resources
management and sustainable regional development in the “global South” has grown
signiﬁcantly, inparticular withaviewtotransformingpatterns andpolicies inwealthy
countries, like Switzerland, that hinder sustainable development elsewhere. From
the start, however, CDE has striven to unite scientiﬁc inquiry with hands-on use
and policy engagement. Over time, the centre’s multilevel research–practice–policy
ambitions have evolved into a distinct inter- and transdisciplinary approach (Hurni
and Wiesmann 2014) that informs all of its efforts towards sustainability transforma-
tions. Along the way, CDE has learned that its contributions to global discourses on
development, the environment, and sustainability are most effective when grounded
in speciﬁc contexts and carried out in collaboration with trusted local partners. Over
the course of three decades, the centre has established partnerships in East Africa,
the Horn of Africa, Central and Southeast Asia, and South America, most of which
endure to the present day.
In this chapter, the authors outline CDE’s theory of change, illustrate it with case
examples, and derive corresponding insights for a transformative research agenda
towards global sustainability.
2
CDE’s Theory of Change and Pathways to Impact
At the heart of CDE’s mission to enable transformations towards sustainability lies
a robust theory of change (Oberlack et al. 2019), created and consolidated in 2021
through a concerted team effort. It is illustrated below.
Fostering Sustainability Through Research and Education? The …
359
CDE is an academic institution dedicated to cutting-edge research across the spec-
trum of sustainability science (CDE 2021). Through the centre’s diverse educa-
tional programmes, we foster sustainability skills at the bachelor’s, master’s, and
doctoral level. CDE cultivates long-term international partnerships with institutions
that anchor its research in concrete settings around the world. Operating across disci-
plines and beyond is fundamental to the centre’s approach, making it possible to
harness both academic and non-academic knowledge for sustainable solutions. This
integration is facilitated through practical and inclusive exchange formats, character-
ized by transdisciplinarity and a commitment to contextual relevance and grounded
sensitivity.
CDE puts its own theory of change to work within four distinct pathways to
impact. They are as follows.
Pathway 1: Scientiﬁcally sound knowledge generation. CDE is committed to
pioneering advanced scientiﬁc analyses, generating key insights across the expan-
sive landscape of sustainability science. The centre’s research produces robust
evidence characterized by a systems perspective, providing a basis for informed
decision-making and actions aimed at addressing pressing sustainability challenges.
360
C. Bader et al.
Pathway2:Nurturingsustainabilitycompetences.Througheducationalprogrammes.
Encompassing graduate and post-graduate studies as well specialized advanced
study programmes, the centre’s educational initiatives equip younger generations
with the skills and awareness essential for sustainable development. By empowering
future leaders with transformative literacy and practical expertise, the centre actively
contributes to the foundations of a sustainable world.
Pathway 3: Cultivating long-term international partnerships. CDE’s enduring
commitment to international partner networks underscores its dedication to contex-
tual relevance and global collaboration. By fostering sustained relationships, CDE
ensures ownership of transformative initiatives in concrete contexts and the mean-
ingful applicability of its research in diverse regional settings, bolstering its collective
efforts towards sustainable change.
Fostering Sustainability Through Research and Education? The …
361
Pathway 4: Tailored exchange for transdisciplinary learning. CDE champions a
dynamic exchange of knowledge through customized, inclusive learning formats that
bridge academia and hands-on practice. The synergy of academic and non-academic
perspectives, facilitated by transdisciplinarity research methods and formats, fuels
the co-creation of solutions on behalf of a more sustainable, inclusive future.
In the following section, individual case examples are presented that illustrate
the centre’s work within the four pathways to impact. These real-world examples
demonstrate how CDE’s theory of change translates into concrete transformations
across scientiﬁc knowledge, education, international partnerships, and the dynamic
exchange of knowledge.
3
Illustrations of Impact Pathways: Highlighting
Real-World Change
Scientiﬁcally Sound Knowledge Generation: Research for Sustainable Agricul-
tural Trade
Maintaining high academic standards while pursuing systems, target, and transfor-
mation knowledge, CDE is committed to engaged and transformative science (CDE
2017, 2021). The centre’s research analyses complex global change processes and
their consequences. It explores interactions between land use and ecosystems; overall
framework conditions (e.g. policies, regulations, governance structures); and the
standards of living, lifestyles, and well-being of diverse populations.
As one example among many, the recent project “Fostering Sustainable Food
Systems through Trade Relations” demonstrates how the centre’s research provides
useful knowledge for informed decision-making at various policy levels. Similar
to other CDE projects, it is characterized by proposing concrete action—in this
case introducing a zero draft for a new Swiss agricultural trade law—on behalf of
a pressing sustainability challenge. The project highlights how governments can
play a pivotal role in fostering diversiﬁed and sustainable food systems through
trade relations. It shows how authorities can distinguish between sustainably and
less sustainably produced food without compromising fundamental principles of the
362
C. Bader et al.
global trade framework, particularly the principle of non-discrimination. This, in
turn, can pave the way for more nuanced and structured trade regimes that champion
diverse food systems.
Article 104a lit. d of the Swiss Federal Constitution mandates the Confederation
to establish the groundwork for “cross-border trade relations that contribute to the
sustainable development of the agriculture and food sector.” To date, the constitu-
tional provision remains unfulﬁlled and its execution appears far from straightfor-
ward. The complexity arises, in part, due to critical narratives that have cast agricul-
tural trade as intrinsically unsustainable. However, the crux of sustainability lies in a
crucial question: How can the public sector bolster the market presence of sustainably
produced goods while curbing access to unsustainable products via product differ-
entiation? And how can this be done without harming the most vulnerable actors in
the supply chain, in particular small-scale agricultural producers in countries of the
global South?
Drawing on insights from a CDE study comparing European Free Trade Associa-
tion (EFTA) negotiations with Mercosur and the EFTA–Indonesia agreement, several
pivotal principles emerge (Bonanomi and Tribaldos 2020). Central to this process
is the ability of the state to distinguish between sustainable and unsustainable food
production—a task made easier when internationally accepted standards serve as
reference points. While existing World Trade Organization (WTO) rules seemingly
restrict states from discerning sustainable from non-sustainable products in trade and
commercial contexts, further examination reveals room for manoeuvre. Challenging
widely held assumptions, CDE research highlights the potential for states to navigate
within WTO restrictions while fostering sustainability (Musselli et al. 2022a, b).
Other project-related CDE research on the trade and marketing of “sustainable”
ﬁsh reveals the risks of relying on labels and certiﬁcation processes to ensure
sustainability (Baumgartner and Bonanomi 2021). Similarly, a CDE study exam-
ining Swiss soy imports from Brazil ﬁnds shortcomings in the prevalent GMO-free
and certiﬁed soy model (Frey et al. 2022). Accordingly, the research team argues that
private initiatives must be complemented by public-sector efforts to ensure quality
through regulations and incentives. However, states must proceed with care, striving
to balance fundamental equity principles and WTO requirements. This means they
must create incentives and regulate trade in a way that enables context-sensitive
solutions and provides market access to low-income partners and small producers in
other countries.
Since the project was embedded in the “Sustainable Economy” research
programme of the Swiss National Science Foundation (SNSF), the team was required
to present their ﬁndings in a way that is easily accessible and understood by both the
Swiss government and policymakers in general. For this reason, the team chose to
render their synthesis very concretely in a hypothetical legislative act on sustainable
agricultural trade.
Fostering Sustainability Through Research and Education? The …
363
Nurturing Sustainability Competences: Education that Bridges Theory and
Practice
As a university centre that strives to spearhead engaged and transformative science
and usher in sustainable futures, CDE’s most immediate contribution and effec-
tive lever to these ends is its work in educating and collaborating with students.
It can hardly be overstated how much the leadership and capacity of younger
generations is needed to enable transformations towards sustainable development.
CDE’s educational programmes are designed to build corresponding competences
in students.
A key challenge lies in the fact that necessary competences for the twenty-ﬁrst
century are difﬁcult to predict. What appears most needed are “transition managers”
or “change agents”, a concept that CDE’s new master’s programme seeks to develop
further. The curriculum is designed to instil in students a deep understanding of
sustainability challenges and the tools needed to address them at various scales.
CDE and partners from the educational unit at the University of Bern have designed
a competence model for university study programmes that builds on academic
knowledge, professional skills, and critical awareness (Barth and Rieckmann 2016;
Brundiersetal.2021;HammerandLewis2023;Herwegetal.2021;Wieketal.2011).
Students are taught how to develop inter- and transdisciplinary problem framings as
well as how to initiate, manage, and evaluate concrete transformation processes at
different societal levels. In this way, CDE’s educational initiatives go far beyond
development of theoretical knowledge. The centre emphasizes the practical appli-
cation of sustainability principles, encouraging students to translate their learnings
into tangible actions. Whether through ﬁeldwork, case studies, or hands-on projects,
CDE students help to bridge the gap between theory and real-world impact (e.g.
Trechsel et al. 2023).
By nurturing sustainability competences in students, the centre actively
contributes to the foundations of a more sustainable world. Graduates emerge not
just as skilled professionals, but as advocates and agents for positive change—espe-
cially via global partnerships and collaboration. Through CDE’s engagement in the
doctoral-level International Graduate School (IGS) North–South programme, the
centre seeks to promote equitable, partnership-based research and to foster the devel-
opment of individual and institutional capacities. Doctoral candidates are encouraged
to address sustainability challenges in the context of international partnerships that
enable them to build their own scientiﬁc networks (Trechsel et al. 2020). In addition
to online and on-site doctoral training courses, the core of the IGS North–South is
a two-week international learning event (summer school) designed to train doctoral
candidates and future trainers—that is, junior and senior lecturers unfamiliar or inex-
perienced with the training approach needed for research for sustainable develop-
ment. In this setting, international students are challenged to go beyond traditional
classroom experiences and to develop the skills, methods, and attitudes required to
address global challenges in an interdisciplinary, team-oriented manner. Apart from
invaluable networks that open up for both students from the global South and the
364
C. Bader et al.
global North, the sharing of knowledge with diverse stakeholders is highly illumi-
nating for the academic participants—in particular, they realize the potentials and
limits of their function as scientists in addressing societal problems and exploring
sustainability pathways (Trechsel et al. 2021). Last but not least, the international
beyond-classroomexperienceoffersparticipantsanimmersionexperienceinaninter-
cultural learning environment as well as hands-on exploration of power structures
along the lines of gender, race, class, and social origin.
The experience of one graduate illustrates the potential of CDE’s international
exchange architecture. The graduate’s name has been changed to protect her privacy.
Martine Nzabonimpa joined CDE via a research project on the commercialization
of agriculture, co-funded by the Swiss National Science Foundation and the Swiss
Agency for Development and Cooperation. As a doctoral student in this international
project, examining the livelihood effects of export agriculture in four countries, she
engaged in the peer network with the rest of the doctoral students—ﬁrst through the
project and later through the IGS North–South network. She developed her proﬁle
by acquiring skills through targeted IGS North–South courses, but also through
direct exchanges with researchers in Switzerland. She demonstrated her intellectual
strength and exceptional commitment in various exchange semesters in Switzerland.
She used these precious opportunities to advance her scientiﬁc work in an environ-
ment where she was less torn between her roles as a doctoral student, a member
of a research team at an NGO, and a mother. Through the international exposure
with students from around the globe, she gained intercultural competences. She also
realized how to negotiate her own interests in her professional environment at home—
scientiﬁc as well as personal—with her superiors (mostly men). Today, she is one
of very few women holding a PhD in her country—at the time of her defence, the
number of PhD holders in Rwanda was under 1,000, with only a handful women
among them. She now has an inﬂuential position in the government, where she is
instrumental in shaping the country’s agricultural strategy. Martine’s story demon-
strates the transformative effect of the partnership-driven concept of the graduate
school, highlighting the type of impact that is not often showcased in higher education
debates or in the framework of international development.
Cultivating Long-Term International Partnerships: Seeds Planted in Africa
Bear Global Fruit
Since its 1980s-era inception as a research group, CDE has held that it is not
possible—or desirable—to conduct meaningful sustainability research in the global
South without partners in and from the regions under study. Over the decades, CDE
has proactively avoided the traps of “helicopter research” or “parachute science”
(Adame 2021), whereby academics from wealthy Northern countries brieﬂy visit
low-income countries to gather data—for example, on neglected tropical diseases—
only to return home to publish results and advance their own careers. Instead, working
shoulder-to-shoulder with local scientists and communities in countries of Africa,
South America, Asia, and beyond, CDE’s founding researchers recognized early
on that “solutions” to development challenges—like poverty, water scarcity, or land
degradation—would only succeed if they were co-created with affected stakeholders
Fostering Sustainability Through Research and Education? The …
365
and led to anchoring of knowledge and expertise in situ. Partnership was seen not
only as the right thing to do from a normative perspective, but also practically and in
the sense of mutual self-interest—interest in learning from one another as peers and
in tackling global threats like climate change (Hurni and Wiesmann 2014). Together
withtheirinternationalpartners,CDEresearcherswerealsoinstrumentalindesigning
a conceptual framework for partnership research between the global North and the
global South. The resulting “KFPE principles” are now widely regarded as gold-
standard guidelines for building and working in global partnerships (KFPE https://
kfpe.scnat.ch/en/11_principles_7_questions).
TheﬁrstseedsofCDE’spartnership-basedresearchapproachweresownineastern
Africa in the 1980s, above all in hands-on projects aimed at helping ensure the liveli-
hoods of smallholder farmers and other land users living in harsh, unpredictable,
and changing climatic conditions. In Kenya, for example, CDE researchers began
working with local experts in the Mount Kenya region, exploring ways of enabling
local populations to share the ﬁnite water resources that ﬂow down the mountain in
the rainy season (CDE 2015). In addition to enabling Swiss and African colleagues
to gain expertise and earn advanced degrees side by side, this research gradually
supported the co-creation of locally embedded Water User Associations (WUAs)
whose members share river water by mutual agreement based on scientiﬁc moni-
toring data. Meanwhile, in Ethiopia, initial cooperative research focused on ﬁnding
practical solutions to soil erosion in the Ethiopian Highlands, helping to preserve
or restore fertile croplands that feed millions. Among other things, this research led
to collaborative reﬁnement of techniques of soil and water conservation across the
region—with global implications. For example, joint advances were made in the use
and understanding of age-old practices like cropland terracing, which were revealed
to have the added long-term beneﬁt of capturing and storing climate-warming CO2
in the fertile humus layer of rejuvenated soils (Amare et al. 2013).
Decisively, these partnership-based research efforts in the global South were not
limited to short ﬁeld visits and isolated projects, but rather continued for decades
and led to cultivation of mutually beneﬁcial relationships of scientiﬁc cooperation
and friendship. In the early 2000s, the growing collaborations received a major
boost when the Swiss government-approved the creation of the National Centre of
Competence (NCCR) North–South, a vast, 12-year development-focused research
programme hosted by CDE that brought together six Swiss research institutions and
140 partner institutions in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. The programme estab-
lished a network of scientiﬁc and practical exchange on sustainability challenges
between researchers and students active in over 40 countries. In some cases, Southern
experts who had worked with CDE since the earliest days earned key positions in
regional programme hubs, helping to solidify their reputations and institutionalize
sustainability science at local universities in eastern Africa and elsewhere. Ulti-
mately, 140 young researchers from the global South earned doctorates within the
programme, in addition to 90 researchers from Switzerland and Europe. Perhaps most
signiﬁcantly, repeated surveys of Southern graduates from the programme showed
that the vast majority returned to work and advance their careers in the global South,
leading to mutually beneﬁcial “brain circulation” rather than exploitative “brain
366
C. Bader et al.
drain” (Karrer et al. 2023). Since 2012, the successor programme—IGS North–
South, also hosted at CDE—has carried on the work of facilitating doctoral-level
research exchange between up-and-coming Swiss scientists and their counterparts
in low- and middle-income countries of the global South.
Over the course of more than three decades, CDE’s partnership-based research
has vividly illustrated the advantages of long-term transboundary collaborations for
sustainable development (Michel et al. 2013). Above all, these international part-
nerships build research relationships rooted in a sense of shared mission, jointly
negotiated concepts and principles, and trust between individuals and institutions.
Southern researchers gain access to the scientiﬁc resources, expertise, and networks
of higher-income countries, not least of all enabling them to publish their results in
establishedjournals.Northernresearchersgainagroundedviewofdevelopmentchal-
lenges, ﬁrst-hand insights on data collection and management in a non-industrialized
context, as well as access to local communities and national policymakers in the
South, enhancing their personal motivation, credibility, and ability to effect change.
Both groups beneﬁt from the hands-on approach to real-world development chal-
lenges, which quickly drives home the need for collaboration across disciplines and
in concert with affected (Trechsel et al. 2020).
At the same time, CDE remains well-aware of the persistent shortcomings of
North–South research partnerships and the urgent need to transform them further. In
particular, as part of its wider ongoing efforts to “decolonize” sustainability research
and academia itself, CDE is actively working to strengthen the funding and agenda-
setting position of individual Southern researchers and institutional partners.
Tailored Exchange for Transdisciplinary Learning: A Knowledge Network to
Tackle Ecological Harms
Soil degradation, which impacts food security, climate change and biodiversity, is a
major global challenge. Using accumulated knowledge for effective land resource
management is key to address it. This is where the World Overview of Conservation
Approaches and Technologies (WOCAT) comes in, an initiative in which CDE has
long played an instrumental role. WOCAT is a global network on sustainable land
management (SLM) that closes knowledge gaps and spurs innovation.
Founded in 1992 and jointly managed by CDE, FAO, and ISRIC, WOCAT
has evolved into an esteemed global network that maintains a user-friendly global
database on SLM practices. Offering a treasure trove of practical knowledge, it has
been recognized by UNCCD as the primary global database of SLM best practices.
The UNCCD recognition gives WOCAT the mandate to support the 196 signatory
countries in recording their SLM best practices and using the SLM knowledge of
stakeholders worldwide—from land users to decision-makers—to improve local land
management. This dynamic alliance spans from land users to decision-makers and
promotes the sharing of knowledge and solutions.
WOCAT is an excellent example of collaboration that promotes mutual learning
between scientiﬁc actors and more practice-based stakeholders (e.g. small farmers),
driving overall sustainability and positive change around the world. In CDE’s quest
fortransdisciplinarylearning,WOCATisanimportantallythatreinforcesthecentre’s
Fostering Sustainability Through Research and Education? The …
367
vision of comprehensive, tailored knowledge co-production and sharing. Its extensive
database of SLM practices offers diverse solutions, linking theoretical concepts with
real-world application. The mix of academic and non-academic perspectives that
lies at the heart of transdisciplinarity is embodied in WOCAT’s pool of knowledge,
enablingco-creationofpractical,evidence-basedsolutions.TheglobalSLMdatabase
contains over 2,300 SLM good practices from all over the world and is linked to
WOCAT learning modules as well as external platforms, tools, and applications
such as the Framework for Ecosystem Restoration Monitoring (FERM). It serves
as a basis for various knowledge products, including good practice compilations,
scientiﬁc papers, policy briefs, books, factsheets, and videos that are co-produced
with different partners. Indeed, WOCAT has become CDE’s prototype programme
for a user-driven, citizen-science informed database. Other examples include the
Land Matrix, a database that compiles key facts on large-scale land acquisitions, and
the Lao Decide Info project, in which granular village-level socio-economic data are
made accessible for multiple uses by government and development agencies.
The WOCAT database is currently being linked to a digital application—the
“farmbetter” app—in the project “AgriPath: Empowering smallholder farmers’ tran-
sition to sustainable agriculture through effective and efﬁcient digital pathways”.
Together with users in the target countries, this application is being developed and
tailored to the needs of a large and diverse set of users. The algorithm of the “farmbet-
ter”appmatchesfarmers’needswiththeSLMsolutionsofferedintheglobalWOCAT
database. By providing farmers and extension services with tailored solutions that
can be shared, learned, and promoted digitally, smallholder farmers are empowered
to increase their agricultural productivity, income, and climate resilience. Ongoing
research is assessing the impact of these digitally provided services and comparing
them with other agricultural extension services. This is an illustration of how CDE
initiatives strive to inform and improve existing, locally anchored practices with
scientiﬁc insights for social and technological innovations.
4
Conclusion and Considerations for a Future Research
Agenda
In order to shape the future research agenda for sustainable development, CDE is
committed to expanding its traditional research domains by integrating emergent
themes and addressing areas previously underrepresented in sustainability research.
This includes giving greater attention to sectors like labour and employment and
investigating the central role of ﬁnancial markets in driving or preventing sustain-
ability transformations. Here, innovative post-growth frameworks are highly inspi-
rational and useful for exploring emerging themes. Opening up perspectives beyond
368
C. Bader et al.
traditional growth paradigms offers a new frontier to sustainability science. Mean-
while, CDE remains committed to engaging in critical discourses on global inequal-
ities, emphasizing the need to tackle disparities in order to achieve true, inclusive
sustainability.
One key challenge is to continue reﬁning the methodological repertoire of sustain-
ability research, further advancing transdisciplinary approaches and generating rele-
vant transformation knowledge. Adaptive methodological frameworks are imper-
ative to chart pathways to sustainability in the diverse contexts that CDE works
in. Methodological advances will also necessarily feed into CDE’s teaching and
educational programmes. Digitalization—carefully assessed for each purpose—will
enhance these efforts, widening the scope of tools, techniques, audiences, languages,
and approaches.
Another particularly crucial, far-reaching issue is the need to critically eval-
uate institutional structures, project architectures, and unfolding initiatives therein.
Decolonization, though not new to CDE’s working culture, has discursively regained
momentum globally and offers a useful framework for reassessment of institutional
governance structures within academia and beyond (Rakotonarivo and Andriami-
haja 2023). For its part, CDE not only fosters interdisciplinary teams that transcend
conventional academic boundaries, but is also increasingly working to transform
established academic hierarchies. In the context of its third tracer study of the IGS
School North–South (Karrer et al. 2023), CDE began reﬂecting more critically on
its programmes and structures through a decolonizing lens. It found that the ﬁrst
step towards addressing structural barriers in the academic world is asking the right
questions—such as: “Who is invited to sit at the expert table and who is systemi-
cally excluded?” (Rutazibwa 2018, p. 168) or “Why are we producing knowledge?”
(Rutazibwa2018,p.171).Decolonizationalsoentailsdeconstructingthepowerstruc-
tures that inﬂuence positions and careers in academia—power structures that are
easily reproduced if we do not raise awareness and challenge our own blind spots as
academics and researchers.
Concretely, CDE is actively working to develop models that empower diverse
young scientists all over the globe. Initiatives in this direction include signiﬁcant
revision of doctoral programme curricula, with the express aim of elevating the role
of Southern universities to positions of leadership and decision-making. This step
not only enriches the academic landscape, but will also ensure that voices from
the global South signiﬁcantly contribute to future research agendas for sustainable
development. Going forward, CDE is dedicated to fostering equitable collabora-
tions between universities from the global South and North (see also Rakotonarivo
and Andriamihaja 2023). Such partnerships are envisioned as platforms for mutual
learning and shared research, challenging traditional North-centric paradigms of
knowledge creation.
In aligning with a research agenda for sustainable development, the integration
of sustainability transformation and future competencies into university curricula
and teaching methodologies is paramount. This involves designing academic
programmes that not only impart knowledge about current sustainability challenges,
but also equip students with the skills, mindset and—increasingly—resilience,
Fostering Sustainability Through Research and Education? The …
369
needed for innovation and leadership in this ﬁeld. This points also to the inclusion
of transformative learning by encouraging critical self-reﬂection and a questioning
of preconceived notions, thereby fostering profound personal and societal change.
Courses should thus foster critical thinking, systems thinking, and aim for proﬁciency
in addressing questions within complex global interdependencies. By emphasizing
collaborative projects, problem-based learning, and real-world case studies, univer-
sities can ensure that students are trained to translate their theoretical models into
real-world contexts; to improve, upon that translation, their theories as well as their
practical approaches; and thus to be prepared to drive sustainable transformations. In
addition, the inclusion of cross-disciplinary studies and partnerships with industry
and communities can enrich the learning experience and provide students with a
broad and grounded understanding of sustainability in a wide variety of contexts.
This paradigm shift in education is critical to enable graduates who grasp sustain-
ability challenges, remain aware of their role as citizens, and are capable of designing
and implementing effective solutions that are embraced by those they are meant to
serve.

The Role of the Ofﬁce

of a Coruña in Promoting Sustainability
Verónica Torrijos, Martina Dono, Domingo Calvo-Dopico,
Amparo Casares-Gallego, and Manuel Soto
Abstract By working on issues such as governance, education, research, outreach,
and campus operations, higher education institutions play a critical role in achieving
sustainability, through green and sustainability ofﬁces that coordinate those efforts.
The Ofﬁce for the Environment (OMA-UDC) of the University of A Coruña (UDC)
was created in 2008 with the dual aim of taking responsibility for environmental
managementandpromotingtheawarenessandparticipationoftheuniversitycommu-
nity in environmental issues. The actions of the OMA-UDC started with a ﬁrst
analysis of the environmental impact of the UDC, the calculation of the ecological
footprint, the ﬁrst sectoral plans for energy and mobility and various actions in energy
saving and water use efﬁciency. At the same time, an environmental outreach program
has been launched in which the network of environmental scholarship students is a
key part. Later, the UDC joined the international program Eco Campus. These lines
of action were accompanied by research-action and learning-by-doing methodolo-
gies, which showed greater potential for the implementation of sustainability goals.
The current programs of the OMA-UDC are: education for sustainability, manage-
ment of forest spaces on campus and biodiversity, urban vegetable gardens, on-
site composting systems for organic waste from the canteens, selective collection

Keywords Sustainability · HEIs · Campus · Green ofﬁces · Participation
1
Introduction
The climate crises we are facing today is no longer a doubt, but a statement. The way
the ruling socio-economic system is threatening life on Earth has already showed
some cruel evidence of its great impact in many different shapes, which somehow
discerns the future that awaits. That is why the key question now is how to mitigate
the changes and adapt to the new conditions (IPCC 2022).
In this matter, there are many agents that play an essential role in worsening the
situation, but also having the potential to contribute to the solution. Higher Educa-
tion Institutions (HEI), albeit contributing themselves by their own carbon foot-
print, they also have a special social responsibility and should “lead by example”,
as they contribute to the education of future leaders, they perform an outstanding
part of research, and they may constitute a model of action and awareness around
sustainability (Bautista-Puig and Sanz-Casado 2021; Amaral et al. 2015).
However, as stated by Leal Filho et al. (2019), sustainability in HEIs is a multi-
dimensional topic, and should be addressed as so. The six categories they propose
are (a) Institutional frameworks, (b) Campus operations (resources, management,
and infrastructure); (c) Teaching; (d) Research; (e) Outreach/Collaboration; and (f)
Assessment and Reporting. Moreover, as stated by the Sustainable Development
Goals, sustainability should be approached through a triple vision: environmental,
economic, and social (Martínez-Buján et al. 2020).
Inthatsense,GreenandSustainabilityOfﬁcesariseasagoodandeffectivestrategy
for coordinating the efforts towards sustainability in HEIs (Leal Filho et al. 2019).
In fact, 65% of the top 100-ARWU (Academic Ranking of World Universities) 2015
ranking had an ofﬁce of this characteristics with broad and diverse areas of action,
being the most typical type of Institutional Organ for sustainability (Salvioni et al.
2017).
However, although useful, they are usually not sufﬁcient, as they encounter obsta-
cles that hinder their work, such as “lack of speciﬁc funding and lack of support
from the administrations”. Moreover, although mobilization and integration of staff
and students are a usual objective of these ofﬁces, they often experiment difﬁculties
reaching and engaging students (Leal Filho et al. 2019). As highlighted by Adomßent
et al. (2019), students should be seen as contributors for sustainability progress in
HEIs, not only as addressees of the politics implemented by the institution. There-
fore, different types of student and staff participation may be considered to effectively
The Role of the Ofﬁce for the Environment at the University of a Coruña …
375
involve them towards the construction of a “strong institutional culture of sustain-
ability”, at the same time they actively participate in their own education and training
on sustainability.
It is for this purpose that the combination of research and actions of sustainability
manifest its great potential. Action research and learning-by-doing methodologies
are attracting great interest for their potential contributions to sustainability. These are
methodologies whose paradigm combines theory and practice, integrating learning,
researchandactionandincludingcollaborativepartnershipsandahighlevelofreﬂex-
ivity. It stimulates transformative learning among participants, seeking to improve
the situation of participants and social transformation (Cebrián et al. 2015; Cicek
et al. 2019). Action research projects are carried out by professional researchers and
the members of an organization, community or network, i.e. stakeholders, through
the cycle of planning, implementation, observation and critical reﬂection (Torrijos
et al. 2020). On the other hand, learning by doing is active, hands-on and engaging
for students.
AnotherstrategyforpromotingsustainabilityimplementedinmanyUniversitiesis
the Eco Campus program, coordinated by the Foundation for Environmental Educa-
tion (FEE), which is known as Green Campus at UDC. This program started in 2003
and at this date counts with 125 registered campuses. It constitutes a broad frame-
work that, through a seven-steps procedure, pursues to involve university community,
especially students, in the implementation of sustainability measures on campus and
seeking long term commitment to continuous improvement and systemic integration
of a sustainability perspective (FEE 2022). Those campuses that correctly implement
the seven steps methodology, develop their own action plan, and reach their objec-
tives are awarded the Green Flag (Pérez-Montero 2020), which has to be renewed
every two years, in order to assure their commitment to constant improvement
(Ryan-Fogarty et al. 2016).
This article analyzes the speciﬁc case of the work developed by the Environment
Ofﬁce of the University of Coruña (OMA-UDC, name changed to Ofﬁce of Sustain-
ability (OdS) in May 2024) as well as the progress and participation in sustainability
issues achieved in recent years, all within the framework of the UDC’s sustainability
management structure. The article includes the analysis of the research developed
in close collaboration with the OMA-UDC or that was the result of action research
programs. This is due to an approach where OMA-UDC’s sustainability actions
incorporate not only the active participation of the university community, but also
research methodologies to deﬁne and improve actions, as well as their monitoring
and evaluation. This applies, in particular, to the promotion of selective waste collec-
tion in educational centers, to decentralized composting on campus, to awareness,
prevention and efﬁciency in water use, to the use of nature-based solutions in the
campus, to the study and conservation of the natural environment and its enjoyment,
to the calculation and analysis of the ecological footprint, as well as to general educa-
tion programs for sustainability. It was also carried out by including service-learning
and project-based learning approaches (Bugallo-Rodríguez and Vega-Marcote 2020;
Servia et al. 2020; Torrijos et al. 2021; Dono et al. 2023).

V. Torrijos et al.
2
Description of the Sustainability Management Structure
at UDC
2.1
The Context: The UDC as an Institution, General Data
and Figures
In the academic year 2021/2022, with a renewal of 3,407 new students, the UDC
community reached 17.104 students, 1.444 teaching and research staff, 796 admin-
istrative staff members and 411 employees in other job categories (UDC 2022b).
The UDC area of inﬂuence comprises more than 600,000 inhabitants, corresponding
to the contiguous counties of A Coruña and Ferrol. UDC is one of the three public
universities of Galicia, an autonomous region of Spain with about 2,700,000 inhab-
itants, in which Galician and Spanish are the ofﬁcial languages. Because Galician
is the minoritized language, the University states in its Statutes (UDC 2022c) that
Galician is the normal vehicle of expression and its use will be encouraged in all
activities.
The University of A Coruña is territorially structured in the two campuses of A
Coruña and Ferrol (Fig. 1), with the ﬁrst one concentrating 84.4% of the students
(UDC 2022b). However, these two campuses include 8 different geographical loca-
tions. Two of these areas, Elviña and A Zapateira, which belong to the Coruña
Campus, are located contiguous on the edge of the urban area and constitute the
UDC Main Campus.
The main Campus is located in a marginal space in terms of the conservation of
natural ecosystems, with invasive and ruderal species being dominant, although with
vestiges of the ancient and fertile valley of the orchards of Elviña and the heritage
value of the Celtic fort located there, and which bears the same name. The topography
determines the difference between the areas of Elviña and A Zapateira. Zapateira is
the highest area, reaching 170 m above sea level. There are several centers that include
Philology, Tourism, Architecture, Chemistry and Biology studies. It also contains the
Monte da Fraga, an area of botanical and forestry interest. From this area there is
a sharp difference in level to the adjacent campus of Elviña, at only 36 m above
sea level. Elviña campus hosts most of the students. Other areas of implementation
of the UDC are those of Oza, Riazor and Bastiagueiro, the latter belonging to the
Municipality of Oleiros, bordering A Coruña. In addition, A Maestranza, an area
located on the coast of the city of A Coruña, hosts the administrative building of the
Rectory and the Nautical classroom. In the three areas of A Maestranza, Riazor and
Oza, most of the buildings have architectural and historical interest.
The Ferrol Campus has ﬁve study centers and other buildings that house admin-
istrative, research and study services. Very close to the center of Ferrol, it is a purely
urban campus but of important botanical, gardening and architectural value (UDC
2022d).
Further details of campus locations can be found on the UDC web link (UDC
2022a). Table 1 shows a summary of the main ﬁgures of the UDC. The space occupied

and administrative centers.

Cantabrian-Atlantic province, Galician-Portuguese sector (UDC 2011), character-
ized by a humid continental climate, but with an oceanic character and mild
temperatures, weak thermal contrasts and a short period of summer drought.
2.2
Sustainability in the UDC and the Role of the Ofﬁce
for the Environment
The 2013–2020 Strategic Plan of the UDC was in force until 2022, therefore during
the years that relate to this article (UDC 2013). This strategic planning included a
series of objectives and indicators, with two horizons, 2015 and 2020. Among them,
The Role of the Ofﬁce for the Environment at the University of a Coruña …
379
some stand out: (i) the preparation of environmental plans at school level, reaching
a minimum of 6 teaching centers before 2015 and all of them before 2020, (ii) the
implementation of the culture of recycling, with the aim of achieving the separate
collection of 80% of waste in 2020, (iii) the promotion of more sustainable mobility,
reducing the use of private cars in 2020 by 30% compared to 2008, (iv) the improve-
ment in energy efﬁciency, with the aim of reducing speciﬁc annual consumption by
10% in 2020 compared to 2011, as well as in (v) water savings, to achieve in 2020 a
10% reduction in consumption compared to 2011. The follow-up of these objectives
was assigned to the OMA-UDC.
Some results in relation to these objectives and indicators will be presented
throughout this article. Meanwhile, the renewal of the strategic plan is currently
underway, covering the period 2022–2026. This renewal process included a special-
ized work group in the area of “Social Responsibility and Sustainability”, following
the vision of the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for the transition to
a more ecological model of society that respects the environment and people.
An outline of the different services related to or complementary to environmental
sustainability at the UDC is shown in Fig. 2. The rector’s team includes the Rector, the
General Secretariat, the Management and nine vice-rectorships. The OMA-UDC is a
service that depends on the Vice-rectorship of Infrastructure and Sustainability (VIS),
which is the one with the greatest impact on sustainability issues. The Architecture,
Urbanism and Equipment Service also depends on the VIS, as well as the facilities
maintenance service. Another ﬁve vice-chancellorships are related to the issues of
environmental and social sustainability, complementing directly or indirectly the
scope of action of the OMA-UDC. Added to this are the services that depend on
the General Secretariat, such as the prevention of occupational risks (SPRL) and the
service for normalizing the use of the Galician language (SNL).
The thematic areas of the UDC are framed in three specialization campuses, one
of which is directly related to environmental content, the “Sustainability Campus”,
which promotes training and transversal research in the following four lines of
action: City and territory, Circular and sustainable economy, Social sustainability
and environmental education, and Healthy lifestyle. The other two areas of special-
ization are the “Industrial Campus”, focused on the industrial ﬁelds linked to the
economic potential of the region, especially in the naval and ocean ﬁeld, and the
“Innova Campus”, which deals with the impact of innovation on economic growth
and business development promoted by the university.
2.3
The Operating Structure of the OMA-UDC
The OMA-UDC participates in the coordination and implementation of different
environmental actions at the UDC. Its objectives fall into two priority areas: environ-
mental management and the awareness and participation of the university community
in issues related to the environment and sustainability. In this way, the actions of the
380
V. Torrijos et al.
Fig. 2 Map about different services related or complementary to environmental sustainability and
to the OMA-UDC
OMA-UDC can be framed in the following thematic blocks: (1) Environmental infor-
mation and disclosure on the UDC campuses, (2) Environmental participation and
co-responsibility, and (3) Sectoral projects related to environmental management and
sustainability. For its actions, the OMA-UDC currently counts with hired technical
staff (1 or 2 people), a network of students with scholarships, the hiring of external
services, and a part-time management ﬁgure.
The management of the OMA-UDC exercises the function of coordination. This
function is carried out by a member of the teaching staff with partial dedication
to these tasks. Since the creation of the OMA-UDC in 2008, scholarship students
have been signed, who initially performed work tasks (graduate students) and from
2011 participated in mixed training-diffusion programs (undergraduate students). In
addition, since the beginning of 2018, OMA-UDC has had one person hired to carry
out technical environmental work, develop environmental projects and collaborate in
the coordination of scholarship staff, among other tasks. Recently, since December
2021, a second person has joined this technical team.
For the good functioning of the OMA-UDC and to amplify the service to the
different locations and university disciplines, the collaboration of the scholarship
staff, who develop awareness and communication tasks towards the university
community, especially the student body, was decisive. This is a program of collabo-
ration and complementary training carried out in the OMA-UDC and in the centers
that have a Green Campus program (i.e. centers adhered to the international FEE
Eco Campus program). These scholarships are called by the Vice-rectorship for
Students, Participation and Employability and granted for 9 months (currently, after
The Role of the Ofﬁce for the Environment at the University of a Coruña …
381
the outbreak of COVID-19, only for 7 months) and have a dedication of 8 h per week.
These students receive a monthly ﬁnancial allowance for their participation in the
program. The call is repeated each academic year for the renewal of places, without
them being occupied by the same people from previous years. These scholarships
seek the theoretical and practical training of undergraduate students in the ﬁeld of
environment and sustainability, forming a multidisciplinary team, with scholarship
holders from almost all the degrees offered at the UDC. Until 2017, given the lack of
its own technical staff, the coordination of this network of scholarship holders was
carried out by an environmental NGO hired for that purpose.
Finally, to guarantee a professional and stable operation over time of certain
services offered and coordinated by the OMA-UDC, it was necessary to hire external
entities, usually environmental NGOs. Among the thematic lines with the partic-
ipation of these entities stand out: (1) sustainable mobility and the bicycle loan
service, with the Mobi-Liza association in charge of advising and training bicycle
users who renew each academic year, ( 2) the urban gardens, with Xestión Agro-
gandeira e Natureza SL being in charge of the training in ecological agriculture for
the people granted with plots for biannual periods, (3) the weekly management of
the composting areas developed by Deloga and Ecos do Sur, which train local and
immigrant people at risk of exclusion as master composters for their effective incor-
poration into a job, (4) the Proxecto Rios for the inspection of the Lagar river at the
Elviña Campus, (5) the custody of Monte da Fraga and the study and protection
of biodiversity, with the NGOs ADEGA (Association for the Ecological Defense of
Galicia) and GN Hábitat (Grupo Naturalista Hábitat), among others.
The participation of these entities also responds to another objective such as the
involvement of local society in university life, as well as that of opening the university
to local social and environmental problems.

environmental dissemination (Table 2). In 2009, the environment and sustainability
scholarship program for students also began, initially limited to the main campus, but
consolidated from 2015 in combination with the Green Campus program, gradually
reaching all study centers.

3.2
Current Lines of Action of the OMA-UDC
The main lines of action of the OMA-UDC and some services and activities that
it currently offers are those indicated in Table 3. The OMA-UDC is in charge of
waste management, water efﬁciency, low-impact mobility resources (bicycles, elec-
tric bicycles, …) and the management of certain areas of the campus, such as the
urban gardens, the Monte da Fraga forest area, the bodies of water present on the
campuses. In other areas, such as the use of energy, public road space, urban planning,
buildings, and maintenance, management and planning correspond to the SAUE, in
which the OMA-UDC participates by providing criteria for sustainability.
We can see in Table 3 that the lines of action are not limited to the university
environment, but seek to go further, to the domestic and municipal sphere.
With the development of the Education for Sustainability project (Campus-Home-
City: Labs of Change), the sectoral work lines in water, energy and waste were
extended to the area of residence of members of the university community interested
in participating in this type of action. The similarity, total or partial, in energy, water
and waste issues between the university center as a work or study environment and
the domestic environment, is the basis of the development of OMA-Emapic tools
for the calculation of the ecological footprint of those components, as well as of the
eco-audit manuals and practical workshops offered by OMA-UDC in these subjects.
Under this idea of “Campus-Home-City: Labs of Change” actions are combined in
awareness, training and changes in environmental behavior (and, in some cases, also
in the material means used) that seek to advance more pro-environmental lifestyles.
Thus, we take advantage of the synergies between the actions on campus and at
home, in the ﬁrst instance, and ﬁnally in the area of the city, that is to say, of the local
community.
The OMA-UDC prepares annual or one-off reports relating to the sectoral lines
of action. These reports are necessary for a good monitoring of the actions and for
the registration and subsequent evaluation thereof. All reports are posted in each
speciﬁc section of the website (https://www.udc.es/gl/sociedade/medio_ambiente/),
with access to the general public.
In the following sections, some of the main thematic lines of action of the OMA-
UDC are detailed.

3.2.1
The Forest Space of Monte Da Fraga
In 2006, the University of A Coruña restored the space between the faculties of
Science and Philology, removing most of the eucalyptus trees (a non-native species
that causes multiple negative impacts on the ecosystem and the water cycle) and
reforesting it with native species representative of the Galician forests. With the
restoration of this space, the UDC intended to:
– Offer a space with triple potential: dissemination, teaching and research, for active
and interactive learning about the environment and sustainability. The space also
hosts a water treatment plant through a constructed wetland, sustainable urban
drainage systems, and spaces for teaching practices in botany and ecology, for
identiﬁcation and knowledge of biodiversity, for leisure and ecological trails, etc.)
– Promote the participation of environmental volunteers in the UDC in the custody
of the territory and the ecological recovery of the space.
– Offer a green and natural reference to the city of A Coruña, due to the location
of Monte da Fraga on the urban border of the city and its enormous landscape
potential, with views of Castro de Elviña, the city and the ocean.
– Recover and conserve ecosystems speciﬁc to the oceanic climate of the Atlantic
region,withreforestationactionswithrepresentativespecies,creationofwetlands,
elimination of invasive exotic species and promotion of biodiversity.
In recent years, an intensive program of activities has been carried out centered on
the Monte da Fraga area (Fig. 3). For the work in this space, the OMA-UDC has the
regular participation of researchers from the botany area of the biology department
and the environmental NGOs ADEGA and GN Hábitat, as well as other specialized
associations such as the UDC Big Bang (identiﬁcation and collection of mushrooms),
Sorex (bats studies), Amarelas (forest baths).
3.2.2
Education for Sustainability
‘Education for Sustainability’ is a project that seeks to advance in the formation of
the university community and citizenship in the basic concepts of environmental and
social sustainability and develop its capacity to act on those issues that are nowadays
priorities. Conceived as a multidisciplinary program, it covers a wide range of ages,
extending the last calls to children’s, primary and secondary education, in addition
to the university audience targeted by the previous editions. The target audience are
students, but also includes the teachers and people working in educational centers,
such as administrative, research, gardening, or dining rooms staff, among others.
Under the general name ‘Campus, Home, City; Labs for change’, the ‘Education
for Sustainability’ program includes the ‘Environmental March 2022’, an online
summer course on ‘Ecological footprint and climate emergency: contributions from
the UDC’, as well as speciﬁc actions spread throughout the academic course.
Throughout the ﬁve editions developed until 2022 at UDC, it has reached 10,449
participants with an average dedication time of 2 h. Each edition renews the content
The Role of the Ofﬁce for the Environment at the University of a Coruña …
387
Fig. 3 Some education and awareness activities in Monte da Fraga. 1. Flora biodiversity mapping,
2, 7, 8. Interpretative routes, 3. Volunteering reforestation, 4, 9. Construction and placing of bird nest
houses, 5. Creation of wetland zone, 6. Biodiversity inspection at wetland zone, 10, 11. Removal
of invasive exotic ﬂora
of the program, innovating and offering topics of interest in the nearest present, which
are addressed through different types of activities: conferences, panel-tables discus-
sion, workshops, volunteering, cinema, among others (Fig. 4). The University of A
Coruña accredits the involvement of students in these training actions, including the
recognition of credits for degree students in accordance with the regulations updated
annually (Annex I, point 8: UDC 2022f).
Meanwhile, last year’s primary and secondary school participation reached 442
students and 29 teachers from six centers in A Mariña (Lugo), with more than 800 h
of dedication. In addition, three centers carried out sustainability projects related to
waste separation, composting and energy saving.
3.2.3
OMA-Emapic Calculators of Ecological Footprint
OMA-Emapic calculators are currently available for both mobile and computer
devices at the following link: https://emapic.es/custom/oma, under the input viewer
shown in Fig. 5. The tools are linked to each other for the calculation of the overall
Ecological Footprint, facilitating to know the complete CO2 emissions associated
with the current lifestyle of people, being possible to participate independently in
each tool. A speciﬁc feature of the tool is the positioning of contributors on the map,
thus promoting citizen science through participatory geo-referencing (Varela-García
et al. 2022).

The application of these tools for sustainability has an interesting potential that
is evident in lines such as: (1) promotion and better learning of the terms of sustain-
ability, (2) contribution of online tools for the understanding and learning of sustain-
ability, especially for the Z and Alpha generations (from the year 2000 and 2010,
respectively), (3) environmental education through the analysis of daily habits and
teaching tips, (4) information obtained from the calculation of different components
of the carbon footprint and derived learning.
The development of these tools requires research on the situation of each topic in
the geographical and social context of the area of application, which in this case was
the one corresponding to Galiza as an autonomous community of the Spanish State
(Soto and Varela 2018). The infrastructures for waste management, energy produc-
tion, transport and mobility, together with cultural and consumption habits condition
basic aspects of the applied methodologies. The ecological footprint calculator for
food and clothing is still pending.
3.2.4
Sostauga Project and Rivers Project
Launched in 2010, the Sostauga project aims to achieve a sustainable use of water
and improve the quality of water and associated ecosystems. To achieve this goal,
the Sostauga project deﬁned some priority goals to be achieved through applied
research on campus, environmental education and awareness activities. Among these
goals and priorities, the following stand out: the reduction of water consumption in
university facilities and activities (Torrijos et al. 2020), the potential use of endoge-
nous resources (rainwater, underground and spring water) (Carballeira et al. 2011),
the study of the feasibility of an ecological wastewater treatment model based on
constructed wetlands (Carballeira et al. 2021; Sánchez et al. 2023), the management
of urban runoff through nature-based solutions through bioﬁlters and rain gardens
(Lage et al. 2019) and the potential for the restoration of the campus’ pre-existing
river courses.
390
V. Torrijos et al.
Fig. 6 Images of different actions and activities related to sustainability at the UDC. 1. Bicycle
loan service; 2. Rivers Project; 3. Urban gardens on campus; 4. Group of scholarship students: 5.
Green Flag; 6. Volunteers in the UDC composting area
Sostauga also promotes environmental education and awareness among the entire
academic community. With this aim, since 2011 the methodology of the Rivers
Project (‘Proxecto Ríos’: ADEGA 2005) has been applied, in particular in a stretch
of the Lagar River as it passes through the Elviña Campus. The Rivers Project is
a Galician environmental volunteer network for river inspection through quality
parameters based on biodiversity and the physical and chemical quality of aquatic
ecosystems (Fig. 6(2)). Due to its educational interest, since 2017, the activities of
the Rivers Project have been incorporated into the Service-Learning program of the
Faculty of Sciences. It was also the subject of several Degree Thesis at the UDC.
3.2.5
Composting and Urban Vegetable Gardens
The dining hall waste composting program on campus began in 2010 and was born
linked to an urban vegetable garden project that was ﬁnally launched in 2013. The
goal of the composting program is to produce high-quality organic amendments and
fertilizers to be used in urban agriculture and campus gardening. This association
composting-gardens-food production forms an ideal situation in which two of the
objectives of the sustainability policy of the UDC are met, such as the dissemina-
tion and promotion of local-traditional and ecological agricultural practices and the
sustainable management of organic waste (Torrijos et al. 2021). The UDC currently
has 9 composting areas in different locations on campus (Fig. 6(6)). It also has 40
plots of urban gardens (20 m2 each) for renting to members of the university commu-
nity (students and staff) for a period of up to 4 consecutive years (Fig. 6(3)). New
settlements for the expansion of urban vegetable gardens are currently under study.
This combination provides a robust service to the university community that is
well received by students and staff. On a scale of 1 to 4 points, the gardens of the
The Role of the Ofﬁce for the Environment at the University of a Coruña …
391
UDC were rated with 3 (45%) and 4 (52%) points by the users, in the responses to
a survey carried out in the fall of 2019. This represents a very positive assessment,
notwithstanding some aspects which, according to the survey, could be improved. In
addition, the majority of users stated that the UDC should enable more garden spaces
for the university community (79%). Also the majority (85%) considered that the
size of the plots is sufﬁcient, while 15% considered it insufﬁcient. More than half of
the users frequently cultivated a variety of eight vegetables, reaching more than 25
different species as a whole.
Currently, the amount of compost produced is sufﬁcient to cover all the needs
of this urban vegetable garden. In terms of chemical composition, the compost has
an excellent quality, generally Class A in the content of heavy metals, thus compat-
ible with the requirements of the organic agriculture regulations. The quality of the
compost was rated as good-very good by the users (65%) or fair (31%), and only
4–6% of the users declared that it seemed bad. Compost is offered stabilized but
unreﬁned. In this sense, 56% of users considered it convenient to pre-screen the
compost, to remove bones, shells and other coarse particles.
The research work played a key role in the implementation and consolidation of
the composting program at the UDC. The beginning of the program was formulated
as part of a doctoral thesis (Vázquez 2015), which included the development of
different technologies to apply in decentralized composting based on the amount of
organic waste to be treated (Vázquez et al. 2015, 2020). Research in this ﬁeld is still
ongoing, both to achieve better product sanitation (Torrijos et al. 2021) and to expand
the application of decentralized composting not only to kitchen waste but also to the
organic fraction collected separately in general areas of university centers (Torrijos
and Soto 2022; Torrijos et al. 2023). This organic waste stream usually includes a
greater amount of inappropriate substances that can affect the quality of the compost.
3.2.6
Bicycle Loan and Sustainable Mobility
The use of bicycles as a mean of transport and travel reduces trafﬁc congestion,
improves environmental quality in cities, contributes to reducing greenhouse gas
emissions, and improves the health of the people who use them. In this way, the
objective of this program launched in 2008 is to promote the use of the bicycle as a
vehicle for sustainable mobility, facilitating access to a bicycle for those interested
in using it to travel to university centers. The loan is aimed at the entire university
community, students and staff, even though students are the main users. The loan
service at the UDC is designed as a transfer of use for an entire academic year,
promoting the incorporation of this means of transport to people who previously
did not use the bicycle. With a very low cost for users, the program favors the
empowerment and consolidation of people as future cycle users (Fig. 6(1)).
People interested in borrowing a bicycle have the option of choosing between
two sizes of bicycle, and recently, since the 2021/2022 school year, also folding
and electric bicycles. Currently, the service has a ﬂeet of 115 bicycles, which are
accompanied by all the mandatory and safety accessories. In addition, the service is
392
V. Torrijos et al.
completed with training activities on basic rules of safe circulation, ergonomics and
basic bicycle maintenance. In the OMA-UDC “Bicycles” web section, the best routes
to access the different campuses by bicycle are published in online map format.
At the end of each loan period, cycle users make an overall assessment of the
service. This assessment obtained for the period 2016–2022 the average score of
4.36 points out of 5. This evaluation also conﬁrms that the bicycle loan service is an
effective instrument to increase the number of users of this means of transport within
the university community. The users are mainly students who change to an address
during the course other than the family address. The results of this analysis indicate
that the users estimated the possibility of obtaining a bicycle easily and at low cost
as a good opportunity to check the effectiveness of this means of transport and also
measure the real use they could make of it during the academic year. Although there
are still conﬂicting points on the bike path to get from the city to the main campus,
the number of people who used the bike every day to get to the UDC has gradually
increased in recent years. The training in terms of circulation rules, ergonomics and
maintenance of the bicycle was perceived as an element of great importance, given
that the percentage of people on the loan who are new bicycle users is considerable.
The city of A Coruña is making progress in the implementation of the bicycle
in the urban area, creating a well-conditioned network of cycle lanes and spaces
enabled for safe parking. These improvements will strengthen the potential for more
sustainable mobility between university centers and the city in the future.
The OMA-Emapic model of the mobility ecological footprint calculator (see
Sect. 3.2.3) was adapted for its speciﬁc application to the displacements of the univer-
sity community because of their university activities. This tool is now standardized
for the calculation of this component of the global ecological footprint of the univer-
sity. That component is of great importance, because the resulting CO2 emissions are
higher than those derived from energy use at the university, contributing to approxi-
mately half of the total ecological footprint (Perez-Lopez et al. 2021). The use of this
tool in recent years has made it possible to investigate both the effect of the COVID-19
pandemic and the reduction of collective public transport prices on people’s modes
of travel (UDC 2023). At ﬁrst, and during the 2021–2022 academic year, COVID-19
reduced travel by the university community but increased the use of private vehicles.
This last trend changed in the opposite direction in the autumn of 2022 due to the
effect of the reduction in the price of public transport for periodic trips. This reduc-
tion was ﬁnanced in Spain by the governments with public funds and in some cases
reached total gratuity.
3.2.7
Scholarship Program and Environmental Volunteering
Several details of the scholarships program at UDC are given in Sect. 2.3. In addition
to the 4 scholarships offered at OMA-UDC for science, engineering and communica-
tion students, each Green Campus center has at least one scholarship student selected
from among the students of the degrees implemented in the respective center. This
reaches a total of 20 places, of which a maximum of 17 have been ﬁlled (Table 5).
The Role of the Ofﬁce for the Environment at the University of a Coruña …
393
This makes it possible to create a transversal and interdisciplinary network of action
and training.
Coordinated by the OMA-UDC, scholarship students participate in general
sustainability activities, particularly in all those related to education for sustain-
ability, dissemination and communication, and the monitoring of the various sectoral
programs (water, waste, composting, biodiversity…). For this, weekly or fortnightly
coordination meetings are held, either in person or online, with the participation of
OMA-UDC staff and several or all scholarship students. Their participation is not
limited to assistance and participation in the activities, but includes participation in
programming, management and their evaluation. At the end of the academic year,
scholarship students complete an assessment survey, which obtained an average score
of 4.37 out of 5 (n = 66) for the period 2017–2022.
The university community of the UDC can choose two ways of involvement
in environmental volunteering: (1) participating in speciﬁc days, usually of 2–3 h
duration, generally these are ﬁeld activities with varied themes (biodiversity, mapping
environmental issues, water audits, waste…), (2) taking a stable commitment for the
academic year, usually involving 1–3 h per week. In the latter case, the volunteer
receives speciﬁc initial training to carry out the actions autonomously, albeit with
periodic expert supervision.
The environmental volunteering of the UDC is managed by the OMA, following
the rules of the Ofﬁce of Cooperation and Volunteering that manages general
volunteering in social matters. The UDC recognizes the involvement of students
in these environmental volunteer actions, being included in Annex II, point 8 of
the regulations on recognition of credits for undergraduate students (UDC 2022f)
(Fig. 6(6)).
3.2.8
Green Campus Program
The Green Campus (GC) program is based on participatory and common methodolo-
gies at an international level, deﬁned by the Foundation for Environmental Education,
and speciﬁed for Spain by the Environmental and Consumer Education Association
(ADEAC). These entities act as external auditors, so that Green Campus can be
assimilated to an environmental management system. The methodology includes
the creation of an Environmental Committee, the realization of an Eco-audit and
the preparation of an Action Plan (Ares-Pernas et al. 2020). The positive audit by
ADEAC grants the green ﬂag to the center (Fig. 6(5)), and certiﬁes the confor-
mity of the program developed. The program is under continuous supervision and,
under ordinary conditions, is renewed every two years. The university community
is sought to participate in the identiﬁcation, prevention and provision of solutions to
sustainability problems.
The GC program began to be applied at the UDC from 2014, gradually incor-
porating various centers, and now reaching all the teaching centers of the UDC,
although with different levels of intensity and consolidation. This application of the
program at the center level, or grouping of centers by campus area, instead of a

single program for the whole university, is a distinctive element of GC at UDC and
guarantees grassroots participation and gives it a strong bottom-up character. Thus,
it contrasts with other centralized or top-down approaches. The OMA-UDC acts as a
link between the different GC programs and for coordination with external agents, in
particular ADEAC. The GC program has already incorporated all the student training
centers and part of the administrative and research centers (Fig. 7). Currently, it has
15 green ﬂags (positive evaluations) covering 28 buildings of the University of A
Coruña.
The evolution of the Green Campus program at UDC was analyzed in a recent
study, which paid attention to the difﬁculties and shortcomings identiﬁed and
proposed solutions (Dono et al. 2023). Being one of the few scientiﬁc reports on the
FEE Eco Campus, the study highlighted the insufﬁcient knowledge of the program
on the part of the students of the UDC and identiﬁed their involvement as one of
the main challenges. The participation of members of the university community in
the Green Campus program is fundamentally voluntary, and greater recognition is
needed. However, the program received a good overall rating from participating staff
and students.
