3.3
Indicators of Participation in Sustainability Actions
at UDC
The participation data over the years of the university community in the main sustain-
ability actions coordinated by the OMA-UDC are shown in Table 5. The ﬁgures indi-
cate the number of people-action participants, so they are not necessarily different
people; moreover, the time of each action can be very variable, depending on its
nature and duration. Even so, the ﬁgures indicate a notable increase in participation
in these topics, which roughly multiplied by a factor of 10 over the last decade.
It is estimated that, currently, between 15 and 20% of the university community
participates directly in one of these sustainability programs and actions.
The number of participants was obtained from the review of the activity reports
of the different years. Until 2016, the records are partial, so the ﬁgures are indicative.
3.4
Some Indicators of UDC’s Environmental Performance
Regardingtheconsumptionofmaterialsandgenerationofwaste,verypositiveﬁgures
were recorded in this period from 2010 to 2021, with a reduction of 39% in total waste
generated, an increase from 40 to 70% of separate collection at source. In addition, a
reduction of 84% in the consumption of paper was recorded in reprographic services,
due in large part to recent social and technological changes. These are absolute
ﬁgures, for a period in which the university community has also shrunk by 20%
in size. An improvement in the efﬁcient use of water was also recorded, with a
39% reduction in total consumption, representing a 23% reduction in per capita
consumption.
However, the ﬁgures for energy use are not so good. Total electricity consumption
fell by 13%, while per capita consumption increased by 9%. Consumption of heating
fuels increased in absolute terms (22%) and per capita (53%). This led to a maintained
consumption of total energy (+0.2%) in the period, as well as an appreciable increase
in total energy consumption per capita (+26%). Although net reductions in total
energy consumption were recorded in 2020 as a result of the successive periods of
quarantine due to COVID-19, the increase recorded in recent years can be explained
by ventilation measures to reduce the presence of radon gas in buildings and to
improve conditions against COVID-19. The reduction in the intensity of use of the
facilities due to the reduction in the number of students also explains the increase in
per capita consumption rates.
The area in which the greatest difﬁculties were encountered for improvement was
the transport of the university community to the study and work centers. Mobility
is dominated by the use of private cars, both among staff and among students. The
modest advances recorded over the years have been cut short by the response to
COVID-19 which has led to greater adherence to the private car. In this way, more
than 50% of the total carbon footprint of the UDC is due to the transportation of
The Role of the Ofﬁce for the Environment at the University of a Coruña …
397
people, despite the recent improvements following the reduction in public transport
prices, as already indicated.
Finally, since the ﬁrst participation in 2016, the UDC has improved positions in
each call of the Green Metric International Ranking, appearing in 2021 as the 49th
most sustainable university in the world and the 4th among the Spanish universities
(UDC 2022e).
4
Further Remarks and Conclusions
HEIs must play a key role in achieving the United Nations SDGs for 2030, due to their
contribution to governance, education, research, outreach and their responsibility in
campus operations (Gonçalves Seraﬁni et al. 2022; Elmassah et al. 2022). However, it
has been argued that the contribution of HEIs should not be measured in terms of mere
scientiﬁc and knowledge production, but rather in terms of their ability to address
major local challenges through collaboration, civic engagement and dissemination
(Cottafava et al. 2022). That is, they must be main agents in the local change towards
a more sustainable development. It is for this goal that the combination of research
and action for sustainability manifests its great potential. Thus, the OMA-UDC’s
sustainability approach incorporated both the objective of active participation of the
university community, through learning by doing and service learning activities, as
well as action research methodologies to deﬁne and improve actions and their results.
The OMA-UDC has developed intense work for the implementation of sustain-
ability initiatives on UDC campuses and centers, and to raise awareness among
students and staff on sustainability issues. Currently, the OMA-UDC’s permanent
programs are education for sustainability, management of campus forest areas and
biodiversity, urban gardens, on-site composting systems for organic canteen waste,
waste prevention and separate collection, eco-audits for water saving, bicycle loan,
ecological footprint calculation and environmental volunteering coordination. With
regard to the structure and working methods, participation is a key aspect, which the
UDC has been promoting through programs such as the network of environmental
scholarship students and the Eco Campus program which involves the creation of
environmental committees in all centers. The work developed by the OMA-UDC is
complemented to a large extent by other parts of the UDC’s sustainability and social
responsibility management structure, which deal with issues such as health, gender
equality, inclusiveness, volunteering or cooperation.
Action research and learning by doing methodologies were applied, in partic-
ular, to the promotion of the selective collection of waste in centers, to the on-site
composting of organic waste from campus canteens and the use of compost in the
fertilization of urban vegetable gardens, to awareness, prevention and efﬁciency in
the use of water, to the calculation and analysis of the ecological footprint through the
development of own calculators adapted to local reality, to the activation and partic-
ipation in the international Green Campus program, as well as to the general educa-
tion programs for sustainability. These experiences, published in different research
398
V. Torrijos et al.
articles elsewhere, can serve as an example and motivation for other universities
and HEIs. The correct management and recycling of waste is a ﬁrst step towards a
more circular economy, but it is not enough. On the way to greater circularity, new
needs arise, such as the research and implementation of sharing, exchange and repair
models and services. There is also a need to explore new ways to move forward in
reducing emissions through greater individual and collective commitment to miti-
gating climate change. They are also new opportunities for the UDC to maintain and
strengthen its role as a leader of sustainability at the local level.
This sustainability approach at UDC has a marked bottom-up character, charac-
terized by the voluntary action of many of the agents, such as the people active in
the Green Campus program. Its consolidation and maintenance in the medium and
long term requires greater institutionalization as well as solutions to the difﬁculties
of participation and lack of means that have been highlighted in the analysis of some
of the ﬁelds of action.

Research and Educational Opportunities
Powering Sustainable Development: The
Critical Role of Energy Research
Aliaksandr Novikau
Abstract Energy is a critical component of sustainable development, and energy
research is essential to achieve the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals
(SDGs), including SDG 7, “Affordable and clean energy.” Energy is also vital
for achieving other SDGs due to its strong links to human health and well-being,
economic growth, environmental sustainability, and social development. Nonethe-
less, current energy systems are rarely sustainable, primarily because they rely on
fossil fuels. Hence, there is a pressing need for research to develop sustainable energy
solutions. This chapter highlights two essential aspects of energy’s role in sustainable
development research. First, research should concentrate on making energy more
sustainable, emphasizing the need for a green energy transition. Second, research
should focus on the relationship between energy and other SDGs, speciﬁcally how
sustainable energy can contribute to achieving them. The paper discusses the signif-
icance of sustainable energy solutions, such as wind, solar, hydro, and biomass, as
well as the crucial role of energy efﬁciency in reducing energy consumption. Addi-
tionally, the chapter explores the link between energy and poverty, education, gender
equality, and health, emphasizing how sustainable energy can help achieve these
SDGs. The chapter also stresses the need for international cooperation to achieve
SDGs.
Keywords SDG7 · Energy · Energy poverty · Sustainable development
1
Introduction
Energy is an indispensable prerequisite for the sustenance and progress of human life.
Like all living organisms, humans need energy to sustain their biological functions,
including metabolism and growth. Fundamentally, any living organism on our planet
can uphold its internal order only by acquiring free energy from the environment
A. Novikau (B)
Department of Political Science and International Relations, International University of Sarajevo,
Hrasnička Cesta 15, 71210 Ilidža, Bosnia and Herzegovina
e-mail: anovikau@ius.edu.ba
© The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024
W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_23
403
404
A. Novikau
through sunlight or nutrients while concurrently releasing an equivalent quantity of
energy back into its surroundings as heat and entropy.
However, unlike other living organisms, humans extensively utilize energy in
other forms. For instance, maintaining thermal comfort is of utmost importance for
survival. The signiﬁcance of ﬁre for the well-being and longevity of early humans
became apparent during colonizing new regions with colder climates (Roebroeks and
Villa 2011; Smil 2017). In recent centuries, thermal comfort research has primarily
focused on addressing the issue of low temperatures. Nevertheless, a signiﬁcant
portion of the global population, numbering in the billions, resides in regions char-
acterized by constant hot outdoor temperatures. Even in Europe, recent heat waves
have demonstrated the necessity of implementing air conditioning systems to alle-
viate the stress caused by elevated temperatures. Therefore, it is imperative to broaden
the scope of thermal comfort research to encompass the challenges posed by high-
temperature environments and develop appropriate strategies for mitigating their
detrimental impacts on human well-being. Similarly, improving lighting conditions
enhances the quality of life, job performance, and safety.
Due to inherent limitations in physical mobility, humans have consistently strived
to explore alternative energy sources for transportation. Throughout history, people
have employed the power of water, wind, and animals for it. Nonetheless, a remark-
able milestone in transportation was reached when people started using engines that
work on coal or oil products. The introduction of the steam engine and its subsequent
implementation in steamships and railways resulted in a revolutionary inﬂuence on
global trade, signiﬁcantly improving the overall standard of living. Consequently,
the invention of the internal combustion engine and the emergence of automobiles
and airplanes enabled travel to previously insurmountable distances. The continuous
advancement of transportation technologies has even pushed the boundaries to the
extent that space travel is now perceived as a realistic and attainable prospect.
Energy positively affects the manufacturing of industrial goods and agricultural
products. Access to reliable and inexpensive energy has enabled industries to power
machinery, equipment, and processes, increasing production rates and improving
product quality. The availability of energy-intensive processes, such as assembly
lines, automation, and precision farming technologies, has reduced labor needs and
enhanced overall productivity.
Energy is crucial for modern communication. Even thousands of years ago,
before the advent of electricity, humans relied on ingenious methods to commu-
nicate across vast distances that required energy, such as using lights and ﬁres. The
progress in electricity made advanced communication possible—ﬁrst telegraph and
telephone, and currently emails, instant messaging, and videotelephony, enabling
instantaneous communication over very long distances. Not surprisingly, energy
has become paramount for development and human security. Without an affordable
energy supply, human development and even life are often threatened.
At the same time, energy use leads to environmental degradation and adversely
impacts human and planetary health (Novikau 2022). Nearly every aspect of energy
use exerts detrimental effects on the environment. The processes involved in fossil
fuel extraction and transportation invariably lead to the contamination of terrestrial
Powering Sustainable Development: The Critical Role of Energy Research
405
and aquatic ecosystems, posing signiﬁcant hazards to all life forms. Crude oil spills
disseminate across vast expanses of land and water, spanning hundreds to thou-
sands of miles and inﬂicting prolonged damage on affected regions, often requiring
decades for complete recovery. The combustion of fossil fuels emits hazardous
substances, including carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, ozone,
lead, and particulate matter, primarily into the atmosphere (EPA 2023). Further-
more, releasing carbon dioxide during fossil fuel combustion contributes to global
climate change, resulting in an average temperature rise of approximately 1.2 °C.
This increasing global temperature has brought many climate change risks, affecting
both natural and human systems. Among these risks are sea-level rise, loss of biodi-
versity, extreme weather events, and the emergence of food and water shortages
(IPCC 2018). Besides fossil fuels, other energy sources, such as nuclear energy,
present their dangers related to the risks associated with the production, usage, and
management of nuclear fuel.
Energy plays a central role in sustainable development due to its positive and
negative effects on human development, health, and the environment. On the one
hand, access to reliable and sustainable energy is essential for human prosperous
and fulﬁlling life and economic, social, and technological progress. On the other
hand, unsustainable energy use can adversely impact the global climate, planetary
health, the sustainable use of natural resources, and overall harmony with nature. In
this regard, the UN envisions a world “where human habitats are safe, resilient, and
sustainable and where there is universal access to affordable, reliable, and sustainable
energy” (United Nations 2015).
Achieving SDGs is facing challenges on a global scale. Speciﬁcally, the achieve-
ment of SDG 7 in developing countries is below 10% (Leal Filho et al. 2023). For
instance, progress in providing universal access to electricity and clean cooking has
slowed, and the share of renewables in the energy mix remains low (United Nations
2023). Despite projected improvements for the three indicators, they are unlikely to
achieve the goals by 2030 (He et al. 2022). Current energy systems are rarely sustain-
able, primarily due to their heavy reliance on fossil fuels. Modern energy systems
exhibitseveraldeﬁningfeatures,includingincreasingenergyconsumption,thedeple-
tion of nonrenewable energy resources, and escalating risks to energy services. Thus,
modern energy systems are fundamentally incongruent with the principles outlined
in SDG 7. The COVID-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine have further augmented
the complexities surrounding the realization of the UN Agenda 2030 (Elavarasan
et al. 2021; Pereira et al. 2022; Leal Filho et al. 2023; Liu et al. 2023).
The scientiﬁc community holds signiﬁcant potential to play a pivotal role in
bolstering the implementation of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through
research, development, and sustainable education. However, energy remains among
the least researched SDGs (Salvia et al. 2019).
This paper aims to analyze the importance of energy for achieving SDGs, identify
critical shortcomings of modern energy systems, and propose main directions for
energy research.

A. Novikau
Thechapterisstructuredasfollows:ThenextsectionexaminestheUNSustainable
Development Goal 7—“Affordable and clean energy.” Section 3 explores the inter-
connections between SDG 7 and other sustainable development goals. In Sect. 4,
the main directions for energy research are identiﬁed. Section 5 emphasizes the
signiﬁcance of international cooperation in energy research and its contribution to
achieving SDGs. The ﬁnal section concludes and offers some directions for further
research.
2
SDG 7. Affordable and Clean Energy
Energy is critical to sustainable development, and energy research is essential to
achieving the SDGs. Contrasting with the Millennium Development Goals, the
United Nations has explicitly incorporated energy as one of its SDGs–SDG 7,
“Affordable and clean energy” (United Nations 2023). The explicit inclusion of
energy in the SDGs highlights the recognition of its critical role in global sustainable
development. By integrating energy into the SDGs, the United Nations acknowl-
edges its signiﬁcance as a fundamental driver of social and economic progress,
environmental preservation, and improved quality of life worldwide. It underscores
the interconnections between energy, poverty eradication, climate action, economic
growth, and several other dimensions of sustainable development. By incorporating
affordable and clean energy as a target, the international community seeks to foster
a comprehensive approach to addressing energy-related challenges, paving the way
for a more inclusive, resilient, and sustainable future (United Nations 2015).
SDG 7 aims to “Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable, and modern
energy for all.” This goal effectively tackles three critical dimensions of contempo-
rary global energy challenges.
First, it emphasizes the reliability and affordability of energy supply, the aspects
traditionally encompassed within the concept of energy security (Yergin 2006). By
highlighting these dimensions, SDG 7 recognizes the signiﬁcance of securing a
consistent and economically viable energy supply to meet the needs of societies and
ensure their stability and resilience.
Second, SDG 7 addresses the environmental dimension of energy security, a facet
often neglected in earlier deﬁnitions. This dimension acknowledges that achieving
energy security should not come at the expense of detrimental environmental impacts
(APERC 2007).
Third, SDG 7 highlights the importance of addressing the individual dimension of
energy security, called energy poverty. It recognizes that 675 million people do not
have access to electricity, and 2.3 billion still use polluting fuels such as wood, coal,
charcoal, or biomass for heating and cooking (United Nations 2023). It inevitably
hinders their well-being and limits their social and economic development oppor-
tunities. The goal of prioritizing energy access for all is to alleviate energy poverty
and promote inclusive and equitable progress. Although SDG 7 does not explicitly
mention the term “right to energy,” in many respects, it implies that modern and
Powering Sustainable Development: The Critical Role of Energy Research
407
sustainable energy should be viewed as a fundamental right of every human being
(Shyu 2021).
SDG 7 has several crucial targets and indicators to make the goal actionable,
measurable, and achievable. These targets and indicators help track progress, foster
accountability, and guide the decision-making process (United Nations 2015).
Target 7.1. “By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern
energy services.”
This target has several indicators:
Indicator 7.1.1. “Proportion of population with access to electricity.”
Access to electricity is a good indicator for measuring the extent to which people
and communities have reliable access to clean energy sources. Monitoring this indi-
cator makes it possible to gauge the progress made in expanding electricity access
to unserved or underserved areas, bridging the energy access gap, and ensuring that
a greater proportion of the global population can beneﬁt from the advantages of
electricity.
Indicator 7.1.2. “Proportion of the population with primary reliance on clean fuels and
technology.”
The second indicator of the target demonstrates the importance of moving away
from ineffective and polluting energy sources, such as coal, charcoal, and biomass,
towards cleaner and more sustainable alternatives, such as electric cookstoves, lique-
ﬁed petroleum gas, or renewable energy sources like solar, wind, or hydro. The indi-
cator reﬂects national and international efforts to improve energy efﬁciency, reduce
indoor air pollution, and mitigate global climate change.
Target 7.2. “By 2030, increase the share of renewable energy in the global energy
mix substantially” with only one indicator:
Indicator 7.2.1. “Renewable energy shares in the total ﬁnal energy consumption.”
Tracking the shares of renewable energy in the energy mix makes it possible to
assess the effectiveness of policies aimed at increasing renewable energy deployment.
This indicator also allows comparisons across countries and regions, identifying best
practices and areas for improvement. It also provides a basis for setting targets, devel-
oping renewable energy strategies, and fostering collaboration among governments,
industries, and other stakeholders.
Target 7.3. “By 2030, double the global rate of improvement in energy efﬁciency.”
• Indicator 7.3.1. “Energy intensity measured in terms of primary energy and GDP.”
Measuring energy intensity allows us to evaluate the efﬁciency gains achieved
in different economies (Novikau 2019). By comparing energy consumption trends
with economic performance, it is possible to identify countries that have successfully
decoupled energy use from economic growth, indicating a more efﬁcient use of
energy resources.
408
A. Novikau
Two sub-targets in SDG 7 support and complement the main targets. Their indi-
cators are typically more qualitative and provide additional context and depth to the
primary indicators.
Target 7.a. “By 2030, enhance international cooperation to facilitate access to
clean energy research and technology, including renewable energy, energy efﬁciency,
and advanced and cleaner fossil-fuel technology, and promote investment in energy
infrastructure and clean energy technology.”
• Indicator 7.a.1. “International ﬁnancial ﬂows to developing countries in support
of clean energy research and development and renewable energy production,
including in hybrid systems.”
Target7.b.“By2030,expandinfrastructureandupgradetechnologyforsupplying
modern and sustainable energy services for all in developing countries, in particular,
least developed countries, small island developing states, and land-locked developing
countries, by their respective programs of support.”
• Indicator 7.b.1. “Installed renewable energy-generating capacity in developing
countries (in watts per capita).”
Both sub-indicators highlight the signiﬁcance of international cooperation,
research, technology, investment, and infrastructure development for modern and
clean energy. They emphasize the need for collaborative actions to mobilize resources
and overcome barriers, particularly in developing countries and regions with speciﬁc
energy challenges.
At the same time, some studies demonstrate the existence of negative correlations
within SDG 7. Speciﬁcally, the progress in Indicator 7.1.2. achieved in some, mainly
developing countries, by the expansion of fossil fuels contradicts Indicator 7.2.1
(Pradhan et al. 2017; Khan et al. 2022).
3
Importance of Energy for Other SDGs
One of the core principles of UN SDGs is their integration and indivisibility, which
means that implementing the 2030 Agenda should consider their interlinked nature
(United Nations 2015; Bennich et al. 2020; Castor et al. 2020).
Energy is vital for achieving other SDGs because of its strong links to economic
growth, environmental sustainability, and social development. Essentially, progress
in sustainable energy can accelerate the achievement of every single SDG (Fuso
Nerini et al. 2017; Elavarasan et al. 2022).
Progress towards affordable energy is instrumental in achieving the targets of
SDG1, “No Poverty,” as energy is crucial for economic growth. Available and afford-
able energy can enhance income-earning capabilities, entrepreneurial opportunities,
autonomy, and overall quality of life for billions of people. The lack of access to
energy services or the inability to afford them can be considered one of the various
dimensions of poverty. When an individual has no uninterrupted energy supply or
Powering Sustainable Development: The Critical Role of Energy Research
409
electricity or cannot afford it, it is often called “energy poverty”—the absence of
reliable and affordable energy (Reddy 2015). According to the United Nations,
minimal energy services encompass lighting, space heating or cooling, and cell phone
charging. However, to ensure decent energy services, the provision of refrigerators,
air conditioners, and television sets is necessary (Rao et al. 2019; United Nations
2021). SDG1 encourages social protection systems, measuring them as one of its
targets, and energy subsidies can be regarded as an integral part of such initiatives.
Energy is a crucial component of the so-called “water-energy-food” approach,
which refers to an integrated framework recognizing the interconnectedness between
energy, food, and water systems. This approach acknowledges the interdependencies
and trade-offs among these sectors and emphasizes the need for coordinated and
sustainable management to achieve multiple SDGs (Namany et al. 2019, 2021).
For instance, in relation to SDG 2, “No hunger,” affordable and clean energy
directly impacts food security, reducing hunger and malnutrition. The availability and
accessibility of inexpensive and environmentally friendly energy are vital for every
stage of the food supply chain. The agricultural sector is particularly susceptible to the
impacts of energy price increases, primarily due to its signiﬁcant energy requirements
for irrigation (Bazilian et al. 2011b).
Affordable and clean energy can signiﬁcantly contribute to achieving the targets
set by SDG 3, “Good health and well-being,” which is not surprising given the critical
roleenergyplaysinhumanhealth.Accesstoaffordableenergyhasbroadimplications
for enhancing well-being and fostering sustainable development. First, it enables
people to meet their basic energy needs, such as lighting, cooking, and heating,
improving living conditions, quality of life, and job opportunities, ultimately leading
to poverty reduction and socio-economic empowerment (Novikau 2022). Second,
access to reliable energy is vital for providing essential healthcare services. Without
affordable energy, healthcare facilities simply cannot operate effectively. Reliable
electricity is crucial for powering medical devices, including life-saving equip-
ment, diagnostic tools, and lighting, enhancing healthcare services’ quality. More-
over, affordable and reliable energy access supports implementing digital healthcare
technologies and electronic medical record systems, enabling efﬁcient healthcare
delivery, remote consultations, and timely information management.
Access to modern energy plays a pivotal role in achieving SDG 4, “Quality educa-
tion,” as it enables the integration of modern information technologies in educa-
tional institutions. With a reliable energy supply, schools can harness the power of
computers, the internet, and digital learning platforms, transforming how students
access and engage with educational content. This integration enhances the learning
experience, fosters a deeper understanding of complex subjects, and encourages crit-
ical thinking and problem-solving skills. Moreover, access to modern energy ensures
that schools have quality lighting and thermal comfort. Well-lit classrooms create
a conducive learning environment, reducing eye fatigue and promoting focus and
concentration among students (Dornan 2014; Fuso Nerini et al. 2017).
Progress in SDG 7 can also contribute to SDG 5, “Gender equality,” in several
profound ways. Women are disproportionately affected by energy poverty, especially
in developing countries, where they often bear the burden of collecting biomass for
410
A. Novikau
cooking and heating, which can lead to adverse health effects and time constraints on
other activities. Providing better access to modern cooking solutions and clean energy
alternatives can signiﬁcantly improve women’s health and alleviate the daily struggle
associated with traditional energy sources. Electric lighting can play a transformative
role in enhancing women’s safety and increasing school enrollment among girls
(McCollum et al. 2018; Matano 2022).
Access to modern and clean energy plays a crucial role in advancing SDG 6,
“Clean water and sanitation.” Modern energy sources, such as renewable energy tech-
nologies, offer sustainable solutions for addressing water-related challenges. Energy
is essential for powering water treatment plants, wastewater management, and sani-
tation facilities, making it a critical component in implementing advanced water
treatment and sanitation systems. By ensuring reliable and affordable energy access,
it is possible to enhance the effectiveness and efﬁciency of these systems, leading to
improved water quality, increased access to safe drinking water, and better sanita-
tion practices. Furthermore, modern energy sources enable the adoption of innovative
technologies, such as advanced ﬁltration systems and decentralized wastewater treat-
ment,whichcanfurtherenhancewatertreatmentcapabilitiesandpromotesustainable
water management practices (McCollum et al. 2018). This transformative potential is
crucial for numerous island populations and densely populated regions in the Middle
East and North Africa that heavily rely on desalination. The desalination process
demands a signiﬁcant amount of energy, posing a severe challenge for countries that
cannot guarantee an uninterrupted supply of affordable energy. Given the escalating
demand for water and the pressing need for sustainable approaches, addressing the
energy-intensive nature of desalination becomes imperative. By embracing innova-
tive strategies and transitioning to renewable energy sources, it is possible to effec-
tively tackle the surging energy demands in desalination operations, safeguarding
water security while minimizing the ecological footprint associated with energy
consumption (Bazilian et al. 2011b).
There is a clear link between energy and SDG 8, “Decent work and economic
growth.” Economic growth, productive employment, and decent work for all can only
be achieved with the help of affordable energy. Access to reliable modern energy
services profoundly impacts productivity and earnings. By incorporating renewable
energy sources and energy-efﬁcient technologies, along with targeted monetary and
ﬁscal policies, it is possible to stimulate innovation and reinforce local, regional, and
national industrial and employment objectives (McCollum et al. 2018).
Although the overall employment effects are expected to be positive, uncertainties
persist regarding some groups that could be adversely affected by the transition to
clean energy. Therefore, ensuring a “just transition” refers to worker protection,
decent work, and job quality preservation while striving to meet affordable and
clean energy goals. Such an approach emphasizes social inclusion and addresses the
needs of workers in sectors that might undergo signiﬁcant changes. By implementing
policies that support reskilling and upskilling programs, providing income support,
and fostering an inclusive labor market, the transition to clean energy can be smoother
and more equitable for all stakeholders (Newell and Mulvaney 2013; Kelly et al.
2020).
Powering Sustainable Development: The Critical Role of Energy Research
411
Access to affordable and reliable energy is essential for developing and main-
taining resilient infrastructure, which is the objective of SDG 9, “Industry, innovation,
and infrastructure.” Energy is required to construct, operate, and maintain infrastruc-
ture systems such as transportation networks, power grids, and waste management
facilities. Access to modern energy services can also have a transformative impact on
industrialization, enabling the establishment and growth of industries, particularly
in manufacturing, agriculture, and services.
Energy can potentially contribute to achieving SDG 10, “Reduce inequalities.”
For instance, modern decentralized energy systems can foster a more inclusive and
democratic approach to managing energy resources (Chaurey and Kandpal 2010;
McCollum et al. 2018).
Energy is vital for SDG 11, “Sustainable cities and communities.” Modern essen-
tial services such as water and sewage, heating, transportation, and waste manage-
ment heavily depend on energy. Therefore, implementing modern energy technolo-
gies in public transit and urban densiﬁcation can further advance urban environmental
sustainability by enhancing air quality and decreasing noise (McCollum et al. 2018).
Having affordable and clean energy can help achieve SDG 12, ‘Responsible
consumption and production.’ Modern energy solutions can slow the depletion of
natural resources. While advanced technologies and infrastructure still require vast
amounts of raw materials, increasing recycling rates can improve the energy efﬁ-
ciency of industrial production, thereby reducing the impacts of all supply chain
stages (McCollum et al. 2018; Gunnarsdottir et al. 2021).
Achieving SDG7 is vital in advancing SDG 13, “Climate action.” Indeed, human
activities, speciﬁcally the emissions of greenhouse gases resulting from the combus-
tion of fossil fuels, have been the primary driver behind global climate change.
This escalating warming trend has given rise to many risks associated with climate
change, which pose signiﬁcant threats to natural ecosystems and human societies.
These risks encompass a broad range of impacts, such as rising sea levels, biodi-
versity loss, extreme weather events, and the potential for food and water scarcity
(He et al. 2022). SDG 7 is crucial, though not entirely sufﬁcient, to achieve climate
change goals. Therefore, meeting the renewable energy and energy efﬁciency targets
of SDG7 is a necessary step toward climate change mitigation strategies (Bazilian
et al. 2011a; McCollum et al. 2018).
Achieving SDG 7 can contribute to the achievement of SDG14, “Life below
water.” The global deployment of renewable energy and improvements in energy
efﬁciency can effectively reduce carbon dioxide emissions, consequently slowing the
rates of ocean acidiﬁcation. Moreover, ocean-based energy derived from renewable
sources such as offshore wind farms, wave energy, and tidal power holds signiﬁcant
potential as an energy resource for island nations and countries along coastlines. The
concept of multi-use platforms, integrating renewable energy generation, aquacul-
ture,transportservices,andleisureactivities,furtherhighlightsthesynergiesbetween
SDG 7 and SDG 14 in promoting sustainable practices that support both clean energy
production and the preservation of marine ecosystems (McCollum et al. 2018).
412
A. Novikau
Achieving SDG 7 is connected to SDG 15,”Life on land,” which focuses on the
sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, such as forests, and preventing land degra-
dation. Indeed, by promoting affordable and sustainable energy sources, communi-
ties can leverage electricity to adopt advanced agricultural technologies and prac-
tices that enhance productivity and reduce the reliance on environmentally harmful
approaches. Access to electricity also facilitates the implementation of alternative
energy solutions, curbing the demand for biomass fuels and mitigating deforestation
(Bazilian et al. 2011b).
The achievement of SDG 7 can signiﬁcantly contribute to achieving SDG 16,
“Peace, justice, and strong institutions.” Justice-based approaches have a consider-
able capacity to contribute to energy decision-making. By providing reliable and
affordable energy services, SDG 7 can improve access to information and communi-
cation technologies, which are vital for transparent governance, effective institutions,
and accountable decision-making processes. Reliable energy sources can strengthen
the infrastructure necessary for security and law enforcement, enabling effective
disaster response and ensuring the safety of communities (Sovacool et al. 2014;
Fuso Nerini et al. 2017).
Finally, achieving SDG 7 can contribute to SDG 17, “Partnerships for the
goals.” Access to reliable energy sources is pivotal in enabling effective partner-
ships and collaboration for sustainable development. Energy is essential for powering
communication technologies, facilitating information exchange, and fostering stake-
holder connectivity. Access to modern energy services can enhance communication
networks and improve connectivity, enabling local, national, and international part-
nerships. Moreover, reliable energy sources support the establishment of produc-
tive and sustainable industries, creating opportunities for public–private partnerships
and cross-sector collaborations. Energy access also enables the implementation of
innovative technologies and practices, promoting knowledge-sharing and capacity-
building initiatives among partners. Additionally, achieving SDG 7 encourages ﬁnan-
cial investment in sustainable energy projects, attracting private sector participa-
tion and facilitating collaboration between governmental, business, and civil society
organizations.
4
The Role of Research
As mentioned in the previous sections, the scientiﬁc community holds considerable
potential in bolstering the implementation of SDGs through research and develop-
ment and sustainable education. SDG 7 is not an exception. Energy research for
sustainable development should focus on several directions.
Powering Sustainable Development: The Critical Role of Energy Research
413
4.1
Energy Efﬁciency and Sustainable Energy Consumption
As explicitly stated in Target 7.3, improving energy efﬁciency is a major contributor
to achieving SDG 7. Energy efﬁciency entails the utilization of energy resources
to minimize wastage and decrease energy consumption while upholding the quality
of products or services. This approach aims to conserve energy by achieving the
same output with reduced energy input. Improving energy efﬁciency across sectors
is essential for sustainable development. Research has shown a positive relationship
between sustainable economic development and energy efﬁciency, suggesting that
sustainable economic growth is associated with improved energy efﬁciency.
Similarly, a positive correlation exists between sustainable ﬁnancial development
and energy efﬁciency, indicating that sustainable ﬁnancial practices contribute to
increased energy efﬁciency (Zakari et al. 2022). Energy efﬁciency reduces waste
through technological advancements, efﬁcient practices, and behavior changes.
For instance, energy-efﬁcient appliances, buildings, and transportation systems can
signiﬁcantly reduce energy consumption and environmental impact. To address the
environmental impact of emissions and promote sustainable practices, there is a
growing interest in energy-efﬁcient building design and the phasing out harmful
refrigerants. Buildings account for around 40% of the world’s annual energy
consumption, mainly due to lighting, heating, cooling, and air conditioning require-
ments. These challenges can be effectively addressed by researching energy-efﬁcient
technologies and practices and adopting policies encouraging energy conservation
(Omer 2008).
4.2
Energy Infrastructure
Energy research for sustainable development should also focus on further devel-
oping energy infrastructure. It can involve building infrastructure, upgrading existing
energy systems, and improving the resilience of energy systems to natural disasters.
It is essential for developing countries even though energy infrastructure in devel-
oped countries can be modernized too to meet stricter energy efﬁciency and pollution
requirements too.
4.3
Renewable Energy
One of the most essential strategies for achieving SDG 7 is to increase research in
renewable energy technologies. Numerous studies demonstrate a signiﬁcant positive
correlation between the adoption of renewable energy and sustainable development
observed in developed and developing countries (Güney 2019; Włodarczyk et al.
2021). The ﬁnite nature of fossil fuel resources and their associated geopolitical
414
A. Novikau
tensions make them unreliable energy sources. Investing in sustainable energy tech-
nologies such as wind, solar, and geothermal energy reduces dependence on these
volatile fuel markets and enhances energy security. Renewable energy sources offer
domestic and diverse energy supplies, enabling countries to reduce their vulnerability
to price ﬂuctuations and geopolitical disruptions.
Moreover, a green energy transition brings economic beneﬁts. Thus, research
focused on sustainable energy systems that can drive technological advancements
and innovation, creating new job opportunities and economic growth. The renewable
energy sector has the potential to generate employment across various ﬁelds, from
manufacturing and installation to research and development. By prioritizing sustain-
able energy solutions, nations can foster the growth of a green economy, leading to
long-term economic stability and competitiveness (Østergaard et al. 2020).
4.4
Digitalization
The scholarly literature provides empirical evidence supporting the afﬁrmative corre-
lation between digital transformation and sustainability (Ghobakhloo 2020). This
correlation extends to the digitalization of energy systems, wherein positive impacts
on SDG7 and other interconnected SDGs have been discerned. Digitalization of
energy systems, or integrating computer technologies into them, has sparked a
profound metamorphosis within the realm of energy. This revolutionary advancement
instills newfound stability in energy systems, facilitating the seamless integration of
power generation with end-users. Consequently, it ushers in a reduction in peak
demand, expedites the restoration of energy supply following disruptions, curtails
operating expenses, and signiﬁcantly streamlines the incorporation of renewable
energy sources into existing systems (U.S. Department of Energy 2021). Further-
more, digitalization plays a vital role in enhancing end users’ energy efﬁciency by
offering real-time feedback on energy consumption, often via the employment of
smart meters. Dynamic tariffs, also known as real-time pricing, mold consumption
patterns, particularly during peak hours (Elavarasan et al. 2021).
4.5
Links with Other SDGs
Sustainable development research should focus on the relationship between energy
and other SDGs, highlighting how sustainable energy can simultaneously contribute
to achieving multiple goals. The importance of the interdisciplinary and transdisci-
plinary character of sustainability research has been emphasized in numerous studies
(Leal Filho et al. 2018). Sustainable energy solutions provide access to affordable and
clean energy, promote climate action, support sustainable cities and communities,
foster innovation and economic growth, and protect ecosystems. By recognizing the
interconnectedness of energy with various dimensions of sustainable development,
Powering Sustainable Development: The Critical Role of Energy Research
415
we can develop integrated strategies that propel us toward a more sustainable and
inclusive future.
4.6
Energy Justice
Energy research should focus on increasing international equity by providing modern
energy services to all (Gunnarsdottir et al. 2021). Ensuring universal access to clean
and affordable energy is fundamental to sustainable development. Many regions,
especially in developing countries, still lack access to modern energy services.
Expanding renewable energy infrastructure, microgrids, and off-grid solutions can
provide clean energy access to remote areas, fostering economic development
and improving quality of life. Furthermore, sustainable energy access is crucial
for social development and equity. Many communities, especially in developing
regions, lack access to reliable and affordable energy sources. Sustainable devel-
opment research should concentrate on developing decentralized renewable energy
systems that provide clean and affordable energy to these underserved communi-
ties. Access to energy is fundamental for improving living conditions, supporting
healthcare facilities, enabling education, and promoting economic opportunities.
Thus, expanding access to electricity and modern cooking technologies in poor
communities is essential.
5
The Role of International Cooperation
Achieving sustainable development goals will require global cooperation and coor-
dination (Leal Filho et al. 2022). SDG 7 is not an exception—As mentioned earlier,
Target 7A explicitly orders, “By 2030, enhance international cooperation to facilitate
access to clean energy research and technology.”
First, international cooperation is vital in facilitating access to clean energy
research and technology because a single company or even a nation cannot inde-
pendently develop, produce, and implement modern energy solutions in today’s
globalized world. Thus, collaboration among academia, business, states, and civil
society is crucial.
Second, international cooperation should help transfer modern energy technolo-
gies to developing countries. It can include technology transfer through licensing
agreements or technical support, as well as providing ﬁnancial support, especially
for communities affected by energy poverty. Additionally, the focus should be on
removing barriers to such technology transfer.
Third, international cooperation should focus on creating regulatory policies that
promote energy research for sustainable development. It involves designing targets
416
A. Novikau
and indicators for implementing modern and clean energy solutions for all. Harmo-
nizing standards and policies across countries can enhance access to sustainable
energy for all.
Finally, international capacity-building initiatives related to energy are crucial for
progress in modern energy. Capacity-building initiatives can include training and
technical assistance for individuals and organizations, both public and private.
6
Conclusion
As highlighted throughout this chapter, energy plays a pivotal role in sustainable
development. The urgency to achieve SDG7 urges focused energy research and the
development of sustainable energy solutions. The current state of energy systems,
predominantly reliant on fossil fuels, poses signiﬁcant challenges to sustainability,
underscoring the critical need for a green energy transition. Moreover, the intercon-
nectionsbetweenenergyandotherSDGs,includingeconomicgrowth,environmental
sustainability, social development, poverty eradication, education, gender equality,
and health, emphasize the far-reaching impact of sustainable energy solutions. Inte-
grating solar, wind, hydropower, and energy efﬁciency measures holds immense
potential for addressing these challenges. However, achieving these goals requires
international cooperation and collaboration to facilitate the transition to sustainable
energy systems. By prioritizing research on sustainable energy and recognizing its
multifaceted beneﬁts, we can pave the way for a more prosperous, equitable, and
sustainable future. Efforts towards sustainable energy must continue, with a strong
focus on innovation, policy support, and collective action to realize the vision of a
world powered by affordable and clean energy for all while concurrently achieving
the broader SDGs.
While signiﬁcant progress has been made in understanding the role of energy
in sustainable development, several directions for further research can enrich our
knowledge and inform policymaking. First, additional research is needed to explore
the potential integration of emerging technologies into sustainable energy systems.
It includes investigating advanced storage solutions, smart grids, and decentralized
energy generation to enhance the efﬁciency and reliability of renewable energy
sources. Furthermore, studies focused on the socio-economic implications of sustain-
able energy transitions, particularly in developing regions, are crucial for under-
standing the distributional impacts and identifying strategies to ensure equitable
access to clean energy. Additionally, interdisciplinary research is required to explore
the intricate connections between energy, climate change, and other SDGs, such as
biodiversity conservation and sustainable urbanization.
Moreover, developing comprehensive methodologies to assess the lifecycle envi-
ronmental impacts of different energy sources, including their extraction, manu-
facturing, use, and disposal, is imperative for informed decision-making. Finally,
research should also examine the role of policy frameworks, ﬁnancial mechanisms,
and international collaborations in accelerating the adoption of sustainable energy
Powering Sustainable Development: The Critical Role of Energy Research
417
solutions at scale. By addressing these research directions, we can foster a deeper
understanding of sustainable energy systems and pave the way for transformative
actions toward achieving the SDGs.

Sustainable Research Agenda
of the International Journal Discourse
and Communication for Sustainable
Education: Current Developments
and Future Perspectives
Dzintra Iliško and Berise Heasly
Abstract The research on sustainability has already become the agenda of the
day. International teams of scholars have already been addressing various themes
of sustainability in sufﬁcient depth and breadth by focusing attention on social,
ecological, economic, political, and cultural aspects of sustainability. By the use of
the method of bibliometric literature review, the authors intend to analyse research on
sustainability, and issues related to sustainable development and education during
the last ﬁve years, as revealed in the Journal of UNESCO Chair on the Interplay
of Tradition and Innovation in Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) at
Daugavpils University, Latvia. The articles provide an extensive overview of the
research agenda and show the scope of sustainability research that has broadened in
scope, and is growing stronger. The article also shows the geography of sustain-
ability challenges, including challenges addressed in practice and everyday life,
reﬂection on methodologies for sustainability research, and institutional policy devel-
opments on sustainability. By evaluating sustainability pathways and approaches and
by addressing challenges of smart governance, the article highlights the cases of good
practice and challenges that need to be addressed. The article also highlights issues
related to sustainability research that still remain unsolved and calls for contin-
uous efforts of improvement and for deeper transdisciplinary processes. Challenges
brought up by unsustainable consumption and an unpredictable intent as a way of
life can not be solved by technological ﬁxes but require deeper sustainability transi-
tions, co-evolution, multi-actor involvement, long-term thinking, open-mindedness
and tolerance of uncertainty.
Keywords Sustainability research · International journal · Sustainability
challenges · Co-evolutionary reconﬁguration processes

D. Iliško and B. Heasly
1
Introduction
The paper presents bibliometric analyses of the Journal Discourse and Commu-
nication for Sustainable Education (DCSE) from 2018 until year 2023. DCSE is
an international peer-reviewed journal that provides a forum for discussion about
sustainability policies with regard to sustainable education, including discussion on
a broader range of issues related to sustainability discourse.
The intention of this study is to analyse several dimensions of the Journal by omit-
ting less signiﬁcant aspects. The analysis of qualitative and quantitative bibliometric
data includes:
(1) representing countries, institutions, authors, geographical scope and the diver-
sity of research on sustainability stemming from diverse parts of the world,
(2) editorial board members and co-editorship practice,
(3) research methodologies applied by the authors,
(4) content analyses: keywords and main themes related to sustainability initiatives
discussed in the Journal.
The paper will pay proper attention to both philosophical and theoretical aspects
of the research in substantiating sustainability and providing the analyses of papers
that reﬂect the cases of good practice in the ﬁeld of sustainable development.
The framework for the analyses of ten volumes of the journal, as suggested by
Whittemore and Knaﬂ(2005) will be used as a basis to synthesize themes within
a chosen sample, paying attention to the following variables: number of contribu-
tions per volume, representation by the countries, institutions, authors, co-authorship
patterns and data analysis methods. The sample comprises 123 articles in ten volumes
published during the last ﬁve years in total.
By the use of a framework for integrative review developed by Whittemore
and Knaﬂ(2005), articles were examined to determine the quality of writing by
comparing data within the articles and by providing a synthesis of themes and
patterns within the chosen sample. The papers will be analysed in terms of research
approaches, methods of data collection and analysis (Petticrew and Roberts 2009).
Quantitative bibliometric data analysis was performed by a simple counting proce-
dure of frequency of the following variables: number of contributions per volume,
representation of countries, institutions, authors, co-authorship patterns, and methods
of data analysis. The coding was carried out by the use of the semantic details from
the title, keywords, abstract, and main part of papers, thus performing the analyses of
literature in the ﬁeld of sustainability research. The research published in this journal
has been analysed in the context of Sustainability Agenda 2030.
Sustainable Research Agenda of the International Journal Discourse …
423
2
Methodology
For the purpose of analyses of research published in the last ten volumes of the journal
the authors have applied both quantitative and qualitative research methodology.
It reveals evolutionary nuances on sustainability research and uncovers emerging
trends, collaboration patterns, as well as helps to identify knowledge gaps and
discovers novel ideas for future investigations.
The bibliometric methodology has been applied for the study of the content of
all ten volumes in terms of the geographical location of the authors presented in
the journal, keywords, research methodology applied in the article and theoretical
approaches chosen by the authors as a research methodology. The bibliometric anal-
ysis includes both objective data (in this case, the number of articles published per
ten volumes, keywords, country representations) and subjective data (thematic anal-
yses, evaluation through informed procedures). As Donthy et al (2021) comment,
bibliometric analysis serves the intentional purpose of gaining an overview of work
done so far, to identify knowledge gaps and positioning contributions to the ﬁeld. It
enables and empowers scholars to gain a one-stop overview and to derive novel ideas
for the investigation by positioning a contribution to the ﬁeld. Meta-analyses will
provide a nuanced insight into the heterogeneity of research offered by the authors
(Baker at al. 2020). Since the studies presented by the authors in the journal are
homogeneous, the authors used meta- analyses with the aim to carry out quantitative
analyses of collected variables in addressing research questions.
The research will be analysed in the light of the developments for implementing
the Sustainability Agenda 2030 and 17 goals of Sustainable Development and values
emphasized in the recent report by the UNESCO (2022) Reimagining our Futures
Together.
3
Research Findings
The study aims to carry out qualitative and quantitative bibliometric analyses of
volumes published during the last ﬁve years. The data comprises the analyses of
articles from ten volumes of the journal with 123 articles in total.
3.1
Bibliographical Indicators of DCSE During 2018–2023:
The Editors, Editorial Board Members
The number of Editors in Chief has changed from four to two. The invited guest
editors were Javad Gholami from Urmia University, Iran for the Volume 10(1), 2018,
10(2),2018,Volume11(1),2019,andtheguestEditorJohannesLindnerfromUniver-

D. Iliško and B. Heasly
12 (2), 2021 and Volume 13 (1), 2022, and Volume 13(2), 2022. All ﬁve years Berise
Heasly has served as an Editor in Chief. She is representing the International network
of JTES and DCSE of the UNESCO chair at Daugavpils University, Latvia in co-
editorship with professors Ilga Salīte and Dzintra Iliško from Daugavpils University,

board, including Michael Buchanan from Australian Catholic University, Mykolas

Academy of Technologies in Latvia, Petro Du Preez and Lesley Le Grange from

Kingdom and Christine G. Schnitika from Auburn University in the United States of
America, as well as Julie Aitken Schermer from the University of Western Ontario
in Canada.
3.2
Geographical Scope of the Research Articles
Ten volumes of the journal comprise 123 articles in total. During the last ﬁve years
the authors who have published in the DCSE, represent diverse geographical loca-
tions and they are from Turkey (19 articles), Austria (16 articles) Germany (7 arti-
cles), Latvia (6 articles), USA (5 articles), Australia (4 articles), Norway (3 articles),
Sweden (3 articles), UK (3 articles), Jamaica (3), and South Africa (3 articles). Two
articles were published by the authors from Iran, Jamaica, Hungary and Finland, and
one paper was published by the authors from Canada, Japan, Philippines, Thailand,
Czech Republic, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Finland, Israel, Denmark, Japan, Vietnam,
Thailand, Ghana and Uzbekistan.
As Acedo et al. (2006) report, with the increased theoretical complexity, the
tendency of co-authorship is increasing in international research. In ten volumes,
in sixty-two papers, there is a co-authorship among the scientists from the same
country, and in fourteen papers; there is a co-authorship among the authors from
different countries and 37 papers are submitted by single authored publications by
research constituent, 26 papers were written in co-authorship of two authors, twenty
six papers were written in co-authorship of three authors, ten papers are written
in co-authorship of four authors and two papers are written in co-authorship of ﬁve
authors. The authors have built scientiﬁc bridges with researchers from neighbouring
countries as well as transatlantic bridges.

3.3
Research Methodology
The articles in ten volumes of the journal present a wide spectrum of methodologies,
beginning with empirical research to case studies and the analyses of documents
regarding sustainability issues. Some studies reﬂect experimental design in search
of better solutions for a sustainable classroom practice. Out of all the studies, thirty-
seven papers contain quantitative research design, sixteen authors choose qualitative
research methodology, eleven studies can be classiﬁed as conceptual studies, two
studies involve a deep and detailed literature review, two are case studies, and four are
purely theoretical studies. This allows readers to conclude that a majority of authors,
particularly scholars from Turkey, gave priority to qualitative research methodology
in their studies.
3.4
The Thematic Elements of the Research Articles
Ten volumes of the journal include topical issues of the day, namely, environmental
concerns, issues related to inclusive and quality education, and previously unex-
plored topics including small-scale studies. The use of both quantitative or qualita-
tive methodologies provided the basis for contextualizing data for the more profound
and large-scale studies. The analysis of keywords allows conclusions that there is
only one reference to Green Deal, one to SDG, one to future thinking, sixteen refer-
ences to sustainability, three to educational leadership, eight references to sustainable
education, eleven to education for sustainable education, three to sustainable devel-
opment and ﬁfteen references to entrepreneurship education. The references in the
papers of the journal are related to environmental sustainability, social sustainability,
economic sustainability, and cultural sustainability. Discussion on issues related
to sustainability ranges across many perspectives by offering interdisciplinary and
solution–oriented research.
Some studies present conceptual and detailed reviews, like the analyses of the
results reached by the UNESCO World Decade of Education for Sustainable Devel-
opment 2005–2014 and outlines future developments with a particular reference to
good and smart governance in respect to human rights by striving towards devel-
opment of civic society as suggested by Brunold and Ohlmeier (2022). Another
conceptual study is offered by Ponce and Villegas (2022) who outlined a vision and
a framework of regenerative futures as contextualized for the higher institutions in
Philippines, by redeﬁning Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through futures
thinking. These studies highlight the need to rethink and to reﬁne the notion of
sustainability and call for further developments in thriving for a more interconnected
and sustainable world. The authors call for a systemic transformational and co-
creative set of processes in overcoming destructive and dualistic patterns of thinking
while dealing with increasing complexity and diversity. Alguren (2021) provides a
profound theoretical overview of sustainability research outlined in 153 articles of
426
D. Iliško and B. Heasly
sustainable education from the educational databases on sustainability competencies.
Kapranov (2021) presents an overview of the discursive representation of education
for Sustainable Development in policy documents in Norway and Estonia. Kerscher
(2019) contributes to the debate about envisioning a sustainable future with regard
to reducing plastics as reﬂected in the EU policies. Fieldman (2021) contributes
to the discussion with his vision of greener Universities by exploring possibilities
of ecological reconstruction and reduction of ecological footprint in universities.
His study presents an overview of cases of climate activism and efforts of greening
education addressed by university-based campaigns.
The scope of studies is quite wide and begins with conceptual and philosophical
papers to small case studies reﬂecting the process and the result of the implemen-
tation of Sustainability Agenda 2030. Similar is the study by Belma Barak and
Avci (2022) who elaborate on implementing a sustainability agenda in secondary
schools in Germany and Turkey. Another example of a small case study for sustain-
ability reforms to be mentioned, that has been implemented in the teacher education
curriculum in Jamaica, is carried out by Clark (2022) who discusses the need for a
more contextually appropriate set of strategies of contextualizing ESD and highlights
salient components of curriculum reforms in Jamaica. Another small-scale study on
implementing sustainability in the Philippine State University has been carried out
by Ponce and Villegas (2022) who suggest a new and conceptual model to inform
regenerative efforts of a state university. The case study for sustainability in Agri-
culture from the Gibraltar Area (Spain) on Education for Sustainability has been
suggested by Casanova-Correa (2022), by prompting sustainability as a powerful
tool for bringing about changes in food production practices.
The group of authors of international team from the UK, Finland, Italy, and
Austria envision innovative sustainability-oriented agenda in fostering transforma-
tive behaviours in transnational and transdisciplinary perspective (Adeﬁla et al.
2021). The paper by Feldman (2021) focuses on possibilities of green initiatives
in the university setting as potential venue of the experimentation in supporting
sustainable development goals and prompting greening strategies by inviting diverse
actors, like business groups, industries, government, trade unions to act as key accel-
erators in fostering sustainable change. The authors have also identiﬁed barriers
of greening universities and discuss potentialities for discursive efforts for trans-
formations of universities. Similarly, Heasly et al. (2021) emphases the need for a
collaborative effort in reaching the goals of sustainable development. The authors
believe that higher education plays a crucial role in promoting the idea of sustain-
able development in cooperation with the NGO’s, a city’s municipality, in fostering
pro-environmental behaviour. The parameters of these smaller-scale projects indi-
cate how such research, while sourced within Educational organisations, also allow
elements of community education to emerge. In this way, Sustainability Goals expand
and bring nuanced information, expertise and skills to the fore.

427
A majority of authors who have contributed their paper to the last ten volumes of
the Journal make an attempt to explore their issue of study through a sustainability
prism while identifying some interconnected aspects in their research.
One of the distinct issues as highlighted in many papers in inclusive quality
education that is envisioning diverse ways and strategies in reaching this ideal
(Ediyanto et al. 2020; Catubigan 2023; Andersen and Bagger 2023; Heasly and Iliško
2023b, a). In line with the SDG goal four, the authors are placing the emphases
on reducing disparities and inequities in education and providing quality educa-
tion for all by ensuring effective learning environments for children with disabil-
ities and special needs, refugees and displaced children. It places an imperative
for the educational system to treat all students fairly, regardless of their ability
to learn together in one environment. Inclusion refers to all students with visible
and hidden vulnerabilities to work together in one environment by offering them
adapted plans. Catubigan (2023) discusses ways of eradicating inappropriate oppor-
tunities with regard to vulnerable groups, particularly, children with the Autism
Spectrum Disorder. Andersen and Bagger (2023) discuss the impact of policies of
inclusion and exclusion in Sweden and Luxembourg on practice in the primary
schools in regards to diverse language backgrounds. Quality education as discussed
in many articles reafﬁrms the agenda that is in the heart of the United Nations (UN)
2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, particularly the Sustainable Develop-
ment Goal 4 and recognized the need to offer inclusive quality education for all
learners from primary stage of schooling until lifelong education, including voca-
tional training and higher education. The research is in line with the UNESCO (2020,
2021) framework that puts an emphasis on advocacy, awareness raising, capacity
building and its implementation in practice.
The authors from Latvia view their issues within the overall framework of sustain-
ability legislation and current developments in their research as a bases for envi-
sioning a more sustainable future (Salīte 2022; Pipere 2019). In Latvia, sustain-
ability is a political principle that is reﬂected in both, a previous Latvian National
Development Plan 2014–2020. and in the new Latvian National Development Plan
2020–2027 (NAP 2027). After the review of the EU’s Sustainable Development
Strategy in 2006, the sustainable development planning process of the Latvian state
has started, with the involvement of citizens to contribute to a vision of the develop-
ment of Latvia in 2030. In Latvia, the principle of sustainability is not only a political
goal, but is the principle of territorial planning as well. Latvian government focuses
on such development, which emphasizes the responsible actions of each individual
on behalf of future generations. Sustainability is not only linked to the responsibility
of the state, but each member of the society must take care of the implementation
of this principle. Lessons learned from the previous Global Action Program (GAP),
can help Latvia to facilitate the implementation of the ESD for 2030 framework by
enhancing knowledge sharing, collaboration, mutual learning and advocacy among
a wide range of education stakeholders (UNESCO 2022).
428
D. Iliško and B. Heasly
In 2015, the UN General Assembly adopted the resolution “Transforming our
world: the sustainable development program for 2030”, or Agenda 2030 with the
17 SDGs and 169 sub-goals that must be achieved in order to reach a sustainable
redevelopment. Agenda 2030 was adopted in Latvia by balancing economic, social
and environmental thus becoming priorities of Latvia and emphasizes the participa-
tion of all in the planning and implementation of the SDG, namely, civil society, the
private sector, countries, national associations, the UN and other institutions.
Much of the attention has been placed on the issue of sustainable leadership
in the papers published by Cayak (2021) and Khumalo (2021). Sustainable leader-
ship is seen as a strategic framework for the organization’s sustainability. By priori-
tizing sustainable leadership, organizations can raise sustainability performance by
embracing a growing complexity of the world and educating long-term thinkers, as
well as developing eco-centric, systemic and long-term mindsets. Sustainable lead-
ership is seen as a capacity to see things in a new perspective and solve complex
problems as they emerge. Sathithada and Niramitchainont (2019) discuss scenarios
of a sustainable e-leadership in Thai higher educational institutions in the era of
information technologies.
One of a widely discussed issues in the Journal was social entrepreneur-
ship by Shaver et al. (2019), Müller et al. (2020), Forcher-Mayr and Mahlknecht
(2020), Kerstin Schmidt-Hönig and Pröbstl (2020), Fernbach (2020), Rigg and van
der Wal-Maris (2020), Pinho et al. (2019), who presented a critical approach to
entrepreneurship in general education by emphasizing individual capabilities by
enhancing entrepreneurial mindset, developing personal initiative, entrepreneurial
competences,andanawarenessofsustainability.Theauthorsassertthatentrepreneur-
ship education need to be fostered already in the primary school stage via creative
arts-based approached by applying a holistic whole school model.
Particular attention has been paid to the sustainable lifestyle in diverse country
contexts, like saving electricity in the schools in the United States as discussed
by Schnittka (2023), teaching recycling habits for the secondary school students
in Turkey by Betül Demİr and Ulukaya Öteleş (2023). Another study by Kotaman
et al. (2022) focuses on the need of educating early education teachers in developing
environmental attitude, environmental awareness, knowledge, attitudes and skills
how to integrate environmental issues in teaching. Kerscher (2019) discusses how
political discussion on reduction of use of plastic can be introduced in the primary
and secondary school agenda. Sustainable lifestyle has been in the centre of attention
of many authors, in relation to everyday behaviors, such as saving energy, choosing
sustainable transportation, reducing waste and recycling in order to educate students
to change their consumption patterns.
