429
4
Further Developments for Sustainability Research
Further research needs to be focused more as a transdisciplinary sustainability
research that could contribute to sustainability transformations, and a long term orien-
tation by involving stakeholders in the experimental and transformative processes in
their local communities by addressing complex contemporary sustainability chal-
lenges. The Sustainable Developmental Goals (SDG) can become an integrated
framework to sustainable development for further research (UN 2015) by indicating
the shift from a conceptual framework to measurable transformations. There is a
pressing need to assess the progress towards implementing SDG’s. Pressure also
seems to be present in the need to support teachers and researchers as a recognisable
global community.
The pandemic has impacted all pillars of sustainability. There is a growing
interest by the authors to tackle the consequences caused by the pandemic but
there is very fragmented research on sustainability research with regard to COVID
19 consequences. There is a research gap on sustainability development in post-
COVID circumstances. Therefore, more research is needed in addressing post-
COVID circumstances in developing future perspectives. More attention is needed
to implement with precision the progress in achieving 17 Sustainable Development
Goals (SDGs), thus leading to more sustainable behaviour. Higher education has
a particular responsibility in achieving SDGs through research, and engagement in
communities of practice by educating students as potential decision makers (Heasly
and Iliško 2022; Iliško and Dedels 2018). Submissions that carry convincing evidence
are demonstrating that the progress in these gaps in reaching SDG’s, is welcome.
The strategic goal of the Editorial staff is to remain open to innovative studies in
the ﬁeld of sustainability research and other inspiring aspects. We support explicitly
submissions from the authors from diverse backgrounds, geographical origins, and
from the authors who are presenting innovative ideas and new conceptual perspec-
tives. In future we will welcome papers who see beyond conventional frameworks.
We are happy to extend geographic scope of the submissions and welcome method-
ologically contributions with qualitative, quantitative, and mixed method research,
including case studies and conceptual political studies.
The speed of publication processes has increased and this leads to difﬁculty
recruiting reviewers who provide high quality of reviews and thus leading to the
increasing processing time and reviewers are not granted sufﬁcient time for the
rigorous review. Being strongly grounded in high quality research, the editorial team
do take a longer time where needed in shaping the publication into high quality
writing. To maintain a high-quality community of researchers, the reviewers provide
careful and relevant constructive feedback until the quality of papers is high enough.
The priority is given to papers that provide solutions to complex issues, and to the
cases of good practice that demonstrate the transformational power of change, both
in knowledge, and in practice.
430
D. Iliško and B. Heasly
5
Conclusions
This study summarizes and provides a meta-analysis on research carried out on a
broad range of issues as seen through the sustainability prism with the aim of deeper
understanding of sustainability as it has been evolving over time and addressing the
goals of Sustainable Development. The study is based on the analyses of research
carried out by the authors who have published their studies in the International
journal: Discourse and Communication for Sustainable Education. Academics and
researchers who published in this journal try to identify the factors that hinder imple-
mentation of Sustainable Developmental Goals, and discuss country-speciﬁc sustain-
able developmental practices though environmental responsibility. Papers published
in the Journal are either empirical studies, analytical studies or policy discussion
papers. Many papers deﬁne sustainability as a responsibility in achieving certain
desired social, economic, and environmental outcomes.
This is observed that when many authors choose focusing more on environmental
and economic aspects of sustainability rather on social aspect and well-being of
all people. Although authors deﬁne sustainable development in terms of generally
accepted understandings of academic rigour, some authors outline integrated and
multi-dimensional models of sustainability through mutual interaction of political,
social, culture and environmental aspects of sustainability. Some authors present
progress of sustainability challenges in some particular regions and institutions.
While Eastern European countries make slower progress towards sustainability,
Western European countries show considerable progress towards sustainable Devel-
opment and Scandinavian countries are far ahead with their innovations with regard
to Sustainability agenda.
Bibliographic and meta-analyses of the last ten volumes of the Journal helped to
identify a geographical scope, co-authorship of research articles, research method-
ology used by the authors, engagement of international editors and editorial board
members, thematic elements related to sustainability, transdisciplinary research,
publications from academia and industry, a number of authors in co-authorship and
thematic clusters is increasingly a highlight.
Sustainability research is encompassing a wide range of issues, related to environ-
mental, social, economic and culture sustainability and address real world problems.
In discussing their issue, many authors adapt transdisciplinary approaches by offering
integrated frameworks for their issue of study and accelerate sustainable solutions
in a joint co-creation process with multiple stakeholders.
In upcoming volumes we welcome sustainability research that is open to
plurality of interests and research traditions by bringing in different epistemic
and non-epistemic views as a starting point to a greater trandisciplinarity research
aiming a greater real world impact. We will welcome diversity and richness of
conceptualization of sustainability for just and sustainable transformations.

A Science Diplomacy Agenda
for Sustainable Development Research
Julia M. Puaschunder
Abstract Science Diplomacy acknowledges the fact that global, commonly-shared
problems are too urgent, large and complex to be solved by one or some nation-states.
By the use of unconventional methods, such as systems analysis and decision science,
science diplomacy spearheads advancements in tackling global challenges. Science
diplomacy thereby combines the forces of research with diplomatic missions. Focus
on scientiﬁc facts—while leaving aside political frictions and historical national
denominations—allows science diplomats to complement traditional global gover-
nance effectively. Aspirational goals of sustainable development demand for scien-
tiﬁc attention to complement traditional national diplomacy for reaching an inter-
national compromise. Science diplomacy advocates for addressing global goals of
sustainable development through academic cooperation and scientiﬁc leadership.
This paper captures the history of Science Diplomacy and presents a comparative
measurement of the potential of different nations around the globe to lead and engage
in Science Diplomacy based on their academia quota and institutions as well as their
diplomatic relations in embassies, consulates and other representations abroad. The
Science Diplomacy potential of countries to lead on climate stabilization will then be
outlined based on the country-speciﬁc responsibility to protect the earth from climate
change. The ﬁndings hold invaluable insights for advocating for science diplomacy
to guide on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The qualitative strengths
of certain science disciplines will be outlined for the pursuit of the SDGs in science
diplomacy. Overall, science diplomacy advantages and success factors for imple-
menting sustainable development in cooperation with conventional governance and
corporate leadership are provided. The discussion closes with future perspectives
and research avenues to advance the ﬁeld of science diplomacy for the alleviation of
the most pressing contemporary challenges.

1
Introduction
Global warming and sustainability management demands heightened the urgency for
global concerted collaboration. This chapter addresses the role of science diplomacy
for sustainability. Science diplomacy conveys the idea to connect world leaders over
scientiﬁc observations in pursuing common endeavors to combat global crises or
accomplish major common endeavors. Science diplomacy thereby allows decision
makers to leave aside political denominations and individual country interests but
connect over scientiﬁc hard facts in the evaluation of risks and creative solution
ﬁnding for global problems. While science diplomacy offers a range of beneﬁts for
sustainability planning, action and management; to this day our understanding of the
use of science diplomacy for sustainability is limited.
Theadvantagesofsciencediplomacyaregainedforscientistsanddiplomacyalike.
Science collaborations can learn from diplomacy in the appreciation for differences.
Researchers can also adopt a high culture to connect ﬁrst over similarities in order to
then discuss topics with different contested viewpoints, which is a common practice
in diplomacy. Science diplomacy can then employ joint forces in order to achieve
common goals and mutually-shared beneﬁts.
At the same time, diplomacy can be strengthened by scientiﬁc information and
engagement networks and channels. Scientiﬁc channels can thus serve as additional
gateways to enact common plans and strengthen international ties. Diplomats can
also use measurable hard-science facts to embrace critical counterparts and engage
them in rational and focused communication leaving aside historical frictions and
contested political terrains. In all these features science diplomacy offers common
denominators in the understanding of global challenges that can only be surmounted
in international agreements.
This chapter addresses the relevance of science diplomacy for sustainability and
offers a unique macroeconomic model of science diplomacy. Science diplomacy
for sustainability offers the advantages of scientiﬁc hard facts and global connec-
tivity of academic circles. Science diplomats also serve the scientiﬁc community
longer and more stable in tenured positions than political appointees. The long-term
vision and academic freedom to pursue endeavors with unknown outcomes, espe-
cially in general research, predestine science diplomats to accomplish sustainability
goals. Science diplomacy is therefore a viable and powerful method to complement
traditional diplomacy and ordinary governmental policy efforts. It is thus surprising
that comparatively little attention has been paid to use the forces of science diplo-
macy to work towards sustainability, in particular in the context of the Sustainable
Development Goals.
This chapter addresses the role of science diplomacy for sustainability research.
An index will be presented including 51 countries around the world ranked on their
A Science Diplomacy Agenda for Sustainable Development Research
437
science diplomacy potential (Puaschunder 2022c). The relevance of science diplo-
macy in the urgent quest to avert climate change through mitigation and adaptation
is stressed. The Science Diplomacy Index will be applied to the Responsibility to
Protect from global warming. The results allow for deriving inferences on the role
of science diplomacy in accomplishing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)
(Puaschunder 2023).
The chapter breaks novel ground to consider the potential of science diplomacy
for sustainable development in light of the SDGs. Clear advantages of science diplo-
macy use for sustainable development are given as well as boundary conditions and
obstacles for science diplomacy to lead on the SDG implementation are mentioned.
Overall, science diplomacy for SDG enactment is a novel and innovative way to
harness the power of academia and soft diplomacy for the alleviation of the most
pressing contemporary sustainable development areas around the world.
The paper is structured as follows: First, the concept of science diplomacy is
introduced. Then the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are presented. The
method of science diplomacy in employing systems analysis is discussed as a way
to help capture complex interaction and implementation terrains. An index that
quantiﬁes science diplomacy is applied for climate action endeavors, which indi-
cates clear directives on which countries have better means of employing science
diplomacy for climate mitigation and adaptation. Science diplomacy potentials for
accomplishing and implementing the SDGs are outlined. The discussion prepares
for research on the role of science diplomacy for sustainable development including
studies on the boundary conditions and obstacles to science diplomacy solutions.
Future perspectives for science diplomacy in law & economics research are provided.
2
Science Diplomacy
The history of diplomacy dates back to the BC age. Modern diplomacy was formed
around the eighteenth century. Since the 1930s the idea of science diplomacy devel-
oped. Human exchange via hard science measurable facts was then coupled with
diplomatic goals of international exchange and mutual collaboration on global chal-
lenges. During the Cold War era of the 1960s to 1980s, science diplomacy excelled in
enabling communication and cooperation between nation-states that were ofﬁcially
not allowed to interact with each other. Institutional ties fortiﬁed research collabo-
ration that was used to establish networks of exchange beyond closed borders. The
rationality of hard science facts helped to overcome problematic political standpoints
and opened gates to embrace a broad range of nations in the accomplishment of global
goals.
Science diplomacy fortiﬁes traditional diplomacy (Barston 2014; Bjola and Korn-
probst 2018; Constantinou et al. 2016; Nye 1990; Sharp 2016; Szkarłat 2020). At
the core of science diplomacy rests scientiﬁc cooperation and compromise for higher
goals of global stability, sustainable development and common security.
438
J. M. Puaschunder
Scientiﬁc collaboration is used in science diplomacy as an additional way to
address global problems and ﬁnd international solutions (The Vienna Statement
on Science Diplomacy 2022). Complementary to traditional diplomatic service and
intercultural exchange, scientists thereby use technical, research-based academic
discourse and scientiﬁc networks to engage international colleagues in tackling
international concerns.
The advantages of science diplomacy are the relative political and ﬁnancial inde-
pendence of scientists compared to statesmen. The political saying ‘science only
concerns scientists’ underlines the rather dislocated role of researchers in govern-
mental affairs, which predestines researchers to exchange information freer from
governmentaloversightandmediascrutinythanconventionaldiplomats.Researchers
are also trained to focus on scientiﬁc hard facts rather than promoting national country
interests or advocating for stakeholder demands like politicians, who often have
to align with their voting bodies. Scientists are also longer in ‘ofﬁce’ given tenure
mandates than conventional politicians, who have terms determined by voting cycles,
or diplomats, who change outposts every now and then.
Historically, even during political travel bans and communication restrictions,
scientists were allowed to travel, for instance, in cases of East–West tensions, such
as with the US and Cuba as well as during the old Cold War era in Europa. Scien-
tists thereby appear to be standing rocks in maintaining communication channels
and key information exchange network participants that transcend national politics
(Gluckman et al. 2022).
For science diplomats, the practice to collaborate internationally on global issues
of concern can also be an additional motivational factor. Science diplomacy can also
serve as additional gratiﬁcation or even remuneration on top of a scientiﬁc career
when considering international exchange programs, such as the Fulbright professor-
ship or international consultancy roles with global governance institutions, scientists
sometimes engage in. Science diplomacy efforts thereby also allow tapping into a
larger pool of resources to mobilize people and prosper their ideas than conventional
national budgets. This strategy appears especially helpful in international develop-
ment goals, where science diplomacy can serve as a quasi-human capital remittance.
Science diplomacy leverages thereby to an additional international aid mechanism.
Funds for scientiﬁc endeavors are also often nationally independent, e.g., think of the
European Research Council grants or European Commission outreach scholarships.
Funding from scientiﬁc resources for general science also mostly comes with the
luxury of no concrete result pressures and leeway in the interpretation of the work
mandate plus the freedom to not have to follow a national-political interest agenda
as well as less red tape involved. Science in its purest form also often comes with
less international media scrutiny and market interference. Scientists also beneﬁt from
their luxury of integrity and only having to serve the higher purpose of truthfulness
and accuracy (Puaschunder 2020a).
Previous cross-border topics of discussion that were supported by science
discourse rather than diplomatic missions include technological advancements and
energy creation, sustainable development and the Ozone Layer, nuclear power use
and outer space missions (Gluckman et al. 2022). In climate change awareness
A Science Diplomacy Agenda for Sustainable Development Research
439
raising, for example, the U.S. National Academy of Sciences became instrumental
in informing the U.S. White House during the George W. Bush administration. The
urgency of action against global warming was stressed and successfully changed the
administration’s course on environmental concerns.
Institutions that engage in science diplomacy and train and employ science diplo-
mats are global governance institutions (e.g., World Bank, International Mone-
tary Fund and United Nations), National Academies of Sciences around the world
(e.g., the US National Academy of Sciences (NAS), the Academy of Science of
South Africa (ASSAf), The American Academy of Arts and Sciences (AMACAD),
The Australian Academy of Science (AAS), The Brazilian Academy of Sciences
(ABC), The Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), The German National Academy
of Sciences (Leopoldina), The Indian National Science Academy (INSA), The Israel
Academy of Sciences and Humanities, The National Academy of Sciences (NAS),
The Polish Academy of Sciences, The Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and
Sciences (KNAW)) and associated and related agencies (such as the Association
for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) in Washington D.C. that houses a Center
for Science Diplomacy, the European Commission that funds global collaboration,
outreach and engagement activities).
One of the ﬂagship institutions that practiced science diplomacy since its founding
in the cold war period is the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis
(IIASA) in Laxenburg, Austria. Set up in the aftermath of World War II on—back
then—neutral territory, this international institution brings together scientists from
all over the world to get familiar with systems analysis. Scientiﬁc ﬁelds represented
at IIASA include mathematics and logic, economics and psychology as well as the
emerging ﬁeld of decision sciences coupled with behavioral aspects.
At IIASA scientists are trained in applying goal-oriented approaches to help iden-
tify systems and procedures that beneﬁt the efﬁcient accomplishment of large-scale
endeavors (Whitten and Bentle 2007). Also trained in methods emerging in decision
sciences, science diplomats would become well-versed in problem-solving tech-
niques that break down complex systems to focus on achievements of measurable
results rather than practicing political customs (Whitten and Bentle 2007).
The Vienna Statement on Science Diplomacy (2022) describes the scientiﬁc
collaboration to address common and shared problems in freedom of cooperation
aside from political agendas. At the same time, researchers can beneﬁt from diplo-
matic tact in the respectful debate of contemporary problems. The traditional diplo-
matic corps wins in science diplomacy through the precision of scientiﬁc facts and
the rigor in the investigation of natural science argumentation. All these credentials
let science diplomacy appear as the most helpful panacea to overcome contemporary
challenges in the global compound.
To this day, science diplomacy is used to discuss common solutions for large-
scale global problems in order to ﬁnd a commonly agreed-upon solution strategy in
the international arena. Today’s global challenges in the rising East–West conﬂict
tension, the global warming problem as well as international pandemic threats and the
regulation of the common digital space on the internet and digitalization advancement
440
J. M. Puaschunder
demand for fast action through mutual understanding of a multitude of international
actors.
In the contemporary climate change negotiations and discussions on the current
state of the world, the United Nations Conferences of the Parties (COP) Intergovern-
mental Panels on Climate Change (IPCC) reports are mainly led by scientiﬁc investi-
gators. Science diplomacy is also one of the most innovative attempts to address the
United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) as aspirational endeavors
to make the world a better place. The SDGs of the United Nations could now also
beneﬁt from the concerted action of scientists in their diplomatic efforts.
3
Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)
The United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are meant to foster
a “shared blueprint for peace and prosperity for people and the planet, now and into
the future” (United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Sustainable
Development, retrieved June 19, 2023). The UN SDGs are a collection of seventeen
interrelated objectives to improve global conditions lastingly for humankind. The UN
SDGs comprise “no poverty; zero hunger; good health and well-being; quality educa-
tion; gender equality; clean water and sanitation; affordable and clean energy; decent
work and economic growth; industry, innovation and infrastructure; reduced inequal-
ities; sustainable cities and communities; responsible consumption and production;
climate action; life below water; life on land; peace, justice, and strong institutions;
and partnership for the goals” (United Nations Department of Economic and Social
Affairs, Sustainable Development, retrieved June 19, 2023).
Sprung out of the Millennium Development Goals, the United Nations General
Assembly incepted the SDGs in 2015 as aspirational long-term goals. Each goal
identiﬁes more speciﬁc targets and indicators as well as concrete progress measure-
ment and tracking techniques (United Nations Resolution 2017). The goals address
the most contemporary global concerns that are often interrelated. The overall SDGs
are further broken down into 169 individual targets. Progress is meant to be measured
by indicators estimating target accomplishments on a more granular and local level
than the actual SDGs (Pierce 2018).
Problems in the implementation are viewed to lie in too many complex goals.
Oftentimes there are partially conﬂicting interests in the pursuit of targets of the
multiple stakeholders involved. National interests may get in the way of global
accomplishments based on mutual cooperation. First-movers are often viewed to
pay the price for free riders in collective action problems. In addition, there is a lack
of political leadership and divergent national interests and approaches mentioned in
the literature on the actual implementation of the SDGs (Biermann et al. 2022). Too
aspirational goals have also been shown to crowd out motivation to work towards
too ambitious plans (Leibovitch and Stremitzer 2022). Cultural aspects and Western-
tainted modalities in implementing the SDGs have been criticized by intercultural
studies demanding for a more inclusive approach than top-down goals. Another
A Science Diplomacy Agenda for Sustainable Development Research
441
critique of the initial SDGs was the lack of paying attention to access to technolo-
gies and digitalization as a panacea for international development obstacles yet also
underestimating digital inequality in the global arena.
In the cost analysis of the SDG implementation, the major national accounting
capital—which is human capital—has largely been ignored and sidelined for a focus
on estimating and monetizing the purely ﬁnancial capital costs. Research on potential
economic short-term gains of disasters (e.g., the short-term economic productivity
gains expected by warming countries in the wake of climate change) has completely
been neglected even though the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)
and the UN Conferences of the Parties (COP) meetings—by now—call for a disparate
impact analysis of climate change and natural disasters in order to fund redistribution
strategies to enact distributional climate justice.
Attempts to make the SDGs inclusive and work for everyone comprise localizing
the SDGs and a Decade of Action Plan (Sustainable Development Goals, Decade of
Action retrieved June 19, 2023). The multi-stakeholder global impetus of the SDGs
requires innovative ways to embrace many voices around the world in a concerted
action plan. Outcome targets and means of implementation targets work concurrently
towards the accomplishment of broad-based goals (Bartram et al. 2018).
Future endeavors to strengthen the SDGs concern cross-border efforts and stream-
lining cooperation between nation-states (Pierce 2018). While the UN SDG frame-
work provides a shared vision from the top down, the implementation and success
will depend on the bottom-up effort in concrete global and local collaboration. In
streamlining the socio-political agenda, synergies will be created based on high-level
thinking to accomplish the goals in the global arena. Employing science diplomacy
systems analysis appears as the most innovative way to complement conventional
goal attainment.
4
Applied Science Diplomacy Employing Systems Analysis
Applied science diplomacy often uses systems analysis, which is the study of proce-
dures and how systems effectively help reaching common goals (Whitten and Bentle
2007). These problem-solving techniques break down complex systems to help
understand how complex system parts interact.
Systems analysis is interdisciplinary and inﬂuenced by many ﬁelds, such as math-
ematics, logic, economics, psychology, engineering and information technology.
This heterodox methodological approach acknowledges a higher Gestalt in large-
scale systems that are larger than its individual components. Systems analysis is also
pluralistic in the openness to creative out-of-the-box high-level thinking. Processes,
procedures and methods ﬁnding in a systems analysis approach beneﬁt from open-
ness to cultural and system speciﬁcities more than other traditional approaches, e.g.,
such as the neoclassical standardized optimization and maximation efforts.
Systems analysis used in science diplomacy is often inﬂuenced by decision
sciences. Behavioral economists thereby inform about outcome likelihoods and
442
J. M. Puaschunder
human choice patterns to better estimate risks and uncertainties’ impact on goal
attainment. Operations and procedures are scrutinized in order to investigate system
features that are beneﬁcial for mutual beneﬁt outcomes.
Systems analysis usually comprises a scope of problem deﬁnition including stake-
holder analysis; a problem analysis to understand the different stakeholder needs and
wants as well as constraints and policy realities; the requirement analysis outlining
the external but also internal conditions applied to the problem; a logical design to
understand the logic relation between key actors and objects involved in the solution
ﬁnding; as well as an informed decision analysis based on risk analysis, logic anal-
ysis and behavioral insights. The big data digitalization age has leveraged systems
analysis to an advanced computational effort in all inﬂuential systems analysis steps.
5
Quantifying Science Diplomacy for Climate Action
Inaﬁrstattempttoquantifysciencediplomacy,Puaschunder(2023)createdaScience
Diplomacy Index that integrates (1) the academia quota per country as an indication
of scientiﬁc excellence based on World Bank Educational Attainment data; (2) a
modiﬁed World Ranking of academic institutions weighted by the relevance of its
academic institutions; and (3) the Lowy Global Diplomacy Index measuring diplo-
matic relations in embassies, consulates, or other diplomatic representations. The
Science Diplomacy Index serves as a measure to identify which countries have the
best starting grounds to engage in science diplomacy action (Puaschunder 2023).
The Science Diplomacy Index identiﬁed U.S. and Russia as leaders in science
diplomacy (Puaschunder 2023). Africa foremost engages in science diplomacy in
South Africa (Puaschunder forthcoming). In Asia, Japan and India but also South
Korea, Indonesia as well as the Philippines, Malaysia and Thailand, Bangladesh,
Vietnam, China, Singapore, Mongolia, Myanmar, Nepal, Brunei and Bhutan are
capable of employing science diplomats (Puaschunder forthcoming). Australia and
New Zealand also have science diplomacy outreach on global issues of concern
(Puaschunder forthcoming). Within Eurasia, Saudi Arabia and Israel engage in
science diplomacy (Puaschunder forthcoming). In Europe, the United Kingdom,
France and Germany are leaders in science diplomacy missions followed by
Spain, Poland, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Belgium, Greece, Hungary, Sweden,
Ireland, Denmark, Norway and Czech Republic, Austria, Finland, Lithuania,
Slovakia, Latvia, Slovenia, Estonia and Iceland (Puaschunder forthcoming). In
addition to the U.S., Canada also features academic diplomacy in North America
(Puaschunder 2023). In South America Brazil, Mexico and Chile engage in science
diplomacy (Puaschunder 2023).
One of the areas of highest concern of a worldwide problem is climate change.
Global warming has been noticed as a trend for decades but the urgency of action
to combat climate change effects has heightened since the turn of the millennium.
Puaschunder (2020b) outlined vast differences around the world in the economic
A Science Diplomacy Agenda for Sustainable Development Research
443
prospects under climate change. Relatively calculated, some countries have a short-
term economic advantage from a warming globe, while other countries lose out the
most and the fastest from climate change (Puaschunder 2020b). These country differ-
ences on a climate change winner and loser spectrum became the basis of assigning
different responsibilities to act on climate change (Puaschunder 2020b, 2023). Most
recently,Puaschunder(2023)appliedamacroeconomicmodelthatintegratestherela-
tive climate change economic prospects with the Science Diplomacy Index around
the world in order to determine the individual countries’ responsibilities to reverse
the negative impacts of global warming (Puaschunder 2023).
When integrating the Science Diplomacy Index with climate responsibility
measures that concern climate injustices, Puaschunder (2023) outlines concrete
countries that have the best conditions but also heightened responsibility to protect
the earth from global warming. The United States, Russia as well as Japan and
India, Germany, the United Kingdom, Canada, China, South Korea and France have
good conditions to establish cooperation through science diplomacy (Puaschunder
2023). These countries also have a heightened responsibility to act on climate change
based on their relative, short-term expected economic gains under climate change
(Puaschunder 2023). Poland, Mexico, Brazil, Spain, Italy and Australia should
also play a role in science diplomacy leadership for climate justice (Puaschunder
2023). Additional countries of interest to help with science diplomacy on global
warming are the Netherlands, Indonesia, Belgium, South Africa, Czech Republic,
Chile,SaudiArabia,Sweden,Portugal,Greece,Austria,Norway,Malaysia,Hungary,
Finland, Israel, Denmark, the Philippines, Ireland, Vietnam, Thailand, Mongolia,
NewZealand,Bangladesh,Slovakia,Lithuania,Latvia,Slovenia,Estonia,Singapore,
Iceland and Nepal (Puaschunder 2023).
This model now can inform future research on the importance of science diplo-
macy and macroeconomic correlates for the global and local cooperation needed to
enact the Sustainable Development Goals.
6
Science Diplomacy for Accomplishing the SDGs
Based on the history of science diplomacy and the historic role of science diplomats
in incepting concepts such as sustainable development and climate change awareness
building; the time has come for science diplomacy to aid in the accomplishment of
the SDGs.
Quantifying science diplomacy potentials has opened novel gates to target essen-
tial proponents of the SDGs. While the United Nations is a ‘one-country-one-
vote’ democratic global governance decision-making authority, other Bretton Woods
global governance institutions favor certain countries’ decisions based on country
contributions, e.g., the International Monetary Fund (IMF) or the World Bank.
In approaching the SDGs and assigning leadership roles on an international basis
for SDG employment, those countries that have established ties in science diplomacy
444
J. M. Puaschunder
networks have the best starting grounds to enact the SDGs. Coupled with redistri-
bution mandates and responsibilities to protect schemes, country comparisons on
science diplomacy could offer insights into what countries have better means but
also face higher responsibilities to aid the world in the accomplishment of the SDG
goals and targets.
Concurrently employing systems analysis could also help in understanding the
realities of target pursuit constraints. Research on the particular disparate impact of
climate change around the world can help elucidate responsibilities in the common
SDG pursuit strategy (Puaschunder 2020b). Comparative global governance could
fortify our understanding of what concepts have worked in certain countries to be
applied to others. In particular, comparative approaches would clarify what science
diplomacy ingredients are favorable in the international compound. Comparing
country approaches could also provide insights into how science diplomacy is related
to macroeconomic stability and resilience variables for international development.
Keeping aid on the most granular local level in mind, science diplomacy can also
call for applied on-the-ground heterodox scientiﬁc methods sharing granting fast and
meaningful aid recommendations.
Science diplomacy for sustainability is employed in multiple facets as the wish
for sustainability and science diplomacy overlaps in fruitful ways. Figure 1 outlines
the goals of science diplomacy and concerns around sustainability as well as the
overlapping connection with helpful results.
Science diplomacy offers international outreach for the global and universal
concern for sustainability. Science diplomacy is driven by precise macroeconomic
results that can be used to quantify the current state, maximize utility and societal
Fig. 1 Connection between sustainability research and science diplomacy
A Science Diplomacy Agenda for Sustainable Development Research
445
welfare over time and discount future predictions—all these features are invalu-
able assets for measuring, implementing, monitoring and evaluating sustainability
research and management. The feature of the lifetime appointment of tenured
academics predestines science diplomats for the pursuit of long-term endeavors as
embodied in sustainability research and management. Search for truth with integrity
to speak one’s mind based on data-driven opinion formation are at the core of empiric
research, which is crucial for the understanding and evaluation of sustainability
status, practice and evaluation. The independence of academics from politics and
industry further enables academics to perform fast-paced without serving multiple
stakeholders, such as voters, donors, political allies, industry lobbyists and interest
groups, to name a few groups politicians have to be cautious about. Scientists can
also ignore historical frictions and political denominations between countries that
traditional diplomats and statesmen/women have to be vigilant about. In their pursuit
of grand ideas and big projects with unknown outcomes, scientists can also serve
to deliver the innovative and iterative solutions needed to enable and enact sustain-
ability around the world in many different domains. Academics also have efﬁcient
information exchange established in scientiﬁc outlets and constant meeting oppor-
tunities around the world, which empowers scientists to become catalysts of change
and transfer agents for best practices as needed for sustainability management in the
global arena. Scientists are trained in complex problem evaluations under tight dead-
lines and have therefore best-starting grounds to support complex interconnected
goals on an international basis, which the Sustainable Development Goals represent.
The diplomatic conveyance of facts that science diplomats are further trained in also
enables them to serve sustainability proponents with fact-based solution ﬁnding. The
futuristic angle of science fulﬁlls the sustainability mandate to address intergener-
ational concerns, against which different overlapping generations may be pitted. In
their role to connect the worlds of industry development and political feasibility,
academics have the potential to contribute successfully to the multi-stakeholder
endeavors of sustainability and the larger international community in their pursuit
of the Sustainable Development Goals. The ethical mandates of academia, such
as the search for truth, honesty, integrity and service to the public, make science
diplomats excellent socially-responsible advocates for international ethical concerns
and voicing the needs of future world inhabitants, which lies at the heart of sustain-
ability. Overall, all the mentioned features and credentials connect science diplomacy
with sustainability. Science diplomacy in the sustainability domain allows for data-
driven global solutions built on international negotiations’ consensus backed by hard
science facts. Science diplomats addressing sustainability, therefore, create global
long-term value for this generation and the following independent of industry or
political interests.

J. M. Puaschunder

Science Diplomacy for Implementing the SDGs
In order to leverage science diplomacy potentials for implementing the SDGs, the
following concrete qualitative science diplomacy strengths should be considered:
GOAL 1: No Poverty: The ‘no poverty’ pledge appears to be closely related to
international development. In order to foster the ‘no poverty’ goal, science diplomats
could be employed to elucidate disparate economic impacts that lead to differences in
wealthdistributionsaroundtheglobe.Foremosteconomistsbutalsolaw&economics
andﬁnanceresearcherscouldhelpinlookingintostrategicredistributionmechanisms
and means to help come closer to no poverty around the globe. Economists could
calculate concrete country differences and further zoom into marginalized popula-
tion groups. Law & economics specialists could help with disparate impact analysis
to connect wealth disparities to policy outcomes. Finance researchers could comple-
ment all these efforts by ﬁnding creative ways how to redistribute funds around the
world but also reallocate resources within society and concrete communities.
GOAL 2: Zero Hunger: Related to ‘no poverty,’ the ‘zero hunger’ call is housed
in international development. Innovatively, the scientiﬁc ﬁelds of economics and
ﬁnance could aid with information on commodity prices and the inﬂuence of stock
market trading in commodities on imposing hunger in third-world countries. Political
scientists may also explore the role of East–West tensions on shortages around the
world, especially when it comes to commodities such as wheat, barley, corn, and
sunﬂower oil. Lastly, the role of sticky inﬂation and supply chain markups could be
further discussed by economists in order to raise awareness of the underlying market
dynamics in the accomplishment of ‘zero hunger’ goals around the world.
GOAL3:GoodHealthandWell-being:‘Goodhealthandwell-being’havebecome
subject to extensive scrutiny by scientiﬁc investigation most recently during the
COVID pandemic. ‘Good health and well-being’ have been acknowledged as hall-
marks of productive societies. Health in relation to individual wealth and national
gross domestic productivity are a newly emerging academic stream (Puaschunder
2022b). Well-being and holistic medical attention are positive advancements in
the aftermath of the COVID pandemic, which may also inspire the discourse and
approach of reaching ‘good health and well-being’ in the SDG efforts of Goal 3 (The
Economist, April 26, 2023). Decision scientists that are trained in systems analysis
may provide advice to individuals about discounting and their personal precaution
and prevention techniques employed. Training in systems analysis will also help to
create the right institutional settings to foster foresighted and holistic approaches to
treating patients effectively.
GOAL 4: Quality Education: ‘Quality education’ is closely related to academia.
Higher education lies at the heart of sciences. Researchers are trained to provide
quality education and sophisticated education is meant to inspire scientiﬁc discourse
and intellectual life-long advancement. Goal 4 as a mandate of ‘quality education’
is therefore closely related to science diplomacy. Science diplomats can underline
the importance and applicability of education for international growth and lasting
prosperity. Science diplomacy for quality education is one of the most interrelated
A Science Diplomacy Agenda for Sustainable Development Research
447
areas, in which research can make a positive impact on the accomplishment of the
SDGs in an actively leading role.
GOAL 5: Gender Equality: ‘Gender equality’ is one of the pledges that underline
the cross-pollination between science and the SDGs. Academia is—to this day—a
profession in which females often are less represented than their male counterparts.
Pushing for ‘gender equality’ in a concerted and standardized way through SDG
Goal 5 can therefore also advance science by advocating for bringing females into
research. At the same time, academics have a long history of embracing gender quotas
and rational efforts to include female participation. ‘Gender equality’ mandates can
learn from academic endeavors to aid female careers in sciences and apply success
factors to other domains and areas of concern, where females are falling behind
or have been left out. Especially the international outreach of scientists may aid
in transposing gender equality sentiments in countries that are currently opening up
market opportunities and liberation strategies for females, e.g., Saudi Arabia allowing
women to drive cars since 2018 and the United Arab Emirates granting citizenship
rights to a female robot that are more extensive than a human woman (The Women to
Drive Movement 2023; Mansoor 2022). These examples underline the importance of
innovative scientiﬁc approaches to open gates for females to participate in economic
and societal life in general. The positive cross-pollination may have been inspired
by academia abroad via science diplomacy and international academic exchange
channels.
GOAL 6: Clean Water and Sanitation: Goal 6 targeting ‘clean water and sanita-
tion’ can beneﬁt from science diplomacy in hard science facts about water resources
around the world, e.g., as measured by satellite imagery. Less discussed appears the
role of scientists in their prerogative of independence from industries and integrity
within market dynamics. Science diplomats may neglect power plays between coun-
tries that share water resources together, e.g., in oceans, rivers and lakes. For instance,
a concrete example where water lines and coastal areas are currently discussed is
the United Nations International Law Commission noticing a trend of countries
advocating for re-writing laws and customary sea borders in light of climate change
that will change sea levels and therefore also land and sea borders. Scientists are
among the ﬁrst to detect these trends and report and discuss these new developments
leaving aside politics and country denominations, which indicate vast differences.
For example, some countries neglect other island states territories’ sovereignty and
therefore are far from the common agreement of sea borders in the Paciﬁc Ocean.
Scientists in their independence from industry lobbying are also among the ﬁrst to
voice concern over water and sanitation quality levels in the eye of medication debris
being hard to be ﬁltered out of water in the cleaning and preservation processes. The
COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the problem with medication consumption
skyrocketing around the world in the past years. Science can also tap its mandate
to provide innovative solutions in addressing the mentioned concerns important for
accomplishing Goal 7 in the search for ‘affordable and clean energy.’
GOAL7:AffordableandCleanEnergy:Oneofthemostvibrantlyinnovativeﬁelds
of development in light of climate change is the quest to ﬁnd ‘affordable and clean
energy’ sources around the world. Scientiﬁc discourse on energy has a long-standing
448
J. M. Puaschunder
tradition. Research on energy innovations complements the rather politically-focused
national energy interests that are often tainted by historically-contested terrains.
Scientists can hereby employ the most recent advancements, such as satellite imagery
but also clean energy solutions. In relation to global warming, the most innovative
approaches to gaining energy while also reducing climate change are the contempo-
rary advancements in ﬁltering out CO2 from the atmosphere. Science innovation and
economic market drivers are also behind ﬁnding sustainable decentralized energy
grids that would use clean energy – such as solar panels, for example—to nurture
energy reservoirs within a household. If sustainable energy is unused by a particular
household, decentralized energy grids would allow sharing of the surplus in energy
among neighbors and neighboring territories. The constant back-and-forth between
households in a common grid would enable saving energy storage and transportation
costs, which make energy inefﬁcient. All these novel advancements spring out of
hard sciences. These sustainable energy solutions’ marketability and market intro-
duction are aided by economics and ﬁnance professionals, who are often in close
contact with and inspired by scientiﬁc frontiers leaders.
GOAL 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth: Science can enlighten economic
growth with an understanding of the cyclical changes in the economy and drivers of
economic growth. Since the early 1930s, governments employ economic scientists
to understand market dynamics that transpire in the overall economy. Academics
have also been instrumental in advocating for decent work conditions. Especially
heterodox political economists have stressed the role of work relations for economic
prosperity but also the political impetus of a country.
GOAL 9: Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure: The SDG on ‘industry, innova-
tion and infrastructure’ predestines science to inform and support Public–Private-
Partnerships with integrity, scientiﬁc advancement results but also international
outreach. Oftentimes, Public–Private-Partnerships are politically-driven endeavors.
Scientists can complement national political insights and strengths with international
outlooks and additional resources that are less dependent on political voting cycles
and political stakeholders. Especially in the developing world and if governments
fail to live up to citizen social services standards, international academic exchange
and scientiﬁc research funds that are allocated for international development and
outreach can serve as a panacea to drive international growth from remote networks.
GOAL 10: Reduced Inequality: Inequality research has a long history in sciences,
in particular sociology, economics and psychology. Especially legal scholars are
trained in disparate impact analysis, which addresses the variegated impact and often
unnoticed implications of policies on certain groups. Coupling the insights of legal
scholars with systems analysis promises to open avenues to detect vulnerable groups
that are affected by inequality. Most recently, also macroeconomists have called for
a more sophisticated group-speciﬁc analysis of large-scale economic concepts, such
as longevity and prosperity (Case and Deaton 2020; Puaschunder 2022a). The socio-
economic consequences of inequality are often addressed by psychologists. Their
insights into group psychology in light of unequal outcomes within society may offer
the most valuable aid in alleviating inequality.
A Science Diplomacy Agenda for Sustainable Development Research
449
GOAL 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities: City planning and sociologically-
inspired research promise to complement traditional governmental and municipal
efforts to engage citizens in landscaping (Ostrom, 1990). Agrohoods and biophilia
trends are booming after the COVID-19 pandemic (New Hope Village and Farm
2021). Agrohoods invite communities to embrace local cooperation and collabo-
ration opportunities. Biophilia is an architectural idea to create living spaces that
resemble nature (Pearlman, 2021). In the United Nations Conferences of the Parties
(COP), most recently sustainable lifestyles have become central focal points (United
Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Fashion Industry
Charter, 2023). All these trends are captured and promoted by academics, who have
therefore best-starting grounds to become science diplomats to push for positive
change through sustainable cities and communities.
GOAL 12: Responsible Consumption and Production: Responsible consumption
is a trend captured in marketing and consumer behavior but also by economists and
ﬁnance scholars. Marketing and consumer behavior specialists have increasingly
noticed the democratization of consumer purchase decisions insofar as consumers are
placing their purchasing choices in line with their social values. Socio-psychological
motives of purchase acts address altruism, self-enhancement through social value
expression and transparency as favourable conditions for responsible consumption
(Puaschunder2017).Digitalizationhasheightenedtransparencyofglobalvaluechain
production standards around the globe in the most recent decades. The contemporary
trend of reshoring captures corporate endeavors to bring back production closer to
consumers for control of ethical production standards. All these novel developments
and trends are closely monitored by scientists, who also study positive conditions to
reinforce sustainable consumption patterns in modern markets and ﬁnance commu-
nities. Training scientists for diplomacy can help integrate the wisdom of science
into markets and ﬁnance in order to support the SDG on ‘responsible consumption
and production.’
GOAL 13: Climate Action: Scientists have long-standing involvement to address
the most pressing global challenges. Therefore, researchers have also been among
the ﬁrst to start noticing weather and temperature anomalies as early as dating back
to the 1950s. Scientists have been at the forefront to alert public leaders about the
lurking climate change crisis. For instance, in the United States, the U.S. National
Academy of Sciences report on global warming changed the White House policy
agenda during the George W. Bush administration. Currently, many innovative solu-
tions for climate stabilization are springing out of academic camps. For instance,
carbon capture projects, such as the Global Thermostat, which ﬁlters CO2 out from
the atmosphere in order to commercialize it for soft drinks and concrete production,
are innovations that have strong ties to academic excellence. Scientists are therefore
essential leaders in guiding innovative applied solution ﬁnding. Training in science
diplomacy skills and the worldwide acknowledgment of researchers as change agents
that can transpire into industry advancement and market innovations are hoped for
in the pursuit of Goal 15 on climate action.
GOAL 14: Life Below Water: ‘Life below water’ addresses the strength of marine
biologists and oceanographers to bundle their hard-science facts with diplomacy
450
J. M. Puaschunder
skills. Especially satellite imagery and sonographic studies to understand oceans
and marine habitats are the newest developments, where scientists team with govern-
mental ofﬁcials at the forefront of scientiﬁc innovation on ‘life below water.’ The
insights derived from these public scientist partnerships are invaluable assets to
strengthen Goal 14 of the SDGs.
GOAL 15: Life on Land: ‘Life on land’ concerns the protection, restoration and
promotion of sustainable land use. Scientists who engage in terrestrial ecosystem
management and foremost climate specialists, who study forestry, desertiﬁcation and
land degradation, may be employed as science diplomats to complement politically-
tainted national dialogues on land use. Scientists can pursue a bird-eye view in
the analysis of cross-boundary habitat protection and biodiversity loss. Aside from
industry interests and national border politics, scientists can voice natural sciences
trends. Researchers are therefore essential stakeholders to be included in the pursuit
of Goal 15 on ‘life on land.’
GOAL 16: Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions: Political sciences and inter-
national development have a long history of focusing on peace and justice. Legal
scholars and global governance-related ﬁelds—such as public administration, public
policyandinternationalaffairs—areconcernedwithﬁndingsuccessfactorsforstrong
institutions to build stable democracies with just societies. The call for ingraining
social justice into academic settings reached unprecedented momentum during the
COVID-19 pandemic and the following age of corporate social justice (Puaschunder
2022a; Zheng 2020). It is therefore not surprising that academia and higher education
are viewed as hallmarks of social transformation. In future research and studies at
higher education institutions, the call for ingraining science diplomacy can there-
fore directly improve accomplishments in the realm of ‘peace, justice, and strong
institutions.’
GOAL 17: Partnerships to achieve the Goal: Building networks of like-minded
scholars is at the core of every ﬁeld of science. Strong intellectual partnership ties
are the gist of any larger research endeavor. Scientists with extensive networks that
transcendnationalboundariesarethereforepredestinedtoleadinthebroad-basedand
large-scale(meta)-analysis, evaluationandimplementationof theSDGs. Researchers
can tap into networks that can expand previous communication and collaboration
ﬂows onto new ventures in the SDG agenda. Science diplomacy thereby allows to
employ of fast action and sophisticated global outlooks that a grand endeavor—such
as the SDGs—will require and their impetus deserves.
8
Discussion and Conclusion
In the current quest for making the SDGs work around the globe, science diplo-
macy appears as an easily-implementable complementary approach to support global
governance leadership and executives on sustainability endeavors. Science diplo-
mats can bring in their individual ﬁelds’ strength, are oftentimes trained to think big
A Science Diplomacy Agenda for Sustainable Development Research
451
and interdisciplinarily and leave political frictions and historical national denom-
inations aside when searching for truth in the hard sciences. The global network
of science offers a broad structure to reach all parts of the world to gain diverse
international information. Yet the scientiﬁc rigor and academic conduct ensure that
a common strategy can be performed that is in line with efﬁciency, ethics and long-
term visions. Science diplomacy for sustainable development therefore appears as a
prominent avenue, yet hardly any information exists on the science diplomacy lead-
ership potential of countries as well as their individual country-strengths to enact
science diplomacy.
When it comes to the SDGs, fast action that combines top-down leadership with a
bottom-up understanding of local communities’ needs should be combined. Science
diplomacy offers the strength of a global common understanding and agree-upon
modi operandi in the respective ﬁelds. Science also can rely on long-standing estab-
lished ties and networks that allow to jump into action in the implementation of
large-scale change processes.
This chapter was meant as a ﬁrst extension of the concept of science diplomacy
on the SDG agenda. Science for SDG awareness, monitoring and implementation
holds many potentials ranging from additional funding to human capital values.
While we gained a ﬁrst understanding of the qualiﬁcation of different countries to
engage in science diplomacy successfully (Puaschunder 2023), future research may
build on the preliminary ﬁndings and elucidate concrete science diplomacy strengths
per country with particular attention to the individual starting grounds and needs of
national communities.
The ﬁrst Science Diplomacy Index was discussed in this chapter as a quantitative
evaluation of countries’ ability to employ science diplomacy in addition to national
governmentalpolicy-making.TheScienceDiplomacyIndexquantiﬁestheleadership
potential of countries to use science diplomacy as a general gateway to pursue higher
goals for the world community compared to each other. This ability to lead on long-
term global goals is crucial for sustainability, especially in the domain of climate
stabilization,whichwillrequirelarge-scalechangesinthewayhumanbeingsproduce
and consume all over the world at a rapid speed. Beyond the quantitative measuring
of countries’ ability to act for sustainability via science diplomacy, this chapter urges
to consider a following qualitative investigation of particular countries’ comparative
advantage to foster concrete science diplomacy ties and build on existing credentials
for sustainability leadership and implementation. In the international arena, research
can connect many cultures. Comparative research can also highlight differences and
underline the common denominator for nations that are ideologically far apart.
Science can also embrace stakeholders on a neutral ground and bestow negotia-
tions with integrity. Sources like research funding but also institutional ties to scien-
tists can become sanctuaries for granted hard-fact-based discussions. Systems anal-
ysis skills will prosper important insights on the viability and success of established
networks as well as allow deriving recommendations on best practices. The inter-
disciplinary, international discourse will help cross-pollination and allow deriving
best practice transplants for complex solution ﬁnding. Adding science diplomacy
452
J. M. Puaschunder
to traditional diplomatic missions and governmental policy-making therefore offers
diversity and diversiﬁcation potential with interdisciplinary value.
In the concrete employment of science diplomacy for the SDGs, one has to
admit that the idea is novel and not much institutionalized in scientiﬁc discourse
and academic practice. Granting opportunities for researchers to collaborate for the
promotion of SDGs, databases on SDG best practices and institutional support (e.g.,
chairs for SDG science diplomacy) are future developments one can hope for. Atten-
tion to unorthodox multi-disciplinary thinking and awareness for applied science
diplomacy options as well as community building are future endeavors for prospering
sustainable development through a rising cadre of responsible science diplomats.
Lastly, ethics trainings in all scientiﬁc ﬁelds (e.g., as in the case of Internal Review
Board proposal trainings) should become standardized in order to raise awareness
for the potential of granting diplomacy scientiﬁc credentials while bestowing science
with noble diplomacy spirit in accomplishing the most pressing human development
goals of our lifetimes.

A Systematic Review of Curriculum
and Its Connections with Education
for Sustainable Development
in the Context of Pakistan
Madiha Khadim
Abstract The connection between what students learn in universities and the ideas
of Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) is really important in Pakistan.
This is because it helps to solve problems about taking care of our environment and
society that we face today, and it also teaches students how to keep doing good things
for the future. The chapter talks about some main points about how the curriculum
is connected to ESD in Pakistan. The curriculum is important for the issues that
Pakistan deals with, it suggests that learners should learn from different subjects,
it talks about getting better at certain skills, it suggests that traditional knowledge
and culture should be part of the curriculum. Further, this chapter is about training
teachers, getting the community involved, and it talks about being good and fair when
it comes to taking care of the Earth and our society. By adding the ideas of ESD into
whatlearnerslearnineducationalinstitutessuchascollegesanduniversities.Pakistan
can help students become people who care about the environment and society, and
who make choices that help the country be better and more sustainable.
Keywords Curriculum · Education for sustainable development · Pakistan
1
Introduction
Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) is a way that people all around the
world agree on to help make the world better and long-lasting. In order to foster
sustainable societies. We should teach through a curriculum about how to take care
of the planet and society. Many countries, like Pakistan, the USA, the UK, Germany,
Japan, Singapore, and Sweden, follow the ESD agenda. They are trying to put ESD
agenda into what they teach. In this chapter, I will look at all the literature on the
connections between curriculum and ESD in the context of Pakistan.
M. Khadim (B)
Lecturer at GCWUF, Punjab, Pakistan
e-mail: madihakhadim@gcwuf.edu.pk
© The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024
W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_26
455
456
M. Khadim
A curriculum means a well-organized plan of different courses, teaching tools, and
learning activities made to reach certain educational aims. Education for Sustainable
Development(ESD)isawayoflearningthatlooksateverythingtogetherandinvolves
many subjects. It wants to make the world better in terms of the environment, society,
and money. The link between curriculum and ESD is very important. This is because
the curriculum decides what is taught in schools and colleges and also affects what
students learn in terms of facts, abilities, feelings, and what they believe in.
The curriculum is the fundamental element of any education system because it’s
the base for teaching and learning. In Pakistan, the National Curriculum of Education
is the guiding system. We can say that a guidebook or a curriculum tells teachers
what to teach at different levels of education. Some studies have looked at how this
curriculum can help with Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) (Zguir et al.
2021). For example, they found that the curriculum for primary and secondary school
talks about things like taking care of the environment and making things last longer.
This is a good starting point to add ESD into what students learn. But there are also
studies by Sund and Gericke (2020) that show some problems. They say that the
curriculum doesn’t cover all the important ideas of ESD, and it doesn’t focus enough
on thinking critically, solving problems, and learning by doing together. These are
all really important components of ESD. The curriculum has not fully covered the
17 SDGs still the lack exists. Although, Teachers play a crucial role in implementing
ESD in the classroom, and their knowledge, skills, and attitudes are key factors in
determining the success of ESD initiatives.
The pre-service teacher education programs in Pakistan do not adequately cover
ESD concepts and pedagogies, and there is a need for in-service professional devel-
opment programs to enhance teachers’ understanding of ESD and their ability to
integrate it into their teaching practices. Additionally, studies have emphasized the
importance of promoting teachers’ ownership and agency in ESD implementation
and involving them in curriculum development processes.
In the context of Pakistan, many studies have highlighted the lack and need for
teacher education and professional development programs that speciﬁcally focus on
ESD. Existing literature suggestions are given below:

Challenges of
