University Teachers’
Perspectives
Teacher educators encounter numerous
challenges when it comes to integrating
sustainability knowledge into pre-service
teacher education. These challenges
encompass a lack of commitment from
students, inadequate support from
management, limited time availability, and a
scarcity of instructional resources.
Additionally, the existing curriculum often
emphasizes narrow-focused courses,
hindering the seamless integration of
sustainability concepts among future
educators
Despite dedicated efforts to incorporate Education for Sustainable Development
(ESD) into the curriculum in Pakistan, scholarly literature has identiﬁed various
challenges that impede its effective implementation (Khadim et al. 2022). These
challenges encompass issues surrounding policy execution, a lack of awareness and
comprehension of ESD among teachers, students, and parents, inadequate avail-
ability of teaching and learning resources, and insufﬁcient support for participatory
and experiential learning approaches. Moreover, socio-cultural factors, including
conventional teaching methods and limited opportunities for student engagement,
have been recognized as barriers to the successful integration of ESD. However, there
are also opportunities for endorsing ESD in the curriculum of Pakistan. For instance,
research suggests that integrating ESD into existing curricula and leveraging local
knowledge, values, and practices can enhance relevance and engagement among
students. Additionally, partnerships among government, academia, civil society, and
other stakeholders can foster multi-sectoral collaboration and support ESD imple-
mentation. Moreover, using innovative pedagogies, such as problem-based learning,
outdoor and experiential learning, and the use of ICT tools, can create effective
learning experiences for students and promote ESD principles.
2
Curriculum and Its Connections with ESD in Pakistan
ESD (Education for Sustainable Development) is a holistic approach to education that
aims to promote sustainable development by equipping students with the knowledge,
skills, values, and attitudes necessary to address social, economic, and environmental
challenges (Leicht et al. 2018). In Pakistan, the idea of including ESD in education
is becoming more important because the country has problems like the environment
getting worse, climate change, not having enough money, and people not being
treated fairly (Bourn et al. 2023). The curriculum is really important for making ESD
happen in Pakistan’s education system. The curriculum creates a structure for what is
460
M. Khadim
taught in schools and outlines what students are expected to learn (Mirza 2020). The
curriculum needs to include current and ﬁtting information about sustainability. This
means adding things from environmental science, social studies, economics, and how
to act ethically. Some examples are climate change, different kinds of living things,
fair treatment for people, doing the right thing when using things, and dealing with
waste (Zguir et al. 2021). When sustainability ideas are put into different subjects
and for different grades, students can see how things like society, money, and the
environment are all connected (Eli et al. 2020).
Research discovered that the curriculum needs to focus on teaching methods
where students are involved and do things to learn. This can mean learning by asking
questions, solving problems, thinking deeply, and working on projects that connect
with real life (Orlovic et al. 2020). Another study found that ways of teaching that
push students to think really carefully, understand hard problems, and do something
about them help them understand sustainability better and how it matters in their lives
and where they live (Bascopé et al. 2019). Moreover, the curriculum must encourage
beliefs and ways of thinking that match with sustainability ideas. These can include
treating differences with respect, understanding others’ feelings, caring for others,
taking responsibility, and making good choices based on what’s right. This can be
done by teaching these values clearly and also by making a good atmosphere for
learning, where students feel like they can do things and have the power to make a
difference in the world and where they live (Alam 2022).
The curriculum needs to show how things locally and around the world are
connected. It should make students think deeply about how what they do can affect
things in different ways. This can mean learning about problems close by with the
environment and people, but also looking at big issues like poor living conditions,
unfairness, climate change, and goals for making the world better (Khalid et al.
2021). When students grasp how things are linked both near and far, they start seeing
the bigger picture and feeling like they’re part of the whole world, which helps them
look at making the world better in a bigger and more organized way.
The curriculum should let students get involved in their neighborhoods and do
things to solve problems about sustainability. This could mean helping out in the
community, going on trips to see things in person, working with local groups, and
doing projects together that help the real world and make things better where they
live (Hadjichambis and Paraskeva-Hadjichambi 2020). When students take part in
the community, they feel like they’re part of it and it’s their job to take care of it, and
they also feel like they have a say in how things work and can help change things for
the better.
The National Education Policy of Pakistan gives a lot of importance to including
ESD in all levels of education, starting from primary to higher education. The policy
says it’s really important to teach things about taking care of the environment, being
fairtoeveryone,andmakingthecountrybetterbyteachingteachershowtodothisand
also by making the curriculum better (Khadim et al. 2021). Pakistan is committed
to achieving the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). These
goals help to look at the big picture and ﬁx problems all around the world (Khadim
et al. 2022). Putting these goals into what students learn is a great way to teach ESD
A Systematic Review of Curriculum and Its Connections with Education …
461
in Pakistan. The curriculum can be designed to align with the SDGs, and they can
include important ideas, topics, and problems that have to do with making the world
better and long-lasting.
Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) is woven into different subjects
including science, social studies, geography, and agriculture, among others. For
instance, in science classes, students delve into subjects like protecting the envi-
ronment, understanding climate change, and exploring renewable energy sources.
In social studies, students investigate matters like poverty, gender equality, and
social justice. In Pakistan, the curriculum is carefully crafted to seamlessly inte-
grate ESD principles, skills, and values into speciﬁc learning goals, evaluations, and
tasks corresponding to each subject (Nousheen et al. 2020).
ESD emphasizes interactive and hands-on learning methods that encourage
thinking critically, solving problems, and taking an active role. The curriculum can
include chances for students to take part in real-world learning experiences that
involve asking questions and are connected to their local surroundings, like going
on trips, doing projects in the community, and working together (Alam 2022). These
experiences where you learn by doing can help students really understand problems
about sustainability and get good at dealing with them. ESD also teaches important
values like understanding others, treating everything with respect, and doing the right
thing for the world and the people in it. The curriculum can help these values grow
by using things like stories, acting things out, and talking (Bosio and Schattle 2021).
And on top of that, the curriculum can help students feel like they can make things
happen and feel hopeful and interested in making the world better in terms of society
and the environment.
Educators hold a crucial position in advancing ESD within the educational frame-
work. The curriculum can outline arrangements for training programs designed to
elevate teachers’ expertise in ESD concepts, teaching strategies, and evaluation tech-
niques. These initiatives can empower teachers to seamlessly incorporate ESD into
their instructional methods and champion sustainability education in their classrooms
(Olmos-Gómez et al. 2019).
The curriculum has a pivotal role in advancing Education for Sustainable Devel-
opment (ESD) in Pakistan’s education system. By infusing ESD principles, skills,
values, and mindsets into the curriculum, Pakistan can nurture a generation of
students well-prepared to comprehend and tackle the sustainability issues that
confront their nation and the wider world. The curriculum’s signiﬁcance in shaping
education for sustainable development is profound, as it establishes the ground-
work for what is taught, how it is taught, and the values and outlooks that are
cultivated. Through the integration of sustainability concepts into the curriculum,
utilization of interactive teaching methodologies, endorsement of values harmo-
nious with sustainability, emphasis on both local and global perspectives, and the
promotion of community engagement, education for sustainable development can
be seamlessly embedded within educational structures. This integration empowers
students to evolve as knowledgeable and engaged global citizens who contribute
constructively towards a more sustainable future.
462
M. Khadim
3
Literature Review
The importance of Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) in Pakistan is
increasingly acknowledged due to the country’s various sustainability challenges.
The incorporation of ESD within Pakistan’s education curriculum has been a subject
of research and deliberation. An examination of existing literature unveils several
central themes and discoveries regarding the interrelation of the curriculum with
ESD in Pakistan. The National Curriculum Policy of Pakistan underscores the infu-
sion of ESD throughout all education tiers. Various frameworks, like the National
Education Policy 2017–2025 and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), estab-
lish a policy structure to advance ESD within the curriculum (Hinduja et al. 2023).
Nonetheless, there exists a necessity for further harmonization and integration of
ESD ideas, abilities, and principles within the prevailing curriculum documents and
policy frameworks (Saqib et al. 2020).
Research indicates that incorporating Education for Sustainable Development
(ESD) into speciﬁc subjects within the curriculum can effectively enhance sustain-
ability education in Pakistan (Rashid, 2019). For instance, investigations have exam-
ined the integration of ESD principles into subjects like science, social studies, geog-
raphy, and agriculture. This integration can be accomplished by infusing pertinent
sustainability ideas, themes, and concerns into the curriculum and aligning them with
the intended learning outcomes and evaluations (Malik et al. 2019). Approaches
involving hands-on learning experiences, such as ﬁeld trips, community projects,
and interactive activities, have been recognized as productive teaching methods
for promoting ESD within Pakistan’s educational framework (Alam 2022). These
methodologies offer students chances to partake in real-life, contextual learning
situations that foster analytical thinking, problem-solving, and active involvement.
A research study proposed that instilling values and mindsets connected to sustain-
ability forms an essential facet of incorporating Education for Sustainable Devel-
opment (ESD) within the curriculum (Nousheen et al. 2020). This encompasses
nurturing values like empathy, respect, and obligation towards the environment,
society, and the forthcoming generations. The curriculum can endorse these values
through narratives, role-playing, and discussions, and by integrating afﬁrmative
attitudes towards sustainability, such as a feeling of empowerment and commit-
ment to societal and environmental matters (Khanum 2019). However, educators
play a pivotal role in advancing ESD within the curriculum. Zguir et al. (2021)
underscore the signiﬁcance of teacher training initiatives that furnish educators
with opportunities for professional growth, enhancing their comprehension of ESD
concepts, instructional methodologies, and evaluation techniques. Another study
accentuated that teacher training can effectively facilitate the integration of ESD into
teachingpracticesandpromotesustainabilityeducationintheclassroom(Khalidetal.
2021). Scholarly literature highlights obstacles in embedding ESD into Pakistan’s
curriculum, includingissues likelimitedawareness, insufﬁcient resources, andadher-
ence to conventional teaching methods (Asif et al. 2019; Khadim et al. 2022).
Khadim et al. (2022) underscore the signiﬁcance of certain suggestions from their
A Systematic Review of Curriculum and Its Connections with Education …
463
study, including the necessity for policy backing, enhancing teachers’ capabilities,
revising the curriculum, and involving various stakeholders to ensure the successful
incorporation of ESD into the curriculum.
To conclude, the examination of the literature underscores the pivotal role of
the curriculum in advancing Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) within
Pakistan’s education framework. The incorporation of subject-speciﬁc integration,
experiential learning, cultivation of values and attitudes, and robust teacher training
emerges as signiﬁcant factors that enhance the nexus between the curriculum and
ESD (Lorente-Echeverría et al., 2022). Overcoming challenges and implementing
recommended strategies can effectively facilitate the integration of ESD into the
curriculum, enabling students to acquire the requisite knowledge, skills, values, and
attitudes for addressing sustainability challenges prevalent in Pakistan. Notably,
Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) constitutes a critical avenue for
addressing sustainability issues and instilling sustainable behaviors among students.
Correspondingly, the curriculum occupies a central role in embedding ESD princi-
ples into the educational domain (Colomer et al., 2021). This systematic review of
literature has sought to delve into the interrelation between the curriculum and ESD
within the context of Pakistan.
The systematic exploration and evaluation of academic databases, journals, and
reports enable the review to pinpoint pertinent literature. Noteworthy are the ﬁndings
of Nousheen’s research in 2020, which underscore vital themes regarding the inter-
play between Pakistan’s curriculum and Education for Sustainable Development
(ESD). These themes encompass the curriculum’s alignment with local sustain-
ability challenges, the embrace of an interdisciplinary methodology, the fostering
of skill sets, incorporation of indigenous knowledge and cultural heritage, enhance-
ment of teacher training and competence, establishment of community involvement
and collaborations, as well as ethical considerations tied to sustainability (Saud and
Ashfaq 2022). The scrutiny of existing literature demonstrates a progressive recogni-
tion of ESD’s signiﬁcance within Pakistan’s curriculum. Endeavors are underway to
infuse sustainable concepts across various subjects and educational levels. Neverthe-
less, gaps persist, andchallenges remaininthecomprehensiveintegrationof ESDinto
the curriculum. Such challenges encompass the demand for more context-appropriate
approaches, heightened investment in teacher training and skill development, and the
forging of robust community engagement and partnerships (Bourn et al. 2017).
The systematic literature review’s ﬁndings have contributed signiﬁcantly to
enhancing comprehension of the present situation and hurdles involved in integrating
ESD into Pakistan’s curriculum. This study offers crucial insights that can guide
policymakers, educators, and researchers in formulating and executing more potent
strategies to embed ESD principles effectively within the curriculum. This, in turn,
will nurture sustainability understanding, skill reﬁnement, and conscientious citizen-
ship among Pakistani students (Zhang et al. 2020). To further cement the relationship
between the curriculum and ESD in Pakistan and to advance sustainable develop-
ment in the nation, additional research and concerted endeavors are indispensable
(Corres et al. 2020; Mirza 2020; Rieckmann 2018).

M. Khadim
4
Analysis
The present systematic review was conducted following the methodological frame-
works introduced by Fink (2020) and Barth and Rieckmann (2018). As explicitly
articulated in the introductory section, the primary aim of this review was to compre-
hensively investigate the extant body of literature concerning the interrelationships
existing between curriculum and education for sustainable development. To ensure
the capture of pertinent research within a contemporary temporal scope, a deliberate
selection was made of a literature sample spanning a duration of seven years for
detailed analysis (Fig. 1).
To conduct the analysis, recent research studies from the preceding seven years
(2017–2023) were employed. These studies underscore the interrelationship between
Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) and curriculum. The systematic
reviewexaminationofthenexusbetweencurriculumandESDinthePakistanicontext
brings forth a number of distinct themes:
5
Theme 1
Relevance to local sustainability challenges: Most studies have found that the
curriculum in Pakistan should address local sustainability challenges such as water
scarcity, air pollution, deforestation and climate change. It should include relevant
and context-speciﬁc examples and case studies to make the material meaningful and
applicable to local contexts. It can help students understand environmental, social,
and economic issues facing their communities and develop solutions for sustainable
development.
6
Theme 2
Interdisciplinary approach: ESD requires an interdisciplinary approach that goes
beyond traditional subject boundaries. The curriculum should integrate different
disciplines such as science, social sciences, economics, and ethics to provide a
comprehensive understanding of sustainability issues. It can help students develop a
comprehensive and integrated view of sustainability, recognizing the interconnect-
edness of environmental, social, and economic aspects.
A Systematic Review of Curriculum and Its Connections with Education …
465
7
Theme 3
Skills development: ESD emphasizes the development of skills necessary for
sustainable living, such as critical thinking, problem-solving, collaboration, and
communication. The curriculum should include opportunities for students to develop
theseskillsthroughhands-onactivities,groupprojects,andreal-worldapplications.It
canempowerstudentstobecomeactiveagentsofchangeandcontributetosustainable
development efforts in their communities.
8
Theme 4
Incorporation of local knowledge and cultural heritage: The curriculum should
recognize and incorporate indigenous knowledge and cultural heritage, as they play
an important role in sustainable development. Traditional environmental knowl-
edge, local practices, and cultural values can provide valuable insights and solutions
to address local sustainability challenges. The curriculum should promote respect
for diverse cultures and encourage students to learn from and appreciate their own
heritage.
9
Theme 5
Teacher training and capacity building: Teachers play an important role in effec-
tively delivering ESD. The curriculum should include provision for teacher training
and enhancement of ESD concepts, procedures, and teaching skills. Teachers must
be equipped with the necessary knowledge, skills, and resources to effectively inte-
grate ESD into their teaching practices and create a supportive learning environment
for students.
10
Theme 6
Community engagement and partnerships: ESD is not limited to classroom
learning. It should also include active engagement with the local community and
partnerships with relevant stakeholders. The curriculum should encourage students
to engage in community-based projects, ﬁeld trips, and collaborative initiatives that
allow them to work with the community to address sustainability challenges. This
can help students develop a sense of responsibility towards their community and
promote a culture of sustainability.
466
M. Khadim
11
Ethical Considerations
ESD emphasizes the importance of ethical considerations in decision-making and
sustainability initiatives. The curriculum should raise awareness of ethical issues,
such as environmental justice, social equity, and interracial equality. It should
instill in students the values of empathy, responsibility, and ethical decision-making,
encouraging them to think critically and consider the ethical implications of their
actions.
12
Limitations
The recent research has several limitations. First, the small sample size of the papers
included in this review (29) may limit the generalizability of our ﬁndings. Only arti-
cles published in the English language were considered, which may have resulted in
potential language bias and excluded relevant research published in other languages.
Additionally, I acknowledge that my search may have missed articles published in
journals that do not speciﬁcally focus on education for sustainable development
(ESD), which could have provided valuable insight into the topic. Furthermore,
the ﬁndings are context-speciﬁc as they are based on curriculum and education for
sustainable development practices in the speciﬁc context of Pakistan. It is important
to recognize that curricula vary across countries, and the results of this review may
not be directly applicable to other educational contexts with different curriculum
frameworks.
Another limitation is that I identiﬁed different terms used for curriculum and
ESD in the literature, which may have led to potential inconsistencies or gaps in our
search results. I was unable to examine the authors’ reasons for using particular terms
and the implications of such word choices for the content and focus of the articles.
Despite these limitations, our systematic review provides valuable insights into the
relationship between curriculum and education for sustainable development in the
context of Pakistan. Future research should consider a wider range of literature,
including research from different languages and diverse educational contexts, to
further enrich understanding of this topic.
13
Discussion
Establishing a strong connection between the curriculum and Education for Sustain-
able Development (ESD) is of paramount signiﬁcance in Pakistan, as it fosters
sustainable behaviors and tackles prevailing sustainability issues. The curriculum
is the bedrock upon which students’ knowledge, attitudes, and conduct are shaped.
The integration of ESD principles into the curriculum carries the potential for lasting
A Systematic Review of Curriculum and Its Connections with Education …
467
inﬂuence, nurturing individuals who are environmentally aware and socially respon-
sible over the long term. Empirical ﬁndings underscore the pivotal role of the
curriculuminincorporatingESDwithinPakistan’seducationallandscape.Itiscrucial
that the curriculum addresses local sustainability challenges, adopts an interdisci-
plinary approach, emphasizes skill development, incorporates indigenous wisdom
and cultural heritage, invests in teacher training and capacity enhancement, encour-
ages community engagement and partnerships, instills motivation, and underscores
ethical considerations. By weaving ESD principles into the curriculum, Pakistan
can equip its students to evolve into conscientious stewards of the environment
and socially cognizant citizens, primed to contribute to the nation’s journey toward
sustainable development.
The curriculum’s design should be geared towards tackling local sustainability
issues confronting Pakistan, encompassing concerns like climate change, water
scarcity, deforestation, pollution, and societal disparities. By incorporating perti-
nent local instances and case studies, the curriculum can elucidate the applicability
of sustainability principles within students’ immediate surroundings and communi-
ties. This approach can galvanize them to enact positive changes to counter these
challenges. Furthermore, it’s imperative to acknowledge that ESD necessitates an
interdisciplinary strategy, given the intricate and interconnected nature of sustain-
ability problems. The curriculum should surpass traditional subject divisions and
incorporate sustainability principles across diverse disciplines, spanning sciences,
social sciences, business studies, and the humanities. Such an approach facilitates
the cultivation of a comprehensive grasp of sustainability, fostering interdisciplinary
thought processes crucial for innovative solutions to sustainability challenges.
ESD places emphasis on honing competencies like critical thinking, problem-
solving, communication, and collaboration, all of which are indispensable for
addressing sustainability issues. The curriculum should prioritize skills develop-
ment through hands-on learning techniques that prompt students to dissect real-world
sustainability predicaments, proffer solutions, and engage actively in learning activ-
ities. This pedagogical approach can empower students to be proactive catalysts of
change and contribute effectively to sustainable development endeavors.
Pakistan’s rich cultural legacy and native knowledge systems hold the potential to
contribute signiﬁcantly to sustainable development. In light of this, it is advisable for
the curriculum to acknowledge and incorporate local wisdom and cultural heritage.
Thisintegrationcanserveasaplatformtohighlighttraditionalsustainabilitypractices
and local insights. Consequently, students can attain a deeper grasp of their cultural
heritage, cultivate an appreciation for local sustainability approaches, and nurture a
sense of cultural identity and pride.
In any educational framework, educators wield considerable inﬂuence in imple-
menting Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) within classrooms. Conse-
quently, it becomes imperative to provide teachers with structured training and
capacity-building opportunities. This approach aids in enhancing their comprehen-
sion of ESD principles, pedagogical techniques, and sustainability concepts. Such
468
M. Khadim
efforts empower teachers to seamlessly integrate ESD into their instructional method-
ologies, thereby sparking enthusiasm among students to adopt environmentally
responsible attitudes and conscientious societal engagement.
Incorporating Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) should involve
collaborating with local communities, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and
other invested parties. This collaboration is crucial for fostering a sense of ownership
at the grassroots level and instigating sustainable behaviors. The curriculum should
provide occasions for students to interact with local communities, partake in projects
based within the community, and cooperate with stakeholders. Through these inter-
actions, students can develop an understanding of local sustainability concerns and
jointly generate solutions. This approach facilitates the cultivation of a sense of civic
duty, prompting students to become proactive contributors within their communi-
ties. Additionally, ESD underscores the ethical facets of sustainability, encompassing
social justice, equity, and human rights. Within the curriculum, students should be
encouraged to critically evaluate ethical predicaments tied to sustainability chal-
lenges and nurture a commitment to rectifying social and environmental imbalances.
Such pedagogical practices can instill values of empathy, compassion, and impar-
tiality—essential attributes for establishing an equitable and sustainable society. By
infusing ESD principles into the curriculum, Pakistan has the potential to foster a
generation of informed and accountable citizens, adept at confronting sustainability
issues and contributing to the nation’s drive for sustainable development.
14
Conclusion
It is concluded that the relationship between curriculum and Education for Sustain-
able Development (ESD) in Pakistan is important in promoting sustainable prac-
tices, addressing local sustainability challenges, and training students to be environ-
mentally responsible and socially conscious citizens. is important. Its preparation
is very important. By integrating ESD principles into the curriculum, Pakistan can
promote sustainable literacy, skills development, and values of empathy and respon-
sibility among students, which will ultimately contribute to the country’s sustainable
development efforts and create a more sustainable future.
15
Recommendations
Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) is an important concept that focuses
on integrating sustainability principles into the education system. In Pakistan, to
promote ESD, it is crucial to align the curriculum with the Sustainable Development
Goals and integrate sustainability concepts across different subject areas. Here are
some recommendations for curriculum development in Pakistan and its relationship
with ESD:
A Systematic Review of Curriculum and Its Connections with Education …
469
InclusionofESDprinciplesintheNationalCurriculum:ESDprinciplesshould
be integrated into Pakistan’s educational framework across all tiers, spanning from
primary to advanced education. This integration can be realized by infusing ideas
like safeguarding the environment, societal accountability, and economic durability
into the curricula of diverse subjects, encompassing disciplines like science, social
studies, and business studies.
Incorporation of local and global perspectives: Incorporating both local and
worldwide viewpoints on sustainable development is essential within the curriculum.
Achieving this involves integrating instances and analyses from Pakistan as well
as other nations to underscore how local and global sustainability difﬁculties are
interconnected. This approach aids students in cultivating a more comprehensive
comprehension of sustainability concerns and their intricate associations.
Development of critical thinking and problem-solving skills: Education for
Sustainable Development (ESD) ought to prioritize nurturing critical thinking and the
capacity to solve problems among students. The curriculum should encompass tasks
and undertakings that motivate students to scrutinize tangible sustainability issues
and recommend remedies. This approach will empower students to take proactive
roles in effecting change and lend their contributions to Pakistan’s endeavors toward
sustainable development.
Promotion of active learning and participatory approaches: The way students
learn should focus on doing things rather than just listening. Methods like asking
questions, solving problems, and working on projects can help students learn by
experiencing things themselves. Getting students to talk in groups, argue their ideas,
and work together on projects can also make learning more exciting. This kind of
learning helps students get involved and feel like they’re really a part of understanding
and solving problems about taking care of our world.
Integration of cross-cutting themes: It’s really important to include big ideas
like climate change, saving different plants and animals, making sure boys and girls
have the same opportunities, and treating everyone fairly in what students learn.
These big ideas show that problems about taking care of our world are complicated
and have many sides. It’s super important that these big ideas are part of different
subjects student’s study. This way, students can really understand all about taking
care of the world and learn to think about problems in different ways.
Teacher training and capacity building: Teachers have a really important job in
teaching about taking care of our world. So, it’s necessary to give them training and
chances to learn more about how to teach these ideas and ways of thinking. This can
be done by having workshops, meetings, and programs where they can learn and get
better at what they do.
Engagement of local communities and stakeholders: Education for Sustainable
Development (ESD) should collaborate with local communities and those interested
in the matter to develop a feeling of responsibility and encourage lasting eco-friendly
behaviors within the immediate area. The educational plan should offer chances
for students to connect with local communities, non-governmental organizations

Future Research Direction
Although existing studies shed light on how the curriculum and Education for
Sustainable Development (ESD) relate in Pakistan, there remain gaps in research
that require attention. These gaps encompass aspects like the necessity for practical
investigations to evaluate how well ESD is put into practice in classrooms, the effects
of ESD on students’ understanding, abilities, and viewpoints, as well as the inﬂuence
of local factors on how ESD is carried out in Pakistan. Additionally, there is a dearth
of research concerning teacher training and the development of skills for ESD, along
with strategies to overcome challenges tied to implementing ESD in the Pakistani
context.

Integrating the Agenda for Sustainable
Development into Entrepreneurship
Education: A Combination
of Expectation and Practice
Ratna Lindawati Lubis
Abstract This study delves into the integration of the Sustainable Development
Goals (SDGs) into Telkom University’s Master in Management program in Bandung
City, Indonesia. This is a pivotal step in the ongoing process of curriculum change
set to unfold in the next academic year 2025–2026. Focused on Entrepreneurship
Education (EE), this study examines how sustainability research informs the incor-
poration of the 17 SDGs into entrepreneurship courses. Additionally, it evaluates
the impact of an innovative app designed to immerse students in green business and
sustainable entrepreneurship scenarios. Through qualitative case study analysis, the
study scrutinizes the app’s integration into EE courses, assessing its effectiveness in
enhancing students’ grasp of sustainable entrepreneurship, ethical decision-making,
and social responsibility. By aligning business education with the SDGs and utilizing
technology for sustainability research, the study aims to equip future Indonesian
entrepreneurs with the tools to positively inﬂuence economic and social dimensions.
This endeavor not only contributes to the ongoing curriculum change but also fosters
a conducive environment for sustainable entrepreneurship, aligning with broader
sustainable development objectives.
Keywords Entrepreneurship Education (EE) · Sustainable entrepreneurship ·
Curriculum change · Indonesian entrepreneurs · Business education
1
Introduction
Entrepreneurship stands as a pivotal force in shaping the trajectory of global
economies, offering not only innovation and job creation but also serving as a catalyst
for Sustainable Development (SD). With the growing recognition of its signiﬁcance,

the discourse surrounding entrepreneurship has evolved to encompass its poten-
tial to advance not just ﬁnancial prosperity but also social and environmental well-
being (Hockerts and Wüstenhagen 2010; Schaltegger and Wagner 2011). Central to
this evolution is the acknowledgment of the United Nations’ Sustainable Develop-
ment Goals (SDGs) as a blueprint for addressing the world’s most pressing chal-
lenges (United Nations 2015). The 17 SDGs outline a comprehensive framework for
achieving SD by 2030, spanning areas such as poverty alleviation, environmental
conservation, and gender equality (United Nations 2015).
Embedded within these goals lies immense potential for entrepreneurship to drive
meaningful change and contribute to the attainment of a more equitable and sustain-
able future (Zahra et al. 2009; Schaltegger and Wagner 2011). However, realizing the
potential demands a deliberate integration of the SDGs into entrepreneurial educa-
tion and practices (Zahra et al., 2009; Schaltegger and Wagner 2011). Recent studies
by Muñoz and Cohen (2018) and Sarango-Lalangui et al. (2018) have further under-
scored the role of entrepreneurship in achieving sustainability and the evolution of
sustainable entrepreneurship research and its potential for driving change. Moreover,
the works of Rosário et al. (2022) provides an in-depth analysis of the existing liter-
ature on sustainable entrepreneurship, its deﬁnition, concepts, and applications in
business. It highlights the importance of understanding sustainable entrepreneurship
in driving positive change and contributing to a more sustainable future.
Within the dynamic landscape of higher education, institutions are increasingly
recognizing the imperative to adapt their curricula to reﬂect emerging trends, societal
needs, and global challenges (Gibb 2011). The imperative to adapt higher education
curricula to reﬂect emerging trends, societal needs, and global challenges is a pressing
concern in the dynamic landscape of higher education. This adaption is crucial to
ensure that graduates are equipped with the skills, knowledge, and mindset neces-
sary to navigate the complexities of the modern world. Recent sources highlight
the importance of this adaption in various aspects of education, including the inte-
gration of technology, the development of soft skills, and the emphasis on lifelong
learning. For instance, a study published in 2023 emphasizes the need for colleges
to adapt their curriculum to prepare students for modern job market (Provost 2023).
This adaptation involves integrating technology-driven courses, embracing interdis-
ciplinary programs, and fostering soft skills like communication, teamwork, and
adaptability. Additionally, colleges are building partnerships with industry leaders to
provide students with insights into current industry trends and practical experiences
through internships and co-op programs. In light of the dynamic landscape of higher
education,TheLinkedInGlobalGreenSkillsReport2022(LinkedIn2022)servesasa
pertinent resource. This report provides valuable insights into the evolving demands
of the job market, particularly regarding sustainability and environmental consid-
erations. By understanding the skills and competencies in demand within indus-
tries prioritizing sustainability, Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) can adapt their
curricula to better align with these emerging trends. Integrating ﬁndings from this
report allows educators to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary to
thrive in green job sectors, thereby bridging the gap between academic preparation
and industry needs, Consequently, by leveraging insights from The LinkedIn Global
Integrating the Agenda for Sustainable Development …
475
Green Skills Report 2022, HEIs can play a proactive role in preparing students for
the modern job market while simultaneously addressing environmental challenges.
Telkom University, situated in the vibrant city of Bandung, Indonesia, has been at
the forefront of the pedagogical evolution, particularly within its Master in Manage-
ment (MM) program. In response to the evolving demands of the global economy and
imperative to foster a new generation of socially conscious entrepreneurs, Telkom
University’s MM program has undertaken deliberate efforts to infuse sustainability
principles and the SDGs into its Entrepreneurship Education (EE) and practices
(Lubis 2019, 2022; Lubis and Ghina 2020).
Lubis (2019) delves into the integration of sustainability principles into the Educa-
tion for Sustainable Development (ESD), highlighting the importance of aligning
the environmental problems and societal problems with global sustainability goals
in the context of Eco Learning Camp Bandung City, Indonesia. This study provides
insights into the challenges and opportunities associated with the balance for the
governance mechanisms toward a better future, particularly in promoting ESD and
actively embracing the SDGs in Indonesia, laying the groundwork for subsequent
research on this topic.
In collaboration with Lubis and Ghina (2020) investigates the role of experi-
ential learning tools, such as case studies and simulations, in enhancing students’
understanding of sustainable entrepreneurship practices. This study investigated the
possibility of raising the extent of applying the ecological concept to the issues of
environmental and social challenges in Bandung City, Indonesia. It provides a unique
way of understanding the process of ESD and proposes a new framework which may
lead to the debate if and how the adoption of ESD prepares the educators for taking
their roles as the agents of SDG 4 Quality Education.
Finally, Lubis (2022) synthesizes the ﬁndings of previous studies and offers a
comprehensive framework for integrating sustainability principles into entrepreneur-
ship curricula. This study aims to inspire universities in Indonesia to take action and
support them through their research, learning, and teaching, and community services
or as known as “Tri Darma Perguruan Tinggi” and “Kampus Merdeka.” This study
consolidates key insights and recommendations, providing a schematic represen-
tation of the newly developed 6-credit course that may promote awareness about
17 SDGs, which employ interdisciplinary, action-based learning and multi-actor
involvement and go beyond usual operations.
Meanwhile, in parallel with Telkom University’s initiatives, management
programs in business schools around the world have embraced innovative approaches
to integrate sustainability principles and EE (Global Entrepreneurship Monitor 2024;
Harvard Business School 2024; INSEAD Executive Education 2024). These initia-
tives underscore the global momentum towards integrating sustainability into EE and
practices.
Reﬂecting on the author’s observations as a long-serving entrepreneurship
educator for 23 years in Telkom University’s MM program, it is important to note
that the foregoing discussion provided the recent ﬁndings from the previous articles
(Lubis 2019, 2022; Lubis and Ghina 2020). This study is part of the timeless research
476
R. L. Lubis
that may help the author strengthen the foundation of being the qualitative researcher
on the emerging ﬁeld of EE.
As the future generation of Indonesian entrepreneurs, students enrolled in Telkom
University’s MM program are poised to play a pivotal role in driving sustain-
able economic growth and fostering environmental stewardship. By integrating the
AWorld app (2024) into the curriculum, the MM program aims to cultivate a cohort
of entrepreneurial leaders who are not only adept at creating innovative businesses
but also committed to advancing the SDGs and promoting green business practices.
By leveraging technology and experiential learning platforms like the app, the MM
program equips students with the knowledge, skills, and mindset necessary to thrive
in an increasingly interconnected and sustainability-conscious business landscape.
As these students embark on their entrepreneurial journeys, they carry with them a
deep-seated understanding of the importance of integrating sustainability principles
into business strategies, thereby contributing to the realization of a more prosperous,
equitable, and environmentally sustainable future for Indonesia and beyond.
The rest of this chapter is organized as follows. First, the author reviews the
literature review in the ﬁeld of EE, the integration of SDGs into the realm of EE and
some key aspects that make the AWorld app necessary. Then, the author presents the
design and methodology of the study by aligning business education with SDGs and
utilizing technology for sustainability research. Next, the author presents the ﬁndings
in tables with evidence and explanation of how ﬁndings were reached. Based on those
ﬁndings, the author presents the discussion section which include the cross-check
against the literature and connection of results with other investigations. Based on this
discussion, the conclusion section proposes a comprehensive roadmap for integrating
17 SDGs into EE curriculum frameworks.
2
Literature Review
It is important to understand at this stage what the author understands by EE and
the many views of EE issues in HEIs. The most fundamental issue relating to EE
is addressing the question of whether entrepreneurship can be taught. Mwasalwiba
(2010) reviewed 108 articles devoted to EE and assessed the alignment existing
between its generic objectives, target audience, teaching methods and impact indica-
tors. A semi-systematic literature review is applied using six thematically separated
excel data collection spreadsheets. It has been found that scholars in this ﬁeld of
study, though differing in a number of deﬁnitive issues, are converging towards
a single framework of EE. There is a shift from a start-up view to an attitude-
changing perspective of EE. However, with a diversity of target groups, there is still
a non-alignment between what educators and other stakeholders wish to achieve in
educating for entrepreneurship with the applied pedagogical approaches, and success
indicators.
Theauthor’scomprehensionofEEwithinHEIsisdeeplyentrenchedintheconcept
of sustainability and its application across various disciplines. EE is perceived
Integrating the Agenda for Sustainable Development …
477
as a dynamic learning process aimed at enhancing individuals’ understanding of
entrepreneurship and its associated challenges, fostering the acquisition of requisite
skills and expertise to address these challenges, and nurturing attitudes, motivations,
and commitments conducive to informed decision-making and responsible action
(Nabi et al. 2017; Advance HE 2020). The author duly recognizes entrepreneurship’s
signiﬁcance within the framework of EE, underscoring the necessity for integrated
and experiential learning methodologies to cultivate the skills and knowledge indis-
pensable for sustainable entrepreneurship (Nabi et al. 2017; Advance HE 2020).
Moreover, the author acknowledges EE’s pivotal role in tackling sustainability chal-
lenges, with a focus on equipping learners with the skills and knowledge essential
for sustainable entrepreneurial endeavors (Nabi et al. 2017; Advance HE 2020). The
author’s perspectives on EE issues in HEIs are intricately informed by the broader
literature on EE, which underscores the importance of experiential learning, inter-
disciplinary education, and lifelong learning. Additionally, the author contends that
entrepreneurship is a teachable skill, advocating for its integration into the broader
context of EE, with emphasis on fostering the development of skills and knowledge
requisite for sustainable entrepreneurship.
Gibb (2011), in an article that discusses the concepts that underpin the practice
of the International Entrepreneurship Educators’ Programme (IEEP)—a UK-based
programme focused on staff in higher education (HE) and further education (FE)—
suggest that there is the growing articulation of the notion of the “entrepreneurial
mindset” as central to employability in general and to a wide range of personal and
organizational contexts. This leads to an associated need to widen the entrepreneur-
ship concept beyond the traditional business school-driven new business venture
and growth model to appeal to all students, no matter what their future careers and
personal experience. Furthermore, Gibb (2011) clearly explain that there is a need
to develop understanding of where EE sits within the web of education theory and
concept. Gibb (2011) states that it can be argued that EE can ﬁnd its place comfortably
within a number of well-established concepts broadly clustered under the umbrella
of social constructionist theories of knowledge and learning.
Having framed the many views of EE issues in HEIs, it is important to point out
here the main theories that impinge upon EE, which is set out in Table 1. There
are similarities and overlap between these different concepts. Nonetheless, these key
concepts help the author to recognize the very wide and varied interest in EE.
The article “Concepts into Practice: Meeting the Challenge of Development of
Entrepreneurship Educators Around an Innovative Paradigm: The Case of the Inter-
national Entrepreneurship Educators’ Programme (IEEP)” by Gibb (2011) is a signif-
icant contribution to the ﬁeld of EE. Although it was published in 2011, the ideas and
conceptspresentedinthearticleremainrelevantandinﬂuentialintheﬁeld.Thearticle
highlights the importance of developing entrepreneurship educators around an inno-
vativeparadigm,emphasizingtheneedforashiftfromtraditionalteachingmethodsto
more experiential and interactive approaches. In recent years, the need for innovative
and interactive EE has become increasingly recognized. The article’s emphasis on
the importance of experiential learning and the role of entrepreneurship educators in
fostering entrepreneurial mindsets aligns with contemporary discussions in the ﬁeld.

For instance, the 3E Conference 2024 (https://3e2024.org/) emphasizes the impor-
tance of playfulness and experimentation in EE, which aligns with Gibb’s call for a
more innovative approach to EE. Furthermore, the article’s focus on the development
of entrepreneurship educators as a key factor in successful EE is supported by more
recent research. For example, a study on mediating effects based on entrepreneurial
competence highlights the importance of EE in cultivating entrepreneurial ability
and entrepreneurial intention (Lv et al. 2021).
The integration of SDGs into academic curricula, particularly within the realm
of EE, has gained increasing attention in recent years. This heightened focus stems
from the recognition of entrepreneurship as a potent vehicle for driving sustain-
able economic growth and addressing pressing societal and environmental issues
(Audretsch and Belitski 2020; Gielnik et al. 2021). As global challenges such as
climate crisis, poverty, and inequality become more pressing, the imperative to imbue
EE with sustainability principles become paramount. Traditionally, EE has centered
on imparting students with the skills and knowledge necessary to initiate and manage
businesses. However, there is a discernible shift towards integrating sustainability
principles into entrepreneurship curricula. This shift aims to equip students not only
with the capacity to establish proﬁtable enterprises but also foster ventures that
contribute to social and environmental well-being (Schaltegger et al. 2018, Fayolle
et al. 2019).
The agenda for SDGs, adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015,
providesacomprehensiveframeworkforaddressingglobalchallengesandpromoting
sustainable development. By embedding the 17 SDGs into entrepreneurship courses,
educational institutions can align business education with broader societal goals and
cultivateacultureofresponsibleentrepreneurship(LaukkanenandNagy2016;Hock-
erts 2017). Numerous studies have delved into the potential beneﬁts, challenges, and
strategies associated with incorporating SDGs into EE. For instance, Kuckertz et al.
(2020) underscore the positive impact of sustainability-focused EE on students’ atti-
tudes and intentions towards sustainable business practices. However, challenges
such as faculty resistance, resource constraints, and inadequate institutional support
have also surfaced (Fayolle et al. 2019; Patzelt et al. 2020). Additionally, the Global
480
R. L. Lubis
Schools Program, an initiative of the United Nations Sustainable Development Solu-
tions Network (UN SDSN), provides case studies and guides for educators to incor-
porate ESD into their teaching (Global Schools Program 2024). These resources can
be used to understand the effectiveness and impact of similar educational programs
on promoting SD in schools.
In the context of academic institutions like Telkom University, which increasingly
prioritize sustainability in their educational offerings, empirical research is essential
to examine how SDGs are integrated into entrepreneurship curricula and evaluate
the efﬁcacy of such endeavors. Qualitative case study approaches, as employed in
this study, offer invaluable insights into the design, implementation, and outcomes
of curriculum changes (Yin 2018). In this context, innovative tools and technologies
play a crucial role in facilitating experiential learning and promoting the integration
of sustainability principles into entrepreneurship curricula. One such innovative tool
is the AWorld app, a virtual platform designed to immerse students in real-world
scenarios related to green businesses and sustainable entrepreneurship. Developed
with the aim of bridging the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical applica-
tion, the app offers students the opportunity to explore and navigate the complexities
of sustainable business practices in a simulated environment.
The crucial thing about the AWorld app is its potential to create positive change by
empowering individuals to make sustainable choices and take actions that contribute
to a more environmentally friendly and socially responsible world. Some key aspects
conﬁrm the importance of the app. For example, the app helps individuals understand
the importance of sustainable living and equips them with the knowledge to make
informed decisions; the app goes beyond just providing information by encouraging
users to change their behaviors and consumption patterns actively; the app assists
users in making sustainable purchasing decisions by offering a database of eco-
friendly products and services; the app fosters a sense of community by connecting
like-minded individuals passionate about sustainability; and the app has the potential
to generate a signiﬁcant cumulative impact.
Appendix A showcases an image of the AWorld app, a pivotal component of
the author’s research data. The image not only depicts the interface of the app but
also includes the proﬁle of the author within the app, indicating the author’s active
engagement since signing up in 2020 during the Covid-19 pandemic. Subsequently,
the author incorporated the app as part of the case discussions in Telkom University’s
MM program starting from academic year 2021–2022. The app, which launched
its mobile version in support of the UN ActNow campaign on September 2020
(Onorato 2020), serves as an innovative tool designed to immerse users in real-world
scenarios related to green business and sustainable entrepreneurship. The image in
Appendix Ainform readers about the technology platform utilized within the study,
and underscores the importance of transparency by offering tangible reference to the
tool discussed throughout the research process.
There are no speciﬁc case studies or success stories schools using the AWorld
educational program for sustainable schools. However, there are examples of the
AWorld app being used in undergraduate training courses to promote sustainable
living (Gutiérrez et al. 2021; Tinoco-Giraldo et al. 2023). These authors discuss the
Integrating the Agenda for Sustainable Development …
481
importance of promoting sustainable living through education and awareness-raising
efforts,particularlyamonguniversitystudents.TheAWorldappispresented,amobile
tool designed to disseminate clear and accurate information from reliable sources
with the aim of changing users’ habits and mindset to contribute to environmental
sustainability. These articles present the results of a pedagogical and user interface
usability evaluation of the AWorld app, conducted by twenty-ﬁve experts. The eval-
uation utilized a questionnaire to assess the quality of mobile learning apps. The
ﬁndings suggest that the app has the potential to serve as the educational resources
for promoting sustainable living among university students, encouraging them to
adopt sustainability and healthy lifestyles and address issues such as climate crisis
within higher education environments.
InadditiontothearticlesbyGutiérrezetal.(2021)andTinoco-Giraldoetal.(2023)
which discuss the use of the AWorld app in undergraduate training courses, further
research supports the efﬁcacy of apps and gamiﬁcation in promoting sustainable
behaviors and environmental awareness among diverse populations. For example,
Ligorio et al. (2022) explore the potential of gamiﬁcation in fostering SDGs, demon-
strating how gamiﬁed approaches can engage individuals in sustainable practices and
promote positive environmental behaviors. This study provides valuable insights into
the effectiveness of gamiﬁcation strategies in promoting sustainability. Moreover,
D’Arco and Marino (2022) investigate the relationship between environmental citi-
zenship behavior and sustainability apps, offering empirical evidence on the impact
of such apps on individuals’ attitudes and behaviors towards environmental sustain-
ability. Their ﬁndings contribute to the understanding of how technology-based inter-
ventions, such as sustainability apps, can inﬂuence pro-environmental actions and
contribute to sustainable living practices. These additional sources complement the
existing literature by highlighting the broader context of technology-based interven-
tions in promoting sustainability, providing further support for the potential of the
AWorld app as an educational tool for promoting sustainable living among university
students.
This literature review discusses the increasing attention given to integrating SDGs
into academic curricula, particularly within EE. In notes the shift towards incor-
porating sustainability principles into entrepreneurship courses to equip students
with skills not only for proﬁtability but also for social and environmental impact.
The adoption of SDGs provides a framework for aligning business education with
broader societal goals. While studies highlight the positive impact of sustainability-
focused EE on student attitudes, challenges such as faculty resistance and resource
constraints remain. Initiatives like the Global Schools Program offer resources for
educators to integrate ESD. The review emphasizes the importance of empirical
research, particularly qualitative case studies, to examine the integration of SDGs
into entrepreneurship curricula and evaluate their effectiveness. It also introduces
innovative tools like the AWorld app, designed to immerse students in sustainable
business scenarios, though speciﬁc case studies of its implementation in schools are
lacking. Overall, the review underscores the potential of integrating sustainability
principles into EE to address pressing global challenges and promote responsible
entrepreneurship.
482
R. L. Lubis
3
Materials and Methods
This study adopts a qualitative case study approach to deeply explore the integra-
tion of SDGs within Telkom University’s MM program. This approach is meticu-
lously chosen to provide a profound understanding of how SD principles permeate
the entrepreneurship course, acknowledging its nuanced and context-speciﬁc nature
(Yin 2018). By embracing qualitative research, this study seeks to unearth rich and
multifaceted insights into the experiences, perceptions, and motivations of students
involved in the integration process (Creswell and Poth 2018).
Through semi-structured interviews, observation, and a Likert scale question-
naire conducted with the students who enrolled the entrepreneurship course during
academic year 2023–2024, the study aims to capture the essence of SDG integra-
tion within the MM program (Creswell and Creswell 2017). These methods are
meticulously selected to unravel the complexities and intricacies of the integration
process, allowing for a holistic examination of motivations, strategies, challenges,
andperceivedeffectivenessofcurriculumchanges(MerriamandTisdell2016).Atthe
culmination of the semester, following the completion of the entrepreneurship course,
the author collected the Likert scale questionnaire from all the participating students.
These questionnaires served as invaluable instruments to quantitatively assess the
students’ perceptions and experiences with the AWorld app. Furthermore, the author
conducted semi-structured interviews with a subset of students to gain deeper insights
into their perspectives, experiences, and perceptions regarding the integration of the
app into the course curriculum. Speciﬁcally, interviews were conducted with 10 select
students to gather diverse perspectives and understand the varied impacts and impli-
cations of the app’s integration. While there is not a strict rule or deﬁnitive reference
specifying the exact number of interviews needed in qualitative research, the concept
of saturation is widely discussed and accepted in qualitative research methodology.
Saturation refers to the point at which new data ceases to provide additional insights
or themes, indicating that enough data has been collected to adequately address the
research questions (Guest et al. 2006; Saunders et al. 2018). Ultimately, the speciﬁc
number of students to interview should be determined based on the research goals,
the complexity of the topic, and the depth of analysis required.
Given that the total students who enrolled the entrepreneurship course during
academic year 2023–2024 are 46, and considering practical constraints such as time
and resources, conducting interviews with approximately 10–20% of the student
population could be a reasonable approach. Therefore, interviewing 10 students may
provide a sufﬁcient range of perspective and insights while ensuring that saturation
is likely to be achieved. These interviews provided a qualitative dimension to the
data collection process, allowing for a comprehensive understanding of the students’
engagement with the AWorld app and its impact on their learning experiences. The
semi-structurednatureoftheinterviewsofferedﬂexibilityforstudentstoexpresstheir
thoughts freely while ensuring that key research objectives were addressed. Through
the data collection process, the author garnered rich and diverse perspective that
contribute signiﬁcantly to the study’s ﬁndings and conclusions.

Creswell and Poth (2018), Table 2 provides a concise overview of the data collection
methods employed in this study.
As stated earlier, the Telkom University’s MM program equips students with
the knowledge, skills, and mindset necessary to thrive in an increasingly intercon-
nected and sustainability-conscious business landscape. Looking to the future also
reﬂect the broad variety of methods of EE in Telkom University, and there is no one
correct deﬁnition and comprehensive deﬁnition of its content. Indeed, it is a dynamic
phenomenon as shown in Table 1 (Gibb 2011). In this regard, the author acknowl-
edged that conducting the case study by emphasizing the signiﬁcance of aligning
business education with the AWorld app (2024) for sustainability research was seen
as a signiﬁcant effort to promote sustainability research.
During academic year 2023–2024, spanning from September 2023 to January
2024, the author undertook the delivery of entrepreneurship course for Telkom
University’s MM students. Speciﬁcally, the course focused on “Corporate
Entrepreneurship” and attracted a total of 46 enthusiastic participants. As an integral
part of the course curriculum, all students were actively engaged with the AWorld app,
having signed up for it since the beginning of the semester. Prior to administering
Likert scale questionnaires, comprehensive information sessions were conducted
to familiarize students with the app’s features and functionalities. These sessions
aimed to ensure that students grasped the essential aspects of the app, enabling them
to provide accurate responses to the questionnaire prompts. The Likert scale ques-
tionnaires, designed to gauge student’s perceptions and experiences with the AWorld
app, are provided in Appendix B.

Focusing on the MM program at Telkom University as a singular case study
enables an in-depth exploration within the Indonesian higher education landscape
(Stake 2013). This deliberate choice empowers the author to examine the integra-
tion process within a speciﬁc academic context, fostering a deeper understanding of
the dynamics at play (Yin 2018). Engaging with 46 students during academic year
2023–2024 further enriches the study by capturing diverse perspectives and experi-
ences (Patton 2015). Throughout the research journey, reﬂexivity remains paramount
(Finlay and Gough 2008). The author continuously examines their biases, assump-
tions, and preconceptions to ensure the integrity and trustworthiness of the ﬁnd-
ings (Charmaz 2014). This reﬂexivity cultivates methodological rigor, safeguarding
against potential biases and enhancing the credibility of the study’s outcomes (Tracy
2013).

of sustainability research integration within the Telkom University’s MM program.
By embracing multi-dimensional perspective and engaging deeply with students, this
study aspires to generate invaluable insights that contribute to the ongoing discourse
on aligning business education with sustainability research (Creswell and Poth 2018),
ultimately paving the way for SD within higher education institutions.
4
Findings
The ﬁndings of this study offer valuable insights into the integration of SDGs into
Telkom University’s MM program, with a speciﬁc focus on EE. Through a combina-
tion of quantitative analysis of Likert scale questionnaires and qualitative exploration
via semi-structured interviews, this section presents a comprehensive examination
of students’ perceptions, experiences, and attitudes towards the AWorld app and its
integration into the entrepreneurship curriculum. From evaluating the effectiveness
of the app in enhancing students’ understanding of sustainability entrepreneurship
to uncovering challenges and opportunities associated with its implementation, the
ﬁndings shed light on the complexities and nuances of aligning business education
with the broader agenda for SD. By synthesizing quantitative and qualitative data,
this section offers a holistic perspective on the impact of the curriculum change
Integrating the Agenda for Sustainable Development …
485
initiative and the role of innovative technologies in fostering sustainability-oriented
EE.
The ﬁndings of data collection are presented in Table 3, which provides a detailed
overview of the quantitative responses obtained through Likert scale questionnaires
administered to 46 students enrolled in the “Corporate Entrepreneurship” course
during the academic year 2023–2024. The table encompasses a range of key metrics,
including students’ perceptions of the AWorld app’s usability, its effectiveness in
enhancing their understanding of sustainability entrepreneurship, and their overall
satisfaction with its integration into the curriculum.
This Table 3 summarizes the responses for each category of questions related to
awareness about sustainability, behavior change, sustainable product recommenda-
tion, collaboration on sustainability initiatives, and long-term impact. Each response
option is presented as a percentage of total respondents.
Additionally, qualitative insights gleaned from semi-structured interviews with a
select group of students provide direct insights into the experiences, perspectives, and
sentiments expressed by students regarding the integration of the AWorld app into
the EE. The summary ﬁndings of data collection are presented in Table 4. Through
thematic analysis, the qualitative ﬁndings are organized into emergent themes that
capture the multifaceted nature of students’ experiences with the AWorld app and
its implications for EE. Together, the quantitative and qualitative ﬁndings offer a
comprehensive depiction of the impact of the curriculum change initiative and the
AWorld app’s role in shaping students’ learning experiences in relation to sustainable
entrepreneurship.
After presenting the ﬁndings, the author now moves into the discussion section,
which include the cross-check against the literature and connection of results with
other investigations.
5
Discussion
The ﬁndings of this study offer valuable insights that contribute to ongoing academic
debated and align with relevant peer-reviewed publications in the ﬁeld. The student’s
perceptions and experiences with the AWorld app as well as its implications for EE
resonated with discussions in academic literature concerning the role of education
in fostering sustainability-driven in entrepreneurship (Fayolle et al. 2019; Gielnik
et al. 2021). Similarly, the study’s emphasis on practical, hands-on learning experi-
ences and effectiveness of tools like the AWorld app align with recommendations in
scholarly literature advocating for experiential learning approaches to enhance under-
standingandengagementwithsustainabilityconcepts(Hockerts2017;Kuckertzetal.
2020). However, challenges such as resource allocation, faculty training, and tech-
nological integration, are consistent with ﬁndings from previous studies examining
barriers to sustainability integration in higher education contexts (Laukkanen and
Nagy 2016; Audretsch and Belitski 2020). Despite these challenges, the perceived
effectiveness of the curriculum changes in fostering students’ understanding of

embedded within students’ responses, illuminating the complex interplay between

One of the key themes that emerges from the analysis is the students’ anticipation
of potential challenges during the implementation of the curriculum change initiative
and integration of the AWorld app. As Stake (2013) and Yin (2018) argue, educa-
tional reforms often encounter various hurdles, ranging from resource constraints to
resistance to change. The students’ recognition of these challenges underscores their
pragmatic outlook and their understanding of the realities of enacting educational
reforms in a complex and dynamic environment. Moreover, their emphasis on the
importance of practical skills for addressing real-world challenges reﬂects a commit-
ment to collaborative problem-solving and continuous improvement in EE. Another
salient aspect is the students’ deep appreciation for the practicality and real-world
applicability of the AWorld app. As Finlay and Gough (2008) and Tracy (2013) assert,
experiential learning plays a crucial role in fostering critical thinking and problem-
solving skills among students. The students’ recognition of the AWorld app as a
valuable tool for immersing them in real-world scenarios related to green business
and sustainable entrepreneurship speaks to the transformative potential of innova-
tive technologies in education. By bridging the gap between theory and practice,
the AWorld app empowers students to apply theoretical concepts to real-world chal-
lenges, thereby enhancing their learning experience and preparing them for success
in the competitive landscape of entrepreneurship.
Through this study, the author proposed a comprehensive roadmap for integrating
17 SDGs into EE curriculum frameworks. The roadmap encompasses various stages,
from laying the foundation and designing research methodologies to data collection
and analysis, knowledge generation and synthesis, impact assessment and evalua-
tion, and scaling and sustainability efforts. Each stage involves speciﬁc activities
aimed at promoting interdisciplinary collaboration, generating actionable insights,
and fostering meaningful partnerships with stakeholders, as shown in Table 6.
6
Conclusions and Outlook
As mentioned at the beginning of this chapter, this study represents a signiﬁ-
cant contribution to the author’s ongoing journey as a qualitative researcher in the
emerging ﬁeld of Entrepreneurship Education. The concept of integrating business
education with the 17 SDGs and leveraging the AWorld app to drive a paradigm shift
in sustainability research is crucial for facilitating ongoing curriculum changes. This
study serves as a cornerstone in strengthening the foundation of qualitative research
within the realm of EE.
In conclusion, this study marks a signiﬁcant milestone in advancing the author’s
understanding of the intersection between EE and SD goals. By proposing a compre-
hensive roadmap for integrating 17 SDGs into EE curriculum frameworks, the author
has laid the groundwork for fostering a more sustainable and socially responsible
approach to business education. Moving forward, it is imperative that everyone in

Possible future research directions include exploring the long-term impact of
sustainability integration on student outcomes, conducting comparative studies
across different educational contexts, and investigating the role of technology in
enhancing sustainability education effectiveness. For example, leveraging innovative
tools such as the generative Artiﬁcial Intelligence called “ChatSDG”, as discussed
in a recent article by the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business

ences focused of sustainability education (Shinn 2024). By exploring these research
avenues, academics and professionals in HEIs can collectively contribute to trans-
forming the landscape of EE. This collective effort is essential for equipping future
generations with knowledge and skills needed to address global challenges and create
a more sustainable world.

Integration of the Triple Helix Model
in Sustainability Research. ISOSCAN
as Case Study
Jose Manuel Diaz-Sarachaga
Abstract At the United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Summit, the UN
2030 Agenda was adopted to push society towards a sustainable development path.
Understanding how to guarantee the well-being of current and future generations
within the limits of the natural world is the overarching goal of sustainability research.
However, rather than deﬁning a research agenda based on sustainability as a holistic
and integrated view, some particular topics, inter alia climate change, green energy,
social sustainability and sustainability education have been individually examined.
Therefore, in an effort to bridge this gap, this chapter introduces the Sustainability
Instituteof Cantabria(ISOSCAN) as anexpressionof theTripleHelixModel inSpain
to face main regional challenges by a comprehensive approach that jointly covers
all sustainability dimensions. To this end, The Regional Development Agency of
Cantabria (SODERCAN) championed a cluster comprising four private companies
and one university of the region. A detailed plan to revitalize the most declining rural
areas of Cantabria was presented as case study to emphasize research through the
collaboration between university, industry and governance.
Keywords Innovation · Partnership for sustainability · Sustainable development
goals · Sustainable entrepreneurship · Triple helix model
1
Introduction
The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was approved by a majority of
member countries of the United Nations in September 2015 (United Nations (UN)
2015) representing a universal call to action in order to achieve the 17 Sustainable
Development Goals (SDGs) before the end of 2030. As this global appeal was made
to engage all organizations and individuals, the components of the Triple Helix
Model of innovation (THM) are particularly relevant to strengthen collaborations

e-mail: diazsjose@uniovi.es

W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
