among stakeholders and study the interplays connecting innovation and sustainable
development (Etzkowitz and Zhou 2019). These interactions result in the fourth and
ﬁfth helices regarded by Zhou and Etzkowitz (2021) as a potential disruptive factor
negatively impacting on the THM. Similarly, innovation, science and technology are
three key cornerstones towards the SDGs, further highlighting the contribution of
industry and academia to this purpose (Badillo et al. 2017).
The present world is anchored on the necessity of favoring economic development.
Conversely, entrepreneurial ecosystems are principally created in universities where
teaching is alternated with applied research and knowledge production (Klofsten
et al. 2019). Companies are meanwhile regular demanders of training and research
(Bogers et al. 2018). Universities have thus left their passive attitude aside to become
outstanding players on the social and economic chessboard (Kochetkov 2023). Public
institutions offer regulatory frameworks, budgetary policy instruments and ﬁnan-
cial support to stimulate partnerships between business and academia (Volkmann
et al. 2021), closing the circle around these three major stakeholders. Etzkowitz
and Leydesdorff (2000) theorized the THM to reﬂect the interaction among the
university-industry-government (U-I-G) trinomial in the innovation process. The
university, however, is less important than the two other helices.
Beyond the relevancy of the own helices, their mutual relationship plays a promi-
nent role as well (Ivanova and Leydesdorff 2014). The interactions between society,
environment and sustainability substantiate the inclusion of two additional helices
giving way to the quadruple and quintuple helix models (Carayannis and Camp-
bell 2009; Carayannis et al. 2012) as shown in Fig. 1. Helix models share various
commonalities with complex systems such as inter- and transdisciplinarity, innova-
tion as a nexus between social ecosystems, and the dynamic nature of subsystems.
Furthermore, these models reﬂect diverse interactions among societal subsystems to
foresee their evolution, for which the involvement of academia through research is
essential. Moreover, they outline the engagement of various agents participating in
the innovation process.
Under this context, this chapter aims to shed light on the inﬂuence of the helix
models in the design of a research agenda for sustainability. The next two subsec-
tions describe the contribution of the THM and the N-helix models in sustainability
Fig. 1 Shift from the triple helix model to the quintuple helix model. Source Author
Integration of the Triple Helix Model in Sustainability Research. …
505
research. The case study of the Sustainability Institute in the Spanish region of
Cantabria (ISOSCAN) is presented in the fourth section, whilst the last section
summarizes main conclusions drawn from this study.
2
The Triple Helix Model and Sustainability Research
Figure 2 displays the interactions between academia, industry and government as
per the THM, primarily based on collaborative value creation entailing knowledge
co-creation along with education and funding research (Lew and Park 2021). As
such, it acts as a knowledge center where innovation is the hallmark to generate
new ideas and knowledge (Etzkowitz and Zhou 2017). Universities and research
institutions hence become pivotal actors to develop a knowledge based economy for
which funding is necessary to align socio-economic interests towards the design of
effective policies (Armeanu et al. 2018). Another consequence is the emergence of
a variety of new joint ventures (i.e., industry consortia, entrepreneurship incubators,
public research projects) with common goals (Redman et al. 2021) encompassing
players with distinct interests, motivations and values (Gustafsson and Jarvenpaa
2018).
Socio-economic returns and research systems are the key aspects deemed in the
THM to assess the impact of projects ﬁnanced by institutions and/or companies in
the pursuit of economic development (Ritala and Huizingh 2014). This approach
is related to the concept ‘academic entrepreneurship’ that (Ray 2013) deﬁnes as “a
means of commercialization, which is the transformation of knowledge into products,
processes and organization along with their contribution to economic growth and
innovation”, providing an entrepreneurial dimension to the universities (Galvao et al.
2019). The entrepreneurial capacity of universities relies on a dynamic organization,
but it may be constrained by environmental factors. Setting an organizational culture
with a deﬁned line of thought and clear objectives is crucial to boost academic
entrepreneurship (Klofsten et al. 2019).
Fig. 2 Conﬁguration of the
triple helix model of
innovation. Source Author
506
J. M. Diaz-Sarachaga
This new condition is leading universities to change their practices from teaching
to research and ﬁnally, to innovative entrepreneurship (Brem and Radziwon 2017),
which strengthens the integration and collaboration among the U-I-G triad to build
wealth and a knowledge-based society (Sarpong et al. 2017). Given that the close
relationship between sustainable development and technological progress boosted
by the aforementioned process, the THM turns into an efﬁcient research instrument
to balance the four sustainability dimensions (social, economic, environmental and
institutional).
The contribution of sustainability research transcends the mere generation of
knowledge to propose transformative approaches that assist in the implementation of
sustainability principles into practice (Leal Filho et al. 2023) by integrating multiple
disciplines (Stock and Burton 2011) and developing a normative frame (Schneider
et al. 2019). Approximately two thirds of sustainability research topics are geared
towards curriculum, research, outreach and campus greening (Diaz-Sarachaga and
Longo Sarachaga 2024), the remainder are related to governance and other subjects
such as entrepreneurship, social innovation, management, etc. (Bolger 2021). Despite
the current gaps and further opportunities, sustainability research has received scarce
attention (Wooltorton et al. 2015) and consequently, the development of new theo-
retical frameworks to foster research in sustainability is yet to be addressed (Rau
et al. 2018). The transformative change linked to scientiﬁc practice of sustainability
research (Lawrence et al. 2022) should be accompanied by a collaborative, integra-
tive and reﬂexive approach (Büttner et al. 2023). But the integration of knowledge
is sometimes limited, by dint of the existence of multiple perspectives, views and
values (Beck and Forsyth 2020).
Gibbons et al. (1994) formulated the ﬁrst two models of knowledge to explain
the role of research in the economic development. Mode 1 consists of a linear model
predominantly based on university research without a necessary contribution to
industry. Knowledge was produced focusing on application in mode 2, which in
turn evolves into the THM by considering institutional interactions as a non-linear
model of innovation (Fidanoski et al. 2022). Thus, the THM represents the complex
relationship between university, industry and government. Although university is
regarded as the least powerful helix, the triad is not dominated by a single actor which
would have a negative impact on the generation of ideas and initiatives (Etzkowitz
et al. 2023). On the contrary, the THM is a cooperative partnership oriented to the
promotion of economic growth (Leydesdorff and Smith 2021).
3
Implications of N-Helix Models for Sustainability
Several perspectives have been adopted to compare THM with quadruple, quintuple
and N-helix models. Zhou and Etzkowitz (2021) view helices of the THM as actors
or institutional spheres, as distinct from helices of other N-helix models envisaged
as subsystems. In response, the concept of ‘Triple Helix Twins’ was introduced
Integration of the Triple Helix Model in Sustainability Research. …
507
to supplement the U-I-G THM by incorporating an additional University-Public-
Government (U-P-G) helix model that emphasizes the value of the public dimension
(Cai 2022). Table 1 illustrates the development of the THM. Leydesdorff and Smith
(2021) conceive N-helices as the interaction of a combination of triple helices. This
vision is not shared by Carayannis et al. (2022) arguing that N-helix integrates and
contextualizes the prior N-helix. The sextuple helix in such a way encompasses all
the quintuple, quadruple and triple helices.
The quadruple and quintuple helix models were originally articulated by
Carayannis et al. (2018) in the frame of co-opetitive (portmanteau of cooperation
and competition) innovation ecosystems. These ecosystems are clusters of various
stakeholders with conﬂicting and converging objectives involving social, economic,
institutional or technical dimensions to be managed via entrepreneurial development
in which the core stakeholder is the triad U-I-G, the foundation of the THM.
Veldhuizen (2020) disclosed the evolution of N-helix literature towards sustain-
ability in search of satisfying the needs of the present generation without compro-
mising necessities of next generations by means of technological, social or interna-
tional innovations (Armeanu et al. 2018). But the liaison between helix models and
sustainability was ﬁrstly outlined by Etzkowitz and Zhou (2006) who acknowledged
changes in the physical and social environments due to innovation. Environmental
preservation has gained increased momentum in the ﬁeld of N-helix models (Sunina
and Rivza 2016). In this sense, ecological balance requires the active engagement of
diverse actors that may obtain prominent economic and social outcomes (Grundel
and Dahlström 2016) characterizing a sustainability approach. The limited participa-
tion of social agents in triple-helix research has contributed to evolve THM towards
N-helix models by adding social helices (Höglund and Linton 2018). Table 2 thus
reﬂects as the U-P-G helix model puts the focus on sustainability taking as reference
the U-I-G scheme.
Although the THM has been traditionally employed in distinct contexts, addi-
tional matters were addressed in quadruple and quintuple helix models related to

society, sustainable resources, innovation in ecology or smart cities for the former
(McAdam et al. 2016), and environment for the latter (Baccarne et al. 2016). The
quintuple helix model particularly highlights the function of societal and natural
environments in innovation processes. Societal environment consists of individuals
with similar lifestyle, whilst the amalgamation of natural resources, ﬂora and fauna
represents natural environments. Considering that quintuple helix model seeks to
identify opportunities to produce knowledge and innovation intended for tackling
ecological and environmental issues, the protagonism of universities as drivers of
research is to be reshaped. This shift means a more entrepreneurial attitude aligned
to meet social and environmental needs (König et al. 2021).
4
The Sustainability Institute of Cantabria (ISOSCAN)
4.1
Cantabria in a Nutshell
Located in the northern Spain and facing the Atlantic Ocean, the region of Cantabria
covers a land area of 5326.54 km2, by 1% of the country’s surface area, where
forestry (51%) and farmland (40.5%) are predominant. Regional population steadily
increased by 5.6% from 2005 (561,038) to the peak in 2011 (592,393). A slight
Integration of the Triple Helix Model in Sustainability Research. …
509
reduction of 1.3% was then experienced until 2022 (584,708). In Cantabria, residents
live in 102 municipalities clustered in 10 comarcas (ICANE 2024). The city of
Santander is the capital of the region with 172,726 inhabitants.
Gross domestic product (GDP) in 2022 was e15.4 billion (e26,167 per capita),
representing 1.15% of the national GDP, whilst the unemployment rate was 7.48%
of workforce. Service sector, with 55% of the GDP, leads the regional economy,
followed by manufacturing (17%), construction (13%) and the primary sector (3%).
Dairy industry dominates the ﬁrst sector, being Cantabria the ﬁfth milk producer in
the country. Manufacturing is based on foodstuffs, automobile components, chemical
industry and home appliances.
There are two universities in the region. The public university of Cantabria was
created in 1972 to offer a wide range of degrees within graduate, postgraduate and
doctorate programs and be a social, cultural and economic enabler of the region.
Teaching, research and knowledge transfer primarily involve four main areas: water
and energy; biomedicine and biotechnology; banking, ﬁnances and entrepreneurial
activity; and heritage and language. Universidad Europea del Atlántico (Uneat-
lantico) began its activity in 2014 promoting entrepreneurial initiatives and encour-
agingstudentstobecomefamiliarwiththerealworldbydevelopingcreativeandinno-
vative thinking. Collaborative agreements were purposely signed with companies
and individuals in diverse professional areas to build synergies between university,
industry and society.
4.2
ISOSCAN: An Excellent Opportunity to Relaunch
Cantabria
Adopted by the Spanish Council of Ministers on 22 February 2019, the Spanish
Urban Agenda, a strategic document without binding force, aims at aligning the
global commitments included in the 2030 Agenda, the UN New Urban Agenda and
the Urban Agenda for the European Union to the Spanish context. The Sustainability
Institute of Cantabria (ISOSCAN) was originally conceived as an effective research
instrument to assist the Government of Cantabria in the deﬁnition of common guide-
lines to be applied by all municipalities of the region in the achievement of the
Spanish Urban Agenda. And the assessment and monitoring of metrics that allow to
compare performance among municipalities to identify improvement opportunities,
and practices and lessons learned.
Alongside this initial target, ISOSCAN also intends promote and support applied
research as well as the development of studies, methodologies and projects for the
sustainable development of rural and urban areas. Proposals would be ﬁrst imple-
mented in Cantabria to be then exported to other national or international locations.
This pioneering initiative is differential with respect to other actions by integrating
all the sustainability dimensions (social, economic, environmental and institutional)
510
J. M. Diaz-Sarachaga
in solving problems with a direct impact on people under the collaboration of public
institutions and using scientiﬁc method as primary tool.
ISOSCAN posed the following lines of action:
• Implementation of the 2030 Agenda/Urban Agenda in cities.
• Application of intelligent solutions (‘Smart Cities’) in sustainable urban develop-
ment.
• Enhancement of urban resilience as response to impacts of climate change on
urban development.
• Initiatives to foster sustainable tourism.
• Recovery of deprived rural areas through comprehensive sustainable projects.
• Sustainable integration of renewable energy in rural areas.
• Design of a regional productive plan grounded on principles of sustainability and
circular economy.
• Assistance for the use of corporate sustainability reporting in public companies.
• Training of ofﬁcials on sustainable development.
As illustrated in Fig. 3, ISOSCAN comprises six actors in representation of the
university (Uneatlantico), industry (Hurbannia, Star Project Consulting, Inﬁnia and
InstitutodeIngenieríadelCantábrico)andgovernment(SODERCANastheRegional
Development Agency of Cantabria), shaping the U-I-G Triple helix model.
Hurbannia, an entrepreneurial initiative approved on 27th August 2019 by
SODERCAN, was the foundation stone to launch ISOSCAN. Hurbannia provides
comprehensive consultancy services for the design, application and monitoring of
actions in the ﬁeld of sustainable development for the private sector and public admin-
istrations in order to address issues associated to social, economic, environmental and
institutionaldomains.StarProjectConsultingoffersaportfolioofservicesfocusedon
generating added value among public and private entities in strategic areas, inter alia,
business planning; research, development and innovation; optimization of industrial
Fig. 3 Composition of ISOSCAN building on the U-I-G Triple helix model. Source Author
Integration of the Triple Helix Model in Sustainability Research. …
511
processes; marketing; and risk assessment. Inﬁnia specializes in urban sustainability,
namely through accessibility, mobility and eco-urbanism. Other add-on services are
training, project consultancy, construction technical assistance and audit manage-
mentsystem.InstitutodeIngenieríadelCantábricoisanengineeringandarchitectural
ﬁrm mainly renewable energy facilities and environmental management.
4.3
Project to Revitalize the Most Declining Rural Areas
of Cantabria
Industrialization has hastened the decline of the rural world. Spain has been no
exception to this global trend as evidenced by a paltry demographic density in the
countryside, lower than 3 inhabitants per km2. From a total of 8125 municipalities
in Spain, 5000 have a population under 1000 residents, whilst 1286 house less than
100 persons (Diaz-Sarachaga 2020). A dramatic reduction in the population along
with deindustrialization and economic recession characterize the rural decline as
consequence of the population shift to urban areas, which triggers poverty and social
exclusion (Liu and Li 2017). Rural revitalization accordingly emerges as a compre-
hensive and integrated approach seeking economic growth and the improvement of
living quality.
In this context, a strategy on the scientiﬁc method was suggested employing
a participatory process to revitalize some rural areas of Cantabria at severe risk
of depopulation under a partnership scheme that involves governance, industry and
university (Diaz-Sarachaga 2020). A three-stage methodology was outlined in Fig. 4.
Firstly, some areas of intervention were identiﬁed after conducting an in-depth
cross-sectoral analysis. Three working groups discussed and determined diverse
multidimensional actions in the second phase, to be lastly associated to the SDGs.
Fig. 4 Methodology followed to revitalize some rural areas of Cantabria. Source Diaz-Sarachaga
(2020)
512
J. M. Diaz-Sarachaga
Data provided by the Institute for Statistics of Cantabria (ICANE) from 2005 to
2018 about residents, fertile women, workforce, retired people and immigrant popu-
lation were analyzed in the ﬁrst step. Gross domestic product (GDP) per economic
sector, orography of the terrain and prospective development axes connecting rural
and urban areas were additionally evaluated to discover potential economic activities
to be strengthened, land for agriculture, or development priorities, respectively. No
signiﬁcant variation in GDP per capita was observed for rural areas mostly dedicated
to farming. Among all the municipalities of Cantabria, San Miguel de Aguayo (143)
andPesquera(50)accountedfortheleastnumberofpeopleby2030.Intermsoffertile
women, San Miguel de Aguayo showed the highest rate (33.8%), whilst employable
and ageing people (67 and over) were 60.3 and 22.5%, respectively. Similar ﬁgures
for Pesquera, 10 km from San Miguel de Aguayo. Due to the similarity of the topog-
raphy of the studied municipalities, the cluster Pesquera-San Miguel de Aguayo, near
the city of Torrelavega (51,494 inhabitants), was ﬁnally chosen to foster development
in both communities.
For the second stage, a multidisciplinary panel was shortlisted in pursuit of project
proposals to individually handle social, economic and environmental issues. A group
of four regional entrepreneurs on behalf of farming, meat industry, tourism and food
processing industry were appointed to explore economic opportunities. A maximum
of six persons born and resident in Pesquera or San Miguel de Aguayo, including at
least a woman, analyzed main social questions affecting both villages. Environmental
matters were assessed by a wildlife expert, an environmentalist and a practitioner in
renewables, all currently working in Cantabria.
Workshops and the Delphi technique were combined to coordinate insights from
the working team. Three rounds were undertaken from December 2019 to February
2020. In the ﬁrst one, panelists ascertained priorities and the SDGs considered as
cornerstones of the project. A preliminary list of actions was later agreed to be reﬁned
in the third round.
The proposal recommended 52 actions as shown in Table 3. From a total of
169 SDG Targets, 40 targets tied to 10 SDGs were represented in the action plan.
SDG 8: Decent work and economic growth and SDG 12: Responsible production
and consumption gathered the largest number of related SDG targets, with seven
each. Between two and three actions were associated to SDG 9: Industry, innovation
and infrastructure, SDG 10: Reduced inequalities, SDG 11: Sustainable cities and
communities and SDG 15: Life on Land. SDG 13: Climate action, SDG 16: Peace,
justice and strong institutions, and SDG 17: Partnerships for Goals were featured by
a single action. The four sustainability dimensions were present in the plan. Social
initiatives (17) prevailed over environmental (16), economic (11) and institutional
(8) facets.
With the purpose of consolidating the population of both municipalities, job
creation for 30–50 heads of households, aged from 25 to 40, is expected within
the ﬁrst three years to thus accommodate their families in the area. Immigrant and
vulnerable groups with experience in farming are the preferred workers. Family
reconciliation and female labor are also sought. Ecological crops, organic poultry,
agro-tourism, food processing and e-commerce are the key pillars of the productive

model. Milestones in the third, ﬁfth and tenth years were set in the project schedule.
During the ﬁrst triennium, refurbishment of abandoned homes, land preparation
and construction of facilities should be completed for immediately starting opera-
tion. Cooperative model should serve to manage all businesses. Initial proﬁts were
foreseen in the ﬁfth year to reimburse the funding received at the end of the tenth
year.
Despite the fact that the action plan was principally inspired by the U-I-G helix
model, the U-P-G model is also latent. Whilst Uneatlantico (U) helped to identify
the best organic crops for the selected rural areas and design efﬁcient techniques for
food processing, the regional government (G) through the Agronomy Research and
Education Center of Cantabria (CIFA) contributed to increase agricultural produc-
tivity. Cutting red tape for businesses was an additional support from public admin-
istrations. Enterprises (I) involved in the project developed a feasible business plan
with the participation of local residents (P), who in turn discussed social implications
of the arrival of newcomers to the villages. Unlike existing literature most concerned
about theoretical discussions, ﬁndings showcased how conceptual approaches may
be applied to real cases.
5
Conclusions
This chapter ﬁrst analyzed the Triple Helix Model (THM) of innovation as an efﬁ-
cient instrument of collaboration between university, industry and governance to
foster a research plan on sustainability through the joint consideration of social,
economic, environmental and institutional dimensions. Nevertheless, the THM has
been morphed into further N-helix expressions to accommodate other actors. As part
of the N-helix models, research plays a signiﬁcant role and therefore, it has been later
discussed taking as reference the Sustainability Institute of Cantabria (ISOSCAN), an
entrepreneurial initiative to promote sustainable development in the Spanish region
of Cantabria where major challenges are to be tackled. A cluster of four private
enterprises and one university was proposed to this end.
The following conclusions emerged from the action plan designed to revitalize
the most declining rural areas of Cantabria:
516
J. M. Diaz-Sarachaga
• The application of research methodology has been instrumental in the deﬁnition
of proposals related to social, economic, environmental and institutional domains.
• Partnerships are essential in the search of solutions to major issues.
• The participation of diverse stakeholders in the design of sustainable proposals to
face multidimensional challenges suggests not limiting the application of a certain
N-helix model, but the combination of several models.
• Research activities have room in the use of N-helix models.
• N-helix models may also contribute to the achievement of the Sustainable
Development Goals.
As future line of investigation, the deﬁnition of further helices to complement
existing N-helix models in sustainability research shall be addressed. The implemen-
tation of these models in the promotion of sustainable development is also highly
encouraged.

Scientiﬁc Research as a Driver
of the Sustainable Development Agenda:
A 6-year Study of Dissertations
in a Graduate Program
in Administration at a Brazilian Higher
Education Institution
Franciele Pereira Zazycki, João Gabriel Moreira, Henrique Lapa Lunardi,
Ana Regina de Aguiar Dutra, Robert Samuel Birch,
and José Baltazar Salgueirinho Osório de Andrade Guerra
Abstract Growing public awareness of climate change, social inequality, and
economic uncertainties has driven the demand for more responsible business and
government practices. Global movements have been decisive for countries and orga-
nizationstotakeresponsibilityforthedamagebeingcaused,whilepromotingpolicies
that minimize the future impacts resulting from economic expansion. Essentially, this
is the context in which the Sustainable Development Goals of the United Nations’
2030 Agenda was created. Universities play a fundamental role in this agenda, as
they train professionals, contribute to the development of the regions where they
operate, in addition to being catalysts to produce knowledge and the evolution of
science.
The aim of this chapter is to analyze how the scientiﬁc production of the Graduate
Program in Administration at a Brazilian university is aligned with the Sustainable
Development Goals (SDGs). For this purpose, a qualitative analysis was conducted,

involving the mapping of theses and dissertations from the program, in order to
identify those directly addressing topics related to the SDGs. A qualitative approach,
comprising a mapping of theses and dissertations arising from the Graduate Program,
was used to identify those that address the SDG theme directly. This process was
followed by a categorization and quantiﬁcation of the resulting data to generate
a frequency map and bring visibility to areas of sustainability that are receiving
attention from the academic community. This study brings clarity to which SDGs that
are underrepresented in the Brazilian institution’s scientiﬁc production that indicates
possible gaps in its academic research towards the fulﬁlment of the 2030 Agenda.
Keywords Scientiﬁc research · Higher education institution · Sustainable
development · SDGs · Graduate program in administration
1
Introduction
Increasing public awareness of climate change, social inequality, and economic
uncertainties has led to a greater demand for more responsible practices in gover-
nance. Global movements have played a crucial role in pressuring countries and
organizationstotakeresponsibilityfortheharmcaused,whileencouragingtheimple-
mentation of policies to reduce the future impacts of economic growth. It was in this
context that the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) Agenda emerged. Although
widely debated, it is not a simple task to conceptualize the term “sustainable devel-
opment”. However, a widely accepted deﬁnition is that proposed in the report from
the World Commission on Environment and Development: Our Common Future, of
1987, which deﬁnes it as “the development that meets the needs of the present without
compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs” (WCED
1987, 42). Waage et al. (2010) proposed a revision of the term, the conclusion of
which demonstrated that to achieve sustainability, all communities need to adapt
to new conditions, considering changes in ecosystems and natural limits to growth.
The importance of abandoning an unwanted reality, such as a polluted environment,
promoting a systemic approach instead of focusing only on the symptoms, was high-
lighted in their research. However, as Leal Filho (2011) demonstrated, it is paradox-
ical that even though sustainability is one of the most relevant and important issues
affecting all contemporary society today, the introduction of the 2030 Agenda and
its SDGs was necessary to emphasize the urgency of conducting academic research
that could support the achievement of these goals (UN 2015).
The scientiﬁc research has the role of developing new approaches that are needed
for the examination of the SDGs in seeking a better understanding of their dissem-
ination and achievement of the objectives. As this is a global issue, the concepts of
the SDGs were outlined emphasizing a collective participation of all nations in the
formulation of the goals to ensure ownership and commitment at local and national
levels(Waageetal.(2010).Tothisend,theyhavebeenconceivedinanopenandinclu-
sive process that ensures this national and local implementation while encouraging
Scientiﬁc Research as a Driver of the Sustainable Development Agenda …
523
international partnerships that are in-line with the dynamics of an evolving global
context. The challenge, according to UNESCO (2014), is that the commitments
being implemented require coordinated changes at multiple levels, i.e., in gover-
nance, planning, academic programs, facilities management and ﬁnancial systems,
and a deeper innovation from staff and cross-institutional development are needed
to transform curricula and pedagogy. In this context, Leal Filho et al. (2018) argue
that the SDGs have represented a signiﬁcant opportunity to revive studies related to
sustainable development, especially in universities. Leal Filho et al. (2019) highlight
several areas of study related to sustainable development that have been elevated to
a new level of relevance due to the implementation of the SDGs and the deadline set
to achieve this agenda by 2030 has created a sense of urgency, spurring high-quality
research focused on these goals.
Inthiscontext,highereducationinstitutions(HEIsastheyfocusontrainingprofes-
sionals and generating scientiﬁc knowledge, play a fundamental role in sustainable
development and knowledge about sustainability (Brusca et al. 2018). Mulà (2017)
perceived that promoting this subject at HEI level fosters dissemination amongst
students who, having been educated to perpetuate the cultural assumptions and
professional practices they explore in their studies, will be assuming responsibilities
in society. Supporting Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) is a commit-
ment to reorient students’ learning experiences so that they understand their profes-
sional responsibilities, capacities and personal motivations (Mulà 2017). The expe-
rience of HEI study can offer insights into sustainability, but they avoid the deeper
challenges to unsustainable practices. It is essential then that the actions of indi-
viduals involved in HEI activities are focused on sustainable development research
and extension; one of the pillars in the production, promotion and dissemination of
knowledge and consolidation of sustainable practices (Leal Filho et al. 2015).
The present research deals with sustainability aiming to demonstrate that scien-
tiﬁc research is indispensable for sustainable development. Scientiﬁc investigation
provides a solid foundation of knowledge, tools, and solutions to address the complex
environmental, social, and economic challenges of today. Through research, scien-
tists can better understand the impacts of human activities on the environment and
society, identify patterns and trends, and develop effective strategies to preserve
natural resources, reduce carbon emissions, and promote social equity. Similarly,
academic scientiﬁc research drives technological innovation, enabling the develop-
ment of new technologies, more efﬁcient industrial processes, and sustainable agri-
cultural practices. Without continuous and targeted scientiﬁc research, it would be
difﬁcult to achieve the sustainable development goals set by the global community,
thus compromising the well-being of present and future generations.
Considering the relevance of scientiﬁc research towards the achievement of the
17 SDGs, the aim of this study is to analyze the approach of themes related to
these goals in the dissertations of students studying in the Graduate Program in
Administration, strictosensu, at theUniversityof SouthernSantaCatarina(UNISUL)
in Brazil, over a period of 6 years from 2017 to 2023. This is a sustainability research
project with the following speciﬁc aims: (a) identify which SDGs are receiving
greater or lesser academic dedication, (b) point out gaps in academic research in
524
F. P. Zazycki et al.
relation to sustainable development, (c) give visibility to the impact of scientiﬁc
research towards the fulﬁlment of the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda, (d)
formulate recommendations to increase the contribution of Graduate Program in
Administration (PPGA) to sustainable development in Brazil.
The research was carried out in two stages. The ﬁrst stage consisted of a structured
bibliographic survey, encompassing pertinent studies on scientiﬁc research as a driver
of the sustainable development agenda. To this end, the Knowledge Development
Process-Constructivist (ProKnow-C) software application was used. In the second
stage of the investigation, qualitative research was carried out by mapping the subject
material of dissertations with the aim of identifying those that addressed themes
directly related to the SDGs. After this, a categorization and quantiﬁcation of the
data was carried out with the purpose of generating a frequency map and bringing a
visibility onto which of the SDGs are receiving greater or lesser attention from the
academic community.
The choice of focus on PPGA was justiﬁed because it is the environment where
science is produced for the management of public and private companies, which are
the fundamental institutions for the implementation of effective practices towards
sustainable development. According to Mascena (2013), organizations should seek
to adapt to the new demands and interests of their stakeholders, including approaches
related to social responsibility, sustainability, business ethics, governance and envi-
ronmental management in their strategic planning and corporate income statement
reports. Kiesnere and Baumgartner (2019) state that studies have shown that compa-
nies must integrate sustainability at all levels, areas, and processes, impacting existing
architectures and corporate culture. Such statements reinforce the importance of
research in administration for the evolution of organizations.
As a contribution, this research sought to provide a clear view of the SDGs that
receive less prominence in the HEI’s scientiﬁc production, identifying potential gaps
for the fulﬁlment of the sustainable development agenda. It is intended that this
mapping encourage the academic community to direct the focus of its scientiﬁc
research in order to accelerate the fulﬁlment of all the SDGs.
2
Methodological Procedures
The methodological framework used for this work can be categorized as exploratory-
descriptive research as it seeks to investigate and describe the characteristics of the
scientiﬁc literature speciﬁc to the sustainable development agenda. In doing so, it
deﬁnes a set of articles and their relationships between bibliometric variables. The
process involved a qualitative-quantitative approach that presents the information
in terms of numerical data, using fundamental statistical methods for analysis, espe-
cially in bibliometrics. During the selection phase of articles for the Bibliographic
Portfolio, the approach was qualitative, since it is based on the individual perceptions
and values of the researchers.
Scientiﬁc Research as a Driver of the Sustainable Development Agenda …
525
2.1
Process for Knowledge Development—Constructivist
Intervention Instrument (ProKnow-C)
To carry out a structured bibliographic survey encompassing pertinent studies on
scientiﬁc research as a driver of the sustainable development agenda, Knowledge
Development Process-Constructivist (ProKnow-C) protocol was used as the main
search instrument. This protocol requires the researcher to select a bibliographic port-
folio within the area of interest, with due consideration to the established delimiters,
so that the articles included in a portfolio have scientiﬁc recognition and are aligned
with the theme of the research (Ensslin et al. 2020). The ﬂowchart of the ProKnow-C
architecture showing the various analytical stages of its application comprising four
distinct phases: (a) selection of a portfolio of articles related to the research topic; (b)
bibliometric analysis of the portfolio; (c) systemic analysis; and (d) deﬁnition of the
research question and objective. For this study, only the ﬁrst phase, the bibliographic
portfolio selection (highlighted in red) was operationalized to select the portfolio of
articles on the research topic. Thus, a portion of the essential knowledge about the
researched topic was acquired (Ensslin et al. 2015; Dutra et al. 2015).
During this stage, the following procedures were performed: (a) the collection
of articles in the databases that form the initial set of articles; (b) an evaluation
and ﬁltering of the collected articles according to the research theme; and (c) the
veriﬁcation of the representativeness of the bibliographic portfolio, involving the
selection and analysis of the bibliographic references of the articles present in it
(Ensslin et al.2010). To begin the process of selecting the initial set of articles it was
necessary to establish the research axes and keywords. This implied a deﬁnition of
the areas of knowledge pertinent to the research, as illustrated in Table 1.
The Boolean expression resulting from the intersection of the sets of keywords
from each axis (areas of knowledge) was created to represent the speciﬁc part of the
literature delimited by the researchers and was used in the search for publications in
Table 1 Deﬁnition of research axes and keywords. Source: Authors (2024)
526
F. P. Zazycki et al.
the databases. The next stage dealt with the selection of the databases in which the
scientiﬁc articles were searched. For the present study, two databases were searched:
Scopus, resulting in 192 articles, and Web of Science, resulting in 151 articles. These
databases were selected with a view to the possibility of access through the Portal
of Journals of the Coordination for the Improvement of Higher Education Personnel
(CAPES), the alignment with the research proposal and its importance around knowl-
edge. After completing the identiﬁcation of the areas of knowledge, the keywords
and the databases to be consulted, the process of selecting the scientiﬁc articles to
compile the raw bibliographic portfolio could be carried out. The procedures for this
selection were carried out in December 2023 using combinations of the keywords
deﬁned by each research axis while restricting the search to the article titles. Criteria
were established to restrict the results to the time window of 6 years from 2017 to
2022.
After searching the named databases, a total of 343 articles were obtained as search
results, which were exported to the reference management software, Endnote, for
ﬁltering and selection of the bibliographic portfolio. According to the ProKnow-C
protocol, the process of ﬁltering the raw bibliographic portfolio (shown in Fig. 1)
took various aspects into account such as: (i) the presence of repeated/redundant
articles; (ii) the alignment of the titles of the articles with the theme; (iii) the scientiﬁc
recognition of articles; (iv) the alignment of the abstracts with the theme and (v) the
availability of the full articles in the databases. As the objective of the study was to
gather only relevant articles aligned with the theme, the ﬁrst ﬁlter was to check for
duplicate/redundant references which excluded 109 articles, thus leaving 234 articles
for analysis regarding the alignment of titles. After eliminating the duplicates, the
titles of the articles were read and analyzed, and those in which the researchers did
not identify an alignment with the area of knowledge studied were excluded from
the process. This left 70 articles aligned with the research theme.
After applying these levels of the ﬁlter, the next step was to carry out the analyses
for scientiﬁc recognition. In this research, relevance and scientiﬁc recognition were
characterized by the number of citations received by articles in Google Scholar. As
Fig. 1 Summary of the process for ﬁltering the bibliographic portfolio Source Authors (2024)
Scientiﬁc Research as a Driver of the Sustainable Development Agenda …
527
a convention to determine the relevant articles, the set of articles that represented
90% of the total citations were selected, resulting in 27 articles, being conﬁrmed
as having scientiﬁc relevance. In this way, a Repository K was formed (a bank of
non-repeated articles, aligned title and scientiﬁc recognition). After this, the abstracts
of the 27 articles in this repository were read which resulted in the ﬁnal 23 articles
being identiﬁed as aligning with the proposed research theme and stored in the
ﬁnal Repository A. According to the ProKnow-C protocol, the last stage of analysis
was a representativeness veriﬁcation test which aimed to analyze the bibliographic
references cited in the primary articles of the bibliographic portfolio. This ﬁltering
process did not result in the identiﬁcation of new articles adhering to the theme.
Thus, these 23 articles remained as the primary articles and closed the selection
process of the bibliographic portfolio. This constituted the theoretical portion of the
research to identify and compile a bibliographic portfolio for the theme according to
the perception and delimiters of the research.
2.2
Procedure for Data Collection and Analysis
of the Dissertations of the Graduate Program
in Administration (PPGA)
Following the identiﬁcation and selection of the bibliographic portfolio, the method-
ology advanced to a mapping and analysis stage of the dissertations of the PPGA of
UNISUL. This mapping process was carried out through a survey of the University
Repository of Ânima (RUNA) and treating its contents in two stages using a research
tooldevelopedbythePolytechnicInstituteofTurin(Italy)andareading/classiﬁcation
process carried out by the group of researchers. Subsequently, the extracted data were
consolidated into Excel tables and graphs which facilitated an analysis of the results
and correlation with the bibliographic references in the portfolio. Figure 2 illustrates
the procedure adopted by the researchers in this phase which was divided into four
parts.
– Datacollection:ThedissertationswereﬁlteredfromtheÂnimaUniversityRepos-
itory (RUNA), which aims to manage the intellectual production of the university,
maximise its visibility, use, and impact of its production in the community. RUNA
uses the freeware, Dspace, for data management (see the link https://repositorio.
animaeducacao.com.br/handle/ANIMA/2859).Forthisstudy,thefollowingﬁlters
were applied: UNISUL > Theses and Dissertations > Graduate Program in Busi-
ness Administration > By date of publication. When consulting the results, the
downloaded PDF ﬁles in a drive were shared exclusively among the researchers
for the organisation of the research ﬁles. After this data collection process, the
dissertations were subjected to a ﬁnal reading to ensure their adherence to the
research theme and eliminate any duplication in the database. This resulted in
112 dissertations being identiﬁed between 2017 and 2022. Considering the distri-
bution of the volume of dissertations per year, 19 papers were published in 2017,
528
F. P. Zazycki et al.
Fig. 2 Data collection and analysis structure Source Authors (2024)
13 in 2018, 21 in 2021, 29 in 2020, 25 in 2021 and 5 in 2022, as shown in the
graph in Fig. 3.
– Data treatment: After surveying the dissertations in RUNA, the abstracts were
inserted into the Polytechnic Institute of Turin’s research tool to identify which
SDGs were present in a text via a cross-reference between keywords obtained
in the goals of each SDG. To clarify the procedure, Fig. 4 shows screenshot of
spreadsheet where the information is entered comprising the title of the text,
abstract, author(s), year of publication, main theme of the text, type of publica-
tion (Journal/Book title), presentation of the text at conference and the Digital
Object Identiﬁer (DOI). From the completion of the information, the spreadsheet

Fig. 4 Example of using the Polytechnic Institute of Turin’s research tool Source Authors (2023)
presents the results automatically providing a “YES” or “NO” in the respective

The application of the Polytechnic Institute of Turin’s research tool identiﬁed
that 36 of the 112 dissertations analyzed mentioned topics related to the 17 SDGs
or to the theme of sustainable development in a more comprehensive way (“cross
keywords”). To exhaust the analysis, the abstracts of the dissertations were read to
deepen the understanding of the topics studied. From this, it was observed that 42
more dissertations dealt with content aligned with the SDGs. These results were
included in the spreadsheet and classiﬁed according to the SDG represented in the
theme. As a result, among the 112 dissertations of the PPGA published between 2017
and 2022, 78 were found to be linked to themes adhering to the SDGs, and 34 have
no correlation with the theme.
– Data consolidation: The data from the spreadsheet produced in the second step
of the analysis were submitted to a triple check to ensure the validity of the
obtained information. After this check, the collected data were reworked into
several spreadsheets and graphs, to increase the visibility and understanding of
the ﬁndings.
– Data analysis: The consolidated results were analyzed and correlated with the
bibliometric research process carried out previously.
3
Results and Discussion
The development of an individual as part of an ever-evolving society naturally
requires the need to seek knowledge to keep up with this progress. Unquestionably,
a university stands out as one of several contributors to personal and social growth
(Goebel and Miura 2004). Through a continuous ﬂow of shared information, a univer-
sity offers a degree and specialization that is critical, reﬂective and ethical, based on
the inseparable link between teaching, research and extension. Andrade et al. (2003)
suggest that, although there are several conceptual approaches, the term ‘Univer-
sity’ can be broadly deﬁned as an extensive network of scientiﬁc-academic-social
communication and experience, interconnected through the sharing of information
530
F. P. Zazycki et al.
that, individually or collectively, aggregates to generate applicable knowledge. As
mentioned, the uniqueness of HEIs is closely linked to other areas and contributes
signiﬁcantly to their own value, in addition to enriching the community, preserving
the environment and boosting economically not only the region in which they are
located, but also their surroundings.
According to Findler et al. (2019), HEIs not only act as catalysts for the production
of innovative knowledge and the advancement of science but also serve as organi-
zations that foster a positive impact on the development of the regions in which
they are situated. Also, universities have inﬂuence in the formulation of sustainable
policies and in the research and development of solutions on the subject (Lozano
et al. 2015). In view of this reality, this work ﬁrst sought to analyse the published
academic scientiﬁc literature and present an external overview that demonstrates
the relevance of the theme behind the aims and objectives of this research. For this
purpose, using a methodology based on the ProcKnow-C analysis application and
using a time window of six years, it was possible to deﬁne a bibliographic portfolio
that supports the relationship to the subject of SDGs in scientiﬁc research. Further
analysis of the RUNA repository valorised the SDGs in the choice of themes of the
dissertations of the PPGA at UNISUL. In the last 6 years, the institution had 112
stricto sensu dissertations published, 78 of which were identiﬁed as being linked to
themes adhering to the SDGs, corresponding to 70% of the total publications of the
program.
As for the distribution of dissertations in the timeline (as shown in Fig. 5), the
highest number was published in 2020 (29 dissertations), followed by 2021 (25
documents). The year with the lowest number of publications was 2022, with only 5
publications being made. This result is justiﬁed because these are works by master’s
degree graduates who enrolled in the course in 2020, the year in which the Covid-
19 pandemic peaked, resulting in a low number of freshmen entering courses. The
frequency of publications of studies on topics related to the SDGs follows the curve
of the overall number of publications, corresponding to 70% adherence in relation
to the total. The year 2019 stands out, with a percentage of 85% of the dissertations
with themes that contributed to sustainable development.
The high frequency of studies focused on topics related to the SDGs in manage-
ment research demonstrates that it is a strategic dimension for companies to drive
long-term growth and proﬁtability, as well as a contribution to the market or commu-
nity in which they operate. Stubbs and Cocklin (2008) point out that organizations
that aspire to ensure a sustainable focus in their business models must build an entire
ecosystem around the theme. To this end, they need to develop internal structural
and cultural capacities, internalizing management principles for sustainability and
encouraging their stakeholders, throughout their value chain, to incorporate strategies
and practices in the ﬁeld of sustainability.
Kiesnere and Baumgartner (2019) emphasize that studies have shown that compa-
nies must integrate sustainability at all levels, areas, and processes, impacting existing
architectures and corporate culture. In their research, they considered three topics that
would inﬂuence the internalization of sustainability in an organization’s culture: (i)
agents of change and motivation; (ii) drivers and results; and (iii) issues of integrating
Scientiﬁc Research as a Driver of the Sustainable Development Agenda …
531
Fig. 5 Dissertations of the Graduate Program in Administration/PPGA Source Authors (2024)
sustainability into the organization. Bhowmik et al. (2018) add that, for sustainable
development, Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) are strategic through the dimen-
sions of education, research, extension, and management. In view of this ﬁnding,
it can be said that research in management plays a crucial role in the evolution of
organizations, the market and society.
Despite the evident relevance of research for economic and social advancement,
this investigation observed that the proportion of dissertations related to the SDGs
remainshighbutstablecomparedtothetotalnumberofpublishedworks.Considering
the merit of the theme, it would be worthwhile for HEIs to invest in increasing the
percentage of research on the SDGs. One way to do this would be to expand the
efforts of HEIs in internalizing the culture of sustainability, which would accelerate
progress in research on the topic and, consequently, contribute to actions towards
achieving the 2030 agenda. In this sense, Serra et al. (2018) reinforce that research
produced in HEIs is essential for building innovative knowledge. The authors also
warn that for scientiﬁc advancement to effectively contribute to regional growth, it is
necessary for companies to have access to and utilize the results of scientiﬁc research
in their practices.
One of the most traditional ways of accessing research from HEIs is through phys-
ical libraries and digital repositories, where investigations are made available to the
academic community and other interested parties. Moreno et al. (2022) reinforce that
libraries play a signiﬁcant role in promoting sustainability, as they directly contribute
to the teaching and learning process, besides being institutions aware of their respon-
sibilities to society. The authors also mention that to consolidate the sustainability
approach in people’s and organizations’ daily lives, awareness and applicability are
necessary.
532
F. P. Zazycki et al.
Taking into account the insights provided by the aforementioned scholars, it
becomes evident that sustainability research could attract more engagement from
researchers through a coordinated effort by HEIs to enhance the dissemination
and accessibility of research ﬁndings. This effort should aim to reach not only the
academic community but also public and private organizations within the community.
As emphasized by Seraﬁni et al. (2022), higher education institutions play a pivotal
role in advancing sustainable development goals. However, achieving this requires
a comprehensive integration of these goals into various aspects of their operations,
including management, education, research, and outreach efforts.
Regarding the focus and volume of research, Bauer et al. (2021) emphasize the
importance of the role of university management, as leaders have the autonomy to
steer scientiﬁc research and teaching towards initiatives necessary to address local
and global challenges. In the same vein, Giesenbauer and Müller-Christ (2020) high-
light that effective governance can manage scientiﬁc resources from various sources,
leading to actions that address complex real-world problems, such as those outlined
in the Sustainable Development Goals. In addition to the visibility on the volume
of dissertations aligned with the SDGs, this research also generated a map of the
frequency in which themes related to the SDGs appeared in the studies, as shown in
Fig. 6.
Figure 7 is a representation of Fig. 6, categorizing the frequency of mention of
the SDGs in the dissertations of the Graduate Program in Administration (PPGA) at
different levels.
Fig. 6 Frequency of SDG in Dissertations Source Authors (2024)

Fig. 7 Frequency level of mention of the SDGs in dissertations Source Adapted from Sustainable
Development Goals Report. Special Edition/UN, 2023
Considering the object of study, it was possible to ﬁnd 117 mentions of themes
converging with the SDGs. In 21 citations, more generic expressions were visu-
alized, such as “2030 Agenda”, “sustainable development goals” or “sustainabil-
ity”. Also with 21 appearances, SDG 16 was the most observed. As it is about
“Promoting peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, providing
access to justice for all and building effective, accountable and inclusive institutions
at all levels”, the theme has a lot of adherence to the research themes chosen by the
master’s students in Administration, who researched subjects related to management
models, governance, performance and social innovation, with a view to improving
the community impacted by the public and private companies investigated.
SDG 4 (Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong
learning opportunities for all) emerged in 16 mentions, reinforcing the relevance that
the academic community has on sustainable development. According to Jarchow
et al. (2018), research plays a strategic role in student engagement where institutions
should direct sustainability investments towards leveraging this area. Despite having
high relevance and a high frequency of publications in this study, SDG 4 still lacks
encouragement in research and actions, as it exhibits one of the most unsatisfactory
performances according to the results presented in the Sustainable Development
Goals Report Special Edition, 2023.
The third most observed SDG in the dissertations was SDG 9, “Build resilient
infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization, and foster inno-
vation”. This occurrence is related to the fact that the region where the university
is located is considered an innovation hub in the country and, therefore, the inves-
tigated entrepreneurs are attentive to the creation of more inclusive and sustainable
processes.
534
F. P. Zazycki et al.
SDGs with low occurrence in the PPGA studies (from 2017 to 2022), are SDGs
2 (Zero hunger and sustainable agriculture), 5 (Gender equality) and 6 (Clean water
and sanitation), with only 1 occurrence of each of these in the dissertations. The
contents related to SDGs 13 (Action against global climate change), 14 (Life below
water) and 15 (Life on land) were not identiﬁed in any PPGA dissertation while SDG
10 (Reduce inequality within and between countries) occurs only twice. At the stage
of reading these texts, it was possible to verify that these studies selected objects of
local or regional interest, which may have had an impact on the absence of the themes
mentioned above, since they are more relevant and understood as global indicators.
The research gap on the SDGs 2, 5, 6, 10, 13, 14, and 15 has been identiﬁed in
this study, prompting reﬂection on actions to address this scarcity. One possibility
mentioned in the literature is the clear direction of university leadership towards
incentivizing research on SDGs, following the example of how research efforts
were directed during the COVID-19 pandemic (Leal Filho et al. 2022). During this
period, university administrators kept research active and prominent, which propelled
scientiﬁc knowledge to tackle the challenges of the moment.
According to the Sustainable Development Goals Report 2023 (UN, 2023),
humanity’s ability to use science, technology, and innovation to address crises
in transformative ways and promote the public good became evident during the
pandemic. Thus, the strategies that were effective can be replicated to achieve the
goals of the 2030 Agenda. One of the catalysts was the increase in ﬁnancial invest-
ments in research. According to the report, global expenditures on research and
development as a proportion of GDP increased from 1.69 percent in 2015 to 1.93
percent in 2020, and the number of researchers per million inhabitants increased
from 1,160 in 2015 to 1,342 in 2020. Therefore, it recommends the development of
effective policies to stimulate investment in research and to increase the number of
researchers in sustainable development, especially in developing economies.
In addition to resulting in a clear map of the frequency of research by SDG, this
study found that many research projects deal with themes relevant to the SDGs,
however, they do not directly cite them. This fact points to the still evident need
for greater understanding of sustainability concepts and the 2030 agenda within the
university environment. A study conducted at a university in the southern region
of Brazil (Gazzoni et al. 2018) found that sustainable development is not yet fully
integrated among staff, in terms of understanding the concepts of the theme, being
informed about the institution’s projects, as well as practicing behaviors aligned
with sustainability in their routine. On this, Kolb et al. (2017) emphasize the impor-
tance of training university workers so that they develop the necessary competen-
cies for effective support of the campus’s research and teaching practices towards
sustainability.
Ribeiro et al. (2021) warn that the basic concepts and principles of sustainability
are still misunderstood or understood superﬁcially, even among an educated popu-
lation. This ﬁnding was the result of their research with students from HEIs in Santa
Catarina, Brazil, including UNISUL (i.e., the object of this study), which may also
explain the fact that many dissertations discuss topics intrinsic to the achievement
of the SDG goals, but without mentioning the SDG itself. These same authors found
Scientiﬁc Research as a Driver of the Sustainable Development Agenda …
535
that HEIs are involved in building knowledge and increasing awareness of sustain-
able development, identifying that research is the most effective tool for this purpose.
In view of this statement, and considering the results found, this study generated a
set of recommendations for HEIs, that are aimed at that their Graduate Programs
contributing exponentially to the achievement of the SDGs.
One of the recommendations is to provide training and ensure clear, in-depth and
accessible information to all audiences of HEIs about the SDGs and the impacts that
each of these can generate individually. Regarding raising awareness and dissemi-
nating information on sustainable issues, HEIs have the capacity to integrate sustain-
ability related content into their academic programs, carry out awareness campaigns,
and use their communication channels, such as websites and social networks, to
disseminate good practices and pertinent information (Leal Filho et al. 2023).
Far beyond communication, it is recommended that HEIs develop strategic plan-
ning, with the consequent establishment of tangible goals and performance indi-
cators. Performance measurement promotes a detailed assessment of the progress
made against each SDG and allows the identiﬁcation of gaps for action. In addi-
tion to establishing indicators, the transparent disclosure of results allows all those
involved to contribute to the implementation of future actions and investments. It also
gives visibility to the themes that require greater incentive to carry out research and
interventions, with the purpose of directing efforts. For the governance of this recom-
mendation, it is pertinent to consider the suggestions of key factors by Abubakar et al.
(2020), which are: (i) the development of a clear vision, policy, and strategic plan for
sustainability for the respective HEI; (ii) the implementation of SD goals in research,
education, outreach, partnerships, and campus operations.
Another recommendation is the integration between researchers from different
graduate programs. This action encourages multidisciplinary research and projects
focused on the SDGs, under the maxim that collaboration provides the exchange of
knowledge, resources and experiences, thus expanding the impact and contribution to
sustainabledevelopment.Similarly,itisrecommendedtopromoteknowledgebeyond
national barriers, through international partnerships with educational and research
institutions around the world, in order to share good practices related to the SDGs.
The internationalization of the program and research stimulates interdisciplinarity
and multidisciplinary working. Collaboration between different areas of knowledge
and multiple regions is essential to address the complexity of socio-environmental
challenges. HEIs should encourage interaction between researchers and students
from diverse disciplines, creating an environment conducive to the exchange of ideas
and the development of integrated solutions. Another suggestion is to encourage the
engagementofexternalstakeholders,involvingcivilsocietyorganizations,theprivate
sector, governments, and local communities in research activities, which can broaden
the reach of initiatives and ensure a more comprehensive and inclusive approach.
In their study, Fuchs et al. (2023) also recommend the establishment of part-
nerships between HEIs, the local community, and the private and public sectors in
a collective effort for sustainable development. The scholars highlight the need to
disseminate scientiﬁc knowledge on SD beyond the classroom and assign to HEIs
the responsibility of promoting spaces and tools for this purpose. Giesenbauer and
536
F. P. Zazycki et al.
Müller-Christ (2020) emphasize the importance of leadership in providing platforms
that allow for co-creation and collaboration among faculties and knowledge areas,
thus broadening the impact of their initiatives.
It is recommended to strengthen the institutional commitment of the HEI and the
graduate programs to the SDGs by establishing a clear and comprehensive commit-
menttotheSDGs.Thismeansaligningtheirmissions,visionsandstrategicplanswith
the principles and goals of the 2030 agenda and involves integrating the SDGs into the
developmentplansoftheinstitutionanditsprogramstoensureresearch,teaching,and
extension activities are aligned with these goals. To leverage the chances of success,
an effective management process must be the compass towards more sustainable
universities and societies. Finally, according to Seraﬁni et al. (2022), this theme will
receive more attention in research agendas as guides are published that encourage
dialogues on how universities are stages for the generation of knowledge and practical
experience of guidelines for sustainable development.
4
Conclusion
Growing awareness of climate change, social inequality, and economic uncertainties
has driven greater demand for more ethical and sustainable business and government
practices. Global movements have played a crucial role in pressuring countries and
organizations to take responsibility for the damage caused, while advocating policies
that reduce the future impacts resulting from economic growth. This context was
fundamental for the creation of the SDGs Agenda.
In this context, HEIs play a fundamental role, as they are organizations that
generate a positive impact on the development of the regions where they are located,
in addition to being catalysts to produce innovative knowledge and the evolution
of science. In addition, HEIs also have inﬂuence in the formulation of sustainable
policies and in the research and development of solutions on the subject. Consid-
ering this social function of HEIs and the relevance of scientiﬁc research towards
the achievement of sustainable development goals, this study aimed to analyze the
approach of themes related to the 17 SDGs of the United Nations in the dissertations
of the Graduate Program in Administration, stricto sensu, of a Brazilian university,
in a period of 6 years (from 2017 to 2023).
As speciﬁc aims, it was sought to (a) identify which SDGs are receiving greater
or lesser academic dedication, (b) point out gaps in academic research in relation
to sustainable development, (c) give visibility to the impact of scientiﬁc research
towards the fulﬁlment of the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda, (d) formulate
recommendations to increase the contribution of PPGA to sustainable development
in Brazil. These aims were addressed in the “Results and Discussion” section, where
it was possible to observe the solid research work conducted, adding relevance to
this chapter. Thus, the main objective of this chapter of the book, to analyze how
the scientiﬁc production of the Graduate Program in Administration at a Brazilian
university aligns with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), was achieved.
Scientiﬁc Research as a Driver of the Sustainable Development Agenda …
537
Initially, exploratory-descriptive research was carried out for the construction of
a theoretical framework, using the Knowledge Development Process-Constructivist
(ProKnow-C) tool as a method for the investigation of the theme. After searching the
named databases, a total of 343 articles were obtained as search results, which were
exported to the reference management software Endnote for ﬁltering and selection
of the bibliographic portfolio. In the process of ﬁltering raw articles (Fig. 2). This
resulted in a ﬁnal bibliographic portfolio of 2 articles. In a second stage employed
a qualitative research process to create a map of the theses and dissertations of the
stricto sensu programs at UNISUL that aimed to identify which of them address
themes directly related to the SDGs so that, after categorization and quantiﬁcation
of the data, it became possible to create a frequency map and bring visibility to the
areas of sustainability that are receiving more academic attention. In all, 112 (one
hundred and twelve) dissertations were analyzed, where it was possible to observe
that the most cited SDGs were 16, 4 and 9. The SDGs with the lowest representation
were 13, 14 and 15, which were not mentioned in any of the dissertations. However,
it can be considered that SDGs 2, 5, 6 and 10 also represent gaps, as they received
only 1 or 2 mentions.
As a contribution, the study brought clarity about the SDGs that are underrep-
resented in the institution’s scientiﬁc production, pointing out gaps in academic
researchtowardsthefulﬁlmentoftheSustainableDevelopmentAgenda.Theresearch
offered signiﬁcant contributions to the literature by describing the current situation
of the PPGA, about the integration of the dimensions of social innovations and
sustainable development aligned with the United Nations 2030 Agenda. In addition,
this work developed a strategic map on how this program of work has addressed
these issues, as well as the current stage of promoting sustainability through its
research. Another relevant contribution was the analysis of the recommendations
to enhance the contribution of a HEI and the PPGA to sustainable development in
Brazil. This analysis focused on the communication of each of the 17 SDGs showing
that, although the HEIs may demonstrate a certain degree of commitment to these
goals, not all of them explicitly mention the corresponding SDGs.
It was observed that the works ﬁltered in the bibliographic research present a
literature review for subjects that deal with the SDGs in education, without any of
them proposing to make the list of the SDGs, as the objective of this work. This
is a suggestion that can be applied to future work, giving visibility to the demands
of research in graduate programs. A difﬁculty encountered in the methodological
was the limitation of the tool for identifying the SDGs, which can be attributed to a
restricted number of keywords, the exclusive use of words instead of sentences, or
even cultural adequacy. To ensure the validity of the results and, since it is based on
using a research instrument developed in Italy, all dissertations were submitted to a
reading of the contents. This enabled the understanding of which texts really had a
connection with the SDGs. This fact made it possible to discover that there is still a
demand for the development of a more assertive tool for identifying the SDGs in the
texts.
A shortcoming of this study was the restriction to only one |Graduate Program in
Administration at a university, which restricts the results to a local reality. This gap
also presents a good opportunity for future research, including a greater number of
programs, universities and regions, generating a broader map and encouraging work
538
F. P. Zazycki et al.
with a greater multidisciplinary approach and breadth, which is more aligned with
the complexity of the theme of sustainable development.
Finally, the differential of this work is the applicability of its results, as they were
presented to the leadership of the university and the Graduate Program in Adminis-
tration, generating awareness and commitment to the implementation a management
process and monitoring of the evolution of research, towards the fulﬁlment of the
SDGs.

Co-Creation and Participatory Research:
Climate Assemblies in Schools
as a Means to Sustainability Transitions
Anna Boqué-Ciurana, Gisela Cebrián, and Jon Xavier Olano
Abstract To promote new ways of life and sustainable social practices, people
and communities must be able to engage in community learning and sustainability
research processes that promote environmental awareness and action, as well as
the acquisition of new sustainability knowledge and competencies. This contribu-
tion presents school climate assemblies, conceived as a co-creation and participa-
tory sustainability research practical approach. School climate assemblies are inno-
vative democratic processes to learn, deliberate, make decisions, and seek solu-
tions for change climate and local and regional sustainability. Thus, climate assem-
blies are understood as a new form of participatory sustainability research that can
contribute to the co-creation of climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies
within educational communities and the development of sustainability competen-
cies amongst students, and in turn inﬂuence policy making, through identifying
actions, priorities and indicators for which community learning and action can make
a real contribution to climate change and sustainability. This chapter presents a
practical participatory sustainability research approach, school climate assemblies
designed and implemented within the EDUCLIMAD project, where the theoretical
and methodological conceptualisation and groundings are outlined, including the
key elements, main phases and outcomes in the co-creation of climate change miti-
gation and adaptation strategies and transformative and community learning towards
sustainability.
Keywords Co-creation · Participatory research · School climate assemblies ·
Community learning
