1
Introduction
The crucial importance of education in building a more sustainable, fair, and socially
just society is widely acknowledged by national and international organizations
(European Commission 2022; UNESCO 2005; United Nations 2012). Educational
institutions at all levels, starting from preschool and extending to higher education,
should equip learners with the necessary knowledge, values, and skills related to
sustainability. This preparation is essential for empowering individuals to effectively
address present and future sustainability challenges in a constructive, accountable,
and collaborative manner (Leicht et al. 2018; UNESCO 2017; Wals and Lenglet
2016).
Various regional and global initiatives have aimed to encourage and expand the
integrationofEducationforSustainableDevelopment(ESD)andlearningforsustain-
ability across education systems on a global scale. ESD is rooted in values such as
justice, equity, tolerance, and responsibility, emphasizing collaborative and dialogic
approaches that encompass systemic thinking, critical reﬂection, the utilization of
innovative methodologies, and active and participatory learning processes (Cebrián
and Junyent 2015).
On a global level, it is vital to highlight the United Nations Decade of Education
for Sustainable Development (UNDESD 2005–2014), its subsequent Global Action
Programme (GAP), and the framework entitled “Education for Sustainable Devel-
opment: Towards Achieving the SDGs” (ESD for 2030) (UNESCO 2005, 2014,
2020). The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, adopted by member states
in 2015, introduced 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be achieved by
2030, and reafﬁrmed education’s pivotal role as a fundamental agent for promoting
sustainable lifestyles and cultivating sustainability competencies among individuals
(United Nations 2015). Target 4.7 within SDG 4—Quality Education, underscores
the importance of ensuring that all learners acquire the necessary knowledge and
skills to promote sustainable development. This includes recognizing the relevance
of ESD, sustainable lifestyles, human rights, and global citizenship, among other
aspects (UNESCO 2017). The ESD for 2030 framework has identiﬁed ﬁve priority
action areas to achieve the 17 SDGs and the necessary social transformation, which
encompass policy advancement, learning environments, educator competencies, and
youth and community-based action (UNESCO 2020). This chapter presents a prac-
tical participatory sustainability research approach, school climate assemblies, which
seeks to engage and empower children and youth and their educational communities
in the co-creation of climate change and sustainability solutions.
Furthermore, in recent decades there has been a growing academic interest in
shaping and reﬁning frameworks for sustainability competencies in education. These
competencies are generally understood as a blend of cognitive abilities, practical
skills, and ethical values necessary to develop in citizens the required capacities to
effectively address current and future sustainability challenges (Bianchi et al. 2022;
Brundiers et al. 2021; de Haan 2006). Over time, multiple frameworks for sustain-
ability competencies have been formulated, which coexist among them and also
Co-Creation and Participatory Research: Climate Assemblies …
543
show a general consensus on the essential competencies that facilitate individual
and societal transitions toward sustainability. These include problem-solving, inter-
personal competence, systems thinking, future thinking, action-oriented approaches,
and strategic and value-driven competencies (Brundiers et al. 2021; Shephard et al.
2015; Wiek et al. 2011).
Recent studies on transformative learning for sustainability advocate for devel-
oping more blended and participatory pedagogies involving various actors and
perspectives (Lotz-Sisitka et al. 2015). This entails establishing open and transdis-
ciplinary learning environments (Bürgener and Barth 2018) and exploring the inter-
play and connections between cultural traditions and innovation (Tilbury 2011; Mulà
et al. 2022). Achieving this goal involves linking formal, non-formal, and informal
learning; establishing social learning spaces that address the diversity of values
and ideas; questioning the roles and relationships among educators, learners, and
stakeholders; and reconsidering the teaching and learning methods used to promote
learning for sustainability and ﬁnding appropriate assessments paths. This involves
questioning the conventional learning process and curriculum design and reeval-
uating how sustainability competencies can be most effectively nurtured. In this
context, the literature emphasizes the need for integrating learning with the local
community to instil a sense of environmental connection and involve individuals in
climate change and sustainability initiatives (Green and Somerville 2015; Symons
2008). Active student participation in community learning and action becomes essen-
tial, taking the form of service-learning programs, educational-community projects,
and collaborations facilitated by the active involvement of various stakeholders,
offering and sharing diverse perspectives and knowledge from both within and
outside academia (Anderson and Jacobson 2018; Östman et al. 2019; Taylor et al.
2019; UNESCO 2017). As highlighted in previous research, support from fami-
lies, the community, and local authorities plays a fundamental role in engaging the
students and the entire educational community in sustainability efforts (Evans et al.
2012; Symons 2008).
Establishing a connection between students’ experiences, sustainability issues,
and decision-making processes is vital for fostering transformative learning that
promotes pro-environmental attitudes, behaviours, and choices (Jucker and Mathar
2015). Additionally, there is scientiﬁc evidence suggesting that students and youth
have the potential to act as catalysts for change within their societies, as shown by the
emergence of youth-led social movements advocating for sustainability and climate
action, such as Fridays for Future (Biasutti 2015; Deisenrieder et al. 2020). Conse-
quently, citizen science and community learning have gained prominence as tools
to help advance scientiﬁc research in sustainability. These forms of learning also
enhance public understanding and awareness of climate change and sustainability
challenges while fostering sustainability behaviours and competencies among citi-
zens(Cebriánetal.2020;Fritzetal.2019;Hsuetal.2014).Schoolclimateassemblies
outlined in this chapter are conceived as a form of citizen science and as a prac-
tical participatory sustainability research that engages school students and members
in sustainability learning and the co-creation of climate change and sustainability
solutions that are relevant to their local communities.
544
A. Boqué-Ciurana et al.
Engaging citizens and local communities actively in climate action and sustain-
ability provides unique learning opportunities and contributes to well-being, personal
fulﬁlment, and encouraging more sustainable lifestyles (Leicht et al. 2018). This
active involvement fosters full societal engagement, encourages creativity and inno-
vation, and instigates individual and collective behavioural shifts. It equips citizens
with better information, autonomy, and an active role in addressing social challenges
like climate change, sustainable development, and environmental protection. In turn,
active and community-based approaches can contribute to the achievement of the
green transformation outlined in the United Nations’ 2030 Agenda, the Spanish
Law on Climate Change and Energy Transition (Law 7/2021), the Spanish Strategy
for Decarbonization of the Economy, and the European Green Deal, to attain a
climate-neutral country and continent by 2050. Despite these endeavours, there
remains a limited understanding of the impact of participatory, transformative, and
community-based learning processes that involve diverse stakeholders in collab-
oration co-creating solutions to address climate change and current sustainability
challenges.
In terms of co-creation, Font Barnet et al. (2021) emphasized it as a dynamic,
innovative, and communal process rooted in collaboration among diverse stake-
holders. It aims to achieve consensus on a speciﬁc topic through a collective approach
conducted in focus group settings. The application of co-creation is versatile, span-
ning various economic sectors and serving different objectives. For instance, Vedeld
et al. (2019) utilized co-creation to enhance farmer engagement in weather and
climateservices. Hofstadet al. (2022) orchestratedcollaborativeurbanclimategover-
nance with insights from co-creation experiences in Copenhagen and Oslo. Ziervogel
et al. (2022) advocated for transformative climate adaptation through knowledge co-
creation in South Africa. In alignment with these principles, the conceptualization of
school climate assemblies in the EDUCLIMAD project emerges as a tangible mani-
festation of the commitment to quality education for sustainability and the promotion
of co-creation and participatory sustainability research and learning approaches. The
EDUCLIMAD project (TED2021-129854A-I00) “School Climate Assemblies: co-
creation of climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies and sustainability
competencies’ development”, is an applied research project funded by MICIU/AEI/
10.13039/501100011033 and by the European Union NextGenerationEU/ PRTR.
This project seeks to raise awareness and engage children and youngsters and their
educational communities in sustainability, through school climate assemblies in 25
Primary Schools in the region of Camp de Tarragona (Spain). It encourages innova-
tive democratic processes designed to learn, deliberate and make informed decisions
through climate assemblies, where students search for climate change solutions, and
propose actions to promote sustainability at local and regional levels. This innova-
tive initiative provides a practical sustainability research tool for developing sustain-
ability competencies and empowering the educational community in climate action
and sustainability transitions, which in turn aligns with the global efforts outlined in
the 2030 Agenda, reinforcing the transformative potential of education in creating a
more sustainable and just future.
Co-Creation and Participatory Research: Climate Assemblies …
545
In conclusion, individuals and communities must be empowered to actively partic-
ipate in sustainability research and transformative and community-based learning
processes to instigate novel lifestyles and socially responsible practices. These
processes, as advocated by Brundiers et al. (2021), aim to cultivate environmental
awareness and action while fostering the acquisition of fresh knowledge and skills
in sustainability. The potential of children and youth as catalysts for change within
their societies becomes evident in the rise of youth-led social movements centred on
sustainability and climate change (Biasutti 2015; Deisenrieder et al. 2020). Against
this backdrop, citizen science and community learning have recently become effec-
tive strategies. These approaches advance scientiﬁc research in sustainability and
enhance citizen understanding and awareness of climate change. Simultaneously,
they play a crucial role in nurturing new knowledge and skills in sustainability
(Cebrián et al. 2020; Fritz et al. 2019; Hsu et al. 2014).
This chapter presents a practical participatory sustainability research approach,
school climate assemblies, which allows connecting science with society and action,
and thus promotes sustainability learning and empowerment of school members and
stakeholdergroupstoco-createsustainabilityactionsthatareauthenticandrelevantto
their communities. We present the theoretical and methodological conceptualization
of school climate assemblies (Fig. 1), conceived as a transformative and community
learning process and as an innovative form of participatory sustainability research
that can contribute to the co-creation of climate change mitigation and adaptation
strategies within educational communities and the development of lifelong learning
sustainability competencies amongst students.

2
Co-Creation and Participatory Sustainability Research
The EDUCLIMAD project is based on a Participatory Action Research (PAR)
approach grounded in social and community action, knowledge democratization,
equal participation, empowerment, social justice, and shared ownership. This
methodology provides active engagement opportunities and transforms sustainability
practices (Reason and Bradbury 2008). PAR addresses power dynamics, partic-
ipation, and decision-making (Kemmis and McTaggart 2005). Participatory and
action research are guided by methodological principles like integrating research
and action, collaborative partnerships, viewing participants as co-researchers and
co-learners, maintaining a high level of reﬂexivity, fostering transformative learning,
considering broader political and historical contexts, and starting from an aspira-
tion for social transformation and justice (Carr and Kemmis 2009; Somekh 2006).
PAR empowers all project participants to play active roles as co-researchers and
co-creators of knowledge throughout the design, implementation, and testing of
School Climate Assemblies. Community members and stakeholders engage in the
project and research process, ensuring actions resonate authentically with commu-
nity experiences and needs, considering diverse contexts and realities (Hergenrather
et al. 2009). Ultimately, PAR facilitates the integration of science with society and
aligns action with research, informing the design, implementation, and validation of
School Climate Assemblies through a collaborative and participatory sustainability
research approach with participants rather than merely on participants (Bradbury
Huang 2010).
Stakeholder groups, including primary education students, teachers, families, and
local community members, collaboratively formulate solutions and take actions
to address climate variability and change during School Climate Assemblies.
These efforts are supported by academic and non-academic experts and practi-
tioners specializing in education, climate change, and sustainability. The primary
objective is to enhance a real-world situation or problem—speciﬁcally, addressing
climate change and sustainability challenges in the EDUCLIMAD project. The co-
creation processes within School Climate Assemblies aim to yield evidence-based
research on the development of climate change mitigation and adaptation strate-
gies and sustainability competencies through the implementation of an intervention
sustainability research. Emphasizing reﬂection and action as central elements, the
learning-by-doing process takes precedence (Noffke 2009; Reason and Bradbury
2008).
The impact of School Climate Assemblies is assessed through empirical research
utilizing a mixed-methods approach. Experimental research methods evaluate behav-
ioral, social, and cultural changes, while qualitative inquiry methods, incorporating
participatory processes, provide in-depth insights into individual and collective
sustainability learning and competency development. EDUCLIMAD, an applied
sustainability research project, is designed to actively engage and empower indi-
viduals and communities to address climate change challenges within the Tarragona
Co-Creation and Participatory Research: Climate Assemblies …
547
region at both individual and collective levels. This aligns seamlessly with the imper-
ative for citizen engagement and social innovation, as emphasized in the Spanish Law
on Climate Change and Energy Transition and the EU Green Deal.
Engaging in participatory and action-oriented approaches is crucial for fostering
organizational learning and driving change toward sustainability in private and public
organizations (Doppelt 2010; Dunphy et al. 2007; Molnar and Mulvihill 2003).
Numerous publications have highlighted case studies demonstrating the successful
impact of action research and participatory research in promoting Education for
Sustainable Development (ESD) curriculum development, professional growth, and
organizational learning and change within schools and universities (Cebrián 2018;
Gayford 2003). This underscores the growing recognition within academic research
of the effectiveness of innovative, participatory, collaborative, and action-oriented
sustainability research approaches to explore sustainability and educational change
during the research process (Cebrián et al. 2013, 2015).
The fundamental learning processes integral to ESD promoted through school
climate assemblies and its participatory approach include dialogue and collabora-
tion, learning-by-doing, systems thinking, innovation, and active learning, which
align seamlessly with the principles of participatory and action research approaches
(Cebrián 2018; Tilbury 2011). Action research processes are deemed critical
for fostering the awareness, agency, and collaboration necessary to address the
challenges posed by sustainable development (Ballard 2005).
Utilizing the co-creation methodology proposed by Font Barnet et al. (2021),
our sustainability research approach integrates participatory action research and co-
creation to foster active engagement and shared decision-making. This combination
empowers participants in the school climate assemblies to collaboratively design and
implement adaptation and mitigation actions for pressing environmental concerns,
such as water, energy, tourism, and air quality, contributing to a more inclusive and
impactful process (Fig. 2).
3
School Climate Assemblies: Key Elements and Phases
In the past few years, there has been a notable increase in promoting citizen assem-
blies for climate, seen as progressive democratic mechanisms facilitating learning,
deliberation, informed decision-making, and exploring solutions to tackle climate
change while advancing local and regional sustainability. These assemblies actively
encourage citizen participation, exemplifying innovative approaches to enhance
democratic engagement in pursuing sustainable solutions (Stack and Griessler 2022).
The emergence of climate citizen assemblies underscores their efﬁcacy as inﬂuential
instruments for fostering a more inclusive and participatory democratic process in
the quest for innovative climate change and sustainability solutions, and a form of
citizen science and sustainability research. Citizen assemblies, comprising a diverse
group of individuals who convene to contemplate, discuss, and educate themselves
on a speciﬁc topic, aim to achieve consensus on actions and priorities (Grewin 2018).
548
A. Boqué-Ciurana et al.
Climate assemblies in schools
Environmental 
concerns
Co-creation
Participatory 
Action 
Research
Fig. 2 Elements constituting school climate assemblies
Employed in the United Kingdom (UK) and other nations like Australia, Canada, and
the United States, these assemblies have effectively addressed various intricate social
issues. In recent times, there has been a surge in the utilization of citizen assemblies
speciﬁcally focused on climate-related matters, serving as participatory processes
to enhance broader democratic engagement in seeking solutions to climate change,
driven by the insights of ordinary citizens (Capstick et al. 2020).
Across Europe, national citizen assemblies for climate have been organized in
countries such as Ireland (2016–2018), France (2019–2020), the UK (2020), Scot-
land (2020–2021), Denmark (2020–2021), Germany (2021), Finland (2021), and in
Austria and Spain in 2022 (Stack and Griessler 2022). France and the UK pioneered
the organization of climate citizen assemblies, aiming to amplify citizens’ voices and
involve a broad cross-section of the population in proposing measures and recom-
mendations for addressing climate change nationally (Climate Assembly UK 2020).
In 2021, the Spanish Government initiated its inaugural climate assembly, featuring
the participation of 100 citizens representing the diversity of Spanish society. The
Citizen Assembly for Climate is central in the Declaration on Climate and Environ-
mental Emergency in Spain, embedded in the Law on Climate Change and Energy
Transition. It signiﬁes a novel approach to fortify public participation by facili-
tating knowledge-sharing and identifying and discussing proposals to expedite urgent
responses to climate change.
Co-Creation and Participatory Research: Climate Assemblies …
549
Historically, climate assemblies are high-rank events, and have been predomi-
nantly organized by governments or municipalities. The EDUCLIMAD project seeks
to unlock the innovative possibilities inherent in this tool by tailoring and incorpo-
rating climate assemblies into the school environment documenting the learning
and outcomes derived from this participatory sustainability research process. Unlike
previous approaches, this process is orchestrated by schools and their communities,
taking a bottom-up approach. This contribution introduces the conceptualization of
school climate assemblies by drawing insights from past experiences conducted with
the general public. Stages in the implementation of school climate assemblies involve
the conceptualization of these assemblies as creative democratic procedures. They
aim to facilitate learning, deliberation, decision-making, and the pursuit of solu-
tions for climate variability and change, as well as local and regional sustainability.
Additionally, these stages include the assessment of their impact on environmental
awareness and the cultivation of sustainability competencies.
The progression of school climate assemblies involves a structured sequence
comprising three key stages: learning, deliberation, and decision-making. Facili-
tated by a team of experts, these stages are designed to ensure active participation
and the inclusion of all voices in the process. This approach is informed by the
works of Grewin (2018) and Ferejohn (2008). The typical phases incorporated into a
climateassemblyare:(1)Theinitiallearningstage,termedthelearningphase,encom-
passes preparatory materials and activities. It involves engaging climate change and
sustainability experts, who contribute through presentations, facilitated group discus-
sions, and expert panels or interactive conferences. Collectively, these elements offer
diverse perspectives on the subject matter; (2) The deliberation phase fosters dialogue
and discussion among participants, allowing them to share, co-create, and reﬁne their
perspectives and insights within the assembly. In this stage, experts play the role
of critical friends and facilitators. Various techniques are employed, such as open
plenary sessions, small group activities, active learning approaches, role-playing,
and workshops designed to envision different scenarios; (3) The decision-making
phase entails guiding participants in formulating collective and mutually agreed-
upon conclusions derived from their acquired knowledge, reﬂections, and discussions
during the assembly. The ultimate goal is to generate action plans accompanied by
policy recommendations.
The following diagram (Fig. 3) presents the key elements to consider in organizing
school climate assemblies in each of their three key phases:
The methods and strategies employed in school climate assemblies prioritize
participatory approaches. This involves utilizing tools such as participatory mapping,
envisioning alternative futures through visualization, incorporating artistic elements,
engaging in active learning, implementing role-playing exercises, and utilizing
problem trees (Shared Future 2020).
In the context of the EDUCLIMAD project, the school climate assemblies in the 5
and 6th grades of Primary Education commence with an initial phase involving prior
learning and inquiry on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) within schools.
Following this, the project orchestrates an inaugural session of the school climate
assembly. This session is overseen, facilitated, and guided by a team of university

experts in climate change and sustainability. Each class group is invited to partici-
pate, along with members of the educational community, social and environmental

The inaugural session of the school climate assembly involves several differenti-
ated steps:
1. Learning and Reﬂection Phase: Conceptual maps are crafted within small
groups, highlighting various environmental topics. The objective is to pinpoint
perceived environmental challenges at neighbourhood, municipal, regional, or
provincial levels. Students also explore positive and negative aspects and brain-
storm potential opportunities or actions to address these challenges at individual,
school, neighbourhood, or municipal levels.
2. Deliberation Phase: This stage involves reaching a consensus on the ten priority
actions. The group collaboratively formulates a decalogue outlining these chosen
actions, subsequently sharing them with the entire group.
3. Voting and Individual Prioritization: Participants vote and individually priori-
tize the most signiﬁcant actions. This step aids in determining the actions deemed
most relevant by the assembly members.
Furthermore, in each school participating in the initiative a concluding feedback
session is organised. This session is dedicated to fostering agreements and a wider
consensus among the actions identiﬁed within different class groups. It also entails
assessing and merging the suggested actions and the achieved outcomes, comparing
them across the participating educational centres to subsequently produce a report
with the actions proposed and agreed in the climate assemblies and policy recom-
mendations to be shared with policy makers, the local community and other relevant
stakeholder groups.
The school climate assemblies, organised in Primary Education schools within
the framework of the EDUCLIMAD project offer a methodological approach that
Co-Creation and Participatory Research: Climate Assemblies …
551
directly contributes to providing tangible material for applying, developing, and
exploring the European sustainability competence framework GreenComp within
real educational settings. Recently published by the Joint Research Center (JRC) of
the European Commission (EC), the GreenComp framework (Bianchi et al. 2022)
serves as a competence framework for lifelong learning, emphasizing key sustain-
ability competencies. It includes 12 sustainability competencies across four areas:
embodyingsustainabilityvalues,embracingcomplexityinsustainability,envisioning
sustainable futures, and acting for sustainability. GreenComp is designed to enrich
education programs. Its purpose is to assist learners in cultivating knowledge, skills,
and attitudes that foster thoughtful, empathetic, responsible, and caring approaches
toward the planet and public health.
School climate assemblies emerge as an innovative participatory sustainability
research approach to be implemented within schools and educational communi-
ties, that can help operationalise the GreenComp framework, in which sustainability
competenciesaredeveloped,speciﬁcallythecompetencereferredtocollectiveaction.
This competence focuses on fostering collaborative efforts for change and encour-
aging learners to actively engage in democratic processes, thereby realizing more
sustainable societies.
4
Conclusions
School climate assemblies, a practical participatory sustainability research approach,
allow connecting science with society and action, promote sustainability learning and
empowerment of school members and stakeholder groups to co-create sustainability
actions that are authentic and relevant to their communities. In charting the course
for the EDUCLIMAD project, implementing school climate assemblies emerges
as a transformative endeavour that not only intersects society and primary educa-
tion schools with the academic landscape, but also resonates deeply with the urgent
need for climate action. This methodological approach represents a deliberate stride
towards integrating educational innovation, community engagement and learning,
and sustainability advocacy. By threading together, the complex fabric of local and
regional challenges posed by climate variability and change, this initiative aspires to
be more than a project milestone—it envisions itself as a catalyst for change, echoing
across the educational echelons and radiating into the broader landscape of societal
transformation. As we delve into the methodological intricacies of school climate
assemblies, the following conclusions distil the key insights and implications of this
innovative approach, pointing towards a future where education becomes a dynamic
force in shaping resilient and sustainable communities, and where students can expe-
rience and live sustainability in real world settings. The main conclusions that can
be drawn from the methodological conceptualisation of school climate assembles as
a participatory sustainability research approach are:
552
A. Boqué-Ciurana et al.
• By embracing the anticipated role of these assemblies as innovative educational
tools, the initiative aligns with and addresses through an applied research approach
both the social and scientiﬁc sustainability challenges articulated in signiﬁcant
policies such as the Spanish Law on Climate Change and Energy Transition, the
Spanish Decarbonization Strategy, and the European Green Deal.
• At its core, the implementation of school climate assemblies seeks to delve into
the co-creation and devising strategies and solutions for climate change mitiga-
tion and adaptation by actively engaging primary education students and local
communities in a participatory research process.
• School climate assemblies are conceptualized as bottom-up democratic proce-
dures designed to facilitate learning, deliberation, decision-making, and collabo-
rative problem-solving within the local and regional contexts affected by climate
variability and change.
• School climate assemblies contribute signiﬁcantly to the broader goal of realizing
the Sustainable Development Goals, emphasizing the active participation and
engagement of the school community.
• The methodology proposed fosters sustainability learning experiences and
embodies a community-oriented approach, positioning schools and educational
communities as key agents in driving meaningful climate action within their local
and regional environment.
• Beyond its immediate application, the innovative nature of school climate assem-
blies suggests scalability and adaptability to diverse contexts and educational
phases. This model can be a replicable and impactful strategy for addressing
climate challenges in other regions and countries.
This chapter provides a comprehensive insight into the conceptual and method-
ological sustainability research approach for implementing school climate assem-
blies in primary education schools. In essence, the implementation of school climate
assemblies emerges as a promising initiative, combining educational innovation,
community engagement and learning, and sustainability research for a shared, partic-
ipatory, comprehensive and impactful response to climate change. School climate
assemblies have the potential to foster sustainability learning and the development
of sustainability competences amongst participants, while promoting the co-creation
of climate change and sustainability solutions that are relevant to local communities.

Role of Higher Education Institutions
in Promoting Sustainable Development
Goals Through Research, Teaching
and Outreach
Aline Bento Ambrosio Avelar
and María Luisa Pajuelo-Moreno
Abstract This book chapter explores the role of Higher Education Institutions
(HEIs) in promoting Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through research,
teaching, and outreach. A Systematic Literature Review was conducted by data
collected from databases focusing on relevant peer-reviewed research papers
published between 2018 and October 2023. The study used both qualitative and
quantitative methods, including Descending Hierarchical Classiﬁcation (DHC) and
chi-square inferential statistics. Among the main results are that HEIs foster multidis-
ciplinary collaborations, employ novel research approaches, and facilitate knowledge
dissemination. They equip future professionals with the skills and competencies to
address the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and cultivate students who can
serve as catalysts for change. The chapter also addresses the integration of sustain-
ability principles into teaching practices and curricula, and their efforts to connect
with communities, legislators, and industry stakeholders through outreach activi-
ties. HEIs have the potential to signiﬁcantly impact society, the economy, and the
environment. However, there are gaps in the strategic approach and more research
is needed, especially in developing countries. HEIs can foster a society that values
sustainability, inclusivity, and collective well-being through outreach activities.
1
Introduction
The economic, social, and environmental considerations embedded in the formula-
tion of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) demand an inte-
grated and interconnected approach (García-Feijoo et al. 2020). These goals require
aninterdisciplinaryperspective, whereinall stakeholders—individuals, corporations,

M. L. Pajuelo-Moreno

W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_31
557
558
A. B. A. Avelar and M. L. Pajuelo-Moreno
private and public entities, and governmental bodies—actively assume their respec-
tive responsibilities. In this context, the UN issued a special call for Higher Educa-
tion Institutions (HEIs) to actively promote and support the SDGs in education and
research (Annan-Diab and Molinari 2017).
However, it is important to note that the contributions of HEIs should not be
assessed solely in terms of scientiﬁc production and knowledge creation (Cottafava
et al. 2022), but rather beyond, as HEIs’ contributions should be considered in their
ability to address local grand challenges through collaboration, civic engagement,
and dissemination (Leal Filho et al. 2018). Recognition exists that sustainability in
higher education requires concerted action within the environment and society, with
a long-term and integrated vision based on the principles of human life and the world
in which we live (Leal Filho et al. 2019).
HEIs assume a pivotal role in the attainment of SDGs within society. However, for
their integration into HEIs, they are required to embrace an interdisciplinary approach
(Annan-Diab and Molinari 2017; Avelar et al. 2023) as well as a transdisciplinary
approach(Avelar andFarina2022). This involves advancingsustainabledevelopment
throughtheincorporationofSDGsacrossthethreeprimarymissionsofHEIs,namely,
education, research, and outreach (Avelar et al. 2019).
Therefore, it is expected that HEIs act as “change agents” (Bohunovsky et al.
2023). HEIs are called upon to assume a pivotal role in advancing these objec-
tives, given their signiﬁcance as inﬂuential contributors to the holistic development
of future citizens (Piza et al. 2018). Thus, HEIs have been globally recognized as
important stakeholders within the SDG framework (Leal Filho et al. 2019; Seraﬁni
et al. 2022), occupying a leadership position in guiding education, research, and soci-
etal outreach toward the sustainable development of people and societies (Cottafava
et al. 2022).
In response to this call and armed with the SDGs framework, an increasing
number of HEIs are internalizing SDGs into their strategic thinking, daily opera-
tions, and embracing sustainability as a core value (Cottafava et al. 2022). HEIs
are re-evaluating their teaching and research programs, and even the so-called third
mission (outreach) as part of their navigation toward sustainable development (Fia
et al. 2023). HEIs are taking a multi-faceted approach to align with the 2030 Agenda
and contribute to the SDGs. This includes strategic planning, curriculum develop-
ment, research, partnerships, community engagement, Global Vision, Active Peda-
gogy and Assessment and Training (Fuchs et al. 2023; Fia et al. 2023; Leal Filho
et al. 2023).
Due to the crucial role of HEIs, there has been a proliferation of research in recent
years on this integration with the aim of providing access to information, knowl-
edge, and the dissemination of best institutional practices by HEIs and organizations
(Franco et al. 2019; Alcántara-Rubio et al. 2022). It has been investigated not only
in relation to planning, pedagogy, curricula, and research but also in research on
institutional practices (Annan-Diab and Molinari 2017).
However,ashighlightedbyFiaetal.(2023)afterconductingasystematicliterature
review on the integration of SDGs in HEIs in research, teaching, outreach, and
managing operations, despite the growing literature on the activities that HEIs are
Role of Higher Education Institutions in Promoting Sustainable …
559
undertaking in this regard (Chankseliani and McCowan 2021), on the one hand, the
knowledge base revolves around an array of activities, and there have been only
attempts to synthesize these scholarly resources which makes the literature seem
fragmented. On the other hand, with some exceptions (Seraﬁni et al. 2022; Avelar
et al. 2023; Fia et al. 2023, among others), reviews of this topic have mostly focused
on a single university mission (e.g., teaching and not research) (Alonso-García et al.
2019; Weiss and Barth 2019), with very few focusing on all three missions.
To ﬁll this gap, the present study conducts a comprehensive literature review,
developing a methodology for classifying activities that can facilitate additional
knowledge growth (Fia et al. 2023). Speciﬁcally, we examine the role of HEIs in
advancing SDGs through research, teaching, and outreach. The primary focus is to
analyze existing literature on how the promotion of these missions intricately links
to the SDGs’ Agenda 2030. A systematic literature review will explore how HEIs’
can signiﬁcantly contribute to the SDGs through teaching, research, and outreach.
In this way, we classiﬁed 190 selected papers based on the type of university
activities considered (research, teaching, and outreach). Subsequently, we identiﬁed
the main gaps in the literature and discussed future avenues for addressing HEIs’
role in accomplishing SDGs.
The organizational framework of this chapter comprises ﬁve sections, with the
introductory segment (Sect. 1) articulating the signiﬁcance of conducting mapping
studies that speciﬁcally investigate the contributions of HEIs to the SDGs. Section 2
elucidates the theoretical framework by delineating three primary missions of
HEIs, namely teaching, research, and outreach. Section 3 outlines the methodology
employed for conducting the systematic literature review. Subsequently, Sect. 4
provides an in-depth analysis of the obtained results, while Sect. 5 encapsulates
the concluding remarks.
2
Theoretical Framework
Currently,challengesassociatedwithSDGsareaparamountconcernandsigniﬁcance
for HEIs (Fia et al. 2023; Leal Filho et al. 2023). HEIs have three key missions, which
interrelate and complement each other: teaching, research, and outreach (Avelar et al.
2022a). All these missions are intertwined with sustainable development, playing a
critical role in achieving SDGs (Leal Filho et al. 2019; Avelar and Farina 2022;
Seraﬁni et al. 2022). HEIs are now working to address various sustainability-related
challenges, which are linked to this institutions’ tripartite mission (Cottafava et al.
2022). To achieve effective integration, sustainability must be conveyed through
education, research, and outreach (Avelar et al. 2022b). In this context, HEIs must
walk the talk about SDGs across all these dimensions to achieve a true integration
(Fia et al. 2023).
Since we are going to determine how HEIs integrate the SDGs through teaching,
research, and outreach, we will proceed to brieﬂy deﬁne and highlight some of their
most relevant aspects.
560
A. B. A. Avelar and M. L. Pajuelo-Moreno
2.1
Teaching
Education encompasses curriculum, competencies, teaching methods, and the impli-
cations of the hidden curriculum (Hueske and Pontoppidan 2020, p. 99). Concerns
in teaching include how disciplines are formed, reviewed, and how sustainability is
integrated into curricula through multidisciplinary involvement and interdisciplinary
guidance (Annan-Diab and Molinari 2017; Avelar et al. 2022a, b).
As highlighted by Avelar et al. (2023), within the framework of SDG 4, dedicated
to education, SDG Target 4.7 aims to ensure, by 2030, that all learners acquire
the knowledge and skills essential for promoting sustainable development. This
includes, among other aspects, education for sustainable development (ESD) and
sustainable lifestyles (UN 2015, p. 17). Recognizing that ESD serves as a pivotal
instrument in achieving the SDGs, UNESCO deﬁnes ESD as empowering learners
to make informed decisions and take responsible actions for environmental integrity,
economic viability, and a just society for present and future generations (UNESCO
2017, p. 7).
Therefore, it is imperative for future decision-makers to comprehend the
impending challenges of sustainability (Dyllick 2015). Consequently, ESD directs
individuals to reﬂect on knowledge management and understand the effects and
complexity of behaviors (García-Feijoo et al. 2020).
According to Piza et al. (2018), HEIs play a critical role in preparing future
decision-makers by providing information that contributes to the skills and compe-
tencies necessary to address sustainability challenges in increasingly complex and
global contexts. For them, sustainable HEIs are deﬁned as educational institutions
that offer a clear perspective on how students, professors and administrators can
contribute to sustainability (Piza et al. 2018). HEIs promote the SDGs through
teaching by embedding sustainability into their educational offerings, developing
leadership skills among students, and engaging in partnerships that enhance the
practical application of sustainability principles (Hauser and Ryan 2021; Son-Turan
2021; Obrecht et al. 2022).
To achieve this, higher education institutions (HEIs) must shift their paradigm and
curriculum towards sustainability, transitioning from the economic paradigm to the
humanistic paradigm (Avelar et al. 2023). This entails incorporating the theoretical
foundations of sustainability into courses, fostering critical thinking and decision-
making, and providing opportunities for students to engage with and connect to the
real world (García-Feijoo et al. 2020).
HEIs through the efforts of their educators and institutional initiatives, possess
the capacity to raise students’ awareness regarding the imperative of contributing to
sustainable development (Dyllick 2015). This involves broadening students’ knowl-
edge base and actively involving them in discussions related to sustainability and
SDGs (Leal Filho et al. 2019). Educators, given their inﬂuential positions and exten-
sive reach, wield the potential to serve as catalysts for change. Leveraging their
expertise, skills, and perspectives, educators can actively contribute to transforming
students’ attitudes and behaviors concerning sustainability, with the expectation that
this transformative process will be evident in students’ actions (Avelar et al. 2022a,
b).
Role of Higher Education Institutions in Promoting Sustainable …
561
2.2
Research
The 17 SDGs comprise themes that are aligned with education, research and outreach
(Wersun 2017). Leal Filho et al. (2018) point out that HEIs and their staff should try
to take more advantage of the many opportunities that the SDGs offer, not only with
regard to teaching and research, but especially with regard to their outreach activities
(the so-called “3rd mission”) and act as public defenders in support of the SDGs.
Universities should be ahead of the package, not behind it (p. 294).
HEIs are promoting the SDGs through research by engaging in interdisciplinary
approaches, focusing on problem-solving for societal needs, and aligning their
research specializations with the goals most relevant to their institutional proﬁles
(Pietrzak 2022).
However, while SDGs have inﬂuenced the traditional curricula of HEIs in recent
years, the research motivations and personal attitudes of scholars remain subjects
of individual interactions and are still under investigation (Cottafava et al. 2022).
HEIs´managers can support and guide these interactions through interdisciplinary
approaches, policies and organizational strategies, such as research groups, research
centers, and dedicated budgets (Sonetti et al. 2019). This approach would enable
them to engage the most adept researchers with theoretical knowledge in the service
of public policy, thereby promoting impact or academic engagement (Cottafava
et al. 2022). Furthermore, HEIs can encourage researchers to bridge and synthe-
size various perspectives, thereby cultivating a holistic and systemic approach to
addressing challenges posed by SDGs (Secundo et al. 2020).
The potential of SDGs to mobilize and sustain interest within a HEI necessi-
tates the integration of education, sustainable development, and human development
(Agbedahin 2019). As underscored by Cottafava et al. (2022), if an HEI’s commit-
ment to SDGs is genuine and the organization undergoes transformation, local poli-
cymakers may enhance their decision-making processes regarding local sustainable
development issues by leveraging the expertise of the university’s highly skilled
researchers and up-to-date scientiﬁc knowledge for local interventions (Miotto et al.
2020). Moving beyond the campus, HEIs are poised to become pivotal actors driving
the transition towards sustainability and SDGs (Körfgen et al. 2018; Seraﬁni et al.
2022).
2.3
Outreach
As previously outlined, the UN attributes to HEIs a critical role, especially by
preparing future professionals and leaders and disseminating the wide-ranging
aspects of sustainability (Findler et al. 2019). Leal Filho et al. (2021) emphasize that
another form of contributing to positive change towards sustainability is community
outreach(Berchinetal.2019),i.e.,initiativesbyuniversitiestoengagemutuallybene-
ﬁcially with communities in their regions. Thus, beyond what is known as the “third
562
A. B. A. Avelar and M. L. Pajuelo-Moreno
mission,” sustainability transformations may be supported through cross-sector part-
nerships with diverse local actors in a speciﬁc location, region, or societal sub-sector
(Leal Filho et al. 2021).
So, HEIs, as leaders in education, research, and innovation, play a key role in
social change and promoting SDGs (Blasco et al. 2020). Therefore, HEIs are increas-
ingly cooperating with the community, providing societal impact (Medved and Ursic
2021). The relationship between HEIs and communities can take various forms and
encompasses the different activities of universities, such as research, teaching, and
outreach (Plummer et al. 2022, p. 2), including active partnership activities related
to the operations within the institutional structure of HEIs.
HEIs are increasingly recognizing their role as agents of change and are working
on outreach in various ways. They are seen as key players in introducing and imple-
menting sustainability in a holistic manner, connecting people and including social
and institutional considerations (Longoria et al. 2021). This involves strategies and
tools to promote SDGs among all community members, as their participation is
crucial in deﬁning the full process of research or project development, targeting,
facilitating, and supervising sustainable transformations (Useh 2021).
Therefore, under their capacity as agents of change, HEIs exhibit a public aware-
ness and civic commitment to generating positive impacts in real-life problems and
situations(LealFilhoetal.2021).Thisroleiscrucialatboththelocallevel,generating
positive impacts in their local communities (e.g., Vickers et al. 2017; Unangst and
Crea 2020; Finatto et al. 2023), who analyze the impact of HEIs in addressing refugee
issues), as well as in guiding national and international policies and contributing to
global initiatives like the Agenda 2030 or the SDGs (e.g., Avelar et al. 2022a, b, or
Leal Filho et al. 2021, focusing on the 17 SDGs, or Lange Salvia et al. 2020, focusing
on the energy goal).
However, integrating sustainability and SDGs in all dimensions of HEIs (educa-
tion, research, and outreach) requires a strong sustainable management agenda (Kolb
and Kolb 2017), where both teachers and HEIs need to consider the inﬂuence of the
SDGs in deliberations on incorporating sustainability in these HEIs comprehensively
and interdisciplinarity (Annan-Diab and Molinari 2017), both internally and exter-
nally with reference to activities and programs of action within society (Hueske and
Pontoppidan 2020). In this context, outreach activities come into play, which must
entail collaboration with society (Muff et al. 2017). For this, HEIs must establish
continuous dialogue with their stakeholders (Haertle et al. 2017), promoting innova-
tive pedagogies, outreach projects, and partnerships with them, seeking to increase
entrepreneurship related to SDGs, with a focus on sustainable gains for society rather
than personal and business gains (Avelar et al. 2022a, b).
Outreach on sustainability can be described as universities’ actions “to engage
withthecommunitiesintheirsurroundingsinamutuallybeneﬁcialprocessofsustain-
able development” (Berchin et al. 2019, p. 1), promoting sustainable, inclusive, and
participatory planning (Castro Pena et al. 2017) and providing social engagement
(Mora et al. 2018) and volunteerism (Shiel et al. 2016). Although outreach is not one
of the most discussed roles of universities towards sustainability, these institutions
Role of Higher Education Institutions in Promoting Sustainable …
563
need to acknowledge their mission to contribute to democratic processes within their
campuses and also throughout society (Andrade et al. 2018).
Thus, the implementation of the SDGs through outreach is aligned with sustain-
able management education and includes working with other HEIs, various govern-
ment and business entities, as well as the broader local community, on matters
pertaining to sustainable development (Hueske and Pontoppidan 2020, p. 97),
highlighting the inﬂuence and contribution of universities to society, especially
by preparing future professionals and leaders and disseminating the wide-ranging
aspects of sustainability (Findler et al. 2019).
However, except for papers that speciﬁcally examine the outreach mission, there
is a limited number of papers focusing on it. Seraﬁna et al. (2022) arrived at this
conclusion after conducting a literature review, highlighting that only a small number
of studies analyze the alignment of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) with
outreach projects of Higher Education Institutions (HEIs), and there is a need for
further research in this area. Therefore, it is necessary to delve deeper into the study
of the outreach mission of HEIs, as we will do in this study.
3
Methodology
We conducted a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) to examine the role of HEIs in
promoting SDGs through research, teaching and outreach. SLR allows researchers
to analyze problems in an organized and systematic manner, thus improving the
quality of research results (Jesson et al. 2011). SLR helps researchers identify key
evidence relevant to research questions and ensures transparency (Walker 2010).
This method is considered appropriate in management and allows the researcher to
conduct a comprehensive study by examining a large amount of literature without
partial selection (Booth et al. 2016).
3.1
Data Collection, Review Process and Inclusion Criteria
For data collection, we used the database Scopus and Web of Science to discern rele-
vant patterns in articles appropriate to our research objectives (Jesson et al. 2011). We
chose those databases due to their reliable indexing (Stahlschmidt and Stephen 2020).
We identiﬁed relevant peer-reviewed research papers published in English between
2018 and October 2023, given that 5 years is sufﬁcient to review the publications and
acquire relevant knowledge (Booth et al. 2016). Limit the search to peer-reviewed
articles considered to be of higher quality than other contributions (Jesson et al.
2011). We also focused on the areas of economics, business, management, social
sciences, and education and educational research to ﬁnd articles more relevant to our
focus on Promoting SDG through research, teaching and outreach.
564
A. B. A. Avelar and M. L. Pajuelo-Moreno
We considered the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews
and Meta-analyses) approach: a script designed to improve the quality of systematic
reviews by considering a checklist of multiple validation elements. This method
ﬁrst uses a combination of keywords. The PRISMA statement, published in 2009,
aims to help authors of systematic reviews transparently document the justiﬁcation
of their reviews. This approach aims to improve the quality of systematic reviews
through the use of checklist items. In general, PRISMA performs four important
steps: searching using keywords and appropriate databases, ﬁltering for inclusive
and exclusive features, synthesis by classifying the data, and ﬁnally analysis of the
data that can explain the results of the article (Page et al. 2021).
Then, speciﬁc criteria are applied for (i) identiﬁcation: 181 in Scopus and 171 Web
of Science; (ii) screening: duplicated studies were removed from comparison of the
bases; (iii) eligibility: assessed the articles by carefully sifting through the abstracts,
main content, practices, and outcomes. Finally, 190 articles were considered for
further analysis. After separating the texts, they were imported into the software
Iramuteq 0.7 Alpha 2 (Interface of R for multidimensional analyses of texts and
questionnaires), used for the treatment of qualitative data.
Analyzes were performed using IRAMUTEQ software and both qualitative
and quantitative methods were used. Qualitative methods examine words used in
published papers, while quantitative methods examine the frequency of words and
use chi-square inferential statistics. Descending Hierarchical Classiﬁcation (DHC)
for analyzing the content of text corpora (Reinert 1990). DHC examines text frag-
ments, classiﬁes them according to their respective vocabulary, and presents their
variants as a set of text to be analyzed, thus grouping statistically signiﬁcant words.
The DHC technique uses the method of Reinert (1990), which classiﬁes small text
fragments composed of speciﬁc words whose corresponding attributes are derived
from the respondent’s speech and is obtained from the entire corpus without a priori
information. extracted. Likewise, Reinert’s algorithm segments text into Elementary
Context Units (ECUs) of roughly similar length; these include phrases or phrase
fragments separated by punctuation. The occurrences and co-occurrences of words in
each unit are then examined and the results are formed into a matrix. The occurrence
and co-occurrence of words is the basis for assessing the similarity between the
text segments that constitute their grouping (Retinaud and Marchand 2012). Each
published paper is called an Initial Context Unit (ICU). The text segments that make
up each category are called ECUs and are obtained from the ICU. Each controller is
characterized by a vocabulary that is similar within its class but different from other
classes.
The analysis performed by this software is both qualitative (because it analyzes
words) and quantitative (because it calculates frequencies and performs chi-square
tests). The chi-square value estimates the importance of the association between a
word and the vocabulary used in a speciﬁc part of the text (a chi-square value of 3.84
corresponds to a random probability of association of 0.05%). Often, meaning is
related to the presence of words in a speciﬁc part. However, a form that is frequently
associated with a particular word is rarely associated with the part in which it is
Role of Higher Education Institutions in Promoting Sustainable …
565
least frequently used, even if it occurs more frequently in other parts (Retinaud and
Marchand 2012).
4
Analysis of Results
This subsection presents general information about the 190 studies through analysis
and systematic overview, the characteristics of scientiﬁc production help to determine
how to approach the topic from a temporal perspective. Considering the trends over
time (Table 1), in 2023, the number of HEI publications promoting the SDGs through
research, teaching and promotion increased, with a total of 58 articles published. This
trend in the number of publications has only recently increased, with a sharp increase
in the number of publications from 2018 to 2023.
Regarding journals, International Journal of Sustainability in Higher Education
(21.05%) and Sustainability (17.37%) emerge as the foremost publications, distinctly
surpassing others in the dissemination of articles pertaining to the subject under
examination.
The preponderance of paper authors shares a common country of origin (66.29%),
whereas papers authored by individuals from multiple countries are less scarce
(33.71%), underscoring the imperative to foster international collaboration. More-
over, although many of these works are authored by a single author (11.05%), the
majority of them are conducted collaboratively among multiple authors, primarily
three (21.58%), two (18.95%), four (16.84%), and ﬁve (10.53%), with the remainder
being carried out by numerous authors ranging from six to even fourteen authors
from various countries.
Concerning the countries and regions analyzed, a majority of papers are focused
on a singular country (67.24%), with a minority concurrently investigating multiple
countries (36.76%). While prevailing literature often concentrates on developed
countries, our study reveals a slight prevalence of analyses in developing countries
(39.53% compared to 37.21% in developed countries). A substantial percentage of
studies considers both development levels and conducts comparisons between them
(23.26%). Regarding regions, Europe stands out as the most studied region (33.33%),

followed by Asia (14.12%), Latin America (10.73%), and Africa (10.17%), with
numerous studies conducted at a global level (18.08%).
In terms of methodology, a predominant share of papers employs cross-sectional
approaches (65.70%), with a smaller proportion utilizing longitudinal studies
(31.98%) and a minimal number employing mixed methods approaches (2.33%).
Moreover, a signiﬁcant portion of the studies adopts a qualitative methodology
(43.53%), while a smaller proportion employs a quantitative approach (30%), and
some integrate both methodologies in a complementary manner (26.47%). In the case
of quantitative studies, univariate methodologies are predominantly used, featuring
exploratory and descriptive studies, with limited use of multivariate approaches
(18.24%), primarily regression or PLS-SEM. Lastly, it is noteworthy that the primary
data source is surveys in the majority of papers (56.18%), with minimal reliance on
Higher Education Institutions’ reports for analysis (2.81%).
In Table 2, we have compiled the most cited research papers on Sustainable
Development Goals (SDGs) across the domains of research, teaching, and outreach.
Leal Filho et al. (2019, 2021) focus on integrating the SDGs into higher education
institutions. Therefore, they emphasize the importance of integrating the SDGs into
university curricula and emphasize the need for a framework or model that facilitates
this integration. Vega Avila et al. (2019), Leal Filho et al. (2019) highlighted the
challenges universities face in promoting sustainability, citing barriers such as lack of
planning, limited resources and resistance to change. The focus is on the challenges
faced by institutional academics and staff without delving into the structural and
institutional challenges that prevent universities from effectively implementing the
SDGs.
Alexo et al. (2021), Leal Filho et al. (2019) recognized the importance of student
awareness and engagement in promoting university sustainability and highlighted
that they will be the most important inﬂuencing factors in the future. Franco et al.
(2019),LealFilhoetal.(2019)focusontheneedforastrategicapproachtointegrating
the SDGs into higher education and highlight existing gaps that need to be addressed
to achieve more effective integration.
Lazzarini et al. (2018), Aleixo et al. (2021) conducted an in-depth study of
the performance and engagement of academics and students committed to main-
taining stability, whose papers were suspended for promoting cultural change without
engaging in maintaining stability. Vega Avila et al. (2019), Zamora-Polo et al. (2019)
identiﬁed barriers to innovation and sustainability in higher education that arise
following a disconnect and understanding of SDGs among students and higher educa-
tion professionals. These articles identify barriers to innovation and sustainability
but do not provide in-depth analysis of the causes of these barriers, such as lack
of institutional support, bureaucratic structures, or even systemic issues in higher
education.
The importance of integrating the SDGs into academic curricula across disci-
plines and sectors is underappreciated, highlighting the need for a more holistic and
interconnected approach to sustainability. Our most cited academics have conducted
extensive research on HEI papers without SDGs. Overall, these works provide a

4.1
Descending Hierarchical Classiﬁcation (DHC) of Role
of Higher Education Institutions in Promoting
Sustainable Development Goals Through Research,
Teaching and Outreach
For a deeper understanding of the classiﬁcation and thematic analysis, content anal-
ysis techniques were used. This required a careful review of the title, abstract,
and keywords. This process was facilitated by Iramuteq 0.7 Alpha 2 software,
which is designed for processing qualitative data. By using Descending Hierarchical
Classiﬁcation (DHC), we strive to group words and understand their hierarchical
relationships, generating statistical results that require theoretical interpretation by
researchers.
Role of Higher Education Institutions in Promoting Sustainable …
569
Qualitative methods examine language use in discourse, whereas quantita-
tive methods focus on word frequency and apply chi-square inferential statistical
methods. DHC analyses are used to examine the textual corpus. In particular,
DHC classiﬁes text fragments according to their respective vocabulary, allowing
the identiﬁcation of statistically signiﬁcant word clusters.
The DHC technique is based on Reinert’s (1990) method of segmenting text into
elementary context units (ECUs) and examining the occurrence and co-occurrence of
words within each unit. This process creates a matrix that helps identify meaningful
patterns in the analyzed content.
To understand the approaches/lenses that involve research on role of HEI in
Promoting SDG through research, teaching and outreach, Iramuteq software was
used, which allowed content analysis to be performed to identify different themes
and approaches.
A combination of the title, the keywords, and the summary of the articles was used
for this analysis. A thorough inspection of the results allowed us to group the various
themes into four dominant lenses (classes), namely: (i) Class 1 (28,2%) Outreach;
(ii) Class 2 (21%) Research; (iii) Class 3 (28,7,4%) HEI; and (iv) Class 4 (22,1%)
Teaching (Fig. 1). These lenses provide a framework that helps in evaluating and
understanding the literature on HEI in Promoting SDG.
Class 1 (28,2%) represents approaches to implementation on HEIs play a critical
role in society by engaging in outreach activities that are designed to ensure sustain-
able and inclusive development. These institutions are pivotal in driving change and
addressing complex global challenges, such as gender inequality, poverty, and the
Fig. 1 Representation of themes and lenses
570
A. B. A. Avelar and M. L. Pajuelo-Moreno
impacts of COVID-19. By aligning their efforts with the United Nations Sustain-
able Development Goals (SDGs), HEIs contribute to the creation of a more equi-
table world for current and future generations, while also focusing on human capital
development within their local and global communities (Useh 2021).
Outreach programs are essential in fostering a sustainable society by promoting
inclusive education and research that not only addresses immediate societal needs
but also anticipates future challenges. Through these programs, HEIs play a transfor-
mative role by integrating sustainability into their curricula, research, and commu-
nity engagement efforts. This approach helps to ensure that the next generation is
equipped with the knowledge and skills necessary to tackle complex issues such as
climate change, poverty, and health disparities (Longoria et al. 2021).
Moreover, the role of HEIs in outreach is crucial in the aftermath of the COVID-
19 pandemic. Useh (2021) emphasizes the pandemic has highlighted the need for
resilient and adaptable education systems that can respond to global crises. HEIs
have the opportunity to play a leading role in rebuilding communities and ensuring
that recovery efforts are aligned with sustainable and inclusive principles, thereby
contributing to the reduction of poverty and the promotion of gender equality.
Class 2 (28,2%) represents approaches HEIs are increasingly aligning their
research activities with the SDGs to contribute to global sustainability efforts. This
alignment is evident in the growing number of publications on sustainability and
higher education, which often feature a variety of keywords related to sustain-
able development (Bautista-Puig et al. 2022). HEIs contribute to the SDGs through
interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary research that addresses societal problems and
focuses on local development (Monteiro et al. 2023). This research is often guided
by the need to solve real-world issues and is characterized by its relevance to the
various themes encompassed by the SDGs.
The research activities of HEIs are structured around four main axes: governance
and campus operations, learning and teaching, research, and community engagement
(Monteiro et al. 2023). These axes reﬂect the comprehensive approach that HEIs are
taking to integrate SDGs into their core functions. By focusing on these areas, HEIs
can ensure that their research not only advances academic knowledge but also has
practical implications for sustainable development.
Moreover, the research conducted by HEIs is becoming increasingly specialized,
with different types of HEIs focusing on different SDGs based on their academic
proﬁle. For instance, a study on Polish public HEIs revealed that HEI of life sciences
had the highest publication productivity for SDGs related to environmental and life
sciences, while HEI of technology and economics focused on SDGs related to their
respective ﬁelds (Pietrzak 2022). This specialization indicates that HEIs are lever-
aging their unique strengths and expertise to contribute to the SDGs in targeted and
impactful ways.
In the context of research conducted by HEIs to promote SDGs, various method-
ologies and approaches are employed, which often include the use of question-
naires, analysis, interviews, and surveys. These tools are essential for collecting data
and gaining insights into the effectiveness of initiatives and the progress towards
achieving the SDGs (Table 3).

Class 3 (28,2%) represents how HEIs access, analyze, and propose strategies to
better align themselves with the 2030 Agenda and make substantial contributions
towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals.
HEIs are increasingly recognized as pivotal actors in the global effort to achieve
the SDGs outlined in the 2030 Agenda. To better align themselves with these goals
and make substantial contributions, HEIs are adopting a variety of strategies and
approaches. Firstly, HEIs are integrating the SDGs into their strategic planning
processes. This involves considering the SDGs at the time of HEI strategy formula-
tion, design, and implementation of processes and practices (Leal Filho et al. 2023).
By doing so, HEIs can ensure that their educational, research, and societal missions
are aligned with the objectives of sustainable development.
Secondly, HEIs are assessing and revising their curricula to incorporate sustain-
ability principles and the SDGs. This is crucial for training professionals who are
committed to sustainability and can address related challenges and opportunities
(Fuchs et al. 2023). The curricula are being reviewed, discussed, and amended to
reﬂect the SDGs, often with a transdisciplinary approach that promotes integrated
and transformative practices beyond the classroom and across disciplines (Fuchs
et al. 2023).
Thirdly, HEIs are engaging in research that supports the SDGs. They are providing
expertise in research and education on all sectors of the SDGs, which is essential
for cross-sectoral implementation (Leal Filho et al. 2023). This research is not only
focused on environmental aspects but also on a systemic perspective that includes
education, campus operations, outreach, and assessment and reporting (Fia et al.
2023).
Fourthly, HEIs are fostering partnerships with governments, communities, and
other stakeholders. These collaborations are necessary to identify priorities, deter-
mine feasible options, and assess the measures implemented to achieve the SDGs
(Leal Filho et al. 2023). By working with policymakers and other actors, universi-
ties can use their expertise and skills to inﬂuence the adoption of more sustainable
policies and practices.
Fifthly, HEIs are investing in outreach programs to involve students in their local
communities. These interventions ensure efforts from all stakeholders and enhance
their beneﬁts, contributing to the public projection of unsustainable practices and
mobilizing students for social intervention through new ideas and projects (Fuchs
et al. 2023).
Lastly, HEIs are focusing on transparency and the global vision of sustainability.
They are encouraged to create platforms that integrate different sources of data
expressing interconnected results, which will allow for the automatic treatment of
the information produced. This requires careful planning and ﬁnancial commitment
from the institutions (Fuchs et al. 2023).
Class 4 (22,1%) represents approaches HEIs promote SDGs through teaching by
integrating sustainability into the curriculum, thereby preparing students to address
complex real-world problems such as climate change, resource exhaustion, and social
inequality. HEIs play a crucial role in transforming society towards a more sustain-
able development paradigm, challenging worldviews, assumptions, and values. This
Role of Higher Education Institutions in Promoting Sustainable …
573
transformative approach to education is essential for developing future leaders, engi-
neers, economists, and educators who are environmentally conscious and equipped
to lead sustainable initiatives (Obrecht et al. 2022).
Furthermore, HEIs are recognized for their potential to signiﬁcantly impact
society, the economy, and the environment through their core elements, which include
teaching (Son-Turan 2021). By aligning their educational programs with the SDGs,
HEIsensurethatstudentsacquiretheknowledgeandskillsneededtopromotesustain-
able development (Hauser and Ryan 2021). This is achieved by fostering multi-
stakeholder partnerships and industry-academic alliances that enhance the relevance
and applicability of sustainability education (Son-Turan 2021).
Additionally, HEIs are adapting their teaching and professional practice to include
speciﬁc tools and methodologies that align with environmental, social, and economic
sustainability principles, as well as the principles of the circular economy (Pedro et al.
2022). By doing so, they are actively contributing to the achievement of the SDGs
at both national and global levels (Table 4).
Teaching in the context of higher education institutions (HEIs) is intricately
connected to various aspects of academic and operational activities, as reﬂected
in the cited texts.

5
Conclusion
HEIs play a critical role in achieving SDGs through their interconnected missions of
teaching, research, and outreach. A systematic approach was used to identify, screen,
and analyze relevant articles, employing both qualitative and quantitative methods
to examine the role of HEIs in promoting the SDGs. HEIs have the potential to
signiﬁcantly impact society, the economy, and the environment through their teaching
and research.
There is a growing body of literature on the role of HEIs in promoting the SDGs,
with a slight prevalence of analyses in developing countries and a need for more
international collaboration.
The integration of the SDGs into academic curricula is crucial, and there is a need
for a more holistic and interconnected approach to sustainability in higher education.
The literature review highlights the need for HEIs to adopt interdisciplinary and
transdisciplinary approaches to effectively contribute to sustainable development.
ResearchpapersfocusontheintegrationofSDGsintouniversitycurricula,empha-
sizing the importance of student awareness and engagement in sustainability issues.
Student awareness and engagement are recognized as important factors for promoting
university sustainability and will be inﬂuential in the future.
There are existing gaps in the strategic approach to integrating SDGs into higher
education that need to be addressed for more effective integration. Moreover, more
research is needed, especially in developing countries and regions.
Outreach activities conducted by HEIs are essential for fostering a society that
values sustainability, inclusivity, and collective well-being. The Literature Review
demonstrated outreach activities conducted by HEIs are essential for fostering a
society that values sustainability, inclusivity, and collective well-being. So, article
advocates for the critical role of HEIs in advancing sustainability and inclusivity
through outreach activities, which not only beneﬁt the institutions and their students
but also the wider community and society as a whole.
The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the signiﬁcance of resilient and partici-
patory planning, with HEIs playing a crucial role in recovery and promoting sustain-
able practices. HEIs contribute to democratic processes and social engagement
through outreach, which is aligned with sustainable management education and
involves collaboration with various stakeholders. Through outreach, HEIs are seen
as transformative entities that integrate sustainability into their curricula, research,
and community engagement efforts, ensuring that future generations are prepared
to address complex sustainability issues. Barriers to innovation and sustainability
in higher education are identiﬁed, including a disconnect and lack of understanding
of SDGs among students and professionals, but the causes of these barriers are not
deeply analyzed.
Despite the contributions, Literature Review has limitations. Only articles in
English, published in journals, were considered for this research, omitting, for
example, conference articles and research in other languages, which may also contain
Role of Higher Education Institutions in Promoting Sustainable …
575
relevant information. Future research should focus on developing countries to better
understand and enhance the effectiveness of HEIs’ outreach efforts.

Supporting Research and Education
Stakeholders in Meeting the Sustainable
Development Goals Through the HESI
SDG Publishers Compact Fellows
Derek M. Lough, Rebecca Kirk, Victoria Gardner, Nikita Lad,
and Gerald Beasley
Abstract The communication of research relating to the Sustainable Development
Goals (SDGs) is an essential aspect of delivering meaningful change towards the
goals. Here, we outline the strategy and activities of the Higher Education Sustain-
ability Initiative (HESI) Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) Publishers Compact
Fellows who are a diverse and action-oriented group of volunteers. International
representatives across educational sectors including academia, publishing, tech-
nology, and related industries e-meet weekly. During general meetings and topical
working groups, the Fellows collaborate to drive progress toward the United Nations
SDGs by organizing the provision of advice, training, practical tools, and actionable
guidance. In this chapter, we share some of the challenges and opportunities that these
stakeholders face while supporting the aims of the SDGs, as well as a brief history
of the creation of the SDG Publishers Compact and the Fellows. We outline the role
of the interdisciplinary Fellows in supporting each stakeholder group alongside our
philosophy of driving this emerging international trend through both ‘quick wins’
and system change. We then highlight our top tips, our event series, and the role of
the Fellows group itself in structuring public engagement with the SDGs within and
across international institutions, education, research, and publishing. Taken together,
