1
Introduction
Launched at the Frankfurter Buchmesse, an annual event for the publishing industry
(SDG Publishers Compact 2020), the Publishers Compact builds upon the founda-
tions laid by the United Nations (UN) Global Compact, which has been advocating
for ten principles of sustainability for the past two decades (UN Global Compact
2024). Both the SDG Publishers Compact and the UN Global Compact align with
the international community’s objectives, particularly the Sustainable Development
Goals (SDGs). The UN Global Compact addresses corporate sustainability across
various sectors, while the SDG Publishers Compact is tailored to the needs of the
publishing industry. The commitments under the SDG Publishers Compact revolve
around ten action points designed to further the SDGs (United Nations 2023a, b).
These actions include promoting and publishing content that educates, develops,
and motivates action towards these goals, advocating for the SDGs, and maintaining
responsible production and business ethics (Fig. 1). The commitments in Fig. 1 are
taken directly from the UN Publishers Compact website (United Nations 2023a, b).
Potential signatories have the option to sign up to the Compact immediately after
reading the ten principles. These principles echo the UN Global Compact’s focus
on human rights, labor, environment, and anti-corruption. Both Compacts foster a
culture of collaboration and networking among their participants, encouraging a
collective movement toward sustainability. They provide platforms for sharing best
practices and facilitating cooperative learning. The voluntary nature of participation
in both Compacts underscores the role of the private sector and the importance of
industry-speciﬁc contributions to sustainable development.
Approximately one year following the launch of the Publishers Compact, the
SDG Publishers Compact Fellows emerged as a manifestation of this broader ethos.
Their focus is on identifying and implementing necessary actions for all parties in
the publishing sector to achieve the SDGs.
Figure 2 outlines this chapter, which will include the initiation of the Fellows,
their development as a multi-stakeholder volunteer group, and provide examples and
case studies from this group for actionable interventions to drive forwards the SDGs
in scholarly communications and the broader research community.
2
The Ambition and Complexities of SDGs
The SDGs, introduced by the United Nations in 2015, represent an ambitious and
far-reaching plan designed to tackle some of the world’s most pressing challenges.
These 17 goals are committed to ending poverty, ﬁghting hunger, providing quality
Supporting Research and Education Stakeholders in Meeting …
581
Fig. 1 SDG Publishers Compact Commitments. United Nations
education, and protecting our environment, among other vital objectives. They form
an equitable roadmap for building a world that is prosperous while also focused on
harmony with the biosphere.
The true challenge of the SDGs lies in their interconnected nature, addressing a
wide array of issues simultaneously. Progress in one area can signiﬁcantly impact
others, weaving a complex tapestry of cause and effect. This interconnectedness
calls for strategies that are both comprehensive and ﬁnely tuned. This challenge
affects policy-making, allocation of resources, and practical implementation in varied
global scenarios. The goals highlight the need for substantial ﬁnancial investment,
innovative approaches, and a commitment to collaboration, particularly in developing
countries with fewer resources (United Nations 2023a, b).
In this landscape, the publishing industry and the SDG Publishers Compact
Fellows have a critical role. The publishing sector is uniquely positioned to educate,
inform, and shape public opinion and policy (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows
2022b). Under the SDG Publishers Compact (Fig. 1), industry leaders pledge to
support these goals by promoting relevant materials, advocating sustainable prac-
tices, and setting examples of responsible business behavior. Their choices and
actions are key to guiding the publishing sector’s contribution towards achieving
the SDGs, managing its complexities while underscoring the importance of these
582
D. M. Lough et al.
Fig. 2 Chapter outline. SDG
Publishers Compact Fellows
transformative objectives. The Compact Fellows are at the forefront of steering the
industry towards these sustainable goals.
3
HESI SDG Publishers Compact Fellows
3.1
Construction of the Fellows
Heady exuberance, a determined feeling, and the slight anxiety of venturing into the
unknown imbued the ﬁrst publishers and academics to form the SDG Publishers
Compact Fellows under the Higher Education Sustainability Initiative. It began
with an inquiry to the UN and the International Association of Scientiﬁc, Tech-
nical, and Medical Publishers (STM) by the President at the US Partnership for
Education for Sustainable Development and the President of Yorkville University
in Toronto, ON. The Global Director for Sustainability at Elsevier helped form the
Supporting Research and Education Stakeholders in Meeting …
583
Publishers Compact in 2020 and answered this new call to form a working group to
address implementing necessary changes within the publishing industry. Over time,
the group swelled to include the Associate Director of the Pedro Arrupe Center for
Business Ethics at Saint Joseph University, as well as the Director of International
Marketing and Development at Cabells, who stated about those early days, “We were
a group of publishers and academics from several different countries who all wanted
to be involved with something that meant more than getting a company name on
a website—we wanted to see real action towards the SDGs being realized by the
publishing community.” Soon after the idea for the Fellows was realized.
In October 2021, a general meeting of the Publishers Compact Fellows took place
after a call-in at the 2021 International Conference on Sustainable Development,
bringing together a diverse group of professionals centered around the publishing
industry. This included both everyday practitioners and high-level executives actively
engaged in implementing sustainability practices within their organizations. The
founding members also encompassed scholars from various regions, including the
Global North and South, alongside graduate students who are emerging as thought
leaders in the ﬁeld of sustainability. The group is now further enriched by the partic-
ipation of librarians from academic institutions and business development experts
from the private sector. This assembly of dedicated professionals, all volunteers, met
to address next steps in forging a sustainable future.
3.2
Supporting Research and Education Stakeholders
in Meeting the SDGs
The HESI SDG Publishers Compact Fellows Action Group now stands out as a
leading force in steering sustainable development research. Having been created
with the purpose of supporting actionable outcomes for the UN SDG Publishers
Compact, its mission is to be a tangible resource to researchers and educators across
the international publishing industry. The Group envisions effective collaboration
across sectors to practically implement the SDGs by 2030 (SDG Publishers Compact
Fellows 2022b). Much of its work is done at the center of a network of stakeholders in
sustainability as it advances the intricate outputs necessary to create lasting outcomes.
Volunteer representatives from across educational and research sectors including
academia, publishing, technology, and related industries meet weekly (SDG
Publishers Compact Fellows 2023c). During general meetings and topical working
groups, the Fellows collaborate to drive progress toward the UN SDGs through the
provision of advice, training, practical tools, and actionable guidance.
584
D. M. Lough et al.
4
Multifaceted Stakeholder Perspectives
The realization of interconnected objectives like the SDGs inherently demands inter-
disciplinary collaboration. Fulﬁlling such ambitious targets necessitates the fusion of
highaspirationswithpracticalpossibilities.ThisprincipleguidedtheSDGPublishers
Compact Fellows as we tackled the various challenges presented by the Compact’s
ten commitments (Fig. 1). Similarly, as a HESI action group, we were inspired by
our parent organization to establish four focused working sub-groups/workstreams
to cater to speciﬁc stakeholder requirements. One was dedicated to enhancing the
inclusion of SDG-related content in academic publications and textbooks. Another
aimed to bridge the gap between research and practice, ensuring that practitioners
have direct access to the latest ﬁndings. The third group concentrated on motivating
and rewarding the creation of SDG-focused research. The fourth group, tasked with
shaping cultural change, explored ways to fast-track the adoption of the SDGs, recog-
nizing their growing importance on the global stage. Throughout this journey, the
Fellows committed to merging existing research with the needs of various stake-
holders, not only initiating swift, impactful changes but also creating pathways for
systematic adaptation to the evolving landscape of the global SDGs. The Fellows’
mission is to synergize existing research with diverse stakeholder needs, striving for
immediate impactful changes and long-term systematic evolution in line with global
SDG dynamics (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2022b).
4.1
The Evolution of Publishing in the Context of the SDGs
The SDG Publishers Compact, initiated to motivate publishers towards SDG achieve-
ment, emphasizes the pivotal role of publishers in informing and inspiring action
(SDG Publishers Compact et al. 2020). Hundreds of publishers have embraced its
principles, showcasing the Compact’s role in driving industry change. The publishing
ﬁeld is markedly diverse, encompassing a wide array of organizations with different
objectives and community engagements. This diversity is mirrored in the Compact’s
signatories, indicating varied approaches towards SDG contribution and commitment
implementation (United Nations 2020).
Focus areas differ, with some prioritizing environmental sustainability, as
evidenced by initiatives around Goal 13: Climate Action (Johnston and Pickett
2022; Martin et al. 2023). Publishers’ inﬂuence extends beyond direct organizational
actions, as exempliﬁed by publishing trade body STM’s aggregation of member activ-
ities supporting Climate Action (STM Association 2023b; Wise 2021; International
Publishers Association 2021). However, publishers play a crucial role in dissemi-
nating research that informs stakeholders’ actions towards all SDGs, with challenges
in optimizing such dissemination being discussed industry wide (Irfanullah 2022,
2023; Folan 2023).
Supporting Research and Education Stakeholders in Meeting …
585
To enhance the identiﬁcation and ampliﬁcation of SDG-related research, the
Fellowscompiledindustryeffortsforafutureuniﬁedtaxonomy,contributingtocross-
industry progress and aiding STM’s development of an SDG roadmap for publishers
(Ratings, Rankings and Assessment and SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2023, b,
c, d, e; STM Association 2023b). The development of an aligned SDG taxonomy
is ongoing and is now led by STM, with a focus on developing a web-based solu-
tion that would be available to all publishers without customization, integration, or
technological investment.
The SDG Publishers Compact was launched with the aim of inspiring action
among publishers and publishing associations to drive meaningful change towards
achieving the SDGs. The press release speciﬁcally called out the important role that
publishers have in achieving the goals by “publishing books and journals that will
help inform, develop and inspire action in that direction” (SDG Publishers Compact
et al. 2020). In the three years since the launch, the SDG Publishers Compact has
been a catalyst for change. These factors together have resulted in publishers and
their associations being one of the key stakeholder groups for the Fellows to engage
with, and for the Fellows to be drawn from.
4.2
Libraries and Academic Institutions
Librariesandacademicinstitutionsplayapivotalroleinmakingacademicpublishers’
works accessible. However, the gap between academic outputs and practical impacts,
such as policy inﬂuence, often persists due to barriers like paywalls and language.
Recognizingthis,theFellowshaveinitiatedmultipleprojectsthatspeciﬁcallyaddress
these challenges.
A key objective is for libraries and academic institutions to support both the
production and dissemination of sustainable research. The Fellows’ top tips (Fig. 3
and outlined in more detail below) initiative has signiﬁcantly contributed to this goal
(Havemann et al. 2023). Moreover, the formation of a Joint Task Force on Outcomes
and Impacts, in collaboration with another HESI Action Group, the Rating, Rankings
and Assessment Action Group, marks a signiﬁcant step in deﬁning and advancing
these objectives (Ratings, Rankings and Assessment and SDG Publishers Compact
Fellows 2023).
Libraries and academic institutions are often in a position to make the work
of academic publishers available to their communities. Indeed, academic research,
even when published in journals or monographs, often remains inaccessible to the
policymakers and practitioners who would most beneﬁt from it. The Joint Task
Force has explored this issue and notes that this is often due to a focus on incen-
tivizing outputs (such as the number of academic publications) over outcomes or
impacts (such as reducing poverty). Barriers to access for those outside academia are
often ﬁnancial (e.g. the research may be located behind a paywall) and the Fellows
are therefore keen to explore the beneﬁts of open access, open data, open educa-
tional resources, and open research. However, many other barriers to the equitable
586
D. M. Lough et al.
Fig. 3 top action tips for Academic Librarians. SDG Publishers Compact Fellows
distribution of knowledge also exist, especially concerning language. Since a large
proportion of researchers come from the Global South, widely accessible publica-
tions are not usually available in these academics’ and practitioners’ ﬁrst languages.
Additionally, research outputs typically employ specialist technical language that
makes sense to the author’s academic peers but unfortunately less so to the action-
oriented people who work outside the academic domain. Therefore, the opportunity
for academic publishers to interact with representatives from libraries and academic
institutions to address these issues is one of the most signiﬁcant opportunities that a
multi stakeholder group like the SDG Publishers Compact Fellows can offer. It has
already inspired several initiatives engaged in by the Fellows, notably including the
taxonomy outlined above that aims to connect academic research outputs to indi-
vidual SDGs and a well-attended workshop (Hazlett 2023) for researchers interested
in adding Plain Language Summaries (PLS) to their research articles. PLS are added
to academic journal articles so that they can reach a wider audience by summa-
rizing ﬁndings in terms that are accessible (and comprehensible) to people outside
the research discipline.
The long-term goal is for libraries and academic institutions to support both the
production and dissemination of research related to sustainable research. The top
tips for librarians played a large role in their activation (Havemann et al. 2023).
One lever to achieve this long-term goal is through recognizing and celebrating
those institutions that already align their work with this goal. The Joint Task Force
on Outcomes and Impacts has focused on this aspiration in its work. The Task Force
met almost monthly since September 2022 and recently produced a report containing
important deﬁnitions and recommendations for next steps, including tiering higher
education institutions, positioning applied research as equal to pure research, and the
Supporting Research and Education Stakeholders in Meeting …
587
use of artiﬁcial intelligence (Ratings, Rankings and Assessment and SDG Publishers
Compact Fellows 2023).
4.3
Research Sector
The research sector is instrumental in achieving the SDGs, where the SDG Publishers
Compact Fellows play a crucial role in fostering global SDG-focused research. The
group emphasizes practical applications of research, cross-disciplinary collabora-
tions, and accessibility of research ﬁndings to non-specialists. This approach aims
to equip various stakeholders, including policymakers and the public, with action-
able information to advance SDGs. Graduate students within the Fellows team also
contribute by developing action tips for research alignment with SDGs (Ashida 2022;
Worthington et al. 2023). This holistic approach underscores the sector’s responsi-
bility in advancing technologies and knowledge for SDG fulﬁllment. The research
sector plays a vital role in the achievement of the SDGs through a multitude of
initiatives, collaborations, and inventive projects. In this realm, the SDG Publishers
CompactFellowsformacommittedgroupsingularlyfocusedonleveragingthepower
of publishing to drive SDG-related outcomes. This group is focused on incentivizing
and recognizing the production of research centered around the SDGs. Martin (2023)
found that when publishers were asked to share their research on the SDGs, around
30% of research revolves around or is related to the SDGs. The third goal, Good
Health and Well-being is the most well-known, while SDG 13 (Climate Action) is
widely referenced (Fig. 4).
Fig. 4 SDG-related research. Sustainable solutions summit. Martin (2023)
588
D. M. Lough et al.
The research sector holds a major place in bringing advanced technologies and
improving existing knowledge for achieving the SDGs. Thus, empowering this sector
requires signiﬁcant attention and efforts, which the Fellows are working towards.
4.4
Education and the SDGs in a Global Context
Integrating global sustainability goals into education is even more crucial today
when skepticism about science is increasingly evident (Alberts 2022). Though still
in K-12 classrooms, the next generation of voters needs to understand the urgency
of climate change and efforts to limit global temperature rise. Educators face the
challenge of explaining whether global efforts to address these issues have been
successful or not (Lough 2022; Watts 2023). The resilience shown by students during
the global pandemic demonstrates the potential of international cooperation, empha-
sizing the need for education systems, particularly in the Global South, to adopt the
UN Agenda 2030 and the 17 SDGs. Agbedahin (2019) highlights the necessity of
effective governance and political will for the real implementation of sustainable
development strategies.
To avoid exacerbating the humanitarian crises predicted by scientiﬁc research,
education systems at all levels should engage in sustainable development education
(Iyengar and Kwauk 2021). The SDG Publishers Compact Fellows have addressed
this need through various initiatives. Their development of the Sustainable Develop-
mentGoalsRubricisanotableexample(SDGPublishersCompactFellows2024a,b).
Initially created for textbook editing to enhance sustainability literacy, this rubric has
also become a useful tool for educators in curriculum development and implementa-
tion (Lough et al. 2022). In addition, the Fellows have established partnerships with
entities like the International Council for Local Environmental Initiatives (ICLEI),
an NGO comprising over 1,200 local governments primarily from the Global South.
TheseconnectionsenabletheFellowstotranscendtraditionalresearchandpublishing
barriers, facilitating education that spans societal and national boundaries and more
effectively inﬂuencing policy decisions.
Finally, the Fellows have taken signiﬁcant steps within the publishing industry
by developing an additional top tips resource focused on equity (SDG Publishers
Compact Fellows 2023b). This initiative is at the core of our mission, focusing on
educating industry participants and colleagues to ensure they have the appropriate
tools and access to inﬂuence high-level policymakers. This comprehensive educa-
tional approach is essential for spreading knowledge and fostering awareness of
sustainable development on a global scale. Educating the public through webinars,
academic societies, and hosting events for the publishing industry remains a focal
point for the Fellows.
Supporting Research and Education Stakeholders in Meeting …
589
4.5
Practitioners’ Engagement with the SDGs
The Fellows aim to make sustainable development research practical and actionable
for policymakers and practitioners. This involves creating a bridge between research
ﬁndings and their real-world application, as outlined in the United Nation’s SDG
targets. Accordingly, one of its lists of top tips is aimed speciﬁcally at connecting
researchers and practitioners. More speciﬁcally, the Fellows aim to enable profes-
sionals and practitioners to get the answers they need, make informed decisions,
and enact change at their desks, onsite, in the ﬁeld, or indeed with patients (SDG
Publishers Compact Fellows 2024b). The Fellows also believe that research can help
equip policymakers, science writers, journalists, and the general public with clear
information on decisions, steps, and actions they can take—and pitfalls they can
avoid—when addressing issues related to sustainable development. The theoretical
framework for a bridge between the SDGs and practitioners on the ground has already
been set by the targets which the UN attached to each of the 17 SDGs. But these
targets can hardly be achieved without applying the ﬁndings of higher education.
Research and education initiatives explicitly co-designed and co-produced with
their intended beneﬁciaries are especially valuable in this regard. The Fellows there-
fore seek to convene meetings of researchers and practitioners. This has already been
a focus for two virtual events held in 2023: a Sustainable Solutions Summit on April
5th and a collaboration with the Open Climate Campaign and OpenPharma for a
virtual workshop entitled “Writing for non-academic audiences to achieve progress
towards the SDGs” on May 17th (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2023b). More
events are planned for 2024. The Fellows are aware that researchers frequently ﬁnd it
either difﬁcult or unrewarding to link their work to practical outcomes. To help over-
come this barrier, the Fellows act as convenors. Valuable contacts with organizations
such as ICLEI allow the Group to reach beyond higher education to practitioners
on the ground. These initiatives, coupled with strategic partnerships, are designed
to translate academic insights into tangible, on-the-ground solutions for sustainable
development.
5
Translating Vision into Reality
5.1
The Dual Approach: Quick Wins Versus Systemic
Changes
The pursuit of the SDGs by the SDG Publishers Compact Fellows has often centered
around a pivotal question: what is the most effective strategy to drive progress? The
Fellows, a diverse collective of strategic thinkers, problem solvers, and pragmatic
doers, engage in ongoing discussions about the most impactful approach to achieving
these goals. Central to these debates is whether to focus on incremental changes or
to advocate for radical, systemic transformations.
590
D. M. Lough et al.
This dichotomy mirrors broader debates in policy and business sectors about the
nature of change management. In these realms, there is a juxtaposition between the
philosophy of ‘kaizen’, which emphasizes continuous, incremental improvement,
and the concept of business process re-engineering, which advocates for compre-
hensive and radical change (Jin 2020). Both approaches have their merits and can be
effective in different contexts. As a group committed to practical solutions, the SDG
Publishers Compact Fellows have embraced a pragmatic approach that combines
elements of both strategies. We recognize that the path to achieving the SDGs is not
one-size-ﬁts-all but rather depends on the speciﬁc context and requirements of each
situation. This dual approach allows us to adapt and respond ﬂexibly, applying quick
wins where immediate results are feasible while also engaging in deeper, systemic
changes where more fundamental shifts are necessary.
By not limiting ourselves to a singular methodology, we can leverage the strengths
of diverse approaches. Quick wins provide immediate, tangible results that can build
momentum and demonstrate the efﬁcacy of our efforts. Such examples include a
video produced to introduce the Fellows, a policy brief published under the UNESCO
World Higher Education Conference, several author guides, and the top tips aimed at
a variety of stakeholders (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2023e). These smaller-
scale achievements can pave the way for broader acceptance and support for larger,
systemic changes. On the other hand, systemic changes, though often challenging
and time-consuming, are crucial for addressing the root causes of issues and bringing
about long-lasting transformations. That type of change requires direct collaboration
outside of the Fellows groups and will be detailed later in this chapter.
In implementing this dual strategy, the HESI SDG Publishers Compact Fellows
aim to strike a balance between the urgency of immediate action and the need for
deep, sustainable change. It is a dynamic process of assessing, adapting, and acting,
always with the ultimate goal of advancing the SDGs in the most effective and
efﬁcient way possible.
5.2
Top Tips for Balancing Incrementation and Radical
Change
The aforementioned top tips have been developed by the Fellows and comprise
practical and actionable tips to help members of the community support the SDGs.
The top tips have become a hallmark of the Fellows, and some are summarized in
Fig. 5 (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2022c).
Many of the ideas are easy to implement, requiring only minor changes to prac-
tice. Others are wider reaching. Each tip sheet created by the group typically offers
its target audience a mix of incremental and radical tips that they can choose to
implement in their work and activities.
In the example in Fig. 6, the ﬁrst tip is easy for a graduate researcher or student to
implement (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2021). Linking a research project to
Supporting Research and Education Stakeholders in Meeting …
591
Fig. 5 Top actions tips overview. SDG Publishers Compact Fellows
an SDG is a simple action that can help to build out networks and connections. Tip
2 offers the opportunity for longer-term change to the research design process. This
encourages readers to pivot to a ‘systems-thinking’ perspective (Arnold and Wade
2015).
Thetipsheeton“Connectingresearchandpracticeforprofessionals,practitioners,
policymakers and the public” focuses on the longer-term and more radical end of the
change management spectrum (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2022a, b, c, d).
Fig. 6 Top action tips for graduate researchers and students. SDG Publishers Compact Fellows
592
D. M. Lough et al.
Fellows reviewed examples across journals, and existing work on sharing the impli-
cations of research, and quickly came to the conclusion that there are many potential
audiences, which could be grouped into two types: those working in professional
environments who can apply what the research has uncovered in their daily work,
and non-specialists who could regulate change, communicate what changes to make,
or make change themselves. To address the different needs of those two groups, the
Fellows produced two sets of guidance for authors about when, how and where
to summarize the practical implications of their work (SDG Publishers Compact
Fellows 2022a). The Fellows have encouraged authors to think about creating lay
summaries, policy digests, or PLS formats (discussed earlier in this chapter) to
communicate the outcomes of their research to non-academic audiences. Feedback
from authors indicates that while there is an appetite to support the production of
this type of work, there is an absence of both incentives and training to support
this output. Many funders and higher education institutions acknowledge this chal-
lenge and are accordingly reforming their research assessment practices to encourage
broader engagement with research ﬁndings (Evaluation Reports Steer Away From
‘Automated’ UK Research Assessment 2022; Early Decisions Made for REF 2028
2023).
However, this broader structural change will take time to bed in and is indicative of
longer-term systems change. As a step towards reforming research assessment prac-
tices, the SDG Publishers Compact Fellows Action group collaborated with HESI’s
Ratings, Rankings and Assessment Group and formed the previously discussed Joint
Task Force on Outcomes and Impacts. Such exploration of how higher education
stakeholders couldmovetowards anoutcome-focusedwithinsustainabilityprocesses
could help academics reinterpret their works in totality, as well as through the SDGs
in particular (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2022d).
Our Top Action tips offer practical advice to support publishers, societies and
librarians, researchers and students (who can also be editors, reviewers or authors)
to align with the SDGs and to increase connections to practitioners (Fig. 7).
TheFellowsdonotsimplyadvocateforchangebutaimtoprovidepracticalsupport
and guidance to the communities that they engage with. To encourage researchers
to write for non-academic audiences, the group hosts and collaborates on numerous
events to provide practical tips and advice to attendees on how they might begin
this process themselves (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2023d). The Fellows
are keen to empower the communities that we work with to take responsibility for
driving change and to become activists in supporting the SDGs. Solutions Summits
(Fig. 8) are another form of event regularly hosted by the group with an aim to inspire
attendees to become change agents.
The purpose of these events is stated clearly as an information transaction aimed
at actionable outcomes by the attendee (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2023d).
These events put the onus on attendees to take responsibility for the role that they
can play in driving change. This isn’t a one-way street, however; we hypothesize that
engagement with the SDGs helps research to have more impact (Martin 2023) and
makes it easier for readers to ﬁnd and make use of the published insights (Meschede
2020). Supporting the SDGs is a win–win for all involved.

6
Engagement, Outreach, and The Future
As a small group, the SDG Publishers Compact Fellows face the ongoing challenge of
maximizing the impact of our actions within the practical constraints of limited time
and resources. To extend the reach and effectiveness of our work, we have adopted a
strategy of forging connections with like-minded organizations, pooling resources,
and collaborating to engage broader audiences. Our efforts in this direction have
been multifaceted and productive.
As previously mentioned, in partnership with the publisher trade association STM,
we have co-developed an SDG roadmap. This roadmap offers practical advice and
support to publishers, guiding them towards making substantive progress on the
SDGs beyond merely signing the Publishers Compact (STM Association 2023a).
Another signiﬁcant collaboration has been with the Association for Professional and
Learned Society Publishers (ALPSP). Here, we have supported the creation of a
Special Interest Group on the SDGs, which facilitates the sharing of best practices
and provides guidance to members on integrating the SDGs into their publishing
strategies and programs (Association of Learned and Professional Society Publishers
2023). Additionally, our collaboration extends to organizations such as ICLEI (Local
Governments for Sustainability), the European Association of Scientiﬁc Editors
(EASE), the Open Climate Campaign, and OpenPharma. These partnerships focus
on advocacy and training events, enhancing our collective ability to inﬂuence and
educate (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2022c).
Central to all these initiatives is our commitment to maintaining an equity lens
in promoting public engagement with the SDGs. This approach ensures that our
strategies and methodologies are inclusive and considerate of diverse perspectives
and needs (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2023b). Through these collaborative
efforts, we aim to amplify our impact and effectively contribute to the global pursuit
of the SDGs.
6.1
Public Engagement with the SDGs
The Fellows play a pivotal role in enhancing public engagement with the UN SDGs.
Central to our mission is fostering widespread awareness and understanding of the
SDGs. The Fellows prioritize creating and disseminating educational and academic
content that is both accessible and engaging to a diverse audience. We work towards
bridging the gap between complex research ﬁndings and their practical implications
for communities, aiming to inspire a cultural shift towards the adoption of sustainable
practices.
In our commitment to promoting equitable access to SDG-related information,
the Fellows have been instrumental in developing resources like the SDG Rubric.
As outlined above, this tool is designed to enhance sustainability literacy across
different educational materials; ensuring the concepts and importance of the SDGs
Supporting Research and Education Stakeholders in Meeting …
595
are effectively communicated to learners of all ages and backgrounds, empowering
advocacy across education for sustainable development (Iyengar and Kwauk 2021;
Lough 2022; Lough et al. 2022). Moreover, the Fellows extend our educational
outreach beyond academic circles, reaching wider societal and international audi-
ences by collaborating with organizations like ICLEI and distributing top tips (Fig. 9)
aimed at different stakeholders (Worthington et al. 2023).
The Fellows’ strategies to reach a broad audience also include hosting impactful
events like the Solutions Summits. These gatherings serve as platforms for change
agents from various sectors to share ideas, strategies, and success stories, thereby
motivating and empowering communities to take actionable steps towards achieving
the SDGs. Furthermore, as outlined, the Fellows actively support researchers in
translating their ﬁndings into formats that resonate with non-academic audiences,
thereby fostering a deeper public understanding and engagement with sustainability
issues (SDG Publishers Compact Fellows 2023d).
Finally, the SDG Publishers Compact Fellows were well represented at the annual
High-Level Political Forum at the UN and presented during the Higher Education
Fig. 9 Example of SDG Publishers Compact Fellows Public Engagement. Higher Education
Sustainability Initiative SDG Publishers Compact Fellows. Logos, 33(4), 45–51. https://doi.org/
10.1163/18784712-03104053

United Nations High-Level Political Forum 2023). A short summary of the past year
and future plans can be seen in Fig. 10.
In the realm of publishing, the Fellows advocate for open access to SDG-related
research and strive to tackle language barriers, ensuring that valuable insights
and innovations are accessible to a global audience. Our support for the SDG
Publishers Compact underscores our commitment to driving action within the
publishing industry, emphasizing the production and dissemination of content that
not only educates but also inspires action toward the SDGs (Mudditt 2023; SDG
Publishers Compact 2020; United Nations 2020). Overall, the SDG Publishers
Compact Fellows’ efforts exemplify a comprehensive and inclusive approach to
advancing the SDGs, with a speciﬁc focus on engaging the public. Our work high-
lights the crucial role of knowledge sharing, cultural inclusivity, and community
empowerment in driving sustainable development worldwide.

7
Lessons Learned and Recommendations for Future
Action
The HESI SDG Publishers Compact Fellows serves as an example of how multi-
stakeholder volunteer collaboration can be powerful and effective. As the Fellows
group has evolved over time, however, important considerations have emerged which
continue to be a source of deliberation, with reﬂections on some major areas noted
below. Awareness of these points may be of value to those considering similar actions.
7.1
Make the Most of Your Resources
Although there is much enthusiasm in the group, the Fellows comprise volunteers
with many demands on their time and availability outside of the group. There have
been challenges in balancing the long list of possible actions and activities with the
capacity of the Fellows to support and deliver. A clearer overview of capacity will
support planning and allocation of resources.
7.2
Focus Can Be Hard to Find
The Fellows have a vast number of avenues to explore to support of driving progress
towards the SDGs. It has been challenging to agree on which avenues might be the
most impactful in supporting our aim, and there has been a temptation to act in
multiple areas simultaneously, which risks the groups’ ability to deliver sustained
change. The Fellows are still understanding how best to balance focus (doing fewer
things well) with the vast array of possible avenues and actions but have been helped
in this work by creating tools such as a Dashboard to provide insight into areas of
activity as well as a series of focused goals to inform priority areas for action.
7.3
Global Representation is Hard to Achieve
TheFellowsstrivetobeinclusiveanddiverse.However,ithasbeendifﬁculttobetruly
representative, due both to practical considerations (time zones) as well as systemic
issues around the burden of representation falling on those from traditionally under-
represented groups and regions. Continued awareness of, and efforts to address this
issue are crucial to driving change and improving representation.
598
D. M. Lough et al.
7.4
Call to Action
The Fellows have set the following goals for future action: building communities
conﬁdent in driving change; establishing best practice, standards and guidance,
and taking action to drive systems change. Partnerships are a critical mechanism
to support in achieving these aims—and the main call to action for readers.
The Fellows strive to align with inﬂuential partners and welcome collaboration
with those who share common goals. Current and future partners include institutions
who are leading the way in changing incentives and research culture to focus on
outcomes not outputs, practitioner organizations such as ICLEI who serve as a bridge
between research and application, and high-level bodies such as the United Nations
whoprovideinspirationforchange.Changingresearchcultureisalsoaboutcontinued
engagement with researchers. The Fellows will continue to partner with and support
academics by making their content more accessible and usable to wider audiences
through future training events, summits, and sharing of the top tips. They will also
advocate for more interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary research as a means to
make progress on the complex and cross disciplinary components of the SDGs.
Theroleofartiﬁcialintelligence(AI)inmakingSDGrelatedcontentmoreﬁndable
and useable is also an area of focus, and one where the Fellows welcome support
from partners. AI could support research translation into local languages for use
by communities, could support with summaries of content, and could also serve to
synthesize the vast research corpus into new formats that could be better used by
non-academic audiences to effect real world systems change.
8
Conclusion: An Emerging International Trend
The Higher Education Sustainability Initiative Sustainable Development Goals
Publishers Compact Fellows have made signiﬁcant strides in aligning the publishing
industry with the United Nations SDGs. This diverse and dedicated group of volun-
teers from various sectors has demonstrated the power of collaboration in driving
sustainable development. Through our weekly meetings, topical working groups,
and active engagement in creating tools and guidance, we have tackled challenges
and capitalized on opportunities to promote sustainable practices within and beyond
the publishing industry.
The Fellows’ interdisciplinary approach and commitment to ‘quick wins’ along-
side systemic changes have been instrumental in fostering a culture of sustainability
across international institutions, education, research, and publishing. Our initiatives,
such as the development of the SDGs Rubric and various top tips, have provided
practical support to stakeholders in implementing SDGs. Additionally, our efforts in
organizing events and series have signiﬁcantly contributed to raising awareness and
structuring public engagement with the SDGs.
Supporting Research and Education Stakeholders in Meeting …
599
The impact of the HESI SDG Publishers Compact Fellows extends to several
key areas. In the realm of research and education, we have bridged the gap between
academic ﬁndings and practical applications, ensuring that sustainability research
is accessible and actionable. In publishing, we have inﬂuenced publishers to adopt
sustainable practices and promote SDG-aligned content. Libraries and academic
institutions have been guided to support the dissemination of sustainable research.
Furthermore, our engagement with practitioners has translated research insights into
tangible solutions for sustainable development.
Looking ahead, the challenge remains to maintain and build on the momentum
generated by the Fellows. Continued collaboration, innovative approaches, and
strategic partnerships will be crucial in advancing the SDGs. The success of the HESI
SDG Publishers Compact Fellows serves as a model for other sectors, demonstrating
the effectiveness of collective action and interdisciplinary cooperation in achieving
global sustainable development goals. Our journey underscores the importance of
shared responsibility and concerted efforts in addressing the world’s most pressing
challenges, setting a path for future initiatives aimed at creating a sustainable and
equitable world.
The Fellows are building a virtual community to share ideas, and lessons learned,
and to continue to develop resources to drive change. We invite readers to visit our
websiteathttps://www.sdgcompactfellows.org/andtosignuptojointhiscommunity.

publishing and business executives, policymakers, doctoral students, and librarians in this common
endeavor. This chapter is for all those over the past three years who participated in furthering the
initiatives of our Fellows.

harm.” BMJ n2177. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.n2177
Worthington R, Martin RP, Beasley G, Gardner V, Lad N, Lough DM, Patel C (2023) Higher
education sustainability initiative SDG publishers compact fellows. Logos 33(4):45–51. https://

Sustainable Development Agenda 2030
Goals and Early Childhood
Education—A Case Study
of Project-Based Learning in Higher
Education
Niina Väänänen, Hanna Kettunen, Anne Posti, and Virpi Turunen
Abstract Sustainable development is integrated into the Finnish education system
at all levels of education from early childhood to higher education. Early childhood
educators’ study for a bachelor’s degree in higher education in Finland. The studies
comprise many subjects, such as learning and teaching literacy and numeracy, but
also developing, for instance, motor skills or creativity through arts and crafts. Craft
studies are a ﬁve-credit course of the bachelor’s degree. In this case study, future
early childhood teachers were given a project-based learning task to incorporate the
Agenda 2030 goals into their craft project, and to contextualize it to early childhood
learning situations. We are interested in gaining knowledge about how to concretise
learning the Agenda 2030 goals through crafts in early childhood education. The
purpose of this study is to describe and analyse how early childhood teacher students
concretize the Agenda 2030 Goals through crafts in a project-based learning task
and what they learn during the process. We view through their learning portfolios
how the students reﬂect learning through play and their interaction with materials
and crafting methods, in order to understand their connection to their surroundings,
while at the same time, developing their senses, motor skills, creativity, and thinking
skills.
Keywords Early childhood education · Teacher education · Craft education ·
Sustainable development · Agenda 2030 goals
N. Väänänen (B) · H. Kettunen · A. Posti · V. Turunen

1
Introduction
Adults working in early childhood education are teachers (sosionomi in Finnish,
Soziomon in De, Bachelor in social service in Eng), and basic nurses (Opetus-ja
kulttuuriministeriö 2023). The teachers are responsible for pedagogical content and
activities in the actual work in early childhood education. However, ‘socionomes’
tasks are related to socio-pedagogical topics and usually basic nurses look after the
children’s basic care (see also Kettukangas 2013, 2017).
Early childhood teacher education in Finland is achieved at university-level higher
education. The studies are a three-year, 180-credit study programme resulting in a
Bachelor’s degree in Education (Opintopolku n.d.). The studies also give the qual-
iﬁcation to practice as a teacher in early childhood education. This means that
early childhood teachers are responsible for turning the curriculum into action in
their workplaces together with their working teams. The studies for early childhood
education prepare the students with the necessary skills that will be required in their
teaching work. At the University of Eastern Finland, the studies are structured in
ways such as Orientation-, language and communication studies for 15 ECTS, Basic
studies in education (early childhood education; 25 ECTS), Intermediate studies
in education (early childhood education; 40 ECTS), Professional studies in early
childhood education and pre-primary education (75 ETCS), and voluntary studies
of 25 ETCS (UEF n.d.). Early childhood education studies also include 60 ECTS of
pedagogical studies and practical training, research methods, and different topics of
early childhood education, such as literature, language, mathematics, arts, culture,
physical education, and play.
The aim and objective of the study is to describe and analyse how early childhood
teacher students concretize the Agenda 2030 Goals through crafts in a project-based
learning task and what they learn during the process. Next, we will place our study
in the research context of education for sustainability in early childhood education
through crafts. We continue by describing our case study and the process of analysis
in the methods, view the reﬂective process of the participants learning outcomes
in the results and discussion. Finally, we make conclusions of the case study for
education for sustainability in early childhood education.
2
Theoretical Background
2.1
Early Childhood Education
Early childhood education in Finland is arranged, for instance, in early childhood
education and care (ECEC) centres in the public or private sector for children under
school age (the year they turn 7) (Varhaiskasvatuslaki 540/2018 [Early Childhood
Education Act]). Pre-primary education is enforced by the Perusopetuslaki [Basic
Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 Goals and Early Childhood …
605
Education Act] (628/1998) and mandatory for children the year they turn the age at
six years old.
The Finnish National core curriculum for early childhood education and care
(Finnish National Agency of Education, FNAE 2022, pp. 23–24) is based on a
leaning concept that sees children growing, developing, and learning in commu-
nication with other people and the immediate environment. Children are seen as
active learners, who are curious to learn and repeat things. Learning is situated every-
where, and it connects knowledge, skills, actions, emotions, senses, embodied expe-
riences, language and thinking. Learning happens through imitation and play. There
are six generic competencies that early childhood education is geared for: thinking
and learning, cultural skills, communication, and expression, looking after oneself
and everyday skills, multiliteracy, digital competence, participation and inﬂuencing
(p. 26). Figure 1. conceptualizes these themes and generic skills together.
Multiliteracy through makerspace pedagogy, for instance, is seen to enhance
science education in the early years and to create learning opportunities and devel-
oping 21st century skills (Vartainen and Kumpulainen 2019). Vartiainen and Kumpu-
lainen (2019) experimented maker pedagogy with children by making parachutes and
exploring science through play, and this kind of Playful meaning-making has also
been seen as enhancing multiliteracy.
Fig. 1 Early childhood education learning themes and generic skills. Modiﬁed from FNAE (2022,
40, Fig. 1)
606
N. Väänänen et al.
2.2
Early Childhood Craft Education
Craft education connects to all learning themes set by the ECE curriculum (see
Fig. 1.) indirectly and directly. An indirect connection to crafts can be seen in the
curriculum (FNAE 2022) to the theme Language enriched world through learning
language and communication, since communication and learning language is also
part of crafts and could be implemented by story crafting, hence, a method of crafting
or constructing the semiotics of a story (see also Rönkkö and Aerila 2013; Walan
et al. 2020). Me and our community theme is about ethical thinking and learning
about the community’s history, present and past, also through media. The content of
these topics could also involve getting to know history through museum and, often
crafted objects (see also Rönkkö et al. 2016; Vartiainen 2014). Growing, moving,
and developing theme is focused mostly on physical activities, food education, and
learning about health-related issues. In crafts, these can be introduced to the children,
for instance, by using food waste like onion or fruit peels, plants, or coffee grounds
to dye textile materials and later craft these materials into an artefact (see Alanko
2020). Safety is also part this theme and part of the safety education could be, for
instance, understanding how to use sharp tools safely without injuring yourself or
others.
A direct connection to craft education in mentioned in the theme of Diverse forms
of expression, where crafts are part of other art forms (FNAE 2022, pp. 46–48).
Expression through arts is seen to enhance children’s learning abilities, social skills,
and positive self-image. When children explore and interpret while practicing arts,
they develop their abilities to understand and construct the surrounding world through
thinking and learning skills. Crafts are also seen as part of the cultural heritage and
as part of cultural identity. Interaction with various methods, and the manipulation of
materials and aesthetics with instruction are needed to ﬁnd ways to express thoughts,
feelings, observations, and creativity (see also Boyd 2020; Karlson Häikiö 2018).
Considering crafts, according to the curriculum (FNAE 2022, pp. 46–48), design
skills, creative problem solving, ﬁne motor skills, knowledge of structures, materials
and techniques, as well as aspects of design are practiced with the help of technical
craft and textile craft work methods suitable for children. Handmade expression
involves methods like moulding, cutting, nailing, sawing, and sewing. The goal is
to offer children the joy of experimenting, working together, and creating visible
handcrafted pieces. Children explore varied materials, learn craft techniques, and
generate their own ideas. Local craft traditions related to their backgrounds can also
be incorporated.
Another direct connection to crafts education is in the learning theme Exploring
and interacting with my environment. This theme also connects to environmental
education and sustainability. According to the curriculum (FNAE 2022) part of
early childhood education is to give the children possibilities to observe, construct
and understand their surrounding environment, whether it is built or natural. STEM
contents/Environmental/Science and technology education as well as mathematics
are part of this learning theme that is recommended as being learnt through embodied
Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 Goals and Early Childhood …
607
learning and play. This can be done by pointing out how to count trees or rocks in the
play-yard, or by arranging toys in distinct categories (e.g., from smallest to biggest),
or by constructing or crafting (see also Lindfors et al. 2021). Also relevant are things
such as learning about the cycle of the year, learning about plants and animals, and
how to be responsible in the environment they live in (see also Rule and Zhbanova
2012). Environmental education and sustainability are speciﬁcally highlighted in
the early childhood education curriculum. Environmental education includes three
dimensions: learning in the environment, learning about the environment, and acting
for the environment. Especially, local nature and the built environment are seen as
both learning targets and learning environments (FNAE 2022, pp. 46–48). Davies
(2010, pp. 30–31) explains that learning in the environment refers to returning to
nature. Children also need to learn about the environment and learn what can they
do for the environment to develop interconnections, human-nature relationships, and
to increase pro-environmental behaviour (see also Ginsburg and Audley 2020).
According to the curriculum (FNAE 2022) environmental education guides chil-
dren to ﬁnd a quiet place to relax and experience nature aesthetically. Building a
respectful relationship with nature is one of the goals, together with a sustainable
lifestyle,forinstance,bynottrashingnature,responsibleandfrugalbehaviour,energy
efﬁciency, sorting and reducing waste by recycling or maintaining products. It is also
important to learn how to take responsibility for one’s actions and see the results in
such a way that they are not held responsible as children (see also Nussbaum 2011).
The curriculum (FNAE 2022) points out that the goal for technology educa-
tion is to encourage children to explore and experiment with different technological
solutions or materials in their environment by asking questions and seeking results
together with adults. By experimenting with varied materials and hands-on activities
and learning about technology that is familiar to children, such as toys and other
everyday objects/artefacts, children would gain an understanding that all technology
is designed and made by people.
2.3
Finnish Crafts Education
Finnish crafts education has its roots in the 1860’s when education in Finland started
to form on a national level (Marjanen and Metsärinne 2019). The early developer Uno
Cygnaeus (1810–1888) was inspired by the works of Fröbel and Pestalozzi, and their
approach to learning through play (Marjanen and Metsärinne 2019; Kraatari 2016).
Later, Finnish craft education has reﬂected the societal needs of each period (Lepistö
and Lindfors 2015; Porko-Hudd et al. 2018; Kouhia 2021) but has remained a prag-
matic way of learning by doing in the national curriculum. The current curriculum
was changed in 2016 and considers crafts as a multi-material and holistic process
of making crafted objects (Pöllänen 2020; Väänänen and Pöllänen 2021). Multi-
materiality means that in crafts, all kinds of materials can be used with various
techniques to craft without dichotomizing between textile or technical craft. Holistic
craft process means that the person making the product starts the crafting process
608
N. Väänänen et al.
from ideating, designing, experimenting, making, and evaluating the product (see
also Rönkkö 2011; Porko-Hudd et al. 2018). Therefore, the Finnish craft concept
includes the elements of design (visual or technical) in making, although they can
also be seen as separate from each other (see Ihatsu 2002; Nugraha 2012; Shiner
2012).
Yliverronen et al. (2021) describe the holistic craft process with technology and
science education as investigative activities among young children, which can be
separated into modes of action. Everything begins with ideation, and with the help
of the teacher’s questions, discussions, and joint reﬂection about the task at hand
can be realized. The children can carry out investigations or trials of how things
work before making in a holistic process with concrete products. This process is
characterized with playfulness and a child-centred pedagogy, with the assistance of
support techniques acting as scaffolding.
The maker pedagogy in the curriculum is described as non-linear, where learning
is encouraged to shift from the individual to collaborative work in an interdisci-
plinary manner, breaking the boundaries between different school subjects (Härkki
et al. 2023). Furthermore, the craft process itself is non-linear, the end solutions
are unforeseen, as are the process goals, stages or tools needed for the task. Conse-
quently, a lot of ﬂexibility and courage is required from the teacher to follow this type
of pedagogy (Härkki et al. 2023; also, Kangas et al. 2022). Seitamaa-Hakkarainen
and Hakkarainen (2019) compare linear and non-linear pedagogy and see that the
non-linear pedagogy better reﬂects learning skills that respond to the challenges of
this century. This means that, for instance, open and ill-deﬁned design problems are
being resolved in collaboration with others. Even though the task itself may be craft
and design-oriented, the pupils and students are developing their problem-solving
and collaboration skills at the same time. Also, from the viewpoint of sustainability,
ill-deﬁned problems are usually ‘wicked’ and do not necessarily have only one right
answer or a solution to solve them (see also Salonen 2019). With the non-linear
pedagogical approach, this kind of uncertainty can be learned to be coped with.
2.4
Craft in the Finnish ECE
The pedagogy of ﬁve-year-olds and the current implementation of the Diverse forms
of expression learning theme in the curriculum for ECEC (FNEA 2022) have been
evaluated by the National Centre for Assessment of Education in Finland (KARVI)
(Juutinen et al. 2021). This study found that craft was the least implemented of all the
expressive arts content in this theme. In the study, ECE teachers’ self-assessments
of craft implementation received the lowest scores. In addition, ECE craft activities
were not very regular, the equipment available was limited, and the teachers’ skills
were only moderate. The KARVI evaluation pointed to the need to strengthen the role
of expressive arts and the implementation of craft education. It also indicated that
particular attention should be paid to the opportunities for experimentation and explo-
ration through a variety of craft materials and techniques (Juutinen et al. 2021). The
Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 Goals and Early Childhood …
609
results of a study by Karila and Leikola (2022), in which they interviewed teachers
taking part in in-service training in craft and technology education, together with the
KARVI evaluation (Juutinen et al. 2021), show that the content and implementation
of craft and technology education should be strengthened already in the early phases
of childhood teacher training.
2.5
Agenda 2030 Goals and Craft Education
The Agenda 2030 goals offer a detailed framework through which to focus on speciﬁc
and broad topics in a sustainable development context. There are 17 goals with 169
more speciﬁc targets. These goals and targets focus attention on people, the planet,
prosperity, peace, and partnership (UN 2015). Education for sustainability aims to
developskillsandcompetenciessuchascreativity,problem-solving,criticalthinking,
decision making, resilience (Boyd and McLeod 2021; Leal Filho and Pace 2016),
active participation in the communities, as well as understanding and embracing the
complexity of sustainability (Linhares and Cavadas 2021; Bianchi et al. 2022).
An earlier study viewed the Agenda 2030 goals in a Finnish craft context and noted
that all 17 goals can be viewed through crafts and educated through craft education
(Väänänen and Pöllänen 2021). In early childhood education and at elementary level,
this is done, for instance, through material encounters, rehearsing skills and getting
to know the holistic craft process. The material in use could be upcycled and children
could innovate with new uses for them (see also Karlson-Häikiö 2018). Practicing
skills and interaction with materials are seen as crucially important for childhood
development, because this is a sensitive time connecting senses and mental processes
(see also Huotilainen et al. 2018; Pöllänen 2020). The education for sustainability
through arts and crafts has been noticed to be affective way of learning, however,
it needs further examination, especially in the ECE context (Karlson Häikiö 2018;
Boyd and McLeod 2021).
3
Method
The purpose of this study is to view and understand (1) how early childhood educa-
tion teacher students understand the Agenda 2030 goals in their craft project and
(2) what they learn by making a craft-based project for the early childhood educa-
tion context. This case study (Stake 2000; Creswell and Poth 2018) ﬁrst describes
students’ craft projects in an early childhood teacher education context and second
analyses their collective student portfolios. Portfolios are widely used in craft educa-
tion to document and reﬂect on the learning process (Saarinen et al. 2021; Jones
and Shelton 2011). The study module was based on a socio-constructivist view of
co-creation and learning through a project-based learning task (Härkki et al. 2023;
Seitamaa-Hakkarainen and Hakkarainen 2019). This means that the students were
610
N. Väänänen et al.
given an open-ended design and project task within a given framework, along with
some boundaries for their crafting.
3.1
The Case
This study was conducted in an early childhood teacher education university-level
context. The students were attending a course in Early childhood craft education at
the University of Eastern Finland. The course included both theoretical and practical
studies of crafts, including textile and technical working methods and materials
(see also Pöllänen 2020). The theme and course structure had been developed for a
few years before this study. The students ﬁrst learned about the importance of craft
education in early childhood in lectures. Secondly, they practiced the basic skills
needed in craft workshops. The students learned skills such as forming, measuring,
pattern transforming to material, sewing fabrics by hand, felting wool, and printing
textiles in the textile workshops. In the technical workshops they learned how to
measure, clamp pieces safely, saw, sand, drill, joinery, painting as techniques on
wood and plywood, as well as using a cordless drill. The techniques taught in the
workshops gave the students basic skills and knowledge of how to use these hand-
held tools and machines. Also, through making a model-based craft (see Rönkkö
2011; Kröger 2016), as well as making a structure of a wooden toy, they learned
technology through crafts. Another task was to explore and make moving toys such
as a boat sawn from a piece of polyurethane sheet, plywood, cocktail sticks, and a
rubber band.
The third part of the course was ideating, designing, making and evaluating a
craft project. The project was thematised by the teachers to use the UN Agenda 2030
goals as a source of inspiration for their project. Their project work was to concretise
the UN Agenda 2030 goals into a playful toy or game using the crafts skills and
knowledge that they were learning at the same time. The students were introduced
to the goals and had to choose at least one goal to design a toy or a game that could
be used in an early childhood education context.
The students crafted their project in teams of 2–5 persons. The students had two
online design sessions for three hours to ideate and design their project. For the
actual making of the game or toy, they had 18 h (3 × 3 h of technical; and 3 × 3 h of
textile craft). One of the guidelines in the project was to incorporate both methods
and materials in the game or toy. The course’s ﬁnal tasks were to present the project
in an exhibition at the university in such a way that the possible end-users—children
and adults—would be able to play with the toys. They were allowed to keep their
projects for themselves or donate them to an early childhood care unit. The students
also needed to write an academic report with a reﬂection on the early childhood
pedagogy and crafts process. These portfolios were written as a group assignment.
Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 Goals and Early Childhood …
611
3.2
Data and Analysis
We collected data from early childhood teacher students who studied early childhood
education at a university level in December 2023. The students’ participation was
voluntary. The purpose of the study was explained, and we asked for their permis-
sion to use their portfolios as study data. We also asked if the students wanted to
portray their crafting process through photographs taken during the workshops and
exhibition, with the risk of these leading to recognition. Otherwise, the data was
analysed and treated anonymously with the ethical considerations taken into account
throughout the research process.
This study analyses the written project portfolios by ﬁrst describing them, and
then through a process of thematic content analysis (Weber 1990). We received
permissions from 3 group portfolios from 9 students for our analysis. We analysed
the portfolios by carefully reading the written parts and viewing the photographs
from the process, for instance, the plannings and drawings attached to the portfolios.
After reading the texts, the texts were coded with the help of Atlas.ti software, and
the codes categorized into themes. In this analysis, we focused on what the students
were saying rather than seeking for meanings behind their texts (Bengtsson 2016).
4
Results
The student group portfolios revealed several themes of their project-based learning
task. The students entangled the Agenda 2030 Goals and themes from the National
Core Curriculum in their projects, but they were also reﬂecting on their crafting
process from practical and theoretical perspectives. The students also reﬂected on
the gaming and playing perspectives of the project in learning these themes.
The Agenda 2030 Goals were used as a starting point for the crafting project as
an idea with the purpose of concretizing the Goal into an educational task. Overall,
in the course, many of the themes were used as a source of inspiration. Yet, in this
data, there were only two themes that were used for ideation. The themes were Goals
14 Life Below Water (2 groups) and 4 Quality Education (1 group).
Group 1 had three students and their Goal was Life below water. The students
designed a board game that can be used even with the smallest children to ﬁnd
and name ﬁgures of sea life or more simply of colours and shapes. The students
conceptualized the theme of the game as:
The game board, on which we painted the underwater world, the ﬁsh and organisms living
there, offers children the opportunity to see and structure marine life. In the game, the
emphasis is on visualizing and naming different organisms and characters. The game also
reminds children about the protection of water bodies. There is also a piece of garbage on
the game board (a plastic bottle) that does not belong in the sea.
They also considered that through the game the children get to know the life of
water bodies. They also thought that the game could awaken the children’s interest
612
N. Väänänen et al.
in underwater life and increase their knowledge of species and their knowledge
of issues related to the condition and protection of waters. They also considered
that through the game, the children would learn how to follow rules, wait for their
turn in a gaming situation, and other skills for interaction, as well as handling and
regulating emotions. The students reﬂected that the children would learn concrete
conceptualization, hence, naming colours and numbers beside the species. They also
reﬂected that children would learn logical reasoning and problem-solving, as well as
visualization, concentration, and focus.
Group 2 had four students working on Goal 14: Life below water. Their game was
a more traditional ﬁshing game with a ﬁshing rod, ﬁshes, and other water species.
They added plastics in the game to show that plastics do not belong in water to
raise discussions of sorting waste and treating the environment with respect. They
reﬂected on the purpose of the game as:
The ﬁshing game will help the children concretely practice acting responsibly in nature
through play and adopting a sustainable lifestyle at the same time. In addition to the sea
creatures, we made garbage for the ﬁshing game that can also be ﬁshed. The game is easy
to apply with all ages, due to its versatility and adaptability.
