Fishing game. The ﬁshing rods have magnets that pick up the sea creatures
and the trash. For safety reasons (small parts) the game is suitable for children above three years
and only when playing with adults. Photos Väänänen (2023)
The students also connected the game to the content areas of early childhood
education, especially the theme of environmental education. The goal of environ-
mental education is to strengthen children’s relationship with nature, and to guide
them to act responsibly in the environment and towards a sustainable lifestyle.
Group 3 had two students. Goal 4—Quality education—acted as a source of inspi-
ration for this group. The students were concerned with mathematics skills and took
developing mathematical skills as a centre for their project. These students, in fact,
made a set of mathematics education toys and games. One of the toys was ﬁnger
puppets with mathematical and story-based characters, such as the number 5 turning
into a fox or the number 2 reassembling a duck or a swan, as we can see from
Photograph 5. The students had done some background research and found that
paying attention to mathematical ﬁgures or numbers with stories can enhance chil-
dren’s attention to these in theme children’s environments (see also Mattinen and
Hannula-Sormunen 2020). The student’s interpretation of this was then realized into
playful ﬁnger puppets that can help visualise the stories and concepts of numbers.
The numbers can also be arranged from the smallest to the largest or vice versa.
Another way that the students’ embodied learning was with a giant dice that can be
rolled to learn numbers and incorporate some physical activity (see Photograph 4).
The students based this idea on the research of Pönkkö and Sääkslahti (2020) arguing
that physical exercise can help children restore, remember, and concretize abstract
concepts.Thestudentshadalsopreparedawoodenscaleforunderstandingtheweight
of objects, and colourful wooden blocks to understand different geometrical forms.
614
N. Väänänen et al.
Photographs 4 and 5
Learning mathematics through games and stories. Photos Väänänen
(2023)
The analysis revealed that the students described their crafting processes
concretely but also about craft theories. The students were reﬂecting on the craft
project through materials, methods and the processes they were created in. All of
them described their crafting process as a holistic process of ideating, designing,
making and evaluating the project. Their descriptions included how the ideation and
design process proceeded and how the initial plans changed or got more precise
during the process.
We noticed the importance of designing. By making a good plan we were able to keep up
with the schedule. Although we noticed that some of our plans did not work in practice, we
still had time to make changes and come up with another solution. Making things together
and ideating together usually brings up better solutions than just designing on your own.
(Group 2)
The actual making part included descriptions of techniques that they learned
through the products they were making during the workshops. They did admit that
making something for the ﬁrst time created a feeling of nervousness, but the determi-
nation to ﬁnish the task weighted more that giving up. This concept was interpreted
from a range of reﬂections for instance these students felt that:
We should have been more precise in measuring as the components were of slightly varied
sizes. But we managed to sand the pieces to equal size and shape. […] The fear of failing
increases when making things for the ﬁrst time with completely new machinery, and you are
expected to succeed at once. However, failure is one part of the creative problem-solving
process and making mistakes should not be feared. (Group 1).
Another realization from the students was that learning is holistic, and not isolated
into individual subjects. In Group 3’s report that focused on Quality education Goal
4 through mathematics education and play, alongside the tools they made during
Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 Goals and Early Childhood …
615
a craft practice, they also highlighted that crafting offers a learning environment
where the holistic approach to learning can be realized. The following example
nicely conceptualizes most of the students’ reﬂections:
We started to think about craft pedagogy from the perspective of our project so that the
products we made could be used as tools for action-based science education in preschool
and also as a source of ideation and inspiration for joint craft and technology projects. The
scale we made could be used as a tool for learning about weighing, mechanics, strength and
materials, for example. With the children, you could come up with ideas and design your
weighing instrument based on these considerations. (Group 3).
5
Discussion
The purpose of this study was to describe and analyse how early childhood teacher
students concretize the Agenda 2030 Goals through crafts in a project-based learning
task and what they learn during the process. The main results of this study were that
using Agenda 2030 Goals as an inspiration for crafting worked well in gamifying
(FNAE 2022) rather serious themes such as Life below water or Quality Education,
in an early childhood teacher education context. Taking these concepts into practice
in early childhood education is on its way.
First, the students got to know the Goals more precisely through their group
work, and they really had to think about how they could concretize these for the
children they taught. Children cannot be blamed or held responsible for previous
generations’ actions, and they can only be educated for future decisions and actions
(see Nussbaum 2011). Therefore, one of the goals in early childhood education is to
learn about the environment, in the environment or for the environment (FNAE 2022;
also, Davies 2010), which was also noticed by the students. For instance, the students
who chose the Goal Life below water were discussing how they could communicate
the importance of sustaining the largest ecosystem (United Nations n.d.; Linhares
and Cavadas 2021). Integrating plastics that do not belong in the oceans as part of
their ﬁshing or identiﬁcation game could lead to conversations with the children
about what belongs in the waters and what we could do so that they do not end
up in the waters. This also linked to the early childhood education goals of ethical
development of the children (see also FNAE 2022).
Secondly, they learned about basic craft skills and a holistic craft process, which
applies to any project-based learning situation with the advantage of embodied
learning (Härkki et al. 2023; Kröger 2016; Väänänen and Pöllänen 2021). Even
though the students discussed the purpose and beneﬁts of crafts for early childhood
development, they did not discuss how they would realize future craft projects with
the children (Rönkkö and Aerila 2013; Walan et al. 2020). What we as teachers and
researchers can learn from this is to ﬁnd ways of conveying the value of crafting
together more punctually with the children. Although the students did not directly
transfer this project into their practice, they did ‘realize that learning by doing is
important’ (Group 2) and found crafting as an important means of learning. They also
noticed that applying crafts in practice in their future job requires becoming familiar
616
N. Väänänen et al.
with techniques and materials. Hence, ‘learning craft skills and getting assurance
for one’s skills ideation and variation gets easier’ (Group 3). Therefore, the teacher
themselves must be equipped with the necessary skills for their work. We hope that
this course was able to bring them a positive experience and offer them the conﬁdence
to continue crafting in their future jobs with children.
6
Conclusions
The results of the study showed that playing, imagination and stories incorpo-
rated into conceptual learning such as mathematics, linguistics, or semiotics. Hence,
naming, together with tactile and haptic senses, movement, and group activities are
seen to enhance learning (see also Rönkkö and Aerila 2013; Vartiainen and Kumpu-
lainen 2019; Lindfors et al. 2021). This means that crafts education in early childhood
education should be emphasized more to promote creativity in solving problems
(Karlson Häikiö 2018; Boyd 2020). Since there are indications that crafts, espe-
cially technology education, are sometimes neglected in early childhood education
(Juutinen et al. 2021; Karila and Leikola 2022), we need to encourage pre-service
teachers to become familiar with variety of techniques and materials to be comfort-
able to pass these skills in practice. More importantly, learning the method of holistic
crafting process (Rönkkö 2011; Kröger 2016) would broaden students’ conceptions
of crafting, and direct them to discover and use materials and methods innovatively
already in ECE context (see also FNAE 2022). We also conclude that the learning
method, an open-ended learning task approached in co-creation learning process
(Kangas et al. 2022; Härkki et al. 2023), was enhancing the students understanding
about both sustainability (Davies 2010; Boyd and McLeod 2021; Leal Filho and Pace
2016) and crafts education in early childhood context (Karlson Häikiö 2018; Yliver-
ronen et al. 2021). Future research could view teaching practices in early childhood
environments, for instance, by viewing how teachers incorporate crafts and sustain-
ability education in practice. For a sustainable future, we need to be able to imagine,
play with thoughts, design, and try different solutions with a little encouragement,
know the boundaries of the material world, and ﬁnd the best solution to get the job
done, and also look back in reﬂection at what could be done better.

Promoting Renewable Energy Research
in Brazilian Higher Education
Institutions: A Vision Aligned
with Sustainable Development Goals
Luana de Aguiar Vieira, Henrique de Souza Medeiros,
Ana Regina de Aguiar Dutra, Anelise Leal Vieira Cubas, Robert Birch,
and José Baltazar Salgueirinho Osório de Andrade Guerra
Abstract Initiatives to promote the integration of research in renewable energies in
Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) in Brazil are crucial steps toward building an
ecosystem capable of contributing to the sustainability and economic development
of the country. HEIs can play a crucial role in advancing society towards sustain-
able development with their fundamental pillars, structured in teaching, research,
extension, leadership, and innovation activities. Therefore, education emerges as a
positive inﬂuence on energy policies, highlighting the importance of educational
investments as an essential part of the strategy to promote sustainable development.
In this sense, this article seeks to provide an overview of the actions adopted, both
directly and indirectly, by HEIs in many countries that promote the study and applica-
tion of renewable energies on their campuses, academic communities, and so forth.
The article also highlights actions and policies that have shown good results and/
or need to be implemented to advance sustainable goals. Examples from two HEIs
located in the Brazilian state of Santa Catarina, show how their actions and strategies

Keywords Renewable energy · Research · Higher Education Institution (HEI) ·

1
Introduction
The concept of sustainable development has increasingly captured the attention of
the academic community and professionals, a trend signiﬁcantly inﬂuenced by the
publication of the Brundtland Report by the United Nations World Commission on
EnvironmentandDevelopmentin1987(Brundtland1987).Thisseminalreport,high-
lighting the interdependence of economic, social, and environmental sustainability,
has played a pivotal role in shaping the contemporary understanding of sustainable
development. It posits that sustainable development meets the needs of the present
without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs,
laying the groundwork for the widespread adoption and integration of sustainability
principles across various sectors (Wasiluk 2013).
Climate change has demanded technological innovations and forms of manage-
ment to solve complex problems related mainly to environmental impacts. According
to the Sixth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
(IPCC 2022) on environmental impacts, the world is expected to reach the peak
of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in 2025, considering the growth of industrial
activities and exponential increase in the world’s population. In this sense, the Inter-
governmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC 2022) states that, in order to reverse
this reality, decision-makers from governments, civil society, and the private sector
must act for the planet and take sustainable actions to mitigate the negative effects
on the environment and reduce GHG emissions urgently.
The study by Zhang et al. (2018) explores the determinants inﬂuencing the formu-
lation of renewable energy and energy efﬁciency policies across a broad array of
countries. Their analysis reveals a positive correlation between factors such as educa-
tion level, the extent of globalization policies, and domestic credit availability, and
the enactment of comprehensive energy policies. In contrast, the abundance of per
capita oil reserves is found to negatively affect the adoption of renewable energy
policies. Notably, the study underscores the signiﬁcant role of globalization policies
in promoting both renewable energy and energy efﬁciency initiatives. The ﬁndings
suggest that countries’ active participation in international political organizations
plays a pivotal role in creating an enabling environment for the progression of
energy policies. Zhang et al. (2018) conclude that deeper engagement with inter-
national bodies can provide strategic avenues for governments to advance future
energy policy initiatives.
Promoting Renewable Energy Research in Brazilian Higher Education …
623
Public policies play a key role in establishing guidelines and strategies to achieve
the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), with emphasis on collective and indi-
vidual actions towards global sustainability, encouraging practices and measures
that aim to reduce the impacts of climate change. In this context, the transition to
renewable energy sources is urgent and requires not only signiﬁcant investments in
infrastructure, but also the contribution of Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) to
the transformation of society through their research groups and infrastructures for the
generation of knowledge. In their role as a trainer of professionals to potentially work
in different areas aligned with sustainability, such as renewable energies, and energy
efﬁciency, HEIs are able to meet the collective challenge of building the collaboration
between different sectors of society, i.e., between government, industry, academia,
and the community at large.
The study carried out by Leal Filho et al. (2019) investigates the engagement of
50 higher education institutions worldwide in energy efﬁciency measures and their
use of renewable energy sources. The ﬁndings reveal a modest reliance on renewable
energy across the majority of these institutions, with 1–20% of their energy consump-
tion being derived from renewable sources, predominantly solar/photovoltaic energy,
which accounts for about 70% of this share. Furthermore, approximately 54% of
the surveyed universities demonstrated a signiﬁcant commitment to transitioning
towards renewable energy, especially within their buildings (78%) and equipment/
machinery (56%). This research underscores the imperative of sustainable energy
use on campuses striving for sustainability, highlighting gaps in the current energy
initiatives of HEIs. Leal Filho et al. (2019) emphasize the need for enhanced commit-
ment and more comprehensive strategies in the adoption of renewable energy within
the academic sector.
HEIs are recognized as key catalysts for advancements in energy and sustain-
ability policies. Their mandate extends beyond the mere education of professionals;
there exists an imperative for HEIs to actively engage in research and development
aimed at the practical implementation of innovative energy solutions within their own
infrastructure. This dual approach not only reinforces the commitment of academic
institutions to sustainability but also serves as a living laboratory for sustainable prac-
tices. The research by Zhang et al. (2018) further elucidates the instrumental role of
education in bolstering energy policies. It demonstrates that enhancements in educa-
tional outcomes can indirectly foster a conducive environment for the evolution and
adoption of robust energy policies. This insight suggests that increased investments
in education by countries can serve as a strategic mechanism to indirectly support
the future development and reﬁnement of energy policies. In this context, the article
discusses the correlation between HEIs, SDGs, carbon emissions, and renewable
energies, highlighting the role of HEIs on these issues and presenting successful
actions and some case studies.
624
L. de Aguiar Vieira et al.
2
Theoretical Background
In the theoretical framework of this study, we will systematically explore the intricate
connections between HEIs and theSDGs, focusing on their pivotal role in addressing
carbon emissions and advancing the use of renewable energies. This examination
seeks to elucidate the critical contributions of HEIs in fostering sustainability, high-
lighting how they can act as catalysts for change by integrating sustainable practices
into their operations, research, and educational mandates. The framework will draw
upon existing literature and theoretical models to analyze the potential of HEIs to
inﬂuence and drive progress towards achieving global sustainability targets, thereby
underscoring the signiﬁcance of academic institutions in the global sustainability
agenda.
2.1
Higher Education Institutions and the Sustainable
Development Goals
Contemporary society’s approach to natural resources—as mere sources of raw mate-
rials and waste repositories—has precipitated environmental degradation that now
represents a civilizational crisis, jeopardizing the sustainability of life on Earth (Leff
2006). In response to this dire situation, the international community has proposed
various strategies to mitigate such impacts, among which the 2030 Agenda for
Sustainable Development stands out prominently. Unveiled at the United Nations
Summit on Sustainable Development in 2015, this agenda delineates a comprehen-
sive plan of action to be pursued over the ensuing decade, aiming to address and
rectify these environmental challenges (UNSDN 2017).
The pursuit of SDGs encapsulated in the 2030 Agenda extends across all societal
strata, with HEIs playing a crucial role. These institutions are actively exploring
and implementing initiatives geared towards the SDGs’ realization, reﬂecting on
their pivotal social responsibility. The discourse on how universities and the scien-
tiﬁc community can effectively contribute to achieving these SDGs is increasingly
becoming a focal point of academic inquiry and action (Buckeridge and Philippi Jr
2020).
HEIs have their structural pillars based in teaching, research, extension, lead-
ership, and innovation which are a fundamental part of driving society’s progress
towards sustainable development (Ribeiro et al. 2021; Seraﬁm and Leite 2021).
According to Zhang et al. (2018), education is one of the most important prac-
tices capable of exerting a positive inﬂuence and, consequently, improvements on
energy policies. These authors also highlight the importance of countries considering
investments in education as a mandatory item in the strategy to promote sustainable
development. More than this, the results of the same study indicate that the training
given by academics in a HEI, which only results in the improvement of the economic
position of the individual, implies that the growth of gross domestic product (GDP)
Promoting Renewable Energy Research in Brazilian Higher Education …
625
per capita does not automatically present a strong correlation with the improve-
ment of actions that can foster sustainable development in a region. In other words,
socioeconomic development alone is not enough to ensure behaviour in line with
sustainable practices.
In this context, the universities are identiﬁed as vital centers for knowledge gener-
ation and dissemination, where the interplay among research, teaching, and commu-
nity engagement is foundational to the cultivation of comprehensive strategies for
sustainability. These institutions are uniquely positioned to lead by example in the
implementation of concrete actions toward achieving the SDGs. Central to their
mission is the imperative to prioritize educational excellence, equipping students
not only with the knowledge but also with the critical skills and motivation needed
to engage with and contribute to the SDGs. This approach aligns with the aims of
‘education for sustainable development’ (SDG 4), advocating for an educational
paradigm that integrates sustainability principles across all learning and teaching
activities (Kestin et al. 2017).
2.2
Higher Education Institutions and Carbon Emissions
Barron et al. (2021) point out that the commitment to carbon neutrality is one of the
clearest strategies adopted by world leaders to tackle the climate crisis. As of 2020, at
least 25 national governments and the European Union have committed to achieving
net carbon neutrality by 2050. These individual commitments can help align global
emissions to a pathway that can keep global temperature rise well below 2 °C, as
envisioned in the Paris Agreement.
Abdullah and Muhammad (2023) underscore the inadequacy of current govern-
mental policies in curbing the adverse impacts of human activities on the climate
system. Against this backdrop, the research highlights the pivotal role of non-state
actors, including both non-proﬁt and for-proﬁt organizations, in championing climate
action and signiﬁcantly contributing to the reduction of carbon emissions. These
entities have been instrumental in introducing innovative decarbonization strategies,
signaling a commitment to transitioning towards a low or zero-carbon economy.
Practices such as the adoption of internal carbon pricing, procurement of electricity
from renewable sources, pledges towards carbon neutrality, and the setting of ambi-
tious climate mitigation goals aligned with limiting global temperature rise to below
2 °C, exemplify their proactive engagement in addressing climate challenges. This
body of work by Abdullah and Muhammad (2023) illuminates the critical contri-
bution of the non-state sector in advancing effective climate solutions, challenging
policymakers to recognize and support these initiatives in the broader framework of
climate governance.
Regarding the actions of HEIs as an active agent in the reduction of carbon emis-
sions, for example, in 2006 leaders of several HEIs in the USA joined at the forefront
of the Climate Commitment of the Presidents of American Colleges and Universities
organisation; a movement which was brought together to develop goals and plans
626
L. de Aguiar Vieira et al.
to achieve carbon neutrality “as soon as possible”. These early commitments to the
ambitious goal of carbon neutrality make this sector unique in the USA. As a way
to make it more agile and economically viable, the strategy of establishing, ﬁrst, a
chain of suppliers that adopt practices to reduce carbon emissions was highlighted.
A second strategy was the adoption of greener campuses, aiming at sequestering a
carbon equivalence to their emissions and ultimately seeking to achieve net carbon
neutrality. This strategy reﬂects a balance between the need for continuous oper-
ations and environmental responsibility, although there is much discussion about
the effectiveness of this approach, since decarbonization has not yet been achieved
(IPCC 2018; Barron et al. 2021).
As outlined in a study conducted by Wiryadinata et al. (2019), emissions inherent
to renewable energy systems throughout their life cycle primarily stem from the
construction, transportation, and decommissioning phases, intrinsically linked to
the use of fossil fuel-powered equipment. Emissions over the life cycle of these
renewable systems prove advantageous compared to fossil systems, ranging from a
40% variation in the highest emissions to 1% in the lowest, potentially reaching up
to 975 gCO2/kWh. Among the various renewable systems analyzed, it is noteworthy
that biomass power plants require signiﬁcantly more land area per megawatt (MW)
capacity while also contributing to the creation of the largest job contingent. This
phenomenon is attributed to biomass-related activities such as raw material collection
and transportation, plant operation, and product disposal. It is worth highlighting that
when biomass residues are used as raw materials, a biomass power plant can exhibit
a carbon sequestration effect, resulting in net negative emissions over the life cycle.
This perspective underscores the complexity and varied ramiﬁcations associated
with different renewable systems, not only in environmental contexts but also in
socio-economic dimensions.
In this context, these same authors argue that the implementation of an infrastruc-
ture based on renewable energies in its different forms (solar, photovoltaic, wind,
etc.) can contribute substantially to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by HEIs.
According to Dyer and Dyer (2017), by adopting an approach to promote sustainable
practices, HEIs can play a vital role in the successful implementation of renewable
energy strategies around the world.
2.3
Higher Education Institutions and Renewable Energies
In order to address the contemporary climate challenges caused by global warming,
there is a growing emphasis on the search for renewable energies and technologies
aimed at minimizing environmental impacts. A signiﬁcant example of this move-
ment can be found in the automotive sector, which has dedicated notable efforts to
replacing combustion engine vehicles with electric models (Arangues et al. 2022).
In Brazil, for example, the transportation sector emerges as the main source of CO2
emissions, being responsible for 210.4 million tons of carbon dioxide equivalent
(MTCO2e) in 2022 (Brasil 2023). This shift in focus highlights the urgency of
Promoting Renewable Energy Research in Brazilian Higher Education …
627
addressing GHG emissions and the need for transitions to more sustainable and
eco-conscious technologies.
Approximately 70% of the planet’s CO2 emissions come from oil or coal ﬁred
power plants and the transport sector (United Nation 2021; Zheng and Peng,
2021; IPCC 2022). This establishes a direct connection between the commitment
to preserving the climate and the need to carry out a comprehensive and rapid
transformation of the energy production system, directing it towards scalable and
emission-free sources such as solar, wind and nuclear energy (Yates 2018). This
move highlights the crucial importance of adopting more sustainable and environ-
mentally friendly energy sources, reinforcing the urgency of an effective transition
to mitigate the adverse impacts of GHG emissions.
According to the Global Wind Energy Council (GWEC 2023), the COVID-19
Pandemic and the current situation of the conﬂict between Russia and Ukraine
triggered a prolonged period of high energy prices on a global scale. This shows
that we are facing a signiﬁcant energy crisis, the result of a late transition between
energy production and capture technologies, leaving energy markets susceptible to
and dependent on fossil fuels. In response to this crisis, governments around the
world have been implementing measures to accelerate this transition, setting ambi-
tious targets for the phase-out of technologies based on non-renewable fuels and
prioritizing clean generation in both industry and transport. However, Bosman and
Chelberg (2019) point out that the development and promotion of renewable energy
technologies are inseparable from public support and talent training.
Currently, the absence of qualiﬁed professionals with innovative awareness and
skills in technologies for Renewable Energy Sources (RES) represents a consider-
able obstacle to its promotion (Lucas et al. 2018; Ciriminna et al. 2023). Education
emerges as an effective means to foster public awareness and achieve higher levels
of professionalism in this ﬁeld (Afkar et al. 2019; Lee et al. 2013). While research
indicates that most peoplehaveabasicunderstandingof theenergycrisis andenviron-
mental pollution, it is crucial to strengthen the sensitivity of this awareness through
educational initiatives. Therefore, improving people’s awareness through education
represents an effective strategy to overcome barriers related to the promotion and
innovative application of RES (Guven and Sulun 2017). The incorporation of educa-
tional programs that emphasize the importance of renewable energies and stimulate
innovation in the sector emerges as a fundamental element in the formation of a
solid base of conscious and qualiﬁed professionals. This approach will not only
assist in overcoming today’s challenges but also pave the way for a sustainable and
energy-efﬁcient future.
Renewable energy is deﬁned as energy derived from natural processes that are
continuously replenished or possess the ability to regenerate within a human lifespan.
This category includes a diverse array of sources such as solar, wind, biomass,
geothermal, hydroelectric, tidal, and biofuels, which are considered inexhaustible
due to their sustainable regeneration capabilities (Scholten and Bosman 2013). Rocha
(2024) further reﬁnes this deﬁnition by characterizing renewable energy as stemming
from natural resources that can be utilized at levels sustainable for production and
consumption, thereby maintaining a balanced cycle without depleting the source.
628
L. de Aguiar Vieira et al.
These sources, predominantly non-fossil based, align with the principles of sustain-
able development by supporting a harmonious relationship between energy usage
and natural regeneration. However, as Dunlap (2015) notes, while renewable energy
contributes to sustainability by leveraging environmentally friendly processes, it is
not inherently synonymous with ‘clean energy.’ The distinction lies in the envi-
ronmental impacts associated with the production and use of these energy forms,
emphasizing the need for a nuanced understanding of renewable energy’s role in
fostering a sustainable future.
Fundamentally, since the 1970s, HEIs in several countries have promoted educa-
tional programs with certain levels of content and actions that emphasise renewable
energies in their curriculum matrices (Ehrlich and Geller 2017). However, Wang and
Guo (2021) believe that a review of the teaching process seems necessary to have a
more effective training in the promotion of RES and proposes that it be carried out
based on three pillars: design, teaching, and evaluation process.
HEIs deal with renewable energies mainly in their Graduate Programs in an envi-
ronment where in-depth research projects take place with students and professors
specialized in the subject. However, because of the interdisciplinary nature of the
subject, content with different approaches and objectives on renewable energies
can be incorporated into academic programs that exist already at the undergraduate
level. This can have a very signiﬁcant effect on the individual student’s continuity in
specializing in areas of knowledge related to renewable energies. HEIs around the
world already adopt approaches that involve renewable energies in their undergrad-
uate courses at various levels of teaching, research (scientiﬁc initiation and course
completion work), and extension.
3
Renewable Energy Research on Brazilian Higher
Education Institutions
In Brazil, many HEIs, through their research groups and Graduate Programs, have
dedicated themselves to research on the theme of renewable energies as a way to
contribute to energy efﬁciency and the reduction of GHG emissions. Avila et al.
(2019) highlighted measures to make climate change more present in research and
university teaching. To further corroborate, Matana Júnior et al. (2023), researchers
from the University of Passo Fundo/Brazil, reported that Brazilian HEIs, listed in
the UI GreenMetric 2020 Ranking, commonly adopt sustainable practices related
to lighting and renovation of air conditioning systems to ensure energy efﬁciency.
As for renewable energy generation, solar photovoltaic (PV) is the most common
practice used by HEIs. Moura-Leite et al. (2023) studied the Brazilian federal univer-
sities regarding compliance with the Sustainable Logistics Management Plan that is
mandatory for public agencies, where electricity was the most addressed topic in the
reports on these HEIs.
Promoting Renewable Energy Research in Brazilian Higher Education …
629
3.1
Case 1: Catholic University Center of Santa Catarina/
PUCSC and Its Research on Renewable Energies
In the State of Santa Catarina, there are also mobilizations of HEIs towards studies
on renewable energies. The ﬁrst example comes from the Catholic University Centre
of Santa Catarina/PUCSC, located in Jaraguá do Sul, Santa Catarina. Content with
an emphasis on renewable energies is already part of the curriculum of the Electrical
Engineering and Mechanical Engineering courses where both theoretical and prac-
tical aspects are covered. The city of Jaraguá do Sul is the cradle of a multinational
industry that manufactures components and carries out the assembly, installation and
activation of PV and wind energy plants around the world. This provides incentive
for students and researchers to study in this ﬁeld of renewable energies. Developing
the relationship with this sector is fundamental for renewable energies to gain more
and more space in the curricular matrices of HEIs and research groups.
Catholic University Centre of Santa Catarina/PUCSC has a research group, called
SUSTENTARE, which is fundamentally based on renewable energies distributed in
lines such as: sustainable materials, energy efﬁciency, wind energy and photovoltaic
solar energy, and has a laboratory equipped with PV panels, a wind turbine, with its
control systems, and a wind tunnel. After strengthening joint actions between the
institution’s management and researchers, it was possible to identify gains in the
integral training of students, whether to work in the job market or to participate in
research groups and to enter Graduate Programs to study for a higher degree.
3.2
Case 2: University of Southern Santa Catarina (Unisul)
and Its Research on Renewable Energies
Also noteworthy in Santa Catarina is the University of Southern Santa Catarina
(Unisul), which promotes, within the scope of its research groups and Graduate
Programs, cutting-edge actions and research in the context of renewable energies. In
2015, the German-led 4-year REGSA Project (Electricity Generation from Renew-
able Sources in Latin America) sought to increase the share of renewable energy
production in Bolivia, Brazil, and Chile. This Unisul project, which was conducted
by its Centre for Sustainable Development (GREENS), was linked to the Graduate
Program in Administration and provided the installation of PV panels in a school
located in a remote rural area that became the ﬁrst solar school in Brazil (Berchin
et al. 2015). In 2016, in conjunction with the Energy Efﬁciency Program of the Santa
Catarina Power Plants, Unisul replaced more than 1000 ﬂuorescent lamps with LED
and installed PV panels for the generation of clean energy.
These examples demonstrate the role of HEIs in the direction of their studies
and practices related to renewable energies, through teaching at its different levels
(undergraduate, lato and stricto sensu), extension and through its research groups
630
L. de Aguiar Vieira et al.
whose aims are to mitigate the effects of GHG emissions and are aligned with the
SDGs, especially SDGs 7 and 13.
4
Conclusions
There is a challenge in ﬁnding qualiﬁed human resources to progress the specialised
ﬁeld of sustainable development. Clearly, HEIs can play a crucial role in advancing
society towards sustainable development with their fundamental pillars, structured in
teaching, research, extension, leadership, and innovation activities. Therefore, educa-
tion emerges as a positive inﬂuence on energy policies, highlighting the importance
of educational investments as an essential part of the strategy to promote sustainable
development. However, it is essential to emphasize that the strengthening of HEIs
should not be limited to economic improvements but should be intrinsically linked
to the promotion of practices that drive local and global sustainable development.
In promoting sustainable practices, HEIs play a vital role in the successful imple-
mentation of renewable energy strategies around the world. A review of the teaching
process, focusing on the pillars of design, teaching, and evaluation, reveals the need
for more effective training in the promotion of renewable energy. The inclusion of
content on renewable energies in undergraduate and graduate courses, as well as the
promotion of practical approaches, are essential to the training of professionals who
are aware and prepared to face the challenges of climate change, particularly those
derived from GHG emissions resulting from energy inefﬁciency.
Finally, HEIs also play a multifaceted and strategic role in promoting sustainable
practices and advancing RES. By integrating content, practices, and partnerships with
the industrial sector, these institutions not only prepare professionals for current
challenges, but also contribute signiﬁcantly to building a sustainable and energy-
efﬁcient future. Continuous commitment to innovation, research, and education is
essential to consolidate the role of HEIs as catalysts for sustainable development on
a global scale.
Therefore, it’s possible to designing an agenda for future sustainability goals based
on Renewable Energy in HEIs by the following proposed points:
(i) Establishing research groups with adequate infrastructure and specialized
professors in the ﬁeld,
(ii) Collaboration between different departments such as Engineering, Business
Administration, Law, and others,
(iii) Forming partnerships with industries of the region to drive and support research
projects and internships, and
(iv) Developing education and awareness programs for the academic community
and society.

An Agenda for Research
on Sustainability Reporting: Europe
and Beyond
Josef Baumüller, Michaela-Maria Schaffhauser-Linzatti, and Karina Sopp
Abstract Recent years have seen a consolidation of existing sustainability reporting
standards as well as the emergence of new players on that ﬁeld of regulation. In
particular, the publication of the ﬁrst European Sustainability Reporting Standards
in Europe (ESRS) and IFRS Sustainability Disclosure Standards (IFRS SDS) as
the intended “global baseline” for sustainability reporting attracted considerable
attention. The new regulatory environment for corporations in Europe as well as
in other jurisdictions is subject to drastic changes. But while the (political) ambi-
tions behind these developments are very similar, new questions arise with regard to
different approaches that are taken and potential obstacles that prevent actors from
achieving the aims. This chapter outlines these developments and some of the ques-
tions they evoke. It summarises some of the underlying assumptions of European and
international regulators that will now be put to an empirical test. Its results should
inform any further regulatory ambitions and thus contribute to the aim of changing
corporate behaviour, thus transforming business models and supporting sustainable
development.
Keywords Sustainability reporting · European Sustainability Reporting Standards
(ESRS) · Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) · IFRS Sustainability Disclosure
Standards (IFRS SDS)
J. Baumüller (B)
Institute of Management Science, Technical University of Vienna, Theresianumgasse 27, 1040
Vienna, Austria

M.-M. Schaffhauser-Linzatti
Department of Accounting, Innovation and Strategy, University of Vienna, Wasagasse 12/2/1,
1090 Vienna, Austria
K. Sopp
Entrepreneurship and Business Taxation, Technical University of Freiberg, Schlossplatz 1, 09599
Freiberg, Germany

W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_35

636
J. Baumüller et al.
1
Introduction
Whilst the origins of sustainability reporting can be traced back to the second half of
the 20th century, the publication of the ﬁrst set of guidelines by the Global Reporting
Initiative (GRI) 1999/2000 is considered as marking the point in time when this
reporting concept was fully formulated (United Nations Environment Programme
(UNEP) 2019; Larrinaga and Bebbington 2021). As these guidelines were further
developed over the next two decades, they were taken up by large, mostly publicly
traded companies around the world. In many cases, this uptake was driven by volun-
tary practices; mandatory legislation was still more the exception then the rule (Chris-
tensen et al. 2021). The great ﬂexibility granted to companies because of their volun-
tary adoption, together with the increasing availability of more frameworks and stan-
dards, however, harmed the overall effectiveness of the reports published. This, in
turn, often raised concerns about “greenwashing practices” in which these companies
can indulge (Marquis et al. 2016; Gatti et al. 2019; Vigneau and Adams 2023).
In the early 2010s, this regulatory environment slowly started to change. The
ﬁnancial crisis in 2008/2009 highlighted a need for the stronger regulation of corpo-
rations to protect ﬁnancial markets and avoid the risk of “short termism” (Kinderman
2020). In the wake of the Paris Climate Conference and the publication of the Sustain-
able Development Goals in 2015, a global consensus was achieved that more efforts
were needed in the ﬁeld of sustainability regulation and that corporations should be
required to contribute more to sustainable development (United Nations Environ-
ment Programme (UNEP) 2015). This culminated in the creation of a sustainable
ﬁnance agenda to help give greater weight to sustainability when ﬁnancing decisions
are made on capital markets; at the same time, the agenda requires increased efforts
to be made to enhance the transparency of corporations’ sustainability performance
to allow appropriate capital allocation to take place (Migliorelli 2021).
This global development changed the business environment in which corpora-
tions operate around the world, both with regard to increasing stakeholder expecta-
tions and to the adoption of a regulatory framework. In the European Union, these
changes materialised at the highest pace: By 2018, the EU Commission had already
published its Action Plan on “Financing Sustainable Growth” which supports efforts
to implement the principles of sustainable ﬁnance in the EU capital market. Only
one year later, the Green Deal expressed the ambition of the newly elected European
Commission to establish the jurisdiction as a global forerunner in pursuing the goal
of sustainable development. Amongst all the different measures cited in these publi-
cations, corporate sustainability reporting played a vital role in achieving the political
aims (Baumüller and Grbenic 2021; Chiu 2022; Zetzsche and Anker-Sørensen 2022).
These efforts resulted in work on the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Direc-
tive (CSRD), which was ultimately published in 2022, and in the European Sustain-
ability Reporting Standards (ESRS) introduced by the CSRD to provide European
corporations with detailed and binding guidelines to direct their reporting. Many
considered this to be a “game changer”, presenting companies with ﬁnancial chal-
lenges by imposing considerable costs on them as well as operational challenges by
An Agenda for Research on Sustainability Reporting: Europe and Beyond
637
requiring an unprecedented level of transparency on sustainability matters in corpo-
rate reporting (e.g. Grabs and Stuchtey 2023). However, opinions differ regarding
whether the CSRD and ESRS have led to competitive advantages or disadvantages
for European corporations.
Thirdcountriesfollowedsuitebymakingsimilar,althoughlessfar-reachingdevel-
opments. Concerning the introduction of reporting requirements, these developments
were in many cases driven by the eminence of a new organisation that set bench-
marks for standards in the ﬁeld of sustainability reporting: the IFRS (International
Financial Reporting Standards) Foundation. In 2020, this foundation proposed to
create a new set of detailed international sustainability reporting standards based on
the IFRS. This move was not only greeted by considerable support from around the
globe, but also changed the landscape of such reporting standards. Currently, capital
market regulators as well as many jurisdictions outside of the European Union have
announced their intention to adopt these international reporting standards, namely
the IFRS Sustainability Disclosure Standards (IFRS SDS).
As a result, sustainability reporting is increasingly moving from a voluntary prac-
tice to a legal requirement. And the landscape for the standards on which these reports
are based is subject to harmonisation and subsequently centring around three impor-
tant sets of standards: the ESRS, the IFRS SDS, and the GRI standards. The latter
served as an important starting point for the work on the former two sets of standards
and are still most often used by corporations around the world (KPMG 2022).
These important changes also imply that contributions from researchers are
needed to support those setting standards, legislators and corporations that are
required to translate the new reporting requirements into practice. This chapter ﬁrst
outlines the key features of the future landscape for sustainability reporting. A Euro-
pean perspective is highlighted, taking into consideration the global developments
and their unavoidable implications for European companies. Subsequently, impor-
tant research questions that arise from recent developments are outlined. Finally, a
summary and an outlook conclude this chapter.
2
The Changed Landscape for Sustainability
Reporting—An Overview
2.1
CSRD and ESRS: Mandatory Requirements Driven
by High Ambitions
In the EU, the CSRD (published in 2022) replaced the reporting requirements deﬁned
in the Non-Financial Reporting Directive (NFRD) from 2014. The NFRD was once
considered a milestone in corporate reporting and established mandatory sustain-
ability reporting requirements across the European Union. But its shortcomings
soon became obvious: Its application has not resulted in the completeness, compara-
bility, or reliability of data that has been reported by European companies (European
638
J. Baumüller et al.
Commission 2021; Baboukardos et al. 2023). The main drivers for these deﬁcits
were found to be a limited scope of application, vague and unspeciﬁed reporting
requirements, and a lack of external assurance requirements. Differences in the legal
incorporaton of the Directive into national law in the Union’s member states also
contributed to these issues (European Commission 2020).
Whilst developing the CSRD, the European Commission tried to address these
shortcomings and thus create a more ambitious regulatory framework that meets
the demands of the newly adopted sustainable ﬁnance agenda. Regarding the many
aspects where the CSRD introduced new requirements, one stands out due to its
important role in the entire reform process: the concept of “double materiality”. By
introducing this concept in the regulatory framework, the European Commission
strove to ensure that corporations not only report on sustainability matters that are
relevant for their business models but also consider all their material impacts on
environment and society, even if these do not ﬁnancially impact their operations.
Furthermore, the CSRD was developed to encourage companies to report on how they
address all these impacts in their governance, strategy and operations. This implies
that the reporting content has an extensive scope (Baumüller and Sopp 2022). On
an abstract level, this directive ultimately reﬂects different approaches that can be
taken to achieve sustainability: to fulﬁl a moral obligation (impacts on environment
and society), to meet a business requirement (ﬁnancial impacts), or to satisfy the
combination of these (Allen and Craig 2016).
The CSRD extends the scope of reporting corporations have to do on their sustain-
ability performance to encompass all large corporations based in the European Union.
In addition, under certain conditions, non-EU groups and corporations also have to
apply the CSRD regulations. Whilst the ﬁrst corporations that are subject to the
directive will have to publish their reports for the ﬁnancial year 2024, the scope is
slowly being extended up to the ﬁnancial year 2028. According to the CSRD, sustain-
ability reports have to be included in the management commentary, be published in
a digital format and will be subject to an external review by auditors or other assur-
ance providers. Corporations failing to meet the new reporting requirements will
be subject to penalties speciﬁed by the member states; these should be similar to
penalties imposed due to deﬁcits in their ﬁnancial reports.
The CSRD introduces ESRS into the regulatory framework. The ESRS have a
structure similar to that of established standards, such as the GRI’s standards for
sustainability reporting, but also the IFRS in the context of ﬁnancial reporting. These
standards were designed to provide clearer and more comprehensive guidance for
corporations that fall under the jurisdiction of the new reporting requirements. Only
the basic structure of these standards, their fundamental principles, and the most
important sustainability topics to be covered are laid out in the CSRD.
The European Commission tasked the EFRAG (formerly the “European Financial
Reporting Advisory Group”) to develop drafts for the ESRS. The EFRAG is an
association initially set up to advise the Commission during the process of adopting
the IFRS into European law; given its expertise in setting standard processes, it was
considered as the most suitable partner for supporting the development of standards
for sustainability reporting. However, due to the lack of public authority, the ESRS
An Agenda for Research on Sustainability Reporting: Europe and Beyond
639
(drafts) subsequently had to be endorsed by the European Commission in the form
of delegated acts to become legally binding in the EU member states.
Set 1 of the ESRS was formally adopted by the European Commission on
July 31, 2023. These standards consist of twelve sector-agnostic standards, cate-
gorised as either cross-cutting standards or topical standards on ESG matters. These
contain reporting requirements for European corporations regarding their ﬁrst reports
published. However, these requirements also refer to other standards that have to be
considered, and most importantly the IFRS SDS (see Sect. 2.2) and the GRI stan-
dards (see Sect. 2.3). In the next few years, the EFRAG will be tasked with improving
the previously issued ESRS and developing new standards, including SME-speciﬁc
standards by the end of 2024 and sector-speciﬁc standards by mid-2026.
2.2
IFRS SDS: The New “Global Baseline”
for Sustainability Reporting
Whilst the European Commission started its project to replace the NFRD with the
CSRD in early 2020, the IFRS Foundation raised eyebrows when it published a
discussion paper on extending its activities into the ﬁeld of sustainability reporting
in September of the same year (IFRS Foundation 2020). Motivated by a perceived
demand on the market for a set of globally harmonised standards as well as by its
experience in setting standards, the IFRS Foundation suggested establishing a new
International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB). This Board is tasked with devel-
oping sustainability reporting standards in close collaboration with the International
Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and with extending the existing standards and
initiatives in the ﬁeld of sustainability reporting.
In its initial outline of the suggested standards, the IFRS Foundation already made
clear that its understanding of sustainability report content differed from that of the
ESRS. So, instead of taking a double materiality approach, the IFRS Foundation
favoured the concept of single materiality, establishing investors as the main audience
for the new standards. They also formulated a “climate-ﬁrst approach”, arguing that
climate-related disclosures should be published ﬁrst and that reporting standards on
other sustainability matters should be subsequently prioritised.
The ISSB was formally established in November 2021 at COP26 in Glasgow. At
the same time, the consolidation of the US-American Value Reporting Foundation
(VRF) and the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) into the IFRS Founda-
tion was announced. Consequently, the IFRS Foundation took on the responsibility
for the reporting standards maintained by these organisations, and most importantly
the sustainability reporting standards of the Sustainability Accounting Standards
Board (SASB) and the International Integrated Reporting Framework by the Inter-
national Integrated Reporting Council (IIRC). This approach was taken to form the
basis for the work on the IFRS SDS and support their harmonisation efforts with the
IFRS, tasks which could be streamlined because resources were taken over from both
640
J. Baumüller et al.
the VRF and the CDSB. Regarding the impact of this consolidation on the corporate
reporting landscape, Forbes magazine dubbed this as “the biggest change in corpo-
rate reporting since the 1930s” (Mirchandani 2021), referring to similar attempts at
collaboration between U.S. American and international organisations to set standards
in the ﬁeld of ﬁnancial reporting that have failed for decades.
In June 2023, the ﬁrst two standards developed by the ISSB were published:
IFRS S1 and IFRS S2. The former deﬁnes general reporting principles whilst the
latter addresses climate-related disclosures. Because they incorporated the SASB
standards, the IFRS SDS refer to the SASB sector-speciﬁc disclosure requirements
thatcomplementthegeneralreportingrequirementsofIFRSS2.UnliketheESRSand
the GRI standards, the IFRS SDS are already characterised by a strong industry focus.
However, with regard to other ESG matters that are considered to be material from
a single materiality perspective, the IFRS SDS require companies to refer to other,
more comprehensive reporting standards such as the ESRS or the GRI standards.
Most notably, the IFRS SDS lack the legal authority to mandate the application of
their standards to any number of corporations. Therefore, although the IFRS SDS are
applicable from the ﬁnancial year of 2024 and onwards, it is not clear which corpo-
rations will actually apply these standards. However, several jurisdictions—albeit
outside of the European Union—have already announced that they will either adopt
the IFRS SDS or will develop their own set of sustainability reporting standards
based on these standards. What is more, the International Organization of Securities
Commissions (IOSCO) was among the ﬁrst to express its support for the IFRS SDS
and has already endorsed them (International Organization of Securities Commis-
sions (IOSCO) 2023). This could imply that securities market regulators around the
world might impose the requirement of applying the IFRS SDS to listed corporations
in the future.
Against that background, the IFRS Foundation has described its aim to develop the
IFRS SDS into a “global baseline” for sustainability reporting, remarking that “IFRS
Sustainability Disclosure Standards are intended to provide a global baseline and
to be compatible with jurisdiction-speciﬁc requirements, including those intended
to meet broader stakeholder information needs” (IFRS Foundation 2022a). Again,
with regard to the latter reporting requirements, the ESRS and the GRI standards
are especially addressed, thus outlining the ambition for close cooperation between
these sets of standards instead of competition.
2.3
GRI Standards: A Pioneer in Search of Future Directions
The developments that led to the publication of the ESRS and the IFRS SDS put
the GRI in a peculiar situation: As a pioneer in global sustainability reporting, the
GRI paved the way for both new sets of reporting standards. And whilst the GRI
standards have been established as the most important reporting framework referred
to by European companies in the past (Centre for European Policy Studies (CEPS)
2020) under the NFRD, the changing regulatory environment implies that it has
An Agenda for Research on Sustainability Reporting: Europe and Beyond
641
become considerably less relevant in Europe and has a new, powerful competitor on
a global level. For many, this placed the future of the GRI as an inﬂuential standard
setter in question (see also de Villiers 2022).
The GRI responded to these developments in several ways. First, it contributed
to both the developments of the ESRS and the IFRS SDS. Especially with regard to
the collaboration with the EFRAG, this work started early and was considered to be
very fruitful: By the time the work on the ESRS commenced, both organisations had
already signed a statement of cooperation (EFRAG and GRI 2021). Subsequently,
the GRI standards were fundamental to the development of the ESRS—an aspect
reﬂected in the Basis for Conclusions to the ESRS, which describes how the ESRS
were extensively aligned with the GRI standards. What is more, after the ﬁnal version
of the ESRS was published, work on an interoperability statement was intensiﬁed.
This statement shows the similarities between both sets of standards and allows
corporations that report under the CSRD/ESRS to claim a “reference to” the GRI
standards in their sustainability reports (EFRAG and GRI 2023).
Regarding the development of the IFRS SDS, cooperation was also sought
between the GRI and the IFRS Foundation. However, this cooperation was not
pursued as intensely as the one between the EFRAG and the GRI, probably mainly
due to the different priorities of both sets of standards, i.e. addressing the perspectives
of investor vs. stakeholders in a broader sense. A Memorandum of Understanding
was signed in 2022 (IFRS Foundation 2022b):
[…] The IFRS Foundation and GRI recognise the considerable public interest in aligning
where possible their respective work programmes, terminology and guidance, helping to
reduce the reporting burden for companies and to further harmonise the sustainability
reporting landscape at an international level.
By working together, the IFRS Foundation and GRI provide two ‘pillars’ of international
sustainability reporting—a ﬁrst pillar representing investor-focused capital market standards
of IFRS Sustainability Disclosure Standards developed by the ISSB, and a second pillar
of GRI sustainability reporting requirements set by the GSSB, compatible with the ﬁrst,
designed to meet multi-stakeholder needs.
Furthermore, a Sustainability Innovation Lab was established as part of the coop-
eration between the organisations. However, the difference between the quality of
this cooperation and that resulting from the close work with the EFRAG is obvious.
“Coexistence” is the clear aim.
At the same time, the GRI started to work on its own reporting standards to
more clearly deﬁne their proﬁle. This work comprises placing a stronger focus on
presenting the impact of company activities and on providing guidance regarding
how these impacts can be identiﬁed by performing a materiality analysis. The sector-
speciﬁc reporting requirements with regard to these impacts should also be extended
(Adams 2023). In consequence, the GRI is trying to position their standards as a
complement to the IFRS SDS whilst informing the discussions in the European
Union on impact reporting.
642
J. Baumüller et al.
3
Research Questions for Addressing the Challenges
of the New Sustainability Reporting Landscape
3.1
“Completeness” of Sustainability Information
Although the NFRD faced considerable criticism, research has shown that it induced
a change in corporate behaviour to a certain extent (Cuomo et al. 2022; Fiechter et al.
2022): Corporations adapted their business activities to create “reporting content”
that met the expectations of their stakeholders. Obviously, however, this change
was not considered to be sufﬁcient. Thus, European corporations are facing being
subjected to far more ambitious legislation in the form of the CSRD and the ESRS.
This directive and these standards extend both the extent to which the corporations are
subject to the new reporting requirements and to the content required in these reports.
On a global level, the adoption of the IFRS SDS in many jurisdictions implies that—
also outside of Europe—corporations will have to meet demanding new regulations
when doing their reporting.
It will become more and more important for European corporations to measure,
report and ultimately manage their impacts on environment and society. Given the
elusive and difﬁcult-to-conceptualise nature of impacts, this requirement presents
corporations with a highly complex and potentially burdensome task. It is, never-
theless, of high importance for companies to complete this task to fulﬁl the overall
ambitions set forth in the new regulations (Pesci et al. 2023). Compared to the ESRS,
the IFRS SDS seem to have taken a simpler approach to addressing this aspect
(Abhayawansa 2022). One obvious but still highly important task that researchers
must carry out in the future is to compare the costs for corporations with the beneﬁts
and to clearly deﬁne ‘sustainable development’ in a company context.
The understanding of the principle of materiality is another key element of the
new regulation. In the past, researchers had described materiality as fundamental
for sustainability reporting (Baumüller and Schaffhauser-Linzatti 2018), but this
principle has also been the object of heated discussions recently. The fact that the
deﬁnitions used for materiality in the ESRS and the IFRS SDS differ is considered
to be one of the major differences between these standards (Spandel et al. 2023).
Researchers will be able to contribute more to the discussion on the content of
sustainability reporting once they shed more light on the beneﬁts and restrictions
of this heterogeneity, as well as show possible ways forward regarding the need for
alignment.
Another idea which underpins both the ESRS and the IFRS SDS is the need
to adopt ﬁnancial reporting concepts to build robust and effective sustainability
reporting standards. This applies to individual elements and principles as well as
to the overall structure of the standards (Abela 2022). Empirical testing is needed,
however, to determine the actual usefulness of this approach. Moreover, the literature
proposes moving from sustainability reporting to integrated reporting as a next step
to improve the relevance of corporate reporting as a whole (Cenci 2023). In both the
ESRS and the IFRS SDS, this is reﬂected by invoking the concept of connectivity;
An Agenda for Research on Sustainability Reporting: Europe and Beyond
643
as the IFRS Foundation has taken over the Integrated Reporting Framework by the
IIRC (see Sect. 2.2), it can be reasonably expected that both reporting concepts might
converge in the future (Wagenhofer 2024).
Even when considering standards other than ﬁnancial reporting standards, there
seemstobeaconsensusamongEFRAG,IFRSFoundationandGRIthatsustainability
reporting standards must reﬂect sector-speciﬁc elements to provide useful informa-
tion. For that reason, sector-speciﬁc disclosures are needed for each set of standards.
Although such disclosure requirements echo previous demands from the literature
(Eccles et al. 2012), empirical ﬁndings show that sector-speciﬁc disclosure require-
ments may suffer from the same challenges as sector-agnostic disclosure require-
ments: Heterogeneity might also be an issue within an industry, thus restricting the
usefulness of such disclosures and requiring a level of granularity as well as ﬂexibility
that accordingly goes beyond the existing approaches used in sustainability reporting
standards (Costa et al. 2022). However, despite the importance such sector-speciﬁc
standards are granted in the current debate, there is considerable lack of evidence
regarding how they should be designed to address such issues effectively.
3.2
“Comparability” of Data on Sustainability Performance
In Europe, the shift from the NFRD to the CSRD marks the next step in a journey
that started with the introduction of the NFRD, i.e. the move from voluntary to
mandatory sustainability reporting (Christensen et al. 2021; Breijer and Orij 2022).
For the ﬁrst time, a huge proportion of European corporations will have to publish
such reports based on clearly deﬁned, binding standards. Other jurisdictions will
make similar experiences as the IFRS SDS are implemented on an ongoing basis.
This new regulatory framework introduces new levels of complexity, and it will
be put to the test if these mandatory requirements on a large scale are truly more
effective than a market-based approach. At the very least, considerable side effects
should be expected in the form of additional costs imposed on companies, although
the evidence for potential beneﬁts for corporations is scarce (Centre for European
Policy Studies (CEPS) and Milieu 2022).
At the same time, an underlying assumption is being made in the current devel-
opments: As reporting principle, comparability is as important and effective for
sustainability reporting as it is for ﬁnancial reporting. However, this assumption may
not be true, and the nature of impacts and the ways a corporation operates within its
environment and society might call for a more ﬂexible reporting system (Adams and
Abhayawansa 2022). In any case, the idea of comparable sustainability information
differs from our common understanding of comparable ﬁnancial information (Korca
et al. 2023). More information is also needed to determine how aware sustainability
report users are of these differences and how they integrate them into their analyses.
Regarding another facet of comparability, the new sustainability reporting stan-
dards will be compared in terms of their applicability and effectiveness. This will
not only reﬂect differences in their content but also in the costs they impose on
644
J. Baumüller et al.
companies subject to them. It seems likely that, in any case, these costs will be
considerable. For this reason, researchers must further develop and evaluate the idea
of interoperability with reference to corporations that have to apply two or more of
these standards. They also need to work out reasonable cost–beneﬁt relationships
and how organisations setting standards can (and should) collaborate in their work to
ensure the acceptance of these standards (Giner and Luque-Vilchez 2022; Baumüller
and Leitner-Hanetseder 2023). In turn, this work might enable these organisations
to converge and consolidate sustainability reporting standards still further in the
future and enable researchers to answer the question of the optimal extent of global
harmonisation. It may even enable these groups to determine how many different
sets of sustainability reporting standards are needed (Ali et al. 2023; Stolowy and
Paugam 2023) and help corporations determine which set of standards is more useful
for them under speciﬁc circumstances (Christensen et al. 2021). In a wider context,
it will be of interest to see how the GRI will deﬁne its future role, as it has to position
its standards against both the ESRS and the IFRS SDS (de Villiers et al. 2022).
3.3
“Reliability” of Reports Published by Corporations
With respect to the reliability of information, the external assurance of sustainability
reports has become one important element of current reforms. Whilst the IFRS SDS
and the GRI standards address and recommend such assurance, the CSRD mandates
that every report based on its provisions must be externally validated. This presents
both corporations and their assurance service providers with considerable challenges;
at the same time, this might give ESRS-based reports a competitive advantage over
reports based on other sets of standards given the stakeholders’ increased awareness
of the problem and their tendency to react strongly to the threat of greenwashing.
The requirements with regard to external assurance, however, are amongst the
most ﬂexible provisions in the CSRD (Accountancy Europe 2021). Even if the overall
ambition is to ensure that these assurance provisions are on par with the requirements
for ﬁnancial statement audits, they fall short in several aspects. Thus, new expec-
tation gaps might arise (Association of Chartered Certiﬁed Accountants (ACCA)
2023). This could undermine attempts to fulﬁl many of the ambitions associated
with the regulation. For that reason, this problem of the expectation gap under the
new regulatory framework requires close attention.
First, the CSRD grants considerable ﬂexibility with regard to the question of
who might be tasked with assurance reporting. Besides the statutory auditor of the
ﬁnancial statements, other auditors or even independent assurance-service providers
(IASP) could be mandated to perform this task. This option is currently being debated
by the member states as the CSRD is translated into national law. Whilst empirical
research shows that, in the past, auditors were most often employed (Fernandez-
Feijoo et al. 2016; Alsahali and Malagueño 2022), sustainability report users do
not seem to value assurance services from auditors more than from IASP (Simnet
et al. 2009; Thompson et al. 2022). Empirical evidence on the pros and cons of the
An Agenda for Research on Sustainability Reporting: Europe and Beyond
645
corporations’ choices and the consequences of this choice on the informational value
of sustainability reporting are scarce. Given the heated nature of the debate on who
should be tasked with these services (e.g. Willems 2023), performing more objective
research would beneﬁt all parties involved.
The questions of who should be responsible for assuring sustainability reporting,
the scope of services provided, and, most importantly, the intensity of these services
merit further consideration. Regarding the latter question, the CSRD initially requires
only limited assurance services, as opposed to reasonable assurance services, which
are common for ﬁnancial information audits. Will sustainability report users be able
to distinguish between these different levels of reliability or contrast these levels with
the level of assurance available for ﬁnancial information? Previous research indicates
that this might not be the case (Sheldon and Jenkins 2020).
Flexibility is also granted—and necessary—with regard to the standards serving
as the basis for the assurance of sustainability reports. Currently, there is no glob-
ally accepted assurance standard that can be applied fully address speciﬁc aspects
of either the ESRS, IFRS SDS, or GRI standards. To tackle this problem, the Inter-
national Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) has published its ﬁrst
draft International Standard on Sustainability Assurance (ISSA); once a ﬁnal draft
has been published, this could be adopted into European law and probably will also
be employed in other jurisdictions.
Finally, researchers have shown that assurance services impact the reporting—and
subsequently business—activities of their respective clients (Liu et al. 2023). Thus,
assurance service providers might contribute to the change that is desired by intro-
ducing the new reporting standards and their accompanying legislation. However,
this new ﬁeld of activity might also change these assurance service providers, and
especially audit ﬁrms whose corporate culture might need to adapt to reﬂect the new
skill set of people engaging in these assurance activities (Bakarich et al. 2023). Such
change in the service providers should therefore be monitored carefully in the future.
4
Summary and Outlook
The world of sustainability reporting and the entire corporate reporting landscape
are going through a period of signiﬁcant change. Driven by political ambitions and
changing stakeholder expectations, recent years saw both the development of new
sustainability reporting standards as well as the consolidation of existing standards.
Whilst some initiatives have been created to promote the stronger harmonisation of
these reporting requirements, nevertheless, it is obvious that each of the emerging
new standards reﬂects different understandings of how corporations should be held
accountable for their activities in the light of sustainable development. These stan-
dards all have one thing in common: They express an ambition that, in the future,
sustainability reporting should become much more similar to ﬁnancial reporting
regarding its relevance and reliability.
646
J. Baumüller et al.
Going beyond mere reporting requirements, an important next step was under-
taken by the European Union in 2023: By agreeing on a new Corporate Sustainability
Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD), a new directive was introduced that will require
certain European and non-EU corporations to actively engage in sustainability prac-
tice, and especially to protect human rights and reduce their emissions (European
Commission 2023). In addition, the CSDDD describes severe sanctions for corpo-
rations that do not comply with the new requirements, including the right for stake-
holders all over the world to sue these corporations. As both the scope and elements of
the CSDDD and the CSRD/ESRS are similar in many respects, and as sustainability
reporting per se is a fundamental aspect of the required sustainability due diligence,
this new directive will contribute to the relevance of sustainability reports published
in the future. However, the complexity of the regulatory environment will increase
as well (Villiers 2022). It can be expected that many of the questions outlined in
Chap. 3 will gain more weight.
While this chapter covered three sets of sustainability reporting standards, a fourth
one will emerge soon: In 2022, also the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
(SEC) proposed rules for requiring registrants to include climate-related in their
public ﬁlings (SEC 2022). Although it is still unclear which concrete requirements
will be part of the ﬁnal regulation, it can be expected that—unlike the existing sustain-
ability reporting standards—an approach will be taken which focuses on ﬁnancial
reporting disclosures. And whilst this regulation will only be relevant for domestic
and foreign registrants on U.S. stock markets, its expected impact will be important
enough to place it on par with the European Union and IFRS Foundation standards.
Reﬂecting that importance, the literature already uses the term “Big Three Sustain-
ability Disclosure Standards” (e.g. Ohl et al. 2022). This opens the door for more
comparative research, and especially on the interconnection between ﬁnancial and
sustainability reporting and on the impacts that heterogenous approaches might have
on decisions made by corporations and their stakeholders.
In conclusion, although recent years have seen considerable changes in the regu-
latory environment for sustainability reporting, a similar abundancy of regulatory
changes is expected in the upcoming years. The pace of activities to set standards
has been deﬁned by political priorities and due processes during their development,
and the ﬁrst-time application of the new reporting requirements will open the door
to extensive empirical analyses of the effects of this regulation. But there also seem
to be many questions about conceptual work that merit closer attention, some of
which address fundamental assumptions of the current reforms and deserve further
examination. Such studies, in turn, can inform standard setters, helping them decide
how to set priorities and improve their activities to reach the common aim of all sets
of standards and the organisations that apply them: to change corporate behaviour
and transform business models to support sustainable development.
For more than a decade, the promise of sustainability reporting has been nothing
less than “accountants will save the world” (Bakker 2013). In the next years, this
promise will be put to the test.
