Making Education for Sustainable
Development (ESD) More Inclusive
and Engaging Through Universal Design
for Learning (UDL): A Case Study
at the Westminster Business School
Gustavo R. Espinoza-Ramos
Abstract There is a growing effort to embed sustainability in higher education
curricula through the application of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development
Goals (SDG). However, this process faces different challenges, including a lack of
student engagement due to an emphasis on traditional teaching approaches. To over-
come these challenges and improve Education for Sustainable Development (ESD),
there is a need for alternative teaching methods and innovative forms of assessment.
Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is an educational framework aimed at teaching
and learning being more inclusive and transformative for students of all abilities, thus
promoting an inclusive sustainable education (SDG4). The studies on UDL have
been increasing in the last decade; however, there is a gap in the literature around
the application of UDL to the curriculum and evidence regarding its impact. This
chapter showcases the application of UDL principles in the design of Sustainable City
Economies (SCE), a second-year undergraduate module at the Westminster Business
School. This case study shows how providing different learning spaces, including
on-campus classes, ﬁeld trips (walking or virtual tours), online learning material and
assessment methods that meet students’ learning preferences and improve student
agency in their learning. In sum, the learning material and assessment are aligned
with the UDL principles of action and expression, representation, and engagement.
Keywords Business · Universal Design for Learning (UDL) · Education for
Sustainable Development (ESD) · Problem-Based Learning (PBL) · Inclusivity
G. R. Espinoza-Ramos (B)
Westminster Business School, SFHEA, London, England
e-mail: g.espinozaramos@westminster.ac.uk
© The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024
W. Leal Filho et al. (eds.), An Agenda for Sustainable Development Research,
World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_36
651
652
G. R. Espinoza-Ramos
1
Introduction
The transition to becoming a sustainable society requires the participation of different
groups of stakeholders, who will identify, evaluate and adopt new daily practices
in different sectors, including extractive industries, manufacturing, retail and tech-
nology. Education has been one of the key sectors setting the foundations for sustain-
able practices. For this reason, in recent decades, there has been a growing effort to
embed sustainability in higher education curricula (Lozano et al. 2015), recognising
the need for students not only to be aware of sustainability issues, but also, to develop
a set of competencies that will help them to address current socio-environmental and
economic challenges.
Initiatives to embed sustainability in the curricula have been growing at a fast
pace in recent years (Fekih Zguir et al. 2021). However, further research is required
when embedding sustainability in universities’ activities (Leal Filho et al. 2019).
This gap in the research is due to a low integration of sustainable development in
the transformation of higher education, and the lack of connection between learning
and teaching, research and governance (Leal Filho et al. 2019).
To promote sustainable development in education, UNESCO developed the
Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) in 1992 (Rieckmann 2017). ESD
is an initiative that supports educators and policymakers in higher education, which
requires innovative teaching methods and assessments to meet different learning pref-
erences according to students’ abilities (Rieckmann 2017). When designing these
teaching methods, a key question that an educator should reﬂect on is to what extent
the learning activities related to sustainability are inclusive. The solution requires the
development of a learning environment and methods that are transformative (Leal
Filho et al. 2019), decolonised, co-created and integrate diverse ways to develop and
express knowledge (Ferguson et al. 2022).
Fisher and McAdams (2015) argue that every higher education institution should
develop their own model when embedding sustainability in the curricula. For that
reason, this case study endeavours to ﬁll the research gap by providing an overview
of Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) and the principles of Universal
Design for Learning (UDL). It details how both were embedded when developing
inclusive and sustainable learning activities in Sustainable City Economies (SCE),
a second-year undergraduate module at the Westminster Business School (United
Kingdom). The chapter aims to give practical advice on the structure of learning
activities, teaching tools and assessments that can be applied to other disciplines.
2
Methodology
This case study applies autoethnography as a qualitative research methodology, for
which the researcher reﬂects on personal experiences and his position in the study to
analyse cultural experiences, beliefs, and practices (Adams et al. 2017). According
Making Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) More Inclusive …
653
to Koopman et al. (2020), autoethnography enhances reﬂexivity and critical thinking
as the researcher engages emotionally and cognitively during the analysis of the
subjective experience (Peterson 2015). As autohemotherapy allows researchers to
explore their own personal experiences as a source of knowledge and insight, it
promotes a deeper understanding of different factors of culture and interpersonal
dynamics in varied locations such as organisations (Edwards 2021).
In this case study, autoethnography has been selected as the best ﬁt methodology
to understand the module leader’s experiences when designing Sustainable City
Economies (SCE), a second-year undergraduate module at the Westminster Busi-
ness School (England). Moreover, the case study showcases the process of embed-
ding ESD in a module that has more than 340 students enrolled since its creation in
the academic year 2021/2022.
3
Education for Sustainable Development (ESD)
The concept of Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) has its origins in
the 1990s, through early discussions in conferences organised by United Nations
in acknowledgement of the importance of raising awareness and developing educa-
tion initiatives on sustainable development. This was demonstrated in 1994 when
UNESCO developed the Environment and Population Education and Information
for Human Development Project, known as EPD. Later, in 1997, the name was
changed to Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) in an attempt to clarify
its purpose (York University 2023).
EducationforSustainableDevelopment(ESD)isaprocessoflearningthatenables
students to develop the values, knowledge and competencies needed to address
the current local and global challenges (UNESCO 2023). Moreover, it endeavours
to harmonise socio-economic interests with cultural traditions and environmental
protection (Afolabi 2019). To achieve this, ESD seeks to develop student agency so
that learners are accountable for their actions and empowered to develop solutions
to the current sustainability issues.
DespitethenoblecommitmentofESDtowardsequippingstudentswiththeknowl-
edge and skills needed to work and live in a way that safeguards environmental,
social and economic wellbeing, embedding it in the curricula has been challenging.
According to the Calvert et al. (2023), some barriers include scarce understanding
and application of ESD in learning activities and assessment, resistance to change,
no clear policy and procedure to apply it as well as lack of time and ﬁnancial
resources. To overcome these barriers, adopting a holistic and systematic approach
to ESD, involving leadership, pedagogy, research, and quality assurance procedures
is recommended (Lozano et al. 2015; Leal Filho et al. 2019).
654
G. R. Espinoza-Ramos
3.1
Pedagogical Approach
Embedding ESD in the curricula of all disciplines requires a multi-method peda-
gogical approach that develops interactive, experiential, and transformative learning
(Lozano et al. 2017). Moreover, some student-activating methods that support under-
standing and ﬁnding solutions to sustainability issues can be developed inside and
outside the classroom. Ceulemans and De Prins (2010) identiﬁed the following
methods for use in the classroom: videos, case studies, presentations, jigsaw, business
challenges, discussion, and voting. Meanwhile, some learning activities developed
outside the classroom include ﬁeld trips, excursions, and visiting exhibitions.
ESD guidelines do not prescribe a unique pedagogical approach that is applicable
to all disciplines. Instead, the pedagogy that ﬁts with ESD is the one that connects
learning with the students’ contexts and real-life problems (Rieckmann 2017), such
that they are familiar with the learning spaces and encourage class participation
when ﬁnding solutions to sustainability challenges. Some pedagogical approaches
to meet the above aims have been deemed to include problem-based learning and
project-based learning.
4
Problem-Based Learning (PBL)
The term Problem-based Learning was originated in 1974 by Howard Barrows as
an innovative approach in medical education (Neufeld and Barrows 1974), and then
it has been used in other disciplines, including engineering, psychology, economics
and education (Servant-Miklos 2020). PBL is seen as a teaching and learning strategy
in which students are responsible for their own learning, work in small groups and
undertakeresearchtoﬁndalltheinformationrequiredtosolvearealproblem(Tejedor
et al. 2019). During this process, ﬁnding the solution is not the key outcome; it is
the process of ﬁnding the solutions, including social interaction and understanding
the challenges and constraints that are the key part of their learning (Nurtanto et al.
2020).
PBL has been implemented in different disciplines in higher education when
students solve sustainability issues. For example, when engineering students solve
socio-environmental issues (Hansen and Gonzalez 2014); and when management
students work in partnership with companies to improve their sustainability perfor-
mance in waste management and adoption of renewable energy (Wiek et al.
2014).
Making Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) More Inclusive …
655
5
Project-Based Learning (PjBL)
Project-based learning is a teaching and learning method that has originated from the
constructivism theories since the 1960s (Aldabbus 2018) and has been implemented
in educational institutions worldwide (Pereira et al. 2017). According to Guo et al.
(2020) PjBL involves the following activities: identiﬁcation of a real problem, formu-
lation of a question, collaboration in teams, use of scaffolding technologies and the
creation of tangible artefacts. It is the development of artefacts, the key difference
that distinguishes PjBL from PBL and other teaching and learning methods (Guo
et al. 2020).
Research has demonstrated that PjBL develops key capabilities in higher educa-
tion students, including critical thinking, problem-solving, interpersonal communi-
cation, teamwork, innovation, and creativity (Häkkinen et al. 2017). For that reason,
the application of PjBL in higher education has been growing. For example, PjBL
has been applied in engineering studies (De Los Ríos et al. 2010) and when ﬁnding
solutions to sustainability issues and circular economy (Alves et al. 2017).
5.1
Aligning Learning Outcomes with Key Competencies
for Sustainability
When embedding sustainability in courses, it is important to align the course/module
learning outcomes to ESD to identify its purpose and ensure its alignment with
the learning activities and assessment. UNESCO has developed key competencies
for sustainability aimed at all learners of all ages worldwide that encapsulate the
knowledge, skills, and attitudes that students need to address socio-environmental
issues at local and global levels. These competencies can be aligned with the learning
outcomes of which there are eight that are divided into three categories (QAA and
Advance HE 2021).
Ways of thinking
• Systems thinking competency: The ability to understand how a problem is
composed by a complex system, their interconnections, and their causes and
effects.
• Anticipatory competency (Future thinking): The ability to understand, anticipate
and evaluate current and future challenges as well as the potential consequences
of their actions and their contribution to a sustainable future.
• Critical thinking competency: The ability to conceptualise, apply, analyse, synthe-
sise, and evaluate information and arguments. Moreover, learners will be able
to recognise their own personal assumptions and values that inﬂuence their
behaviour.
656
G. R. Espinoza-Ramos
Ways of practising
• Strategic competency: The ability to develop and implement strategies to solve
sustainability issues. This competency includes goal setting, time and resource
management, implementation of solutions, and stakeholder management.
• Collaboration competency: The ability to develop communication, group manage-
ment, and self-awareness skills to work ethically and professionally with others
to achieve common goals.
• Integrated problem-solving competency: The ability to develop and apply multi-
disciplinary and interdisciplinary knowledge to address different and conﬂicting
priorities when aiming to solve complex real problems.
Ways of being
• Self-awareness competency: The ability to reﬂect on one’s own emotions, moti-
vations and personality that have an impact on behaviours so that learners develop
a sense of agency and responsibility to develop sustainable solutions.
• Normative competency: The ability to understand and reﬂect their own norms and
values that shape their behaviours. Moreover, by understanding justice, equity,
inclusion and responsibility, learners are able to identify biases and barriers to
sustainable solutions.
The alignment of the UNESCO’s key competencies for sustainability with the
learning outcomes will shape the course/module design. The next steps include
the development of the learning environment, activities and assessment, which
will stimulate the development of these competencies in an inclusive way. The
Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is the framework that can effectively guide
the development of these learning spaces.
6
Universal Design for Learning (UDL)
Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is a framework for teaching and learning
design that has gained prominence since the 1990s. It focuses on reducing barriers in
the learning environment so that a higher diversity of learners can engage in rigorous
and meaningful learning (CAST 2023a). It provides an educational framework in
which the educational curriculum, procedures and content are not a one-size-ﬁts-all
learner approach.
The concept of Universal Design (UD) originated in 1970s, in the ﬁeld of archi-
tecture and is generally credited to the work of Ronald Mace, who envisioned the
universal design of buildings that are accessible for anyone, including disabled people
(Unluol Unal et al. 2022). Then, in 1990s, the concept of universal design was
adapted to learning by The Center for Applied Special Technology (CAST), such
that the learning environment, by acknowledging that students come from different
backgrounds, and have different abilities and learning preferences (Almumen 2020).
Hence, UDL suggests a change in the curricula so that students have multiple options
Making Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) More Inclusive …
657
to access and interact with the learning material and express knowledge in multiple
ways.
The application of UDL in curriculum design has been growing over the years as
it provides different beneﬁts, including a reduction of the attainment gap in higher
education, especially after Covid 19 pandemic (Luke 2021), mitigation of student
discouragement, insecurity and isolation during their studies as well as improvement
in student learning, outcomes, engagement and satisfaction (Hills et al. 2022).
6.1
Principles of UDL
UDL comprises three core principles, nine guidelines and 31 checkpoints that guide
the design and implementation of the learning objectives, activities, instructional
materials, and assessment.
Multiple means of representation:
• It implies the development of course material in multiple formats, where learners
have different ways to access, process, and comprehend learning content. There-
fore, there is not one way of representing learning material that is optimal for all
learners. For example, the learning material should be provided in visual, audi-
tory and written ways to support learning (CAST 2023b). Providing options for
representation in different formats, such as videos, audio recordings, text, graphs,
and other multimedia, will support students in developing connections between
new information and previous experiences.
• This principle has three guidelines and checkpoints that guide its application:
perception, language and symbols, and comprehension.
Multiple means of action and expression:
• This principle involves the development of alternative ways in which students can
express their understanding and opinion about the content. Moreover, students can
express themselves in writing, verbally, through social interactions, individual or
group work and plenary sessions. For example, students can use multimedia and
assistive technology to plan and organise learning material in incremental and
multimodal formats or use online whiteboards and presentation tools to demon-
strate their understanding of the lessons. In addition, some assessment methods
include interviews, podcasts, quiz/test, posters, graphs, presentations, reports/
essays (Al-Azawei et al. 2016).
• This principle has three guidelines and checkpoints that guide its application:
physical action, expression and communication, and executive functions.
Multiple means of engagement:
• Students have different ways to engage and motivations to learn. Accordingly, this
principle involves offering different choices of content modality to encourage
students to become involved in the learning activities. Instructors can develop
658
G. R. Espinoza-Ramos
learning material that is linked to real-life situations and students’ interests and
motivation (Luke 2021) to improve their engagement. Moreover, this engagement
process can involve the use of social interactions with their peers or self-reﬂection.
For example, developing a safer learning environment and giving the students the
autonomy to choose the artefacts they can use to learn and express knowledge,
will improve engagement.
• This principle has three guidelines and checkpoints that guide its application:
recruiting interest, sustaining effort and persistence, and self-regulation.
The application of Universal Design for Learning (UDL) principles will support
embedding sustainability in the curricula by offering different learning spaces,
modes, activities and assessments through which students can gain and express
knowledge that is suitable for all abilities and backgrounds. The following section
shows the practical application of ESD and UDL in higher education, by sharing
good practices when developing the learning outcomes, activities and assessment.
7
Sustainable City Economies
Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) has been applied at the University
of Westminster through the development of core modules that are focussed on
sustainability. For example, Sustainable City Economies is a second-year under-
graduate module at the Westminster Business School that has been delivered since
the academic year 2021/2022. The module aims to provide students with theoretical
and practical knowledge regarding sustainable cities, developing a critical under-
standing of the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) and reﬂecting on the
role of stakeholders as well as their own when achieving a sustainable city.
In addition, the principles of Universal Design for Learning (UDL) were applied
as a pedagogical framework to develop an inclusive learning environment, material,
and assessment that is meaningful to their learning preferences. The application of
ESD and UDL principles in this module was done through the following stages,
including the development of the learning outcomes, selection of pedagogy, presen-
tation of learning material, assessment opportunities, student engagement spaces
and co-design of the module with the students. Table 1 shows a summary of the
application of UDL principles in the module.
7.1
Development of Module Learning Outcomes
First, the development of four learning outcomes (LOs) aligned with UNESCO’s key
competencies for sustainability to determine the purpose and competencies devel-
oped when completing the module. The LOs shaped the development of the learning

7.2
Selection of Pedagogy
Second, the LOs and key competencies for sustainability supported the identiﬁcation
of the pedagogy suitable to achieve them. In this case, problem-based learning (PBL)
was selected as the main pedagogy, where students were able to develop critical
analysis when evaluating the two sustainability issues, evaluating their causes and
impact and when developing solutions to these real-world problems. In addition,
the application of PBL in the module improved student agency in that they became
Making Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) More Inclusive …

for sustainability, especially in terms of critical thinking, integrated problem-solving,
and self-awareness.
7.3
Presentation of Learning Material
Third, developing and presenting learning material in a range of modalities was
important to cater for the different student learning abilities and preferences as it facil-
itated students to process and understand the concepts covered in the module. More-
over, providing students with various ways to access and engage with learning mate-
rial supports the application of the UDL principle: Multiple means of representation,
especially guideline 1—perception, and guideline 3—comprehension. Speciﬁcally,
the range of modalities in the learning material includes the following.
• PowerPoint slides used in lectures and seminars to present information and
instructions to students; the virtual learning environment (VLE) used at the
university allowed students to download alternative document versions, such as
downloadablePDFﬁles,HTML,audio,electronicbrailleandanimmersivereader.
• Videos with captions were used in some learning activities, where students had
to answer questions. The length of the videos varied from three to eight minutes.
662
G. R. Espinoza-Ramos
• The two-hour live lectures were recorded; the captions were automatically
embedded by the university video platform. In addition, a mic was used to improve
the sound quality during the live lecture and when watching the video recording.
• Reading list: physical and electronic versions of the essential and further reading
were available for students.
7.4
Assessment Opportunities
Fourth, the development of assessment opportunities for students was critical for
measuring the extent of their learning and evaluating their level of understanding. In
this module, formative and summative assessments were implemented. The former
is not graded, permits the lecturer to identify concepts that need clariﬁcation and
takes the form of ongoing feedback that will prepare students for the summative
assessment. Summative assessment counts towards the ﬁnal module grade and is
used to evaluate student learning carried out at the end or at a speciﬁc time of the
module. Giving students the option to express knowledge differently is aligned with
the UDL principle: multiple means of action and expression, especially guideline 4—
physical action; and guideline 5—expression and communication. In this module,
the range of assessment opportunities includes the following.
Summative assessment: two different assessment components were designed so
that students can demonstrate knowledge according to their learning preferences.
Moreover, within each assessment component, students could choose the concepts
and tools to apply.
• Assessment 1 was an individual poster that permitted a visual representation of
knowledge. In this assignment, students could choose:
• The city of their preference from a sustainable city ranking that shows 100 cities.
• Two Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that complement SDG 11: sustain-
able cities and communities.
• The two sustainability issues that they wanted to analyse, which could be social
or environmental ones.
• The root cause analysis tool that helped them to identify the underlying causes of
the two sustainability issues.
• Assessment 2 was a report through which students could express knowledge in a
written way. In this assignment, they could choose:
• A different city than in assessment 1 (poster), as some were unable to ﬁnd more
information to complete the other sections of the assessment.
• Two solutions to address sustainability issues.
• To reﬂect on two solutions that they experienced during the ﬁeld trip, regardless
of whether they completed the walking or online tour.
Formative assessment: the seminar learning activities required students to answer
some questions based on a case study or short video. Then students had to discuss
Making Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) More Inclusive …
663
their answers in groups or individually as well as expressing their knowledge using
different tools.
• Flip chart papers and markers; or a padlet, an online whiteboard on which students
can use an electronic device such as a mobile phone or laptop. In both cases,
students had the opportunity to contribute and share their ideas in a written form.
• Short presentations through which students could verbally express their ﬁndings
from their ﬂipchart papers or padlets.
7.5
Opportunities for Engagement
Fifth, as students have different motivations when learning, offering different oppor-
tunities to interact with the learning material and information was important. More-
over, student engagement varies according to the learning activity (individual or
group work) as well as their afﬁnity with the examples used in class, during outdoor
activities and the type of technology. Giving different spaces so that students engage
in the activities is related to the UDL principle: multiple means of engagement, espe-
cially with the guideline 7—recruiting interest; and guideline 8—sustaining effort
and persistence. In this module, the different learning opportunities such that students
could engage included the following.
• Examples and case studies: Those used in the lecture and seminars are from devel-
oped and developing countries. In addition, giving the options to select between
social or environmental issues contributes to student engagement.
• Individual and group work: During seminars some activities included individual
and group work, for which they needed to answer questions based on a short case
study or video. These activities promoted collaboration, improved their social
skills, in particular, shy students tended to participate more when working in
small groups, rather than in the plenary.
• Online games: During the lectures, a Poll Everywhere competition was used,
where students had to answer multiple-choice questions in an online quiz that
brought out the participants’ competitive side as they competed for points and
they could see their names on the leaderboard after each question. In addition,
in two seminars, a different free online game was used so that students could
compete against each other when developing solutions to sustainability issues.
• Outdoor learning: a ﬁeld trip was organised so that students could explore sustain-
ability issues and solutions in London. The ﬁeld trip was organised in week 6 and
in two modalities, such that they could choose according to their learning prefer-
ence: walking or virtual tour. In week 7, the tour guide was a guest speaker and
shared the key ﬁndings of the ﬁeld trip so that all students had a summary of the
key learning during this experience.
664
G. R. Espinoza-Ramos
7.6
Co-Design of Module with Students
Sixth, students became key partners in module design as they had opportunities to
have their voices heard in written and verbal ways during the semester. This practice
provides different beneﬁts, such as developing learner-centred courses and enhancing
the student sense of belonging in the module. The participation of students in module
design contributes to all the principles of UDL and in this module, it was implemented
in the following ways.
• Student reps: Every seminar group selected a student rep who was responsible
for listening, gathering and communicating the views of all about good practices
and positive changes aimed at improving the student learning experience, which
included: learning material, student–teacher dynamics, and assessment support.
There were two meetings during the semester that helped the module leader to
identify areas for improvement, which were subsequently acted upon.
• Feedback on the ﬁeld trip: Students had the opportunity to complete a feedback
form on their learning experience during the ﬁeld trip, such that good practice and
areas for improvement were identiﬁed for improving this activity.
• Student Module Evaluation (SME) form: The students had the chance to provide
written, anonymous feedback about the module, learning materials, teaching
support and assessment. They had seven weeks to complete this form and this
helped the module leader identify good practices and areas for improvement.
In addition, students could communicate with the module and seminar leaders
through different channels and opportunities during the semester.
• Communication channels: Students could raise questions, give feedback and
ﬂag up concerns using the electronic discussion board, emails (university email
address or messages through the VLE), one-to-one meetings and during classes.
7.7
Impact of ESD and UDL
Since the academic year 2021/2022, when the Sustainable City Economies module
was delivered, the impact of embedding ESD and UDL principles has been noticeable
indifferentareas,includingassessmentgrades,studentmoduleevaluationandwritten
feedback.
Assessment grades
The average grades in both assessment components have been increasing throughout
the academic years. For example, in the ﬁrst academic year, students demonstrated
concerns related to the lower assessment 1 grades. For that reason, in the following
academicyears,moresupportwasgiventopreparethemfortheassessment,including
Q&A sessions to help them have a better understanding of the assessment brief;
seminar learning activities linked to a speciﬁc section of each assessment; formative
Making Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) More Inclusive …
665
feedback on their assessment drafts; and the use of the discussion board on which
students could share their questions about the assessment. This support and having
a different non-traditional type of assessment, in this case a poster, had a positive
impact on written feedback:
“I enjoyed the poster (CW1) and it should be kept in for future years” and “I like that the
assignments allow you to be creative and the ﬁeld trip was also a good activity”.
Field trip
Having an outdoor learning activity contributes to the learning experience of some
students. Since the academic year 2021/2022, there has been a clear trend in the
student’s preference for attending the virtual tour (60%) rather than the walking one
(40%). This could be related to factors including weather conditions, family/work
commitments, and students’ preferences to engage more through online activities,
rather than on-campus ones. Regardless of the modality of the ﬁeld trip, students
gave positive feedback:
“I mostly liked going on the sustainable London walking tour ﬁeldtrip”; “Loved that it was
possible to take the tour online, as I had no chance of participating in the tour in London”;
and “I liked the lecture materials and also liked the practical application through the ﬁeld
trip”.
Student Module valuation (SME)
The SME results are steady at around 4.2/5. The written feedback shows diverse
opinions about learning sustainability in business studies, with some students ﬁnding
it challenging and not considering it a being related to business. However, there are
others who enjoyed the module content and assignments. Every academic year, more
examples of sustainable business practices have been embedded in the module, which
may have enhanced student learning experience. Related to UDL, students enjoyed
the choice of assessment that improved their agency in their own learning. In addition,
some students enjoyed the fact that in this module only classes in weeks 6 and 12
were online, as they reported how they struggled to engage in online learning.
“I really enjoyed this module, it was probably my favourite of this semester”; “I like that I had
a lot of choice when it came to assessments - I could choose the city, problems, solutions”;
and “The fact that we only had online lessons due to either the ﬁeld trip or strikes on the
tube was the best way to apply them and the only way that I ﬁnd acceptable”.
8
Further Research
This chapter contributes to the literature on Education for Sustainable Development
(ESD) and Universal Design for Learning (UDL) by presenting a case study that
applied both concepts in module design that will guide other practitioners in higher
education. However, there are some areas that need further research.
666
G. R. Espinoza-Ramos
In the case of ESD, there is a need to investigate further the application of ESD in
general management studies, especially in the ﬁeld of logistics (Putz et al. 2018). In
addition, there is a need to improve the understanding of how pedagogical approaches
have an impact on sustainability competencies (Lozano et al. 2017). In addition, the
pedagogical approaches of ESD require further evaluation.
Whilst the literature on the application of UDL in higher education has been
increasing, there remains a need for additional research on its application in the
business studies context. According to Unluol Unal et al. (2022), there are scarce
studies on the effectiveness of UDL training when developing lesson plans, especially
when analysing the impact on populations from different backgrounds.
In addition, there is a need to research the implementation of UDL at the university
level (Hills et al. 2022). Meanwhile, Kennette and Wilson (2019) argue that more
research is required to understand the students’ perspectives on the level of UDL
principles applied in their courses and its impact on their learning.
9
Conclusion
This chapter contributes to the literature about the application of Education for
Sustainable Development (ESD) and principles of Universal Design for Learning
(UDL) in module design in higher education. Some of UNESCO’s key competen-
cies of sustainability were embedded in the module learning outcomes that shaped
the development of the learning activities and assessment. The three principles of
UDL were embedded in the module in different ways. The multiple means of repre-
sentation principle was demonstrated when providing multiple formats of module
material, such as lesson slides, videos with captions as well as physical and elec-
tronic versions of books. The principle of multiple means of action and expression
was demonstrated when providing assessment components that permit visual and
written ways to represent knowledge (poster and report, respectively) as well as
when students were able to express themselves in verbal ways through presentations.
The principle of multiple means of engagement was demonstrated when different
examples from developed and developing countries were used as part of the learning
material; when students engaged more in individual or group activities; and through
using online games or a ﬁeld trip that allowed students to apply concepts covered in
the class.
The results from assessment grades, student feedback, and Student Module Eval-
uation (SME) demonstrate that there is not one teaching and learning method that ﬁts
all students’ preferences. In addition, it is clear that there has been an improvement
in assessment grades, and in students’ perceptions. At the undergraduate level, the
majority of students continue to prefer to have on-campus classes and a few asyn-
chronous online learning activities. However, it is necessary to explore whether the
current rise in the cost of living may have changed this student perception. Moreover,
student agency is improved when giving options in the learning and assessment activ-
ities. For example, the ﬁeld trip and its mode of delivery (walking or online tours)
Making Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) More Inclusive …
667
provided a clear application of concepts in an outdoor learning activity. Finally,
further studies should be carried out to analyse students and lecturers’ perceptions of
the effectiveness of UDL, in particular, more research should be undertaken regarding
its application in business studies.

Towards a Responsive Science Education
for Sustainable Development
Ian Phil Canlas
Abstract Quality Education is one of the seventeen goals of the 2030 Agenda for
Sustainable Development and is recognized as a key driver of the rest of the sustain-
able development goals. Without question, science education is an essential driver
of sustainable development. Although the debate continues, there is some under-
standing that scientiﬁc literacy, including other literacies, is considered an essential
measure of quality education. Therefore, the author hypothesizes that most, if not
all, concepts and underlying principles of sustainable development and scientiﬁc
literacy are complementary. This chapter presents the current landscape of science
education in the context of sustainable development drawn from document analyses
of 183 papers extracted from the Scopus database following a document selection
criteria. By examining titles, abstracts, and objectives, key themes were identiﬁed
and presented in this chapter, including a reﬂection on gaps and opportunities in the
nexus of science education and education for sustainable development research.
Keywords Science education · Sustainable development · Scientiﬁc literacy ·
Sustainability
1
Introduction
There is a consensus about the role of quality education as a key driver in achieving all
the other sustainable development goals (SDGs) of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable
Development (which will be referred to as the Agenda in the text). With 2030 nearing,
all sectors of society, including the education sector, are pressured to hasten the
implementation of the Agenda amidst ever-changing socio-economic, political, civic,
and climatic landscapes. Aiming to contribute towards advancing the agenda for

School of Arts and Sciences, University of Central Asia, Naryn, Kyrgyz Republic

Philippines

World Sustainability Series, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-65909-6_37
671
672
I. P. Canlas
sustainable research, this chapter elucidates the role of science education within the
framework of education for sustainable development (ESD). Speciﬁcally, it unveils
opportunities for research along the intersection of science education and sustainable
development.
Drawingfromexperienceandtheliterature,theauthorarguesthat,ontheonehand,
all SDGs can be genuinely understood only with strong and higher levels of scientiﬁc
literacy,therebygainingmoresigniﬁcantsupportandachieved.Ontheotherhand,the
relevance of science education can be enhanced by integrating content and principles
of sustainable development goals into existing science education frameworks and
curriculum standards.
In the last few years, an increasing number of studies have explored ESD in the
context of the different aspects of formal education systems. For example, a study
by Sonetti and colleagues (2020) explored ESD practices among Italian universities,
along with their mission statements and drivers thereto. A study by Wamsler (2020)
developed and assessed the impact of a course, Sustainability and Inner Transforma-
tion, that focuses on inner dimensions and capacities and transformation as a vehicle
for improved education for sustainability. Another study by Trott and Weinberg
(2020) examined how school children’s climate change learning inﬂuenced science
engagement, thus improving perceived relevance of and attitudes toward science.
Lastly,astudybyParryandMetzger(2023)exploredandreportedteachers’perceived
barriers in learning for sustainability, including the existence of disciplinary silos, a
focus on high-stakes assessments, and inadequate teacher professional development
for in-service and preservice teachers.
Notably, although the literature offers a number of frameworks and models,
including approaches toward relevant and responsive science education, certain
elements and underpinning principles of science education and scientiﬁc literacy
have remained relevant over time. This includes, for example, the scientiﬁc method,
the process of scientiﬁc inquiry, and views on the nature of science.
2
Scientiﬁc Literacy
Theliteratureoffersanumberofdeﬁnitionsofscientiﬁcliteracy,andanumberofdeﬁ-
nitions are relevant to the nexus of science education and ESD. An earlier work of the
United Nations Educational, Scientiﬁc and Cultural Cooperation (UNESCO 1993),
Project 2000+ , is perhaps one of the earliest international declarations that recog-
nizedtheessentialroleofscientiﬁcandtechnologicalliteracyinachievingsustainable
development, calling for a science and technological education at all levels that is
responsive to the human needs in a scientiﬁc and technological society. The Organi-
sation for Economic Co-operation and Development deﬁned it as “the capacity to use
scientiﬁc knowledge, to identify questions, and to draw evidence-based conclusions
in order to understand and help make decisions about the natural world and the
changes made to it through human activity (p. 15).” The National Research Council
(cited in National Academies of Sciences, Engineerin 2016) deﬁned scientiﬁc literacy
Towards a Responsive Science Education for Sustainable Development
673
Fig. 1 The Spectrum of scientiﬁc literacy (Roberts 2007; Sjöström and Eilks 2018; Sjöström and
Talanquer 2014)
as “the knowledge and understanding of science concepts and processes required
for personal decision-making, civic and cultural affairs, and economic productivity
(p.139),” while Holbrook and Rannikamae (2007) deﬁned it as “developing the
ability to creatively utilize sound science knowledge in everyday life, or in a career,
to solve problems, make decisions, and improve quality of life (p. 1359).” Be that as it
may, upon close examination, all deﬁnitions lead to personal and societal groundings
(DeBoer 2000).
Roberts’s (2007) initial work on visions of scientiﬁc literacy, further advanced
by Sjöström and Eilks (2018), Sjöström and Talanquer (2014) with their work on
levels of humanized science education, presents a spectrum of scientiﬁc literacy as
depicted in Fig. 1.
Choi and colleagues (2011) offered reconceptualized dimensions of scientiﬁc
literacy that considered the demands of the twenty-ﬁrst century. The said dimensions
include (a) content knowledge, (b) habits of the mind, (c) character and values,
(d) science as a human endeavor, and (e) metacognition and self-direction. The
conceptualization can be visualized with ﬁve pillars; on the four corners are the
ﬁrst four dimensions, the center pillar is metacognition and self-direction, and three
layers: the bottom layer represents personal context, the middle represents societal
context, and the topmost represents global context (Choi et al. 2011).
3
Education for Sustainable Development
UNESCO (2017) described ESD as “holistic and transformational education that is
an integral part of lifelong learning and quality education, that addresses learning
content and outcomes, pedagogy and the learning environment, aimed at developing
competencies that empower individuals to reﬂect on their activities that account
their present and future social, cultural, economic, and environmental impact (p. 7).”
ESD could achieve SDGs by raising awareness of the 17 goals, promoting critical
and contextualized understanding of SDGs, and mobilizing action towards achieving
SDGs (UNESCO 2020, p. 16).
674
I. P. Canlas
Through ESD for 2030, UNESCO (2020) “aims to build a more just and sustain-
able world by strengthening ESD and contributing to the achievement of the 17
SDGs by fully integrating ESD and the 17 SDGs into policies, learning environments,
capacity-building of educators, the empowerment and mobilization of young people,
and local level action.” (p. 14). Further, UNESCO (2020) “aims to transform educa-
tion by mainstreaming ESD in education policies and frameworks of government;
provide all learners the opportunity to acquire knowledge, skills, values, and atti-
tudes needed for promoting sustainable development and achieving the 17 sustain-
able development goals through the whole-institution approach to ESD; people in
cities and communities recognize ESD as the key instrument for lifelong learning
to achieve sustainability at the local level; all educators having the opportunity to
develop capacities to foster societal transformation and sustainable future; and youth
becoming change agents and youth organizations providing ESD training for the
youth.” (pp. 22–23). UNESCO (2020) determined ﬁve priority action areas in ESD
for 2030 to include: “advancing policy by integrating ESD into global, regional, and
national policies of education and sustainable development (p. 26),” “transforming
learning environments by promoting a whole-institution approach (p. 28),” “building
capacities of “educators by providing capacity development opportunities (p. 30),”
empowering and mobilizing youth by providing opportunities for youth engagement
(p. 32),” and “accelerating local level actions by empowering local communities as
‘nodal’ platforms for all priority areas (p. 34).”
Along this line, more than a decade ago, Sleurs (2008) proposed the “Dynamic
Model of ESD Competencies in Teacher Education, identifying three competen-
cies (teaching, reﬂecting/visioning, and networking) and ﬁve domains (knowledge,
systems thinking, emotions, ethics and values, and action) (p. 54).” UNESCO (2017)
proposed three key pedagogical approaches toward ESD: a learner-centered approach
(seeing students as autonomous learners, active involvement of knowledge), action-
oriented learning (engaging in action and reﬂecting on experiences for personal
development), and transformative learning (empowering learners to question and
change the ways they see and think about the world) and a number of learning
methods (collaborative real-world projects, vision-building exercises, analysis of
complex systems, critical and reﬂective thinking activities) (p. 55).”
Bögeholz and colleagues (2014) recognized ESD’s integrative and interdisci-
plinary nature; thus, many of its elements and principles could coincide with science
education. Some studies have explored the literature landscape of science education
in the context of sustainable development, such as Maryanti and colleagues’ (2022)
work on bibliometric analysis of SDGs in science education.
Some literature associates the nexus of science education and ESD with science,
technology, and society (STS) (Martins 2013; Reis et al. 2020), science, technology,
and innovation (STI) (Gutnikov et al. 2017), science, technology, environment,
and society (Zoller 2013), trans-contextual and context-based science education
(Burns 2001; Chowdhury et al. 2020), innovative education approach (Reen et al.
2021), interdisciplinary approach (Stacchiotti et al. 2019; Türk et al. 2018), and
transdisciplinary education (Kubisch et al. 2021, 2022), among others.
Towards a Responsive Science Education for Sustainable Development
675
A very extant position paper by Kyle (2006) reﬂected on connecting science
education with sustainable development and other related social movements (e.g.,
human rights, democracy, social justice) and argued that science education has to
enable learners to understand “how the natural world works, how human and natural
systems interact, assess the status and trends of crucial natural systems and promote
a long term sustainable relationship with the natural world (p. 1).” This is supported
by Hogan and O’Flaherty (2022), who explored the nature and culture of science as an
academic discipline and its capacity to integrate ESD, suggesting greater emphasis on
inquiry-based learning, enhancing ESD themes in science modules, and the adoption
of a coherent strategy to promote ESD. Colucci-Gray and colleagues (2013) reﬂected
on epistemological and educational practices of science education for sustainability
and emphasized three key points: (a) implications of taking a sustainability view
about the knowledge process, (b) language and communication process to retrace the
connections between language and culture, and (c) teaching and learning situations
involving prospective teachers in action research contexts.
An earlier work of the author pointed out that for science education to be respon-
sive to ESD, explicit teaching and integration of the Nature of Science (NoS) (referred
to as the inherent values and assumptions of science (Lederman 1992, p. 331)) and
Science-Technology-Society (STS) (referred exploring and understanding the ways
that modern science and technology shape modern culture, values, and institutions,
as well as how modern values shape science and technology (Mansour 2009, p. 287))
must be strengthened (Canlas and Karpudewan 2020).
4
Method
This chapter reports the current research landscape and rich research opportuni-
ties in science education in the context of sustainable development. Informed by
document analysis research design, 206 documents were initially extracted from the
Scopus database for preliminary analysis on March 11, 2024. These documents were
extracted using the search key: “science education” AND “sustainable development”
from the search ﬁeld: article title, abstract, and keywords. Additionally, the search
was limited to articles (document type), English (language), and journals (source
type). After reading the extracted documents, 23 were excluded because the said
documents were not directly or indirectly related to science education and sustain-
able development, thus having a total of 183 papers that underwent further and more
detailed analysis.
The document analysis of the extracted abstract repeatedly examined the subject
of the reported study (topic, objectives, ﬁndings) and employed constant comparative
analysis until themes were established. The iterative process resulted in determining
speciﬁc sustainable development goals and sustainability competencies addressed
in science education research, including other themes that are complementary to
science education and sustainable development, such as STEM education, indige-
nous and traditional knowledges, the use of socio-scientiﬁc issues, and readiness
676
I. P. Canlas
for science education for sustainable development. The succeeding sections of this
chapter elaborate on the said themes.
5
Results
Upon close examination of studies reviewed for this chapter, ﬁve strategies/
approaches that bring together science education and ESD were identiﬁed. Firstly, the
related content and competencies of sustainable development goals are directly
addressed in the science teaching and learning process. Secondly, the association
of environmental education with science education as a response to the call for
sustainable development. Thirdly, the role of science, technology, engineering, and
mathematics (STEM) education in improving quality education and as a promising
educational framework for sustainable development. Fourth, integrating indigenous
and traditional knowledge through dialogues between heterogeneous epistemolo-
gies as quality education. Lastly, the socio-scientiﬁc issues-based approach in inte-
grating ESD in teaching science and technology. These themes are elaborated in the
next subsections.
5.1
Science Education and the Sustainable Development
Goals
Quality education. There is a recognition of the role of quality education as an enabler
of all the other sustainable development. Some studies in STEM education have been
explicitly associated with quality education (Jamali et al. 2023). Moreover, Seehawer
and Breidlid (2021) suggested that heterogeneity and plurality of epistemologies and
a dialogue between them could be a platform to integrate indigenous knowledges
in science education and, therefore, an element of quality education. Hogan and
O’Flaherty (2022) explored the implications of integrating ESD into the nature and
culture of science. At the same time, Molina and colleagues (2021) compared quality
education approaches in the natural sciences curriculum guidelines between Taiwan
and Columbia.
Good health and well-being. A recent study by Beniermann and colleagues (2023)
explored the link between health education and ESD through [sleep] health literacy
in science education curricula, particularly on light pollution and sleep disruption.
A study by Arnold (2020) examined the role of science teaching and different
knowledge types in health-related decisions about non-communicable diseases.
Genderequality.Somestudiesprobeddigitalgendergapsininformationandcommu-
nication technology integration in science education (Palomares-Ruiz et al. 2020),
the existing infrastructure, and gender disparity in information and communication
Towards a Responsive Science Education for Sustainable Development
677
technology literacy, considering its impact on science education (Liu, 2024). In addi-
tion, Addabbo and colleagues (2016) dissected gender differences in international
science assessment performance.
Affordable and clean energy. Studies on affordable and clean energy were associ-
ated with using themes on clean energy to develop systems thinking skills related to
renewable energy (Abdurrahman et al. 2023), decision-making on sustainable devel-
opment issues (Şeker and Aydinli 2023), and environmental literacy associated with
hydropower and renewable energy (Wilujeng et al. 2019).
Climate action. Science education studies on climate action reported in the litera-
ture include teaching and learning interventions, such as the Heat-Cool Initiative in
STEM to improve climate literacy (Kumar et al. 2023), and experiential learning
modules on climate change and futures thinking (Levrini et al. 2021). A paper
by Kubisch and colleagues (2022) explicated quality science education for climate
action through transdisciplinary education. Dzvimbo and colleagues (2022) explored
the role of higher education institutions in climate change adaptation and disaster
risk management.
Responsible consumption and production. van Dam-Mieras and colleagues (1995)
proposed a university course on cleaner production strategies, a ﬂexible international
learning resource for sustainability and sustainable development. There is also the
work of Korte and colleagues (2023) on “Burger.i.doo”, an innovative science educa-
tional game anchored on sustainable meat consumption, and Sanders and colleagues’
(2023) work on the use of hypothetical scenarios about the seafood industry to
develop the systems thinking capacity of undergraduates. Zowada and colleagues
(2020) investigated the relevance of topics on the use of pesticides for chemistry
education and its connection with ESD. Anchored on the circular economy model,
Canino and colleagues (2021) reported a learning experience whereby teenagers
acted as science communicators to raise awareness of the sustainable use of raw
materials and increase STEM interests.
Life on land. de Freitas and da Silva Freitas (2013) explored sustainability, the
Amazonia, and the environment for science education. Meanwhile, João and
colleagues (2023) designed an in-service teacher education program through an
educational design research approach considering the 2030 Agenda for Sustain-
able Development on the theme ‘soils.’ In addition, Tarng and colleagues (2015)
proposed developing a virtual butterﬂy ecological system based on augmented reality
and mobile learning technologies to improve motivation, interest, and learning.
Meanwhile, Funa and colleagues (2022) contextualized instructional materials that
involved Pili (Canarium ovatum) and assessed students’ and teachers’ knowledge,
attitudes, and behaviors toward ESD.
Life below water. Most studies along this SDG are related to ocean literacy, such as
evaluating ocean literacy of elementary school students (Mogias et al. 2019), ways of
increasing ocean literacy of primary school students for ocean sustainability (Mokos
678
I. P. Canlas
et al. 2020), and an account of the ocean science education network for the Ocean
Decade (Scowcroft et al. 2021).
Partnershipforthegoal.Rauch(2013)reportedthedevelopmentofregionalnetworks
in education to enable sustainable development of learning. A study by Fyfe (1997)
about earth system science for the twenty-ﬁrst century acknowledges the need for
integrated teams of experts to provide the best alternatives for new development
problems. At the same time, Lees and Webb (2018) informed the development of the
Global Learning Partnership model to create shared learning opportunities between
academics and students. Lastly, Kubisch and colleagues (2021) reported a project,
Science Education for Action and Engagement Towards Sustainability, to analyze
different partnerships between schools and out-of-school institutions in European
countries.
Peace, justice, and strong institutions. Cummings and colleagues (2023) explored
the application of epistemic justice (fair treatment of individuals and groups in
knowledge-related and communicative practices) in sustainable development. Mean-
while, Tsaparlis and colleagues (2013) assessed undergraduates’ knowledge of
nuclear science in connection with civic scientiﬁc literacy in the context of world
peace and sustainable development.
Reduced inequalities. Alam (2023) investigated the question of secondary science
education becoming an elite product in emerging nations and reﬂected on sustain-
able education in the context of the millennium and sustainable development goals,
arguing that science education as an international product should be a ‘right-
based education program’ that is available to every capable student regardless of
socio-economic status.
Other related themes. Some themes were directly related to SDGs, such as those
associated with citizenship and waste management. For example, Rodríguez-Loinaz
and colleagues (2022) explored the role of citizen science as an educational tool
in promoting science learning and ESD in schools. Svyrydenko and Revin (2023)
explored how European educational systems instill values of civic engagement,
respect for others, and environmental awareness. In addition, Sauermann and
colleagues (2020) discussed the integration of citizen science and sustainability
transition, while Chowdhury and colleagues (2020) proposed addressing sustainable
development by promoting active and informed citizenry through trans-contextual
science education.
Along with waste management, Li and colleagues (2024) assessed the effect of a
chemistry lesson about take-out plastic use on attitudes and behaviors in connection
to Confucian ecological ethics. Stacchiotti and colleagues (2019) presented a didactic
activity about waste and circular economy, while Borreguero and colleagues (2018)
explored and analyzed the integration of concepts on waste within the framework of
sustainable development in the secondary education curriculum.
Towards a Responsive Science Education for Sustainable Development
679
5.2
Scientiﬁc Literacy and Sustainability Competencies
The literature on science education and ESD offers a number of studies that measure
levels and changes in levels after an intervention of psychological or behavioral scien-
tiﬁc literacy-related and/or sustainability competencies variables. These include, for
example, systems thinking(Bozkurt 2023), futures thinking(LahertoandRasa2022),
and reasoning and decision-making in sustainable development- and socio-scientiﬁc-
relatedissues(ŞekerandAydinli2023).Informationandcommunicationstechnology
integration and literacy (Liu 2024; Palomares-Ruiz et al. 2020), situational judgment
(Li et al. 2022), and social and ecological responsibility (Børsen et al. 2021) were
also included, as well as systems thinking, critical thinking, creative problem-solving
(Blatti et al. 2019), and creative self-efﬁcacy (Cheng et al. 2022) in STEM education.
Murphy and colleagues (2021) assessed self-efﬁcacy, critical engagement, sustain-
ability competencies, and transformative pedagogies among teachers, while among
preservice teachers, their beliefs about ESD (Ates and Sungur Gul 2018) and proac-
tivity and personal pedagogical knowledge in ESD (Gopalakrishnan et al. 2019),
among others.
5.3
Science Education, Sustainable Development,
and Environmental Education
Earlier studies in the literature associate the link between science education and
ESD with environmental education. For example, Gough (2017) traced the shift and
shaping of environmental sustainability, science education policies, and curricula
from ESD discourses, while Breiting and Wickenberg (2010) traced the progressive
development of environmental education and ESD in Sweden and Denmark. Some
studies assessed environmental-related competencies, such as Uitto and colleagues’
(2011) work with students’ interests, attitudes, and values about environmental issues
in the context of school science, Gilmanshina and colleagues’ (2018) proposed peda-
gogical frameworkfor buildingenvironmental literacythroughschool natural science
education, and List and colleagues’ (2020) investigation on cross-national differences
and correlates of environmental awareness among the 2015 Program for International
Student Assessment participants. Some studies relate to interventions, such as Ku and
colleagues’ (2020) work on analyzing basic characteristics of environmental science
education multimedia animation materials’ visualization and the development and
design methods. Moreover, Hernández-Barco and colleagues’ (2020) work on the
evaluation of the ﬁnal degree dissertation anchored on service learning principles
towards soft skills acquisition and SDG promotion.
680
I. P. Canlas
5.4
The Case of STEM Education
Vuong and colleagues (2021) pointed out the critical role of STEM education in
promoting sustainable development. STEM education is associated with quality
educationandisconsideredapromisingeducationalframeworkforsustainabledevel-
opment (Jamali et al. 2023), a key element of quality education (Chong 2019). A
signiﬁcant number of studies point to STEM education as a platform for combining
science education and ESD. Chowdhury and colleagues (2020) explored the trans-
contextual science education model, built from an initial student-relevant, soci-
etal issue-related STEM contextualization focused on developing science concep-
tual understanding. For preservice teachers, Türk and colleagues (2018) explored
a STEM curriculum design anchored in an interdisciplinary approach and teacher
collaboration.
Henze and colleagues (2022) developed and assessed a pedagogical approach
that combines robotics, coding, artiﬁcial intelligence, STE(arts)M, and sustainable
development. Cheng and colleagues (2022) assessed the implementation and impact
of a project-based program on creative self-efﬁcacy. Kulshreshtha and colleagues
(2022) designed and implemented foldscope-adapted curricula (a culturally sensitive
pedagogy involving translingual instruction) in post-secondary education to teach
themes in biology. Additionally, Blatti and colleagues (2019) explored the impact of
the systems thinking approach on undergraduate interdisciplinary research projects.
Meanwhile, Abdurrahman and colleagues (2023) assessed the impact of integrating
engineering design into STEM maker space on systems thinking skills among year
11 students.
5.5
On Indigenous and Traditional Knowledges
An important discourse in science education related to ESD is tapping and inte-
grating indigenous and traditional knowledges. Early on, Glasson and colleagues
(2010) elucidated the impact of merging worldviews and hybridized knowledge
and languages on creating a third space for curriculum development dialogue,
thus connecting indigenous ways of living with Eurocentric science. Ramirez
and colleagues (2017) proposed a multicultural science education sustainability
model incorporating ancient knowledge and indigenous heritage. At the same time,
Seehawer and Breidlid (2021) introduced dialogue between epistemologies as an
approach to integrating indigenous knowledge systems with Western knowledge in
education.
A study by Barret (2017) reﬂected and drew insights from science education,
indigenous knowledge, and ESD and argued that connecting formal and informal
knowledge is essentially the work of secondary education. An earlier study by Onwu
and Kyle (2011) proposed reforming the agenda in science education by increasing
socio-cultural relevance oriented toward sustainable development.
Towards a Responsive Science Education for Sustainable Development
681
5.6
Using Socio-Scientiﬁc Issues in Science Teaching
and Learning
Over the years, a signiﬁcant number of science education scholars have proposed
using socio-scientiﬁc issues in teaching and learning science. Less than a decade
ago, Eilks (2015) proposed models for using socio-scientiﬁc issues to bring ESD
into science teaching and learning. A recent study by Jackson and colleagues (2023)
presented a conceptualization and enactment of a program for high school biology
classrooms centered around sustainability-related socio-scientiﬁc issues. Tsai (2018)
assessed the effect of online argumentation of socio-scientiﬁc issues on senior
high school and undergraduate students’ scientiﬁc competencies and sustainability
attitudes.
Morin and colleagues (2017) proposed and validated an interactional reasoning
framework upon engaging students with socio-scientiﬁc discussions through socially
acute questions. Eggert and colleagues (2017) assessed the effect of computer-based
concept mapping scaffolds on conceptual understanding of climate change and socio-
scientiﬁc reasoning and decision-making, while Reis and colleagues (2020) assessed
the impact of student-curated exhibitions about socio-scientiﬁc issues on students’
perceptions of their scientiﬁc competence and science classes. Şeker and Aydinli
(2023) developed a module program on energy transformations and biodiversity,
narrating socio-scientiﬁc issues to foster positive decision-making on sustainable
development issues, and Kong and colleagues (2022) elucidated on the development
and prospects of socio-scientiﬁc issues teaching in the context of immersive media
technology.
5.7
Readiness for Science Education for Sustainable
Development
Indeed, there is a need to advance the nexus of science education and ESD. Nonethe-
less, the question lies extensively with teachers’ readiness and preparedness, consid-
eringthatESDremainsanemergingthemeinscienceeducation.Studiesoncapability
building and support for in-service and preservice teachers are imperative.
The literature presents some studies along this line. For example, Karaarslan
Semiz and Teksöz (2020) assessed the development of systems thinking skills of
preservice teachers through an outdoor ESD course. Ates and Sungur Gul (2018)
investigated preservice teachers’ beliefs on ESD and their sustainability behaviors.
Gopalakrishnan and colleagues (2019) explored the relationship between proac-
tivity and personal pedagogical knowledge in education for sustainable development
among preservice teachers. In addition, Martin and Carter (2015) explored preservice
teachers’ agency concerning education for sustainability.
With in-service teachers, João and colleagues (2023) presented the design and
assessment of an in-service teacher education program through an educational design
682
I. P. Canlas
research approach aimed at developing skills for experimental practical teaching of
sciencetopicswithinthescopeofeducationforsustainabledevelopment.Meanwhile,
Murphy and colleagues (2020) developed an innovative professional development
program for primary school teachers to teach sustainability through inquiry-based
science.
6
Conclusion
Aiming to contribute to the advancement of the agenda for sustainable develop-
ment research, this chapter presents a study that explored the intersection of science
education and ESD from 183 papers extracted from the Scopus database. The ﬁnd-
ings demonstrate the complementary role of scientiﬁc literacy and ESD and that the
nexus of science education and ESD remains fertile ground for research and develop-
ment. Such studies can reﬂect ESD in the context of science education or vice versa.
Although there is somehow a big picture and holistic understanding of sustainable
development and ESD, many pieces of its puzzle still need to be made clear and
known. Be that as it may, the literature provides evidence of the key role of science
education in sustainable development.
Science, from the Latin word ‘scientia,’ which means ‘to know,’ remains a strong
pillar and key to achieving the SDGs. The characterizations of scientiﬁc literacy,
including the visions and dimensions of scientiﬁc literacy and views on the nature of
science, strongly relate and adhere to most, if not all, facets of ESD. Exploring ways
of building, developing, and strengthening conceptual understandings of concepts
around SDG phenomena is necessary. While a holistic and higher-order under-
standing of SDGs is imperative, building solid foundational knowledge as a platform
is equally important. The rigor in building conceptual knowledge and replicability
of the science inquiry process continues to be relevant in exploring, knowing, and
learning different SDG phenomena.
The elements of the scientiﬁc inquiry process and the scientiﬁc method remain
relevant in understanding the complexity of the SDGs. More than ever, there is
a need to nurture curiosity and courage among learners to explore the unknown.
Views on the nature of science need to be strengthened to ensure appropriate and
responsive actions/behavior towards emerging socio-scientiﬁc issues and problems.
Related thereto, using socio-scientiﬁc issues in teaching and learning could foster
objectivity, data-driven planning, and decision-making, among others. It may be
necessary to explore further relevant teaching and learning approaches that include
some elements of inter- and transdisciplinary approaches to teaching and learning,
as well as problem-, project-, and research-based learning, among others.
Consideringthesimilaritiesandcomplementarityofscientiﬁcliteracyandsustain-
able development competencies, intuitively, sustainable development competencies
could be developed through science education in general. Therefore, developing and
implementing a sustainable development-informed science curriculum, including
relevant pedagogies, instructional materials, and authentic assessment, is imperative.
Towards a Responsive Science Education for Sustainable Development
683
Developing a holistic and more coherent science education for sustainable develop-
ment framework or model that merges the elements and principles of science educa-
tion and ESD may be necessary. The need for a contextual framework for STEM
education, integration of indigenous and traditional knowledges, and environmental
education under the umbrella of science education for sustainable development may
be necessary.
Finally, there is a need to hasten research on the intersection of science education
and ESD. Reﬂecting ESD in rationales and problem statements could induce sustain-
able development-responsive science education research that utilizes old, new, and
innovative research designs.

Distance Learning and Digitization
as a Means to Challenge Students’
Thinking Toward Sustainability
Research
Luis Velazquez, Nora Munguia, Alma Gabriela Pulgarin-Herrera,
Jesus Salvador Gutierrez-Ruelas, and Claudia Jayne Falcon-Perez
Abstract Researchisasubstantivefunctionofhighereducationinstitutions,through
which they encourage undergraduate and graduate students to master research
methods to solve fundamental societal problems. Given the nature of distance educa-
tion programs, the use of digital technologies is an invaluable competitive advan-
tage in training new scientists in the ﬁeld of sustainability research, mainly due
to their rapid adaptation to the digital demands of the students of generations Y
and Z. This chapter aims to explore the role of distance learning and digitalization
that has sparked young higher education students’ interest in research activities to
ensure the successful functioning of sustainability science in the coming years. The
content suggests that challenging students’ thinking toward sustainability research
goes beyond teaching proven research methodologies for completing a thesis. At
present, sparking the interest of young scientists in sustainability research requires
the reengineering of research processes in higher education, where digitization is
necessary to ensure the successful functioning of sustainability science in the coming
years.
Keywords Distance learning · Information and communication technology ·
Higher education · Sustainability research · Artiﬁcial intelligence
