1
Introduction
Research is a substantive function of higher education institutions, through which
they encourage undergraduate and graduate students to master research methods
to solve fundamental societal problems. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Develop-
ment supports higher education scientists conducting research during the last decade.
Under this framework, Sustainable Development Goal 4: Quality Education has been,
without a doubt, one of the top priorities for higher education institutions (HEIs)
because SDG 4 is an umbrella goal for higher education institutions (HEIs) that
allows research on all the other SDGs. Particularly, target 4.7 states:
By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustain-
able development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development
and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace
and non-violence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture’s
contribution to sustainable development (U.N. General Assembly 2015).
Based on this target, HEIs instruct prospective sustainability scientists in multidis-
ciplinary research approaches to carry out their theses to obtain a degree. Nowadays,
training scientiﬁc apprentices requires novel education structures characterized by
digital tools. There is a simple reason: higher education enrollment comprises Gener-
ation Y and Z students (Kuleto et al. 2021). These students are characterized by their
high digital proﬁciency level (Ranieri et al. 2021). Still, despite solid similarities,
particular differences in their learning styles need to be recognized because Genera-
tion Z will soon become the largest group of students (Andheska et al. 2020). Gener-
ation Y students are characterized by the incorporation of the use of mobile devices,
spatiotemporal mobility, interaction through social networks or multi-platforms, the
use of information and communication technologies (ICTs), ﬂexible schedules, and
a reduction in take-home tasks, as well as teamwork and the formation of multidis-
ciplinary networks to solve problems (Avila-Lopez and Zayas 2019). On the other
hand, Generation Z students are considered the ﬁrst true digital natives, different
from the previous generation (Millennials), so they process information and learn
differently; they are more autonomous and need ICTs in their learning processes as
an essential factor (Coppo 2020).
The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the digitization of educational processes
at universities worldwide, revealing a vast digital divide between professors and
studentsregardingtheirbasicdigitalabilitiesandskills(Maliarchuk2022).Ofcourse,
students also underwent a process of adaptation to digital technologies where the
interaction with the platforms and teaching systems was their total responsibility
(Sanchez-Santillan et al. 2016). Their relation with online learning caused problems
of different kinds, mainly because students had to adapt to a new reality for which
many were not prepared economically, mentally, and emotionally (Ammade et al.
2022), or they did not have the technological support or knowledge necessary to face
it (Giatma et al. 2020). Some scholars reported that students presented disorienta-
tion, distraction, and cognitive overload because, for the ﬁrst time, they tried to use
programs that were confusing or difﬁcult to manage (Scheiter and Gerjets 2007).
Distance Learning and Digitization as a Means to Challenge Students’ …
693
The psychological aspect was also affected by the pressure generated by reading or
understanding materials and taking exams independently, often at a different pace
than the rest of the students in their class (Maqbulin 2021). An investigation of a
group of university students showed that they experienced mild to moderate stress
levels during the pandemic (Wahyu and Simanullang 2020).
It should be noted that those students with previous digital knowledge showed
more resilience against the severe COVID-19 disruption (Laher et al. 2021; Liu
et al. 2023). Likewise, this reality was also disturbing, complex, and challenging
for tenured science professors who faced severe stressors that caused them stress,
anxiety, and other psychological symptoms, negatively impacting their academic
performance (Munguia 2023). In response to the disruptions of COVID-19, the use
of technology to overcome learning difﬁculties in current educational systems has
become a challenge for academic institutions (Anholon et al. 2020). For higher educa-
tion institutions, speciﬁcally, strategies were identiﬁed to allow them to face unknown
uncertainties during the pandemic based on four main dimensions: resilience and
change management, digital transformation and online learning, curricular change,
and sustainability (Rasli et al. 2022). The inclusion of sustainability as part of these
also makes educational systems essential actors to advance towards fulﬁlling the
2030 Agenda, which increases the challenges of institutions with a multidisciplinary
character (Ranjbari et al. 2021). In some way, the pandemic served to alert professors
of the need to strengthen their digital skills. In the post-COVID world, training young
scientists demands that science professors be digitally competent by mastering ICTs,
digital platforms, and artiﬁcial intelligence (Mindigulova et al. 2023). In this context,
this chapter aims to explore the role of distance learning and digitalization that has
sparked young higher education students’ interest in research activities to ensure the
successful functioning of sustainability science in the coming years.
The following sections of this chapter offer insights into the fascinating adven-
ture of challenging young students’ thinking toward sustainability research through
distance learning and digitizing the research processes in higher education.
2
Theoretical Foundations of Distance Learning (DL)
Concerning Research
Educating scientists has been linked to digitization in many ways, from the funda-
mental execution of commands to the current artiﬁcial intelligence programs. Nowa-
days, it is expected that digital platforms, such as Zoom, Microsoft Teams, and
other ICTs, be used to support research meetings, international conferences, and
congresses. Which offer a wide range of services and beneﬁts that strengthen the
global scientiﬁc community through interaction and connectivity through comfort,
convenience, and ﬂexible schedules; however, long before, the research logistics
were different.
694
L. Velazquez et al.
Various terms have been used to deﬁne distance learning, such as virtual educa-
tion, e-education, online education, non-conventional modalities, and remote educa-
tion (García Aretio 2002). Regardless of the speciﬁc term, this education modality
raises the quality of teaching–learning because it respects its ﬂexibility or avail-
ability; that is, the times and spaces that result from the new communication tech-
nologies and digital information and the creation of network access systems (Lara
2022). Furthermore, distance education also focuses on education programs, whose
methodology uses teaching–learning strategies to overcome the limitations of space
and time between the actors within the educational process (Arias et al. 2010).
According to Peters (2002), it ﬂourished from about the mid-nineteenth century
when printed media, the postal service, and the telephone served to develop the educa-
tional process. Still, the greatest boom in DL was in the second half of the twentieth
century (Begoña Tellería 2004). By the 1980s, technologies such as compact discs
and videodiscs began to be incorporated into education. In the 90 s, the internet started
transmitting knowledge as part of teaching–learning. By the middle of the 2000s, the
use of Web 2.0 began the transition from a behaviorist approach to a constructivist
one, in which the student constructs knowledge more actively without depending so
much on the instruction of a professor (Passerini and Granger 2000). During that
period, new paradigms of DL were generated as technology evolved (García Aretio
and García Blanco 2016). Although there is no signiﬁcant disagreement about DL’s
importance for science, there is no consensus about how those paradigms evolved.
On the one hand, some authors argue that DL represents a deviation from traditional
education, which is implemented with trial and error and lacks theoretical founda-
tions (Keegan 1980; Holmberg 1995; Nichols 2003). On the other hand, however,
other scholars claim the existence of several DL theories with scientiﬁc methods
to systematize the laws, ideas, principles, and norms that describe, explain, verify,
and predict the educational phenomenon of the distance modality and regulate its
pedagogical development (Aretio 1989; Keegan 1980).
Wedemeyer (1971) introduced the theory of independence study. This theory
maintains that this DL should facilitate the independence and autonomy of students
so that they can achieve their learning goals and self-regulate their processes, which
implicatestheresponsibilityforbuildingtheirknowledgeattheirownpace.Similarly,
Moore (1977) incorporated the concept of transactional distance, where students play
an active role during the educational process.
From a different perspective, however, in a complementary way, principles based
on industrial models are transferred to educational processes to explain the charac-
teristics of distance education, which gives rise to the industrial model (Peters 1994).
Brenes Espinoza (2004) states that the industrial model theory is somewhat similar to
industrialization approaches such as the specialization of tasks, the division of labor,
its potential to reach students regardless of their geographical location, the existence
of evaluations of the process and the products to increase their effectiveness, its
objectivity and its proﬁtability irrespective of the number of students. Finally, the
theory of interaction and communication aims to establish communication channels
between professors and students to foster self-learning. This theory becomes a guided
didactic conversation model through the interaction with the teaching materials. As
Distance Learning and Digitization as a Means to Challenge Students’ …
695
there is a personal relationship between teachers and their students, students feel
motivated to achieve the learning goals through the didactic materials, the interaction
via conversations and messages, and feedback (Keegan 1986). Students’ competen-
cies, well-structured didactic materials, and good interaction between professors and
students are critical factors in the success of this model (Keegan 1986; Barberà et al.
2001).
After having explored the previous theories, it is possible to conceptualize the
evolution of DL into four stages, proposed by Simpson and Anderson (2012):
correspondence, telecommunications, telematics, and the internet, which is the
current stage in which technology has become a necessity for most social, scien-
tiﬁc, economic, and political spheres. Furthermore, it originated a radical change or
advance since media began to promote communication and synchronous activities.
Some scholars have proposed a ﬁfth “virtual” stage based on interaction and interac-
tivitybetweenstudents,media,activities,andevaluation(LealAfanador2013).These
technological innovation processes have enabled educational institutions to improve
pedagogical practices and allow the professional and institutional development of
the entire scholarly community (Cebrián Serna 2003).
Like any other scientiﬁc discipline, sustainability science has incorporated
technological innovations to make its tasks more efﬁcient, determining modern
sustainability research trends.
3
Sustainability Research Trends in the Context of the 2030
Agenda 2030
New technologies produced changes in science teaching methods that promote new
skills in students with more dynamic and collaborative characteristics to challenge
students’ thinking toward sustainability research. Today, the information society
demands a transformation in science education that allows trained professionals to
insert themselves into the unique demands of the current social paradigm and, as
Aretio (2019) mentioned, to form a population capable of facing new situations.
Over time, this scenario, with high digital literacy and greater social awareness,
provided an ideal breeding ground for scientists interested in research based on the
2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.
Inrecentyears,animpressivegrowthofSDGs-relatedliteratureinElsevierScopus
has been observed (Alﬁrević et al. 2023), emphasizing this research topic’s scientiﬁc
relevance. The existence of monitoring and performance systems to rank worldwide
higher education institutions in contributing to meeting SDGs is also remarkable
since research is one of their critical criteria (Times Higher Education 2023; UI
GreenMetric 2023). These outcomes reﬂect what happens daily in university research
centers where undergraduate and postgraduate professors, students, and tutors jointly
696
L. Velazquez et al.
conduct research projects focusing on the SDGs of the 2030 Agenda for Sustain-
able Development. The latter is desirable because SDGs are interwoven to address
challenges posed by wicked problems.
According to Rittel and Webber (1973), wicked problems have ten characteristics:
1. There is no deﬁnitive formulation of a wicked problem.
2. Wicked problems have no stopping rule.
3. Solutions to wicked problems are not true or false but good or bad.
4. There is no immediate and no ultimate test of a solution to a wicked problem.
5. Every solution to a wicked problem is a “one-shot operation” because there is
no opportunity to learn by try-and-error; every attempt counts signiﬁcantly.
6. Wicked problems do not have an enumerable set of potential solutions, nor is
there a well-described set of permissible operations that may be incorporated
into the plan.
7. Every wicked problem is essentially unique.
8. Every wicked problem can be considered to be a symptom of another problem.
9. The existence of a discrepancy representing a wicked problem can be explained in
numerous ways. The choice of explanation determines the nature of the problem’s
resolution.
Although the concept of a wicked problem was ﬁrst characterized in the plan-
ning/governing system theory domain, sustainability scholars have embraced the
term because many of these characteristics apply to sustainability problems, mainly
in their social dimension. It is a fact that adapting to respond to the signiﬁcant chal-
lenges that these types of complex situations represent requires excellent intellectual
effort and investment of resources to address the lack of consensus on norms and
values (Leal Filho 2022; Block et al. 2022). Sustainability in itself is considered a
¨wicked problem¨ based on its complex relationships between the economic, envi-
ronmental, and social dimensions and the presence of multiple heterogeneous stake-
holders (Brønn and Brønn 2018). According to Pryshlakivsky and Searcy (2013),
the high levels of complexity in the situations associated with sustainability seem to
fall into this category. Even in operational terms, sustainability implies ambiguity,
complexity, and uncertainty transferred to the different logistical stages; the Sustain-
able Development Supply Chain is considered a perverse problem (Pederneiras et al.
2022). The social and institutional implications and scientiﬁc complexity have led
to a lack of clarity in alternative solutions for sustainable supplies, which is why this
category is also called a “wicked problem” (Ranabahu 2020).
External to sustainability, other issues associated with its framework of action are
also considered a “wicked problem.” Climate change falls into this classiﬁcation,
given its severe implications for the lives of human beings (Lehtonen et al. 2018).
Perry (2015) even deﬁnes adaptation to climate change in this classiﬁcation, given
the absence of clear solutions and the disagreement of the parties on values, norms,
and ﬁrst steps, which makes adaptation difﬁcult. Poverty is considered an excellent
example of a wicked problem because it is hard to ﬁnd agreement on its deﬁnition,
causes, and solutions in the academic framework (Pradilla et al. 2022). Food safety
is also identiﬁed as a perverse problem due to the different interpretations of its
Distance Learning and Digitization as a Means to Challenge Students’ …
697
deﬁnition that cause divergent solutions without a consensus that allows adequate
solution policies (Grochowska et al. 2014).
The COVID-19 pandemic severely disrupted every substantive function in higher
education institutions. In many ways, university life changed for everybody. For
obvious reasons, the suspension of classes was the most signiﬁcant concern for the
university authorities, who focused all their resources and efforts on restoring the
return to the classrooms by all possible means (Treve 2021). While all this chaos was
happening in instruction, researchers also struggled to keep their research centers and
students’ activities functioning (Bozkurt et al. 2022). This unprecedented transforma-
tion experienced by universities led to a rethink of how higher education institutions
researched to ensure inclusive and equitable higher education for all. Novel research
strategies were fundamentally characterized by digital technologies, which guaran-
teed to regain momentum toward knowledge generation. However, it was more than
evident that adopting digital solutions under the label of distance education was
not, and still is not, an easy task since it implied modifying traditional structures
that go far beyond the acquisition of computers and software (Warren and Churchill
2022). In particular, software training and capacitation created additional challenges
in conﬁguring research methods. Researchers, professors, and students had to adapt
to virtual environments, which generated new sociocultural realities (Poddubnaya
et al. 2021).
Although using digital platforms and other communication technology tools
caused doubts among the scientiﬁc community during the ﬁrst months of the
pandemic, over the years, the knowledge acquired on ICTs has proven effective in the
transition to online research (Batdı et al. 2023). During the pandemic, scientiﬁc jour-
nals began to publish bibliometric studies showing the beneﬁts of distance learning
and ICTs (Sanjaya and Pandey 2021). These studies allowed us to learn about the
increase in investigation and its direction during this period. The adoption of distance
education due to the pandemic increased the number of publications referring to this
topic, with the most signiﬁcant number of publications associated with accessibility
to electronic learning being recorded in 2020 (Obidat 2022). The subﬁelds of artiﬁcial
intelligence, machine learning, and deep learning constitute new research directions
for e-learning that also emerged as a consequence of the pandemic (Brika et al.
2022). In a broader spectrum, bibliometric studies also addressed research associ-
ated with sustainability. Some works used a merged bibliometric data set to examine
the relationships between Coronavirus, sustainability, and development (Gatto et al.
2023). Another bibliometric study suggests that the growth of scientiﬁc literature
related to sustainability is concentrated in the disciplines associated with applied
social sciences, environmental sciences, energy, management, engineering, human-
ities, and psychology (Côrtes and Rodrigues 2016). Other studies have emerged on
the issues of value chains within the framework of sustainable trade (Agrawal et al.
2022). By early 2022, bibliometric methods had become dominant in SDG studies
(Mishra et al. 2023). The bibliometric studies have identiﬁed that the economy and
social effects are the ﬁrst research topic associated with the SDGs, with exploratory
studies and case studies being the most used types of research, with the majority
698
L. Velazquez et al.
of studies focusing on industrialized and developing countries (Indana and Pahlevi
2023).
In addition to the evidence supported by bibliometric studies, future trends in
sustainability research will likely be inﬂuenced by the development of ICTs, so it
is not surprising that distance education should lead this development. The digital
reengineering of higher education institutions towards sustainability science should
not be further delayed.
4
Sustainability Research Ethics
Young scientists must learn from day one that unethical practices are intolerable and
there is no place for them in science. Conducting credible scientiﬁc research is related
toscientiﬁcmethodologyandethicswhenapplyingsuchmethods.Scienceprofessors
must emphasize scientiﬁc ethics before teaching research methodologies, whether
experimental or non-experimental, qualitative or quantitative. There is nothing more
essential to research than credibility. It goes further than measuring and avoiding
implicit bias in research, which may negatively affect the conﬁdence of stakeholders
in a particular scientiﬁc work (Spaulding 2022).
Artiﬁcial intelligence (AI) integration in scientiﬁc research has undergone a
gradual process and has evolved over the last decades. Institutions dedicated to gener-
ating knowledge emphasize disciplines where data science converges to manage the
knowledge generated effectively. Artiﬁcial intelligence has beneﬁted this task, espe-
cially metadata management (Trejo Medina 2022). For the speciﬁc case of content
generation through Chat Generative Pre-Trained Transformer, or ChatGPT, applied
to scientiﬁc research, they have the potential to facilitate interaction with pre-existing
data, information, and relevant resources through the so-called generative artiﬁcial
intelligence, which is capable of generating new content such as texts, images, music
or even programming codes (Wang et al. 2023). Scholars have also highlighted the
potential usefulness of AI in facilitating the search for information, the processing,
and even the interpretation of the content that a researcher could use for their publi-
cations (Krenn et al. 2022; Magallanes et al. 2023; Medina Romero 2023). AI Tech-
nology has permeated all facets of education, both for the tasks carried out by students
and for its use, which will become more common in the coming years. As a result,
science students and young researchers can generate research content with the quality
of a tenured researcher, which is desirable and plausible.
On the other hand, the proliferation of AI tools in academic research has raised
considerable concerns among scholars because much remains to be done regarding
academic integrity (Díaz 2023). Although everything mentioned above seems ﬁne, in
reality, this has generated controversy, especially from an ethical point of view, since
the use of chatbots can generate scientiﬁc content that anyone could attribute the
responsibility to authorship in works generated by AI, in addition to the patentability
of inventions created by algorithms, and legal liability if an AI generates content
Distance Learning and Digitization as a Means to Challenge Students’ …
699
that infringes pre-existing intellectual property rights (Salvagno et al. 2023). There-
fore, it is essential to establish mechanisms to identify and sanction the unethical
use of chatbots in scientiﬁc writing; human supervision is necessary in the scientiﬁc
process to guarantee the quality and integrity of the results (Bianchini et al. 2022).
Another essential aspect to consider regarding ownership of data or content gener-
ated from AI is the speed with which this content is developed since it is constantly
evolving, so there is no applicable global consensus in legal terms in an area where
changes are constant (Qadir 2023). Artiﬁcial intelligence in science is undoubtedly
essential in raising signiﬁcant considerations about human–machine collaboration,
knowledge management, and scientiﬁc communication. Although it is still in doubt
whether artiﬁcial intelligence can replace human intelligence in the nature of scien-
tiﬁc research (Barrios 2023) it also entails risks and ethical challenges that must
be addressed through regulations (Suazo 2023), responsibility, transparency, and
legality regarding scientiﬁc dissemination (Lopezosa 2023).
5
Illustrative Case Study
This illustrative case study presents the strategy from the coordination of a
Distance Learning Sustainability Bachelor’s degree to engage students in scien-
tiﬁc research through developing an undergraduate bachelor thesis. This bachelor’s
degree has a pedagogical perspective for the challenge of promoting teaching–
learning processes that develop competencies for sustainability to provide solutions
to socio-environmental problems, seeking to generate awareness for sustainability in
the context of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. It belongs to a large
public university in northwestern Mexico with a long tradition as a sustainable educa-
tion promoter. In 2008, the university implemented and Certiﬁed an Environmental
Management System (EMS) with the ISO 14000 international standard. The EMS
was linked to their academic sustainability programs to promote cooperation with
industry and other economic sectors (Velazquez et al. 2000). The institution occupies
an exemplary position among the world’s top sustainable universities within the UI
Green Metric World University 2021 Ranking, 172 (UI GreenMetric 2023).
Notwithstanding the above, attracting Generation Y and Z students to science is
an issue of growing concern in the bachelor’s degree program because of the small
number of talented and motivated students who desire to write an undergraduate
thesis. According to data from the Direccion de Planeacion y Evaluacion (2023),
which compiles statistics, the Interdisciplinary Engineering Faculty students who
achieved their university degree by writing a thesis in 2023 were less than 3% out
of 5,627. Table 1 shows the records are lower in the academic department where the
Sustainability bachelor’s degree is assigned.
To determine the potential causes of these unsatisfactory rates in the elabora-
tion of the thesis, the school carried out a focus group made up of four experts
who participated in the design and adaptation of the program and who were also
now part of the teaching staff and coordinators of the bachelor’s degree. Experts
700

suggested two reasons for such a situation: ﬁrstly, to graduate with a bachelor’s
degree, the institution offers students eight options, one of which is to write a thesis.
In general, elaborating a thesis document can take up to two extra years after the
student has completed their academic courses. This fact discourages most students
because other degree options are more expeditious. Secondly, though writing a thesis
is rewarding in terms of satisfaction, few students graduate through this option, given
the complex, stressful, time-consuming, and frustrating process. Higher education
literature has diversely explored these factors preventing thesis writing (Man and
Zhan 2023; Gezahegn and Gedamu 2023; Quinto 2022; Sadouki 2023). As a result
of the focus group, experts endorsed the proposal to develop a strategy that integrates
all phases of writing a thesis, such as reading literature, designing the methodolog-
ical approach, collecting data, analyzing results, and elaborating conclusions. The
strategy is based on the principles outlined in a UNESCO document, describing a
framework for implementing education initiatives during the decade of action to
meet SDGs by 2030 (UNESCO 2020). Experts also highlighted the importance
of fostering ICTs to promote digital literacy and strengthen curricula and research
methodologies. Finally, the experts recommended progressive advances in preparing
the thesis document from the beginning of the academic program instead of waiting
until the last semesters, when theses usually begin to be written at this institution.
Thus, to boost sustainability research, the curriculum map integrates the academic
load and thesis preparation over six semesters so that students can graduate through
the thesis option and get the diploma simultaneously at the end of their studies. The
thesis topics must be directly related to a particular goal of the 2030 Agenda for
Sustainable Development.
In this context, the thesis document starts to be written when the student enters
the ﬁrst semester of the degree and continues on a semester-by-semester basis. In
the ﬁrst semester, the students aim to analyze the main sustainability problems at the
international, national, state, and local scales. Moreover, it begins with an in-depth
analysis of what is established in the 2030 Agenda to determine the areas covered in
each SDG. Subsequently, work is carried out on the search for different problems and
their delimitation to visualize their solution with the available scientiﬁc resources
Distance Learning and Digitization as a Means to Challenge Students’ …
701
and the feasibility of addressing them from a project for sustainability. When the
topic to be worked on has been deﬁned, the formulation of the research questions
and objectives begins to be developed, which, with the help of the facilitator, are
established according to the institution’s guidelines.
During the second semester, the students are aimed to develop a theoretical frame-
work. They are taught techniques to review literature for the adoption of referen-
tial theories and methodologies to justify their sustainability projects and back up
their hypotheses or research questions. In addition, plagiarism and the guidelines
for writing, citations, and references of the theoretical foundation are discussed. The
use of AI chatbots like ChatGPT as a tool for cheating is penalized, and rules have
been made to discourage this practice. When the theoretical framework is ﬁnalized,
mentors must validate the draft’s authenticity using plagiarism checker software.
Students develop the methodological design of their sustainability project in the
third semester. The general purpose of the module is to identify and select the method-
ological techniques according to the formulated problem, that is, for the student to
analyze the different types of methodological designs that are used in sustainability
science to propose a method of research that meets the stated objectives to provide an
answer to support or refute their hypothesis. At this point, students have developed a
thesis document containing their goals, research questions, hypotheses, and clearly
deﬁned methodology and methods, including the instruments for data collection and
a Gantt chart.
Students determine the ideal way to collect quantitative, qualitative, or a mixture
of both data during the fourth semester. They often conduct surveys, interviews,
report reviews, focus groups, and testing to gather data in an unbiased manner. Two
seminars are scheduled during the semester to report partial results. In the ﬁfth
semester, students learn techniques for measuring, synthesizing, and analyzing data.
Then, they write their ﬁnal thesis draft supporting or refuting their hypothesis or
answering their research questions. The last semester is devoted to preparing students
to effectively defend their thesis, which includes public speaking and PowerPoint
skills.
At present, sparking the interest of young scientists in sustainability research
requires the reengineering of educational processes in higher education, where digi-
tization is necessary to ensure the successful functioning of sustainability science in
the coming years. Figure 1 depicts the sustainability mindset endorsed by faculty,
which is currently stimulated by ICTs. For instance, the Moodle platform has allowed
the incorporation of SDGs-related bibliographies into all courses. It also includes an
alert system for students to know their activities’ schedules and progress processes.
It has been widely accepted and very user-friendly, saving time when sending activ-
ities by email. On this platform, students also ﬁnd all the information necessary to
consult the requirements for the preparation of the thesis in each of the stages, which
was enriched with the use of other auxiliary digital platforms, such as YouTube,
suggesting tutorial videos., which are more friendly and accessible for students to
understand in terms of the guidelines to follow, especially in the ﬁrst stages of
preparing the thesis, which are the ones where the most signiﬁcant complexity is
perceived. It also allows the completion of multiple-choice exams and the obtaining
702
L. Velazquez et al.
Fig. 1 Digitization of educational and research processes to meet SDGs at universities
of results instantly, where students can also receive feedback on the correct answers
to their incorrect answers. Likewise, the use of a reference manager such as Mendeley
has contributed to the administration of references in shorter times, making it easier
for students to ﬁle information with the required formats, saving them search time
and tedious manual reference processes, allowing them to download information
from the network in the correct format directly. Using Zoom and Teams platforms
has led to greater rapprochement between students and tutors, who have established
better communication through spaces more tailored to their needs.
This illustrative case study notes that ICTs have been essential in challenging
students’ thinking toward sustainability research. So far, results have been promising,
but the number of students graduating through the elaboration of a thesis is less when
compared to other graduation options.
6
Conclusions
By suggesting that challenging students’ thinking toward sustainability research
goes beyond teaching proven research methodologies for completing a thesis, this
chapter aimed to explore the role of distance learning and digitalization that has
sparked young higher education students’ interest in research activities to ensure
the successful functioning of sustainability science in the coming years. The chapter
included a case study to illustrate an approach to promote the elaboration of the thesis
in a Sustainability bachelor’s degree since students may not present sufﬁcient moti-
vations to graduate through scientiﬁc research. The main lesson of this case study
is that ICTs are attractive tools to speed up thesis progress. The nature of distance
education programs and the use of digital technologies is an invaluable competitive
Distance Learning and Digitization as a Means to Challenge Students’ …
703
advantage in training new scientists in the ﬁeld of sustainability research, mainly
due to their rapid adaptation to the digital demands of the students of generations
Y and Z. No doubt that distance learning has a relevance that it perhaps never had
before in the history of humankind. In addition to the evidence supported by biblio-
metric studies previously shown in this chapter, the development of ICTs will likely
inﬂuence future trends in sustainability research, so it is not surprising that distance
education should lead this development. The digital reengineering of higher educa-
tion institutions towards sustainability science should not be further delayed. The
role of distance education in higher education research has never been as highly
valued as it is today, especially after the unprecedented COVID-19 pandemic that
continuously forced educational institutions to modify, update, and apply strategies
and processes increasingly focused on using and managing technologies to generate
sustainability knowledge.
It is expected that distance education will increase its importance in the coming
years, inducing new generations of researchers and sustainability scholars to main-
tain ethical behaviors that allow the use of ICTs as support tools in activities such
as the organization of information, the management of references, the administra-
tion of activities, but not to create knowledge without a solid and demonstrated
base. Finally, it must be noted that particular concern in forming young sustain-
ability scientists is related to their academic and research integrity. ICT’s continuous
growth and development, particularly AI, is changing the way of conducting scien-
tiﬁc research; therefore, sustainability science students must learn the importance
of behaving with honesty, trust, transparency, and responsibility when conducting
sustainability research.

vol 4. Free Press, New York, pp 548–557
Online Courses and Educational
Networking: Ontological Approach
to Integration of SD-Linked Outcomes
into Advanced-Learning Courses
Jintao Yang, Kirill Savrassov, Nikolai Gorbatchev, and Tatsiana Tkalich
Abstract Online courses and educational networking present both challenges and
opportunities for advanced learning educational content management. With the
continuous evolution of global markets and the need for individuals to stay updated
with the latest advancements to maintain competitiveness, the integration of sustain-
abilityintothecurriculumbecomescrucial.Thisintegrationensuresthatfuturegener-
ations are equipped with the necessary knowledge and abilities to tackle sustain-
ability challenges and build a more sustainable world. Particularly, the utilization
of online courses has led to a shift in information-seeking behavior, resulting in a
decreased demand for physical books and printed materials in traditional university
libraries. This shift necessitates adjustments in collection development strategies,
leading libraries to prioritize electronic resources to better support online learning.
This paper includes a case study on the integration of Sustainable Development Goals
(SDGs)-linked outcomes into advanced learning online courses. These courses, such
as “Foundations of Insurance-linked Securities (ILS)”, “Investment Management”,
“Project Management”, and others, were delivered to professionals from Europe,
Americas, and Africa. The case study demonstrates the integration of knowledge
domain ontology into the interdisciplinary course library to enhance the effective-
ness and efﬁciency of educational content updating and support teaching, learning,
and research activities. By incorporating domain knowledge ontology, educators and

1
Introduction
Since the introduction of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the global
community has been actively striving to integrate sustainability into operations across
all sectors (UN 2015). The objectives aim to tackle worldwide issues such as poverty,
inequity, environmental degradation, and climate change, while also advocating for
peace and fairness (Leal Filho et al. 2023a). In the era of online learning, tradi-
tional libraries have undergone a transformation in response to the evolving needs of
learners and educators. This transformation extends beyond the conventional concept
oftraditionallibrariesasrepositoriesofphysicalbookstoencompasstheirpivotalrole
in facilitating access to digital resources, supporting online educational initiatives,
and promoting sustainable development through knowledge dissemination.
The integration of sustainability into the curriculum and its inherent connection
to the role of libraries in sustainable development underscores the libraries’ signiﬁ-
cance as enablers of global progress. Libraries serve as catalysts for sustainability by
curating and providing access to educational materials that promote a deeper under-
standing of sustainability challenges and solutions. Moreover, through their support
of online courses with sustainability-focused content, libraries actively contribute
to the dissemination of knowledge essential for addressing environmental, social,
and economic sustainability issues. By fostering awareness and understanding of
sustainable development goals and initiatives, traditional libraries become instru-
mental in shaping a generation of learners equipped to engage with and address
the multifaceted challenges of sustainability, thus reinforcing their pivotal role
in advancing sustainable development through educational networking and online
learning platforms.
The implementation of knowledge domain ontology within the educational
content management system further emphasizes the pivotal role of traditional univer-
sity libraries in enabling sustainable development. By integrating knowledge domain
ontology, libraries can facilitate the seamless organization and dissemination of
educational content related to sustainable development goals. This approach not only
enhances the efﬁciency of content management but also reinforces the interconnect-
edness of multidisciplinary courses aiming to address SDGs. Through the system-
atic integration of SDG outcomes into educational resources, libraries can actively
contribute to the cultivation of a comprehensive understanding of sustainability chal-
lenges and solutions among students and educators. This proactive approach aligns
with the broader mission of traditional libraries in supporting the advancement of
sustainable development by providing a structured framework for the integration of
Online Courses and Educational Networking: Ontological Approach …
711
SDGs across diverse disciplines, thereby enriching the educational experiences and
fostering a culture of sustainability within academic communities.
Online courses and educational networking have transformed the education sector,
providing accessible and ﬂexible learning opportunities for learners globally (Castro
and Tumibay 2021). Currently, they play a critical role in facilitating lifelong learning
by providing accessible and ﬂexible educational opportunities for individuals of all
ages (Tzenios 2022). Online courses and educational networking enable individ-
uals to engage in learning activities regardless of their location, work schedules,
or personal commitments. This accessibility is particularly beneﬁcial for working
professionals, parents, and individuals with mobility constraints (de Souza Rodrigues
et al. 2021). Online courses provide opportunities for individuals to acquire new
skills, expand their knowledge base, and enhance their professional qualiﬁcations.
This can be particularly valuable for career advancement and transition into new
ﬁelds.
Online courses and educational networking can help bridge the gap in access
to quality education, a goal aligned with SDG 4 (Quality Education). By lever-
aging digital platforms, individuals from diverse geographical locations and socio-
economic backgrounds can access educational resources and courses, contributing to
the goal of universal education. Educational networking platforms facilitate collabo-
rative learning, knowledge sharing, and the exchange of best practices among global
communities. This aligns with the essence of several SDGs, including SDG 17 (Part-
nerships for the Goals), which emphasizes the importance of global collaboration to
achieve sustainable development. Moreover, online courses contribute signiﬁcantly
to the promotion of decent work and economic growth as outlined in Sustainable
Development Goal 8 (SDG 8). Online courses provide global access to educational
resources, allowing individuals from diverse backgrounds and geographical locations
to acquire market-relevant skills and knowledge, thus fostering inclusive economic
growth. Online courses can also be designed to educate learners about environ-
mental sustainability, climate action, and responsible consumption and production,
supporting SDG 13 (Climate Action) and SDG 12 (Responsible Consumption and
Production), among others.
However, these changes also present challenges for university libraries, primarily
related to information management, copyright, and digital divides. Mixing traditional
and online resources is crucial for libraries to support diverse learning styles and
meet evolving student needs. Curricular alignment with online courses and collab-
orations with faculty members can enhance the libraries’ role in academic success.
As a networking platform, online courses allow libraries to share resources and best
practices, facilitating continuous improvement. The emergence of open educational
resources (OER) also provides opportunities for libraries to support affordable and
accessible education.
This study contains a case study of the integration of SDGs-linked outcomes
into the CPD-certiﬁed advanced-learning online courses library (“Foundations of
Insurance-linked Securities”, “Investment Management”, “Project Management”
and others), which was attended by numerous professionals from Europe, the Amer-
icas, and Africa. These courses have implemented several contemporary approaches
712
J. Yang et al.
to e-learning to enhance the learning experience of professionals: open educational
resources, interactive learning modules, virtual networking opportunities, blended
learning approaches, and adaptive learning technologies. By incorporating knowl-
edge domain ontology, the course organizes various content in a structured and
interconnected manner, enabling learners to navigate and retrieve relevant course
materials more effectively. This approach can also facilitate the linking of related
concepts, topics, and resources, providing a more cohesive and comprehensive
learning experience for the participants (Leal Filho et al. 2023b).
Sustainability outcomes integrated into courses’ curricula require interdisci-
plinarity as they are addressing complex sustainability challenges. They involve
a variety of interconnected factors, such as social, economic, environmental, and
technological aspects. These factors get within the domains of various disciplines,
and a holistic approach is needed to effectively understand, analyze, and address
sustainability issues. Interdisciplinary collaboration allows for the integration of
diverse perspectives, expertise, and methodologies, leading to more comprehen-
sive and effective solutions that account for the multifaceted nature of sustainability
outcomes.
Educational communities dedicated to online courses continually generate and
reﬁne a wealth of educational content, which holds signiﬁcant value for students
and researchers alike. The diverse and evolving nature of this content necessitates
robust management processes to ensure its accessibility, relevance, and applicability
across various educational contexts. Knowledge domain ontology serves as a crucial
tool in enhancing the management of this continually expanding educational content.
By structuring and organizing the content according to domain-speciﬁc knowledge,
ontology facilitates efﬁcient categorization, retrieval, and utilization of educational
resources.
2
Methodology of Managing the Educational Content
The continuous exchange of data, information, and knowledge within educational
communities in forums, social networks, and video conferencing indeed leads to a
signiﬁcant increase in the volume of content (Haleem et al. 2022). This growing
body of content can certainly be categorized as “prospective educational informa-
tion resources” as it holds the potential to be utilized in content management systems
for the creation or updating of advanced learning courses (Lungu 2022). The accu-
mulation of diverse perspectives, insights, and resources within these educational
communities serves as a valuable pool of content that can enrich the development
of electronic courses. By leveraging this wealth of prospective educational infor-
mation resources, content management systems can be enriched with up-to-date,
relevant, and diverse content, enhancing the quality and relevance of electronic
courses (Komleva and Vilyavin 2020). The effective utilization of this content within
contentmanagementsystemsrequiresthoughtfulcuration,validation,andintegration
Online Courses and Educational Networking: Ontological Approach …
713
Fig. 1 Engagement of educational and methodical network communities’ members in cultivating
personal competencies. Source Based on the diagram with author’s revisions (Gorbatchev et al.
2011)
processes. These processes can help ensure the accuracy, reliability, and pedagogical
value of the content that is being added or updated within electronic courses.
Figure 1 illustrates the three levels of interaction among members of a networking
educational and methodical community in the development of personal competencies
are as follows:
Personal Level: At this level, individual members engage in direct interaction
to enhance their personal competencies. This may involve self-study, reﬂection,
skill development, and personal development activities aimed at improving one’s
competencies within the educational and methodical context.
Shared Knowledge Networks Level: This level involves the collaborative
exchange of knowledge, ideas, and resources among members within shared
networks. Members actively participate in sharing best practices, insights, and exper-
tise with their peers. This level fosters a culture of knowledge sharing and collective
learning, contributing to the enhancement of personal competencies through the
collective intelligence of the network.
Educational Networking Communities Level: At this level, members engage
within formal or informal educational communities, such as online forums, social
networks, or professional groups. Within these communities, members interact,
collaborate, and support each other in the development of personal competencies.
Educational communities provide a platform for peer learning, mentoring, and the
exchange of valuable educational resources that contribute to the enrichment of
individual competencies within the educational and methodical domain.
These levels collectively represent the multi-faceted nature of interaction within
networking educational and methodical communities and their signiﬁcant impact on
the development of personal competencies.
714
J. Yang et al.
However, the personiﬁcation of authorship in networking communities is a topic
of debate within the ﬁeld of knowledge management. In networked environments
such as online forums, social media platforms, and collaborative workspaces, the
lines of authorship can become blurred due to the ease of sharing, remixing, and
co-creating content (Hung and Yuen 2010). This has led to discussions around issues
such as proper attribution, intellectual property rights, and the impact of collaborative
authorship on the value and integrity of knowledge within these communities (Paske-
vicius 2021). Currently, different perspectives exist on whether the personiﬁcation
of authorship enriches or hinders knowledge management in these environments.
One of the promising technologies that may be effective for educational content
management in educational networking communities is the knowledge domain
ontology (Saito et al. 2007). By providing a formal representation of knowledge
domains, ontology facilitates the organization, structuring, and retrieval of educa-
tional content, as well as enhancing intellectual property management for educational
content within networking communities.
Knowledge domain ontology is a formal representation of knowledge within a
speciﬁc domain or subject area (Zouaq and Nkambou 2009). It involves capturing the
concepts,entities,andtheirinterrelationshipsinastructuredandstandardizedmanner
(Sattar et al.2020). This representationenables theorganization, retrieval, andutiliza-
tion of knowledge within the domain, and the development of advanced search and
recommendation systems in various applications, including online courses. Ontolo-
gies play a crucial role in the Semantic Web, and their importance and recognition
have grown signiﬁcantly due to being seen as the solution for achieving interoperable
semantics in contemporary information systems (Konys 2019).
The history of knowledge domain ontology in educational content management
can be traced back to the advancements in the ﬁeld of information technology and the
evolutionofthesemanticweb.Knowledgedomainontologybecameakeycomponent
of educational content management systems as it allows for the representation of
domain-speciﬁc knowledge and relationships in a structured and machine-readable
format (Gladun et al. 2012).
The concept of ontology in the context of knowledge representation and manage-
ment has its roots in the ﬁeld of philosophy, but it gained prominence in the ﬁeld of
computer science and artiﬁcial intelligence in the 1990s (Grimm et al. 2011). The
term “ontology” is used to refer to a formal representation of knowledge within a
speciﬁc domain, including the concepts, entities, and the relationships between them
(Guarino 1995).
In the context of educational content management, the use of knowledge domain
ontology gained traction as educators and content creators sought more effective
ways to organize, manage, and disseminate educational materials. By representing
the knowledge domain using an ontology, educational content management systems
could become more intelligent and capable of understanding the semantic meaning
of the content, enabling better search, retrieval, and organization of educational
resources.
The Semantic Web initiative, led by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C),
has been instrumental in promoting the use of ontologies for representing and
Online Courses and Educational Networking: Ontological Approach …
715
sharing knowledge on the web (Rajapaksha and Kodagoda 2008). This initiative
contributed to the development of standards and technologies, such as the Resource
Description Framework (RDF) and the Web Ontology Language (OWL), which are
crucialforbuildingandutilizingknowledgedomainontologiesineducationalcontent
management systems (Davies et al. 2006).
As a result, knowledge domain ontology has become an integral part of advanced
educational content management systems, allowing for more precise categorization
and organization of educational resources, personalized learner experiences, and
interoperability between different educational platforms and systems (Tarus et al.
2018). With the advent of digital technology and the increasing volume of digital
resources, the need for more advanced and ﬂexible methods of knowledge organi-
zation became apparent. Knowledge domain ontology emerged as a solution to this
challenge by providing a way to represent knowledge in a machine-readable and
structured format, allowing for more precise categorization, search, and retrieval of
information.
The relationship between traditional libraries and knowledge domain ontology
can be seen in the transition from physical to digital knowledge organization and
management (Aung et al. 2022). While traditional libraries rely on human-created
classiﬁcation systems, knowledge domain ontology enables the representation of
knowledge in a way that can be understood and processed by computers (Ferilli and
Redavid 2020). This transition has facilitated the development of digital libraries and
online knowledge repositories, where ontology-based approaches are used to cate-
gorize and organize digital resources more effectively. Knowledge domain ontology
has inﬂuenced the development of semantic web technologies, linked data initiatives,
and digital library standards, leading to improved interoperability, search capabilities,
and the ability to integrate diverse sources of information.
Over the past decade, ontologies have been extensively utilized across diverse
ﬁelds including biomedicine, ﬁnance, engineering, law, and cultural heritage, as
indicated by a recent review of ontology engineering (Tudorache 2020).
Knowledge domain ontology of educational content developed for a course
involves organizing knowledge in a hierarchical and structured manner, which leads
to several beneﬁts in the context of online course content updating (Chen et al. 2013).
At the stage of the design and development of online course curricula, knowledge
domain ontology can enhance the works of educators by providing a clear framework
for organizing and sequencing learning objectives and content due to its structured
representation of knowledge within a speciﬁc domain (Lefebvre et al. 2005).
With a well-deﬁned ontology, it becomes easier to identify areas where content
needs updating (Pandey et al. 2024). This enables the automation of certain aspects of
content updating, such as identifying outdated information or adding new knowledge
componentsbasedonthechangesintheﬁeld.Ontologiescanbeusedtocreateperson-
alized learning paths for students based on their individual needs and learning goals
(Chen 2008). This enhances the quality of the educational experience by providing
tailoredcontentupdatesandrecommendations.Thisapproachalsofacilitatesinterop-
erabilityandreusabilityofeducationalcontentacrossdifferentcoursesandplatforms.
In the result, course owners get efﬁcient updating and sharing of content, leading to
716
J. Yang et al.
higher quality and more comprehensive educational materials. Implementation of a
knowledge domain ontology for the course library facilitates the creation of sophis-
ticated semantic search and recommendation systems, aiding in the identiﬁcation of
pertinent content updates aligned with speciﬁc learning goals and needs.
Ontology can facilitate the identiﬁcation of the most active and knowledgeable
experts, which may belong both to educators and learners, in speciﬁc ﬁelds of study
within the networking community. By analyzing the qualitative and quantitative
relationships between ontology units and individual competencies, the system can
pinpointmemberswhopossessexpertiseinrequestedﬁelds.Ontology-drivencompe-
tencies management can facilitate the identiﬁcation of potential collaborators or
mentors within the networking community. Members with complementary compe-
tencies can be matched for collaborative projects, knowledge sharing, and mutual
support.
There are several international projects that collaborate for the creation of
SDG-related taxonomies and ontologies (OLS n.d.; UN n.d.). The development
of a taxonomy and ontology for SDGs involves the categorization and structuring
of concepts and relationships related to sustainable development, including SDG
indicators. Several international projects collaborate to create and maintain such
taxonomies and ontologies to facilitate the understanding and implementation of
SDGs across various domains. As an example, the United Nations Economic and
Social Council’s efforts to develop an ofﬁcial taxonomy and ontology framework for
the SDGs (UNEP n.d.). This framework aims to provide a standardized approach for
classifying and organizing data and information related to sustainable development,
thereby enabling better monitoring and reporting on progress towards achieving the
SDGs. The collaborative development of SDG-related taxonomies and ontologies
plays a crucial role in promoting a common understanding and implementation of
sustainable development initiatives at both national and global levels.
The application of SDG ontology in advanced and lifelong educational projects
holds signiﬁcant promise for advancing sustainable development initiatives. By
utilizing an SDG ontology, lifelong educational projects can effectively align their
objectives and activities with the speciﬁc targets and indicators outlined in the SDGs.
3
Application of Knowledge Domain Ontology
to Interdisciplinary Content Management
This approach was implemented for a thematically related set of CPD-certiﬁed
advanced learning courses (Project Management, Investments Management and
Fundamentals of Insurance-Linked Securities and others). These courses are based
on a uniﬁed repository of ontology-driven library of educational content (reposi-
tory). The main tasks of this were to integrate the SDG-related outcomes into the
courses, to provide the in-time updating of educational content, to involve the educa-
tional networking community in updating the content library, to provide individual
Online Courses and Educational Networking: Ontological Approach …
717
learning passes to learners and to enhance the courses’ quality via knowledge sharing
and reviewing using educational collaboration and networking. As the basis for
this, an educational content library based on knowledge domain ontology was struc-
tured using a layered architecture that incorporates ontology-based categorization,
retrieval, updating and management of educational resources (Fig. 2). This approach
leverages the following key components to optimize the handling of educational
content libraries.
A. Domain Ontology: This layer includes the representation of knowledge
domains, concepts, and relationships within the educational content space. Concepts
and relations are deﬁned to categorize educational resources based on subject matter,
topics, and learning objectives.
B. Resource Metadata: Educational resources are tagged with metadata linked to
theontology,includingconcepts,topics,andknowledgedomains.Thislayermanages
the storage and retrieval of resource metadata, enabling efﬁcient categorization and
indexing of educational content.
C. Educational Resources: This layer stores various types of educational content,
such as texts, multimedia, simulations, and interactive materials, as well as content

generated by learners and educators (networking communities’ content). Resources
are associated with metadata that aligns with the ontology, allowing for structured
organization and retrieval based on knowledge domains.
Ontology-Based Search Engine: A search engine is integrated with the ontology to
provide users with the ability to explore and discover educational resources based on
speciﬁc knowledge domains, concepts, and relationships. Search queries are mapped
to ontology concepts for accurate resource retrieval.
User Proﬁling: This layer captures information about user competencies, learning
preferences, and knowledge domains of interest. This data is utilized to provide
personalized recommendations for educational resources aligned with the user’s
competencies and learning goals.
Intellectual Property Management: This layer ensures compliance with intellec-
tual property rights by managing access controls, usage rights, and permissions
for educational resources. Ontology-based metadata facilitates the enforcement of
copyright and licensing requirements.
Usage Analytics: This layer captures usage data and interactions with educational
resources, providing valuable insights into resource popularity, user engagement, and
competency development trends. In perspective, analytics will be linked to ontology
taxonomy to measure competency growth in speciﬁc knowledge domains.
Another advantage of the implementation of a knowledge domain ontology in
a course management system is the integration of SGD-related outcomes. This
approach was previously suggested by various research in relation to other ﬁelds. For
example, a knowledge organization system was introduced in Joshi et al. (2021). It
incorporates an ontology representing the components of the SDG indicator frame-
work. This framework presently encompasses 17 Goals, 169 Targets, and 231 distinct
indicators,alongwithover450associatedstatisticaldataseriesmanagedbytheglobal
statistical community to oversee advancements towards the SDGs (Fig. 3).
The knowledge domain ontology integrates Sustainable Development Goal
(SDG)-related outcomes into a comprehensive online course library focusing on
“Foundations of Insurance-linked Securities,” “Investment Management,” “Project
Management,” and other relevant subjects. The top-level model of the ontology
encompasses the following key elements:
Courses’ Experts: This component of the model identiﬁes and categorizes the
subject matter experts responsible for developing and delivering the courses within
the library. It speciﬁes their areas of expertise and contributions to the content.
Indicators of Courses: This element encompasses the various qualitative and quan-
titative indicators used to assess the effectiveness and relevance of the courses. It
includes metrics related to learning outcomes, engagement, user satisfaction, and
overall impact.
Users’ Satisfaction: This part of the model captures the feedback and satis-
faction levels of the learners who engage with the courses. It may include user
ratings, reviews, and survey data to gauge overall satisfaction and identify areas for
improvement.

Fig. 3 A Fragment of knowledge domain ontology at high-level of details. Source Developed by
authors
Case Studies: The ontology incorporates case studies relevant to the courses,
providing real-world examples and applications to enhance learning and under-
standing of the subject matter.
Courses’ Outcomes: This component outlines the speciﬁc learning outcomes and
objectives of each course, aligning them with SDG-related goals and targets.
The integrated model facilitates the alignment of course content with SDG-related
outcomes, ensuring that the courses not only provide valuable knowledge but also
contribute to broader sustainability and development objectives.
Alignment of educational courses’ library with SDG ontology provides several
beneﬁtstocourses,selectedforthisresearch.CPD-certiﬁedadvanced-learningonline
courses library (“Foundations of Insurance-linked Securities”, “Investment Manage-
ment”, “Project Management” and others) are oriented on ﬁnance and business
learners, insurance brokers, local and international authorities as well as on layers
and managers. SDG ontology assists in aligning the curriculum with the speciﬁc
goals and targets of the SDGs.
This ensures that learners receive education that is directly linked to global sustain-
ability objectives, thereby fostering a sense of responsibility and awareness of the
broader societal and environmental challenges. Another advantage is facilitating the
interdisciplinary approach to the course library. An SDG ontology facilitates a deeper
720
J. Yang et al.
understanding of the interconnectedness of sustainable development issues across
various topics and outcomes. This engagement also fosters a collaborative approach
to education and empowers individuals to contribute meaningfully to sustainable
development efforts within their communities to create new SDG-oriented educa-
tional content and to update current courses’ elements. Finally, by integrating SDG-
relatedconceptsandindicatorsintoeducationaladvocacyefforts,coursestakeholders
can work towards inﬂuencing policies that support sustainable development at local,
national, and global levels.
4
Feedback Analysis Methodology
The effectiveness of the proposed methods was examined from the perspective of
the learners. During the preparatory phase, the most crucial ﬁndings concerning the
concepts of SDGs in both global and regional contexts were identiﬁed based on a
review of current research. The research survey’s objective is to evaluate the extent of
awareness, comprehension, and integration of SDGs both prior to and following the
completion of the courses. Its aim is to investigate respondents’ viewpoints, actions,
and attitudes regarding these concepts. The survey involved the selection of a diverse
and representative sample of participants from various regions, industries, and back-
grounds. The ﬁrst step in the process was to design the questionnaire, which consisted
of a mix of closed-ended and open-ended questions. The closed-ended questions were
aimed at collecting quantitative data, and included multiple choice questions and
Likert scale questions where respondents could rate their level of agreement with a
statement on a scale of 1–5. The open-ended questions were aimed at collecting qual-
itative data and allowed respondents to provide more detailed and nuanced answers.
After the survey responses were collected, the data was analyzed using descrip-
tive statistics. Descriptive statistics was applied to summarize the data and provide
an overview of the respondents’ opinions. Finally, the results of the survey were
compiled into a report that summarized the ﬁndings and provided insights into the
current state of knowledge and attitudes among insurance professionals towards the
outcomes related to SDGs.
The questionnaire included 38 questions, thematically grouped into 5 sections:
– General section (location, professional group etc.)
– Awareness and understanding of SDGs (familiarity with the speciﬁc goals and
targets, perceived relevance of SDGs to the course content)
– Perceived impact and signiﬁcance (learners’ opinions on the importance of inte-
grating SDG-related topics into the course curriculum, as well as the potential
impact of such integration on their professional development and contribution to
sustainable development efforts)
– Integration of SDG concepts (the learners’ perceptions of the extent to which the
course addresses issues related to sustainable development, and how effectively
these concepts are integrated into the content)
Online Courses and Educational Networking: Ontological Approach …
721
– Recommendations and Feedback (suggestions for enhancing the integration of
SDG-related topics into the course curriculum based on their learning experience
and understanding of the subject matter).
The survey was distributed to the selected respondents through available chan-
nels among course alumni. Once the data collection phase was completed, the
collected responses were compiled and analyzed. This involved using statistical anal-
ysis methods, such as frequency analysis, cross-tabulation, and descriptive statistics,
to gain insights into the research objectives. The research ﬁndings are presented
below in the form of descriptive summaries, charts, and tables.
5
Results of the Survey on Educational Content Quality
in the CPD-Courses’ Library
Information was gathered through a survey that was distributed to graduates of the
CPD-certiﬁed advanced-learning online courses library (“Foundations of Insurance-
linked Securities”, “Investment Management”, “Project Management” and others)
using the random sampling technique. Limitations of selection are related to the focus
of the group of alumni mostly on the insurance and ﬁnance sectors. The geographic
distribution of respondents can be found in Fig. 4.
Signiﬁcantly, the survey revealed that Europe (30%) and Asia (27%) were
the regions with the highest representation among the participants. The research
also garnered participation from professionals in other regions such as Africa and
Australia/Oceania, contributing to a more diverse and global perspective.
